Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The strap on my backpack keeps sliding off my shoulder like it’s trying to run away, too. I hitch it up again and it squeals against the sweat on my skin. It’s already hot at 9 a.m., the kind of heat that feels like a dare. The air’s thick and wet and smells like sugar and rotting fruit and beer that’s been left in a cup overnight. Above me, a balcony drips ivy and Mardi Gras beads, purple and green and gold like someone hung up a bruise. I’m in New Orleans. I keep saying it in my head like if I repeat it enough, it’ll stick to me and I’ll know who I am here. Or at least I’ll know where my feet are. I press my thumb into my phone like maybe by some miracle it will resurrect, but it’s on 2 percent and then it blinks away, black and smug. Last text is still burned into my eyelids: Mom: Come home. Then: We can talk about this. Then the call from the school counselor, who I blocked. I imagine his pinched face when I told him he could go reorganize his filing cabinet of microaggressions. I wonder if I should feel bad for that. I don’t. My name is Taylor, I remind myself. Not the old one, not the one that tastes like pennies in my mouth. There’s a stupid tourist shop window with TAYLOR printed on a rack of keychains and for a second it feels like fate before I remember it’s one of those names. That hums in my brain anyway. I rest my forehead against the cool glass just to have something solid. Inside there are shot glasses and alligator plushies and a sign that says “Laisser les bons temps rouler,” which I can’t pronounce in my head without making it sound like a lawnmower trying to start. “You gonna buy something or you just gonna fog up my window?” A woman with bright nails and a bun like a cinnamon roll grins at me from behind the counter. Her gold hoop earrings catch the light and throw it back at me. The shop smells like incense and bleach. It’s a little too much, and my stomach churns with the leftover bus fumes and nothing else. I ate a granola bar at a gas station in Mississippi and it feels like it’s a thousand years old inside me. “I’m just—sorry,” I say. I sound small and young and I hate that. I push the strap up again. “Do you know where I can get, um, something cheap to eat?” She looks at my backpack like it has a neon sign that says Runaway. Maybe it does. Maybe I’m projecting. “There’s a place down on Decatur sells beignets for tourists and a café au lait they pronounce wrong,” she says. “There’s better further uptown. You look like you could use a shower and something more than sugar fried up.” She watches my face like a cat watches a fly. “You got people here?” I swallow. My throat sticks. “Yeah,” I lie. It comes out too fast, and I can feel my ears get hot. “I mean—yeah, I’m meeting someone. Later.” She leans her elbows on the counter, rings clicking. “You watch your bag,” she says. “Don’t let nobody tell you they gonna watch it for you. And don’t get on no scooters. That’s how they know you’re fresh.” Something in me wants to dump the whole thing out there, tell her I ran away, I’m a disaster, I’m sixteen pretending to be anybody but me, I don’t know where to go, and my left sneaker has a hole in it you can almost see the sock through. But there’s another part—this new fierce, mean part—that says keep your mouth shut. Trust should be rationed like cereal. “Thanks,” I say. I open the door and the air wraps around me again like a wet towel. On the corner, a brass band tears into a song that sounds like a laugh. The tuba makes my ribs vibrate. A kid around my age with half his hair bleached sits on the curb drumming on an overturned bucket. His sticks are just chopsticks taped together. He’s got a jaundiced bruise peeking over his collar. He taps a rhythm on the pavement as if his hands can’t stand to be still. There’s a sign by his foot that says: Spare some change, not advice. I smile despite myself. It feels like someone else’s face. He catches me looking and lifts his chin. “You look new,” he says. “New new. Like still got the map in your head new.” I shift my backpack up. God, the strap again. “Do I have to pay the new person tax?” My voice comes out snappier than intended and I wince. Be tougher. Or at least pretend. “Nah. Just the looking-around tax,” he says. He clicks his sticks together fast, nervous. “Name’s Finn.” “Taylor,” I say. My name sits better here. It’s loose in my mouth, slouchy. “Do I look that obvious?” He shrugs. “Everybody does, at first. You blink too much. Also you’re wearing shoes you bought at a chain store. You’ll wanna map your safe bathrooms. Starbucks on Canal—no questions asked if you look like you know where you’re going. No scooters, no Bourbon Street after midnight unless you’re with a crew, no telling your whole life to the first person with a harmless face.” He tilts his head at me, eyes crinkling. “How long you been gone?” This is a test. This is me with my hand hovering over the wrong answer. I make my own test. “What time is it?” I ask. He laughs, a harsh little bark that doesn’t sound like joy and sounds exactly like it. “You got jokes. It’s Tuesday. Or Wednesday. It’s summer. The clock here is vibes. You got somewhere to be at a certain hour? You carrying an appointment book?” I don’t. I have exactly seventy-two dollars in wrinkled twenties, a library card with my deadname that I want to burn but might need for something, a half-empty bottle of water that tastes like plastic, and a grocery bag with one shirt and a toothbrush that I stole from the last gas station bathroom. I can hear Mom in my head, which is unfair because I ran to get away from her, but Moms are like glitter—once they’re in, you never get them all out. We can talk about this. So can a brick. Or a hurricane. “I need food,” I say. “Cheap. Maybe a shower later. Also—” I swallow. “I need to figure out... things.” Finn looks at me like my face is a puzzle with a missing piece. He nods toward the quarter where the street narrows and gets meaner. “There’s Miss Carla on Royal,” he says. “She used to run with—whatever, she’s cool. Sometimes she feeds kids that are—” He waves his sticks at me. “Kids like us. For free if she likes you, cheap if she doesn’t. She won’t let you shower but she’ll point you toward a church that will if you don’t mind a speech about loving your soul.” “Church,” I say. I try to make it taste like something besides choke. “Cool. Love that for me.” He smirks. “You don’t gotta believe to use water. C’mon.” He stands, slings a canvas bag over his shoulder that looks like it might be held together with willpower and duct tape, and we start walking. He moves like a feral cat, always keeping three feet between him and the street, eyes on reflections in windows instead of the sidewalk. I can’t tell if that means I should trust him or not. As we pass a guy in a Saints jersey, Finn goes tight, shoulders up. The guy’s eyes slide over us, away. Finn only breathes when we turn the corner. “Rule,” he says. “If a grown man knows your name and you didn’t tell it to him, you tie your shoes and walk the other way fast.” “Okay,” I say. “You know a lot of rules.” “Cuz I broke all of them and lived,” he says. “Mostly.” We find Miss Carla’s by smell—something like garlic and coffee and a frying pan that never gets fully clean. The sign’s old and hand-painted; the A in Carla has a little heart at the top. Inside it’s dark and blessedly cooler, a box fan pushing stale air. The woman behind the counter looks like she’s been carved out of gumbo—warm, heavy, a little dangerous if you rush it. “Finn,” she says in a voice that could cook rice. “You bring me trouble or gossip?” “Both,” he says. He gestures at me. “This is Taylor.” “‘Morning, Taylor,” she says. Her eyes are sharp. “Hungry?” “Yes,” I say, and it comes out like a prayer. If God is here anywhere, He’s in fried food. She slides a plate across the counter to me with something golden and perfect that crunches under my teeth like it was crafted to make my brain stop screaming. My eyes sting. Ridiculous. Don’t cry over food in a place like this. Rule number whatever: If you’re crying in public, be strategic about your audience. “You from here?” she asks, casual. “No,” I say. “Tennessee.” She arches a brow. “Ah. You got an aunt stays on Dauphine or you got nowhere?” I set the plate down. The strap slides again and I want to throw the whole bag into the Mississippi and watch it sink. “Nowhere,” I say. It feels like jumping off a low roof. If I break anything, it’ll be small. She nods once, like that’s math that adds up right. “We close at three,” she says. “You can sit here till then. You need a phone to call somebody, we can pretend. If you need a number for Covenant House, I got it. They ain’t saints but they got a bed sometimes.” Finn watches me with his chin on his fist, as if he’s waiting to see if I’ll run. A flicker of something—pride?—because he brought someone in and it didn’t blow up. Or maybe I’m projecting. “I don’t—” The word home is a bruise inside my mouth. It still aches when I touch it. “I’m not going back.” My voice is too loud. I lower it. “I mean. Not right now.” “You ain’t gotta explain your whole life to me,” Miss Carla says. “Long as you don’t steal and you bus your table.” “Yes, ma’am,” I say automatically, and something about the ma’am fits weird and sweet on my tongue, like a set of clothes I want to grow into. It makes heat ripple through my face. Finn’s eyes flick to mine. I can almost hear him clocking it, storing it away with all the other hints about who and what I am. He doesn’t say anything. That’s good. Or it’s nothing. According to the New Orleans clock, it’s vibes. “You got a place to sleep?” he asks after we mop up the last of the grease with a corner of bread like civilized animals. “You can crash at the park till cops kick you out, but it’s loud and the mosquitoes will bleed you dry. There’s a squat in the Bywater. Kinda sketch. The roof leaks, and there’s a guy named Rascal who’d sell his grandma, but he won’t bother you if you stay in the back room. Or I know a dude has a couch, but he likes to…collect. You gotta tell him no about three times and he gets the message.” He says it like he’s giving me the weather—these are conditions, not value judgments. “Fun options,” I say. I pick at a splinter in the counter with my thumbnail. “What about you?” He shrugs one shoulder and it looks like it hurts. “I go where I go.” He taps his sticks on the table. “I was sixteen last week,” he says, almost like he’s trying to make it sound casual and it’s a secret anyway. “Happy birthday,” I say. It’s stupid but what else. He makes a face. “You got people mad at you?” he asks, and there’s the needle finding the vein. I feel it slip in. “Like will they come looking?” In my mind, Mom’s hand is clutching the phone, knuckles white. My brother breaking stuff in his room when he’s mad, the cheap door that Mom never fixed. The counselor with his Sit down, I can help you tone that down. I feel the burn of the misgendering, the clatter of she and wrong name and you’re just trying this on for size and do you know how hard this is for me, like I don’t. It’s like a car alarm going off behind everything else all the time. “They can be mad,” I say. My voice is steadier than I feel. “I’m not going back.” I don’t say: I don’t know where I’m going instead. Or: I’m scared. Or: Please, someone, tell me there’s a version of this where it’s not all just sweat and lies and corners. Finn nods slow. “Okay,” he says. “Then we do the day.” He says it like a plan. “You need a shower. There’s a church. They’ll talk at you but I can fake a prayer face in my sleep. Then you need socks. Clean socks will save your life out here. Shoes too, but socks are first line of defense.” He looks at my backpack. “You got a knife?” I laugh and it’s a gross, hysterical sound. He raises his eyebrows. “I mean, yeah,” I say, and I fish out the little folding one from the side pocket where I keep it for string and boxes and terror. The handle is scratched. I don’t know if I could ever stick it into someone. I hope I never have to find out. I hope I’m scarier than I look. “Keep it where you can feel it,” he says. “Don’t wait till you need it to find it. Also don’t stab nobody unless you have to. That life sticks.” There’s something in his tone when he says it. A weight. I want to ask what he doesn’t want sticking to him anymore, but I file it under Don’t, yet. We leave Miss Carla’s with her blessing and her number on a napkin, pressed into my hand like a relic. The street is all the way awake now. A man in a suit jogs past on an errand that looks urgent and small. A woman with a parasol floats. A kid in a Spider-Man costume sticks to a lamppost and yells for tips. The sky is white, not blue, like it’s been bleached. We hit the church and sit through five minutes of an earnest guy talking about sheep while the water heats up in the pipes. He gives us towels and doesn’t look at our faces long enough to try to slot us into boxes. Finn hums something under his breath—maybe a song, maybe just a habit. I scrub fast and vicious like I can get Tennessee off me. I watch a little black river swirl down the drain and feel a jolt of joy that’s not reasonable. When I come out, hair plastered and clinging, I feel like an empty soda can with the tab pulled off. Lighter. Crushed. “Here,” Finn says. He tosses me a pair of socks that are not new but are clean. They smell like nothing. I almost cry again. God. I hate me. “Thanks,” I say. He shrugs like it’s nothing, but he watches me pull them on like it’s something he needs to see. As we walk, he tells me about the river as if it’s a person. “It’ll be there even when everything else is lying to you,” he says. “It’s proud. It don’t care about your name. You can sit with it and it don’t ask nothing.” He stops then, head cocked. “But you don’t go in if you’re not with someone who knows it,” he adds. “It looks slow. It’s not.” We sit on a bench by the Moon Walk and the Mississippi heaves by like a whole animal. I feel small and right-sized for the first time in days. My backpack strap slides, and I let it for a second, and then I pull it back up. It squeaks. A barge drifts past, stacked with blocks that look like Lego for giants. I hug my knees and rest my chin on them. My reflection in the water is fractured and not useful. Good. I don’t want to look at me right now, not really. I want to be multiple choice. I want to be fill-in-the-blank. There’s a guy in a dirty polo who’s been hovering a little too long. Finn tenses, the way a cat does. “We should move,” he says softly. “You don’t wanna be in a place where someone’s decided you belong.” We stand. I hitch the strap again. “You have secrets,” I say suddenly. It comes out before I can catch it. Stupid. Obvious. Finn grins with half of his mouth and it’s ugly and bright. “Yeah,” he says. “Me too.” He kicks at a cigarette butt. “You tell me yours, I’ll tell you mine.” “I told you,” I say. I spread my hands. “I left. I’m…me. I said it two days ago and they didn’t like it. Are you happy?” He squints at me, like he’s taking a picture in his head. “You said it out loud,” he says. He whistles low. “That’s big. That’s why you look like you jumped off a roof. Your insides don’t match the outside pressure yet. They’ll catch up.” “Thanks for the physics,” I say. I feel stupidly relieved that he didn’t stumble around it. That he didn’t call me—anything else. That he slid over my name like it was normal. My chest loosens. I didn’t know it was tight until it wasn’t. We wander through the market where spices are piled up like tiny mountains and there’s a man selling frogs that look rubber until they blink. A lady with a headscarf reads tarot cards and looks at me like she knows my Social Security number. Finn flinches when a cop car creeps by, barely moving. The back of my neck prickles. I fight an urge to duck. I am not wanted. Not yet. Not on paper. But I feel wanted like you feel an argument before it starts. We end up under
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a transgender teen runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans. The writing excels in creating an authentic first-person perspective with Taylor's internal monologue revealing their vulnerability, defiance, and uncertainty. The prose is rich with sensory details that bring New Orleans to life—the humidity, the smells, the sounds of brass bands—while maintaining Taylor's distinct perspective. The character development is particularly strong. Taylor feels fully realized through their conflicting emotions: the determination to escape an unsupportive home environment balanced against the fear of the unknown. Their interactions with Finn and Miss Carla reveal different facets of their personality—defensive yet desperate for connection. The backstory is woven in naturally through memories and reflections rather than exposition dumps. Finn serves as an effective foil and potential ally, with his street-smart demeanor and hints at his own troubled past. His character introduces tension and mystery while providing Taylor with necessary guidance. Miss Carla is similarly well-drawn in her brief appearance, showing compassion without sentimentality. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinct voice. Finn's staccato street wisdom contrasts with Taylor's more hesitant, sometimes sarcastic responses. The dialogue feels natural and reveals character while advancing the narrative. The prose strikes a good balance between vivid description and teenage vernacular. Metaphors like "the air wraps around me again like a wet towel" and observations like "Moms are like glitter—once they're in, you never get them all out" feel authentic to Taylor's voice while being genuinely insightful. The writing avoids becoming overwrought despite dealing with emotionally charged subject matter. The narrative effectively builds tension through small interactions and observations that hint at danger—Finn's wariness around certain men, the advice about knives, the hovering stranger by the river. These elements create a sense of precariousness that reflects Taylor's situation. One minor weakness is that the piece ends abruptly mid-sentence with "We end up under," suggesting it was cut off rather than concluded intentionally. This prevents a proper assessment of how well the story arc is resolved. Overall, this is a compelling and skillfully written narrative that creates a vivid sense of place, authentic characters, and emotional resonance while addressing complex themes of identity, belonging, and survival. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 18

+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 88.7
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The day began, as most days did since the world misplaced its batteries, with a committee meeting. The committee consisted of Midas and the animo-tronic stuffed koala he’d pulled out of a vending machine museum in the ruins of Old Navarre Mall. The museum had been free after the collapse, and Midas had always found it hard to resist a bargain, even if it stared at him with plastic eyes and emitted phrases at random intervals like a haunted warehouse. They sat on a sagging canopy roof overlooking the marrow-white bones of the city. Midas adjusted an elbow pad (fashioned from a kneecap pad, never mind the details) and squinted at the horizon. Chewy lay on his back, the little shirt on his plush torso reading WE CARE: HUGS INSIDE. One of his ears had been sewn up with catgut, badly, but with conviction. “Right,” Midas said, adopting the posture of a person who didn’t know what he was doing but felt that projecting confidence would confuse the enemy. “We need water. And something that isn’t jerky. And perhaps a change of luck.” Chewy’s mouth whirred. His eyes flickered once, twice, like fireflies reconsidering their life choices. “Chewy cuddles make every day brighter!” “That’s not really water,” Midas said. “Unless you’re implying some sort of trade. Hug-for-water exchange. I’m not sure the market conditions favor that.” The wind tugged at Chewy’s remaining ear. Somewhere, a building remembered it was supposed to fall and bent politely into the street. Midas unfurled a map made of glued-together takeaway menus and pointed his finger at a blue splotch labelled PRE-COLLAPSE WELLNESS COMPLEX. “The spa. They had a pool for floating therapy. It’s underground, so there’s a chance it hasn’t evaporated or turned into soup.” Chewy’s chest emitted a tiny mechanical purr, a leftover feature that had kept Midas warm during nights that didn’t respect the concept of enough clothes. “Refreshment is just a hug away.” “Not helping,” Midas said, rolling up the menu-map with a sigh. “Fine. The spa, then. On the way back we’ll swing by the amphitheater and see if anyone’s trading mushrooms for battery packs.” Chewy was silent for a while, which is how you knew his batteries were running low, and then chirped, “For the moments that matter, trust TambleCare.” “Exactly,” Midas said, rising and slinging his pack over his shoulders. “We’ll trust TambleCare. If they’re still accepting patients, I’ll check in for a spa day and affirm my wellness.” They climbed down the canopy ladder, which was mostly a polite suggestion to gravity. Midas’s boots hit the ground with a resigned thud. The streets had sprouted gardens of opportunistic life—feral vines threaded through supermarket trolleys, sunflowers faced a sun that had grown bored of being worshiped, and the remains of a billboard read ONLY YOU (the rest had been eaten by ivy). “Remember,” Midas said, moving at a cautious lope, “we’re just going in, taking a sip of not-disease, and coming out. No side quests.” Side quests were how Midas had nearly lost a thumb to a community that believed in the healing power of antique staplers, and how he had once traded a decent poncho for a box of “nutrition-enhanced sand” that turned out to be sand. The apocalypse was big on the value of learning experiences, which tended to ask for payment upfront. They crossed an intersection where traffic lights gestured at nobody and rounded a block where storefronts displayed faded promises: TODAY ONLY. BUY TWO, FORGET THREE. Midas eased open a rusted gate (Please—he’d always found “ease” a more aspirational instruction) and the Wellness Complex revealed itself like a particularly discouraging cake. It had peeled off its own signage and presented instead the impression that it might collapse on any visitor who didn’t pay for the deluxe package. The lobby was a greenhouse of dust. Plants had colonized the water feature, and a fern held the receptionist’s bell hostage. Midas stepped around blossoms growing from cracks in the marble, their petals the pale pink of regrets. “Looks friendly enough,” he said. Chewy’s head rotated three degrees and clicked. “Experience tranquility. Enroll today.” “In we go.” The pool was below, down a stairwell adorned with motivational posters. A man with a six-pack as improbable as the old world smiled, cracked, and slid down the wall. Believe! he commanded, although it sounded more like beleh, as if the letters themselves were tired. The pool room smelled like evaporated promises and metal. The water was a green coin at the far end, mostly covered by a carpet of algae that had risen up to govern. Still, in the corner, the surface showed a patch of something like clarity. Midas knelt, eyes narrowing. “Do you reckon I can filter that?” he asked Chewy, like a man asking a teddy bear an opinion that mattered. The trick to staying sane, Midas had found, was to pretend conversations were two-way radio rather than two-way mirror. Chewy snuggled into the crook of his elbow. “Family size. Value pack.” “Famously unhelpful.” Midas reached for the water, cup poised, when a shape under the algae moved. There are many kinds of motion: the confident sway of a predator, the skitter of a creature with too many legs, the steady translation of a rock that refuses to stop rolling because the world has ended, not gravity. This was the shimmy of something large and stubborn that had set up shop. It surfaced with an expression that could be described as: you again? Midas froze. A turtle the size of a coffee table blinked, ancient and entirely unimpressed. Most of its back hosted a small archipelago of barnacles. It exhaled a sound like a tired librarian. “Ah,” Midas said. “Local management.” The turtle advanced, slowly but with malignant intent. It did not need speed. Speed was for creatures that hadn’t learned the value of inevitability. Midas backed away. “We’re just”—he waved a cup as one might wave a white flag at a particularly litigious cloud—“here for a taste.” The turtle opened its mouth to reveal a tongue that suggested a long history of crushing. It stepped onto the last stair and kept coming. Midas glanced around for options. The options did not glance back. “Plan B,” he said to Chewy, scooping the koala with one hand and slinging himself onto the railing. He slid, graceless as a man attempting to rejoin his childhood from the wrong angle. The turtle followed, not to the railing, because the railing had standards, but to the idea of relentless pressure. At the top, Midas landed in a gout of dust that declared its independence. He sprinted past the motivational man, who gave him a look like we all made choices, and burst into the lobby. The fern cheered him on because cheering was what it did. Outside, the sky was in the process of making weather. Rain negotiated with heat. The first drops were exploratory diplomats. They got a block away before Midas slowed, breathing hard. His problem, he decided, was that he was always a day late to good ideas. If he’d had a net, a plan, a friend who wasn’t mostly fluff. If he had— Chewy, nestled in his arm, chirped, “Instant savings! Limited time only.” “Story of my life,” Midas said. This was when the side quest arrived to complain about being neglected. Three figures stepped out from behind a bus whose destination still read City Center in cheerful, obdurate letters. They were dressed in an appealing patchwork of leather, optimism, and the-intimidation-value-of-metal-studs, and they carried implements that had started life as gardening tools and aimed, one day, to be weapons. “Afternoon,” said the leader, a woman with hair braided in a way that suggested both patience and a certain number of clerical incidents in her past. “That’s a sweet toy. We’ll take a toy tax.” Midas held Chewy tighter. “He’s not a toy. He’s a friend. Also, tax authorities require documentation.” “We’re very forward-thinking,” the woman said. “We document on the inside of our heads.” Chewy’s eyes flickered. “Feel good about your choices with Omni-Nurture.” “See?” Midas said. “Omni-Nurture. He’s licensed.” The woman cocked her head. “You bartering anything else, treasure hunter?” Midas considered his inventory: three filters, two tins of beans, one potato reduced to a starchy rumor, and a coil of copper wire he’d been convinced would be important any day now. “Truly, no,” he admitted. “Well then,” the woman said, and lunged. Midas ducked. It was not graceful. He swerved toward the amphitheater, because he had said he would and it seemed rude not to follow through. The amphitheater hosted a market every third afternoon, when traders came to exchange radishes, stories, and scowls. The stairs were crowded with people, and the world responded to the idea of being crowded by making Midas collide with someone who owned a bucket of mushrooms. Mushrooms flew with a sorrowful plop. The crowd decided this was entertainment and shifted to a better seat. “Sorry!” Midas called, which was the kind of thing you shouted when sorry didn’t exist anymore as a currency. He vaulted a crate that turned out to be nothing of the kind and received the corner of a bartering stall in the shin. The woman with the braided hair and her two innovation specialists pursued him, moving like a lot of debt toward a small wallet. Midas’s mind engaged the part of itself that loved catastrophe the way some people love crosswords. He bolted through the center and toward the back, where traders stored things they valued less than money but more than their left foot. He dove into a curtain and found himself backstage, which was not much different from front-stage except there were more ropes and fewer witnesses. “Okay,” Midas told Chewy, panting. “Time for a miracle.” Chewy bleeped like a microwaved confession. “Power down to plush mode in: ten, nine…” “Don’t do that,” Midas hissed. He grabbed a rope at random because too much thinking had never improved his choices. The curtain yoinked upward as if offended. Behind him, the pursuers emerged, muttered, and spread out, which was precisely the wrong decision if one wanted to avoid whatever Midas was planning. He didn’t know what he was planning, but he had a reputation for unpredictability, mostly among inanimate objects. He pulled another rope. A counterweight descended in the form of a sandbag that had opinions. It swung, not at his pursuers, but at him. This was typical. He ducked and the sandbag continued, catching the woman in the shoulder. She staggered, then regained her balance with a look that suggested new creative taxes. Midas flung himself through a door marked Staff Only. The sign fell off in solidarity. The hallway beyond was a tangle of pipes and a smell of old popcorn attempts. He ran, and ran, and ran into the exit that presented itself as a suggestion. Outside, rain had graduated from negotiation to enthusiastic treaty. The street reflected the world in a reluctantly flattering tone. Midas sprinted through puddles that tried to be lakes. Behind him, his pursuers wavered. Rain wasn’t anyone’s friend. In a different life, Midas had loved rain. Now it had the habit of finding the holes in his coat and writing him letters: wet, wet, wet. He turned down an alley he knew, which swung around a building that had once taught yoga and now taught a more general lesson about the limits of flexibility. The alley opened onto Home Base, also known as the Refrigerator. It had earned the name by being a refrigerator. The walk-in sort, one of those stainless-steel boxes where restaurants stored ambitions and lettuce. In the building’s backend it had survived because there was something about heavy sealed doors that the apocalypse felt was too obvious. Midas had dragged in rugs and set up a stove and painted a sun on the wall that looked like it knew everything and was weary. He collapsed inside and slammed the door, which absorbed his panic with its usual courtesy and settled into silence. Outside, footsteps faltered, then faded. The rain hammered an unconvincing Morse code: go out again, we dare you. Midas leaned back and laughed in the way that is like crying with opinions. He slid down the door and ended up on the floor, which was a good place for a man to make friends with reality. Chewy’s eyes dimmed to cinnamon. “You can’t buy happiness,” he said softly, as if sharing a secret. “But you can lease it.” “That’s a hell of a philosophy,” Midas said. He wiped rain and fear off his face with his sleeve and took stock. The pack was soaked. The filters were damp but salvageable. The beans had opinions about the weather. His shin would bruise with artistry. He had acquired no water, no mushrooms, and a new cohort of people who wished to discuss taxation models with him. He stood, wincing, and stoked the stove with carefully curated wood. He hung his coat from a hook and draped a towel over Chewy like a ridiculous cowl. The koala’s mouth clicked quietly, a clockwork acceptance that the world had turned and they had not fallen off. Midas poured a cup of yesterday’s boiled water into a tin. He sipped. It tasted like patience and metal. “Right,” he said. “Tomorrow, we try the library. They had a children’s aquarium. It might have water.” Chewy didn’t reply. His eyes went dark. He had powered down, plush-mode engaged. Midas resisted the urge to shake him awake with a combination of fondness and terror. He lay back on his rug and listened to the rain write its long letter on the roof. He thought of turtles who managed their pools without paperwork. He thought of the woman with her braided hair and the ever-expanding bureaucracy of survival. He thought of how, in the before-time, the world had been run by people who believed in slogans about happiness and savings, and how perhaps nothing had changed except the lighting. He reached out and set his hand on Chewy’s little soft paw. “Thanks,” he said. “For the moments that matter.” In the night, the storm popped a gasket somewhere in the roof and water found the path it always finds, trickling down the wall and dripping into the pot Midas kept in readiness. He woke to the sound and sat up, blinking. “Well,” he whispered, and smiled despite himself, because sometimes the universe delivered by accident, the way a pot might end up exactly under a drip not because someone planned it, but because planning had done enough damage for the day. He placed two more pots under the leak, then crawled back to his rug. The world outside ground its teeth and slept. Inside, Midas dreamed of pools, floating therapy, and a turtle that let him pass because everyone had to drink. He dreamed of a sign that read HUGS ACCEPTED HERE and, in that dream, the sign had hands. In the morning, the committee would reconvene and the minutes would record that the mission had not gone to plan, that side quests had applied for leadership and won, and that home base had been reached by alternative routes, including but not limited to falling into it. The committee would acknowledge injuries, count the pots, and approve a new agenda item: find an umbrella. But for now there was the soft tick of cooling metal and the heavy softness of a toy powered down, and a man who had survived by shooting through the middle of the worst kinds of trouble, dragging his apocalypse buddy along with him, and making it home by every improbable, ridiculous route the world offered. Somewhere near morning, Chewy stirred. His mouth clicked. “Chewy cuddles,” he whispered into the half-light, “now with thirty percent more care.” Midas laughed, quietly, and let the sound ride the rain down. “We’ll take it,” he said. “We’ll take all we can get.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story successfully captures Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style with its blend of absurdist humor, philosophical musings disguised as jokes, and a world that operates on its own peculiar logic. The post-technological collapse setting is vividly realized through clever details like maps made of takeaway menus, motivational posters sliding down walls, and the repurposing of everyday objects. The relationship between Midas and Chewy is particularly well-executed. Chewy's pre-programmed phrases that somehow manage to be both non-sequiturs and oddly appropriate to the situation create a delightful dynamic. The author cleverly uses these stock phrases to build character and even advance the plot, turning what could have been a one-note joke into a surprisingly nuanced relationship. The prose demonstrates excellent command of Pratchett's style, with metaphors that start in one place and end up somewhere unexpected ("like a man asking a teddy bear an opinion that mattered. The trick to staying sane, Midas had found, was to pretend conversations were two-way radio rather than two-way mirror"). The author employs footnote-like asides within the text itself, another Pratchett hallmark. The mission structure follows the prompt perfectly, beginning with deliberation, proceeding through complications (the turtle, the tax collectors), and returning home "worse for wear" but with an ironic twist of success. The story maintains a consistent tone throughout, balancing humor with genuine moments of poignancy. Where the piece occasionally falters is in some overwritten passages that try too hard to be clever. A few metaphors feel strained, and there are moments where the prose becomes slightly purple. The story also occasionally meanders, particularly during the chase sequence, which could have been tightened. The dialogue, while sparse due to one character being a stuffed koala with limited phrases, is effective. The author cleverly uses Chewy's pre-programmed lines as both comic relief and occasionally profound commentary. The ending strikes a perfect balance between the wry humor that characterizes the piece and a genuine emotional connection between the characters. It avoids being overly sentimental while still providing a satisfying conclusion that feels earned. Overall, this is an excellent response to the prompt that captures Pratchett's style while creating its own unique world and characters. The relationship between Midas and his apocalypse buddy Chewy forms the emotional core of the story, elevating it beyond mere pastiche. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 90.2
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
“Close the door.” “I—sorry—of course.” The man stumbled backward, fingers fumbling at the latch as if it might bite him. He shut the door, then kept his palm pressed to it as if the outside might shove through. He was breathing a little too quickly. He did that thing famous faces do when they try not to be recognized: head down, cap low, sunglasses even though the sky outside was Welsh-cloud grey. “Mind,” I added, and pointed at the hand-scrawled sign. “Please. It sticks.” He read it without taking off the sunglasses. “Right. It sticks. That’s a metaphor.” “It’s a door.” He smiled at that. It was a practiced smile, the sort that had won him magazine covers and an arms-length of phone numbers, but the edges twitched with real relief. He still didn’t take off the sunglasses. He hunched beneath the hanging fern that drooped over the till like an old woman ready to tell your fortune, and his shoulders eased when no one else behind him barreled in with lenses and shouts. “Is there a back door?” he asked, voice pitched low, careful. “I can pay you for the inconvenience.” “There’s a back,” I said. “But if you go out it’ll open onto the alley where they’ve parked.” “So they are here.” He peered toward the beveled glass, where the street beyond was mostly fogged rain on rain. Somewhere out there I could hear a van door slide, a crow complaining, the undertone of town life. “Of course they are,” he said with theatrical despair. “I am, apparently, very interesting.” “You’re blocking the crime novels.” At that, his head tilted, just enough. He glanced down at the display table he was half leaning on, then up again, as if recalibrating his angle of attack. “Am I? Tragic. I’ve been accused of worse. Murder by charisma.” I kept my mouth from smiling. I’m good at that. Customers come in to browse and leave with stacks and stories; I sell them the stacks and keep my stories folded up between page one and two. “You can be accused of stepping to the left,” I said, and he stepped, instant obedience. The sunglasses finally came off, and there it was: the face that had been larger than life last summer on the billboard by the bypass, smirking in a tuxedo under the words He always gets his man. He was shorter in real life. Most of them are. “Hi,” he said, as if we weren’t already in the middle. “I’m—” “I know,” I said before I could catch it back. It came out flat, because I meant it as information, not invitation. The name danced around the air anyway; I saw the moment he waited for it—Rhys Llewellyn—and when I didn’t give it, I watched the faintest flicker of disappointment in a face trained to control such flickers. His grin brightened a notch, survival instinct. “Yes. That,” he said. “I’m that. And you are the gatekeeper of this sanctuary. I am in your debt. Name your price. Tea? Books? Lifelong gratitude? I can offer all three with varying degrees of sincerity.” “Buy a book,” I said. “I’ll throw in the gratitude.” He laughed, and it was better than the smile, more honest. “Done. Do you have—” He cast around. “Something obscure and intelligent that I can pretend to have already read twice?” “You want a backup.” I slipped around the counter, brushing past the fern. “In case they interview you through the window.” “In case you interview me,” he corrected, following with that loose-hipped stride that made millions. “But more importantly: because I like it when clever people like me. It’s one of my tragic flaws. Right alongside cheekbones.” “I can’t help with those.” I led him into the narrow aisle where Welsh poets sat with their spines earnest and the smell was old paper, damp wool, and the faint salt of the bay. My bell-alone bookshop in Penmaes, a place tourists call quaint and locals call there when they need it. Middle shelves are for the steady sellers: cookbooks with mugs of tea on their jackets, thrillers with embossed guns. The lower shelves, a cheeky tangle of small presses and oddities. He let his fingers trail along spines, as if the books were fur he could pet. “I like this place,” he said, like a man placing a bet. “It feels like my grandmother’s attic, if my gran had excellent taste and better curation.” “Your grandmother has poor taste?” “No. She has a deep commitment to hoarding ceramics.” He angled a look at me. “And expensive whisky. That part I inherited.” “Along with the cheekbones.” “They are a burden.” He sighed tragically, then ruined the moment by bumping his shoulder against a shelf and wincing. “I’m actually here for a film,” he added, because he needed me to know. “I’m not hiding from my own wedding or the law.” “Only photographers.” He pressed his mouth together on a true grimace. “Only them.” He softened it. “We’re shooting at the old slate quarry up the mountain. At least we were, until the rain turned the set into a skating rink. The director hates rain. In Wales. The audacity.” “The slate has a mind of its own,” I said. “It’s older than the lot of us. It doesn’t care about money.” He turned his whole body toward me. “Do you climb?” “Just a little,” I managed. My tongue took a half-second longer to cooperate, because his attention had weight. “Indoor mostly. I grew up scrambling over the quarry walls when you could still get away with it. There’s a limestone crag up near Cwm-y-coed. Have you been?” His eyes lit, not the showface light but the kind that comes from somewhere marrow-deep. “I went last week on our day off. I had a guide who swore at me in English and Welsh alternately. I have blisters in the shape of Gwynedd.” “You were bad.” “I was enthusiastic,” he said, with dignity. “I’m good on things I can rehearse. On the wall, it’s just you and your hands saying: try again. It’s infuriating and holy.” “In that order.” “In both orders. Do you climb?” “I just told you that I do.” “No, but do you climb.” He tugged an invisible rope between us, daring. “When you can’t sleep? When you’ve had a day and you need to feel something under your palms that isn’t a screen? When your head won’t shut up?” The rain ticked harder at the window. I folded my arms so that my hands had something to do. “Yes,” I said finally, simple. He let out a breath he’d been holding. The rogue went quiet, the charm took one knee. “Good,” he said. “Me too.” Somewhere outside, someone shouted his name. Not inside here. “Pick a book,” I said, because this was my shop and rules were anchors. He scanned the lower shelves and plucked out a battered copy of a mountaineering memoir, Welsh climber, small press, cover half-faded, title: On Crag and Cloud. “This looks appropriately pretentious,” he said. “It’s excellent,” I said before I could bite it back, and watched his mouth curve, because I’d let something slip. “He writes like he’s on belay. Tension, release.” “You love it.” “Yes.” “Then I should have it.” He tucked it under his arm like a trophy, then hesitated. “Unless you’ll be mad to part with it.” “It’s a business. Things leave.” “You run this alone?” he asked, and asked like he wanted the answer, not just the anecdote. “I have Aled on Saturdays when the rugby’s not on,” I said. “And my niece on school holidays. Mostly it’s me.” “It suits you.” He gestured to the chalkboard with the month’s book club schedule on it. “Control. Curating. Tiny kingdom. Small rebellions. The fern that looks like it gossips.” “It does. She knows your secrets.” “She already told me,” he said solemnly. “She said, ‘Stop using charm like a crowbar.’” I didn’t mean for the laugh to escape. It slipped anyway. It made his eyes soften, and that was dangerous. The undercurrent that had been humming since he walked in shifted keys. I stepped back toward the till because the safest thing to do when you feel the river catch is to find a rock. He followed at a respectful distance. “You didn’t ask for a selfie,” he said lightly. “Most people do. Or they pretend not to recognize me for twenty minutes and then ask me to sign their cousin’s baby.’ “I don’t do babies.” “Autographs?” “I don’t do pretending,” I said. “And if I asked you for a selfie you’d smile exactly the way you’ve been trained to smile, and you’d step into the light, and I’d look at it later and feel like I’d stolen a piece of something that wasn’t you.” “You’re a philosopher disguised as a bookseller.” “I’m a woman trying to have a quiet Tuesday.” He pressed his palm to the counter. His hands were nicked—real blisters, not makeup. “You don’t like me,” he said, and it wasn’t a question. It was the hurt child under the grin, prodding a bruise to see how bad it is. “I don’t know you,” I said. Then, because the truth sometimes demands an amendment, I added, “Yet.” The corner of his mouth did something complicated. He looked at the fern. He looked back at me. “Okay,” he said softly. “Okay.” We both breathed. The rain battered the window and then gentled, because weather is a creature like any other and needs to exhaust itself. He dug in his jacket for a wallet that probably cost more than my rent and yet was scuffed the way only honest things get. He put down a card. It had a name on it that made my stomach flip, which annoyed me. He saw the flip, because of course he did. He is a man who has made a life from noticing the way attention casts shadows. “Do you have a loyalty card?” he asked, teasing himself before I could. “Buy ten, get a restraining order free?” “We stamp with a dragon.” I pulled the little ink stamp from under the counter. “After six you get a tote bag with a quote that makes me roll my eyes.” “What’s the quote?” “Between the pages of a book is a lovely place to be.” He grimaced theatrically. “Weaponized twee. I love it. Stamp me.” I stamped the card. He watched the dragon bloom, and something like contentment moved across his face. Not the actor’s drafted version; the original. The bell over the door tinkled, but no one came in. It was the wind. “They’ll tire,” I said, nodding at the window. “Paparazzi. They’re like gulls. If they think there’s no chips they’ll move on.” “You are aggressively practical,” he said, admiration disguised as complaint. “It’s very hot.” “Stop that.” He put up both hands. “Right. No crowbars.” Silence settled between us, surprisingly easy. He drummed his fingers once, twice, then stilled them, as if practicing stillness. “What are you reading?” he asked, gesturing to the paperback face down beside the till. The spine was cracked, the cover corner scalloped from my habit. “Right now? Carver’s letters,” I said. “He’s an awful man who writes beautifully, which is inconvenient.” “Do you like awful men?” “No.” The answer was too quick. I gentled it. “I like men who know they could be awful and decide not to be.” The sound he made wasn’t quite a laugh. “Okay,” he said again. “Okay.” He tucked On Crag and Cloud closer to his chest, like he might breathe through it. The rain had eased. The van door outside slid shut. A gull cackled, offended to be compared to paparazzi. “Will you …” He stopped. He changed tack. “There’s a wall in town, isn’t there? The climbing gym? With the mural of the red dragon left over from the 2016 competition? The holds are terrible and everyone’s thirteen and better than me.” “Yes.” The word felt like a step on secure stone. “I usually go in the mornings, before set call.” He looked down at his hands. “It quiets me, before a day of pretending.” He glanced up, from under lashes that had sold seductions to Netflix. The rogue stepped aside and let something braver through. “Would you—if you ever go in the mornings—if you want—if you could pretend not to be immune for an hour—” “I’m not,” I said. His head came up. The words had escaped again, traitors. I let them stand. “Immune,” I clarified. “I’m not. I’m just … cautious.” His shoulders dropped with a relief so palpable I felt it in my own. “Cautious is fair,” he said. “Cautious is sane.” “I have the shop,” I added, defense and confession both. “Most mornings.” “Right.” He nodded. “Right.” “But Thursdays,” I said. It surprised both of us. “Aled opens. I could—” I pressed my lips together. “If you’re not filming. If you want a belay.” His grin came back, not slick, not polished; it came like the sun when it breaks through and everyone pretends they knew it would. “I would like that,” he said. “Very much.” “Fine,” I said, because I had to pretend to be the person I am when he’s not in the room. “Eight?” “Eight.” He slid the loyalty card into his wallet with reverence. “If you stand me up, I will come back here and make a scene so endearing you’ll have to forgive me.” “Don’t make scenes in my shop.” “I will make a quiet scene,” he amended. “Tasteful. Curated.” “Good luck with that,” I said, and he laughed again, and the bell finally rang for real as someone pushed the door open. Two damp tourists peered around him. They blinked at his face, blinked again, whispered the whispered name. He flicked the sunglasses up in a salute that was half apology, half benediction, and stepped away, small as he could make himself. “Thank you,” he said, just to me, soft enough to be a secret. “For what?” “For not letting me be the poster,” he said, and then he was gone, swept back into the rain and the faint swell of gulls and cameras, the door sticking and the sign reminding him, and me, and the fern, that metaphors were doors and doors were metaphors, and sometimes the trick of them is that they do, in fact, stick.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a romantic encounter between a famous actor and a bookstore owner in Wales, with excellent attention to the requested character dynamics. The writing establishes a strong sense of place with subtle Welsh references and creates a bookshop that feels lived-in and authentic. The dialogue is particularly strong, carrying the narrative and revealing character through distinct voices. The bookstore owner's voice is reserved, practical, and slightly defensive, while the actor's dialogue reveals his charm offensive, fragile ego, and genuine moments of connection. The writer skillfully shows the actor's transition from practiced charm to authentic interest when his usual tactics don't immediately work. The internal conflict of the bookstore owner is well-conveyed through small physical details and brief moments of self-awareness ("The words had escaped again, traitors"). We see their outward resistance to the actor's charm while glimpsing their inward attraction through subtle cues rather than explicit statements. The prose is elegant without being overwrought, with occasional poetic flourishes that enhance rather than distract from the scene. Metaphors like "rules were anchors" and the recurring motif of the sticking door work effectively. The imagery is specific and evocative, particularly in establishing the bookshop atmosphere. The pacing is excellent, with the conversation building naturally to the climactic agreement to meet at the climbing wall. The ending provides satisfying closure to the scene while leaving open possibilities for the larger story. A few minor weaknesses: occasionally the metaphors become slightly too self-conscious ("weather is a creature like any other and needs to exhaust itself"), and there are moments where the prose could be tightened. The climbing discussion, while providing common ground for the characters, occasionally feels slightly forced as a device. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted scene that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating distinctive characters whose chemistry feels earned and whose voices remain consistent throughout. The writer demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of how to convey attraction through subtext rather than explicit statements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 89.5
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The door gave before Aya’s gloved palm with a sigh like a dying lung. Cold exhaled from the underhold as if the sea itself were nested down there, salt and rust and some older perfume of dust that had learned to ferment in the dark. The hinges complained in abraded whispers. Behind her, Simeon’s pocket watch ticked loud as a judge’s gavel. Tick. Tick. Tick. Katra’s hand brushed Aya’s elbow just once—a warning, a reassurance, or simply a reminder that the living still had warmth. “Too quiet,” Katra said, low, the syllables chewing through her accent like flint on bone. Her boots hesitated at the threshold. “Like a church after the congregation’s been buried.” Aya forced herself forward. The lantern swayed from her hand, throwing marine shadows across the oil-bricked stairwell. The steps drooped toward the deep like the spine of a sunken animal. She dared a breath and tasted the copper of brine and stale blood, the oily sweetness of lamp fuel, the mechanical tang of iron filings. Morska had a way of putting its flavor on your tongue when you least wanted it. She had been born above that taste with sugar and port in her mouth, and her mother’s last breath had tasted of rope and winter. She did not think of that now. She thought of the Scythan relic below, humming its myth in a tongue no one had the luxury to understand. She thought of credits, leverage, the slow-bowed heads of men who would call her Master. She thought of masks and whether she had worn hers long enough to forget what lay underneath. They reached the underhold level, where the brick gave to black basalt cut centuries ago when men still thought a king’s bones kept a country loyal. The corridor unfurled in a long curve, cables clinging to its ribs like veins. Their lantern met other lights: low hissing lamps guttering blue on copper sconce-work, a constellation placed by a careful, unhurried hand. Too unhurried. “Aya,” Simeon whispered, watch tapping time against his sternum, “I’ve got a feeling in my teeth.” “Keep them,” she said. “Teeth are expensive.” The corridor opened to an antechamber ribbed with ironwork like the inside of a whale’s skull. There, the air thickened with a faint harmonics, the sort that made a molar sing and the eye seek a seam in reality where none existed. In the middle of the chamber, a vault mouth yawned—interlocking plates of brass and whalebone fused with rivets the size of thumbs. Its lock wore sigils that pulsed like bruises. And between Aya and that hulking promise, a figure in a high-collared greatcoat of oil-black leather, her profile cut against lamp glare like a knife left on a butcher’s block. Hair smoothed into a severe knot. Boots planted delicate as a spider. Eyes that had been rumored, whispered about, attributed to portraits sold in back-alleys and burned. Marla Vostrik—Lord Vostrik to most tongues—did not look particularly incarcerated. She held a pistol in each hand like a pair of opinions she did not expect to revise. Around her, four men in seafarer’s rig stood at range with long rifles braced, bayonets glinting dull as the teeth of something that had never learned mercy. “Well,” Marla said, and her voice had sand in it, and honey after. “Watch your fingers on the door, little fish. Underhold’s hungry.” The undertow of fear took Aya by the ankles. She stopped because stopping made it look like choice. Katra shifted to flank, palms already flexed toward knife hilts not yet visible. Simeon’s breath went thin and quick. His watch did not care. Tick. Tick. “We heard you’d been taken,” Aya said. Her mouth shaped the lie with aristocratic ease, the one tool that had proved more reliable than any lockpick. “Dragged out of bed like a common salt-thief.” “A true thing often wears a false wig,” Marla said, mouth gentle, fingers steady on the triggers. “They took someone. I gave them someone. Our friends in brass are not so clever as they think. They trust leverages and levers. Oil and steel and paperwork. Magick, though—” Her gaze flickered like a blade at Aya’s mask, the fish-bone porcelain cheekbones painted blue-black, the beaked bridge hiding everything that ever mattered. “Magick frightens them. It frightens them because it is not a machine you can take apart on a desk.” Katra’s voice rasped like a whet-stone. “You’re meant to be rotting in the King’s wet room.” “Am I,” Marla murmured. “I do disappoint so many.” Aya felt the immateria ripple in the dark corner of her mind, the way old tidewaters spoke in sloshes against stone. It was like realizing there was a door in your spine you had never noticed, and that something leaned on the other side, listening for the latch. Her mother had taught her to turn the handle gently, with prayer and suspicion. The guild had taught her to wrench it wide. Marla’s presence made the handle hot. “Guns down,” Marla said softly to her men without looking away. The guns did not lower. The command was ceremonial. “Masks off.” Katra shifted, not a step, but a calculation. Aya lifted a gloved hand as if to remove the mask herself, and the world lurched. Rope sang. A net of wire bit down from the rafters in a hiss like steam venting from a wounded engine. The mesh caught Katra first, the hooks kissing her shoulders, her arms yanked up so sudden the knife she had not yet produced clattered useless. Simeon tried to sidestep and the second snare took him around the ribs, hoisting him to his toes, watch thumping frantic against its chain. Aya lifted her hand to cut—toward what? The hinge on the world? A pair of shadows from the corners swept; not shadows, men all in oil-cloth with goggles, the underhold’s keepers. A loop of wire settled with brutal grace around Aya’s wrists, teeth biting into glove and skin. Another around her throat, not choking, not yet: a promise of it. “Don’t,” Marla said, and the word cracked through the room. “Don’t even think, little fish. I know what you do. I’ve seen the way the lamps go sick when you’re near. Your little parlour tricks. Your mother’s old wickedness. You open a door here, and I’ll have Simeon’s heart put in a jar to pace the time I let him live.” Aya felt heat rise under the mask. “You don’t have jars big enough.” It was foolish, and she heard it. But she had spent months speaking as a blade; now, taken, she wanted any edge, even the dullest. Marla smiled as if someone had told a joke at a funeral. She nodded to one of her men. The man stepped in close and plucked at the mask’s straps with pliers. Leather bit. Aya resisted the urge to jerk away. There was no dignity in it. She had learned how to look bored under a hangman’s knot watching her mother wobble. She could do bored while being unpeeled. The mask came away with a suction sound. The air under it tasted sharper, like a winter fruit. The oil-lamps reflected off her skin like she was something polished. There was a moment, a bright, thin moment where nothing happened, and then everything did: Katra’s eyes widened, Simeon’s breath hitched like a misfired valve. The men with the guns did not change; they had not known her. Marla—Marla changed. Her lips parted as if the city had slid, revealing a seam she had not expected. “Sweet saints,” Simeon said, then seemed to swallow the words like loose shot. Tick. Tick. Tick. Katra hissed something in her mother’s language that tasted like blood. Marla tilted her head the smallest degree. “I had wondered whose little ornament you were.” She studied Aya’s cheeks, her eyes. “Aristocracy loses interest in charity when the ports freeze. But this—this is not charity. This is taste.” She looked faintly amused. “Miss Aya Darnicourt. Your father sells coal to men who have never seen a mine. Your mother—” She gestured with the pistol. “Ah, but we none of us remember her in polite company, do we.” Aya did not blink. She had learned from mirrors. “My father sells debts to men who have never learned to count. Call him what he is.” “And you,” Marla mused. “You sell nights to men who do not know it is really morning.” She nodded to the wires around Aya’s wrists. “Bring her.” They were tugged forward like fish on a string. Simeon stumbled, boots skidding on the basalt’s damp sheen. His watch ticked and ticked and Aya could hear the exact fiber of spring, the exact tremor, and behind it the immateria calling with voices like moth-wings and funeral bells. Marla looked at the vault. “The Scythan thing hums such delicate hymns. Makes even the air think of better days. Do you hear it?” Aya did. Or perhaps she heard the shape of something like hope and dressed it in foreign vowels. She swallowed. The wire at her throat tightened. “If you were going to shoot us, you’d have done it upstairs.” “Yes,” Marla agreed. “I am cheap sometimes, but I am not wasteful.” “Then don’t be,” Aya said. She lifted her chin against the bite of the loop. “You know who I am now. You know what my father will do. You’ve got his pet constables in your pocket, but he owns their rooms and their women and their children’s milk. You kill me, you bring Morska on your head. You don’t want that. Not in this quarter. Not when you’ve just made such a pretty show of being dead.” Katra twisted against the net. “Aya—” “Let me.” Aya’s mouth had never saved her before; perhaps there was novelty in it. “Keep me,” she told Marla. “Send word to the Darnicourt estate. See what price a man puts on a name. You’ll be paid twice by a father and a city. Leverage the one against the other. That’s all you’ve ever done, isn’t it? You make fortunes out of the space between a man’s fear and his pride.” Marla’s gaze did not flicker. “Listen to you, buying your own gallows. What if I say no?” Simeon made a small sound—no word, more a squeak from a machine in need of oil. Tickticktick. The watch seemed to hurry, impatient with human shape. Aya felt the immateria lean, hungry. It would be so easy to open her throat and let it speak. But they would die for it. Simeon with his small clever hands. Katra with her sandpaper voice and bone-deep loyalty, that ugly, lovely thing. And Aya—Aya would not die yet. She had not yet decided what she would do with the aftermath of being seen. “You won’t,” she said, injecting certainty into the hollow where belief should have been. “Because I am more useful breathing. Because rumor will do more work for you than blood. The guild survives on dread. Imagine what that dread looks like when you hold a Darnicourt daughter in your underhold and the city whispers your name between its teeth.” Marla’s mouth did a small, asymmetrical thing. She lowered one pistol a fraction. The men with the rifles did not move. “I do like whispers,” she admitted. “I keep them in boxes and feed them raisins.” She stepped closer, until Aya could smell peppermints on her breath—cheap ones, bought in paper cones. “What do you think your father will do, truly? Aside from cry into his brandy and strike his steward.” “He’ll send men,” Aya said. “He’ll send machines. He’ll beg the Church to sanctify an arrest warrant. They’ll smile and nod and they’ll do nothing. Because if they break you to save me, they admit you were stronger. They admit they need magick to fight magick. And that’s not—polite.” Marla considered. The humming under the vault deepened, a whale note in stone. Simeon’s watch ticked time against it, stubborn metronome refusing to be seduced by hymns. Katra watched Marla with murder in her eyes and murder’s patient hands. “What is it you want from the door, little fish?” Marla asked, almost curious. “What would you have done with a thing older than our bad habits?” “Open it,” Aya said. The truth slid out because lying cost too much right now, and because perhaps truth tasted sharper. “Listen. Maybe learn to speak back.” “You would.” Marla exhaled as if it amused her. “You and your mother and all your pretty dead.” She lifted her hand and, delicate as a choirgirl, touched the place where Aya’s mask had been, just under her left eye, with the barrel of the pistol. Cold kissed bone. “You will not open anything while you are mine.” “Says the woman who sells doors,” Aya said, and then winced because it had come out too clever by half and she had no right to be clever with wire on her wrists. Marla’s smile did not reach her eyes. “Take them to the pit,” she told her men. “We’ll keep Miss Darnicourt where the air can see her. Write a letter. Send a runner. If anyone asks, we tell them we found a fish that learned to walk.” She glanced to Aya. “And do not worry, little fish. I’ll put you on a chair and let you watch me count the ransom. You can tell me when to stop.” Simeon’s watch ticked agreement or protest—who could say. Katra spat at Marla’s boots and missed by an inch. As they were dragged backward past the vault that moaned slightly of its own accord, Aya felt the press of consequence settle around her shoulders like a wet shroud. The name Darnicourt scraped the air of the underhold until it bled. Simeon’s face held a tightness she had never deserved. Katra’s curses braided with prayers. The immateria knocked, polite, behind her ribs. She did not open. Not here. Not like this. Marla walked beside them a moment, boots whispering on basalt, knives in her voice resheathed for now. “I do hope you are as entertaining unmasked as you are masked,” she murmured. “It is so disappointing when the theatre is better than the man.” “I’m not a man,” Aya said without thinking. “No,” Marla agreed, almost kind. “No. You are appetite.” The men hauled them into a side corridor where the air grew damp with a new rot, and somewhere water dripped in monk-like patience. Simeon’s watch ticked and ticked and ticked, carving seconds into little cogs that would never fit any machine again. Aya breathed through wire and oil and old salt and did not look back at the vault or at Marla’s profile, which already had the quality of a portrait that would survive regimes. “I’ll get you out,” Aya whispered into the cold. It was a debt she wrote knowing it would accrue interest the underhold would demand. “I’ll get us out. I promise.” Katra, hoisted and hamstrung, did not laugh. “We are already out of what we were,” she said. “Now we see if we can breathe.” The door to the pit opened with a wet churn of rust. Aya stepped into a darkness with teeth, and the watch in Simeon’s pocket announced the hour like a tired priest tolling a bell that no one heard anymore. The sound went on, a metronome for fear, as the underhold closed its mouth. And somewhere behind them, a woman in a greatcoat considered how to price a life she had already bought.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response demonstrates exceptional skill in creating a vivid, atmospheric scene that fulfills the prompt requirements while establishing a distinctive voice. The writer has crafted a world that feels simultaneously Victorian and otherworldly, with the "whalepunk" aesthetic coming through in details like "oil-bricked stairwell," "whalebone fused with rivets," and the vault chamber "ribbed with ironwork like the inside of a whale's skull." The prose is highly stylized and dense with imagery, occasionally bordering on purple but generally maintaining control through purposeful rhythm and sensory detail. Lines like "The door gave before Aya's gloved palm with a sigh like a dying lung" establish the gothic tone immediately. The writer excels at creating atmosphere through sensory details: "tasted the copper of brine and stale blood, the oily sweetness of lamp fuel, the mechanical tang of iron filings." Character voices are distinct and consistent with the Victorian-gothic aesthetic. Marla's dialogue is particularly strong, with lines like "A true thing often wears a false wig" and "I keep them in boxes and feed them raisins" establishing her as menacing yet oddly poetic. The dialogue serves both character development and plot advancement effectively. The narrative follows the requested story beats precisely: Aya is captured and unmasked, the trio are taken prisoner, and Aya attempts to negotiate based on her value as a hostage. The writer skillfully incorporates Aya's internal monologue, showing her calculating mind and emotional responses without overexplaining. The worldbuilding is subtle but effective, with references to "immateria magick," the Church's authority, and class divisions creating a coherent society. The fear of magic is well-established through dialogue and character reactions. The Victorian aesthetic comes through in details like pocket watches, oil lamps, and formal speech patterns. The piece does occasionally risk becoming overwrought, with some metaphors that call attention to themselves rather than serving the narrative. A few sentences could be trimmed for clarity without losing the atmospheric quality. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece. The ending avoids incongruent positivity, maintaining the dark tone while providing a natural conclusion to the scene. The characters' predicament feels genuine, and Aya's promise to get them out feels desperate rather than artificially hopeful. Overall, this is an exceptionally strong response that demonstrates mastery of gothic horror elements, Victorian aesthetics, and character development within a constrained word count. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception.
