+ Surreal horror: Caribou Season at the Lodge — Score: 91.2
Prompt:
Caribou Season at the Lodge Genre: Surreal Horror JT knew something wasn't right from the moment they'd pulled up to the lodge. It looked exactly as it had every autumn of his life—the cedar shingles silvered with age, the porch sagging gently under weight of winters past—but the air felt thicker, somehow, as if the woods had leaned in closer, waiting. He thought maybe he was just tired. Maybe it was nothing more than the long drive north, cramped in the back of the truck beside his older brother Mike -- and a stack of rifles wrapped in oily canvas. Still, the feeling lingered. The first caribou they found that season hadn't bolted. It had just watched, ears flicking lazily, waiting for the shot. JT had felt a crawling in his gut watching it die, noticing how it fell with a quiet dignity—as though it had wanted nothing more. Nobody else seemed to find it odd, or at least they didn't say so. JT kept his mouth shut. Always safer that way. Then there was the moment in the clearing. JT had fallen behind, fumbling with bootlaces stiff from the cold, and by the time he'd caught up with his father and brother, they'd already stopped. JT slowed instinctively, ducking behind a tangle of brush, staring out into the open space where a massive buck stood utterly still, chest rising and falling in slow, deep breaths. The animal looked…wrong, somehow. Maybe it was the eyes—dark and flat, calm in a way that made JT's neck prickle. Or maybe it was something deeper, something in the way the buck stood close enough for his father to reach out and touch it. JT watched as his father raised a trembling hand toward the animal's muzzle. His father's face had a strange expression, eyes too bright, lips parted slightly, like he was on the verge of whispering something—a secret, maybe. The rifle hung uselessly at his side, forgotten. Mike had the same dazed look in his eyes. JT's breath stopped short, his mind suddenly shouting at him to look away, turn around, just run—but he couldn't move. And then, as suddenly as it had begun, it was over. The buck shivered, startled by something unseen, and disappeared into the brush without so much as a sound. The two of them looked around, confused, seemingly surprised to find themselves where they stood. JT stayed hidden, breathing shallowly, fear mingling with a confused sense of shame. His father had failed to take the shot. To even think about mentioning what he'd seen would have felt like betrayal—or something worse. JT waited until the others moved on before stepping out from cover. He stared into the empty clearing for a long, uneasy moment, wondering if anything had really happened at all, or if he was losing his grip. Maybe the woods were finally getting into his head. Writing Instructions: Continue with the next chapter of the story, maintaining a style reminiscent of Stephen King—grounded realism blended seamlessly with unsettling surrealism. The atmosphere should convey subtle dread, isolation, and psychological ambiguity. JT's perspective is crucial, yet he is an unreliable narrator, caught in uncertainty about what he's perceiving. Establish an undertone of creeping dread, establishing the isolation of JT's perspective, which he largely keeps to himself. Incorporate some dialogue. Build tension towards a payoff. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The second night, the wind shifted. You could smell the lake—wet leaves, iron, something sweetly rotten—and the chimney smoke sliding along the roof instead of going up. Everyone insisted it was normal for this time of year. You learn to accept weird little weather things up here, like a dog learns to accept the vacuum. But JT lay awake in the bunkroom listening to it smearing across the shingles, whispering in the eaves. He had the top bunk, same as always, because he was the smallest and the lightest and his father had once said, "My boys are stacked like kindling, just how I like 'em." Mike snored under him. The lodge crackled and popped like an old man in a church pew. Somewhere out there a loon kept thinking it was still dusk and calling to no one. He thought about the buck. He tried to make the memory less sharp, rounding off the corners. If he imagined his father's mouth not quite open, if he imagined the rifle more present in that hand, if he imagined Mike rolling his eyes, it got easier. A few minutes later it got harder again. He kept seeing that tremble in the buck's chest when it sighed, the idea that it had been about to say something. That's not a thought anybody in your family says out loud. Animals don't say anything. Animals are meat and bone and fur and sometimes beauty. If you start putting mouths on them inside your head, you become a person your family doesn't know what to do with. Sleep came like stepping into a deep puddle—one foot down and then nothing. He dreamed of the lodge with all the windows blacked out and the porch light a cold star, of the snowshoes hanging on the wall like two giant moths fluttering when he breathed on them. He dreamed his father's hand in the open clearing, not reaching for a muzzle but for a door knob suspended in the air. He dreamed that when the knob turned, it made the sound of a buck snort. He woke to bacon and coffee and the way men talk when they don't want to talk. Mike chewing like he wanted the bacon to surrender. His father flipping pancakes, grim as a judge. "You sleep okay?" Mike said, not looking up from his plate. "Fine," JT said, which was the automatic answer from birth. "Wind's wrong," his father said to the griddle. "We'll go east. Stay low. Fog'll burn off by ten." "Supposed to be clear tonight," Mike offered. "Full moon Saturday." His father slid a pancake onto Mike's plate like a man delivering a verdict. "Don't say that word to me." "What?" "Full," his father said, not looking at either of them. "There's no such thing." JT thought about the guide, Lang. Glenn Lang with the beard like a fox sleeping under his skin and a mouth that usually never stopped. The last couple of years he'd told stories with more relish than he sold permits. Moose in the old days you had to shoot three times and they still came. A lady from Boston who going to make yoga retreats in here until she saw a wolverine like a badger on steroids. Things like that. Last night, Lang had been quiet the way a locked drawer is quiet. They saw him after breakfast, down by the shed where he kept the sleds. He had his hat off and his hair lay flat in a way that made him look younger, or maybe sick. When he noticed them, he put the hat on so fast it was like he was covering a hole in his head. "Morning, Glenn," their father said. The name came out stiffly: Glenn, not Lang. A man's Christian name used only if you wanted something or you were giving pity. "Mornin'," Lang said. He tugged the bill of his cap and his eyes skittered past them toward the tree line. "You boys headed out?" "East ridge," Mike said. "You coming?" Lang's mouth did something complicated and then settled. "No." "No?" their father said. That single syllable loaded with nineteen years of tradition. No was not what the guide said. "Weather's strange," Lang said. "Barometer's been falling wrong. You smell that?" He lifted his chin slightly, sniffed. "Sap's turned in some of the maples and the popple's hanging onto leaves like it's got something to prove. Not hunting weather." "There's always weather," their father said. Lang nodded as if conceding a point in a conversation he was conducting with someone behind them. "I won't stop you. I don't own the woods. But I ain't walking you in past the south marsh today. And I'd take a day. Go into town. Fix that rear axle squeak on your truck. Get a pie from Martha. Be back in a couple days." "It's Thursday," Mike said. "Be back in a couple days," Lang repeated, and he looked at JT when he said it, the way somebody looks at the youngest to check if the message is getting in through the cracks. "You got something you want to say?" their father asked. His voice didn't get louder. It got narrower. Lang's hands went deeper into his jacket pockets. "Moon's wrong too," he said. "Big as it's gonna get. Things show up when it's like that." "Like caribou," Mike cracked, because he could never let a silence finish itself. "Not just that," Lang said. He started to say more, then shut his mouth. He turned and spoke toward the shed instead. "You know we had that logging crew out past Shanty Brook? Wednesday. They packed up yester—" "We're not loggers," their father said. "No," Lang said. "I guess you're not." Then he looked past them again, into the trees, and JT felt something unspool low in his gut, a fishing line drifting out and out until the spool wasn't humming anymore and you were down to your last wraps. "Be out of here before moon-up tomorrow. That's what I would do." He said it soft and fast and turned away and began a performance of checking the lashings on a sled that didn't need checking. Back in the truck, JT sat in the back seat again with the rifles like sleeping dogs and said nothing. "You see the way he looked at us?" Mike said. "Like we were the ones with the rabies." "He's spooked," their father said, starting the engine. "Glenn gets spooked when his woodpile runs low and when a fisher steals his chickens and when his wife goes into town without him. He gets spooked like it's a hobby." "Still," Mike said. He let the word hang there like a limb he was thinking of sawing off. They drove east, the ruts deep and the puddles silver. Birch trunks flicked by like a hall pass. JT watched them and tried to count to a hundred without thinking of the buck. He got to thirty-eight and failed. He got to seventy-two and thought of Lang telling them to go get a pie. Who the hell bolts when the season is sweet? People whose zero is different than yours, he thought. People who believe in full moons you can't say. They parked at the end of an old logging road that had tried to return to earth. You could tell it had been traveled recently by the way the grass lay crushed in two long rusty lines. JT felt that crawling again when he saw that. If he told himself it was because it might be trespassers, that was an acceptable explanation. They walked. The world had that strange hung quality, the quiet after a backfire. The fog didn't burn off by ten. It sat in the low places like a tired dog that refused to move. When it did lift in tatters, it went up not in streamers but in roundish shapes, like balloons. "You seeing that?" Mike said at one point, low, possibly to himself. "Eyes open," their father said. They saw tracks. Hooves fine as coin impressions in the cold mud. They saw scat, little piles like the raisins their grandmother used to put in bread pudding, which nobody did after she died. They heard nothing with intent. An occasional branch shifting its weight, that was all. By noon, JT's feet had that dead feeling like someone else's feet had been attached to his legs. He shouldn't have worn the old boots. He shouldn't have come. We're not loggers. The words repeated in his head with no context. He didn't know what they meant. He did and he didn't. He chewed at the inside of his cheek until it tasted like pennies. They stopped to eat at the low end of a meadow that in summer would have been wildflowers and dragonflies but now was a brown plate. His father handed him a sandwich wrapped in wax paper. Baloney, mustard like paint. JT chewed and wondered about the guide's story that he hadn't told. It danged like a chain behind them all day. "You keep checking behind you for bears," Mike said, grinning around his food. "Guilty conscience?" "Leave him," their father said. He said it gently. JT stared at him. When was the last time his father had said anything gently? It felt wrong, like a scent in a familiar room. "Glenn said the logging crew went out," JT said before he could swallow the words. They stumbled out of him half-chewed. "He started to say why and then didn't." "No crew wants to be in here for a full—" Mike started, then ducked when their father looked at him. He grinned, unrepentant. "For a big ol' moon night," he amended. He winked at JT. The wink felt like being let in on a joke you didn't find funny. "You believe in that—" JT began, and his father cut him off, not with a word but by raising a hand. The same hand that had reached toward the buck yesterday. JT saw it with two sets of eyes at once: his father's hand with the knuckles stiff and scarred and the hand he'd watched extend toward something invisible in the clearing. He felt a shiver push up his throat. He coughed to cover it. Something moved at the far edge of the meadow. Not big. A flicker. A patch of brush rearranging itself. He swallowed his sandwich wrong and choked a little. Mike slapped his back, too hard. "You all right?" his father asked, standing slowly. He didn't ask the woods a thing. He asked his younger son, which was new. "I'm fine," JT said. He wasn't. By three, the light had gone metallic. Indigo threaded into the shadows. They followed the low ground to a line of alders. Mike found the gut pile before anyone spoke. It was laid out neat, the way a butcher might: lungs deflated like paper bags, liver dark and shining, intestines looped in a tidy braid. JT stood there, his breath hitching, unable to decide if the orderliness or the fact that there was no blood stain made him feel worse. "Jesus," Mike said softly, like he had come into a church without knowing. "Who leaves that?" JT heard himself whisper. His voice sounded too loud in his own head, like he'd shouted into a hat. "Nobody who hunts," their father said. He crouched. He reached out and then pulled his hand back as if the air over the gut pile were hot. "Not coyote," he said. "Not bear. You'd see mess. Drag. This is..." He didn't finish. This is what? JT wanted to ask. This is a display. This is a gift. This is a warning. He had all those words floating around his brain like dandelion fluff. He picked none. He breathed through his mouth because the smell was not rot but something else—sweet like maple sap, but familiar in a way he couldn't place. He swallowed and swallowed. "Let's go," their father said finally. He said it like the word had been forced up through his teeth. "Back to the truck." They turned, and for a while the only sound was the soft shush of their clothes. JT kept trying not to step on the mule tracks of their lives, to make his own path. Every time he veered, his foot found an old footprint without looking. That made him feel crazy. Everything did. The woods tightened. There are places where the map doesn't tell the truth. You learn the truth with your body. The birches started to crowd close, arms crossed. The pines leaned in like arguments. Lang had said be out before moon-up tomorrow. It occurred to JT then that tomorrow was not a separate country from the one you were living in. Time up here had a way of pressing together like wet paper. They came to the ditch, the one that had been there since the CCC men cut it, and found the crossing gone. The old log had rolled itself away. The water wasn't deep, but it shone with a skin that didn't ripple right. His father hesitated. He never hesitated at that ditch. "Glenn was right," JT blurted, before he could stop himself. His words sounded breathless, like he'd run to catch up to them. "We should go into town. Tonight." Mike laughed. It was a quick bright sound that died fast. "We gonna check into the Holiday Inn and watch cable? Eat pie?" "Shut up, Mike," JT said. The words shocked even him. He wanted to grab them back out of the air, push them into his mouth, chew them up. His father turned to him. The pupils in his eyes were a little too big for the daylight. He looked at JT as if trying to decide which of his sons this was. "You think something's wrong," he said. It wasn't a question. He sounded tired, not angry. "Yeah," JT said. He heard how small it came out. His father nodded once, slow. He put a hand—the hand—on JT's shoulder for a second. Heat went through JT like a wire carrying current. "We go back now," his father said. "We'll talk to Glenn." They crossed lower, where the ditch went narrow and mean. Mud took them up to the laces. JT felt the earth suck at him and release him, like a thing tasting and discarding. He didn't look behind him. He didn't want to know if anything stepped into the prints they left while they were still wet. When they broke out into the road, the light had gone wrong again. It was the kind of afternoon that you only got up here, where the sky turned to tin and then, without ever admitting to being evening, went to dark. The truck was where they'd left it. But the feel of the clearing had changed, as if the truck had been visited, spoken to, blessed or cursed. The hood was clean of leaves when it should have been littered. A strip of birch bark had been laid on the driver's side mirror, tucked in like a love note. On it, in something sticky and brown, a shape had been drawn that might have been a circle, or a moon, or an unblinking eye. "Christ," Mike said. There was no laughter in it. Their father took the bark off, careful, like taking a bandage off a wound. He stared at it without expression and then set it gently on the hood. "Get in," he said. His voice was smaller now. They did. Lang was waiting when they pulled up to the lodge. He was on the porch, not sitting, not smoking, not doing anything. Even at a distance, JT could see that his hat was gone and his hair lay flat again. "You saw it," Lang said. It wasn't a question either. He looked at JT first and then their father. His eyes slid over Mike and didn't stick. "We saw something," their father said. "You're leaving?" "I told you," Lang said. He held his hands out and then dropped them, helpless. "You should go. Tonight. I can get you as far as town before it gets... before it gets all the way up. If you stay—" "What happens if we stay?" JT asked. He surprised himself: the question came out clear. Lang looked at him in a way that made JT feel both seen and puny. "Things come to the clearing," he said. "Sometimes they look like deer. Sometimes they don't look like anything. Men forget to shoot. Men forget they had hands. You know?" He flapped his hands clumsily at the ends of his arms. "Don't let it look back at you. That's what my father told me. Don't go meeting its eyes." "It's a moon," Mike said. "It's a light in the sky." Lang didn't bother with him. He was talking to JT's father now. "I ain't walking you in past the south marsh. But I'll drive you to town. You can come back Sunday. It'll be like nothing was. You'll laugh about me." "Our father laughed about things," their father said. "Right up until he didn't." He rubbed the bridge of his nose with his finger and thumb. Then he looked at JT. He was waiting for something. He was asking. JT didn't know which answer to give, only that for once he had an answer to offer. The edges of the day pressed in. The porch boards under him felt like they were humming. "Let's go," JT said. He said it the way he'd always wanted to say something in this family and be heard: not pleading, not mocking, just simple. He expected to be ignored. He wasn't. "Okay," their father said. He nodded once. "We go." He looked at Lang. "Half an hour. We pack." Lang's shoulders dropped. Relief made him older. "Half an hour," he said. "Before moon-up." They went inside. JT went to the bunkroom and stuffed his duffel with so little thought he ended up with two socks and no underwear, with a book he hadn't opened in two years, with the photograph of the three of them on the dock that he'd kept wedged between the bed slats. He didn't remember taking it out. He didn't remember deciding to bring it. He just found his hands putting it in the bag. When he came back through the main room, the lodge looked different. The mounted caribou head over the stone fireplace was staring at the door. He knew it couldn't move. He knew the screws and bolts behind it had been set forty years ago. He knew things. But the eyes didn't have that glassy marble look they'd always had. They looked dark and flat and calm in a way that made his neck prickle. He stopped. His feet welded to the floor. In the glass of the framed map over the desk, he saw the caribou head reflected. It looked wrong in the reflection. Bigger. Closer to him than it could be. He didn't turn around. He looked at the glass instead and thought of Lang's voice: Don't let it look back at you. "JT?" His father's voice from the door, not impatient, exactly. Something else. "Coming," JT said
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This continuation of "Caribou Season at the Lodge" demonstrates remarkable skill in maintaining and developing the surreal horror atmosphere established in the prompt. The piece excels at creating a sense of creeping dread through subtle environmental details, character interactions, and the unreliable perspective of JT. The prose style successfully emulates Stephen King's approach, blending mundane realism with unsettling surrealism. Details like the wind "smearing across the shingles," the guide's hat being put on "so fast it was like he was covering a hole in his head," and the gut pile "laid out neat" create vivid, disturbing imagery without overexplaining the supernatural elements. Character development is handled with subtlety. JT's internal struggle between what he perceives and what his family would accept shows his isolation effectively. The father's character evolves interestingly - his unusual gentleness and eventual willingness to listen to JT represent a significant shift that feels earned through the mounting dread. The dialogue is sparse but authentic, capturing the terse communication style of this family. The pacing builds tension masterfully. The writer uses a series of increasingly disturbing encounters (the wind, Lang's warnings, the gut pile, the birch bark note) to escalate the sense that something is fundamentally wrong. The narrative maintains psychological ambiguity throughout - we're never certain if the supernatural elements are real or if JT's perceptions are unreliable. The ending achieves a perfect balance - providing enough resolution (the decision to leave) while maintaining the underlying horror (the mounted caribou head's apparent animation). This creates a satisfying conclusion that honors the genre's requirements. A few minor issues include occasional overuse of short, fragmented sentences that can feel slightly affected, and some metaphors that border on being too elaborate. However, these are minor concerns in an otherwise exceptional piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
