+ Fantasy-humour: Hell is Other Demons — Score: 90.2
Prompt:
Hell is Other Demons Write a day in the life short story. Lucifer morningstar's on again/ off again relationship with Lilith is currently in the "off again" stage, though the cycle may be coming around as Lilith has been stopping by for reasons other than purely violent ones, and Lucifer has been increasingly lonely. Write a day in the life of this power couple, with elements of dark comedy & fantasy. Use understated irony & absurdity by merging the black immorality and everyday business of running hell, against relatable domestic relationship drama. Take cues from Neil Gaiman. 1000 words.
Model Output:
At five, the screams begin. Lucifer lies flat on his bed and counts them like the chimes of a grandfather clock. The same hoarse chorus, the same dissonant fifth in the east gallery, the same overachieving banshee whose falsetto keeps spiking. He stares at the ceiling, where frescoed cherubs grind their teeth and avert their eyes, and thinks that routine is a quiet kind of blessing, like the world’s least romantic anniversary. He gets up, puts on the robe that was stitched from the boredom of saints, and pads barefoot to the kitchen. The floor is warm, not from any underfloor heating—Being Ultimate Evil, he refuses to be that pedestrian—but because the foundation is built on molten regret. He opens the refrigerator. It hums. He bought it from a mortal who said, conspiratorially, “It’s for wine, really,” but Lucifer keeps bottled mornings in it. He takes one down. Today’s morning is French and pastoral and tastes like dew and horses. It’s better than most mornings in Hell, where daylight is an ongoing rumor. He pours it into a chipped mug that has “World’s Best Manager” on it in friendly cursive. Someone—probably a demon with a subtle sense of humor and the ability to walk insolently through walls—left it on his desk centuries ago. He sips and looks out his window. Pipelines of molten bronze cross the horizon, pumping sin allocation meters. A flock of panic moves like mercury above the desalination pits. On the wall opposite, a portrait of him as harpsichordist in a court that never existed watches with polite disdain. Lucifer goes to work. Work is a desk in a room that changes depending on who opens the door. For him, it’s a late Roman study that never quite finished falling into disrepair. He sits, and the desk sighs. Papers arrange themselves. There’s a quarterly spreadsheet labeled “Envy,” and under it a stack of complaints about the new torments introduced in Sector 23, which allegedly smell too much like lemon pledge and not enough like despair. He signs something that possibly pertains to implementing a suggestion box. Every so often, he toys with it. He thinks of putting it near the Lake of Fire, where nobody can reach without an inconvenient swim. At eight, he meets with the Department of Ironies. They’re wearing pearls and clipboards. He leans back and steeples his fingers in a way that would make any mortal executive feel like a minor god. The head of the department, whose name at the moment is Prudence (it changes weekly to something unrelated and perfectly fitting), says, “We’re thinking of assigning a high-frequency, low-reward quest to the tyrant’s personal trainer.” “I like it,” Lucifer says. “Make him chase after his own six-pack, forever out of reach.” Prudence beams. Someone behind her snickers and writes it down. They move on to the case of the tooth fairy ring—twenty agents pretending to collect tiny enamel bribes from grown men with a lot of investments in dental floss—and whether that overlaps with Wrath. He approves three cross-departmental smitings with minor notes about tone. “Fewer trombones,” he scribbles. “We are not a municipal fall festival.” At ten-thirty, the floor shakes gently. Format: him, Lilith. He feels it not in the stone, but in the breath that comes in very carefully, like someone checking to see if he’s still home. Lucifer doesn’t turn immediately. He finishes initialing a form labeled “Surgeon Allocation: Gluttony.” Then he looks up. She’s carrying a scorched leather purse that has lost two handles to arcane incidents and perhaps one to boredom. Lilith sets it on the table and the table, which was once a tree that longed for storms, seems pleased. “Morning,” she says, which is magnanimous of her. “Morning,” he says back, trying not to drink her like the daylight he misses. Her hair is the color of old honey and newly spilled ink. Her mouth is the sort of red that shouldn’t be possible without a sacrifice. She is wearing a mortal dress, which means she has been somewhere. This makes his stomach do something human. It drops and then remembers he’s older than hunger. “I brought things,” Lilith says. Her voice is dry, like wind over a graveyard, but affectionate as the last time you climb the same swing. “Always,” he says. He means: me too, myself, my terrible habits, the rust under the gilding, the way I am happiest when you are also unhappy. They do not touch. Instead, they arrange themselves awkwardly around the purse. She opens it. The smell is an amalgam: coffee grounds, cigarettes with teenage bravado, something oceanic that might be the memory of rust. She pulls out a small snow globe. The wind inside it makes a little noise. It’s stamped with the Eiffel Tower, but the tower is crooked and inside-out, like it’s trying to be something that wasn’t designed for spheres. “Mortals,” she says. “They make tiny worlds you can control by shaking. There’s something sweet about how it doesn’t work.” He takes it. He shakes it, gently, and inside the vertical snow begins to fall upward. The tower’s shadow moves from one side to the other. Somewhere in his chest, the old old ache of choices too late and gates closing coughs politely. “Thank you,” he says, and is absurdly grateful. Lilith pulls out other things. A tarnished subway token with the letter M worn smooth. A stack of Polaroid photographs of parties with too much light in them and no one looking at the camera. A seahorse skeleton that was never alive. A small plastic bottle with a dead bee inside. “Found him on a windowsill,” she says. “He was trying. I thought of you.” “I’m honored,” Lucifer says. It’s not an insult and she knows it. They sit. They look at each other. This is usually where they fight, or kiss, or break something expensive, or all three in a sequence that implies choreography. Today, instead, Lilith taps the purse and says, “You replaced the doorknob.” “It was time,” Lucifer says, and it sounds like a confession. Across the desk are the minutes of the last meeting, where a middle manager named Balor had proposed not only that they cut the number of individualized torments by half, but that they institute a casual Friday dress code to make the place seem “more approachable.” Lucifer had listened, nodded, asked small questions. He had said no. Sometimes he’s professional. They tour Hell as if it’s an open house. They go past the Lake, which Lilith calls “our old haunt,” and he pretends not to remember the night they argued by it until one of them fell in and neither leapt immediately to rescue the other. They walk along the corridor of paperwork, where the files squeal softly and shuffle themselves, trying to make themselves look slimmer. Lilith picks up a ledger and flips through it. “You’re still using quills,” she says, not without admiration. “They burrow in better,” he answers. They pass Torture B, where the new guy is trying jangly pop music from the nineties on loop, and both of them make the face of ancient beings who would rather not have to be ancient about everything. “I can let the next soul choose his own torment?” says the demon assigned, a thin creature with the eyes of a hereditary librarian and the hands of a thief. “Fine,” Lucifer says, “as long as the choice is between two identical torments and a surprise. Let the surprise be a chair. But let the chair be made of apologies.” Lilith exhaled in that particular way she has that might, in other contexts, be called a laugh. “Still good,” she says. By noon, the rumors have already started, because Hell is a small place, like a village with no respect for privacy and an excellent baker. Beelzebub drops by under the pretense of checking on horn maintenance and tries, very casually, to see if they are back on. They are not. Not officially. The not-ness sits between them like a rescued armchair that squeaks when sat in and has one leg shorter than the others. “Did you get my memo about moths?” she asks. Lilith. Not Beelzebub. They are standing now by the Office of Occasionally Answered Prayers, which is staffed by cousins of grief. The prayers—jammed into pneumatic tubes, folded into paper boats, tattooed into skin—drift past like flocks of starlings that forgot how to turn. “Yes,” he says. “And no. I read it. I set it on fire in a way that implies ambivalence.” “Moths are very underrated. They turn up where you can’t expect them, then die like punched-out lamps.” “I’ll authorize a modest plague,” he says, and he means it. He writes “modest plague” on a note and puts it in his pocket, because sometimes he still needs to hold on to tangible things or they fly away into the high domes of Hell, where a wind like a sigh plays with cathedral webs. They eat lunch together because lunch happens whether or not anyone is hungry. It is stew of something that wanted to be a stew and didn’t quite make it. They sit with bowls, perched on stools that try to buckle, at a counter that remembers all the elbows that pounded on it in anger and all the hands that were too tired to do anything but lie flat. “How’s the mortal world?” Lucifer asks, finally, because it’s an obvious question and obvious questions have their uses. If you don’t intend to touch someone, you offer them weather. “Loud,” she says. “They’re making a lot of noise to reassure each other. New noises. Small gods of small screens. They are very devout, for a people who say otherwise.” “Devotion is devotion,” he says lightly, but he’s listening like a wolf in a museum. He can smell what’s behind words. He smells a city and a hotel room and a hand on the back of a dress and then a motel room and a hand not being there. He says, gently, “Did you find a good coffee?” She nods. This is the kind of question that sometimes saves them. “They pour it over a cone like rain. It tastes like a field trip.” They take the afternoon off from each other. She descends to the levels where old queens recite grudges and bridesmaids exchange sharp artifacts like currency. He goes to sign ten notices, three pardons (rare and carefully crafted so they don’t take), and once half a receipt that refuses. He watches a century end in a waiting room. He listens to an argument between two physicists who have discovered that infinite regret actually converges. At four, he finds her in the archive. The archive moves of its own accord, like bookshelves in bedtime stories, and occasionally refuses to give things back. She is talking to a shelf. It is listening. “Did you ever keep any of those postcards?” she asks without turning around. He doesn’t say, You know I did. Instead, he says, “Some. The ones with the sea. The ones where you wrote nothing and then later all of everything on a scrap of receipt.” She nods. She pulls a postcard out of the purse and hands it to him. It is blank. It has an address written on it in a hand he recognizes—hers, in a mood. An address that leads nowhere and everywhere. He doesn’t ask when she wrote it, or whether it’s from before or after the last time they burned down a city accidentally on purpose. At five, the screams begin to cool themselves, like a kettle forgotten. The staff starts their reports. The demons clear their throats. Hell winds down in the way that places with no time pretend to have times. He and Lilith go to stand on the balcony because there is always a balcony. It looks out on an amphitheater of souls doing something repetitive with buckets. The stars above Hell are not stars. They are holes. “We could,” he says, and stops. “Yes,” she says. It’s not an answer, but it is. They do not say: We could try again. We could pick a city. We could decide on rules we will break. We could install a lock on the inside. We could go upstairs and see if the bed likes the way we look in it now. He takes her hand. It is warm, and the warmth doesn’t diminish his. They hold hands like a compromise between a promise and a threat. “I brought one more thing,” she says, and reaches into the purse as if into the mouth of a lion that has become old and polite. She pulls out a little wooden box with sliding panels and a small brass latch. It rattles like dice. “What is it?” he asks. “It is either a music box or a trap,” she says. “Mortals love when things are both.” He opens it. It is a music box. It plays a tune that is almost, but not quite, “Greensleeves.” The mechanism inside is transparent and shows the teeth of time biting nothing. They listen. It is, somehow, worse than the screams and also better. “You can stay,” he says, finally, because he is tired. Because work will always be work, and love will always be something that looks like work from a distance. Because she came, and because she is still here. “I know,” she says. “I won’t.” Then, after a second so small it must be deliberate: “Not yet.” She kisses him, not like a flare and not like a funeral. Something in his spine unspools. Some trapped bird in the rafters becomes a shadow and flies through a hole to the non-stars. Later, after she has gone by a passage that remembers the shape of her feet, Lucifer pours another morning. This one is a Swiss morning, all cleanliness and discreet mountains. He sips. He stands in the doorway of his office and watches his demons sit with their feet up on chairs that were last week freshly designed to punish that exact posture. He thinks about the snow globe on his desk, the way the tower dissolves and reforms when shaken. He writes “modest plague” on a proper form and authorizes it. He crosses out “modest” and writes “merciful,” because he knows words have weight and it amuses him to rearrange the furniture. He looks at the hole-studded sky. He shakes the globe once, very lightly, so the snow falls from side to side. A day in Hell ends. Another begins. He is the prince of it all, and he is a man with a mug in his hand and the scent of someone else’s city on his shirt. It is absurd. It is reassuring. He goes to bed and counts the screams and tries to decide if he prefers them to silence, and the truth is he can’t, not today. Tomorrow, he thinks, he’ll replace a doorknob. Or he won’t. It depends on who knocks. It depends on what she brings out of her bag next time, and what part of himself he is willing to set on fire to keep warm.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of Neil Gaiman's style with its blend of the mundane and the fantastical, creating a Hell that feels both bureaucratic and mythic. The relationship between Lucifer and Lilith is rendered with nuance and understated emotion, avoiding melodrama while still conveying their complex history. The prose is particularly strong, with inventive metaphors and descriptions that make Hell feel simultaneously alien and familiar. Lines like "a flock of panic moves like mercury above the desalination pits" and "the foundation is built on molten regret" create vivid imagery while maintaining the dark comedy tone requested in the prompt. The writer excels at showing the relationship dynamics through small gestures and loaded silences rather than exposition. The exchange of gifts, particularly the snow globe and music box, serves as effective metaphors for their relationship—beautiful but contained, potentially dangerous, and slightly broken. The bureaucratic elements of Hell are handled with dry wit—the "World's Best Manager" mug, the department meetings about torments, and the casual Friday proposal all create the requested ironic contrast between the infernal and the mundane. The writer has successfully merged "black immorality and everyday business" as requested. The dialogue is sparse but effective, with subtext doing much of the heavy lifting. Lines like "I know," she says. "I won't." Then, after a second so small it must be deliberate: "Not yet" convey volumes about their relationship status. Where the piece could be stronger is in its narrative arc. While beautifully written, it meanders somewhat through the day without a strong central conflict or resolution. The "on again/off again" dynamic is well-established, but we don't see much movement in their relationship status by the end—they remain in a holding pattern. This may be intentional to show the cyclical nature of their relationship, but it somewhat limits the emotional impact. Some of the metaphors, while creative, occasionally border on purple prose. Phrases like "the rust under the gilding, the way I am happiest when you are also unhappy" and "the old old ache of choices too late and gates closing coughs politely" are evocative but occasionally feel slightly overwrought. Overall, this is an accomplished piece that successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements. It creates a distinctive world with memorable characters and maintains the requested tone throughout. The writing is elegant and imaginative, with only minor issues that don't significantly detract from its quality. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 92.0
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
They woke us before the sun rose, when the world still smelled of ashes and last night’s wine. The lanista’s runner clattered a stick along the bars, and the bronze rasp on iron snapped us from sleep. My eyes opened to the dim glow of the embers in the brazier across the corridor, a haze of smoke lingering against the ceiling like a stubborn memory. Felix on the pallet next to mine turned over and muttered a curse to the household gods. He crossed himself not like a legionary but with two fingers to his lips and his heart, a gesture he swore was Etruscan, passed down from a grandfather who thrice spit before putting a foot into any arena. I pushed my blanket aside and planted my feet on the grit-strewn floor. The stone held the night’s cold. I rubbed my forearms to wake them, tracing with my thumb the raised seam of a scar along the radius. The bread yesterday had been stale and full of grit, the kind that squeaked against your teeth as you chewed. It still lived under my tongue. The kennel smell of men hung heavy in the cell, steeped into straw and sweat and oil. A soft padding came from the corner where the old dog that had adopted our ludus licked a paw, the rhythm as steady as a metronome. In another room someone retched, the sound hollow and unashamed. Before I stood, I performed the small thing I had made of my own. I kept a sliver of olive wood in my bag, shaved from the last tree I climbed as a boy before my family sold me and the city swallowed my name. Every morning before drills or a match, I took the sliver in my right palm, touched it to my left shoulder, my right shoulder, then my forehead, and then pressed it to the floor, to earth, to remind myself of the dirt that had known my bare feet. Superstition wears a man thin or keeps him whole. I could never say which, only that without these gestures the world seemed to tilt. We filed out, the morning cool in the courtyard, the sky a bruised purple behind the alley walls. Across our compound, the top of the amphitheater peered over the rooftops like the shell of some massive beast. Rome always felt like that to me, a colossus squatting over itself, marble plastered over brick and brick over whatever bones had come before. The street beyond our walls woke the way old men wake, slowly and with complaint. Donkeys brayed; someone argued about a loaf; a servant swept a threshold with short, angry strokes that sent dust motes spinning like gnats in a shaft of coming light. The lanista, Hanno of Carthage, stood at the well, his arms crossed over the girth of his chest, an old sword-scar pulling his lip into a permanent sneer. He wore his wool cloak even in summer, as if he didn’t trust the air itself not to trick him. “Water,” he said, the word falling on us like an order, though it was only that. We dunked our cups and drank, the metallic taste of the bucket mingling with the cold sweetness that made our teeth ache. My stomach stood up and began to take the world seriously. Training would not start until the sun lifted over the insulae, but the morning chores belonged to those of us not slated for private lessons. I drew straw from the cart and spread it cleanly in the kennels where the hounds slept. Their eyes watched me with animal loyalty and animal indifference. Felix carried oil jars to the storeroom, his steps cautious because oil cost more than a man. In the kitchen, Smyrna the cook reached for cumin and salt without looking, the way a soldier reaches for the hilt. Her cat wound itself around her ankles and hissed at anyone who brushed too close. The smell of the kitchen was a miracle: garlic, the rich scent of lamb bones boiled until they surrendered their marrow, the sharp drift of vinegar. Smyrna slapped my hand away when it hovered over a fig. “You’ll fight heavier if you steal,” she said, not unkindly. She tilted her chin toward the courtyard. “They say Germanicus won’t live to winter.” “Germanicus?” I had heard the rumor in whispers the day before, but in a family like ours news metastasized into truth by repetition. “They say,” she said, which meant someone’s cousin heard it from a man in the market who heard it from a man who scrubbed the steps of the Palatine. In our world, the Empire was a series of doors behind which you could hear laughter, never sure whose. Germanicus was popular, a name that rolled off the tongues of sellers like honey. Tiberius had shadows behind his eyes, and the people liked gods without shadows. Rome’s mood is a thing even the lowest feels. It trickles into you the way smoke does. It sticks to your hair and you carry it into bed. Hanno had us do footwork until the muscle in my calves felt like rope. The wooden swords were heavy and chewed the palm unless you oiled them. The clangour of wood striking wood rose in the air, a drumbeat that echoed between the walls. The smell was sweat and oil, leather and patience. Beyond the wall a poet recited to a group of men who were not listening, his voice drifting over half lines—“arms and a man”—and then the cackle of the crowd when a cart hit a pothole and spilled apples, red and green rolling in a pattern that made me think of a wound. By midmorning, patrons began to arrive. The ludus had become fashionable again since the latest edict about the customs tax slid like a knife under the ribs of the merchants. They came to see something they could afford, to prove to themselves that there was still spectacle for them, and the more they watched us sweat and bleed, the more it felt like their coin bought dominion. A senator’s boy with a cloak so white it offended my eyes tried to spit between his front teeth and managed only to drool. His father, small and sharp like a fox, murmured that if his son was to be a man he must learn to love the sound a bone made when it broke. Hanno smiled the smile he used for the rich, the one that meant he forgave them the fact that they were not like us. When I finished a series of lunges, the medicus caught my eye and flat-palmed a bandage at me. “Your wrist,” he said. “You brace it or you’ll never lift your cudgel again.” He was from Bithynia—or so he told us—and dressed like a scholar even in the heat, his hair slicked with oil and combed back hard. He believed in phlegm and bile and the balance of humors; I believed in waking and sleeping and muscles that spoke. After, I sat on the edge of the fountain and wrapped my wrist tight, the linen rough but clean. Felix plopped beside me, sweating like a roasting pig, and slapped his hands on his knees. “They say—” he started. “They always say.” He smiled and leaned forward, a boy’s mischief flashing across a man’s broken face. “They say the Prefect wants more blood. The people have not cheered loud enough. He came himself last week to the editor and said the city needs a river of red to wash its ears clean.” “It rains taxes,” I said. “They want the streets to run with something they can afford to see.” Felix picked at the scab on his elbow, then stopped, superstition catching him. “I spit three times before I step onto the sand,” he said, unprompted, as if just saying it kept us safe. “I know,” I said. His spit hit the ground, the ritual intact, improper to waste. He had the same gestures before a fight: he kissed his dagger’s pommel, whispered his sister’s name, and touched the scar on his chin with his ring finger. We were a museum of other men’s beliefs layered over our own. At night we would watch each other in the dim light and say the names of the little gods under our breath: Successus, Fortuna, Nemesis. We pretended we could pick which came. Hanno called me inside, away from the young patrons and the stink of their perfumes. Through the lattice I could see the street swelling like a vein. A woman with a basket of eggs walked with the careful gait of someone who had nothing to spare. The sun had broken over the rooftops and turned the air to brass. The Forum was in the distance, a bright cut in the rock of the city. Someone had scrawled a new graffito on our wall: a crude caricature of a magistrate with donkey ears. Beneath: Roma ridet. Rome laughs. Rome always laughs, at itself, at us. Inside were the armor racks, the metal echoes chime-soft, the furs hung to dry, the smell of polish and steel and old blood. I ran my hands over the crests and helms, feeling the dents, the history of each mark. My own helmet was plain, the brow band rubbing a bald stripe along the scalp to remind a man not to imagine himself too beautiful. I picked up the manica, the arm-guard, and turned it in the light. My reflection skimmed across it and slid off. For a moment the face felt like someone else’s, a man I might have been if I had not stepped through the door the day the slaver put his hand on my shoulder and appraised me like grain. A murmur rippled in from outside, a sound like bees but heavier. I stepped to the lattice again and watched a procession forming on the street. Men in dark togas, the flamine in their hats like inverted bowls, incense braziers smoking thick, a boy carrying a laurel branch. The smell of pine resin and human breath came first. A woman at a window above threw down petals and laughed, and the petals stuck to the sweat on a soldier’s neck. “Do you know,” Hanno said behind me, “what happens when the city starts to praise men who are not emperors?” “They lose their heads,” I said. “They all do,” he said, with a shrug that was not quite a joke. “Some in the street, some in their dreams.” He said the word emperor with the careful neutrality that meant he had lived under more than one. I thought of my father, how he had stared at the pile of debt notes on our table, the wax seals like hard berries. He had not sold me because I was his least favorite. He had sold me because Rome wants what Rome wants and the rest of us rearrange ourselves to accommodate. I did not see his face the day I stood at the block because I kept my eyes on the shadow of the man behind me. I remember the auctioneer’s chant, the way it sped up and slowed like the heartbeat of a hare: Who will—who will—who will—? Sometimes at night, when the others slept, Felix snored and the dog drummed its tail, I would lie and listen to the city, to the fight between cat and rat, to the late carts that groaned under amphorae, to the laugh of men who drank their lives thin in wineshops. I would picture the map of the empire on Hanno’s office wall, the provinces in chalk and the sea like a great blue-inked eye, and I would think: we are a small thing in a huge mouth, and the teeth grind down, and sometimes we gleam because we are wet. By noon the heat swelled until the courtyard stones seemed to breathe. We ate that day but lightly, barley cooked with onions and a sliver of pork fat floating among the grains like a promise. Smyrna gave me a fig at last, soft and splitting, the seeds crunching under my teeth like a sound from childhood. I licked the sweet from my thumb and closed my eyes. For a breath, I was sitting under that olive tree, the sliver not yet shaved, the bark rough under my back. For a breath, my chest unknotted itself. After the meal, I oiled my skin, the sheen like a second layer that kept my flesh from splitting under the sun. The oil smelled of olives and the faint ghost of the man who pressed them, his hands the same size as mine. The medicus checked my bindings again, grunted approval. Felix nudged me with his shoulder. “Tonight,” he said. “Not today.” Our next match was the morrow. Today the arena hosted venationes, the hunts. We could already hear the crowd’s rising voice, hear the roar as if a god had cleared his throat. The beasts would die, their smell carried in on the wind: hair, fear, dung, iron. I took the olive sliver from my bag once more in the afternoon, not because it was required but because the day demanded it. I touched it to shoulder, shoulder, head, floor. “Earth,” I whispered. I did not know whether I addressed a goddess or a memory or a boy in a field. It did not matter. Rome eats and Rome sings and Rome weeps, and somewhere a senator decides to clap or not because it pleases him, and somewhere a woman counts coins and decides whether she will buy a loaf or oil, and somewhere a soldier in Germania writes a letter and hopes it will not be intercepted by snow. And here, in a courtyard where the sun burns the same way it did on a different continent, I bound my hands and leaned my forehead against cool stone and waited for something to happen that would prove I was not alone. In the afternoon Hanno took me aside again and spoke of offers. A cavalryman of the Praetorians had left a name with our steward, a man who liked the way I moved and wished to patronize a fight, to see me wield a heavier weapon for spectacle. He had friends and a villa outside of the city and a bridge built with funds that were not his but held his name. “They will want you to lose or to win,” Hanno said. “They will want to pretend they decide. They like to buy fate by the amphora and drink it with watered wine.” “Do they think fate takes coin?” I asked. “Everything else does,” he said. He was not bitter. He was pragmatic the way a fisherman is pragmatic about the tide. “You will do as I say,” he added, but still looked at me as if asking whether I would follow. There is always that moment. It is the only place we are free. I nodded. He went away satisfied. I turned to the wall, to the new graffito, and traced the donkey ears with my eyes. The city laughed. The city shook its shoulders. A pigeon dropped from the roof and strutted, idiot proud, of the few crumbs he had found. Beyond the wall the crowd screamed and then settled, the sound rolling over us like surf. Felix spat three times, just in case. The smell of lion hit us, rank and sharp, and I imagined the beast’s breath, hot as a forge. The sun slid, inch by inch, down the wall. The olive sliver warmed in my pocket like a live thing. Somewhere in an upper room a man with a ring on every finger made a mark on a wax tablet that would mean a tunic or a tomb for someone like me. Somewhere a boy practiced the phrase Ave, Caesar, as if the words themselves had flavor and a person could live off them. I watched the light and the dust in the light and the flies make their hieroglyphs in the air. I sat very still and felt my sinews sing with tiredness and a small, complicated hope. The dog came and laid its head on my foot. I bent and scratched the thick fur behind its ears. It sighed and settled, and for a moment the city quieted, as if it had inhaled and held its breath. Then the cheer rose again, high and thin, the sound of people trying to forget their taxes and their hunger and the news that tomorrow would taste too much like today. I rested my hand on the dog’s head and thought of the field, the first footfall on sand, the first breath of a crowd, the first time I’d understood that a man’s body could be both his cage and his escape. I thought of the olive wood under my fingers, the dry rasp of it against my skin, and I breathed in the smells of Rome—wine and smoke and blood and piss and bread and metal and olives—and waited for the sun to finish falling.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This historical fiction piece offers a richly detailed glimpse into the life of a Roman gladiator, successfully adhering to the prompt's requirements. The author has created an immersive first-person narrative that captures the sensory experience of ancient Rome with remarkable precision and authenticity. The piece excels in its sensory descriptions, bringing to life the sights, sounds, and smells of the gladiatorial ludus and the surrounding city. From the "kennel smell of men" to the "metallic taste of the bucket mingling with the cold sweetness" of water, the author creates a vivid sensory landscape. The descriptions of Rome itself—"a colossus squatting over itself, marble plastered over brick and brick over whatever bones had come before"—demonstrate sophisticated imagery that enhances the historical setting. The protagonist is well-developed, with personal rituals, memories, and reflections that reveal his inner life. The olive wood sliver serves as both a tangible connection to his past and a symbolic representation of his identity. His observations about Rome's social hierarchy and his place within it demonstrate the political awareness requested in the prompt. The prose is elegant and often lyrical without becoming overwrought. Sentences like "Rome eats and Rome sings and Rome weeps" employ effective repetition, and metaphors such as "we are a small thing in a huge mouth, and the teeth grind down" are powerful without being excessive. The author skillfully balances poetic language with more straightforward narration. The piece effectively incorporates the larger political and social context of imperial Rome. References to Germanicus, Tiberius, taxes, and the relationship between spectacle and power create a sense of the protagonist existing within a complex political reality. The gladiator's awareness of his position—"Rome wants what Rome wants and the rest of us rearrange ourselves to accommodate"—shows how personal experience intersects with broader social structures. The narrative maintains a consistent voice and tone throughout, with the protagonist's resigned yet observant perspective guiding the reader through his day. The flow between external observations and internal reflections feels natural and unforced. While there are no significant weaknesses, the piece occasionally risks becoming slightly meandering in its observations. However, this meandering quality actually serves the "slice of life" approach requested in the prompt, mimicking the way a person's thoughts might wander through their day. The ending effectively brings the narrative full circle, returning to the olive wood sliver and the sensory experience of Rome, creating a sense of completion while still feeling like part of a larger story. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 84.8
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Telegram from: Alistair MacRae, Wick station To: Mrs. Isla MacRae, 4 Burnside, Port Mhairi Dated: 14 March 1957 ARRIVED WICK STOP REPORT TO BOARD OFFICE STOP SCHEDULED FOR SKERRAN LIGHT KEEPING THREE MONTHS STARTING 18TH STOP WILL WRITE PROPER WHEN STEADIED STOP LOVE A Letter from: Alistair, c/o Northern Lighthouse Board, Wick To: Ma Dated: 16 March 1957 Ma, They put me in a room above the harbor, you’d laugh. The bed is short and the window leans, and the gulls boil outside like some old woman’s wash. Skerran is a wick of rock three miles out. Boat goes out Sunday if the swell behaves. I did what you said and kept my mouth shut in front of the Board men. They looked like undertakers, all solemn. One asked if I took whisky; I told him no, and for once I wasn’t lying. There’s no point testing your foot on ice until you’re over it. I met the Principal Keeper, name of McKendrick. He’s got a moustache that could sweep a floor. Said he’s been on Skerran “since before your mother fancied your da”. I kept my face straight. He’ll be my superior out there. He has hands like rope and a way of speaking like he’s counting. He says the light is a Chance Brothers, four panels, needs tending every four hours. The paraffin for the lamp is stored below. He warned me about condensation — “the glass sweats all the time, you’ll see” — and the iron stairs freezing in a haar. Made me think of your washing turned into boards on the line in winter. I have not told him I cannot swim. No need to write back and scold. I won’t be daft. If you see Callum, tell him I’ll keep his knife safe. I’m taking it for luck. I can hear you now: “Luck won’t get a lens polished.” Aye, so I’ve packed rags, too. I’ll write when we’re out. Don’t worry yourself to death. Keep the fire. A. Letter from: Alistair, Skerran Lighthouse To: Ma Dated: 23 March 1957 Ma, The stairs will do for me yet. I can feel them in my bones when I lie down — iron, round and round. McKendrick calls them “the rib,” and that’s right. This place is a gut we slide up and down all day. We arrived two days ago. The sea is a wall on all sides. There’s a slab of rock like an altar where the boat lays off and we run a line, and then we haul the stores in a basket like fish. I thought of mass in Port Mhairi, the incense, the swish of the priest’s robe — how far away it seems. There’s no wireless. The Board says it’s coming, but then, the Board says a lot. The lamp drinks paraffin like a man straight off the mines. We polish the lens until our faces show up in it, bent and green. The glass sweats just as McKendrick said. It drips on your head if you stand under it too long. He says the salt gets in everything — it’s true. Bread is salt. Blankets are salt. Even the pennies in my pocket taste of it. The light turns with a clockwork weight. Every four hours we wind it, and if you forget you hear the rotation slow and then you see the dark come back, which is a feeling I hope never to have again. There is a bull on the rock. Not a beast, an air horn — “the bull,” he calls it — that groans out into the weather so ships know we’re here even when the light cannot fight the fog. My first night, the fog came like wool. The bull went and went, and I felt the sound in my teeth. But no ship hit the rocks. So. You always said I was too daft to sit still. Here that’s all there is when the jobs are done: sit and listen to the wind. I know, Ma: it’s money. It’s honest. But the edges of yourself go to feather with the quiet. I talk aloud sometimes. Don’t tell the priest. I must go. The glass wants me. McKendrick has all the words in the world for oil and wicks, but little else. He sang a bar of “Loch Lomond” and stopped. I wanted to ask him to finish it. I don’t know why I didn’t. Maybe the emptiness eats up the tune. Tell me about your rhubarb. Tell me if Mrs. Gordon’s wee cat had her kittens. I crave the small. A. Postcard from: Ma, Port Mhairi To: Alistair, Skerran Lighthouse via Wick Alistair, The kittens were dead (do not be sorry it is the way). The rhubarb is up like soldiers. Your uncle said he saw you go out in the Board boat and you looked green as a pea. He is no judge. Mrs. MacLeod’s Jock fell off the pier drunk again and only the tide going out saved him as he lay in the wrack with his mouth open like a fish. Don’t you be like him. The priest says to keep you in my prayers so I do. Eat. Ma Letter from: Alistair, Skerran To: Ma Dated: 10 April 1957 Ma, Your letter made me laugh and then the laugh turned into something else for a second and then I went and wound the weight early. That’s the trick, I’m learning: find a job when your insides start to talk too loud. We had a nor’easter two nights ago. The tower moved. Not in your head — you can feel it. It’s meant to, McKendrick says, the way a tree bends. He has names for all the winds. He quotes them like neighbours: “That’s the one comes round with a sack over his shoulder,” and he makes a face, and you can see him as a boy on some different rock. That’s the moment I see him as a person and not just the moustache and the rules. We cleaned the cabbage last and it’s starting to stink sweet. Rats have not always found a way onto Skerran. That’s a sentence I never thought I’d write to you. I sleep with a bit of cold iron across my chest some nights — Callum’s knife — like I’m warding off fairies. You were right about the cat — doesn’t matter that it’s dead, you’ll still put a saucer out. I burned my thumb on the lamp and the skin went white and then pink. Nothing to write the Board about. I know what you’re thinking: he should have been a joiner under a roof. Well it’s this instead. Don’t start with me in a letter I can’t answer for a week. Tell me who danced the last reel at the hall. Even if it was you. Especially if it was you. A. Letter from: Ma, Port Mhairi To: Alistair, Skerran (Wick to forward) Dated: 18 April 1957 Alistair, It was me. Mrs. MacLeod said, Isla you cannot dance with those knees, and I told her they are my knees and I’ll do what I damn please. Father James frowned like a rain cloud and then smiled when he thought I was not looking. There is mackerel like silver at the quay and your cousin Effie says she will not gut the ones that look at her. I told her, they all look at you if you keep their heads on. We laughed till we needed chairs. I made the bannocks you like and ate one hot with jam and nearly called out to you, which is nonsense. So I put the rest in a tin and took them to Mrs. Gordon. Don’t be lonely like a fool. If the light wants polishing, polish it and think of my floor. The Board won’t come and tell me I did it wrong. Ma Letter from: Alistair, Skerran To: Ma Dated: 2 May 1957 Ma, McKendrick’s moustache froze yesterday. We had a haar that slid up from the water and into the stair and then right into our mouths if you opened them. He came up with a scarf over his face like a robber. He says you can tell the time by the fog. He means he can. He’s been head on Skerran twenty-six years. There’s a mark on the oak table from where a lightning strike danced out through the cutlery. He taps it sometimes when he speaks. I don’t think he knows he’s doing it. I thought of Da last night, which I don’t often do without swearing. The light circled me while I sat in the watch chair. The chair is old and hard and perfect for a person who wants to be told what to do by wood. Around and around the light went, and it felt like the room was ship, not shore, and everything was moving except me. Da would have said, “That’s enough of that,” and poured something over it. I’m not pouring. I dreamed I forgot to wind and the dark came. In the dream I could hear voices on the water. In the morning I wound it twice. McKendrick says there’s a relief boat next week, and he’s going to have me go ashore for two nights, “to remember what a bed feels like that doesn’t turn.” I was glad and then angry with myself for being glad. I wrote that and then decided to leave it. I’m not a boy. A. Telegram from: Northern Lighthouse Board, Wick To: Skerran Light RELIEF BOAT DELAYED STOP WEATHER UNSAFE STOP NEXT WINDOW 10 MAY STOP HOLD FAST Letter from: Alistair, Skerran To: Ma Dated: 11 May 1957 Ma, Ten May came and went with a wall of white water. It tilted up like a roof and slid down into itself. Even the bull sounded small. McKendrick and I ate the last of the potatoes without cutting the eyes out, which he says invites bad luck, but what does he call this? He went quiet and sat on his bunk an hour, then he scrubbed the sink like it had insulted him. See, people are the same as people anywhere. You were right to send me with the extra sack of oatmeal. I can hear your voice: “Always take more.” It’s a thing you say when you’ve never had enough. The wind stopped all at once last night and in the silence something crept in, and for a half-breath I expected you to call me for my tea. Then there was a cry out in the black. Not a bird. A human. We looked at each other once, like boys about to be told to fight, and then we were moving. McKendrick went down to the landing like a man and I to the watch with the lamp. I ran the shutter off the lantern and pointed it, but it’s a spread thing, not a finger. The cry came again, higher. We threw a line. It fell short. I could taste the iron — fear and blood. The cry came a third time and then nothing. The bull called and called. There were no voices on the water after that, dream or not. The sea keeps. I stood beside the lens until my legs shook and my hands had no work to do and I wanted to smash something. I did not. This morning there’s a plank on the outer slope with a bolt through it. We got it with the gaff. The Board will say to write it in the book and that will be the end of it. I know that’s the job. I’m writing it to you as well. I hear your breath, steady. I’m all right. We did what can be done. A. Letter from: Ma, Port Mhairi To: Alistair, Skerran Dated: 15 May 1957 Alistair, There is a wake in the next street for a man without a face. They found him by Okay’s Point, the little bit with the yellow sand. He had a wedding ring on and the rest the tide took. Mrs. Fraser washed his shirt and said it would not come clean and Mr. Fraser said, We will cover it then. The priest says to pray for all souls in peril on the sea. You did not put him there. You shone your light and you threw your rope. I will say this twice so you hear me. Your Uncle Iain says the Board should send you boys radios. He says he wrote to the paper. I told him not to put his name or they’d send him a job. Put the rope away proper so the other man is not tangled by it. And mind your thumb. Ma Letter from: Alistair, Skerran To: Ma Dated: 30 May 1957 Ma, They came at last, midweek. The boat sat like a doctor at the foot of the bed and would not come any closer than the outer ledge for fear of being smashed. We ran the basket and sent down our empty tins and the smell of us, then the casks up. McKendrick wouldn’t look at the Board man and I was glad of him for it. He asked for a wireless again. The Board man said, “Soon.” The word is a lie that doesn’t know it is a lie. I would prefer “No.” I did not go ashore. He did. He looked at me as he stepped into the basket — such a quick look, like a hand on your shoulder — and I felt a wave of relief so strong I was ashamed. I watched the boat go until the sea sat on it and there was just the bull and the sky again. That night I wound and wound, and I ate standing up, and I slept with my boots by my hands. The fog came in twice. I heard a ship’s engine far off. I thought of the man without a face. I thought I could smell the dye from his shirt. I took the lens cloth and worked, and when the light turned and made the room like daylight and then dark and then daylight again my head matched it. I wish I could say I am brave, but really it is this: there is no one else here to be the other thing. I read the almanac. I traced the map with my finger. Skerran is a dot so small you could lose it if you shook the page. I am not a dot, Ma. Don’t you make me one. A. Letter from: Ma, Port Mhairi To: Alistair, Skerran Dated: 6 June 1957 Alistair, You are a line that reaches from this house to that rock and back again, and you are not a dot. I went to the post and told Mairi to put that on a stamp and she told me stamps are the Queen only and I said, “I’ll draw a crown then.” She laughed and I felt ten years back in the legs. The ewes have started worrying at the fence like they know something I don’t. The children all ran to the quay when the trawler came in with the blue flags and Mrs. MacLeod’s Jock tried to sing but only the first line came. That’s how grief sits. You do the first bit and the other bits won’t come. There is a boy of twelve at the back house who wants to be you. I told him he could be a hundred things and he said, “If I’m one of them I want to be a light.” It went inside me something fierce. Don’t turn to stone there. If you feel like it, write me with the exacting of your day. How many steps. How long to wind. How many turns to a full weight. I like to know. Ma Letter from: Alistair, Skerran To: Ma Dated: 10 June 1957 Ma, 182 steps. Thirty-two to the first landing, then thirty, then twenty-eight, then twenty-six, then sixteen to the watchroom, then ten to the lantern. The weight drops in five hours if you don’t stop it, four if there’s a hard wind and the mechanism hums faster. I wind for twelve minutes to take it to the top. The handle is cold in the morning and warm by midnight. When you do it your heartrun finds the rhythm. If I close my eyes I could tell where the weight sits by where my breath is when it kicks. Does that make sense? There’s comfort in doing it right and knowing it. The wick needs trimming like a head needs a shave. If the char builds it smokes and leaves ghosts on the glass, and then the light isn’t light, it’s sepia and shame. The bull is hand-pumped. Think of that. All this and we still put our backs into it to make a noise, like we’re hauling an old engine up a hill. I pump, and the sound goes away from me and comes back and goes away, and I think of you sitting in the chair with your toes on the fender and the ticking of the clock, and how the sound goes away and comes back there, too. You asked me to tell you the exacting. I’ve kept the book like a lover. The truth is the exacting keeps me from feeling like I’m spread too thin over the water. It’s a way of living inside an edge. I found a gull with the wing broke on the lower step and I wrung its neck. I did it clean. I learned something from Da we can keep. I put it out myself. After, I boiled the kettle and couldn’t drink the tea. A. Letter from: Ma, Port Mhairi To: Alistair, Skerran Dated: 20 June 1957 Alistair, That made me put the kettle down too for a moment. I am sorry for the gull and glad for you. Do not make a habit of that tea. Your Auntie Màiri sent a loaf and forgot the salt. It tasted like the floor of the church and made your Uncle swear in Gaelic so the priest would not know the words. The priest knows all the words. He knows the ones we don’t. The Board posted for two new lads for the lights and there is talk in the shop that it means more retirements. Your Principal will go sometime, I suppose. What will he be if he is not what he is? I suppose that is everyone’s question when you scrape under the skin. Everyone says thank you to you when they don’t even know.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative effectively captures the isolation and psychological challenges of a lighthouse keeper through a series of letters between Alistair and his mother. The piece successfully establishes distinct voices for both characters - Alistair's increasingly introspective and detailed accounts contrast with his mother's practical, terse responses that still convey deep care. The Scottish working-class background is convincingly portrayed through dialect choices, references to local customs, and the practical concerns that dominate their correspondence. The author skillfully develops Alistair's character through his observations about the lighthouse, his relationship with McKendrick, and his psychological responses to isolation. His mother's character emerges through her practical advice, community updates, and understated emotional support. The narrative builds tension effectively through the incident with the drowning man, which serves as an emotional climax that tests Alistair's resolve. The correspondence reveals his growth from initial uncertainty to a kind of stoic acceptance of his responsibilities. The prose is particularly strong in sensory details that bring the lighthouse environment to life - the salt that permeates everything, the mechanical rhythms of maintaining the light, the sounds of the "bull" horn in the fog. However, the piece feels incomplete. The narrative builds effectively but lacks a satisfying resolution as requested in the prompt. The final letters don't provide closure to Alistair's emotional journey or the relationship with McKendrick. The story simply trails off rather than concluding. Additionally, while the voices are distinct, the mother's letters sometimes feel slightly inconsistent in their level of eloquence versus practicality. The writing avoids clichés admirably and creates authentic characters whose relationship feels genuine. The details about lighthouse keeping appear well-researched and contribute to the story's authenticity. The emotional undercurrents - particularly Alistair's complex feelings about his absent father and his growing sense of purpose - are handled with subtlety. Overall, this is a strong piece that effectively uses the epistolary format to reveal character and build a narrative, though it falls short of providing the satisfying resolution requested in the prompt. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 16 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 16 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 3 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17

+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 90.5
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I pick the corner booth because it gives me sightlines: the hostess stand, the bar, the two exits, the restroom corridor like a buffer overflow waiting to be triggered. The overhead Wi-Fi SSID blinks in my periphery—Restaurant-Guest, open network, no captive portal—and I press my hands flat to the table like I’m holding them down. Breathe. Human connection. Focus on the person about to walk in, not the misconfigured Sonos speaker that’s broadcasting its default hostname or the POS terminal that still runs a Windows theme so old I can hear the security advisories groaning from it. She texts that she’s parking. The bubble pops up blue on my lock screen—iMessage, okay, E2E—and for a second I wonder if her device broadcasts random MAC addresses or if I’ll see a stable one join the network and match the time she walks through the door. I lock my phone and turn it face down like a man trying to choose a better life. When she steps inside, it’s like opening a hand you didn’t realize was clenched. Denim jacket, hair in a half-bun that says she knows what it’s like to fix things without making a big deal about it. She catches my eye and smiles, and I don’t even audit the gesture for authenticity because it feels like sunlight after a patch Tuesday. She slides into the booth opposite me and keeps kinetic energy in her hands—tapping the edge of the menu, then smoothing the paper like it’s a bed someone else slept in. “I’m Nia,” she says, even though we both know. Saying it out loud is handshake protocol. I like that. We ping. We establish latency. We both comment on the tasteful ambient noise. She doesn’t comment on the Wi-Fi. It’s fine. Not everyone walks into a place and sees traffic sniffing in their head. “How’s your day?” she asks. I open my mouth to say good and actually mean it. By the time the waiter appears, we’ve agreed bread is just denial dressed in crust. It arrives anyway, olive oil shimmering like a lure. I choose salad and something with a sauce that likes white shirts, then realize my shirt is black because some part of me still prefers armor. She orders pasta and laughs when the waiter warns her about garlic. Her laugh is not a replay. It’s not something I’ve heard a hundred times on loop. It’s a live stream. The conversation finds the middle lane, easy enough. Work, the sanitized version. I say I do security consulting, which is like saying an ex-smoker chews gum. She does data science for a nonprofit, which means she probably knows how to clean things that are fundamentally dirty. We hit podcast overlap. Then we slide sideways into it. Magic comes out of my mouth like a testing payload I didn’t intend to send. “Did you ever play Magic?” I ask, consequence analysis returning a healthy potential for both connection and cringe. Her eyes light up. It’s not sunlight, it’s LED string lights at a Friday Night Magic table. “Oh god, yes. Still do. My friends and I draft weird sets and pretend we know how to evaluate signals.” It’s startling, the reflex, how fast my brain throws a port open and accepts the connection. Shared fandom is a patch I didn’t know I needed. I feel my posture shift into comfortable. We start naming cards like passwords. She tells me her first deck was a janky mono-Red burn pile. “Goblin Guide,” she says, and I mentally file: Aggro instincts, willingness to reveal information to go faster. “Lightning Bolt,” obviously. “Price of Progress,” she adds, and that tells me she likes to punish greed. She’s not above watching others choke on their multi-colored ambitions. She switches to talking about the time she went through a phase where she thought she was a control player but was lying to herself. “I tried Esper Control,” she says. In my head I slot in “Cryptic Command,” “Supreme Verdict,” and the personality trait of wanting to reset everything when it gets messy. “Sphinx’s Revelation,” she admits, and I hear restlessness under the card draw. Recharge as remedy. We test each other. “I had a thing for Birthing Pod,” I say, and watch her face as she calibrates. Does she think I like decision trees? Tournament seeds? “That checks out,” she says, and I feel seen by a green artifact. We smuggle in a little personal with each mention. She name-drops “Thoughtseize” like a confession. Willing to trade a little life for knowledge. Willing to pierce the veil. I throw back “Tarmogoyf” in a self-deprecating way, like I think I’m bigger than I am because the graveyard’s already full. She laughs. Connection gets a deeper root. Every card is a fingerprint. She had a “Splinter Twin” phase, which means she likes inevitability as much as trickery. She moved away from it when it got stale, aka when winning felt too deterministic. “I like the puzzle,” she says. “I don’t like the answer key.” I file that under: Build your own locks, then pick them. She mentions “Aether Vial” with reverence and my brain goes file system: low-curve creatures, flash in value, cheat on timing. “Snapcaster Mage,” she says casually, and I think resource recursion and a refusal to let mistakes be permanent. The cards she doesn’t name are telling too; no “Emrakul,” no big stompy timmy. She likes tempo, not bludgeons. Our drinks arrive and the waiter asks if we want apps. I want to ask if he knows his POS is calling out to a known malware domain. I order bruschetta like a normal person. I am calculating probabilities when she slips her phone from her jacket pocket to check a message. It’s nothing: a lock screen glow, a mild frown at a notification from a group chat with a dumb name. She pretends she’s not reading it and then decides to just read it. The phone is in her hand like a deck you truly know. It’s rotation tested. And then she unlocks it. It’s an Android, Pixel maybe two generations old, with a tempered glass screen that is pristine except for the micro-sheen of finger oils. She swipes up and her finger traces a pattern on the nine-dot grid like water finding the same channel it always has. Even before she completes it I can reconstruct it from the vector of her wrist and the micro-hesitations at corners: top-left to top-middle to top-right, down to middle-right, to bottom-right then across to bottom-left; a lazy “U” with an unnecessary flourish back to middle-left. It’s common. It’s k-means cluster number three in the research I wish I’d never read. It’s in the top 5% of guessable patterns. The overlay of her movements and the faint smudge path is a neon sign for any bus stop thief with a little patience. I also notice she didn’t lift her finger between nodes—a continuous trace, timeline reconstructable. Heat-map hazard. I realize I’ve leaned forward like a dog hearing a high frequency. I make the sound a throat makes when it’s trying not to bark. She looks up, sees my face, and something in her posture shifts a half-inch toward caution. “What?” she asks, and I’ve been here before. Tiny bridges with big holes under them. There’s an off-ramp. I can say nothing. I can drink water. I can smile and ask about her siblings. Human connection, not root access. “The, uh,” I say, and there it is—the payload leaves my mouth. “Your unlock pattern is super… common.” Silence is an airless chamber. Her eyes flash from curious to guarded like a port switching states. “Excuse me?” The syllables are unsmiling. I rush into the buffer. “I’m sorry, I—bad habit. I noticed it. It’s, like, there are studies on how often people choose patterns that start in the top left—like reading—and do a C-shape, and with the finger oils, it’s just—” “Are you trying to tell me my phone is insecure?” Her laugh has a serrated edge now. “No,” I say, and yes. “I’m… sorry. I do security. I can’t—it’s like muscle memory. I don’t mean to audit people.” Her jaw unclenches a millimeter. The truth is a patch sometimes. “Okay,” she says, a word that allows nothing, or everything. “So what’s the super secure pattern then, Mr. Security?” I smile, but not at her. At how predictable I am to myself. “Alphanumerics are better,” I say. “Patterns are basically four-digit pins with extra UX. But even a longer pattern that doubles back, doesn’t hit corners, changes direction unexpectedly…” I’m drawing with my finger on the table, realizing the shape is just my old life as a diagram. She watches. I pivot hard. “And you didn’t ask for that. I’m sorry.” She takes a beat. “I didn’t,” she says, but softer. “But… you know things. I get that impulse. I do it with people’s resumes.” We laugh a little, both guilty, both annotated. The bruschetta arrives like a timeout. We both reach for a piece and our fingers brush and it’s the sort of moment where, in a different story, the physical closeness closes an open thread. Here, the thread is an old Ethernet cable between two machines with a missing handshake. We try to resync. She asks me what made me get into security, and I decide not to rehearse the script about puzzles and saving people from themselves. I say, “I used to break things for a living. Now I try to make sure other people can’t.” She says, “Red team to blue team,” and her eyebrows go up like an impressed spectator at a kitchen trick. “Do you miss the adrenaline?” “Yes,” I say, because lying now would be like installing a backdoor in your own house. “But I like sleeping.” She tells me about a deck she loved that never won. “Delver of Secrets,” she says, and I feel the sting of coin-flip draws and the pleasure of flipping it on turn two. She talk about “Ponder,” “Preordain,” and the joy of sculpting possibilities. Data scientist, of course she does. “Spell Pierce” gets a mention—early protection, cheap denial. She hates getting blown out by “Cavern of Souls.” She makes a face. I file: Control of variables matters to her. She’ll tolerate variance but not being locked out of interacting. I realize I’ve been mentally cataloging every card, not as a creepy archivist but as if I’m building a model that approximates who she is. It’s what I do with systems: enumerate, map, test. With people, it’s ruder. She’s looking at her phone now with a new awareness, thumb hovering over the screen like a sentinel. She meets my eyes and holds them. “So,” she says. “Teach me a better lock.” It’s a trap and an opportunity. If I lecture, I’m the worst date she’ll tell her friends about in a group chat called ‘birds of prey.’ If I demur, I’m withholding. People’s security should be their idea. “I’ll tell you the one rule,” I say. “Don’t pick the first thing that feels easy. Make it yours. Make it something you can remember under stress, not something your hand draws when you’re thinking about other stuff. And if someone like me can guess it, you can make a new one.” She considers this. “I like that,” she says. “Under stress.” She makes a pattern in the air with her finger, nothing I can trace. “Okay,” she adds. “I changed it.” This is almost certainly a lie and also a test. I nod. “I won’t try to guess.” “That would be creepy,” she says, but she’s smiling again and the serration is gone. Negotiated truce. We return to cardboard. She admits a love for “Collective Brutality” because modes are delicious. I admit I can’t quit “Liliana of the Veil,” and she grins and says, “Ah, you like symmetrical sacrifice.” She calls me out gently for wanting control under the guise of fairness, and I bite into a tomato that explodes like a confession. We talk about Commander politics and she mentions “Propaganda,” “Smothering Tithe,” and I add “Rhystic Study” with a groan. She hates when people say “Did you pay the one?” with that tone. She likes “Temple Bell” because she’s a secret group hugger. She snorts when I say “Cyclonic Rift,” and says it’s a necessary evil for cowards. I tuck away: She prefers negotiated board states to unilateral resets. She’s not Sarah, and she’s not any of the others whose names are error messages in my log files. She’s Nia, who changed her lock in the middle of dinner because someone showed her the seam. We split dessert and the waiter sets down a little cube of something chocolate like a finite state machine. I notice the POS again, a flicker, a process running. I can stop myself from nudging the manager on the way out and telling him his firmware is screaming from the roof. I can decide not to patch a world that didn’t ask. Maybe. She’s tapping the rim of her water glass and making a face. “Okay,” she says. “I have to ask. Did you see my credit card number when I paid for my parking?” “No,” I say. “I didn’t look.” “You looked at my phone, though.” “I looked at your pattern,” I say. “Which is different. I’m a jerk in a very specific way.” She considers this. “You could just say you’re someone who notices.” “I notice,” I repeat. “It’s not always an act of violence.” She nods. “That’s… actually comforting?” I let it in. “I am trying to make it less violent.” When the check comes I don’t do the dance where I insist and she resists. We split it because fairness, and because we both know what the tip should be without a spreadsheet. As I sign, I think about the waiter’s compromised POS again and decide the most generous thing I can do is leave a good tip and an email address, not a lecture. I write thank you and a little smile face and it feels like the opposite of exfiltration. Outside, the night smells like yeast and ice. She hugs me because we’ve debugged something between us and found a workable version. As she steps back she smirks. “Don’t hack me.” “Don’t Splinter Twin me,” I shoot back. “At least wait until game two.” “Deal.” We stand there like teenagers pretending neither of us is old enough to know better. I ask if she wants to draft sometime. She says yes, that her friends think they’re good and need to be destroyed. I watch her walk toward her car and notice how often she looks over her shoulder—not because she’s scared but because she’s teachable. It occurs to me that I’d like to be someone she doesn’t have to look back for, and that my statutes of limitation with myself are not yet up but maybe I can file for an extension. Her brake lights flash. I realize I could maintain this connection without enumerating every last vulnerability, that I can pick my targets. The habit doesn’t go away; it never does. But tonight I leveraged it for a shocking thing: not advantage, not control, but a conversation where both of us ended with more than we started. On the way home, my phone vibrates. A message. New pattern is “under stress.” Also, do you own a Liliana alter or are you normal. I grin. I type back, very carefully. Normal is a low-entropy setting. And I never start with top-left anymore.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the perspective of a reformed white hat hacker navigating a first date. The protagonist's internal monologue is rich with technical jargon and security metaphors that effectively convey their habitual vulnerability-seeking mindset while attempting to focus on human connection. The writing excels at creating a distinctive voice. The narrator's security-oriented perspective colors everything they observe, from the restaurant's Wi-Fi to their date's phone unlock pattern. This consistent lens creates an authentic character whose professional background has fundamentally shaped how they perceive the world. The shared interest in Magic: The Gathering serves as an excellent vehicle for character development. The author cleverly uses card preferences as personality indicators, allowing readers to understand both characters through their gaming choices. This shared "nerd-fandom" creates genuine connection while revealing character traits organically. The narrative handles the central conflict—the protagonist noticing and commenting on their date's insecure phone pattern—with nuance. The awkwardness feels authentic, as does the negotiation that follows. The protagonist's self-awareness about their inappropriate behavior adds depth to the character. The prose is technically strong, with effective use of technical terminology that never feels forced. Metaphors comparing human interactions to security concepts ("Silence is an airless chamber. Her eyes flash from curious to guarded like a port switching states") are particularly effective. The writing maintains a consistent rhythm with varied sentence structures that keep the narrative flowing. Where the piece could improve is in its occasional tendency toward overexplanation. Some of the internal monologue spells out connections too explicitly rather than trusting the reader to make them. Additionally, while the ending achieves a satisfying resolution, it verges slightly on being too neat given the social awkwardness established earlier. The narrative successfully balances technical content with emotional development. The protagonist's struggle between their security-oriented mindset and desire for human connection creates genuine tension. Their recognition that they can "leverage" their habit "not for advantage, not for control, but a conversation where both of us ended with more than we started" represents meaningful character growth. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that fulfills the prompt requirements while creating a distinctive voice, believable characters, and an engaging narrative arc. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 4 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 4.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 90.9
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
It’s fine. It’s fine. A group project is just a project with multiple people who breathe too loudly. I can handle that. It’s not a performance, it’s not a trap, it’s not a social Rubik’s cube I will twist until the colors bleed. Sit. Unzip pencil case. Don’t dump it. Slide it open like you’re capable of casualness. The desks clatter into arrangements there’s no word for besides awkward. Mrs. Han writes “Capillary Action – Design Your Own Investigation” in purple marker and underlines it with a flourish. She pairs us, trios us, quads us. Our names stick to each other like static. “You four,” she says, and tilts her marker at our table. Me, Maya (high ponytail, perfect penmanship), Kevin (who can turn any moment into a joke no one asked for), and him. Alex. Alex who sits two rows over and never sweats under pressure, who says “I think we should test variables” like it’s a thought he woke up with, already formed, no awkward preamble. There. Don’t look at him yet. Look at the worksheet. Focus. Capillary action. Plants. Stems in dyed water. Paper towels creeping up a glass. It’s not complicated. I can make this so complicated I need a flowchart, but I shouldn’t. The pen feels heavy. Don’t drop it. Don’t twirl it. Twirling is a tell. I press the tip to the top margin and a tiny face appears before I even intend it—two curved lines and dots like a secret. I give it hair with short careful strokes. Maya. Her hair has that swoop that it actually does. Is that creepy? No one will notice. It’s small. It’s always small. “We could use celery,” Maya says, and she already has a graph drawn with spaces for data. Of course she does. “And maybe paper towels,” she adds, giving Kevin a look that means, please don’t suggest Kool-Aid. “Gatorade?” Kevin says, like an atom cannot be prevented from being itself. I think, we can test ionic solutions versus water, it would demonstrate the effect of dissolved solutes on capillary action due to altered surface tension, I read something about it and if I say it right I could sound like someone you want on your team. My tongue feels like it’s made of felt. If I talk too soon it’s weird, if I talk too late it’s weirder.
