Alex opens his mouth, and the sound of my own heartbeat is a basketball in the gym rafters. “Food coloring is fine,” he says. “We can do different concentrations and see if it changes how fast it moves. Like, set up three paper towel bridges between cups.” He looks at me then, not skimming across, but actually landing. “What do you think?” Oh. My cheeks do that thing. Heat flips on like a space heater. I could say, that’s a good control, we can draw a baseline with plain water and adjust one variable while keeping others constant. Say it. Say the thing. The thought is clean in my head, crisp as the graph paper in Maya’s binder. Out loud, it will collapse. Collapse-proofing it requires rehearsal. Option A: Nodding, quiet, unhelpful. He will think I have no thoughts beyond nod. Option B: Too much talking, word salad spread on the desk like spilled glitter. Option C: Exactly the right amount of smart, which is also too much if you’re a girl, which is unfair to say, but the rulebook in my brain bristles with unfair rules. I can hold two truths and flinch at both. “Yeah,” I say. It comes out breathy. Too soft. There’s a second before I add, “We could, um, keep the length of the paper towels the same, and, uh, do like five drops of food coloring vs. ten vs. fifteen—” My voice trips on fifteen like there’s a speed bump. “—and time how long it takes to reach the other cup.” That wasn’t disastrous. Not good, not a meltdown. Like spilling two grains of salt when you were trying for one. Alex nods. “Sound good,” he says. He looks at Maya. “Maya?” “Love it,” she says. She writes “length constant” on the paper and underlines it twice. I draw a small rectangle in the corner of my notes. It becomes Kevin’s blocky haircut, a rectangle with enthusiasm. A dot for his nose. Does anyone see me doing this? I angle the page away. My heart does a gentle tambourine roll. It counts out the seconds like it wants to be helpful. “Okay,” Mrs. Han says, moving around the room like some kind of benevolent shark. “You’ll write a hypothesis and list your variables. Equipment is on the back counter. Be careful with the glass.” I sketch an even tinier face beside the word hypothesis. Alex’s hair is impossible. It’s messy in a precise way. I give him a cartoon wave. That’s creepy. Is that creepy? I slant the paper so the wave is hidden under my hand. “Who wants to go get stuff?” Kevin asks. He looks hopeful, because going to the back counter is a chance to detour past the class clown’s audience and perform his impression of Mr. Sato, which is only funny if you’re not Mr. Sato. “I can,” Alex says, and stands up. The movement is clean, so normal my bones ache with wanting to be that normal. “I’ll go,” I say, at the exact same time. It’s a collision. The word leaps out of me without checking with Security, and then we are both looking at each other like we’ve said something intimate when all we said was an errand. He smiles, a quick left-hand curve of mouth, a comma. “We can both,” he says. He says “both” with a softness that doesn’t feel like pity. Option D: Walk together without tripping over my shoelaces and the conversation. Option D should include one remark about capillary action and not a single word about favorite bands I pretend to like. I stand up. My chair leg screeches on the linoleum and the scraping sound is a scream in a language adults can’t hear. Don’t make eye contact with the entire room. Make it with the floor. The floor is safe. There’s a unibrow of gray scuff marks near the sink. I catalog them like constellations. We move side by side. He smells like laundry detergent and pencil shavings, which is better than Gatorade, which is what Kevin actually smells like, probably because he drinks it like it’s holy water. Do we say something? If we say nothing, it’s the vacuum of space. If I say something and it’s wrong, it’s vacuum plus meteor shower. “Have you done this before?” he asks. Yes. In fourth grade we dyed carnations blue and I was the one who left mine on the windowsill for three weeks to see what happened and it turned brittle and papery and it made a noise like old leaves when I snapped it, and I liked that better than the blue. “Yeah,” I say. I almost say which grade. Not necessary. Extra sentence tax. He picks up a stack of paper towels, I grab the food coloring, because they are light and unbreakable. The droppers sit in a neat line like soldiers. My hand hovers over red, blue, green, the obvious primaries that do what they’re told. “Red and blue?” he asks, reading my hover. “Red,” I say. “Blue.” There’s a version of me that makes a joke about purple being the inevitable consequence of an ill-fated alliance, and that version is fun at parties you don’t have to go to. I am not that version, not today, not with the heat at my collarbones telling tales. We carry things back like we are in a procession for a god of small experiments. Kevin makes the sound of trumpets. He can’t help it. Maya ignores him. She’s numbered the beakers and drawn the most beautiful table. She’s the person you want when you’re lost and need someone to tell you which way is east. Back at the table I measure water into cups, my hands steady because beakers are honest and numbers are a language I can speak without blushing. “So,” Alex says, “we can cut the paper towels into equal strips. Twelve inches?” “Twelve,” I say. “Consistent.” I almost add “standardization reduces error,” but that sits on my tongue like something that will be mispronounced. I cut; the scissors snip with authority. I make the strips the same width as well, because I don’t want some tiny asymmetry to cost us a neat trend line. I draw a dot beside each of our names on my page, each dot is a head and then a tiny accessory. Maya’s ponytail loop; Kevin’s rectangle hair; Alex’s comma smile; me as a circle with a lightning bolt for a heartbeat. I think about adding another mark but that would be too much. It already is too much. We set two cups side by side and make a paper towel bridge. The towel sags, dips its toe into both waters like it wants to dance. The red seeps up and into white, making a new shade the way embarrassment rises into my face. We start the timer. “We need a hypothesis,” Maya says gently, the way she might remind someone to breathe. “We hypothesize that increased dye concentration will increase rate of capillary action,” I say in my head. Out loud, I say, “More drops, faster.” It’s a baby version of my thought. My shoulders inch toward my ears like they want to hide in my hair. “That makes sense,” Alex says. He writes it down, the baby version, and I hate and love that acceptance at the same time. Does my voice sound smaller than I feel? Is he adjusting for that? He doesn’t know there’s a thesis trapped behind my teeth. He’s not responsible for my teeth. We watch the color creep. Kevin times on his phone, pressing start with exaggerated ceremony. “Go,” he says. He could be speaking to the red, to the paper towel, to me. My eyes go from the water line to the movement to my own fingers. I move them like I’m someone who has always had fingers. Not too fidgety. Not too still. If you don’t move at all you look like a mannequin, which is creepier than doodling and I have data to back it up. I flex my thumb once. I press my nails into my palm, half moons, a geometry of self-control. “How do you draw the graphs?” Alex asks. “Like, what style? I always end up making mine crooked.” He’s talking to me. Option E: Share one skill, but not with the weird fervor of the graph evangelist. I say, “Start the axes with a ruler. Label units. Leave space for mistakes.” That last part comes out heavier than I meant. He smiles with his whole face. The comma goes longer. “Space for mistakes,” he repeats. He says it like a useful concept, not a confession. “Forty-five seconds,” Kevin announces. “Red is winning.” He says winning like it’s a race we can cheer for. I feel like I’m in a race where the prize is getting to stay in the room. “Science isn’t a competition,” Maya says lightly, and then we all cheer when the blue catches up because we can’t help ourselves. I write 1:12 next to red. The numbers are neat. They always are. I make a tiny trophy beside 1:12 because I despise and adore myself in equal measure. If anyone notices, they don’t comment. Maybe we all have secret systems. “Do you think we should switch the positions to see if that matters?” Alex asks me. He asks me. He could have asked Maya. He could have asked the air. “Like, swap left and right in case air flow or something.” “Yeah,” I say. “Good control.” The words are thin, but they fit. They are the exact outline of the shape I can handle. When he moves the cups, our hands bump. It’s a soft bump, skin skimming skin, static ping. My brain lights up like a switchboard. A thousand operators plug lines into a thousand sockets: Was that deliberate? Was it nothing? Does he notice the static? My face imposes normal. Neutral expression, small smile. Don’t show your teeth unless you have a reason. Teeth are aggressive. I breathe through my nose. Calm. Not a baby rabbit in a trap. Just a person doing a lab. We set up the second trial. The blue seems to learn from the red, finds its path faster. Or that’s what feelings do to data. My doodles multiply because my pen needs somewhere to be that isn’t between my teeth. Alex’s tiny face now has two commas. That’s too many. I cover it with my thumb. I draw a tiny beaker with a happy face. Neutral. Not creepy. “So,” Kevin says, “what are we calling this. The Great Capillary Race?” “We’ll call it that in our notes,” Maya says, deadpan, and writes it in her tidy letters like it’s a real title. I like her so much for doing that I want to buy her a cupcake. I look at the worksheet where “Conclusion” looms like the last boss in a video game. I can see what to write. I always can. Something about adhesion and cohesion and surface tension, about the interplay of molecules and the way a meniscus curves inward like a bowed head. In my head I write it and it is beautiful—okay not beautiful, but clean, quiet. Out loud, if I volunteer to read it, I will trip on “adhesion” or “interplay” and my tongue will tangle itself in the cords of my vocal cords and I will become the kind of story people tell in the hallway. That’s not rational. I can list everything that can go wrong faster than I can list the names of my family members. “Do you want to write the conclusion?” Alex asks. He asks soft, like he doesn’t want to scare the animal at the edge of the clearing. He hands me the pen. His nail is bitten down a little. Imperfect. My breath gets less insisted. I take it. The pen fits my hand like it knew it would come here. I write. The letters are small but legible. They sit in lines like they’ve practiced. I include the words I wanted. I write “adhesion and cohesion” and the world does not collapse. My inner monologue applauds and then immediately tells me to stop applauding; it’s tacky. I hand the paper back before I can do something weird like sign it. “That’s good,” Alex says, and I point at Maya so the praise gets distributed correctly even though he’s looking at me. The bell rings with a sigh. Everyone leaps up because the next class always feels like a life raft. We’re halfway through. We’ll reconvene tomorrow. “Nice work,” Maya says to all of us, and taps the table once like she’s blessing it. Kevin tucks a paper towel into his pocket for reasons unknown to humanity. Alex looks at me. “See you tomorrow?” he says, an invitation freighted with zero extra anything. “Yes,” I say. One syllable, a bridge between two cups. He steps away, and I look at my page. There we are, four tiny faces. I draw a little line connecting my circle with the comma. It is a ridiculous thing to do. It is safe on paper. I shade it in lightly until the line almost disappears. It’s fine. It’s fine. I survived every second I thought I couldn’t. Tomorrow I will do it again. I will make space for mistakes and fill some of it with color. I will remember to breathe. I will pretend to be normal until the pretending feels like a kind of truth. And if my hands shake when I cut the paper towels, that’s just capillary action reaching across empty space, the way water climbs where it doesn’t belong, the way things move even when no one is pushing them.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the internal monologue of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on her classmate Alex during a science project. The piece excels at portraying the protagonist's overthinking nature, showing the stark contrast between her articulate internal thoughts and her stilted external communication. The character's voice is remarkably consistent throughout, maintaining the intelligent yet anxious perspective of a socially uncomfortable teen. The narrative effectively demonstrates how she rehearses conversations and second-guesses herself through "options" (A, B, C, D, E) that reveal her systematic approach to social interaction. This methodical thinking pattern feels authentic to a bright but anxious young person. The prose is elegant without being overly sophisticated for an 8th grader's perspective. Metaphors like "my brain lights up like a switchboard" and "a thousand operators plug lines into a thousand sockets" effectively convey her overthinking without becoming purple. The writing captures small, telling details that create vivid imagery: the protagonist's doodling habits, the way she notices Alex's "comma" smile, and her careful monitoring of her own body language. The narrative excels at showing rather than telling. Instead of stating "I have social anxiety," the text demonstrates it through the character's hyperawareness of her movements, her cataloging of potential social missteps, and her constant self-monitoring. The protagonist's emotional complexity is well-rendered through her contradictory feelings: "I hate and love that acceptance at the same time" and "I despise and adore myself in equal measure." The piece maintains excellent coherence, following the science experiment from beginning to end while weaving in the protagonist's crush and anxiety. The pacing is appropriate, neither rushing nor dragging. The ending strikes a realistic balance—not suggesting an unrealistic transformation but acknowledging small victories and ongoing challenges. A few minor weaknesses: occasionally the metaphors become slightly overwrought ("the vacuum of space. If I say something and it's wrong, it's vacuum plus meteor shower"). The protagonist's intelligence sometimes manifests in vocabulary that stretches credibility for an 8th grader, even a bright one ("the rulebook in my brain bristles with unfair rules. I can hold two truths and flinch at both"). However, these instances are rare and don't significantly detract from the overall quality. The narrative succeeds brilliantly at its core task: portraying the exhausting process of social anxiety, the gap between internal articulation and external expression, and the particular intensity of an adolescent crush. The reader gains deep insight into the protagonist's experience while maintaining empathy for her struggles. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 95.2
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The TV through the wall is having an argument about a blue car. Or maybe a blue sweater. The words blur, cartoon-flat, laugh track leaking like a faucet that won’t quite turn off. I stare at the clock on my phone until the numbers shimmer, then check my reflection in the black screen. My cheeks are blotchy; I pinch them. It makes them worse. I imagine you noticing the blotchiness first, before anything I say, deciding that blotchy means needy means too much. I press a cold spoon to my face because that’s supposed to help but all it does is make a circle-shaped chill and a story: you saying, Jesus, you’re a lot today. You haven’t texted since last night. “Crash early! Big day tomorrow,” you wrote, sparkles and a yellow heart. The heart looked like a banana to me, soft and a bit blank. You used a different color heart with me last week. I scroll up to check, then feel sick that I checked. The TV laughs and then becomes the low murmur that makes the walls feel porous, like I could put my hand through and have a sitcom family. My jacket sleeve smells like your laundry detergent. I bury my face in it and inhale until my chest hurts. If I could keep this smell I’d be safe, or at least I would know where to put my face when the panic climbs up my ribs like ivy. I imagine you walking in, smelling like this, looking at me like I’m a problem no one assigned you. In the movie version of tonight you say, “We need to talk,” and my throat closes. I practice answers. I’ll be cool. Nodding. Oh totally, I get it, I’ve been busy too. I rehearse a laugh that says unbothered without sounding fake. It sounds fake. The laces on my shoes are loops on loops. I unknot them, retie them. It’s something my hands can do while my head auditions disasters. You take a breath, you say, “You were intense the other night,” and I say, “Right, I’ve been meaning to say sorry if I was, like, emotional in a weird way,” and then you say, “It’s not that, it’s just… I need space,” and this is the part where the floor drops. I picture the table between us, and I grip the edges so hard the wood softens. In one version I stand up so quick the chair falls over and everyone looks at us and I roll my eyes at them like, can you believe this, pretending it’s your problem not mine. Another version, I am the Buddha. I smile and say, “Of course. Space is healthy.” Then I leave and delete you from everything. Then I go back at two in the morning and undelete. I am aware that I do this. That is something I’m supposed to note for progress. My therapist calls it anticipating abandonment. She says, “Just notice,” like it’s a bird on the wire and not a hurricane that keeps stealing the roof. I notice. It is very noticed. The noticing does not change the wind. I tell her, “I’m rehearsing the movie where they leave before they can forget to tell me I mattered.” She tilts her head like a kind owl and asks, “What does rehearsing do for you?” It gives me a script so I don’t stutter on no and please. It makes me angry at you early so when it hurts later I can call it something else. My phone buzzes and I jump. It’s a calendar alert: Pick up dry cleaning. The alert is as neutral as a stone. I swipe it away and imagine you again, but this time you are sheepish. “Hey,” you say, soft. “Sorry I’ve been distant, work’s been insane.” I see your mouth say insane, the way your lips go a little sideways, and I feel the immediate flood, adoration like a heat that turns my skeleton to rubber. You’re here, you’re here, you didn’t throw me away at the curb like a warped chair. You reach for my hand. I let you. I hate that I need it so badly my cells hum with it. Needing is weak, needing is an invitation to be kicked. That’s a law in the country I was born into. The TV says, “Don’t be ridiculous,” in canned sarcasm, and I answer it quietly, “Too late.” If I hear your key in my door I will choke on my own spit. You don’t have a key. You would knock. It would be the exact number of knocks you always do, two and a pause and the third one like a question. If you do that I will open the door like I just happened to be standing there, not like I’ve been practicing being unimpressed. If you hug me I will soften in the places I’ve been holding stiff all day. I will close my eyes, then open them again because then I imagine you looking over my shoulder with boredom. When we texted yesterday and you said, “Can’t wait to see you,” I stared at can’t wait until it turned into can’t. The way my head edits is so fast I should be paid for it. I typed, “Same,” and deleted it. Typed, “Miss you,” deleted it. Typed, “lol me too” and sent that, and then immediately wondered if lol makes me sound thirteen or disinterested or if you like disinterested because you like to chase. Later, you sent me a picture of your coffee with a foam heart upside down because you didn’t rotate it. I then rotated it and stared at it until my eyes watered, which is pathetic but it’s also love, isn’t it? Isn’t this love, the obsessive cataloging, the spinning constellations out of foam? You text now: “Heading out in five! Emotional support snack achieved.” A picture of gummy bears on a steering wheel. I laugh, actually laugh, like a bell in my throat. I clutch the laugh as proof: see, you’re not a monster. Anxiety is a liar. I reply with a bear emoji and then I add a second bear and then I delete the second bear because two bears is too much need. Then I hit send and hate my reply for being nothing. I imagine you looking at it in your car, rolling your eyes. I imagine you smiling. I pick the one that hurts less right now and feed it to the part of me that snarls. I put on lip balm. I take it off. I put it on again. My bathroom mirror says I am a face someone could love if they felt like it. It is a face that is a project. The last person said I was intense and then kissed me like drowning and then said intense again like a diagnosis and then left me. You said intense and said it like, bright. You said, “You make everything feel bright.” My cells lit up like a city. After that I started preparing for the blackout. I could cancel. I could text you, “Hey not feeling great, can we rain check?” Then I could spend the night with the TV voices and my heart chewing its own leg off. Then I could tell myself that I set a boundary. Then I could picture you relieved and find that unbearable. Or I could go. I am going. Going means choosing the terror where there’s a chance of touch, rather than the terror with no touch. I put on my jacket. I take off my jacket. My skin feels too big. The knock is two and a question. My body lights up and then freezes. I count five Mississippi because it makes me feel like I’m not as reachable as I am, like I have layers. I open. There you are, gummy bears shoved in the pocket of your hoodie, hair damp from the drizzle, eyes doing that crinkly thing, mouth already forming my name like it knows it. You say it, and I melt and stiffen at the same time. Cognitive dissonance tastes like mint and copper. You hug me, full. Your coat is cold and smells like rain and that detergent. The hug has weight. I don’t know how to hold it without shaking. I imagine you letting go and stepping back with a scolding face and a clipboard, a checklist that says: neediness, time management, reliability. Instead you say, “I missed you,” and you push your nose into my neck like an animal, and I have to grab the edge of the kitchen counter in my mind to not dissolve into a puddle on the mat. It is too much, which is exactly how I like things. And then the siren goes off inside me: too much is dangerous, you idiot, too much is the trap that makes the drop worse. I mutter, “You’ve been busy,” like a test. You nod, “Yeah,” and you add, “Sorry, it got away from me.” You put your forehead to mine. “I should have called.” The kindness makes me want to slap. Not you—whatever switch you flipped, the one that drenches me and makes it impossible to breathe. I want to push you and yell, “Don’t do that unless you mean it forever,” which is impossible, which is the point. “It’s fine,” I hear myself say, voice smooth like I ironed it. “I get it.” My hand is on your wrist, thumb reading your pulse like braille. It says: here. It says: now. My head says: later. The TV next door blares a theme song, triumphant violins. You say, “Do you want to sit?” You put the gummy bears on my counter like a prize. I shrug like sitting would be a favor I grant you. We sit. You angle your body to mine. You’re present. It should be an aspirin. It is a sparkler held too close to the sleeve. You tell me about work. You complain about your boss using synergy unironically. You do the voice. I laugh. It’s easy, it’s fun, I can do this. I can pretend my stomach isn’t a fist. You reach for my hand between sentences. You do that thing with your thumb on the inside of my wrist, circles like pennies. My eyes sting. I hate that the gesture is a key. I love that it’s a key. The parts of me that are iron bars rattle. Your phone buzzes. You glance. Already I write that glance into a contract. See, I tell myself, you check your phone because you’re bored. See, it’s someone better. It’s your ex, it’s the person with less edges, it’s a world you prefer to me. The truth comes out: you say, “Sorry, my mom’s asking about the cat,” and you put the phone face down. My sternum loosens, immediately furious at itself for doing what it always does: overturn the verdict with a single piece of evidence. If you were mean, if you were cold, I could be justified in the rage that keeps me from collapsing into you. You force me into joy and I don’t trust it for a second. I can see you loving me and loving this and I can see you leaving next week because the way I ask if you’re mad when your eyebrows look like they’re thinking is too much like surveillance. You say, “Hey, look at me,” because I drifted, I fell into the projector room. I look. You’re soft as bread. “I’m here,” you say. You squeeze my hand. I nod. I put your words into quarantine at the back of my throat. They try to leak through, to change the temperature. “I know,” I say, which is almost true for a second. The second stretches, delicate. Then the world thumps next door, the TV laughs at its own joke, and my brain says, Careful. We make dinner. You slice and pass me pieces of pepper and I bite them from your fingers and it’s simple, it’s a short film with warm colors. You tell me about a podcast you liked. I store the name to look up later so I can have a thing to text you about if you go dark again, a rope to throw across a canyon. Between sizzles you say, “I had a weird dream about you.” You grin, and the grin is formatless possibility. I feel my inner jury convene. A dream about me, evidence to bolster the case that I will be held. Then the cross-examination begins: why didn’t you tell me sooner if it mattered, was the dream bad, was I the villain, what if you woke up relieved it wasn’t real. “What was it?” I ask, casual. My voice wobbles. You laugh. “You were teaching me to parallel park a boat.” The sentence is absurd in the best way and my body laughs before my brain can stop it. We laugh together and the sound is a bridge. Then I step to the side and peer down: far drop. There is a moment, later, while you’re stirring, where I see myself from above. A person in a kitchen being loved in small ways and still scanning the ceiling for leaks. I see the pattern like a quilt I’ve had my whole life. It is threadbare in places but it’s mine. I feel a pang of almost-tenderness for the part of me that’s standing guard with a plastic sword. I want to tell it it can nap. Then the pot boils over and you swear and I dab with a towel and the tenderness evaporates like steam. After we eat, you tuck your feet under you on my couch and you pull me into the space you make. It feels assigned, destined even, and that freaks me out. Your hand finds my hair. You say, “Can we be like this for sixty years?” joking, and my heart buckles and then throws up its hands. You tilt my face and kiss me with the kind of concentration that makes the world tilt. The neighbors switch to a commercial, an announcer yelling about prices, and I giggle into your mouth. It is a perfect messy moment and I instinctively look for the exit sign. You say, “I love you,” into my jaw like you tripped over it. It lands and spreads like dye in water. Everything in me says yes, says yes so loud my ears ring. I say it back, I think, I do, and then the panic snarls because now there’s a promise with a timer attached and I don’t know where the timer is. The words feel true and then immediately like a trap someone set using my own hand. I think, You’ll take it back, you’ll regret it, you’ll say you were tired. I think, You meant it and I will choke on it anyway because I don’t have a place inside me that isn’t braced. I recognize that this is the dance. Awareness floats at the edges like dust motes and I try to gather it, to pack it into something heavy enough to anchor me. I press my face under your chin and breathe. The television next door decides a winner of a game show and the studio audience claps, a wall of sound that feels like static on my skin. I whisper into your shirt, “Don’t leave,” and you say, “I’m not,” quick, automatic, sincere. I believe you as much as I can, which is to say with slices of myself, sharp and arranged to form a circle that looks like whole from a distance. You fall asleep with your hand on my waist, lax, trusting. The quiet you make is different than the quiet when I’m alone. It’s heavier, like everyone is finally in their chairs. My mind suggests a reel of all the ways this can end and I let it run, like an old machine that needs to burn itself out. In the dark, I trace your knuckles and rehearse not just the fight but the staying. I whisper lines for both: me saying, I’m scared, and you saying, Me too. We could do that script. We could improvise. The TV mumbles through the wall about the blue sweater again, the audience oohs, and I decide nothing, which is new, and I hate it, and I love it, and I sleep like a person lowered into water, holding my breath but letting my body float.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal experience of someone with borderline personality disorder (BPD). The piece excels at depicting the protagonist's constant cycling between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. The stream-of-consciousness style perfectly mirrors the character's racing thoughts and emotional turbulence. Short, fragmented sentences create a sense of urgency and anxiety: "My jacket sleeve smells like your laundry detergent. I bury my face in it and inhale until my chest hurts." This technique effectively conveys the character's hypervigilance and emotional intensity. The narrative skillfully portrays cognitive dissonance—the protagonist recognizes their patterns ("I am aware that I do this") yet remains trapped in them. The metaphors are particularly striking and authentic to the BPD experience: "My therapist calls it anticipating abandonment. She says, 'Just notice,' like it's a bird on the wire and not a hurricane that keeps stealing the roof." Such imagery powerfully conveys how intellectual awareness fails to diminish emotional suffering. The contrast between imagined scenarios and reality is masterfully handled. When the friend arrives with genuine warmth, the protagonist's inability to fully trust or accept this affection feels painfully authentic: "The kindness makes me want to slap. Not you—whatever switch you flipped, the one that drenches me and makes it impossible to breathe." This paradoxical reaction—wanting connection yet fearing it—captures the essence of BPD's emotional contradictions. The writing employs vivid sensory details that ground the narrative in physical reality while the protagonist's mind spirals: the smell of detergent, the taste of pepper, the sound of the neighbor's TV. These concrete anchors create a compelling juxtaposition with the character's abstract catastrophizing. The piece avoids romanticizing or demonizing BPD. Instead, it presents a nuanced portrait of someone struggling with genuine emotional pain while maintaining moments of self-awareness: "I see the pattern like a quilt I've had my whole life. It is threadbare in places but it's mine." This balance between suffering and insight prevents the character from becoming a mere collection of symptoms. The ending achieves a delicate balance—not suggesting a miraculous recovery, but showing a small moment of potential growth: "I decide nothing, which is new, and I hate it, and I love it." This ambivalence feels true to the BPD experience, where progress often comes in small, contradictory moments rather than dramatic breakthroughs. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that demonstrates profound understanding of borderline personality disorder while maintaining literary excellence. The writing is emotionally raw without becoming melodramatic, psychologically accurate without reading like a clinical case study, and ultimately creates a deeply empathetic window into a complex mental health condition. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 20 Nuanced Characters: 20 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 20
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 20.0, Nuanced Characters: 20.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 20.0
+ Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 93.4
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
They met where the lantern light peeled paint off columns and the air smelled of rotted offerings. The old temple’s roof had collapsed decades ago, and stars hung like dull nails over splintered rafters. Along the center aisle, broken flagstones stitched a jagged path between toppled statues, incense ash, and a trickle of water threading through a fissure in the floor. On both sides, bodies packed in—men in dark jackets and scarves, women in wool caps, faces still and eager, money already changing hands, the sound of bills crisping under calloused fingers. The crowd’s semi-circle left a rectangle of uneven stone open, twenty feet by fifteen, bounded by a fallen beam at the far end and two moss-lipped steps at the near. They would not call each other by name. That courtesy belonged to sanctioned matches. Here, in this slant of shadow and ruin, they were the crest and the tide meeting. The Jigen-ryū fighter stood to the north, back to a headless Kannon statue. He was tall and straight-backed, shoulders yearlit in sweat, eyes heavy-lidded with contempt. His right hand hung near the hilt of a bokken that wasn’t there; his school had forbidden live blades in any context. He had come bare-handed, but he held himself as if a sword waited in his palm. Feet set slightly left-forward, right angled out, knees loaded. His chin lined up over the front foot, weight balanced but itching toward his toes. You could see the calluses on his knuckles even in the lantern light. Opposite, at the southern end, the Piguaquan fighter stood with his left side bladed toward the other man, knees slightly bent, hips loose. His hands were open, fingers relaxed, palms sometimes kissing each other softly as he exhaled, as if he were folding paper. He swayed on the balls of his feet, testing the friction, testing the slick sheen where the thin stream spilled out from the crack and ran skew across the center of the fighting space to vanish beneath a dislodged stone. His eyes flicked, not to the Jigen-ryū man but to the floor, to the columns, to the beam that lay like a longswept brushstroke at the edge—things to step on, around, through. The bettors pressed closer until one of the organizers, a man with a shaved head and a cheap coat, lifted a hand for silence. The murmurs sank, but the tension did not. A coin whispered over linen as it changed hands; someone cleared their throat. The shaved head pointed to the stream. “Watch your feet.” They nodded, not to him, but to the ground. The Jigen-ryū man moved first, not a step, but a collapse inward: spine dropping, hips snapping, right foot sliding a half-step short, and then he exploded. Left foot stomped diagonally forward to the left to clear the slick, right shoulder whipping through, right hand, a bludgeon, cleaving a straight arc to the Piguaquan fighter’s face. It was clean—no feints, no stutter. His body was one unit, pelvis braced, shoulder, elbow, knuckles aligned. He shouted low from the belly—kiai—driving sound and force together. The Piguaquan fighter did not meet that line. He twisted left, hips and shoulders turning away as his left foot pivoted on the ball to open his stance; his right foot stepped outside the punch, to the Jigen-ryū man’s lead. He dropped his center a fraction, let the fist skim his cheekbone, feeling its wind, and used his right forearm to slap the striking arm downward with a short, whipping motion. Not a block—redirect, a change in vector that bent the line toward the floor where the water glimmered. At the same breath, his left hand carved across like a paddle, catching the Jigen-ryū man’s exposed ribs in a short, circular palm strike, heel of the hand snapping in and out like a gust. The thud was solid—meat on stone. The Jigen-ryū man’s punch dropped past his own hip, redirected and now briefly out of position. He did not recoil; he continued through the motion, turning his left shoulder forward to follow with a left hammering ridge-hand aimed for the Piguaquan fighter’s jaw. His footwork was brutal and efficient: left foot forward, right foot chasing, cutting off angle, aiming to align hips and shoulders on the new target. The Piguaquan fighter stepped again, this time retreating to his right. His left foot slid along a dry seam of stone; his right followed, not crossing, but arcing wider to maintain the outside angle. The second strike skimmed past his ear, hair fluttering, and he answered by letting his arm dangle and then whip: his right hand slapped down on the Jigen-ryū man’s left forearm and his left forearm cut up in a rising arc—pi and gua—bisecting the space to the chin. He connected with the ulna near the wrist; the shock vibrated. The Jigen-ryū man’s head snapped back an inch. He stepped into it, absorbing through stance, bringing his right foot forward to square up and slam his forehead into the space where he expected a face. The Piguaquan fighter had already poured out to the side, right foot sealing on the mosaic edge, left foot skipping behind, body carving around the Jigen-ryū man’s right shoulder. He flicked his left hand down to the back of the other’s elbow, guiding, and whipped his right forearm across the shoulder blade, a chopping strike meant to deaden muscle and disrupt the shoulder’s chain. The impact made the Jigen-ryū man flinch, more from the suddenness than the pain. They were near the trickle now. The water cut the ground between them, a slick diagonal. The Jigen-ryū man noted it without looking; his next drive went around it. He pivoted his right heel in, set his left foot outside the stream, and lunged—short-range, torso level, both hands now used like a two-handed strike, right as the blade, left as the sheath, slamming down toward the Piguaquan fighter’s collarbone. He wanted close-in, where there was no room to spin or coil. The Piguaquan fighter dropped weight, knees softening as if he were going to sit. The double strike scythed over, caught air, and he took that momentum to roll his left shoulder forward and under the Jigen-ryū man’s hands, sliding along his torso like water around a rock. His right foot stepped to the outside of the Jigen-ryū man’s left foot, heel hooking slightly to check it. His left palm opened and slapped the Jigen-ryū man’s kidney with a short, whipping arc. The Jigen-ryū man bit the pain and tried to wrap—his left arm snapped back to pin the Piguaquan fighter’s triceps. The grip found fabric but not meat. The Piguaquan fighter twitched his elbow down and away, ribs compressing, and the grab slipped on sweat. He unwound, coiling right, then lashed back: a backhand forearm to the jawline. The Jigen-ryū man dipped his chin, the strike thunking into the forehead ridge instead, and surged forward, chest to chest, hips squared. He slammed his right knee toward the Piguaquan fighter’s thigh, aiming for the outside quad. The knee caught muscle. The Piguaquan fighter hissed and stepped back, right then left, keeping his base wide, refusing to cross the stream with his weight leading. The slick would turn a misstep into a split-second disaster. He circled left, counter-clockwise, angling toward the fallen beam. The Jigen-ryū man tracked him, cutting through arcs with straight lines, corralling him toward wood and shadow. The crowd saw the funnel forming and roared, felt the geometry as if it were heat. Bills lifted, hands gestured, elbows clipped ribs. The organizer’s voice was nothing compared to the hum. At five feet distance, the Jigen-ryū man went again. Right foot forward, left pushed, and he exploded across the last gap. Right hand a straight cudgel to the centerline, left guarding his own head, chin tucked. His shoulders were a drawstring, tightened and released, everything aimed through the knuckles. The Piguaquan fighter slid his left foot onto the damp, intentionally. The sole kissed water. He bent his knee deeper, let his base drop lower than usual, and when the punch came, he didn’t retreat—he moved in a half-beat early and to the right, the fist scraping past his neck. His left hand snapped down on the wrist to carry it through. His right arm whipped, a long arc from hip to temple, forearm and hand both a flail. He struck the side of the Jigen-ryū man’s neck—sternocleidomastoid and carotid—then let the arm continue to circle, taking him into a spin that put his back briefly to the Jigen-ryū man, then out again. His foot skated on the wet. He compensated by letting the slip become turn, right foot sliding, left foot drawing a crescent on the floor, hips rolling to harness the friction loss. The Jigen-ryū man grunted and shoved off his rear leg to chase, punching through the empty space the spin left, then stamping his left foot to anchor and firing a left backfist toward the Piguaquan fighter’s head mid-turn. The angle was clever; the Piguaquan fighter met it by ducking, not with his back bending but by folding at the hips. The backfist whistled over his crown and clipped his topknot tie; string fluttered. He came up inside the Jigen-ryū man’s guard and jammed a low palm under the sternum. The shock staggered the larger man half a step. He responded with a short headbutt forward, skull to face. The Piguaquan fighter’s forehead dipped to intercept with the hard front, and they clacked bone on bone; both saw white sparks. They broke contact—Jigen-ryū retreating one, two short steps to regain full structure, Piguaquan sliding left around the beam’s end, knees full of spring. Their breath steamed in the cold. The trickle kept stitching the floor, quiet and implacable. The Jigen-ryū fighter adjusted his footwork to trap the stream between them and the beam, betting on the treachery beneath the Piguaquan fighter’s feet. His own left foot planted dry; his right pointed toward the center, hips half-closed. He feinted a step left, then shot right, cutting across the stream with a long, stamping step that splashed water onto his calf. Momentum carried him; he timed it to land just to the Piguaquan fighter’s outside, left shoulder driving a body check to pin him to the beam. The Piguaquan fighter saw the line. He retreated one step, then two, letting the check come, then turned—a quick pivot on the left foot—so his right shoulder presented to the impact, not his chest. The Jigen-ryū man’s shoulder thudded into solid deltoid and slid. The Piguaquan fighter let his back brush the beam, then used it. He coiled, the spine bending slightly around the wood, and flung his right arm in a tight circle over and down. His forearm crashed like a falling branch onto the Jigen-ryū man’s clavicle. The Jigen-ryū man’s teeth clacked and he surged anyway, hands seeking to clamp the waist. The Piguaquan fighter dived his left hand under the belt line, palm up, and wedged his forearm against the inside of the Jigen-ryū’s right elbow, prying space. He dropped his hips, slid left along the beam, and took the Jigen-ryū man past him, not quite a throw, but a guided stumble that sent the larger man’s lead foot onto the wet. It was the sound more than the sight—a rubber sole squeaking on a pane of glass. The Jigen-ryū man’s weight pitched forward. His right foot shot out to catch himself on dry stone. He found it, but the moment’s divide between left sliding and right planting rattled through his structure. He cut the stumble by sinking weight violently, turning the tilt into a driven stomp, and returned fire instantly: a right straight at face height, legs low and coiled. The Piguaquan fighter didn’t attempt a full dodge. He turned his head, let the fist brush his cheekbone and ear, and accepted the scrape rather than the crush. It cut skin; a line of red opened on pale. He used that proximity to empty his hands into the Jigen-ryū man’s ribs—left, right, both open-handed slaps that whipped from the shoulder with loose wrists, cracking like wet towels. The sound was obscene in the quiet after the squeak. The Jigen-ryū man’s left elbow dug in to shield, and he took the hits on bone, then countered with a left short hook to the temple. The Piguaquan fighter brought his right forearm up like a door, met the hook on the mid-forearm, absorbed and slid it off, his hand continuing on to cuff the back of the Jigen-ryū man’s head. He tugged, not to pull down, but to misalign. The Jigen-ryū man moved with the tug and then against it, snapping his head back up and stepping his right foot outside, left following, re-centering. He released the labyrinth of elbows and forearms and returned to his pure line. He vanished for a heartbeat, the whole body contracting, then reappeared, launching a straight blast of two punches: right to chest, left to mouth. It was a rectangle of violence, perfectly squared, as if he were cutting a brushstroke through water. The Piguaquan fighter stepped back, left foot along the edge of the stream, right foot crossing behind to a diagonal retreat, body bladed. The first punch drove into his right shoulder. He rolled with it, letting the pressure rotate him instead of crush him. The second came for his face; he ducked under and reappeared at the Jigen-ryū man’s right side. He coiled in, hips turning left, then snapped out with a long left backfist that whipped from shoulder to eyebrow. Knuckles raked skin. The Jigen-ryū man’s eye flashed water and blood. He snarled, not in anger but in focus, and kicked low, a stomping side kick to the Piguaquan’s shin. It connected and hurt; the Piguaquan fighter shifted weight to save the joint, hopped his left foot back, right foot out, drawing a crescent again, and used the motion to whip a right-hand downward chop at the Jigen-ryū man’s neck. They were both breathing hard now. The air skinned their lungs with cold. The crowd’s sound rose and fell, a tide lapping against stone. The Jigen-ryū fighter had eaten counters, but he hadn’t slowed. He compressed the space again, right foot forward, left glued to the floor, and went for decisive end. He reached not with fists but with the whole right side—shoulder, hip, knee—an oblique slam meant to take the Piguaquan fighter off his base and into the ground where one or two hammerfists would end it. He stepped through the stream to do it, trusting his speed to outrun the slick. His left foot slid a fraction on the film of water. The fraction mattered. The hit landed not with the clean thud of structure, but with a glancing shove that pushed rather than crushed. The Piguaquan fighter absorbed through knees and spine, let himself be pushed, then rotated around the point of contact. His left hand slapped the Jigen-ryū’s scapula to guide, his right carved up and then down in a vertical circle that ended at the base of the skull. The blow snapped the head; the Jigen-ryū man’s hands shot out instinctively to post against the beam. They found ancient wood. Fingers splayed. The Piguaquan fighter took the moment—the structure extended, the weight forward, the slick underfoot—and reaped small. He hooked his right foot behind the Jigen-ryū man’s left heel and drew it a finger’s width. Not a grand throw, but a theft of balance. The Jigen-ryū man’s left foot skated on wet stone, his right planted, his upper body trapped between pushing hands and incoming strike. He made the only correct choice: he dropped. Hips slumped, knees bent, chin tucked, he let himself fall to one knee and turned the fall into a sideways roll, scraping along the beam. The Piguaquan fighter’s downward arc hit shoulder instead of skull, numbing his own forearm with the hardness of bone. He shook out his hand, pain flaring. The Jigen-ryū man rolled to his right, away from the beam, and came up kneeling, left knee down, right foot planted. He rose into a thrust, a spear of body toward the Piguaquan fighter’s center, right hand drilling forward. It was as fast as the first rush. The Piguaquan fighter had stepped back to avoid the rolling knee; his left foot was dry, right near the stream. He took one more half-step back with the right, heel flirting with water, then stopped. As the thrust came, he snapped his hips and ribs right, emptying the line, and used both hands like paddles. Left hand slapped the inside of the Jigen-ryū man’s wrist outward; right hand slapped the triceps inward. The two slaps met, the arm suddenly half-hyperextended across space. He completed the circle by stepping left foot forward and to the outside, chest almost to the Jigen-ryū man’s shoulder, and drove his right forearm down onto the locked elbow. He pulled the power, enough to cripple but not break—some line had not yet been crossed. The joint screamed. The Jigen-ryū man’s fist opened for the first time. His left hand shot for the Piguaquan fighter’s throat. The Piguaquan fighter’s chin dropped; his right shoulder rose, and the grasping fingers caught trapezius instead of windpipe. He rotated under and out, palms skating on the Jigen-ryū’s arm, and whipped his left backfist into the eye again, same cut reopening, blood slick now. The Jigen-ryū man blinked red. He made a last attempt to reclaim center. He stepped back from the stream, planted both feet on dry, and drew in air to
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This martial arts narrative demonstrates exceptional technical precision in depicting a fight sequence between two stylistically contrasting fighters. The author has created a vivid, physically coherent battle that meticulously tracks spatial relationships, momentum shifts, and the tactical exchanges between the Jigen-ryū and Piguaquan practitioners. The setting is established with atmospheric detail - an abandoned temple with collapsed roof, broken flagstones, and a small stream running through the fighting area. This environmental element becomes integral to the fight choreography, with the water creating a hazardous surface that influences footwork and strategy. The author skillfully incorporates this environmental factor throughout the fight, making it a third "character" in the confrontation. The physical descriptions of the fighters' techniques are remarkably precise. Each movement is broken down into component parts - foot placement, weight distribution, angle of attack, and defensive responses. The narrative maintains perfect spatial awareness, allowing readers to visualize exactly where each fighter is positioned relative to the other and to environmental features like the stream and fallen beam. The contrast between fighting styles is expertly portrayed. The Jigen-ryū fighter employs direct, explosive movements with straight-line attacks and rigid structure, while the Piguaquan fighter uses circular, whipping strikes, evasive footwork, and unpredictable angles. These stylistic differences remain consistent throughout the encounter and inform each fighter's tactical choices. The prose achieves a remarkable balance between technical precision and poetic flourish. Descriptions like "the crest and the tide meeting" metaphorically capture the essence of the contrasting styles without sacrificing clarity. The language is crisp yet evocative, with sensory details that immerse readers in the experience. The narrative builds tension effectively through the escalating intensity of exchanges. Each fighter adapts to the other's tactics, creating a dynamic chess match of physical problem-solving. The crowd's reactions provide atmospheric context without distracting from the central action. One minor weakness is that the narrative appears to end mid-sentence ("He drew in air to"), suggesting either an incomplete submission or a word count limitation. This abrupt ending prevents a satisfying resolution to the conflict, leaving readers without closure on this blood debt confrontation. Despite this truncation, the piece excels at its primary objective: depicting a physically coherent, technically precise martial arts duel that honors the distinct characteristics of both fighting traditions. The author demonstrates exceptional knowledge of combat mechanics, spatial awareness, and the psychological dimensions of martial confrontation. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 20 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 20.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Physical-spatial: Breaking Formation — Score: 90.2
Prompt:
**"Breaking Formation"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood who's won a scholarship to an elite K-pop training academy in Seoul. Desperately out of place culturally and technically, they struggle with a militaristically precise choreography that contradicts everything about their improvisational background. The punishing rehearsal takes place under a famous instructor known for breaking students to remake them, who sees potential in the narrator's raw talent but not their attitude. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—each dance move, position shift, and spatial relationship must be tracked with precision throughout the studio. Paint an exceptionally vivid kinetic picture through descriptions that capture not just movement but the contrast between the narrator's fluid, expressive style and the mechanical precision demanded. Their internal monologue should reveal culture shock, class anxiety, and the threatening realization that success here might mean losing their authentic movement voice. Include technical terminology that highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, moments when muscle memory betrays them, and a crucial decision point about whether to conform or rebel. Physical clarity is essential—readers must be able to visualize exactly how bodies move through space, how rhythms align or clash, and how the protagonist's body struggles against unfamiliar discipline. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I step into Studio B with my laces double-knotted because I’m afraid of tripping more than I’m afraid of failing. The floor is maple and glossy, reflecting the ceiling fluorescents and the three lines of dancers like a second army below us. The mirrored wall is a horizon of my own face repeated twenty times, every angle catching the cut under my eye, the scar on my left brow, the sweat already wetting the nape of my neck. We line up in formation: five rows of five, squares on squares. I’m third row, fourth from the left, which puts me slightly behind a guy with a shaved head and hyperextension for days, and slightly ahead of a girl whose ponytail is a metronome. The instructor, Lee seonsaengnim—legendary, cruel, the rumor says—works a folded black hand fan as he walks the ranks like he’s inspecting soldiers. He wears a white tee tucked into track pants and a whistle hangs around his neck, but it’s the fan he uses: open, flutter, snap. He stops at me, looks me up and down, and sets the edge of the fan against my sternum. “Chest neutral,” he says in crisp English, accent slicing syllables. “You’re breathing like you’re about to fight.” I tuck my ribs and level my head. In my neighborhood, my chest is always up—posture that says I’m here and I’m untouchable. Here, it only makes me taller than I should be, breaks the line. The music cue is a digital click, then the beat drops: a clean four-on-the-floor with a syncopated hi-hat pattern. “Counts,” he says. He raises the fan, and thirty bodies ready themselves. “Five, six, seven, eight.” First eight-count: A transfer weight right-left, feet hip-width parallel, hands parked at chest level in a hard 90, elbows slicing space on the half-beat. I mirror the shaved-head guy exactly: shift my weight onto the ball of the right foot on the one, roll through to heel on the two, then left foot on the three, plant on the four. Hands—get the hands—he’s palms down, wrists flexed, fingers tight. My fingers want to be loose, to flick out on the ands, to smear sound with movement. I clamp them. “Level one,” Lee says, and we’re on demi-plié from the start. Knees track over toes. No bounce, no bobble. I’m used to groove, the pulse that lives in my torso, the bounce that marks what the DJ doesn’t. They strip it out here. My quads are already shaking, micro-tremors I hope no one sees. Second eight-count: A chest pop on the one—sharp, isolated, like a muscle clap—then a lat spread and a quick contraction to zero. They all hit at the same time, thirty torsos exploding and imploding on a cue so clean it’s surgical. Mine is late by a hair because my body wants to give it sauce, wants to let it travel into my shoulders and down to my hips. “Hit, hit,” Lee snaps, and the fan flies open on a silent one-two, a butterfly blade of reprimand. We move downstage on the three with two steps—right then left—on a diagonal forty-five toward the front corner. The spacing is precise: we pass invisible lines marked by tape on the floor, white T’s and X’s that map the universe of this routine. My tape mark is a small cross; on the four I must land with my right foot exactly on the top of it. I land half a foot ahead and have to adjust. The girl with the ponytail shifts a centimeter left to absorb me, and her eyes in the mirror shoot me a warning. The entire grid relies on each of us. In the cyphers back home, grid is for battle: get in, get out, push them into the edge. Here, grid is law. Third eight-count: A wave starting from the right fingertips traveling through wrist, elbow, shoulder, chest, ribs, hips, knees, ankles, toes. The wave is familiar but different. I grew up making water out of air, traveling with the wave as it spills, letting it break through me. Here it’s segmented, each joint a clean switch, the flow disguised as mechanism. We end it with a freeze: right arm in a blade across the chest, left elbow high, chin tucked, gaze to left front. The instructor walks by. “No head,” he says, tapping my temple lightly with the fan as I slightly tilt to sell it. “Head steady.” We repeat. The kick-ball-change in eight four is the first test of my heel-toe vocabulary. They want a clean pas de bourrée variant: right foot kicks low on one, ball-change left-right on the two and, arms held in second position parallel to the floor. I want to toe in, swivel my heel, drop through my arch and bind it to the floor. I want to eat the floor. I don’t. “Again,” he says. We run it from the top, this time with lyrics: sugary romance with a trap sub-bass. The dynamics are cruel: the song wants softness on the singer’s coo, but the choreographer demands staccato even then. We’re armies in velvet. By the twelfth repetition my calves burn, and sweat builds a slick under my soles that makes my slides dangerous. We’re to step to the right on count five of eight five, foot dragging to a close on seven with no sound. They all skitter silently; my shoe squeaks, a small betrayal. The fan snaps shut. “Stop.” We freeze with our knees bent, hands high in a V. He walks past us, through us, like a conductor through a frozen orchestra. He stops behind me where I can’t use the mirror and puts his cool hand on my lumbar spine. “Neutral pelvis,” he says, pressing my low back forward. My pelvis wants to spill like a bowl tipping to pour. “Posterior tilt. Tuck,” he says. I fight my lordotic back until my core shakes. He taps the back of my left calf with the fan. “No sickle. Heel forward, knee tracking.” The fan snaps open and I flinch. “Again.” We run the cannon: on eight six, line one hits the floor to plank, line two follows on the one, then line three on the two—that’s me—line four on the three, and so on. We become a wave of folding bodies. I drop to plank on my two, shoulders over wrists, fingers spread, abdomen contracted. My right leg wants to slide out and hook because my breaking brain thinks freeze set; instead it’s a controlled step back to a hover. On the four and, we push back to crouch, then on the five we roll through the spine to standing, articulating from sacrum to skull. The shaved-head guy’s roll is textbook. Mine is a shiver. I hear my coach’s voice from home—I never had a coach—just my cousin yelling, “Spine like a rope, bae-bee,” and I’m thinking rope while he’s thinking vertebrae. The difference is audible to the room. “Precision,” Lee says. “Not vibe.” On eight eight, an isolation sequence: head right-left-right center in exact quarter-beats, eyes tracking like a doll. No neck. We all do it in unison and the mirror shows twenty heads snapping perfectly, twenty pairs of eyes clicking left, left, left, then center. Mine lags by a heartbeat because my instincts want to break the beat, to ride the and. My mouth tastes like copper. I have to breathe less so my chest stays still. Water breaks here are rationed by the fan. It snaps shut and we stop. It snaps open, we go. It snaps halfway, and we hover, sweat strings hanging from our chins as we hold plank for another eight. “Your groove pollutes the line,” he says to me without looking up from his clipboard. “We are not in your alley. We are on stage. People pay to see math.” He looks up and smiles almost pleasantly. “But you have something. You move like your joints are teaching your bones.” I swallow. My class shows in the way I drink, fast and greedy, the plastic bottle crinkling, no towel to dab, just the back of my hand. The others sip and blot, their towels monogrammed with the academy logo. I shove my bottle back into my bag and someone’s perfume hits me, sweet and expensive, and I smell myself—underarm and effort. My mouth is dry as chalk. He calls formations. “Section B, ripple one to five on the kick. You,” he points with the fan at me, “be the axis on X three.” X three is dead center, third row, the spine of the piece. I switch places with a girl whose face is smooth like glass and she bows a little as we pass. I step onto the tape and my foot covers the X precisely, heel in line with the vertical strip. The responsibility makes my stomach sink. This is geometry that determines where everyone lands on the last hit. We go. The ripple on the kick is a travel: right knee comes up to hip height on the three, foot flexed, then a straight extension to a low développé on the four, heel slicing out, as line one kicks on the three, line two on the three and, and so on. I must hold my lift until the four and to be the axis, stately and still while motion moves around me. My instinct is to use the knee as a pump, to let it drive a top-rock step across my body, to add a little chest circle on the delay. I keep the knee like a metronome instead, everything dead still except that one leg. I feel air move as line one’s kicks slice past, then line two. My hamstring clenches like a fist. On the five, we all drop together into a jazz fourth, left leg forward, right leg back, both heels flat, weight on the front foot. Hands snap to first position—no, not ballet—first position of street jazz, fists near chin, elbows in. I feel ridiculous and precise and pinched. Eight ten is pure ranae—a barrel turn traveling left into a running man variation that sits in the pocket of the chorus. Barrel turn means both arms up, right across the face, left sweeping, eyes spotting on an imaginary mark on the mirror, torso leaning back, knees tucked as we rotate. My barrel is meatier, always has been; I’m used to throwing my weight and catching it in a freeze. Here, the turn lands on the toes, soft knees, immediate run-run with the legs cycling in place, torso calm while the feet do the work. I count: one to prep, two to jump, three to rotate, four to land, and on the and we’re already in running man, right foot forward, left foot back, then switch on the and and shift lower on the two. My foot catches on sweat and I nearly slide. I tighten my core and adjust. The shaved-head guy’s shoulder grazes mine on the turn because my arc is too wide; I alter my radius on the next run so his and my lanes don’t collide. “Lower,” says Lee, and the fan kisses the back of my thighs. I sink an inch. He brushes the fan along my forearm and I flatten my wrist, the blade of my hand slicing cleaner. Eight twelve is where my body betrays me. The choreo wants a tutting sequence: wrists hinge ninety degrees, elbows fold into sharp angles, forearms draw boxes, then a quick rotation that stacks the hands in a staircase formation in front of the face. In battle I’d melt the corners, turn the boxes into smoke, use the breath to push it. My muscles go to soft edges, and the instructor shrills the whistle. The fan slams shut like a gunshot. “You draw a circle,” he says, disgust sugar. He positions my hands himself. He’s gentle but final, placing my right forearm parallel to floor at lip level, left forearm vertical, fingers together, thumbs hidden. “Box. Not cloud. Again.” We do the tut. I count as my joints click: one wrists, two elbows, three shoulders, four rotate, five flat, six step, seven lift, eight freeze. I keep my breath steady so no extra movement lifts my chest. I’m a building. We finish the section, and on the last eight we hit a formation change: rows fold like an accordion, first row turns to face upstage, second row slides left via a grapevine—cross behind, side, cross front, together—third row, my row, rotates ninety degrees to face stage right, stepping right foot open on the one, left foot closes on the and, and we all end up in staggered diagonal lines, windows open between bodies. My peripheral vision tracks the ponytail girl; she is my window partner. I adjust my spacing with quarter-steps so that in the mirror our shoulders do not overlap. The song stops before the last chorus. Fan snap. “Pause,” he says. He regards us. “If you are here, you will be broken and rebuilt. Some of you already know your shape,” he says, eyes on me, “but your shape is not our product.” He lets the fan rest against his shoulder, closed. “Decide if you want to be a product.” I feel the room tilt. The sweat has cooled on my back and suddenly I’m cold. Back home, my body is a story only I can read. Here, my body is a font they can typeset. In the mirror, thirty faces watch him, then watch themselves. It’s a hall of versions. My muscles hum with the groove I keep suppressing. We go again, from the top. Everything falls into the same clicks, the same joints. I know this is how you get paid. This is how you film a music video, how you make sure the camera finds the angle and the angle is exact. Money is precise like that. On eight sixteen we have a minimal freestyle, four counts of choice before the final drop, but choice is not choice here. They all slip in a prescribed swagger, a tiny approved head nod, a pre-chosen hand path. My turn. My shoulder wants to roll big, to let the clavicle glide forward and down, ribs figure-eight, weight shift through the right hip, toe dig, heel swivel, then a soft jack in my chest that nobody expects. It will ruin the line. It will announce me. The count approaches: five, six, seven— The metronome in my head splits in two. One voice says hit their box. Another says bleed out. I take a breath and my spine stacks straight. On my four counts I choose a compromise I’m not sure I respect: I tuck the jack down into microscopic form, barely a tremor through my sternum that only I feel. My right hand, instead of flying into a swipe, flicks at the wrist on the ands, sharp and within the line. I let my eyes flare for a second, a flash, then drop back to neutral. It’s so small nobody can punish it, so small it feels like a secret I keep under the floorboards. The drop comes and we all drop with it, thirty bodies hitting the same full-out move on the beat. The air thumps around us. As we finish, the fan snaps shut. Silence. He looks at me, head tilted. The corner of his mouth moves a millimeter. “Better,” he says. “Not you. But better.” We hold the ending shape: knees bent, right fist near left cheek, gaze upstage. My quads scream. I lock it. In the mirror my face is someone I don’t know, but my eyes are mine. I’m still in there, somewhere between the tape X under my heel and the alley with chalk lines and broken glass. He opens the fan again and the wind from it touches my jaw. “Again.”
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the experience of a street dancer navigating the rigid world of K-pop training. The piece excels in its physical specificity, tracking movements with precision while maintaining the narrator's distinct voice throughout. The technical dance terminology is impressively deployed, creating a vivid contrast between the narrator's fluid street style and the mechanical precision demanded by the academy. Terms like "demi-plié," "pas de bourrée," "tutting sequence," and "développé" are used accurately and contextually, showing the collision between street and commercial dance vocabularies. The physical coherence is exceptional. Each movement is tracked with clarity - from weight transfers to hand positions, from spatial relationships to formation changes. The writer maintains awareness of the entire studio space, including the positions of other dancers, the instructor's movements, and the protagonist's placement within formations. The description of tape marks on the floor (X3, T's) helps establish spatial awareness. The internal monologue effectively reveals the narrator's culture shock and class anxiety. Small details like drinking water "fast and greedy" versus how others "sip and blot," or noticing the expensive perfume while being conscious of their own body odor, subtly establish class differences. The threat to the narrator's authentic movement voice is palpable throughout, culminating in the crucial decision point where they make a small compromise - hiding a subtle movement that's true to their style while conforming enough to avoid punishment. The instructor character is well-developed through actions and sparse dialogue. His use of the fan as both tool and weapon creates tension, and his final assessment - "Better. Not you. But better" - perfectly encapsulates the central conflict. The prose is elegant and rhythmic, often mirroring dance itself. Sentences vary in length and structure, creating a cadence that enhances the kinetic quality of the narrative. Metaphors are fresh and specific to the context: "thirty bodies hitting the same full-out move on the beat. The air thumps around us." Where the piece could improve is in providing slightly more background about the narrator's home environment. While we get glimpses ("In my neighborhood, my chest is always up"), a bit more concrete detail about their street dance background would strengthen the contrast. Additionally, while the ending effectively captures the narrator's internal conflict, it doesn't quite resolve the tension between conformity and rebellion - though this ambiguity may be intentional. Overall, this is an exceptionally strong piece that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt with technical precision, emotional depth, and stylistic flair. The writer demonstrates deep knowledge of dance terminology while maintaining accessibility, and creates a compelling character study of someone caught between worlds. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Gothic-fantasy-humour: Court of the Dreaming — Score: 90.5
Prompt:
Court of the Dreaming: Territorial Dream Dispute. Write a dark fantasy scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream where a case is being heard to determine ownership of a contested dreamscape. Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit who sits on sleepers' chests causing paralysis and terror, has recently invaded and subverted a carefully crafted recurring dream of a schoolboy, Max. The dream originally featured the boy lying in a field of wildflowers with his crush, always culminating in a muddled almost-kiss and a pleasant confusion of emotions. This dream was the meticulous work of "First Love" (a rosy-cheeked, slightly bashful entity who crafts formative romantic experiences).
