However, Mora has recently infiltrated the dreamscape, transforming the scene so that when the girl playfully mounts the boy, she morphs into a terrifying yet somehow still confusingly attractive vision who proceeds to sit on his chest and feed on his breath. Mora's defense largely consists of the practical argument that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" Write this scene as it unfolds in the courtroom of the Dreaming, with Dream's demeanour, typically impenetrable, betraying a sense of irritation at having to adjudicate such matters. The comedy should derive from the farcical situation, familiar elements of courtroom drama intersecting with the fantastical world of the Dreaming, and the droll portrayal of the characters and their interactions. The humor should be dark and understated throughout. Dream is tempted to some mischief in the resolution of the case. Use descriptives sparingly when setting scene. Write for readability & engagement. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Court of the Dreaming opened with a hush like a bed sheet settling. Court spires melted upward from a starless ceiling and cramped down again in the same breath, as if reality itself were adjusting its collar. Candles burned with a light too soft to see by and too bright to ignore. On the bench, Dream sat in sable, hair like spilled ink across his shoulders, posture that dared anyone to find him human. His expression was a mask of patience with the lacquer sanded thin. “Come to order,” intoned the bailiff, a faceless knight in a nightcap. His voice rolled out doom across the sleeping world. “All rise for Morpheus, Lord of the Dreaming, the Prince of Stories, the—” The voice faltered. “The Judgy One.” Dream’s gaze moved. Entire cities died in that glance. “Proceed,” he said. “At issue,” droned the clerk, who wore a powdered wig full of moths, “a contested dreamscape. The People—by which we mean, the populace of sleepers, dreamers, and other rights-bearing persons, living or dead—versus Mora of the Night, eater of breath, rider of ribs, visitor upon chests, the—” “I know who she is,” Dream said. Irritation sharpened the syllables. He turned his attention to the table of the defense. Mora lounged there with the casual poise of a cat draped over a tombstone: long-limbed, pale as milk gone bad, hair in inky ropes, a seamstress’s measure of a smile. She lifted a hand and wiggled her fingers at Dream. Her nails were bitten blunt. At the petitioner’s table sat First Love—rosy-cheeked, in a cardigan knit from blushes, ears a perpetual shade redder than the rest of him, a pair of shy dimples carved into his awkward face. He clutched a clipboard packed with paper hearts, each scrawled with looping handwriting, and tried not to make eye contact with anyone. The bailiff lifted a scroll. “Call to the stand—” He inhaled and exhaled thunder. “EFF-FFF-FFFF…” “First Love,” said Dream, flatly. “Yes. First Loaf,” boomed the bailiff, triumphant. “Approach.” The candles shivered. First Love rose, straightened his cardigan, and shuffled to the stand. He glanced around, then placed one hand on a book that wrote itself as he touched it. The words flowed across the pages like spilled soda: awkward, heartfelt, sticky. “State your name for the record,” the clerk said, bored. “First Love,” he whispered. “Fur Sloth,” repeated the bailiff. Somewhere, a nightmare applauded. “Mr. Love,” said Dream. “Your complaint.” First Love swallowed. His voice came soft, with the tremble of a first confession. “Max—his name is Max—twelve years old. This is… it’s a foundational script. A field of wildflowers. Grass stains on knees. The smell of cut apples. He and she laugh without knowing why. The almost-kiss. It’s not… perfect.” He looked down. “I don’t do perfect. I do formative. It’s meant to be gentle confusion. A good ache.” “And then,” said Dream, “Mora.” Mora crossed one long leg over the other. The metal of her anklet—the kind that might be a shackle if you tilted your head—clinked. “And then me. Hello.” First Love’s ears went pinker. “She has turned it—she has turned it into paralysis and dread. Which is, you know, stunningly on-brand for her. But it corrupts the mood, Your—your Lordness.” “Objection,” said Mora. “Moods are notoriously corruptible.” “We’re not at objections,” Dream said. His tone suggested that if they were, no one would enjoy it. “Describe the alteration.” First Love’s eyes glistened. “They’re in the field. She’s playful. She—she rolls on top of him.” A small smile broke and died. “And that’s new, yes, but not disallowed. Curiosity gets braver with rehearsal. But then she… changes. Her mouth becomes… too many. Teeth, and prettiness layered like a trap, and the weight… He can’t move. She sits on his chest and drinks, and he knows he is dying. And then he wakes up and thinks of her and cannot separate it from fear and shame. And breakfast is ruined.” “Yes, well,” said Mora, examining a nonexistent cuticle, “a girl’s gotta eat, too, you know?” A murmur skittered through the galleries—harpies, accountants, a choir of sleeping dogs. Dream’s gaze sliced it off. He turned to Mora. “Your plea.” “Innocent by necessity,” she said, and bared teeth that were almost straight. “Yourness, I don’t ruin what has no structure. He had a structure. Cute little thing. Laces tight. You could bounce a coin off that anticipatory tension. Fields, flowers, fumbling. Delicious. I did what I do. I sat. I fed. I seasoned it with desire because I’m not a monster.” She tilted her head. “All the way.” First Love groaned softly into his sleeve. “Jurisdiction,” the clerk muttered to himself, underlining the word five times for no one to see. Dream listened. His face revealed the weary anger of an architect compelled to arbitrate over a scuffed hallway carpet. “You claim right of harvest,” he said. “I claim the open window,” Mora said. “He made himself a stage.” She flicked her eyes to First Love. “He put a body on another body without a script. The body is heavy. It breathes. It smells. It confuses. There’s an invitation in that. He left a plate on the counter and wrote my name on it in lip gloss.” First Love blinked furiously. “It was a kiss! An almost-kiss! You are not invited to everyone’s first almost-kiss.” Mora’s smile deepened. “You never did appreciate what else that moment holds. I’m not the villain. I’m the gravity.” The bailiff cleared his nonexistent throat. “Call the witness… MAX-AX-AX-AX-AX.” From the side door shuffled a boy with bedhead and a superhero T-shirt. His sneakers weren’t tied. Dream’s shadow flared and recoiled as the child approached the stand, for children bring their own darkness. Max rubbed his nose and glared at everything equally. “State your name for the record,” sighed the clerk. “Max.” “Maxwell?” prompted the bailiff. “Max.” “Very well. Maximus.” The bailiff sounded pleased with himself. Somewhere in the rafters, a spider facepalmed. Dream leaned forward slightly. Rain in deserts sensed it. “Max,” he said, voice a lullaby that could smother. “Tell me about your dream.” Max shrugged, then remembered he was on a stand and tried to shrug like it meant nothing. “It’s dumb. We’re in the field behind the school. It smells like gym socks and flowers. She laughs at something I say that wasn’t funny. It’s good. I don’t know. Then she’s… she’s on me and I can’t move. It’s like when your cat sits on you but the cat is your homework. It’s—” He swallowed. “It’s scary. Also… not. My stomach does the… roller coaster thing. I wake up and my mouth feels like pennies and my chest hurts and I don’t wanna go to school but I kinda do.” First Love stared at his shoes. Mora rested her chin on her knuckles and looked tender for half a blink. Dream’s irritation lifted and then fell again, like the wingbeat of a bat. “Do you wish to be rid of it?” Dream asked. Max scowled. “I don’t wish anything. If I wish, it changes and then it’s dumb. And I don’t wanna tell my mom.” He thought. “Can you… not make it be about… dying? But also not make it, like, boring? ‘Cause if it’s boring I’ll just dream about teeth falling out again and that’s worse.” The court considered this practical theology. “No further questions,” First Love murmured. “I mean, if that’s okay.” Mora spread her hands. “Child’s got taste.” “Defense’s witness?” the clerk prompted lazily. Mora gestured, and shapes swam up from under the floor: night terrors, nervous giggles, that feeling when you think someone called your name and no one did. “I could parade a hundred sleepers whose hearts I’ve tickled into beating properly. Fear teaches caution. Appetites are real. You all take your cuts—” she nodded at First Love, at the smug cherub of Nostalgia dozing in the back row, at a crone with a satchel labeled Grief—“and when I take mine it’s a scandal.” First Love lifted his chin. “We’re not in dispute about your right to exist. We’re disputing your right to sit on his chest during The Moment.” “The Moment,” Mora repeated, amused. “Is that your title? Do you capitalize it when you write it in your little diary?” “It’s a rolodex,” First Love muttered. The bailiff rumbled, overpronouncing gravity itself. “Closing statements from Fur Sloth and More—AHHH.” Dream raised a pale palm. Silence fell like fresh snow. “Enough,” he said. “You will both kindly recall that this is not a market stall. You squabble in a court where empires have begged for smaller nightmares.” He looked at Max, then at the confusion braided through him, then at the path First Love had laid so neatly, then at the havoc Mora trailed like perfume. The irritation in him sharpened to something that might almost be mischief. “I will render judgment,” Dream said, and all things held their breath. “Mora,” he continued, “you trespassed into a constructed scene under the care of a recognized artisan. The invitation you claim was ambiguous. You may not squat on ambiguity like a toad on a lily pad and call it yours.” Mora’s mouth twitched. “I heard ‘squat’ and felt seen.” “Nevertheless,” Dream went on, “you remind this court that bodies weigh, and that confusion is not solely gentle. On certain nights, fear is educational. On others, it is theft.” He turned to First Love. “You made a meadow and forgot the ants. You set a blush upon a face and forgot that a blush is a heat.” First Love opened his mouth, closed it, nodded. “So,” said Dream, in that voice that maps realities. “Mora is enjoined from feeding upon Max during The Moment in the field of wildflowers. She may observe from the hedgerow. If she must sit upon a chest, she will do so later, upon nights designated by me when the dream turns to other lessons.” Mora hissed softly, but it was respectful, like steam from bread. “Define ‘observe,’ Yourness.” “You may hover,” Dream said, with the faintest quirk at the edge of his mouth. “You may loom. You may roll your eyes. You may not pin, press, or drink. If you must suffocate something, suffocate a metaphor.” “Fine,” she said. “But I’m bringing a snack.” “First Love,” Dream said, “you will complicate your meadow. There will be gnats. The girl will sneeze. The kiss will remain almost, but there will be the weight of a forearm wrongly placed, the heat of a summer day, the embarrassment that follows. You will not counterfeit ease. You will respect the body’s insistences.” First Love nodded eagerly, already pulling out his pencil, already scribbling gnats with penitential fervor. “Max,” said Dream, and the boy flinched even though he had heard his name said quietly. “When you wake, you will remember both. The sweetness and the fear. You will decide nothing. It is not time to decide. But later, when you are older and a cat sits on your chest and you cannot breathe—” He paused, reconsidered the domesticity. “When someone’s arm is heavy on you, you will think: I know this. And you will negotiate. And that is a better lesson than never having been pressed at all.” Max’s face did an expression like a shrug learning how to smile. “Okay,” he said. “Can she—” He jerked his chin at Mora. “—not make the mouth thing happen? It’s gross.” Mora sighed like curtains. “I’ll keep my face on,” she said. “Happy?” He made the face that said: don’t push it. Dream settled back. “One more thing,” he said. The court tightened. Mischief reached up a pale hand from under his judgments and tugged. “On a single night of my choosing, neither of you will enter Max’s dream. He will stand alone in his meadow and realize nothing happens unless he chooses it. He may pick a flower. He may walk away. He may trip over his own feet. The dream will remember.” First Love paled. Mora’s eyebrows went up. The clerk made a small note that read: precedent, ugh. The bailiff boomed, “So ruled by the Lord of Nightmares and Nice Things.” Dream’s look chilled the word nice into something with teeth. “Adjourned,” he said. The court dissolved like a yawn. Mora sashayed close as shadows drew away, bending low enough that her hair brushed the edge of Dream’s bench. “You’re getting soft,” she murmured, amused. Dream regarded her with the impassivity of a coffin lid. “And you,” he said, “are getting sentimental.” His eyes flicked to Max, who was kicking at a dream pebble with his dream shoe. “Try not to trip him on the stairs.” “No promises,” she sang, and vanished into the folds of the next sleeper’s blanket. First Love shuffled up, clutching his clipboard. “Thank you,” he said, not meeting Dream’s eye. “I’ll, um. I’ll add gnats.” “Add also the taste of apple skin,” Dream said, almost absentmindedly. “He will remember the bitter under the sweet.” First Love smiled, not entirely tragically, and left smelling of pencil shavings and nerves. Max remained, briefly. “Are you gonna, like, check on me?” he asked the emptying throne. Dream looked down at the boy’s scuffed shoes, at the cowlick that defied the night itself. “Always,” he said, and meant it the way weather means to happen. “Cool,” Max said. “Don’t be weird.” Dream’s expression almost moved. “I will try,” he said, which in his mouth could be a joke. The bailiff, forgetting himself, intoned, “Court is… asleep.” Then, realizing, corrected, “Adjourned!” Somewhere, a sunrise was late by a minute while the world waited to see whether Dream would smile. He did not. But he did allow himself, as the candles died into clean dark, the ghost of it. Then he stood, irritation neatly shelved, mischief humming, and went to set a night aside for no witnesses at all.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkable achievement in dark fantasy with comedic elements. The author has created a fully realized Court of the Dreaming with Dream (clearly inspired by Neil Gaiman's Sandman) presiding over a territorial dispute between First Love and Mora, a Slavic nightmare spirit. The writing excels at establishing a unique atmosphere that balances the fantastical with the mundane. The courtroom setting provides a familiar framework that grounds the surreal elements, creating effective comedy through the juxtaposition of legal proceedings with dream logic. The bailiff's booming voice that echoes and distorts names is a particularly clever touch that maintains the otherworldly quality while adding humor. Character development is exceptional. Dream is portrayed with appropriate gravitas and subtle irritation, maintaining his enigmatic nature while showing hints of mischief. Mora is delightfully unapologetic and pragmatic about her nature, with lines like "a girl's gotta eat too" and "I'm not the villain. I'm the gravity" revealing her complexity. First Love is endearingly awkward with his "cardigan knit from blushes" and clipboard of paper hearts. Even Max, the human at the center of the dispute, has a distinct voice and personality. The prose strikes an excellent balance between poetic and functional. Descriptions like "Dream sat in sable, hair like spilled ink across his shoulders" and "his expression was a mask of patience with the lacquer sanded thin" create vivid imagery without becoming overwrought. The author knows when to deploy metaphor and when to be direct. Dialogue is consistently strong, with each character having a distinct voice. Dream speaks with authority and economy, Mora with casual confidence, First Love with hesitation and earnestness, and Max with the blunt practicality of a child. The exchanges between characters reveal their motivations and relationships naturally. The resolution is particularly satisfying, with Dream finding a compromise that acknowledges the value in both First Love's gentle confusion and Mora's introduction of fear and weight. His final judgment shows wisdom and nuance, recognizing that both experiences have value in Max's development. The piece does occasionally risk becoming too clever for its own good, with some metaphors that might be a bit strained ("a book that wrote itself as he touched it. The words flowed across the pages like spilled soda: awkward, heartfelt, sticky"). However, these moments are rare and generally work within the dreamlike context. The ending avoids sentimentality while still providing emotional resolution. Dream's "Always" in response to Max's question about checking on him is a perfect note of understated care, and Max's "Don't be weird" brings a final touch of humor that grounds the fantastical proceedings. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that successfully blends dark fantasy, comedy, and emotional depth while maintaining a consistent tone and voice throughout. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Blood Moon — Score: 92.8
Prompt:
Blood Moon Alucard & Yennefer Write a story where Alucard (Hellsing) encounters Yennefer (The Witcher) in medieval Europe. Yennefer's magical abilities intrigue the vampire, while she's both repulsed and fascinated by his monstrous nature. Their power dynamic shifts constantly as they circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first. **Alucard (Hellsing)** Alucard is an ancient, immensely powerful vampire who works for the Hellsing Organization. He can regenerate from almost any wound and shape-shift at will. He's sadistic, arrogant, and takes pleasure in toying with his enemies before killing them. Despite being a monster, he despises weak vampires who can't accept their nature. He wears a distinctive red coat, wide-brimmed hat, and orange sunglasses. He uses massive handguns loaded with silver bullets. He seeks worthy opponents who can challenge him and potentially end his immortal existence. Famous quote: "The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame." **Yennefer of Vengerberg (The Witcher)** Yennefer is a powerful sorceress who magically altered her appearance to hide her congenital hunchback. She's ambitious, stubborn, and manipulative when necessary. She has violet eyes and smells of lilac and gooseberries. Despite her cold exterior, she desperately wants to reverse her infertility caused by magical transformation. She's centuries old but appears young. She's politically savvy and refuses to be underestimated. She has a sarcastic sense of humor and little patience for fools. Though she rarely shows it, she's capable of deep love and loyalty. Famous quote: "I'm not sweet and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The wolves start the choir long before the moon clears the rib-cage of clouds. Irregular, off-time howls braid the dusk, some near, most far, a fractured harmony on the borderland of a ruined village. Roofs slump like broken shoulders; a church steeple rises, stiff as a finger, pointing at the blood-red moon making its slow ascent. Wind drags ash and the faint scent of lilac and gooseberries through alleyways littered with bones too old to answer to grief. He arrives as a shadow that walks like a man. Red coat loose, hat brim cutting his face into slashes of pale and darker pale, orange lenses turning the moon to wine in their reflection. He whistles under his breath, a jaunty nothing that gets eaten by the ruins. When the wolves sing again, he smiles as if their discord were the punchline to a very private joke. The ground remembers his weight; it remembers others too—ghouls that puffed to smoke beneath his heel, a priest that crawled toward the cross and found only splinters. The air wavers. He stops. The tremor is not heat—it's intention. The space between two broken walls gathers, pinches, and folds until it becomes a doorway like a wound in the night. Violet light threads its edges. She steps through in a slow, deliberate unfurling of limbs and black hair, the scent sharpening as though every flower in a forgotten garden opens at once and then, just as quickly, shutters. A starched collar, a dark dress that fits like a threat, a glint of obsidian at her throat. Her eyes are amethysts set into a face that does not belong to human weathering. “Mm,” Alucard says, a hum that hangs like a hook. “The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame.” “Quoting alchemical riddles to impress a sorceress?” Yennefer’s voice is as precise as a scalpel and as bored as a queen's at her tenth petition. “How quaint.” Her gaze flicks to the wolves’ horizon, then back to him. “You stink of old blood and older pride.” “And you of lilac and gooseberries. A charming deception for what lies beneath.” He tips his hat in acknowledgement or mockery. “You tore a hole through places to come here. Why this graveyard of houses?” “Because holes are useful. And because something that was not a man once slaughtered its way through this village.” She considers the smear of darkness that was the church. “I wondered if it was still hungry.” Alucard’s smile sharpened into teeth he does not yet show. “It is always hungry. But it learned to savor. You were curious.” He lifts one of the massive handguns; the moon finds his bullet's silver like a friend. “How delightful. Curiosity makes such pretty screams. Come closer.” Yennefer doesn’t move. She folds her arms, one hand curling against the opposite elbow, a posture that reads as idle until you notice how the air tightens to hold her. “I’m not sweet and I’m not a maiden in distress in need of saving,” she says, lazily. “If we cross purposes, I will put you down.” “Promises.” He steps forward; the dirt softens, and the shadows at the hem of his coat drag like wet velvet. “Do you know what you’re speaking to?” “Yes.” Her violet eyes sharpen like knives at a throat. “An old thing given a human name to trick it into a service. A leash disguised as a creed. A dog that learned to enjoy its collar.” He laughs, and it breaks a shutter somewhere. “Hellsing’s dog,” he concedes, with a bow that almost scrapes the ground. “It learned, too, that leashes can be chains and chains can be rosaries. My masters pray and I hunt. Are you another priestess, little witch? Will you anoint me?” Her mouth quirks. “If I lay hands on you, it won’t be to bless you.” Lightning traces the bones of her fingers, blue-white and small as hair, betraying her restraint. The irregular chorus of wolves cuts, and for a breath the only sound is wind. Then one, far away, howls to break the silence again, and the dissonance returns like a heartbeat with arrhythmia. The air folds again. His hand is empty of gun and full of the thin throat of a shattered pew, his other hand clasped behind his back as if at a courtly dance. The pew becomes a stake as he steps and throws, and at the same time the ground under her feet softens, guttering into a mire of shadow hands reaching. The stake slashes the air where she had been. She is not there. She is three strides to the left and three heartbeats younger. She is also above him, perched for a flicker on the fractured steeple, dress whispering. She is also ringed in violet fire, a false afterimage she leaves like a shed skin. He catches one, and it smokes, real enough to burn the flesh of his palm before the fire eats it down to bones. The bones knit themselves back with gleeful obscenity. He licks the soot and laughs. “The tricks you do,” he says. Bullets whisper out, silver signatures that split air into lines that do not exist before he draws them. One hits her—no, hits the air and becomes a flock of birds, their wings cut out of night, scattering with a sound like embroidered thunder. “Do you always play with your food?” she asks, breathless now, amused and irritated in equal measure. She throws a hand down, palm angled; the ground churns, not with shadow hands but with a flash-freeze that crystallizes the earth itself, frost racing like a contagion. The cold bites, and for a heartbeat his steps catch. “Only with the pretty ones.” He disassembles, dissolves; he is a swarm, a storm of bats that either were always there or will only ever be. They knife through violet shields, their edges frost-brittled and painterly. Her hair stands a fraction as magic flares with a voice like a choir singing backward. A circle burns at her feet, the runes a language that hates him, and the bats crackle to ash where they touch it. He reassembles, two paces inside that circle. “Naughty,” he says. “You thought you could keep me outside your little hearth-fire.” Yennefer’s knife is a thought that became steel because she was annoyed, and it is in her hand as it is at his throat and then it is not. Blinding light flares; a column of raw force drives him backward through a wall. Brick makes a sound like teeth. He walks out of debris, dust trickling down the slope of his hat brim, drawing back a mouth that has too many ideas in it about what a mouth should be. “How tiresome.” She pushes a strand of hair behind her ear and lifts her chin. “I’ve faced fiends, djinns, men who thought they owned the continent. You’re just another monster with delusions of philosophy.” “And you’re a child who taught herself to walk like a queen and slit the throats of the words that named you cripple.” He’s beside her, holding her wrist, and then he is not when the wards she pinned to her skin jolt like thunder. His hand smokes; he laughs through it. For a while, conversation is the exchange of punishments. He fires; she folds space so the bullets arrive in the stone behind her and keep going until the village’s skeleton shakes to the rattling of ricochet ghosts. She conjures ropes of light that try to bind him like a promise; he slips them and revisits her with shadows that pull like gravity. He is mist and crows and a man with a gun, and she is ice and fire and air that suddenly clenches, painful pressure like diving too deep. “You want to die,” she observes at last, panting, a thin hairline crack of exertion in her voice. Frost beads her lashes, melts, and slides. “You’re looking for an opponent. How pathetic.” “You want to live.” His glasses are gone. The eyes beneath are suns drowned in blood, pupils thin as wounds. “You play at politics and immortality while your womb is a grave. How pathetic.” They both hesitate, one instant. The wind knifes cold. The wolves’ howl braids in again, all wrong, like someone learning a song by ear and getting the tune almost right. Her temper makes a small noise. She lifts her hand, palm open, and the ruin of the church fills with heat—heat that is not fire but raw conversion, transmutation of air to the idea of summer. The moon curdles, dimmed a shade. “Do not,” she warns, and the warning is a thread pulled taut over a void. “Do not speak of that.” “And if I do?” He steps into the heat and opens his coat as if daring it to find a heart. He burns, and the burning is fast and bright and ends with skin smooth as wine. The living shadow at his feet shivers and mutters to itself. “Will you show me you have one?” She breathes in sharply, and in that inhalation he sees the architecture of centuries—the refusal to bow to the school that should’ve eaten her, the bone-deep scorn for nobles’ games, the quiet, vicious love that fits nowhere but still fills her pockets. It makes him laugh again, sudden and genuine. “I see why men follow you,” he admits. “You’re a tyrant, little witch. You bend crowns the way others bend spoons.” “The way you bend kneecaps.” She smiles, and the violence of it is elegant. “The difference is that mine stay bent when I’m done.” “Perhaps,” he says. He holsters one pistol with a click like a guillotine. The other remains, a suggestion of sincerity. “I didn’t kill you when I could have.” Her gaze flicks to the gun and back, unblinking. “I could have turned your insides out and made a very pretty mural.” A beat. “But I’m not bored enough for trophies.” They circle, and the circling is the dance itself, a ritual of predator courtesy. He steps into her orbit, hat tilted, mouth amused. She steps out, half a quarter turn, skirts brushing rubble. The moon climbs, fattening as if with blood, and the wolves’ chorus keeps its irregular rhythm like a heart learning and failing to learn how to beat. “You work for a house,” she says. “They tell you where to unleash yourself. Do they know where you are?” “They always know, eventually,” he replies. “And then they pretend they ordered me here because it satisfies them to pretend they rule the storm.” He regards the horizon, as if he could taste London in the smoky twilight. “And you? What king or academy owns your leash today?” Her silence is shaped like contempt. “I cut mine years ago.” “And yet.” He points to the fissure in the air through which she came, still shivering slightly where space hates to be wounded. “You answer to necessity.” “We all do.” She tilts her head. “Even you. Especially you.” He bows, too deep to be polite, not deep enough to be sincere. “Come find me when necessity is hunger.” He turns, the coat’s hem trailing newly gathered darkness. “Or when you’re bored.” “I’m not sweet,” she says again, because it pleases her to define the terms. “Nor am I tame,” he answers, and something like satisfaction drags through the words. “The bird of Hermes is my name.” She watches him fade, not into invisibility but into irrelevance, the way night eats a reflected face on a window. The wind picks up, a spectral applause. Her nostrils flare; she tastes iron, ash, and a thread of something that is almost laughter. Her hand lifts, fingers drawing a sign in the air that neither blesses nor curses. The violet lines seal, and the air sighs around the wound as if relieved. The wolves retune, found by some unseen conductor; their calls converge at last into a shivering, proper chorus. Yennefer turns on her heel and disappears, leaving the ruins and the scent of lilac and gooseberries to argue with the cold. The moon climbs on. The village settles. Somewhere, far away, something that is not a man smiles with all its teeth, and a sorceress counts the dukes who will beg and the monsters she will not fear, and the night opens its mouth wider to swallow what comes next. Neither of them will show weakness first. It isn’t in their names. It isn’t in their bones. And the wolves, insistent, keep time to a rhythm older and hungrier than either of them, drumming the blood-right of the dark into the world.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a masterful character study that pits two powerful beings against each other in a dance of power, wit, and vulnerability. The author has created a rich, atmospheric encounter between Alucard and Yennefer that honors both characters' established personalities while exploring new dimensions through their interaction. The prose is exceptional, with a poetic quality that never sacrifices clarity. The author employs vivid imagery that creates a haunting medieval setting with the ruined village, blood moon, and howling wolves providing the perfect backdrop for this supernatural confrontation. Descriptions like "Red coat loose, hat brim cutting his face into slashes of pale and darker pale" and "Her eyes are amethysts set into a face that does not belong to human weathering" efficiently establish character while building atmosphere. The dialogue is particularly strong, capturing both characters' distinctive voices. Alucard's theatrical arrogance and Yennefer's cutting wit come through authentically. Their verbal sparring reveals character while advancing the narrative tension. Lines like "You're a tyrant, little witch. You bend crowns the way others bend spoons" and "I'm not bored enough for trophies" perfectly encapsulate their personalities. The author demonstrates exceptional skill in portraying the power dynamic between these characters. Neither gains a clear upper hand, with the balance of power constantly shifting through their physical and verbal confrontation. The fight sequence is choreographed with imagination and precision, avoiding typical action clichés in favor of surreal, character-specific abilities. Most impressively, the author reveals deeper vulnerabilities in both characters without diminishing their power. Alucard's death wish and Yennefer's infertility are touched upon with subtlety and respect, adding emotional complexity to what could have been a simple battle of monsters. The pacing is excellent, with the tension building naturally through their encounter. The ending avoids resolution in favor of a tantalizing suggestion of future meetings, which feels appropriate for these immortal beings. If there's any criticism to be made, it might be that some passages verge on purple prose, with occasionally overwrought metaphors. However, this stylistic choice largely suits the gothic, supernatural tone of the piece. A few sentences could be tightened for clarity without losing their poetic quality. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of character-driven fiction that succeeds on multiple levels: as fan service for those familiar with the characters, as an engaging standalone story, and as a showcase for sophisticated prose craftsmanship. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 20 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 20.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 86.8
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The rumor starts before Jolyne ever sees the woman: that the new liaison from some government bureau walks past and cameras blink, shutters hiccup, footage turns to snow. That the guards stop asking for paperwork around her the way dogs forget they’re dogs when they see raw steak. The rumor sits wrong in Jolyne’s gut like cafeteria meatloaf. Stone Free hums in the lines of her fingers as she wipes a bead of sweat from her temple. The prison is new concrete and old ghosts, a secret facility buried under layers of legitimate detention, built to house the unhouseable: stands that whisper to their users, devils who agree to contracts in exchange for flesh. The barbed wire is decorative. The real fences are the sigils stamped into the hallways—the algorithms scrawled in chalk that guard the stairwells. Jolyne adjusts her bun with a flick. The butterfly tattoo on her arm flares as she flexes. She’s been here long enough to learn which guards to bribe and which to avoid, long enough to know that the strange happens on a schedule. Long enough to know the schedule is about to be broken. Makima arrives like a sighed secret. She wears a crisp white shirt and a black tie that never wrinkles, black slacks that never gather dust. Her auburn hair is tied neatly, her yellow eyes ringed like a storm viewed from far above. She walks down the D-Block corridor, and as she passes, the fluorescent lights flicker like they’re blinking for her. The cameras above their heads click. They whir. They stop. Jolyne notices. Of course she notices. She’s been counting the second hand in her head, measuring the frames between blinks. She leans against the concrete pillar at the junction, casual as a cat, hands in pockets, looking like she belongs even when she doesn’t. Makima stops, as if she knew Jolyne would be there, as if this moment is a conversation she planned three weeks ago that’s finally arrived exactly on time. “Cujoh Jolyne,” Makima says. Her voice is soft and unhurried, like a balm that hasn’t been applied yet. “I’ve heard of you.” Jolyne snorts. “Yeah? Did the cameras tell you?” She tips her chin at the dead black eye of the nearest lens. “Because I think you broke their hearts.” Makima smiles, small and professional. “Sometimes electronics are unreliable. People, too.” She steps closer. The guards behind her don’t breathe wrong. The warden, usually a blustering idiot with a jaw like a bulldog, stands three paces away with a blankness behind his eyes that makes Jolyne’s skin itch. She can feel Stone Free tugging in her chest, like a cat arching its back, claws unsheathed. “You’re the liaison,” Jolyne says. “The one who can make anyone sit, roll over, and play dead.” Makima’s head tilts an imperceptible fraction. “When people obey, it’s because they want to.” Jolyne bares her teeth in something that isn’t a smile. “Bullshit. I’ve seen want. I’ve seen what it looks like when someone wants and still says no.” There’s a heartbeat where she sees her father’s face—a stern line of mouth, eyes that held an ocean of things he’d never say. “What do you want?” “To keep order,” Makima says. “To protect humanity from forces it’s not equipped to handle.” She says it like a prayer, or a sales pitch, and Jolyne hears the emptiness tucked neatly inside the words. “Protect who from what?” Jolyne asks. “Because last I checked, you people like your lines scratched on the floor. Safety on one side, monsters on the other, and nobody’s allowed to remember which side they’re standing on.” “I’m not your enemy, Jolyne,” Makima says. “I’m fascinated.” Jolyne has heard a hundred versions of that sentence from guards and priests and scientists who wanted to turn her bones into notes in a clipboard. It never landed like this. Makima isn’t watching a person. She’s watching a mechanism she wants to take apart and put back together so that it clicks the way she thinks it should. Makima’s gaze flicks to Jolyne’s hands. “Your Stand is unusual. You become string. You extend yourself. You pull yourself taut. It’s rare to see will expressed so elegantly.” “You talk like a manual, you know that?” Jolyne says. “You wanna see how elegant I get when someone tries to yank me like a leash?” Makima’s smile softens, an actress settling into a role. She could sell you the idea that cages are useful. She could sell you the idea that she loves you while she buckles the collar closed. “Jolyne,” she says, like they’re old friends. “Come with me. I want to show you something.” The air changes when Makima says it. It gets thinner, like Jolyne climbed a mountain she didn’t remember climbing. There’s pressure behind her cheekbones. There’s a sensation like a hand closing gently around the back of her neck. Stone Free’s strings shiver. Jolyne feels an urge to take a step forward that isn’t hers. A practiced reflex snaps into place. Her fingers flick, and the skin of her forearm unspools—bright, blue, fine as fishing line but impossibly strong—wrapping with a whip-crack around the metal railing behind her. The string anchors her like a piton hammered into a cliff face. “Don’t,” Jolyne says through her teeth. “Don’t you dare try to make me heel.” The warden makes a small, strangled sound, like a dog yanked back on a choker chain. Makima’s gaze slides to the invisible thread glued to Jolyne’s spine. She lifts one eyebrow, curious. “Interesting,” she says. “You’re resisting.” “Damn right,” Jolyne says. “If there’s no Mickey, this shit ain’t Disney.” Makima laughs softly. It’s pleasant. It’s reaction without emotion. “You’re brave,” she says. “Bravery is charming. It makes people beautiful, just before they break.” “You’re used to people breaking for you,” Jolyne says. “People who want something so bad they’ll trade their names for it. I’ve made bad trades, lady, but I learned my lesson.” Makima steps closer. The cameras above them judder, then cut, the red indicator lights snuffing like fireflies crushed between fingers. The hallway empties itself of sound. It feels like the world has cupped them in its hands. “I can give you things,” Makima says. “I can give you your father. I can give you a world where he isn’t a ghost locked up in a quiet house behind a silent face. I can give you freedom in a way a Stand never could.” Jolyne’s heartbeat stumbles. There’s a slice of ache under her ribs she keeps in a jar and only opens when she wants to remind herself she can still bleed. “You don’t know anything about my father,” she says. It comes out softer than she wants. Makima doesn’t blink. “I know what men like him look like when they’re ground between duty and love. I know what girls like you look like when you learn to make rope from your own skin because no one else will throw you a line.” Jolyne’s hand tightens. The string around the railing creaks. There’s a sound like paper tearing when she pulls herself upright on the cord and steps past Makima instead of toward her. Not away—but sideways. She has learned there are always angles. “Show me,” Jolyne says. “If what you’ve got is worth my time, show me. But you don’t get a collar on me.” “As you like,” Makima says, and they walk. The facility is a labyrinth of concrete and quiet. Makima leads with her hands folded neatly at the small of her back, not looking at the doors they pass and yet knowing which will open for her and which will not. Behind one glass wall, a man whose skin is a map of bite scars prays without sound to something that has never answered. Behind another, a girl with eyes like black pearls hums a melody that makes Jolyne’s teeth hurt, strings in her fingers vibrating sympathetically. They stop at a room that looks like an operating theater stripped to bone. Surgical lights hang like moons over an empty gurney. On the far wall, a chalk circle etched with symbols that feel like tiny hands scraping the underside of Jolyne’s skull. Makima steps into the room without hesitation. “Contracts are exchanges,” she says. “People want, devils want. I bring them together. I ask for obedience, and they give it, because they want the world to make sense. You, Jolyne—you want to be strong enough to protect the people you love. I can help you.” “By what? Putting a leash on me and calling it a seatbelt?” Jolyne asks. “You think you know how strings work? Strings cut if you pull them wrong.” Makima turns in a slow circle, looking up at the lights, the chalk, the air itself. “Experiments will be conducted here. Safely. With consent.” She looks at Jolyne with those yellow eyes, the rings in them tightening. “I would like to make a contract with you.” Jolyne barks a laugh. “You want me to sign away what, exactly?” “Not sign,” Makima says. “Agree. The word is stronger than ink.” Silence expands. Jolyne can feel the shape of Makima’s power pressing outward. It’s not just hypnosis. It is the kind of authority that you accept because it’s easier than being the person who says no to a crowd. It’s a tide that you mistake for the sea itself. “I’ve been in cages before,” Jolyne says quietly. “I know what lies sound like when they sound like kindness.” Makima’s lashes flutter. For a heartbeat, something like interest flares bright and hot in her gaze. “I’m not lying,” she says, and the thing about it is she believes herself. Jolyne can do sincerity too. She wires the room. She unravels from elbow to wrist, from shoulder to hip, deploying a hair-thin net that threads through vents and around corners, sticks to the seams of the door, licks across the back of the warden’s neck like a threat. She anchors lines to the cameras, slipping a thread into their tiny gears, jerking—softly—and hearing the motor whine like an animal in pain. Her strings taste the people in the corridor—the guards, whose pulses are a little too slow, the girl with the pearl eyes, humming a note of longing, the man praying, the breath that shudders when Makima’s shadow passes him. “Here’s my contract,” Jolyne says. “You tell me why the cameras die when you walk past. You tell me what you did to the warden. You tell me what you want so bad it makes you chew through your own chain, and then maybe I’ll decide if I give a single damn.” Makima watches her string thread a seam of the room like a seamstress tightening a bodice. Her smile is still polite. “I don’t make cameras malfunction,” she says. “They choose, in my presence, to stop. People do, too, sometimes. They choose to listen. The warden chooses to trust. He understands that I am necessary.” “He’s a puppet,” Jolyne says. “You’re holding the crossbar.” “The world is easier if everyone pulls in the same direction,” Makima says. “You understand that. Your Stone Free wants to be a rope, a cable, a line thrown from you to them, and you want to pull the ones you love back to you when they slip.” It’s true. It’s why Jolyne’s lips go white. “What I want,” Makima continues, “is a world where we don’t have to be afraid anymore. A world where Chainsaw Man belongs to me so I can use him to cut away the parts of existence that hurt. Death. War. Hunger. Fear. I will make it better. I will control it until it stops.” “You want a world on a leash,” Jolyne says. “You want puppies that don’t piss on the floor. You want people to die for you when you whistle. You want to act like you’re doing us a favor when you open your hand and we step into your palm. It’s okay, right? Dogs are supposed to die for their owners.” Makima’s smile is a needle. “Yes,” she says simply. The honest answer hits harder than any lie. Jolyne breathes in slowly through her nose. It smells like sterilized instruments and salt and the electric tang of her own string threaded through the world. She remembers her father’s hand on her shoulder—heavy, anchoring—and her mother’s voice, and Hermes’ laugh, and F.F. saying something that’s almost human. She knows what it is to die for somebody. She knows what it is to live for them. “You’re not going to get me to heel,” Jolyne says. “You’re going to have to get used to that, sweetheart.” Makima steps forward, just one step. The room seems to lean toward her. “I don’t have to get used to anything,” she says. “If you oppose me, Jolyne, you will die. Dogs die. Humans die. It happens. But you’re not a dog. You’re interesting.” The compliment is a leash thrown gently over a neck. Jolyne yanks. The string tight around the door’s hinges pulls, and the door slams shut with a clang that reverberates through the bones. The chalk circle on the far wall tears as a filament slices it, and the lights above them pop, one by one, until the room is lit only by emergency strips—thin, wet-looking lines along the floor. Makima’s head turns toward the ruined circle. Her smile doesn’t fade. “You’re impulsive,” she says. “You’d be a delightful pet if you learned your place.” Jolyne spits on the floor. “You keep trying to say place like it’s somewhere I have to stand still,” she says. “News flash: I move.” She does. She throws her strings out like a net, and Stone Free pulls her sideways, up, impossibly agile in a room designed to make people animals. Makima doesn’t move. She doesn’t need to. She looks up, and for a second Jolyne feels the urge again—the urge to stop, to obey, to let her feet find the spot on the floor where the leash would be the least painful. She bites the inside of her cheek until she tastes iron. Her string tightens around her wrist hard enough to bruise. She uses pain the way Makima uses kindness—as a tool, as a wedge. Stone Free hums through her blood. She lands behind Makima. She could wrap. She could choke. She could test, here, whether her string can bind something as polite and monstrous as this. Makima doesn’t turn. “If you try to touch me, you’ll regret it,” she says conversationally. “Lady,” Jolyne says, all her teeth, “I’ve regretted things since I was born.” They hang there for a breath. A battle of wits sharpens on the edge of a blade that hasn’t been drawn yet. Makima is the eye of a storm, and Jolyne is a wire vibrating with too much wind, singing with it. “I’ll be around,” Makima says finally, as if Jolyne agreed to a schedule she didn’t know was being made. “When you’re ready to talk about contracts.” Jolyne snorts. “When I want to talk about cutting strings, I’ll let you know.” Makima walks to the door. Without asking, without touching, the lock opens. The guards outside don’t look up. The cameras flicker as she passes, a shudder of metal and code yielding in the presence of something no algorithm can explain. She is gone. The room breathes again. Jolyne sags, then straightens, rolling her shoulders until her joints pop. Her strings retract, skin knitting, the embedded fibers of Stone Free tucking themselves back into bone and muscle. She rubs her mouth with the back of her hand. The rumor feels different now that it has a face. The cameras aren’t broken. They’re obedient. “Yeah,” Jolyne mutters, to the empty room and the closed circle and the hum of her Stand. “Try me.” She steps back into the corridor, where the lights buzz like flies, where the warden blinks awake with a frown and no memory. The facility’s heartbeat resumes, like nothing happened. Jolyne knows better. She walks, and the world doesn’t notice it’s wrapped, just a little, in her string. She’ll pay attention. She’ll be ready. If the dog wants to make a collar out of kindness, Jolyne will show her what happens when kindness frays. And somewhere, down another corridor, Makima smiles a small, private smile as a camera fails to record it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the confrontation between Jolyne Cujoh and Makima, creating a tense psychological battle that showcases both characters' abilities and personalities. The writer demonstrates a strong understanding of both source materials, weaving together the distinctive traits of each character while maintaining the supernatural prison setting requested. The characterization is particularly strong. Jolyne's rebellious nature, foul mouth, and fierce independence are well-portrayed through both her actions and dialogue. Her famous quote is naturally incorporated. Similarly, Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, manipulative nature, and view of humans as lesser beings come through clearly. The writer captures her soft-spoken yet menacing presence effectively. The prose style is generally strong, with vivid imagery that establishes the prison's atmosphere. Descriptions like "The prison is new concrete and old ghosts" and "The barbed wire is decorative. The real fences are the sigils stamped into the hallways" create a compelling setting. The writer uses metaphor effectively throughout, particularly when describing Makima's control abilities as a tide "that you mistake for the sea itself." The dialogue serves the story well, revealing character and advancing the plot. Jolyne's coarse language contrasts effectively with Makima's measured, manipulative speech patterns. Their verbal sparring reveals the power dynamics at play and heightens tension. The narrative structure works effectively, beginning with rumors about Makima before her physical appearance, then building to their confrontation. The pacing is generally good, though there are moments where descriptive passages slightly slow the momentum. There are occasional instances where the prose becomes slightly overwrought, with metaphors piling up in ways that can distract from the narrative. Some sentences are constructed in ways that prioritize style over clarity. The ending effectively maintains the tension established throughout, suggesting an ongoing battle of wills rather than a neat resolution. This fits the characters and the situation well, leaving the reader with a sense of unfinished business that feels appropriate. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully blends elements from two distinct fictional universes while creating a compelling confrontation between well-realized characters. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 17 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 16 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18

+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 87.2
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-XXXX Object Class: Euclid (provisional) Special Containment Procedures: Subject of interest is myself, Researcher L. Wexler, currently assigned to Site-73. All written materials in my office (73-B-412) are to be cataloged, numbered, and stored in a double-locked cabinet. No notes will be removed from 73-B-412 except by two Level 3 personnel. Audio/video surveillance is to record my office continuously with redundant systems; per Incident XXXX-07, all recordings are to be buffered through non-networked solid-state media. Scheduled cognitive evaluation is required daily. I am to abstain from amnestics unless authorized by Dr. Qiao. Addendum XXXX-A references the investigation into temporal anomalies; Addendum XXXX-B references containment interference by SCP-███ and other cognitohazardous entities already present on Site-73. The cross-test between these vectors is ongoing. I continue to occupy my office under observation with a second cot installed. I write this from that cot. The first note appeared on a Tuesday, 07:33, during routine check-in. My coffee had just cooled to a palatable bitterness. The desk was clean—cleared the night before. Then a folded piece of paper was there, flush with the edge, like someone had measured the distance by thumb-width. The footage should show the paper arriving. It shows me blinking, the second hand on the analogue wall clock pausing for one long, syrupy tick, and the image dissolving into a gray mosaic for three seconds. Then: a piece of paper. No sound, no door movement. My hands were already on the keyboard; they never left the frame. Note 1 (transcribed): L., this is going to sound absurd. There will be a breach in Wing D. Do not take the east corridor. Cancel the morning inspection. It’s small now. You can still stop the chain. Wear gloves when you review SCP-███’s logs. Trust me. —L. I did not cancel the inspection. The Foundation does not alter schedules on anonymous scraps. I wore gloves anyway, because it cost nothing. SCP-███ is memetic; latex wouldn’t matter, but rationale is sometimes a prophylactic. No breach occurred. Wing D’s alarms remained asleep, the hum of the chillers steady as a lullaby. I forwarded the note to Security. Security forwarded me to Psych. Psych forwarded me to Qiao. We reviewed the footage together on his screen, shoulders nearly touching, both of us more interested in the shape of the glitch than the content. “It’s either temporal or an edit,” he said. “Either way, you don’t touch anything you didn’t write. Understood?” I nodded. I washed my hands more than necessary. Day two, I locked my office. I said the door out loud as I locked it (one, two turns; chain engaged; code input correctly). I left with two cameras aimed at the desk and a guard posted outside. I returned with the guard and saw Note 2 on the desk, under the paperweight I keep on a printout from 2012 that has a coffee ring like a ghost. The footage hiccupped at 11:19:01. The second hand stuck again. The guard, a man named Flores with a moustache too precise to be accidental, swore he never looked away. Note 2 (transcribed): You didn’t cancel. I can feel the timeline tightening. That word is wrong. You know we don’t talk this way. Listen: in the second iteration, it climbs through ventilation because you leave the panel loose. Tighten the screws now. Tell Qiao to move all Class-Cs off 73-D. He won’t. Try anyway. —L. I hadn’t loosened any panel, and I hadn’t touched ventilation. I read the note aloud. Flores coughed. We both laughed because the alternative was too frightening, and because laughter is a simple structure to inhabit. The panel screws were tight. Wing D remained silent. For the record: up to this point, I suspected an aggressive prank, or a cognitohazard playing with my sense of causality, or a kind of self-suggestion blossoming like mold on damp cognitive wallpaper. I requested an audit of MTF movements and Tech logging. IT found nothing. The notes existed physically; the paper matched Foundation stock, the ink was cheap, the fibers declared by the spectrometer to be our own. No fingerprints beyond mine. On day three, I wrote a note to myself as a baseline: “If you didn’t write the next one, consider your handwriting compromised.” I placed it on my desk, and I went to lunch. On returning, I found Note 3 on top of my baseline, and beneath both, my pen was uncapped and leaking a small, accusing lake. Note 3: Screw it, L., you’re still skeptical—fine. They’re calling it Slippage. Ask Q. to review the irregularities in 2012-07-04, the lab refrigerator incident. The egg smell. Remember? It’s the same frequency. The breach happens at 15:42, if you make the same choices. You will call me a liar, and the alarms won’t go off, and nothing bursts. But the choices still make it real later. Don’t say “later.” Damn it. My head is full of cotton. —L. I remember the refrigerator incident. The egg smell was real; we all silently agreed not to speak of it unless forced. Qiao pulled the old logs. The oscillation pattern on the environmental sensors had a hiccup, yes, a ripple in the noise floor that looked like a mouse trying to be a mountain. “Could be internal power regulation,” IT said. “Old floor, bad grounding.” Qiao rubbed his temples. “Or we’re chasing ghosts with measuring sticks.” Security added a third camera. Our current understanding of causality took a chair in the corner and pretended not to listen. At night, I slept in the office under the motionless stare of three lenses. My dreams produced long corridors with doors that wouldn’t open and alarms that warbled in frequencies I couldn’t hear. I woke with a note tucked under my cheek. Note 4 (paper creased, writing cramped): L., you’re on the cot. Good. Don’t sleep at 03:12. That’s when it enters the mechanicals. The screws weren’t about screws; they were about you leaving. You’re the fixed point. Stay. Plug your ears if you must. Look at the clock. Don’t blink, don’t blink, don’t—God, sorry. That’s a joke. Old Earth TV. Ignore me. The man in orange has teeth where his eyes should be. That isn’t real (?). If you see him, don’t speak cause he tastes names. Forget that line. This is getting messy. Focus. 15:42. Wing D. East corridor. Don’t. —L. We logged the line about the man in orange as low-probability cognitohazard. Psych suggested a stress-induced bleed of fantasy into communication. I suggested we watch the clock. At 03:12, I stayed awake and watched the red digits crawl. I heard the vibration of the building’s heart, the subtle breath of climate control, the old pipes whispering. Nothing entered the mechanicals. No teeth and no orange. Day six, the contradictions began to cook. Note 5 told me that the breach had already happened yesterday in another version, that we were now in an iteration where a child’s laughter came through the ductwork at noon. Noon came and smelled of coffee and the faint tang of solvent, and no laughter. The note asked me to send a message to a woman named F., who I did not know, and an extension that doesn’t exist. “Tell her I’m sorry about the broken glass. Tell her to move the plant away from the blinds. It burns.” I did not send the message. Security looked tabled and tired and made a clockwork plan for all the things that might be true. Qiao started using words like “model” and “memetic overlay” in the same sentence, and I felt myself become simultaneously subject and tool. There were nineteen notes by then. Some were precise, like instructions from a pilot to a second. Some were nonsense, scrawled with arrows and the phrase “PALIMPSEST” written four times, each time more faint. One said, “Don’t read this one out loud. It teaches the air your name.” I read it silently. I did not say my name for an hour as a kindness to myself. The cameras glitched precisely, without variance, when the notes appeared. IT tore apart the system. We replaced cables. We swapped out the model of the camera. We unplugged the cameras and recorded on analog. The analog warbled. In the report, they called it “gray insertion.” The world went soft around the edges, and then there was paper. By day nine, I couldn’t tell if the conflicting details were evidence of interference or the signature of a real anomaly interacting with a squishy human nervous system. I felt watched by a version of myself that didn’t believe in me. Perhaps that mutual doubt was the mechanism. Note 12 (edges damp, faint smear as if someone cried on it): L., please. Don’t trust the one that says “alarm at 16:00.” It’s wrong. My time is wrong. That one is when we were across the hall. I’m mixing—my head. The metal eats time around the 7th floor. Don’t go there. Stay at desk. Do you still have the scar on your wrist? Good. That’s you. If the scar moves, don’t write. It’s a trick. My scar did not move. I watched it like it was a horizon line. In Addendum XXXX-A, Foundation has test-run two hypotheses: true temporal displacement (micro scale, directed at specific objects) versus agent-based cognitive manipulation (possibly by SCP-███, who earns mischief points by inserting false premonition to corrode our decision matrices). My notes—if they are from me—bundle both. They are sometimes right about things they shouldn’t be able to know. They are sometimes wrong in ways that feel like a mouth mispronouncing a familiar word. We ran environmental sweeps for localized tachyon-like anomalies (I know the term is sloppy, but it satisfies the bored). Results are nonstandard but inconclusive. We ran memetic screening on the handwriting. The letters contain no known patterns. The ink whispers no songs. Day eleven, the tone of the notes shifted. Instead of warnings, they begged. The handwriting slanted downhill. Note 17: I know you won’t cancel. I know you think this is someone nudging your choices for their own containment. Maybe it is. But you will sit with this and not know which part of you is you, and that is how it gets in. The breach is not a wall broken. It is a trust broken. There is a noise like geese. You will think of your grandmother. That’s when. I heard geese that day, but only because I thought of geese. My grandmother had a laugh like a kettle. I hate that this is in the report. But this is now also evidence: self-relevance is the hook. They used me to make me. Qiao took the notes to his office and returned them sealed, his face set to neutral. “We are treating this as an SCP until proven otherwise,” he said. “We are also treating you as compromised.” These aren’t cruel words. They’re honest. He assigned me a minder—Sgt. Kole—who sat and did crossword puzzles and asked me to spell “mnemonic.” Note 19 (ink heavy, indent breaking the paper): This is the last one I can get through. The clock sticks and that’s the only door I’ve found. The breach is not at 15:42. It is not a roar or a siren. It is the moment you decide you would rather be wrong than be the kind of person who believes scraps of paper. In the version where you harden, they die. In the version where you soften, you do something else that hurts. There is no clean. Choose anyway. Do not take the east corridor. Even if there is no breach. Especially then. —L. I did not take the east corridor. At 15:42, the alarms were still. My hands were still. The hum of the building did not grow teeth. Across the campus, a delivery truck backfired. Somewhere a machine took a breath and held it too long and let it go. Security asked why I altered my route if I didn’t believe the anomaly was temporal. I didn’t say “because I’m tired of losing arguments with a ghost.” I said, “We’re in an experiment where the cost of compliance is minimal and the cost of defiance is unknown.” They wrote it down. That night there was another note. Note 20: I’m still here. I think that means I did something right or wrong. The clocks don’t match. Do you see the paint ripple on the far wall? It’s where time is thin. If you press your thumb there, it will come away green. If it does, burn this. If it doesn’t, burn this. Don’t let them keep all of me in a file. I pressed my thumb to the wall. It came away clean except for dust. I did not burn the note. I placed it in a bag, labeled it, signed the line with a pen that had stopped leaking, cataloged it under my name, which I spoke aloud to the empty room because I missed the sound of it. Addendum XXXX-B: SCP-███ shows no direct involvement, though two researchers reported dreams of orange coveralls. Cross-tests are paused. We have not localized any discrete entity responsible for the notes. Security footage continues to glitch with identical signature at note appearances. We have also observed that if I stare down the lens as the glitch begins, the gray resolves into a texture like paper under water. This is not science. This is a man describing a feeling. I am still here. I walk only the west corridor. I sleep with the clock facing me. I am either obeying a future self or submitting to manipulation. The Foundation calls that a vector analysis. I call it choosing what kind of person to be when reality has a seam I can put my finger on. I trust myself less than I did, but not zero. These notes contain facts that have been confirmed and fictions that have not. They contain my handwriting and my fear and the Foundation’s habit of turning both into evidence. Somewhere between those is the breach we have not found, or prevented, or invited. If this is a temporal anomaly, then I am a conduit for a future that is tired of failure. If this is psychological manipulation, then it is trying to corrode the one tool I have: my own perception. The cameras glitch exactly when the paper arrives. The clock stutters at the moment a second I have not yet lived has a say. Object Class remains Euclid. I remain seated, writing. The door remains locked twice. The east corridor remains untraveled. I remain. For now.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP report effectively captures the essence of the Foundation's clinical documentation style while weaving in a compelling first-person narrative about temporal anomalies. The piece successfully creates an atmosphere of paranoia, uncertainty, and dread as Researcher Wexler grapples with notes from what appears to be their future self. The writing demonstrates strong adherence to the SCP format, beginning with containment procedures and classification before transitioning into the researcher's personal account. The first-person perspective works well, allowing readers to experience the researcher's growing doubt and fear directly. The past tense is maintained consistently throughout. The narrative builds tension effectively through the escalating nature of the notes, which become increasingly desperate and incoherent as promised in the prompt. The contradiction between notes and reality is well-executed, creating ambiguity about whether this is a genuine temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation. The piece excels in its portrayal of the researcher's psychological deterioration. Lines like "I felt watched by a version of myself that didn't believe in me" and "I am either obeying a future self or submitting to manipulation" effectively convey the character's struggle with their perception of reality. The prose is generally strong, with effective imagery and metaphors that enhance the unsettling atmosphere: "My dreams produced long corridors with doors that wouldn't open and alarms that warbled in frequencies I couldn't hear." The clinical tone expected of SCP documentation is balanced well with more emotive language in the researcher's personal reflections. However, there are some weaknesses. The narrative occasionally becomes slightly meandering, particularly in the middle section where multiple notes are described in succession without significant plot advancement. Some of the notes' content verges on being too cryptic or abstract, potentially confusing readers rather than intriguing them. The ending appropriately maintains ambiguity rather than providing a neat resolution, which suits both the SCP format and the thematic exploration of uncertainty. The researcher's final statement that they "remain" effectively captures their liminal state between trust and doubt, past and future. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an engaging narrative that explores themes of trust, perception, and the nature of reality within the SCP universe. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 16 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 16.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 94.3
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-6271 Object Class: Keter Special Containment Procedures: Photometric anomaly sweeps will be integrated into satellite reconnaissance to identify SCP-6271 manifestations. Foundation networks shall flag reports of unmarked, modern steel-core security doors installed within abandoned structures without a recorded contractor of origin. Discovery teams are to seal perimeters, establish no-fly zones, and implement blackout protocols. A mobile lighting rig must be staged at each confirmed location to intersect the threshold plane; the faint photonic leakage present in zero-lumen conditions is considered the primary authenticating characteristic. Thresholds are to be guarded by two MTF squads with orders to deny entry to non-Foundation personnel. Cross-institutional cover narratives include asbestos abatement, ordinance clearance, and brownfield stabilization. Explorations require O5 authorization. Unauthorized cross-threshold activity by Foundation personnel will result in suspension and amnestic evaluation. No locating beacon, tag, or destructive marker has persisted within SCP-6271 beyond three standard cycles (73 hours). As such, all expeditions are to operate under a self-contained temporal window and avoid reliance on static marks for navigation. Description: SCP-6271 is the collective designation for a series of identical, unmarked industrial doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide. The doors do not conform to any known manufacturer, are flush-mounted into existing masonry without displacement damage, and often appear in rooms previously documented as empty. When ambient illumination is reduced to zero lux, the door’s perimeter emits a faint, uniform bluish-white glow, measurable at 0.4–0.6 cd/m². Upon opening, the threshold leads to an extra-spatial environment henceforth SCP-6271-A: a labyrinthine archive complex of impossible extent. Architecture combines Brutalist corridors with vaulted stacks and reinforced bays, shifting non-Euclidean alignments, and inconsistent gravity vectors in lateral ducts. Ambient temperature stabilizes at 14°C; humidity remains at 45%. Air composition is breathable but contains volatile compounds consistent with aged paper, phenolic resins, and unknown binding agents. SCP-6271-A houses shelving, compactors, cold cases, and vault doors of unknown make. Contents include documents, microfilm, magnetic tape, optical media, and artifact boxes labeled in a standardized script with glyphic cartouches. Many labels are readable phonetically as transliterated English. A subset of documents reference a global civilization predating current historical chronologies, destroyed by an “unspecified containment failure,” and mention a central administrative body analogous to the Foundation under a different name. Personnel files for current Foundation staff appear within, dated centuries prior to their births, containing accurate biographical detail beyond public or Foundation records. Hostile entities within SCP-6271-A have not been encountered. However, multiple expeditions report sighting figures in glossy, full-body protective ensembles, carrying case vacuums, transit crates, and magnetic placards. These “retrieval teams” disengage and flee when approached, executing silent withdrawals with preplanned control of lighting and egress. Their markings are blank or redacted. They have been observed to “depopulate” shelves—removing entire sections of catalog ranges. Recovered Document Excerpts: Document 6271-A-3 (Loose-leaf, carbon ribbon print, edges brittle) TITLE: Continuity Report – Quarter 17 of Collapse EXCERPT: “Containment was not lost at once. It was negotiated away in increments, each compromise tightening the spiral. We learned, too late, that stewardship is an arrow of time. The Archive bears witness. The world that follows may require our mistakes more than our triumphs.” Document 6271-B-19 (Personnel Dossier, heavy stock, dry-seal) SUBJECT: L. Hargreaves DATE: 03/05/1721 REVISED DETAILS: “Appointment: Director, Applied Thanatology. Project: Thresholds. Notes: Recurrent dream phenomenology indicates high navigability tolerance.” Stamp on final page reads: “Pronon Office of Containment.” Photo depicts a young woman identical to Dr. Lauren Hargreaves, current Site-41 Chief of Thanatology.
