Ink analysis dates the document to at least three centuries old. Hargreaves denies ancestry resembling the subject; DNA comparison inconclusive due to minor contaminants, but hair strand found sealed within envelope matches Dr. Hargreaves’ mitochondrial haplogroup. Document 6271-C-77 (Index Card, microfilmed) SUBJECT: O5 Seal Transit Log EXCERPT: “Councilors observed: XI, IV. Authority renounced: none. Petition to view ‘Core Stack’ denied. Unchaperoned interval: nine minutes, thirty-six seconds. Missing materials: three folders marked ‘Primer—Waking World.’” Addendum 6271-1: Exploration Logs Exploration 1 — MTF Tau-31 “Pageturners” Date: 2023-11-02 Lead: Capt. Morales Team: Lt. An, Tech. Sato (imaging), Med. Cpl. Hewitt, Archivist Provisional Kline Entry: 06:12 local. Door discovered in a condemned textile mill. Faint glow present under blackout sheet. On breach, team entered a narrow corridor. Left wall: continuous stacks labeled with alphanumeric codes and pictograms of floodlines, lunar phases, and containment symbols unknown to Foundation iconography. 06:24: Sato records a reading room with long tables. The furniture showed no dust accumulation; chair feet left crisp impressions on the tile, then faded over 30 seconds. A stack of manila folders presented as if recently handled. Kline placed nitrile over nitrile to turn pages. Recovered: Folder “Pronon—Continuity Charter (Partial).” Note, Kline: “They call themselves Pronon. Their use of ‘containment’ is ours, but the grammar feels older.” 06:37: First sighting of hazmat figures at extreme of corridor—three silhouettes, reflective helmets, each bearing a matte-black case. No insignia. When Morales announced presence, figures rotated in perfect synchrony, deployed a portable panel that emitted a soft broadband hiss, and vanished around a corner. Pursuit failed; corridor geometry had altered. 06:51: Team encountered a rolling ladder affixed to a towering bay. Each shelf contained unlabeled cassette cases embossed only with a single glyph. Sato played one via portable reader: audio of waves, distant alarms, then a voice: “It is not the fire. It is the arithmetic.” Extraction: 07:30. Upon return, the textile mill door was closed but remained where placed. The glow intensified for 12 minutes post-exit before returning to baseline. Exploration 2 — MTF Mu-12 “Bookends” Date: 2024-01-14 Lead: Lt. Omondi Team: Dr. Kline (embedded), Agent Rusk, Agent Peña, Comms Tech Ng Entry: 21:01. Threshold located in derelict hospital laundry. The glow was stronger than recorded at Tau-31 site. 21:13: Entered a cold-stack wing with sealed drawers. Each drawer had a gravity lock. Labels: “Cathedra, 2 of 9,” “Repatriation—Scrubbed,” “Mnemonic Rafting.” Omondi authorized opening one marked “Personnel: Scenario-Succession.” Inside were folders with names of current Foundation employees, including Agent Rusk, each dated “1698–1734,” stamped Pronon. Rusk’s file included a behavioral profile matching a sealed disciplinary incident only known to Site-12 HR. The paper smelled of formalin. 21:28: A distant clatter repeated at regular intervals, like a hand truck over expansion joints. Peña spotted two hazmat teams loading crate pallets with beige binders labeled “Field Reports—Restraint Failures.” Contact attempted; teams withdrew, leaving behind a folded card. Ng photographed before it sublimated into translucent ash. Card text (partial): “Not yours. Not yet.” 21:35: Kline recovered a heavy black ledger with steel corners. Title page: “Pronon Office of Containment—Council Minutes.” Names redacted with ink seared into the paper. Margins contain notes in a hand later matched to Dr. █████, then Deputy Director, Site-05, deceased 1998. Handwriting analysis indicates perfect match; ink dates inconclusive. An initialed marginalia reads: “We promised not to repeat ourselves. We broke it the minute we named ourselves.” 21:48: Passage narrowed; stack alignment shifted. Team found a small anteroom with a coat tree. Two hooks bore long, dark coats each with a lapel pin of a ring divided into thirteen segments. One segment was fractured. 21:52: Unauthorized signal on internal comms. Voice: “Do not take the minutes.” Omondi ordered retreat. On exit, Peña observed a reflection in the visor of a departing hazmat figure: a human face bearing an insectile compound pattern overlaying the eyes; could not be verified. Exploration 3 — Classified Annex, Partial Transcript Date: 2024-03-02 Lead: Capt. Morales Team: Agent Li, Archivist Provisional Kline, Dr. Hargreaves (observer) Entry: 03:06. Door within a demolished municipal library basement vault. Glow visible in total darkness as documented. The threshold led to an atrial hub, with seven spokes. At hub center: sculpture of a sphere wrapped in bands engraved with cardinal virtues and containment maxims. Several bands were missing. 03:22: Li located a reading niche with a ledger keyed “O-Seal Transit,” containing dated check-in stamps. Among signatures were symbols matching those on O5 secure seals. Three entries corresponded to internal dates where no O5 movement is recorded. Attached slip: “Escort: Binder-Three.” Note in the margin: “They came without asking. They never came alone.” 03:31: Hargreaves retrieved a folder inscribed “Hargreaves, L. Appointment Renewal.” Date: 02/17/1722. Inside: a charcoal portrait matching her face. Bottom line: “We keep what works.” Hargreaves exhibited tachycardia; med readouts steady. Folder edges lightly warm to touch. 03:40: Distant rumble. A chain of hazmat figures entered a parallel aisle. One carried a signs kit with pictographic warnings; another placed a placard at our aisle head: a circle bisected, then folded. Touching it produced a static discharge; letters appeared, then vanished: “Evacuation Priority: Memory.” The chain lifted entire shelf lengths, which slid weightless into open crates. The space beyond where shelves stood showed a pale void, like paper scorched clean. Morales: “Identify yourselves!” No response. The tail unit paused, faced us, tapped a gloved finger against helmet, then traced a small circle in the air. The motion matched known O5 sealing gesture variants. 03:46: A silhouette emerged at the far end—tall, severe posture, coat with ring lapel pin, one fractured segment. Face occluded by shadow. Ng’s bodycam (mounted forward) registered a biometric mask overlay of an O5 identity hash—no match in our database but correct format. The figure turned, walked with the hazmat chain, and was gone. 03:52: PA tone broadcast through the stacks, a chime trio. A voice: “Core Stack opening reserves. All errors shall be bound.” Hazmat teams accelerated. A rolling ladder glided on its own, then stopped dead beside us. On its top rung lay a single stamped envelope: “Primers—Waking World.” It was empty. The stamp impression matched the missing entries noted in Document 6271-C-77. 04:01: We attempted to tag the aisle with thermal paint; paint cooled instantly and sloughed off. Hargreaves placed her folder back. The shelf rejected it and slid the folder into a side slot labeled “RETAINED.” Extraction: 04:19. Door closed immediately behind last man out. Glow increased to an afterimage that persisted on retinas for minutes. Addendum 6271-2: Internal Review A forensic metadata sweep of Site and Area O5 access logs around the dates found in O-Seal Transit records returned tamper artifacts consistent with high-level redaction protocols; however, three nonconforming audit fragments indicate three Council members authenticated on-site within a 48-hour window of Exploration 3 without mission filing. The implication that one or more O5 Council members have visited SCP-6271-A without consensus or body approval is under Ethics Committee review. No statement has been issued by the Council. Addendum 6271-3: Further Recovered Excerpts Document 6271-D-04 (Bound pamphlet, brittle) TITLE: Primer—Waking World EXCERPT: “To wake is to forget half of what was binding you. We left these anchors in hopes the next hands would knot them tighter. If you are reading this, we failed differently this time.” Document 6271-E-22 (Loose marginalia) TEXT: “Pronon is not a name. It is a promise: ‘for-now.’ We have always been interim.” Document 6271-F-09 (Typed memo, onion skin) FROM: Councilor XI TO: Binder-Three SUBJECT: Petition for Core Access TEXT: “We must see what we locked away. Memory is a containment state. If the box remembers you, it opens. If it does not, it never existed.” STAMP: DENIED Closing Statement: SCP-6271-A presents a paradox of provenance and succession. Its materials reference a predecessor administrative order, Pronon, mirroring and anticipating current Foundation structures. Its personnel dossiers contain accurate data about our present staff, dated centuries prior. Agents report active removal of archive segments by unknown hazmat teams who avoid contact but behave with practiced familiarity, occasionally using symbols and gestures associated with our highest authority. The faint glow escaping the door’s edges in complete darkness is the only constant across sites, an index of aperture state or attentional bleed. Hypothesis space includes temporal recursion, institutional palimpsest, or inheritance from a prior cycle of ordered containment that failed. Whether the hazmat teams represent a remaining Pronon element, a parallel Foundation, or an automated custodial force is unresolved. The presence of O5-aligned signatures within SCP-6271-A, coupled with internal audit anomalies, implies at least one Council member possesses knowledge not reflected within present records. All further exploration is suspended pending an oversight session. In the interim, doors are to be held, watched, and not believed.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates exceptional command of the SCP Foundation format and style. The response creates a compelling anomaly that perfectly fits the prompt requirements while adding layers of complexity and intrigue that elevate it beyond a simple execution of instructions. The concept of doors leading to an impossible archive containing records of a previous civilization (Pronon) that mirrors the current Foundation is brilliantly executed. The writer establishes a sophisticated containment scenario with technical language that feels authentic to the SCP universe. The photometric anomaly details, containment procedures, and exploration protocols all contribute to a sense of institutional realism. The exploration logs are particularly strong, following a logical progression that builds tension while revealing information at a measured pace. The writer skillfully introduces the hazmat teams who flee when approached, and subtly implies O5 Council involvement through recovered documents and observations. The exploration team's perspective is maintained consistently throughout these logs, with appropriate clinical detachment punctuated by moments of unease. The recovered document excerpts are masterfully crafted, containing cryptic but meaningful fragments that hint at deeper mysteries without overexplaining. Phrases like "It is not the fire. It is the arithmetic" and "Memory is a containment state" create an unsettling atmosphere while suggesting profound implications. The writer excels at creating a sense of institutional paranoia and existential dread through subtle details: personnel files matching current staff but dated centuries earlier, marginalia that matches deceased personnel's handwriting, and evidence of O5 Council members visiting without authorization. These elements combine to suggest a cyclical nature to reality itself, with the Foundation possibly being an iteration of a previous containment organization. The prose is precise and clinical when appropriate (in containment procedures) but becomes more atmospheric in exploration logs, creating effective tonal variation while maintaining consistency with the SCP format. Descriptions like "a pale void, like paper scorched clean" and "The glow increased to an afterimage that persisted on retinas for minutes" demonstrate strong imagery that enhances the uncanny nature of the anomaly. The piece avoids common SCP pitfalls like excessive redactions or gratuitous horror elements, instead building tension through implication and the gradual revelation of an unsettling cosmic truth. The closing statement effectively summarizes the paradoxical nature of the anomaly while leaving room for reader interpretation. If there are any weaknesses, they might be in the slightly excessive length of some sections and occasional moments where technical language becomes slightly repetitive. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise exceptional execution of the SCP format. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 90.5
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The ferry veered like a fish, a series of short arcs across the gravity wells between the station and the planet. In that jittering silence that new planets always require—where the voice cannot yet presume to name—the young envoy watched the continent roll into detail: a broad fan of river, a wet green throat opening to a paler sea, and a city crouched where the waters met. It had been called Veld by the first arrivals, an old word for grassland, perhaps, though the green here climbed into blue and ash and other colors that did not belong to grasses at all. The briefing packet rattled in their palms, dull with authority. Tensions high between the Lineages: Littoral, Settle, and Deep; more formal names in the document, but everyone used the simple words. Protocol: Upon arrival you will present yourself, etc. Do not walk alone. They had read Earth's histories in the training months in orbit. They had been told adaptation could come quickly if the climate insisted, if lungs learned different rhythms, if skins found new chemistries to filter alien suns. They had seen the schematic illustrating the Littoral—pelvic arches broadened, hair like a fine dark moss, a salt-shine to the skin. They had seen the Deep—eyes wide and saltless, bones like saplings, an economy of water that no terrestrial body could achieve. The Settle—closest to baseline humanity, everyone said; settled inland, engineered their crops to match them, but the cartilage in their ears showed the same small curling as the native fliers. Official words made tidy lines of change. But tidiness has never been allied with life. The ferry sighed into dock. The air came to meet the envoy with the soft weight of breath through wet cloth. There was a cry, long and high, not human, threading the city's hum. The envoy turned their eyes away from the waiting delegation: the ministerial gray of suits, the app rectangles, the flags with their shallow colors. The envoy's handlers had warned them: a small failure and the colonies become wary of Earth again, the agreements grow brittle. Our presence is only as desired as our listening. They had nodded, because nodding was expected, and because listening is something you can only learn by failing at it. The envoy carried the weight of their own failure already, small as a seed, ready to sprout. In the drift of greeting handshakes, he—the envoy—slipped, step by step, onto a side walkway. A tiny motion, a fish again. No one noticed, or noticed only the gray suit among other gray suits, and soon he was in a side street, then in a market lane where the paving street wore its age in a pattern of gloss and grit underfoot. Smells: salted fruit, the pepper-lime of fermenting river kelp, smoke. The stalls pressed close, and the voices climbed like birds on thermal columns. The cloth first drew his eye. On Earth, fabric had settled toward uniformity: dyes that were all the same, stable, safe. Here, a stall showed him color he could not name. One bolt like the underside of a raincloud walked by stars; another like the mouth of a flower seen from the inside, where the color is not one color but motion; a scarf that seemed to become greener when he breathed on it. The vendor, a woman with Littoral hair, laughed softly at his staring and shook her stall so that the cloth shifted. The warp threads caught and released light the way the river caught and released the sky. Pigments cultivated from a symbiotic fungus in the river reeds, his briefing packet supplied belatedly, tedious, as if one could write an annotation of awe. "You look like the wind is on your skin," the vendor said, and then, because she saw who he was—no one could miss the cut of Earth cloth, the pallor that belonged to ships—she adjusted her tone. "You're new." "I am," he said, and made space in his mouth for the local vowels. "How much for this?" She named a number. The envoy had local currency—polite, token—provided by the Bureau. He paid and took the scarf, and it made his neck murmur of a different air. He asked, "Who wears these colors?" "Everyone," she said, and then, "The Deep, mostly. They like the weight. It hangs in the water better. And it's true-color under depth-light. Yours, from above—it shifts; under, it's plain." "True-color," he said, thinking of truth. "It must be expensive to cultivate." "We cultivate everything," she said with that resignation particular to people who can't stop. "We don't count the labor. We can’t afford to." Then she bit her lip, a small check. "You'll be wanting the official market. It's over that way." He wanted this, the unofficial market, the way he had always wanted things that were not meant for him. He said, "I like it here." "You like feeling lost," she said, not unkindly. Beyond the cloth, the food. He bought a small cone of something crisp and glistening, sweet-savory, like fried ribbon. Children ran barefoot, three children with the cartilage-curl ears—Settle lineage, he thought—and one with a chest wider than a child's had any right to be: a Littoral child, perhaps, lungs made for breath in winds near water. A man stood on a crate and argued about taxation in a voice like good earth—no, not Earth and earth. There were other words here. Ground. Bed. The words shift because the ground shifts. He saw a group of Deep women—no, perhaps they were neither women nor men as Earth counted. Their bodies made long simple lines. Their eyes were dark and bright simultaneously, like polished seedpods. They moved together, and when they laughed, they lifted their faces to catch the wind in their mouths—an old habit of sailors on Earth; a new habit here. They were not fish, the envoy had been told. Do not call them fish. They could sleep underwater for longer than any Earthling had a right to imagine, and their joints bent differently when seated on stones near the river. They wore the handwoven cloth as belts, hanging heavy into water. His packet had said: The Deep make no claims; they ask the same as everyone to be left alone with their ways. The packet had also said: The Deep are obstructionists, preventing the dam project. The dam would provide 30% of projected energy needs for Veld. The Deep damage, by their actions, our hopes for energy independence. He watched a Deep child—lank hair, eyes like wet stone—turn a shell in their fingers. The child lifted the shell to the envoy without solemnity, offering. He took it, the ridges new to his hand. "Thank you," he said, and the child made the small movement that was a shrug here, an opening of the right shoulder. Do not walk alone, the packet had said. He was not alone. The market pressed around him, and the city had already decided how alone he would be. Someone brushed his side—not accident; a hand light as a moth. He looked down. A Settle boy, perhaps ten, stood there, his fingers already closing on the envoy's pocket. The envoy caught the boy's wrist gently. The boy looked up and bared his teeth, not in threat but in warning. It was like watching a feral cat. On Earth the envoy had practiced the words that would bring guards without escalation. He did not say them here. He reached into his pocket and took out a small metal coin—a ship token, old. He placed it in the boy's palm, then released the boy's wrist. The boy looked at the coin as if it were a fish from a cold sea he'd never seen. He snorted, confused, and ran. The envoy thought: He will sell it for cloth, perhaps. Or throw it into the river. Or none of these. The coin warmed his own palm where it had been. He turned as the first ring of shadow fell across the market. Veld's day was long enough to have moods. The high flyers came downriver then, scribing their loops just above the roofs. They were not birds—no feathers, but membraned wings, like lengths of dyed fabric themselves, the color of fog at dawn. The people in the market did not look up. This was their sky, their river. People only looked when strangers asked them to. By the time he thought of returning, his scarf had turned a different green. The clock on his packet sighed a little reminder. The glass tower where the Bureau slept glinted in the far sun. The envoy breathed—Veld air in his throat—and began the walk back through streets named on maps, that had other names in mouths. The return was a narrowing. Official rugs, official corridors. In the reception room the atmosphere dried like cloth left too long in the real sun. The Commander's "Where have you been" carried every planet he had ever landed on. She had Settle ears; her family had been here two generations; she still wore Earth cut. Her mouth bled patience. "I walked," the envoy said, because simplicity is sometimes such a shield that it can be a weapon. "Against protocol." "Against a certain idea of listening," he said, the boldness of the scarf around his neck. "You will meet with Minister of Science in twenty minutes," she said, the words crisp and floor-clean. "You will wear what you are meant to wear. You will keep your observations to yourself until they have been processed through proper channels." "I will meet him," he said. "What is his name?" "Jarcha. From the Settle. He is the governor’s cousin. Remember: he is an appointment. He has never been a scientist. He enjoys reminding our people of that." The Commander looked at the scarf and resigned herself to it. "At least comb your hair." Jarcha's office smelled faintly of distilled water. It had a picture in it of a landscape that might have been Earth if Earth had been once this gentle. Jarcha himself was older than the Commander by thirty years, perhaps, his body long and thin, like a reed. His ears were the easy giveaway. He stood as if it were neither courtesy nor necessity to stand. "Offworlder," he said. "You were lost." "I was learning my way," the envoy said. "I apologize for any offense." He smiled. "Offense is the coin we all deal in. Sit." They sat. Everything Jarcha did had the appearance of leisure. The envoy found themselves matching that pace. "I am told you have concerns about the dam." Jarcha put the slightest weight on you, as one might on a plank before stepping. His language was full of small tests. "I am told that the Deep require the river as it is. I am told that the dam will provide your city with energy sufficient to make you less dependent on imports, particularly in the dry season when your ground crops need irrigation. I am told that this is an engineering matter. I do not think engineering matters exist outside of life." "Concise," Jarcha said, as if he had asked for that. He steepled his long fingers, then flattened them. "When I was a boy, my father taught me to swim in a salt pool. Settle, we don't keep our heads under long. He said: If you must put your face in the water, do it with the conviction that the water will hold you. The water does not care about your conviction, but you will not drown so easily. Our city prefers to act as if water cares. We have built a bridge of beliefs across something that shifts. You walked the market. You saw the colors. Did you notice the drains?" The envoy thought of the lanes. Their training had demanded they notice small things. "The footways tilt at angles not regular to the buildings, to sluice the monsoon flows. The grates are low and wide. The older ones are higher, smaller. The newer ones, wider." "Yes," Jarcha said. "We learn. The first Settle town—I was a child—flooded and stayed flooded, because we didn't understand that here, ground is a verb. The Littoral learned it. The Deep have no need to learn: they grew their bodies from our mistakes. There will be no dam. Not for twenty years." The envoy blinked. The Commander had been certain: he was to persuade. "I don't think your governor agrees." "My cousin is fond of speeches," Jarcha said, the softness not unkind, but a knife still. "He tells the Settle that power is light. He tells the Littoral that power is rising beyond the river. He tells the Deep nothing. He assumes they will not listen. This is a mistake. Everyone listens. Sometimes what they listen to is not you. The Deep are listening to their dead in the river. The littoral listen to the wind." He paused. "You, offworlder, what do you listen to?" "My orders," the envoy said, and drew a breath. "The sound of my own ignorance. The way the air here moves in the throat. The way my idea of you changes when you speak from something beyond the briefings. The market. A child's breath." "Good," Jarcha said, as if a game had been played and the envoy had not lost immediately. "Then listen: There will be no dam. We will let your Bureau write projections and press releases. We will test a smaller structure in a seasonal stream. It will satisfy no one. The real work will be in the hills. We will ask the Settle to plant the deep-rooted ferns that don't burn in drought; we will ask the Deep to teach us how to catch the fall of water as it leaves the fog; we will ask the Littoral to show us how to carry it without losing it to the air. This is politics. This is science. You will write a dispatch that does not shame us." "And if I write the truth?" the envoy said. "That you will not build the dam, that your cousin speaks to satisfy, that the Deep do not obstruct but insist you live in the verb of ground?" Jarcha's eyes crinkled. "Write it. But write also that there will be lighting in the alleys come long-dusk, and that the hospital will be cold in summer for the Settle children with fevers, and that the Deep will get a weather radio that speaks in their cadence. You will be reprimanded for your walk. You will be told you jeopardize relations. Do not jeopardize anything except false certainty. And do not do it visibly. It is easy to be brave where everyone can see. Be useful instead." The envoy felt a slow heat rise under the scarf. "You dislike my presence." "I dislike being reminded that we are still seen as provisional by people who never intend to become less provisional themselves," Jarcha said. "I dislike that we cannot yet turn our backs on Earth. I dislike our debts. But I like your scarf. It becomes you. Did you buy it from Petra's stall? Her mother weaves the true-color threads. She must have seen you and thought, that one will tickle the Bureau. She's right. She's very good at politics." He leaned back. "Tell me something you saw that is not in your briefing." The envoy thought of the child's wrinkled coin, the fliers’ drifting, the salt-sheen on the vendor's wrist where the cloth dyed it, the drains. He said, "People carry small salt vials on cords, not on belts. The cord goes under the shirt. When they work, if they go faint, they lick their fingers and press them to the salt. The children do it casually; the old do it like a prayer. We do not do that on Earth." "Ah," Jarcha said, pleased. "Then you understand something about water and bodies. Good. Carry that understanding into your orders. Take your reprimand and put it to use. And do not walk alone tomorrow." "I will not be alone tomorrow," the envoy said. "Tomorrow, I will be with the Minister of Science." Jarcha laughed then, not unkindly. "Do not flatter me nor yourself. Tomorrow you will be with a city. Drink our water. Learn to have it in your mouth without fearing it." The envoy rose. At the door, Jarcha said, "How will you write me? In your report. What will I be?" "A man who knows the ground is a verb," the envoy said. Jarcha nodded. "Good. And you?" "Lost," the envoy said. "And listening." He stepped out into the corridor, where the conditioned air scoured his skin. He held the scarf at his throat. It had warmed to his heat, but its color kept shifting, agreeing with no one. He thought of the salt vials. He touched his tongue to his fingertip and imagined a tiny crunch, a savor. He would have to ask the vendor if she sold them. Or Jarcha. Or the Commander. It did not matter. He had begun to learn words here, and the words would work on him as the river did. He had failed the protocol. He had succeeded at being in a place. That would have to be enough for a first day. He carried the shell from the child in his pocket, ridges pressing his palm. He walked toward the reprimand, toward the writing of a truth that was multiple and therefore closer to the truth. Outside, the sky began to shift its weight. The drains would be ready. The market, too. The river would not care. But the people would. He did, now. And it would cost him. And he could pay it. Or not. The work was to decide, every hour, with the knowledge he had, and with the more he did not. He stepped into the room where the Commander waited, and found he had begun already, long before she opened her mouth. He had the taste of the city in his mouth, faintly, like someone else's salt. He swallowed. He stood. He listened. He spoke. And the chapter of this was only starting to be written.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response demonstrates a remarkable grasp of Le Guin's style, particularly her ability to blend anthropological observation with lyrical prose. The piece successfully creates a world where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies (Littoral, Settle, and Deep) with physical adaptations that reflect their environments. The writing excels at sensory detail and worldbuilding through small, telling observations: the salt vials worn under shirts, the drains designed for monsoon flows, the cloth that changes color underwater. These details create a lived-in world without resorting to exposition dumps. The envoy's observations feel organic, allowing readers to discover this world alongside the protagonist. The character of Jarcha is particularly well-rendered—a political appointee who nonetheless possesses wisdom and nuance. His statement that "ground is a verb" encapsulates the philosophical difference between Earth's approach and the colony's adaptation to their environment. The dialogue between Jarcha and the envoy reveals layers of political complexity without becoming didactic. The prose maintains a consistent voice throughout, with a poetic quality that never becomes overwrought. Sentences like "Tidiness has never been allied with life" and "The market pressed around him, and the city had already decided how alone he would be" demonstrate a Le Guin-esque ability to compress philosophical insight into simple, elegant phrasing. The narrative structure works well, following the envoy from arrival through unauthorized exploration to the confrontation with Jarcha. The piece avoids the trap of making the envoy instantly enlightened; instead, we see them beginning a process of understanding, still caught between duty and discovery. Where the piece could be stronger is in developing more emotional complexity for the envoy. While we see their curiosity and growing awareness, their internal conflicts could be more deeply explored. The envoy's motivations for breaking protocol could be more clearly established early on. Additionally, while the dialogue with Jarcha is strong, some of the exposition about the political situation feels slightly too neat. Le Guin often allows more ambiguity and contradiction in her political landscapes. Overall, this is an exceptionally strong response that captures Le Guin's anthropological eye, her interest in adaptation and cultural difference, and her elegant, restrained prose style. The piece creates a world that feels simultaneously alien and familiar, populated by characters whose differences reflect deeper philosophical questions about humanity's relationship to environment. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 88.7
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The tiles in the old clinic still bled light. Threads of blue-green glow from the seams where hairline cracks had taken root, like veins under skin. Mushrooms had followed, little discs and umbrella caps that drank the damp and breathed out faint luminescence when the lights were off, a slow pulse, as if the room had a heartbeat. I kept the overhead flood patched together on a shoe last week, but today I left it off to spare the heat. The mushrooms were enough by which to see the lazy oscillation of the ceiling fan I’d sewn back together out of printer motors and bicycle chain. Better that than blow another fuse on the black-market inverter. I leaned over the thermocycler—a breadbox from before all the patents, breathing in the river-sour smell of cultured bacteria and acetone—and pressed the cracked plastic lid down. A strip of duct tape kept the heating element pressed to the worn aluminum block. The machine’s status readout had died before I found it, but I’d learned to count the clicks of relays switching over: denaturation, annealing, extension. Ninety-four to fifty to seventy-two, over and over, like the tides. The thing coughed as it warmed. I listened to it cough like a living thing, timed the wheeze between clicks to see if the heat would hold. The amplification worked some days and not others; the corporate obsolescence had been designed to eat itself, strand by strand, base pairs unraveling after one generation like ash. Their wheat, their corn, their pigs with marbling genes—everything they made came with a fuse inside, and when the spark ran out, it all unstitched. Kept them selling. Kept us buying, until there was no more money, and the satellites were drift, and the patents were paper. What was left was me and a machine that wanted to die and wouldn’t, because I had screwed two extra relays onto its gut and fed it power stolen from a windmill that only spun when the weather fought it. “Your block’s running hot,” Jori said from the threshold. The glow on her cheekbone made her look like she’d been painted for a festival the old folks couldn’t explain. Her hair was braided in copper wire—probably a prayer for reception. She carried dust in her jacket like an aura, and I didn’t have to ask where she’d been; it was in the way she held her arm tight to her ribs, hiding something heavy. “It’s running,” I said. “That’s the part that matters.” “Sit,” she said. “I am sitting.” On a stool that had been a dentist’s once. Its hydraulic hiss was the clinic’s second heartbeat. I turned the stool so she had my side and not the spread of half-soldered boards and a glass petri stacked with glowing fungal membranes. “Your tone says there’s a problem that isn’t my machine.” She smiled like she’d learned it in a mirror. “Who says I can’t have multiples.” The fridge hummed, a scarred thing patched with an aquarium chiller and a block of phase change wax I scavenged from an old HVAC unit. It kept temperatures a suggestion more than a promise. Inside were strips of cold-pack gel I’d repurposed into cold boxes, vials with my life in them: promoter sequences, old plasmids, transcription factors scraped off dried-out culture plates in a burned university where the fire-suppression had painted the walls with a char that wouldn’t scrub out. She didn’t move to the bench, didn’t step over the tangle of charging cords winding from the pedaled alternator to the inverter and back to the heating block. She stayed near the door and kept her back to the corridor. That meant she had someone she didn’t want to see her have come to see me, or someone she did. The settlement liked words like decency. I liked words like contract. “This is you flexing,” I said, low. “I’ll flex back. You’re late, and your payment is late, and my seeds are almost cooked.” “They’re cooked because your Internet of Things is three broken appliances, one of which is probably a bomb,” she said, finally stepping between a stack of centrifuge buckets and a cracked porcelain sink. The basket for the centrifuge had had to be rebuilt. The wobble it had now made it sound like an old radio, hiss and chirp, when I spun it up to separate DNA from soup. I had the balance down to instinct now: a counterweight made of a marble and some solder squares, even with a black-market rotor that had a missing screw. She slid the package onto the bench next to the PCR machine. The click stopped. The room felt like it inhaled and held. The mushrooms dimmed slightly, maybe a draft, maybe a nervous system that didn’t exist. “What’s the contract,” I said. “Three parts,” she said. “One for me, two for them. You’ll take care of me first because I brought this.” She lifted the cloth like she was showing a new baby. Underneath was a freezer brick and a metal capsule the size of my thumb. I could smell it before I touched it, a faint rose-and-tin odour that didn’t belong in the clinic, didn’t belong on this side of any line. “Tell me you didn’t,” I said, because my mouth worked before my brain did. She held up her injured arm, and I saw the black bruise like a galaxy under her skin where someone’s rifle butt had taught her a private lesson. “Put out the mushrooms if you’re going to scold me,” she said. “It’s from a seed vault,” I said, with more reverence than I liked. “A sovereign one. There were words about raids on the radio.” “There were lies on the radio,” she said. “Say your prayers later. Can you sequence it?” Sequence was a generous word for what I did. I chopped and amplified and stuck things together that had no business touching. I bent genes around and got them to sing a new song for one last verse before the suicidal obsolescence devoured the melody. I didn’t read; I reacted. I ran PCR on thermal gradients and guessed at annealing temps and kept the thermocycler running by rubbing it with the non-conductive cloth from an old hazard bag when the static built up the wrong way. But the capsule was marked with a stamp I’d recognize blindfolded: the old agriculture ministry’s crest, two ears of wheat and a caduceus in the middle. Pre-Obsolescence. Pre-license. Maybe pre-profit. “I can,” I said. I touched the metal like it might burn. “Then you’ll do it,” she said. “Longer amylase, cellulose breakdown, drought tolerance. I have a client in Sectors South that will trade for it. Trade big. And you’ll do me a fix while we wait.” The fix. The daily float of nanowrongs and microloans my body had become. I had a flock of the clinic’s mistakes inside me, bare RNA that I had used as scaffolds when the antibiotics ran out and the obsolescence started to eat the bacteria we used as factories. My lungs ran on a weird patchwork of modified alveolar proteins that let me breathe easier after the dust storms, but sometimes when the air was still I could taste copper and see blue halos around things in the dark. My liver had learned how to metabolize a handful of synthetic sugars that the food vats made from plastic-cracking, and in exchange I’d lost an appetite for vanilla. My fingers grew back skin faster than they should, a thin shine that pulled tight and flaked off like blister peel if I worked too hard under the UV. Upsides, downsides. A catalog of hacks I could tune up or down when I got more stock in. “Where?” I asked, and she let me see the bandage under her jacket, the mean, swollen line and the spiderweb around it. Another one of the corporate barbs: a tracker built into wire, built into bullets. They’d planned it so their livestock couldn’t breed true, or run, or resist rust or sun or dehydration. They hadn’t planned for the bullets to go bad, too. The microchemical in the barb wanted to digest itself in a few days. It had. But the owl’s nest of proteins it dragged out of her and rearranged had set, and the heat sat in it like a coin. “You need me to splice you a thing that turns a thing off,” I said. “It’ll eat you while it listens.” “You’ve made worse in this room,” she said. “On purpose.” I held her gaze until the mushrooms dimmed and brightened again. “Lie on the bed,” I said. She didn’t ask for a sheet. I hit the pedal for the alternator and let my legs go, giving the inverter the extra charge while the thermocycler ticked and breathed. The Capsicum peppers I kept in a cracked fish tank rattled when the fan pulled air across them. Jori watched me as if she could see the circuits between my calf and the PCR machine, the way the lab had been a body long before I let it live in mine. The capsule thumped in my palm as I opened it. I let a single seed drop into a dish with the mushroom membrane. The glow went white and then faded back to blue, like the fungus had inhaled. It was a dumb reaction to amino acids, to oils. It made me think of the fields my grandmother had talked about like fairyland: green as maps, and solid, and a foot of water in the ditches when the canals behaved. “You can’t sell them all,” I told Jori without looking up. “If I can make these breed, if we can tie the obsolescence to a switch we know, we could replant. We can trade the trick, not the seed.” “You talk like we have time,” she said. “We don’t. Not yet.” The black markets were just markets where the lights didn’t always work. The client she meant was a woman whose voice came on the radio from a relay tower run on stolen solar, the one that didn’t go dead when the corporate satellites went dark. She hoarded bio in a vault under a stadium where the grass had been replaced with solar laminate. She traded in glow and life and water rights. She had teeth. She’d made it clear she didn’t want me; she wanted my output. Fine. If I had to bend, I bent where the metal wanted heat. I scraped the seed with a scalpel nicked from a surgeon’s kit. I flicked the scales of endosperm into a tube and added buffer I’d made with salt and starch and the luck of a dying chemistry teacher’s notes. Then the enzymes—the ones I’d scraped off cultures that were older than I was, coaxed back to something like function with heat baths made from old espresso machines and water baths sewn from parts of baby incubators. The laminar flow hood was a joke, a cabinet with a fan and cloth filters I soaked in alcohol and left in the sun. “Wake up,” I told the enzymes. “This is your time.” I set the tube in the aluminum block and waited for the relay’s click. Annealing. Extension. I could feel the machine through the bench, the faint warm that made the mushrooms nearest its corner glow less bright. I turned to Jori, who lay still and tense on the bed’s cracked vinyl. “I need your arm,” I said. “I need to find the border of the wrong.” “I hired you because you talk about wrong like it’s a town,” she said, but she rolled her sleeve anyway. Her skin was cool, given what sat inside. The spiderweb went deeper than skin and had pulled it down, left little dimples like a constellation. I tapped my needle with a fingernail to knock loose the air, then slid it in beside the inflamed line. I’d mixed a cocktail of my own making: bits of CRISPR that had been sold as a kid’s science kit once, a viral scaffold stripped and sanded, a switch that would flip off the protease that the barb had started up inside her and that her body, for reasons I couldn’t see, had decided to keep feeding. There would be a cost. There was always a cost. Maybe she’d run fever and see things. Maybe the process would chew her wrist bones a little until I could catch it. Maybe the payoff would be pain she could live with; maybe it would be that she’d start to smell storm clouds a day before anybody else. The syringe plunger moved smooth. The mushrooms flared, then settled. “How long?” she asked. “For your arm? A day,” I said. “For the seed? A night. For the client’s money? That depends on how honest she is when she uses the word generous.” “She says she’ll send meds. Real ones. Antibiotics. Plasma for the kids.” Plasma was a dangerous word. It meant power, and it meant blood, and it meant the stuff the corporations had said couldn’t be made without them. I’d mixed my own stand-ins too long not to feel the ache behind my eyes at the thought of cold bags with real salve inside. “We’ll pack up the sequences into plasmids she can use,” I said. “She grows. We get our cut in full.” “You make it sound like a bakery.” “I make it sound like anyone could walk out and plant a seed and it would become something good,” I said. “That’s not true anymore.” The centrifuge moaned when I spun it, the counterweights clacking. I couldn’t tell if the noise masked the tremor in Jori’s breath or if she was quiet enough to erase herself. The thermal block clicked. I counted. I moved tubes from one rack to another and gloved and ungloved hands to save glove fingertips. I swapped micropipettes that didn’t quite set to the volume they promised, used the fine roller on my thumb like a violinist finding a note. The gel rig hummed; I’d soldered it out of toaster coils and it ran smooth if the inverter didn’t hiccup. The bands showed under the blue lamp. I squinted and prayed to no one in particular that the big ones meant a trick that would hold. Jori slept. I covered her with a tarp and wrapped her fingers around a warm bottle that had been saline once and now kept whatever inside me functioning from crystallizing when the night came cold. In the other room, the radio crackled, a voice checking intervals, code that I’d learned to translate into “are you there” and “are you listening” and “do you want to spend the rest of this year not starving.” Time is a thing that eats itself in a place like this. It chews seconds into hours and spits days into a bowl and calls it soup. When dawn burned the mushrooms into pale ghosts, I had something printed: a strip of useless-looking wet with a load of maybe inside. I had tubes with bacteria that were pregnant with ideas. I had an email that would go nowhere if the wind died and the relay on the ridge didn’t kick. Jori woke at the click of the thermocycler. She flexed her hand. She winced and then didn’t, a two-step I’d seen before when the flip switched under skin. The spiderweb under her skin had loosened: the lines less taut, the heave of the heat gone. She saw me see it. “You’re a witch,” she said. “I’m a mechanic,” I said. “And we have a delivery to make.” In the clinic corridor, the glowing mushrooms had spread to the baseboards. Somebody had stepped on them once and left a footprint in cold fire. The wheels of Jori’s cart—she’d brought the capsule in on it, hidden under cloth and dignity—left trails I could follow with a blacklight if the world fell dark enough. We packed the plasmids into a printout that looked like art and felt like snakeskin. We sealed seeds and false seeds in vacuum bags I’d made out of mylar balloons and glue I cooked over a camp stove. We wrapped it all in old lesson plans—grammar worksheets with red pencil and a note from a teacher: remember your verbs. Jori rolled her sleeve down and tucked the bundle under her jacket. “You’ll get your meds,” she said. “You’ll get…your thing. Whatever you want.” “I want to grow something that can have children,” I said, and felt stupider saying it than I had thinking it. “That’s all. That’s the contract I want. With the world.” “Write it up,” she said. “Stamp it with a crest. Maybe the mushrooms will keep it.” We shook hands around the glow. My skin prickled where it touched hers, as if the changes I’d made in her wanted to see if they could jump. They couldn’t. Not like that. It never had been that easy. Still. I pulled back. She smiled a real smile this time and was gone into the corridor with her cargo, her back straight as a ledger. The radio crackled again. The client’s voice, smooth as machine oil. I loaded my pack with tools in case the turbines on the ridge lean wrong, in case I had to put my hand into their guts and feel for the break. The thermocycler clicked down to warm and then to cold. The mushrooms held their glow, faint and earnest. Behind the clinic, the river made its stupid noises as it hit broken concrete and old pylons. The fields beyond had more dust than dirt, more grit than loam. I had a thumb of wheat that might not know how to stop itself, an organism that might remember seed. I had a pocket full of bacteria that didn’t know what the word obsolete meant. I had a contract not written on paper but on the inside of my mouth, that I’d say the words and mean them when the client asked: yes, we made your thing; yes, we’ll trade; yes, send them what we need; yes, send me something I can use when the next body comes to my door spiked with the last century’s idea of a lock. Outside, the sun scraped light across the tiles and the mushrooms drank it, slowly, their glow sinking the way breath sinks in sleep. I patted the thermocycler. It stayed warm under my hand like a creature that had been tamed, for now. I lay the new seeds in their box, sealed, right where the glow was strongest, and watched them until the fan hummed and the room clicked and the day gathered without asking what any of us planned. I had a blade sharp enough to open obsolescence and see if it bled. I had work to do. I had a world to cheat back into its own design. The market could have its cut. The rest I meant to keep.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk chapter successfully creates a vivid post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering with built-in obsolescence has collapsed society. The author excels at world-building through detailed descriptions of jury-rigged lab equipment and the biohacker protagonist's work environment. The prose is highly atmospheric, with strong sensory details that immerse the reader in this decaying world. Descriptions like "Threads of blue-green glow from the seams where hairline cracks had taken root, like veins under skin" and the detailed explanations of repurposed equipment create a tangible setting. The author effectively uses technical language related to genetic engineering that feels authentic without becoming impenetrable. The protagonist is well-developed through their internal monologue and interactions with Jori. Their expertise, determination, and philosophical stance on genetic freedom come through clearly. The physical toll of genetic modifications is addressed through the protagonist's catalog of bodily changes: "My lungs ran on a weird patchwork of modified alveolar proteins that let me breathe easier after the dust storms, but sometimes when the air was still I could taste copper and see blue halos around things in the dark." The black market contract plot is integrated well, with Jori bringing a valuable pre-obsolescence seed that needs to be sequenced for a powerful client. The stakes are clear, and the transaction feels appropriately tense and morally complex. The dialogue is sparse but effective, revealing character dynamics and world details naturally. The protagonist's voice maintains a consistent tone throughout—knowledgeable, somewhat cynical, but with an underlying idealism about genetic freedom. Where the piece could improve is in its pacing. The narrative sometimes lingers too long on descriptive passages, particularly of equipment, which occasionally slows the momentum. While the technical details add authenticity, they sometimes overshadow character development and plot progression. The ending strikes a balance between pragmatism and hope that feels earned given the world's constraints. The protagonist's determination to "cheat [the world] back into its own design" provides a satisfying conclusion that doesn't feel artificially positive given the grim setting. Overall, this is a strong piece of biopunk fiction that successfully creates a detailed post-apocalyptic world where genetic engineering has gone wrong. The author demonstrates a good command of both scientific concepts and literary techniques, creating an engaging narrative that fulfills the prompt requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Iteration 2 — Avg Score: 90.6
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The transfer vessel's air filtration system hums with a persistent mechanical drone. Arthur Neegan sat in a seat bolted to the bulkhead and listened to it, counting the pulses as if they were the steps of a march. The chair was upholstered in something that pretended to be leather and failed. The ceiling above him arced with ribs of enamel-white metal, each rib marked with crisp serial numerals suggested by people who believed that order could substitute for comfort. Across from him, a man in a uniform that could not decide whether it was dress or armor sat with his hands folded. The insignia on his shoulder—an eight-pointed star with two intersecting orbits—was familiar in only the way a threat is familiar. The Antares Diplomatic Corps. Diplomatic in name, and otherwise practical. "You'll like the view," said the uniformed man, as if that reconciled anything. His voice was neither friendly nor hostile. It was a voice that reported weather and casualties with equal intonation. "We break orbit in twelve minutes. Dock in nineteen." "Antares?" Arthur asked. "You boys are far from your constellation." The man allowed himself a small, official smile. "We don't belong to the star, Mr. Neegan. Only the name." Arthur glanced at the viewport. The Martian sky outside was the color of diluted rust, shadowed by the metallic bones of the transfer tower. His settlement—sediment-stained hab domes, a plastcrete strip, a scatter of antennae that had been straight once and now leaned like exhausted men—was a curve of memory over the horizon. Somewhere under that red, under that brittle crust, under a hundred meters of angry basalt and lightless ice, lay the dark seam that had changed everything. Azra. He had hit it by accident, then confirmed it by every method that would stand up in a technical review and none that would stand up in a court. He rubbed his fingers together. They still smelled faintly of the metal, though chemically Azra had no odor. He had convinced himself that a catalytic accelerator for decay should be cold as sunlight. Yet when he first held a fragment in the glove, it had felt warm. "You took my neighbors' guns," he said. "Temporarily. There were safety concerns." "So when this is over," Arthur said, and felt his voice go dry, "you give them back?" "If it's over," the uniformed man said. The smile had departed. The hatch whispered. A woman entered without hurry. She did not wear the Antares insignia. She wore a garment that might have been a dress if dresses were designed by engineers: straight lines, reinforced seams, a collar that suggested she liked her neck exactly where it was. She carried no weapon unless you counted her eyes. "Mr. Neegan," she said. "My apologies for the abruptness of the invitation. I'm Lydia Voss. I'm here as a facilitator." "For Antares?" "For my client." "And your client is?" She looked at him with the kind of patience that promised the answer would arrive soon, and that—when it did—he would wish she had delayed. "Briefly," she said, and sat opposite him, ignoring the uniformed man without dismissing him. "The situation is unstable. Your discovery destabilizes it further. Everyone is nervous. Nervous people make expensive mistakes." "I agree," Arthur said. "On Mars we prefer our mistakes cheap." The filtration hum shifted half a note as the transfer vessel's attitude thrusters adjusted. Arthur felt the faint pressure of inertia on his shoulders, the way one feels an accusation one has not earned. "Mr. Neegan," Voss said. "You are first-generation colonial stock, yes? Born under the Dome at Syrtis Minor. Engineering academy, fourth in your cohort. Your dissertation was on heat dissipation in vacuum microenvironments. If you had not come to Helios Quadrant to take an unremarkable lease on Sector J-19, you would likely be teaching now, perhaps arguing with auditors about the cost of thermal wafers." "I appreciate the biography," Arthur said. "It saves me the trouble. What would you like?" "What we all want," she said. "A predictable future. And in particular, a future in which Azra does not make all the other futures shorter." She folded her hands. Arthur noticed the absence of rings. He had never trusted hands with much to hide. These hands were plain. That was one thing to fear. "It accelerates decay," she said. "You found a way to tame that. At least locally." Arthur looked at the ceiling. He thought of the vein, of the way the sensors went blind around it. Of how instruments that had never failed now offered numbers that read like poems. Azra made containers weep neutrons and equations develop personalities. Yet in the presence of certain fields and a certain geometry—his geometry—it stabilized. Local, temperamental, expensive. Enough to make a drive roar louder, a bomb whisper cruelty, a civilization recalibrate its tables of half-lives. "I found a way to make it misbehave on command," he said. "Taming is your word." Voss nodded. "It will do. The point is that you control an input. That makes you more interesting than a rock." The uniformed man cleared his throat. "Ms. Voss," he said, making the name a rank. "The passenger is to be prepared for the meeting. Not interrogated." "This isn't an interrogation," Voss said. "It's a courtesy. Mr. Neegan deserves context." "I'd settle for a destination," Arthur said. "We're docking where?" "The relay station at Phobos Alt-2," she said. "Antares maintains a hollowing there. Private. Then we proceed outward." "Outward," he said. "Antares has jurisdiction outward?" "Jurisdiction is an attitude. You'll find there are a great many attitudes in orbit, Mr. Neegan." He stared at her and thought of maps. As a boy he had traced the red. As a man he had learned to read the blue lines the way a driller reads grain. No map had prepared him for this: statelets stacked like cards, authorities intersecting like shadows. "Why me and not some corporate board?" he asked. "Helios Mining would sell me to you and send an invoice." "They would," Voss agreed. "But Azra is not ore. It's leverage. Boards prefer assets to remain in categories they understand. People do not always oblige. Besides, Helios is... occupied." She glanced at the uniformed man, who did not nod. "An audit. Unrelated, of course." "Of course," Arthur said. He felt his mouth twist. The retrofitted construct of colonial law, the long cables stringing Mars to Earth and Earth to the Belt, trembled with Azra's discovery. If you braced a finger along the cable, you could feel the oscillation, the human tone in it. "We'll meet my client," Voss said. "They will make you an offer. You will accept, or not. But I would like you to go in informed. The Antares Corps is one vector. The Central Earth Secretariat is another. The Neptune Arcology Alliance, a third. There are lesser vectors. All believe that control of Azra translates to survival. They are not wrong. All believe they can apply control as if Azra were water in a pipe. They are wrong." "And you?" Arthur asked. "Are you right?" "No," she said. "But we can be less wrong, and sooner." He thought of the first time he had leaned over the pit and watched the drill head stutter. He thought of the call to his sister in Lowell, of her silence when he said the word "Azra," as if her tongue had been told that certain syllables had new prices. "You're not telling me something fundamental," he said. "Several things," Voss said. "But one in particular: Azra isn't confined to your lot. It isn't a Mars anomaly. It is a network phenomenon. The vein is a node. The nodes resonate. The more you extract, the more you wake its neighbors. The more it hears itself, the more it acts like a single thing. My client is concerned that if enough nodes resonate, the network will self-organize." "What does that mean?" Arthur asked. He didn't like where the words were headed. Self-organize was a term he had used only in reference to dust storms and bureaucracy. "It means that the decay will stop being an accident," Voss said. "It will be a choice. And things that can choose—" "Have politics," Arthur said. "Precisely." The transfer vessel shivered along a diagonal. The viewport showed a slice of gray-black studded with the faint geometries of Phobos Alt-2. It was not beautiful. It was efficient. Torch cones glowed a dull cherry as they rotated. Docking booms extended like the feelers of an insect that had adapted to vacuum and budget cuts. "Who is your client?" Arthur said again. "I've done my courtesy. Give me yours." Voss looked at her watch as if it meant something. Perhaps it did. Timepieces in space were less about time than about authority. "The client calls itself the Third Martian Council," she said. "There is no Third Martian Council," Arthur said. "I would have noticed the first two." "There was a First," Voss said mildly. "It met for four hours in a storage unit at Utopia Planitia forty years ago, decided it could not pay for coffee, and dissolved. The Second exists in the charters of several cooperatives who prefer not to use it. The Third exists as an alliance of computational assemblies distributed across fourteen habitats. It argues with itself constantly. It does not pay for coffee either. But it represents an emergent Martian will. It is eager to make you an offer before Earth makes you a threat." "And Antares?" Arthur asked, indicating the uniformed man with his chin. "We rent the room," the uniformed man said. "We ensure the meeting occurs without an accident. Or with the right one." The docking alarm chimed: a gentle, civilized sound designed by someone who had read about bells. The vessel thumped lightly as clamps engaged. "You will have an escort," Voss said. "It will be a courtesy escort, which is to say they will be armed." "And if I decline the offer?" Arthur asked. "You will leave free," she said. "In the sense that someone will own every corridor you exit." The hatch opened with budgeted smoothness. The docking collar extended with a hiss that was theater; there is no hiss in vacuum. They walked. The corridor to the hollowing was a spiral of gray with occasional windows that framed pieces of Mars like fragments of a broken coin. Phobos Alt-2’s interior was a cathedral of mass ratios. Cargo canisters stood in stacks along rails that glided overhead. Men and women in coveralls, in uniforms, in anonymous black moved with intent, each motion a line in an equation that solved for power. At a door marked only with a square of matte blue, Voss stopped. "You'll forgive the formality," she said. "They prefer projections. It keeps the ghosts out." "The ghosts?" Arthur said. "Intention leaves residue," she said. "In a room like this, you can choke on it." Inside, the walls were smooth and indifferent. The light was not sourced; it existed. A table occupied the center—old Earth wood sealed under glass, its grain a reminder that once, biomes made furniture for us. Three chairs waited. In the seat opposite, a shape flickered into being. It was a man of indeterminate middle age and impossible clarity, as if the air had decided to assemble a person out of diligence. "Mr. Neegan," the projection said. Its voice was warm. "I am Third. I apologize for dramatics. We find it constructive." "Third," Arthur said. He sat carefully. Voss took the chair to his left. The uniformed man stood by the door, an armed exclamation mark. "You represent Mars," Arthur said, because someone had to put the sentence into the air to see what it did. "I represent a faction of Mars that believes Mars can be more than a mine," Third said. "I represent neighborhoods and networks. I represent the fact that the people who were born here do not expect to return to Earth to die." "Offers," Voss said gently. "Yes," Third said, and smiled. It was a practiced, human smile. Arthur felt himself like it despite himself. "Mr. Neegan: we cannot protect you from the storm. We can give you windbreaks. You have a claim on a thing that makes engines swift and bombs delicate. You have a method that makes it somewhat safe to touch. Earth will take it. Antares will rent it. Saturn will tempt. The price will be your voice. We propose this instead: you put your seam into a cooperative trust under Martian law. We license your method across nodes we control. In return, we guarantee—through our alliances, through people like Ms. Voss—that your family remains safe, your neighbors remain armed, your name is attached to standards that will be difficult to undo. We will make Azra into a public utility." "A public utility," Arthur repeated. The words tasted like old speeches. "You're asking me to nationalize my vein." "We're asking you not to privatize annihilation," Third said. "We will make mistakes. But we will make them here, and we will make them in public." "And if I sell to the highest bidder?" Arthur said. His voice was softer than he intended. He thought of the price lists that would appear in his message queue, of the lines at his door. He thought of his sister's silence. "Then someone will own the future," Third said. "And they will put a lock on it that does not release." Voss leaned closer. "There are other offers," she said. "I could read them to you. They sound like money and safety and exit visas to houses with gravity and gardens. They are not lies. But they omit costs. The things omitted have a way of appearing later with interest." The projection adjusted itself, a ripple of photons correcting for a room that was never quite still. "Mr. Neegan," it said. "Azra's network notices itself. If we are decisions now, so is it. Do we want those decisions to arise in boardrooms that consider oxygen a line item? Or in assemblies that argue about school hours? It is not romance. It is arithmetic." Arthur put his elbows on the table and laced his fingers. He was a man of ratios and tolerances. He had done the math on thermal wafers and on the cost of replacing a gearbox when the nearest replacement was two months and a bribe away. He had not done this math. He began to. "You'll need my method," he said. "It's in my head, and half in my notes, and half in the way I stand when I tune the coils. You think you can take it?" "We think we can teach you how to teach us," Third said. "We think we can make your method survive you, which is the only survival that matters. We offer you a place to stand. If you prefer to sell your weight elsewhere, you may. The tug-of-war will continue, with you as rope. Here, at least, we intend to let you walk away with your hands." "And Antares?" Arthur asked, turning to Voss. "Antares will help this occur without a fatal misunderstanding," she said. "Our insignia is a warning to those who would misunderstand." "And your price?" Arthur said. "The price is that when Mars calls us, we can say we were useful," Voss said. "Useful organizations live longer." He glanced at the uniformed man. The eight-pointed star answered nothing. Outside, the hum of the filtration system had receded into a background as natural as breath. Arthur, who had built a life out of partitions—between heat and cold, between vacuum and blood—looked at the partitions in front of him and saw that they were provisional, and that the air on both sides smelled like Azra even when it shouldn't. He exhaled. He remembered the way the drill had stuttered. He remembered counting pulses. They had counted back. "I'll need assurances," he said. "Contracts, not meetings. Safeguards. We do this under Martian law, yes? Then Martian law will need teeth." "We have collected some," Third said. "We expect to lose a few in the process." "And I want my neighbors' guns back," Arthur said, looking at the uniformed man. "All of them." "That will be arranged," Voss said. He nodded. It was not agreement. It was the first motion of a lever. He felt the weight of it. There were other rooms to sit in, other offers to hear. But the arithmetic had begun to solve itself, crudely, on the table between them. "Very well," Arthur said. "Let's define 'public utility.' Let's define 'trust.' And then let's define how we keep the network from making decisions we don't." Third's smile held. It was not triumph. It was hope wearing armor. "We began that conversation before you were born," it said. "We will be delighted to continue it with you." The filtration drone was back in his ears. For the first time since the insignia had appeared at his door, Arthur found that he could not hear the hum without also hearing, faintly, the possibility of a different noise: a crowd arguing, a machine learning, an ore singing. He straightened. "All right," he said. "Teach me what you think you know about Azra's mind. Then I'll show you where it's wrong."
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This response is an impressive piece of science fiction that captures Asimov's style remarkably well. The author has created a chapter that feels authentic to classic sci-fi while developing an intriguing political scenario around the discovery of Azra. The prose demonstrates a sophisticated command of language with precise, technical descriptions that evoke the retrofuturistic aesthetic requested. Descriptions like "The ceiling above him arced with ribs of enamel-white metal, each rib marked with crisp serial numerals suggested by people who believed that order could substitute for comfort" efficiently establish both the physical environment and the sociopolitical context. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinct voice that reveals their position and motivation. The exchanges between Arthur, Voss, and Third are layered with subtext and political maneuvering. Lines like "Jurisdiction is an attitude. You'll find there are a great many attitudes in orbit, Mr. Neegan" efficiently communicate the complex power dynamics at play. The world-building is excellent, revealing both the immediate situation and the larger political landscape through natural conversation and observation rather than exposition. The concept of Azra as a network that "notices itself" introduces fascinating philosophical and scientific dimensions that feel true to Asimov's interest in both technology and human systems. Character development is handled with subtlety. Arthur is portrayed as practical and analytical, weighing his options carefully while maintaining his principles. His request for his neighbors' guns to be returned reveals his loyalty to his community. Voss is enigmatic but professional, while Third represents a complex political entity with its own agenda. The pacing is well-managed, with the tension building naturally through the meeting. The stakes are clearly established—control of Azra could determine the future of human civilization—without resorting to melodrama. There are a few moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought, with metaphors occasionally stacked too densely. However, these instances are rare and don't significantly detract from the overall quality. The ending strikes an appropriate balance, avoiding both naive optimism and cynical despair. Arthur's decision to engage with Third while maintaining his independence feels earned and consistent with his character. Overall, this is an exceptional response that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while creating a compelling narrative with depth and nuance. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 19

+ Contemporary romance: Darkroom Revelations — Score: 88.4
Prompt:
Darkroom Revelations Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of Dani, a 25-year-old assertive art student known for her bold style and take-charge attitude in relationships. For the past semester, she's been quietly fascinated by Elliot (he/him), a 19-year-old boy in her experimental photography class. Dani has been intrigued by his unconventional masculinity: killer thrift-shop-nu-goth style, soft demeanour and quiet intellect. When they're paired for a final project requiring late nights in the darkroom, Elliot tentatively shares that he's been questioning his gender identity and expression. Set during one of these intimate darkroom sessions where the red light creates a confessional atmosphere. Explore Dani's complex attraction—her usual assertiveness complicated by her desire to protect Elliot's vulnerability, her excitement at witnessing his self-discovery, and her confusion about what this means for her own identity as someone typically attracted to more defined gender presentations.
