The narrative should capture the tender awkwardness of their conversations, Dani's internal struggle between taking charge and wanting to give Elliot agency, and the unexpected chemistry that develops as both find themselves in uncharted territory. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The darkroom door sighs shut, and the world becomes measured in breath and red light. It paints Elliot’s face the color of a pulse, and somehow he looks even softer, the edges of him turned to velvet and shadow. It should feel like my element—the gritty, wet chemical smell, the familiar clunk of trays on the counter, the way my hands know what to do even when my brain’s a mess. But tonight something else is taking up room, settling where my certainty usually lives. He’s quiet, careful, the kind of person who moves around the enlarger like it could bruise, like he could bruise. A black tee cut raw at the neck, a thrift-store belt with a silver buckle, rings that shine like coins pulled from a river. He wears his hair in a way that makes it look intentional, like a statement and a shrug at once. His boots hardly make a sound. Maybe that’s what I noticed first—how he manages to occupy space without demanding it. Me, I’ve been the opposite my whole life. I push. I shoulder in. I fill. “Okay,” I say, tapping the edge of the easel with my nail. “Show me how you’re framing it.” He nods, slides the negative carrier into the enlarger, his fingers long and ink-stained. He adjusts the focus until the image floats sharp: my laugh caught mid-burst, mouth open, hair in motion—he’s been catching me all semester, like I’m a bird he’s got a gentle hand on. It makes me feel both seen and held, and I’m not used to the second part. “I still can’t believe you got that shot,” I say, even though what I mean is I can’t believe you were watching me with that kind of attention. I don’t say it. I’m the teacher’s pet of not saying things. “I shoot a lot on instinct.” His voice is low, soft, not shy exactly. Measured. “Like if I think about it too hard, the moment gets self-conscious and runs away.” “Yeah,” I say, and it lands between us like we’re agreeing on a secret. It’s the end of the semester, the part where the air on campus freezes into that particular brittle hopefulness. The final project is supposed to be conceptual, collaborative. The professor paired us because she thought my bossiness and his quiet might cancel each other out. “He’ll rein you in,” she’d said. “You’ll pull him out.” I am very good at pulling. I want to be good at not. He flips on the timer, and the enlarger bulb hums like a small, contented animal. I slide a fresh sheet of paper under the easel with the muscle memory of a thousand prints. The red light makes everything seductive, even the damned tongs. We work without speaking for a while, the soundtrack a soft symphony of timers, dripping, our breaths aligning. He slides the exposed paper into the developer, and I take over, rocking the tray gently, watching the image ghost into view. Alchemy, I fell for it the way one falls for the first person who tells you you’re too much and you decide to become even more. “Can I tell you something?” he asks, just as the shadows finish filling my hair. His eyes—eyeliner smudged, lashes thick—are on the tray. He speaks like the words are heavy and he’s tired of carrying them alone. I brace myself without meaning to. I don’t want to bulldoze his confession. I don’t want to say the wrong thing in the right tone and have it sound like permission rather than listening. “Yeah,” I say quietly. “Tell me.” He clears his throat, the sound paper-thin in the red. “I’ve been…thinking a lot about gender.” A beat. “My own.” The developer ticks in the tray against the plastic like rain. I keep rocking. He continues before I can make a shape out of my thoughts. “I mean, I’ve always felt it, but this semester it’s like—I don’t know. Lens flare. Suddenly I can’t pretend it’s an accident.” “And what are you thinking?” I ask, and there it is: I keep my hands moving and my voice soft, like I’m developing his sentences and hoping they turn out. He laughs, a tiny burst, nervous. “That maybe I don’t fit the…conventional masculine thing. That I like he/him. But I also like…that some things feel better when I don’t have to be a certain way to be recognized.” He looks at me then. “Does that make sense?” “Yes,” I say, and I mean it. The word is steady. “It makes a lot of sense.” He looks relieved in a way that makes me want to wrap him up and stand between him and any oncoming storm. That’s my instinct: make myself a wall, a heat source, a shield. My attraction has always been to people who want to be pushed against that wall, who want me to bite as much as kiss. But I’ve been fascinated by the way he exists outside those rules, a softness that isn’t weakness, a masculinity that doesn’t need to win to matter. I’ve noticed his bracelets, the way he touches a print like it might be warm, the quiet he doesn’t apologize for. “I like the pronouns I have,” he says. “I just—I also like painting my nails and wanting people to see it as…part of me, not a contradiction. And some days I like wearing a skirt. I haven’t here. Yet. And I look at the guys in our class who are all…” He wiggles his fingers and I understand he means angles, lines, certainty. “And I don’t see myself in them. And it’s not like I want to be a girl. It’s like the binary is denim that fits someone else’s hips.” I laugh then, soft and probably adoring. I can’t help it. “That’s a good metaphor.” “You like denim,” he says, glancing down at my paint-splattered jeans. He notices things. It’s devastating. “I like you, period,” I almost say. Instead, I lift the print to the stop bath, slide it in. The smell of acetic acid cuts through the air and through my reluctance. “What do you want people to see when they look at you?” I ask. He leans back against the counter, head tilted, looking up like the answer might be stuck to the ceiling. “I want them to see that I’m allowed to be gentle and still be me. That softness isn’t…a curve to be cut off to fit a mold.” He says the last part like he’s bracing for a joke. I feel the familiar heat of my boldness rising—my reflex to make a big statement, to turn this into something I can nail to a wall. I want to say, I’ll fight anyone who tries to sharpen your edges. I want to say, try a skirt, I’ll walk next to you. Instead I take a breath and decide to let him choose the next move, right there in the red light. “Can I be selfish?” I say. “And ask how I fit in this?” It’s as close to vulnerability as I’m used to. I can feel my own outline blurring a little. I like men. I like the ones who meet my push with their own. Elliot complicates the category in a way that puts a sweet ache under my ribs. He turns toward me and the space between us becomes a thing. “I don’t know,” he admits, relief and fear braided in the words. “I haven’t—this is the first time I’ve said any of it out loud. To anyone.” Something loosens. I place the print into the fixer and set the timer. “Then let’s not figure out everything tonight,” I say. “We can start with you saying it out loud and me listening without making it my project.” He smiles, crooked. “You do like a project.” “I do,” I say, grimacing at myself. “But I like you more.” The timer clicks, the third tray now full of a picture of me laughing like I don’t know I’m being witnessed. I turn the print in the fixer and try not to romanticize the metaphor. He reaches past me to grab the next sheet of paper, and in the economy of the darkroom a simple movement becomes clumsy intimacy. His hand bumps the box. It slides. I grab for it. He grabs for it. The flap flies open. The stack of glossy paper thumps against the counter and fans like doomed snow in the red light. “Shit,” we say at the same time. And then: “Sorry,” also at the same time. We both freeze. The papers lie there, exposed and already graying. There’s a second where it feels like we can pretend it didn’t happen if we don’t breathe. I start to laugh, a little hysterical edge in it. The spell cracks without breaking. “Well. That’s…half our budget.” He looks stricken. “I’m so—” “Hey.” I put a hand up like a crossing guard and an apology parachute. “Accidents happen. And maybe it’s good for us. Unplanned. Raw edges.” I’m trying not to boss the situation into a lesson, but the first thing I think is: this is an image too. Blown exposure. Waste as artifact. He eyes me like he’s trying to decide if I’m making him feel better or turning tragedy into a thesis. “We are so screwed.” “We’ll figure it out,” I say. And then: “Maybe we could use it.” I pick up a sheet, gesture at the faint ghost forming just from the ambient exposure. “Conceptually. The idea of what gets overexposed. Overseen. And what we want to protect in the dark.” He blinks, and the corner of his mouth twitches. “You’re impossible.” “And you love it,” I tease, and then realize the word is out there, pulsing. “I mean. You will love it. The idea. Maybe.” His gaze does something that makes my stomach drop in a good way. “I like that your first instinct is to turn spilled milk into a milk painting.” “Dairy-based art is my specialty.” He laughs, the tension dissolving just enough. We gather the ruined sheets and stack them like we’re making a pyre for our mistakes. I make a mental note to buy a new box tomorrow and not tell him how much it costs. “So,” I say, because the quiet hovers in a new shape. “Do you want me to use different language when I talk about you? Or do you want me to…just know and watch?” He props his hip against the counter, the seam of his jeans worn, the ring on his middle finger catching the red. “For now, he/him is good. I think what I want is permission to…dial up or down without needing to justify the settings.” “Done,” I say, too fast, and then I slow down. “I mean. Yes. And if I mess up, tell me, yeah? Don’t make me guess and then resent me for guessing wrong.” His shoulders drop like I’ve cut a string that was holding them up uncomfortably. “Thank you.” I want to step forward and touch the side of his face, to thumb the smear of eyeliner near his eye, to say, I’m here. I want to tell him that his softness is an invitation to my own, which is terrifying. I’ve spent years being the one who knows where we’re going and how we’re going to get there. I can map a project before we’ve even taken the first shot. I can take a lover apart like a machine and put them back together better than I found them. But that’s not what this is. This is new terrain, damp and luminous, edges unsharp. “We should pull that,” he says, pointing at the fixer. I retrieve the print and clip it to the line. My laughing face spins slowly, dripping. “It’s weird to look at yourself on a line,” he says. “Weirder to look at yourself in someone else’s viewfinder,” I say. He considers that, cheeks shadowed. “It’s nice, sometimes. To be held in a frame that isn’t a trap.” We fall into a rhythm again, making do with the few sheets left in the box, our hands occasionally brushing. Each touch is more loaded than the last, like adding a stop more light each exposure. He talks in pockets, like reaching into his own coat and pulling out scraps: how he tried on his girlfriend’s skirt when he was sixteen and felt beautiful and then felt guilty for feeling beautiful; how he wears rings because they make his gestures feel like sentences. I tell him about my first boyfriend who was so sure of himself that I wore his certainty like a jacket until I realized it didn’t fit me either. I tell him how I always fall for men who know they’re men, whose bodies meet mine like a challenge. I do not tell him that his hesitation is turning me inside out. When we’re washing the last print, he says, “Do you think there’s room for me? Like this? With someone like you?” I dry my hands on a towel and choose my words like negatives from a contact sheet. “I think there’s room for whatever we decide. If we decide. I don’t want to…steer you somewhere because it’s easier for me.” He steps closer, the air changing pressure. “The thing is,” he says, looking at my mouth and then away, “I don’t feel like you’re steering. I feel like you’re walking next to me and checking I’m wearing good shoes.” I smile. “Practicality is sexy.” He laughs again, and then he doesn’t. The red light hums. The wash water patters. I can feel him thinking. “Can I—” he starts, and then stops, which is so unlike me that it almost breaks me. I step forward the smallest amount and angle my head in a way that says, you can try. But I don’t close the space. I don’t take. I invite. He leans in and kisses me the way he shoots—a little tentative, instinctive, like if he thinks too hard it will run away. His mouth is warm, unpainted, tasting like chemical air and whatever he had for dinner. It is not the kind of kiss that pins. It is the kind that asks. I answer without swallowing him whole. I kiss him back like agreeing, like yes, like a darkroom where a picture slowly appears and then refuses to disappear again. His hand finds my wrist and doesn't tighten, just rests, matching my pulse. My whole body is a light meter trying not to max out. We pull back and look at each other like we’re checking for blur. “That okay?” he says. “Yeah,” I say, steadier than I feel. “Yeah.” We don’t pretend the questions are gone. We don’t pretend the paper didn’t get ruined. We don’t pretend we’ve named this. We move around each other for the next hour with that kiss hovering between us like a third thing we’re protecting from the wrong light. I don’t boss him into another. He doesn’t apologize for wanting. We make prints that fail and some that don’t. We talk about the project and the idea of overexposure and what it means to be seen too much and not enough. By the time we step out into the hallway, blinking against the fluorescent truth of the school at night, the red afterimage still floats in my vision. I can see the shape of him beside me even in the neutral light. He brushes my shoulder with his, accidentally-on-purpose, and I resist the urge to grab his hand. Instead I ask, “Coffee tomorrow? No darkroom. Just…light.” He nods, the corner of his mouth lifting. “Yeah. Let’s try light.” As we walk, I think about how my attraction has always looked like a strong line and a dark shadow, the comfort of contrast. This feels like a gradient, the kind you have to stand close to to see where one thing becomes another. It feels less like taking and more like opening. It scares me. It thrills me. It makes me want to be gentle without feeling small. Back in my apartment later, my fingers still smell like fixer. I hold them up to my face and think about how some images don’t care what you planned. You set your exposure, you line up your shot, and then the light finds a way in. You ruin a stack of paper and have to start over with something unexpected. You hold someone else’s confession like a print in a tray and tilt it, patient, watching the picture appear. And you learn not to rush it, even if your hands are itching to grab, to lead, to decide. An hour ago, under red light, I saw something I didn’t know I was looking for. I want to keep looking, even if it means I have to learn a new way of seeing. I want to walk next to him, practical and protectively useless in the face of whatever he has to find, art school budgets and all. Maybe I’m not losing my edge. Maybe I’m finding a curve I didn’t know could hold me. Tomorrow we’ll figure out how to pay for new paper. Tomorrow I’ll ask him what kind of nail polish looks best on him and if he wants me to go with him to buy it. Tonight, I let the image sit and fix. I let myself soften and stay.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures Dani's perspective as she navigates her attraction to Elliot during their darkroom session. The piece effectively establishes Dani's assertive personality while showing her internal struggle to temper this trait when interacting with Elliot's vulnerability. The writing excels in creating the intimate atmosphere of the darkroom, using the red light and chemical processes as both setting and metaphor. The sensory details are particularly strong, from the "gritty, wet chemical smell" to the sound of "timers, dripping, our breaths aligning." These details ground the reader in the physical space while the emotional landscape unfolds. The characterization is nuanced and believable. Dani's internal monologue reveals her typical approach to relationships ("I push. I shoulder in. I fill.") while showing her conscious effort to create space for Elliot. Her attraction to his "unconventional masculinity" feels authentic, as does her confusion about what this means for her own identity. The writer skillfully portrays Dani's struggle between her instinct to "bulldoze" and her desire to listen. Elliot's character is well-developed through Dani's observations and their dialogue. His tentative disclosure about questioning his gender identity feels natural and unforced. The conversation flows organically, with realistic hesitations and awkward moments that enhance the authenticity of their interaction. The prose is generally elegant, with effective metaphors that illuminate the characters' emotional states. For example, "I can feel my own outline blurring a little" aptly captures Dani's sense that her usual certainty about attraction is being challenged. The photography metaphors are particularly apt given the setting and the characters' artistic backgrounds. The narrative does occasionally veer into slightly purple prose, with some metaphors feeling a bit strained. Lines like "My whole body is a light meter trying not to max out" work well within the photography theme, but others like "I'm the teacher's pet of not saying things" feel somewhat forced. The dialogue is strong, capturing both characters' distinct voices while conveying their emotional states. The conversation about gender identity is handled with sensitivity and nuance, avoiding both oversimplification and melodrama. The pacing is effective, with the narrative building naturally to the kiss while maintaining tension throughout. The ending strikes an appropriate balance, acknowledging the uncertainty of their situation while offering a sense of possibility that feels earned rather than artificially imposed. Overall, this is a sophisticated piece that successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements. It explores Dani's complex attraction to Elliot with psychological depth and emotional honesty, while creating a vivid sensory experience for the reader. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Contemporary romance / drama: Stolen Moments in Roma — Score: 94.8
Prompt:
Contemporary Romance / Drama: Stolen Moments in Roma. Write a series of interconnected short scenes and dialogues that span a single day in modern-day Rome, in narrative form. This will form the beginning of a larger story. Alessandra, a fiery, independent Roman woman who works as a motorcycle courier, nearly collides with Ben, a somewhat clumsy, overly polite British academic on sabbatical, who is engrossed in a guidebook near the Trevi Fountain. The initial encounter is a clash of cultures and personalities – Alessandra is all sharp wit and rapid-fire Italian, while Ben is flustered apologies and awkward attempts at speaking the language. However, as they sort out the near-miss, a spark of unexpected humor and connection emerges. Alessandra, it quickly becomes clear, is a whirlwind of energy and mischief. She's a self-admitted troublemaker with a secret penchant for kleptomania, a detail she doesn't explicitly reveal, but which manifests in subtle, daring acts throughout the day. She impulsively decides to take Ben on a wild, unsanctioned tour of Rome, dragging him in some specific instances far outside his comfort zone. Ben, despite his initial apprehension and inherent politeness, finds himself utterly captivated by Alessandra's unapologetic spirit and zest for life. He is drawn into her orbit, a willing participant in increasingly outlandish situations, a quiet rebellion brewing beneath his scholarly exterior. The narrative should primarily consist of short, vivid scenes and dialogue exchanges, revealing their contrasting personalities and backgrounds, and the growing, ambiguous tension between them. Ben is captivated by Alessandra's energy and the thrill of breaking free from his routine. There's a clear sense that Alessandra is toying with Ben, pushing his boundaries and enjoying his reactions, but her own feelings remain somewhat enigmatic. The day should be a rollercoaster of exhilarating, slightly dangerous, and humorous moments, leaving Ben completely disoriented but utterly smitten. Explore the underlying tension & chemistry between them, culminating in some payoff as they part ways (or not -- your choice). Include this detail: Write in narrative prose, using immersive storytelling. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The near-collision happens in a slick of shadow, where the Trevi Fountain throws white noise over the cobbles and tourists cluster like shoals. Alessandra is a flash of red helmet, knee out, a streak of exhaust, and then she is a curse and a brake squeal. Ben is a page number, 263, finger sticking to the guidebook as he stumbles backward and his tote bag slides off his shoulder in slow motion, spilling pens and a dog-eared map like confetti. “Ma sei cieco?” Alessandra barks, one foot planting as the bike jerks to a stop, the back end fishtailing with a petulant wiggle. The Vespa’s side panel, mint-green and scarred with a long shredded rainbow of paint, glints in the midday sun. “You walk like—like a turistone zombie.” Ben’s glasses slide down his nose. He grabs at the handlebar as if to steady her, then aborts halfway, flustered. “I’m terribly—terribly sorry. The—er—guidebook warned about pickpockets and I—well, I wasn’t looking.” “No kidding,” she snaps, but her eyes are laughing, dark with curiosity and annoyance in equal parts. “You want to die at Fontana di Trevi? Dramatic. But you will ruin the picture of all the girls throwing coins.” He stoops to pick up his pens. “I wasn’t throwing coins. I—apparently that’s a tourist tax. I’m trying to do the city without… the usual things.” A corner of her mouth twitches. Behind her visor, something like mischief lifts its head. “Ah. An intellectual.” She darts off the bike, quick, compact, as if her bones are wired to springs. She crouches to help him gather his scattered life. One of her hands closes over a small brass coin that seems to have rolled out of nowhere. Ben doesn’t see it. Neither does the businessman patting his pockets ten feet away. Ben looks up. She’s closer than he expects, the smell of gasoline and orange blossom cologne and rain-wet stone all around her. The scratch along the Vespa’s flank is punkish and proud, a story without details. “I’m Alessandra,” she says, flicking the visor up. Her eyes are green enough to be illegal. “And you owe me… a coffee, at least, for almost denting my baby.” She thumps the colorful scar affectionately. “Don’t look at me like that. She was like this when I met her. More or less.” “I’m Ben. From—well, from Oxford.” He hears how pompous it sounds and winces. “On sabbatical. I didn’t mean to—” “Oxford,” she repeats, savoring it like a sweet. “Bene. So. Coffee. Or are you going to run away and read about Rome instead of tasting it?” He allows himself a breathless laugh. “Lead the way.” She grins, full of teeth, and claps him on the shoulder like they’ve been friends for years. Then she pockets the brass coin with liquid ease, a motion as natural as smoothing back her hair. The bar is one of those that hides behind a faded awning two turns away from the fountain, where the city softens and the clack of cups is a semaphore. Alessandra orders without asking him. “Due caffè, uno corretto,” she tells the barista, and raises an eyebrow at Ben. “For your nerves.” “Corretto?” he repeats. “Corrected,” she says. “With grappa. You look like your soul needs a push.” He wants to protest. He doesn’t. The espresso is tar and sunlight, the grappa a thin lightning that warms his ribs. She talks with her hands, sharp little flicks of finger and wrist. He notices how often those hands touch things: a napkin holder, the sugar spoon, his sleeve just above the elbow as if to emphasize a point. Twice, for a heartbeat, the barista’s eyes flick to a bowl of wrapped chocolates on the counter; when they leave, one sits on the saucer by Ben’s cup as if it’s always been there. “So,” Alessandra says, leaning in. “You, Oxford. What do you study?” “Modern—well, not exactly modern—language and literature. Italy in the nineteenth century. The—ah—structures of feeling. How a city makes a person.” “Che poetico,” she says dryly. “And you want to write about my city by walking with your nose in a book.” He flushes. “Point taken.” “Good.” She slaps her palm on the counter. “Then you will let me show you alcune cose. Some things. Not the guidebook. The other Rome.” “Is this,” he ventures, “a tour?” “Unsanctioned,” she says, wicked. “You like rules?” “I—yes.” Then, surprising himself, he grins. “No.” “Bravo,” she says, as if he’s a student and she’s the kind of teacher who breaks rules for sport. “Put on the helmet.” “But—” She’s already tossing him a spare. It smells like the sun. He fumbles with the strap, his fingers clumsy; she tuts and ties it for him, close enough that he can count a thin gold chain at her throat, the pendant a Saint Christopher rubbed smooth with worry. The city comes at him in a rush. They slalom through traffic like a rumor, Alessandra’s knee skimming parked Fiats, her laughter thrown back by buildings older than his country. He clutches at her waist and then, cautiously, at the frame, and then at last he lets go, hands in the air for a second that feels whole. She yells back over her shoulder, no helmet now, hair streaming like a flag. “You’re not dead, inglese! Good!” At a stoplight near Piazza Venezia, a street vendor sidles up, offering selfie sticks and fake gladiator helmets. Alessandra wiggles her fingers in the universal sign for no, grazie. In the same motion, she slips the vendor’s lighter out of view, bright red with a Vespa stamped on it. She flicks it to life in her palm and examines the flame with a cat’s calm. Ben doesn’t notice. Or pretends not to. They park on the Janiculum Hill, the city spread out like a map someone forgot to fold. The noon cannon cracks and Ben flinches; Alessandra grins and says, “They do it to make you jump.” She leads him to a statue of an unpronounceable patriot and tells him a story about revolutions that might be true. In the shade of a pine, she undoes a stray bottle of Chianti with that borrowed lighter, a bit of leather jammed under the cork. “For your dissertation,” she says solemnly, pouring into paper cups. “I don’t—” he begins, and then he does. The wine is cheap and honest. Her eyes on the city are bright and soft, like she’s seeing her favorite friend but won’t say. They share a panino that tastes like heaven and salt, sitting on the low wall, knees almost touching. A school group swarms, photo-taking, and Alessandra swipes her gaze across them as a pickpocket might. When they leave, she has a tourist brochure for a church no one visits and two napkins with lipstick on them. She folds the napkins into tiny boats, sets them sailing in the fountain below with solemn ceremony. He watches her. He realizes he is doing that, this thing of watching, with a kind of foolish hunger. She’s a magnet for accidents and laughter, and he is full of iron filings. “What do you do?” he asks, finally, when she quiets, when the city becomes a hum rather than a shout. She jerks her chin at the Vespa. “Corriere. Motorcycle courier. Flowers, legal papers, love letters, pizza. Anything.” Her smile goes sly. “Sometimes nothing at all. If you pay me to go fast, I go. If you pay me to go slow, I still go fast.” “And the scratch?” he asks, nodding toward the Vespa’s transparent war story. She runs her finger along it. There is affection in the gesture, and something else, a private joke. “A conversation with a wall that wanted a kiss,” she says. “I won.” He laughs. He can’t help it. Her lies, if they are lies, are preferable to most truths. The heat swells and then slides down into slant shadows. She takes him to Trastevere, to a doorway where old men play cards like priests at a vigil. She grins at one, kisses him on both cheeks, calls him zio though he is probably no one’s uncle. She lifts a cigarette from behind his ear, lights it with the Vespa lighter, takes one draw, gives it back. The old man blesses her with his cards. Ben watches the exchange like a traveler reads a foreign phrase and understands more than he thinks. They run, quite literally, through a wedding. She sees the rice, the confetti, the bride like a cream cloud. Her eyes gleam. “Come,” she says, grabbing Ben’s hand, and they crash the reception in the church courtyard for exactly two songs, spinning and whooping and pretending they belong. Ben, mortified and thrilled, is pulled into a tarantella by a grandmother who scolds him for his steps, then beams at his effort. A platter of fried artichokes passes; Alessandra’s hand is sudden and sure. Ben finds himself with a paper napkin heavy with something hot and oily that he did not buy. When the groom notices, when the bride’s brother looks confused and then amused, when Alessandra bows with courtly exaggeration and backs away, Ben can’t stop laughing. His chest hurts with it. “We can’t do that,” he wheezes, even as they do. “We just did,” she says, eyes like mischief’s headquarters. She hands him the lighter. “Hold that.” They end up on the Aventine, then at a doorway with a keyhole that frames Saint Peter’s dome like a secret. They trade places peering through; he smiles like a child. She takes his guidebook at some point, tucks it behind her back, flips it open and reads aloud, her accent turning “Baroque” into something edible. “Put it away,” she finally murmurs. “It will still be there tomorrow. Today is mine.” He obeys, surprising himself again. The sun bleeds out of the sky. Night comes with scooters and distant fights and lovers quarrelling in the lyrical register of Italian. Alessandra drags him into a dive bar with a jukebox that coughs out Mina, then into a tourist bar with blue drinks and British stag parties so he can hate it properly, then into a square where a juggler nearly takes off his ear with a club and apologizes profusely, and she steals a scarf from a statue and wears it as a sash for twenty minutes before replacing it with the care of a restoration artist. There are stops he only realizes were stops later, when he pats his pockets: his watch is still there but a rubber bracelet he’d been given by someone on the flight is not. In its place is a small plastic medallion with a saint and a motorcycle stamped in silver. He doesn’t remember acquiring it. If he asked, she would shrug. At some point, he asks, “Why me?” She doesn’t look at him. There’s a line at the gelato place, noisily cosmopolitan. “Because you were about to walk into my life and then my wheel,” she says, tossing her hair. “Because you’re too polite to say no and too curious to be bored. Because you say ‘sorry’ like you think it makes a difference.” She hands him pistachio, takes stracciatella, steals a bite of his anyway. “And because you said yes.” He is quiet. He watches her lick a smear of gelato off her thumb in a way that probably has a footnote in some anthropology of courtship. He does not say that if she had said, “Follow me,” earlier, the rest of his day would have been the same. They return to the River. Rome at night looks like a memory. On the way, they pass a man selling roses. The man presses one into Ben’s lap shyly, a conspirator. Alessandra takes it, spins it once in her fingers, and twines it briefly through the Vespa’s scratched grill so the petals brush the dent as if to soothe it. He opens his mouth to offer to pay; she is already moving, two euros lighter that seem to have come from nowhere. A minute later, she’s a glove richer that must have fallen from someone’s back pocket. It disappears into her bag; she will return it, she says. Maybe. Her delight is not cruel. It’s a dance with the world’s loose edges. On a narrow street lit by a single yellow lamp, they run out of momentum. The Vespa ticks as it cools. Alessandra’s hair is a mess. Ben’s shirt is creased, and there’s a fig leaf stuck to his sneaker from some moment he cannot, for the life of him, place. “So,” she says, leaning against a wall that has known worse, the rose drooping like a drunk. “Oxford.” He shoves his hands into his pockets, then takes them out again, restless in the way of someone who has just remembered his body. “Yes.” She studies him. The city has left a shadow of soot on her cheekbone like war paint. He wants to put his thumb there and wipe it away. He does not. He is an academic. He has restraint. It feels like a coat that is suddenly too tight. “What do you write about, really?” she asks. “Not the structures of feelings.” “How we disappear,” he says, surprising himself, the words feeling like fruit falling of their own accord. “Or how we fail to. How the city keeps you and you keep the city.” She tilts her head. “Tonight, you did not disappear.” It sounds like praise. “No,” he says. “Not with you.” Silence. The good kind. She pushes off the wall. “I have a delivery at ten,” she says, businesslike. “A real one. Not a wedding we steal.” He swallows. “Right.” “You can come,” she says casually. “If you hold onto me and don’t fall off.” The corner of her mouth lifts, an amused cruelty that is also an invitation. He looks at her, at the scratch on the Vespa with its technicolor brag, at the rose bruising in the grill, at the lighter in his pocket, at the Saint Christopher around her neck, at the city that has expanded to accommodate this new channel. He is, without doubt, disoriented. He is also, without doubt, completely smitten. He hears himself say, “Yes.” She rolls her eyes like he’s predictable and dear. “Bravo,” she says again, softer. They ride. The delivery is a flat envelope, unremarkable except for the way she tucks it into her jacket with proprietary care. The address is across the river. They take the long way, because of course they do. Ben leans into the turns now with her, like a sentence that knows where it is going, even if he doesn’t. At the doorway, she disappears, rings a bell, leaves the envelope in a slot. She returns lighter by a gram and heavier by something that might be sleep. They’re back at the curb when he reaches into his pocket and pulls out the lighter she’d given him to hold. He turns it over. The Vespa logo shines red. “You—I think this is not yours.” She plucks it from his palm with two fingers, then touches those fingers to his wrist in apology. “Everything is mine until it isn’t,” she says. It’s a joke and a confession. He feels something pass from her to him anyway, some temperature, some charge. “Alessandra,” he says, his voice rasping at the edges. He has done enough cowardice for one life. “Will I see you again?” She feigns surprise. “Tomorrow, I will ride. You will read and almost die at intersections. Probabile.” Then, abruptly, less arched: “I will be at the bar near the fountain, where we did the corrected coffee. Nine.” She glances at him, assessing. “If you come, bring me a story. Not from the book. From you.” He nods. “I—yes.” She smiles, and it lands somewhere in his ribs like an anchor. She swings onto the Vespa in one motion, and he wants to learn how to do everything she does. “Don’t fall in love with Rome,” she says, final as a bell. “She will not love you back. She will make you think you are the only one, and then she will make you pay. She is a bad girlfriend. Ask anyone.” “And you?” he asks, before he can help it. “Do you love her?” She looks past him at the river, at the dome hunched like a shoulder against the night. The secret in her gaze curdles for a second into something that might be sorrow. “I owe her,” she says. “Which is not the same.” He wants to ask a hundred questions. He doesn’t. The Vespa’s engine catches like a laugh. She points at the scratch along the side. “Next time, don’t add to it,” she orders. “The colors are perfect now.” He salutes, foolish. She rolls her eyes, charmed and disgusted, and then she is gone, the rose trembling, a comet leaving a tail of noise and possibility. Ben stands there a while, the night settling on him like a second skin. He finds the plastic saint in his pocket with his fingers and closes his fist around it, unsure how it got there, intensely sure that it did. He realizes with an embarrassed little snort that he is grinning at nothing. He opens the guidebook, then shuts it again, the words flat and dumb on the page. He does not go home immediately. He walks the long way, because of course he does, toes scuffing the cobbles, and throws a coin over his shoulder into the Trevi Fountain for someone else’s wish. The splash sounds like a promise he is not entirely convinced he did not make. In the morning, he will go to the bar. Or he will try not to. He already knows which. Rome breathes. He breathes with her. And somewhere, riding a line of light between two points, Alessandra laughs at how easy it is to steal a day and leave nothing but a scratch.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably well-crafted contemporary romance that successfully captures the essence of a whirlwind day in Rome. The author has created a vivid, immersive narrative that brings both the characters and setting to life with exceptional skill. The characterization is particularly strong. Alessandra emerges as a fully realized character - fiery, mischievous, and complex. Her kleptomania is subtly woven throughout the narrative rather than explicitly stated, shown through small acts of theft that reveal her character without heavy-handed exposition. Ben's transformation from cautious academic to willing participant in Alessandra's adventures feels organic and believable. The chemistry between them is palpable and develops naturally throughout the day. The prose is elegant and evocative without becoming purple. The author employs sensory details masterfully - we can smell the "gasoline and orange blossom cologne," taste the espresso that is "tar and sunlight," and feel the rhythm of Rome through the narrative. Metaphors are fresh and effective: "She's a magnet for accidents and laughter, and he is full of iron filings" perfectly captures Ben's attraction to Alessandra. The dialogue is exceptional - sparse but impactful, revealing character through what is said and unsaid. Alessandra's Italian phrases are integrated naturally, adding authenticity without becoming distracting. The exchanges between characters feel genuine and serve to advance both plot and character development. The structure of interconnected scenes works perfectly, creating a sense of a day unfolding in real time while maintaining narrative momentum. Each vignette adds something meaningful to the characters' relationship or our understanding of them. The pacing is excellent, with quieter moments balancing the more adventurous sequences. Rome itself becomes a character in the narrative. The author avoids tourist clichés while still capturing the essence of the city - its history, energy, and contradictions. The setting is integrated organically into the story rather than feeling like a backdrop. The ending strikes just the right note - ambiguous yet satisfying, with the promise of continuation without an artificial happily-ever-after. The final image of Alessandra "riding a line of light between two points" and Ben throwing a coin into the Trevi Fountain beautifully encapsulates the themes of the piece. If there are any weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally, a metaphor might be slightly overextended, but these moments are rare and don't detract from the overall quality of the writing. The piece adheres closely to the prompt requirements while still feeling fresh and original. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of contemporary romance writing that balances character, setting, and plot with remarkable skill. The author has created a compelling narrative that leaves the reader wanting more - exactly what the beginning of a larger story should do. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Cozy sci-fi: The Last Outpost — Score: 89.5
Prompt:
Cozy sci-fi The Last Outpost Nettle (or Nets to her friends) bartends at The Last Outpost -- a lazy hub for miners and merchants in an asteroid belt on the Andromeda outer rim. Escaping from her past life, Nets found a home here at the Outpost. They have, thus far, tolerated Net's flaws which she tries to keep in equilibrium with her assortment of talents. Her evenings involve chatting with patrons, negotiating the drama, intrigue, problems & love lives of the diverse crowd that filter through the Outpost. Tonight is no different, at least, until a frazzled looking stranger, tentacled dreads askew, quietly plops down at the bar: "Vega whisky, neat. Better make that a double." Write a chapter in this story. Establish conflict for narrative interest. Don't resolve the conflict within this chapter. Aim for about 60% dialogue. First person, present tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
I’m polishing a smudge out of the bar top when the door irises open and lets in a gust of tired laughter, ore dust, and the metallic tang of recycled air. The Outpost hums and drifts on its routine: the slow spin of the station windows, the miners’ boots clanking, Merciko’s accordion slurring over whatever passes for happy on the Andromeda rim. My glass washers chatter like teeth in a cold mouth behind me. I keep one eye on the portside camera feed, the other on the neon gleam of the drip line. I keep my past pressed flat between the pages of this place. I’m good at balance. I talk a little, I listen a lot, I pour better than anyone out here. When someone starts to ramble down the gravity well of confession, I tilt their glass, not their heart. “Netty! You deaf or just ignoring me?” Trill yells from table six. Two hands, four elbows, tattooed with constellations I didn’t ask about, she waves a soggy credit chit like a flag. “I heard you,” I say, already pulling her another Pink Nebula. “Still deciding if you get four cherries or none.” “Four!” she says. “Four is lucky. Remember what happened the last time I asked for none?” “You kissed my skimmer pilot,” I say. “And broke his heart. And my skimmer.” Trill grins. “Worth it!” A glass breaks somewhere behind the baffle. It is the thin, high music of disaster. Patrons go quiet a beat, then surge into a cheer. I glance up. Sava, new kid on washers, is pale as a comet and mouth-round with horror. I tap the overhead thanks-to-nothing button. “Broken glass in zone three. Everyone keep your hands.” The floor unit deploys little vacuum beetles. People clap like they’ve never seen bugs clean before. “Breathe,” I say to Sava, and give her a thumbs-up. “It’s just a rookies’ tax.” She nods, breath hitching, and the beetles go to war with glittering shards, their backs blinking hazard-yellow. The Outpost swallows the incident and returns to its lazy: the hand of the dock clock crawling toward shift change, the low crackle of a dying news feed, the thunk of heavy ships docking outside like whales knocking. That’s when they come in. Frazzled, dressed in a jumpsuit that probably used to be green, tentacles spilling like a river of wires from beneath a hood. My skin pricks. Hair—whatever you call those sinewy head-dreads—stands like they’ve been electrocuted. They head for the bar, eyes down, shoulders tight. They slide onto a stool like someone holding a broken wing close. “Vega whisky, neat,” they say, voice quiet and sanded down. There’s a wheeze under the vowels, as though their biolungs don’t fit right. “Better make that a double.” “Rough space?” I ask, reaching for the Vega. It’s the good stuff, and I don’t advertise it. I keep the bottle low, just for me and people who need it. They fish in a pocket and slap a cred chip on the bar. It’s warm and damp, edges gnawed. I catch a glance—there’s a faded insignia half-scratched off, and my stomach does that uncomfortable lurch remembered names bring. No names, I think. That’s the house rule. No slurs, no brawls, no credit on my kindness, no real names unless you offer them yourself. I pry a tumbler loose from the rack, swirl the Vega, let the smell of smoke and starfruit cut the exhaust out of the air. They watch the pour with a measuring kind of hunger. “Keep the bottle close,” they murmur. “In case.” “In case?” I set the glass down, then a napkin, then the bottle far enough that I still own it. “In case things go sideways.” “Things rarely go sideways in here,” I lie. I’ve built a bar out of chaos and habit. Sideways is our default. I lean in, keeping my smile gentle. “You got a name you like?” They take a long swallow, and their face changes, loosens. They wipe the back of their hand across a mouth that looks too human for those eyes. “Nettle,” they say. I blink. “You’re kidding.” “Nettle,” they repeat, gaze flicking to my nametag. The one that reads NETS in filched cargo tape, because the last one peeled off and I didn’t care enough to replace it. “Or Nets, if you’re friendly.” I laugh before I can catch myself. A real one. “That’s—” “A complication?” they ask, smile thin. “A coincidence,” I say, and it’s both. They push two tentacles back under their hood, where someone in a hurry braided them. The braids have come undone. Their nails are black with engine grit. My eyes keep straying to the scar on their collarbone, a crescent like an old moon. “On shift?” Sava calls, hovering. “We’re low on clean rocks.” “Rocks?” Trill says, leering. “Tell me more about your rocks.” “Trill,” I warn, and she sets her mouth like a child who has been scolded but is plotting anyway. “I need a favor,” Nettle—my mirror—says, voice low enough to be swallowed by the Outpost’s murmur. “You just got here,” I say. “You don’t know if I’m the favoring type.” “I know something about people who wrap themselves in nicknames,” they say, eyes flicking up. They are deep-set eyes, storm gray, ringed in purple fatigue. “And I know you’re the only one who isn’t looking at the door every time it opens.” I look at the door just because they said it, because the way they said it makes my blood remember how to run. A miner with red dust in his beard shuffles in, someone’s laugh spikes, someone’s comm chirps and dies. Okay. Nothing. “What do you need?” I ask carefully. “A place to sit where I’m not obvious, and a minute of your quiet,” they say. “And a second double, if your kindness has a generous pour.” “Your cred good?” I nudge the chipped chip back with a fingertip. They lift their chin. “Always.” I slide the bottle back within their reach and tip the Vega again. “We have a corner that pretends to be anonymous,” I say, nodding toward the shadowed booth near the dried herb wall. “On a good day, people forget you’re there. On a bad day, Merciko will serenade you and your ancestors.” “Good day then, please,” Nettle says, but doesn’t move. They cradle the glass instead and keep their back to the room like someone who knows how to be small and knows it won’t help. From the far end, a couple is mid-argument in a whisper that thinks it’s a secret and isn’t. Something about a cargo manifest not matching an invoice, a broken promissory, a niece on Vega Prime. My ear wants to tug toward it. My hands go on autopilot. “So,” I say, wiping down a patch of bar already clean. “You running from a person or a thing?” “Funny how we pretend there’s a distinction,” Nettle says. “What about you, Nets? You run from or toward?” “I pour,” I say. “And I mind my ledger.” They snort with something like approval. “Okay. Then I’ll say this: if anyone asks if you’ve seen me, you haven’t.” “Have I?” They meet my eyes, and for a second the room slides out of focus and it’s just me and another version of a life I almost had. “Not if anyone asks,” they say. Sava approaches with a tray of clean glasses and a look that means she overheard a sliver. I shake my head a hair’s breadth—no. She pivots into another orbit, proud of herself for respecting the unspoken. “Why me?” I ask Nettle. “We’re full of corners.” “Because you didn’t flinch at the gunfire,” they say. “What gunfire?” They smile, and it makes their face beautiful, briefly, like a light turned on in a wreck. “Exactly.” The door irises again. Two security drones drift in, eyes a cold turquoise that matches no ocean. Behind them is a person I hoped had been transferred to some administrative desk far away: Lt. Harrow, Patrol Division, the kind of bureaucrat ethos that dresses its teeth in civility and chews through principles for breakfast. Clean uniform. Clean jaw. Clean gloves. He scans the room like it owes him a feeling. “Evening,” I say, level. The Outpost does not belong to him; it belongs to orbits and old deals. But he walks like it is all under his name. “Nettle,” he says. I freeze before I know it’s my own name he means. He stops at the bar, eyes not on me, but on my mirror. “You made good time,” he says to the newcomer, who has gone still in a way that makes me smell ozone. “You’re a difficult person to chase. You know that?” “Not here,” I say, voice warm. “People drink here, Lt.” He tips his head in my direction, as if acknowledging a bartender is part of some playbook tactic. “I’m not here to ruin your night, Nets.” “I doubt your aim is that good,” I say, smiling because this is a performance and I know my part. “What do you want?” “Just to talk,” he says. “To a guest of yours.” Patrons start the slow migration that says they don’t want to see but want to hear. Trill saunters closer, balancing her Nebula like a crown, eyes bright. Merciko stops playing. The vacuum beetles retreat into their nook like nervous pets. Nettle doesn’t look at Harrow. They drink, swallow, put the glass down without a click. “Talk to my glass,” they say. Harrow smiles thinly. “We received an alert,” he says, tapping a wristband. “Stolen property. Biocybernetic. Hazardous to itself and others.” Everyone in earshot goes thick with interest. You can feel it. The room leans a fraction. “Cool,” Trill whispers to nobody. “Hazardous.” “A misunderstanding,” Nettle says. “I had a permit. I had three.” “Records can be misfiled,” Harrow says. “But you can still misappropriate. Mason Bay dock cam shows you leaving with a unit.” “Units don’t ask for double whisky,” I say, allowing a smirk. “And if you’re thinking of putting hands on my customer, Lt., you’ll need to show me a writ. Until then, you’re a man in a hat in a place that sells drinks.” “It’s not a hat, it’s a regulation cap,” Harrow says automatically, then catches himself and rearranges his features to stern. “Writ’s in the system.” “Must be lonely,” I say. “All your friends in the system.” He does the look that says he wants to sigh and be magnanimous but is plastic. “We can do this pleasant. Or we can shut your feeds for a night and see how your tips do.” I feel my molars in my jaw. The Outpost is a delicate ecology, and the Patrol knows how to kick it. The old part of me, the one that broke and built and ran and landed here, wants to reach for the astral die under the register, the one I swore I’d stop using to choose trouble. I keep my face easy. “Talk,” I say. “At the booth.” I jerk my chin toward the corner. My mirror doesn’t move. “Maybe you should tell your friend what you did,” Harrow says to Nettle. “So she doesn’t hitch her ship to a sinking star.” “I don’t have a ship,” I say. “I have a bar.” “It floats like a ship,” he says. “And goes down like one when someone holes it.” “What did they do?” I ask, and I can hear the tilt in my own question and hate it, because it says I might be willing. “I took something that was missing,” Nettle says before he can. “And it followed me.” “What followed you?” Trill says, suddenly very interested in something aside from cherries. A sound like a whale calling from another world ripples through the hull. It’s not docking. It’s not ships. It’s not anything comfortable. The lights shiver, then settle. Everyone looks up. Everyone looks at me. As if I can look at the ceiling and the laws of physics will deliver an answer. I look anyway. Habit. “See?” Harrow says softly. “Hazardous.” Another sound, closer this time, from the air duct grid above the herb wall. A scrabble. A whisper? No. Clicking. The clink-clink of little metal feet. The grate bows. “Uh,” Sava says. The grate pops, and something drops onto the shelf where I keep the dried nettles for tea and the bottles of promises era gin. The thing is the size of a big cat, shaped wrong, a lattice of silver bones wrapped in translucent skin that shifts like heat. Its eyes are too many. It sniffs the air and makes a small, delighted sound, like a child seeing sugar. Half my regulars swear in languages the station translator pretends not to hear. The creature—unit? hazard?—hops onto the bar. It looks at me. It looks at Nettle. It starts purring, except it’s the kind of purr that resonates with the fillings in your teeth and wakes old dental sins. It curls its tail, which splits at the end into three delicate filaments that taste the air. “Nix,” Nettle says, voice low, aching. “You shouldn’t have come.” It makes a chirp that is either hello or a warning. It leans into Nettle’s hand, tentacles and filaments and fingers all in a soft tangle. Everyone in the Outpost leans forward as one organism. Harrow’s drones tilt like birds considering bread. “Is that biocybernetic property?” someone whispers. “That’s a baby,” someone else snaps. “That’s a bomb,” Trill breathes, delighted. “It’s hungry,” I say, because you can hear the hollow in a living thing. “Nix,” Harrow says, and the name sits wrong in his mouth. “Return.” It freezes, every line of it going taut. It does not obey. It curls closer into Nettle, who presses a palm to its skull like you’d push your hand to your own chest and say stay. “You can’t keep that,” Harrow says to Nettle, the thin kindness drained out of him. “It’s tagged, registered, and expensive.” “They abandoned it,” Nettle says, defiance in their jaw, fear in their hands. “They were going to strip it for parts.” “And as generous as your story is,” Harrow says, “the law doesn’t make exceptions for the soft.” “The law hardly sees the soft,” I say. “Just the obedient.” He doesn’t look at me. He looks at the thing on my bar like it’s a problem he can solve by cutting its rope. He lifts a hand. The drones shift. The room tenses. “No,” Nettle says. “Please. Not in here.” “What’s so special about here?” Harrow asks, but something—maybe the way the whole room has tilted, a human ripple, the mined gravity of all these eyes—slows him. He reconsiders, two beats, like a man tasting his own teeth. “Fine,” he says. “Back office, then.” He looks at me. “You have an office, Nets.” “I have a storeroom,” I say, thinking of the stacks of glass and the crate I keep under the false floor, the one that hums if you stand too close. “And a policy against interrogations between my bottles.” “Policy is not law,” he says. “And law is not kindness,” I say. Nettle’s hand is shaking. Nix makes the sound of a storm inside a shell. The whole bar is a held breath. Sava is clutching a tray so hard the edge digs crescents into her palms. Merciko has started playing again, something low and insistent like a heartbeat not to be frightened by. Trill tips her glass, licks sugar from the rim, eyes bright with the story forming in her head. The dock clock ticks. Outside, a ship groans, turning in its sleep. This is the kind of moment you spend years arranging your life to avoid. It arrives anyway. “Nets,” Nettle says, not pleading, not quite. “Please.” I don’t move. I can play it any way. I can say I never saw them. I can say I don’t know this creature looking at me like I’m a choice. I can call in a favor I didn’t save. I can pretend I don’t remember that insignia etched into a worn credit chip. I can decide to be prudent and watch the Patrol take the softest thing in the room. I can decide to unspool the tidy life I stitched together in this place, one seam at a time. The drones hum. Harrow waits. Nettle breathes. Nix purrs. I reach toward the shelf where I keep the nettle tea, fingers steady, and behind me, through the broken-glass hush of the bar, through the tiny buzzing stars of the vacuum beetles at their dock, the back hatch alarm pulses once, low and insistent, the way a heartbeat would sound if it had a siren. The screen under the bar blinks an external alert: unauthorized magnetic lock release, bay three. “Someone just opened my storage bay,” I say, and the certainty in my voice surprises me. I look up. Harrow, confused. Nettle, alarmed. Nix, all its eyes wide, all its senses pulled toward the back door. The Outpost, my Outpost, shifts under my feet, a fractional tilt deeper into sideways. “We’ll talk,” Harrow says again, but the room is already moving, as if it’s a beast with a mind of its own. And we’re all already in it.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a cozy sci-fi atmosphere with a well-realized setting in "The Last Outpost," a bar in an asteroid belt. The first-person present tense narration through Nettle's perspective is maintained throughout, and the chapter establishes clear conflict without resolution, as requested. The writing excels at world-building through sensory details and casual references that feel natural rather than expository. The bar environment comes alive through descriptions of "ore dust," "metallic tang of recycled air," and the "neon gleam of the drip line." The author skillfully introduces alien elements like tentacled characters, vacuum beetles, and the mysterious creature Nix without overexplaining. Character development is strong, particularly for Nettle, whose past is hinted at without being fully revealed. The dialogue effectively reveals character traits and relationships while advancing the plot. Secondary characters like Trill, Sava, and Lt. Harrow are distinct and contribute meaningfully to the scene. The conflict centers on the mysterious Nettle (the newcomer who shares the protagonist's name) and their relationship with the creature Nix, which authorities claim is stolen property. This creates both external tension (the threat from Lt. Harrow) and internal conflict for the protagonist, who must decide whether to help. The ending effectively leaves this decision hanging, creating narrative tension. The prose balances descriptive richness with readability. Metaphors like "the beetles go to war with glittering shards" and "the hand of the dock clock crawling toward shift change" enhance the atmosphere without becoming purple. The dialogue feels natural and serves multiple purposes: revealing character, advancing plot, and providing exposition without being obvious. There are a few minor weaknesses. Some metaphors verge on being overwrought ("glass washers chatter like teeth in a cold mouth"). The introduction of Nix feels slightly rushed compared to the careful pacing of the rest of the piece. And while the dialogue is generally strong, a few exchanges feel slightly forced in service of exposition. The piece achieves approximately 60% dialogue as requested, and at around 2,000 words, it's longer than the requested 1,000 words, though this doesn't detract from the quality. Overall, this is a strong piece of cozy sci-fi that establishes an intriguing setting, complex characters, and compelling conflict while maintaining a consistent voice and tone. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 17 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 17.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Young adult drama: Gone South — Score: 89.3
Prompt:
Young adult drama Gone South Taylor is a 16 year old teen with a history of "concerning behavioural patterns" (or that's how the stupid smug school counsellor worded it on the phone call to Mom). It shouldn't be a surprise: When you live in a backwater town in Tennessee, your choices are: a. be mind-fuckingly bored, or b. invent some drama. Two days ago, Taylor came out to their family as trans. This disclosure was *not* in the category of invented drama -- it was, in fact, the real deal, and a long time coming. It didn't go well. The last 48 hours had been pure disaster. In a moment of desperate inspiration, Taylor had decided to get the hell out of dodge. And so an escape plan was hatched and executed within the space of 30 minutes. That was last night. Now Taylor was two states away, having been unceremoniously ejected from their hitched ride in downtown New Orleans. Write the next chapter in Taylor's story as they find their feet in this new environment. Tell the chapter over the course of their first day in New Orleans, in which Taylor meets another runaway with issues and secrets. Taylor navigates this new world, not knowing who to trust or what the dangers are. Write in Taylor's voice, and incorporate their internal monologue as they grapple with intense & conflicting emotions. Also incorporate dialogue with the interesting characters Taylor meets. First person, mixed tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
When the old man dropped me by the curb, he didn’t look me in the eye. Just said, “End of the line, kid,” and the rust-scaled truck rattled off like I’d infected his upholstery with bad luck. The street in front of me pulsed. Tourists with sunburned shoulders and drinks the color of cartoon slime poured past, laughing too loud at things that can’t possibly be funny. The saxophone cut through all of it—low and gold and full of a sadness that wasn’t mine but felt like it could be. The player was an old guy with a hat full of crumpled bills. He had a face that looked like carved wood and a mouth that knew something about sugar and salt and other kinds of cost. I stood there like an idiot with my backpack digging into one shoulder and this stupid hope that the city would open its arms and say, “You’re safe.” Ha. Funny. I told myself: you’re smart. You got this far. You can find the next step. My feet, traitor feet, decided walking was the step. So I walked. Past souvenir shops with purple beads sprouting from the doors like vines, past a group of women wearing matching T-shirts that said Steve’s 50th! as if the city would congratulate them. The air was wet in a way Tennessee never was. It pressed against skin, wrapped around me like a damp towel. My hair stuck to my scalp. I could taste something sweet in the air—funnel cakes maybe, burnt sugar—and something rot under it, like swamp breath. “How old are you?” a woman asked, stepping into my path. She had a clipboard and a tight smile and eyes that went over me like I was a math problem. Her shirt said Hope Harbor in a font with too many loops. She smelled like lilacs. “Old enough,” I said, which is what people say when they are not, in fact, old enough. She didn’t leave. “We have a youth center just a few blocks—” “No,” I said, too sharp, felt my throat get that hot, humiliating burn. “Thanks.” She took a breath like she would push again. The saxophone slid into a higher note, a kind of plea. A guy in a neon hat bumped my shoulder and didn’t say sorry. I pivoted and was gone, my backpack slicing through the crowd like a fin through water. Keep moving. Don’t get pinned. I picked a direction. The streets narrowed and the tourist gloss rubbed off. Graffiti climbed the walls where the stucco peeled away. A kid sat on a milk crate with a pit bull at his feet, tapping a plastic bucket between his knees. The beat matched the saxophone’s tail end and for a second the city braided itself together. That’s when my stomach remembered I’d fed it gas station peanuts and a Coke fourteen hours ago. It grumbled loud enough that the kid glanced up and smirked. I hugged my arms around myself like that could quiet a gut. I found a corner store with a hand-lettered sign that said EBT WELCOME in faded marker and bought a bag of chips and a banana with the last of my loose cash. The cashier didn’t look at me. I thanked him anyway because my mother raised me with small politenesses. The automatic door sighed behind me and I stood there with the chips open, shoving salt into my mouth so fast my tongue stung. The banana had a bruise that tasted like too-sweet wine. “You look new,” a voice said, soft and not unkind. My spine went tight. I turned. They were leaning against the brick wall in the shade, one foot up, a scuffed skateboard under their hand. Maybe seventeen, maybe nineteen, wearing a T-shirt that said GIRL POWER in glitter letters, which made me double-take, because their hair was buzzed down to velvet. Eyes like the Mississippi at dusk—wide and a little muddy. Lips they’d chewed raw. A look that said they hadn’t slept indoors every night lately. My kind of person. Not my kind. Dangerous. Don’t trust. “Do I?” I said around a mouthful of chips. Smooth, Taylor. Real smooth. They nodded toward the street. “You got that tourist-staring-at-the-sky thing but without the camera. And your shoes are too clean. Nice backpack, though.” “Thanks,” I said, reflex, and hugged it closer. My grandmother had given me the backpack for “college someday,” and here it was carrying socks and a razored-off ponytail and a phone I hadn’t turned on in two days. Mom would have filled it with snacks. “Not a hustle,” they added, taking their foot down and walking toward me slow, hands visible like I was a deer and they’d learned something about how to approach a skittish thing. “I’m Ash.” “Taylor,” I said, before I could decide to lie. My mouth betrays me like that. Ash tipped their head. “You hungry or you hungry?” “I’ve got chips,” I said, which was not an answer. The saxophone from a block over swooped and someone laughed the way people laugh right before they cry. I wiped salt on my jeans. Ash stared at my face like they were trying to decide on a puzzle piece. Their gaze snagged at my jaw, lingered on my neck where the binder cut a line under my collar. Heat crawled up my throat. Do not flinch. Do not. If you look like prey someone will make you prey. They surprised me by looking away, quick, like they’d been the one caught. “You, uh. You want a place to sit that isn’t a curb? There’s a church a few blocks that does lunch. No questions.” “You just hang out in front of the store waiting for… me?” I meant kids like me. I didn’t say it. Ash shrugged, eyes sliding to the street. “I wait for the old man with the trumpet to hit ‘St. James Infirmary.’ That’s when the line’s the shortest. And I watch faces. It’s a game. Guess who’s running and who’s just lost.” They grinned, quick flash. “I win a lot.” Something sour curled in me—shame because they’d read me and pride because I was seeable. “What’s the prize?” “Chips,” Ash said, eyes on my bag, deadpan. Then, softer, “And sometimes friends. Or not-friends. People.” Their voice did this thing on the word people, like the syllables were heavier than others. I should have said no. Strangers offering food. Strangers offering anything. But the sound of the saxophone braided with the bucket drum and my stomach had gone hollow, echoing. Curiosity and hunger are the same shape sometimes. “Okay,” I said. “Fine.” We walked. Ash pushed the skateboard with lazy little pumps, the wheels clicking over cracks needed to be repaved. They talked without looking at me. “Where you from?” “Up there,” I said, waving a vague hand north. “Um. Tennessee.” They nodded like that made sense. “Lot of folks from Tennessee lately. The buses drop at the terminal and spit people like seeds.” They glanced at my backpack and then away again, and the kindness in that glance made something tilt in me. “You staying with anyone?” “No.” My throat tried to close. No. I chose no. I walked away from a house with lace curtains and seven Bibles. I walked away from my mother’s voice in the hallway saying the word “phase” like it was a stain she could scrub out. Ash kept their eyes on the concrete. Their sneakers had holes in the sides. “Me neither,” they said too casually. Then, like they owed me an explanation, “Got tired of being a problem in a house where problems get left for God.” “You religious?” It slipped out, my curiosity sharper than my caution. “God and I are on a break,” Ash said dry. They flicked their gaze sideways. “You?” “God broke up with me,” I said, and then we were laughing at ourselves, two kids making jokes about a thing that could kill us. The laugh unclenched something in my chest I hadn’t realized was a fist. The church was brick, its steeple cracked and leaning like someone had put a knee into it once and it never got fixed. In the courtyard, trestle tables sagged under trays of spaghetti that smelled like the sauce came from a big can. Volunteers in aprons ladled and didn’t ask names. Ash handed me a paper plate and a plastic fork. The sauce was sweet and too thin, the noodles overcooked. It might have been the best thing I’d eaten all month. We sat on the curb with our backs against the iron fence. The fence had fleur-de-lis with the fleurs chipped. People spread out on the grass, on blankets, on the shade. A man with a face like a topographical map snored under a live oak. Kids with beads tangled in their hair chased each other and shrieked. A woman in a long skirt played with a tarot deck at a folding table, flipping cards like little doors. “You do this a lot?” I asked between bites, spaghetti sauce dotting my knee. “When I’m in this part of town,” Ash said. “Sometimes I’m not.” They wound noodles around the fork like they’d learned from someone who had time to teach them. Then, almost like they couldn’t help themselves, “Why’d you run?” It felt like a test. The spaghetti turned into paste in my mouth. The saxophone from earlier had trailed us somehow; it was far off now, the notes long and lazy, like an exhale. I swallowed. You can say it. And if they weaponize it, you can walk. “I told my family,” I said. The word family tasted like pennies. “I told my mom I’m trans.” Ash stilled. Something flickered in their face—recognition, maybe, or a shadow of it. They didn’t say oh or me too. They just said, “How’d she take it?” “Like I told her I drowned the cat.” I laughed once, a hot, ugly sound. “She said I was making things difficult. That I was… confused.” My cheeks burned. I looked down at my shoes. “I’ve never been more sure of anything in my life.” “People hear sure and think you’re being dramatic,” Ash said quietly. They had set their fork down. The tendons in their hand stood out like cords. “It’s easier for them to pretend you’ll grow out of yourself.” I exhaled. The spaghetti went from paste to edible again. “Yeah.” Ash glanced at the tarot table. The woman flipped over a tower with lightning in it. “You got a name you want me to use? Or… pronouns, I mean.” My eyes stung for no good reason. “He. And Taylor’s fine, for now.” For now rolled around in my gut like a marble. Someday I’d say a different name to someone like this and the sky would not fall. “He,” Ash repeated, tasting it, and then they smiled. It landed on me soft. “Okay. He.” We ate in quiet that wasn’t awkward. A guy in a Saints jersey wandered past and asked if anyone had a smoke. The live oak creaked. The saxophone was closer now, as if the player had drifted down the block, notes like river water slipping over stones. After we ate, Ash took me to the library. “It’s cold in there. You can charge your phone.” The air conditioning hit me like forgiveness. I stood in the stacks and let it raise goosebumps on my arms while Ash showed me the teen section like they owned it. There were kids hunched in armchairs pretending to read, one girl asleep sitting up, a boy drawing dragons in a notebook with a green pen until the page was full of scales. I plugged my phone into an outlet under a table and stared at the black screen. It had been forty-eight hours since I’d last looked at it. Forty-eight hours since my mother had screamed on the kitchen floor. If I turned it on there would be messages. If I turned it on, I might be someone’s son again. If I turned it on, he could also not be. I let it be, dark, a stone skipping across a lake, not sinking. Ash was tracing their fingers over the spines of books like braille. “You read?” they asked without looking. “Yeah.” My throat dried. “When I’m not ruining lives.” They snorted. “You got a library card?” “No.” “You don’t need one to sit.” Ash settled into a chair and put their feet up. Their socks had little lightning bolts on them. They closed their eyes like the act of being in a safe quiet place required conscious effort. I sat across from them and pretended to care about a copy of a battered Stephen King. My brain made lists: where to sleep, how to get cash, where to pee without buying coffee, whether the thing under the bridge that looked like a tent city was an option or a bad idea. The lists skittered like mice. My skin hummed. My heart did tiny pickaxe strikes against my ribs. After an hour, the librarian told us the teen area was closing for a program, which meant out, scrubs. Outside, the sky had sagged into late afternoon. Heat stuck. Hurricane threats curled at the edges of the clouds, maybe or maybe not. Ash stretched their arms overhead and groaned. Their shirt lifted, a thin strip of stomach revealed, pale and scarred in a way I knew not to ask about. “You got a place,” they said, not a question. “No,” I said. “Still no.” “You can crash where I crash,” they offered, too quickly, like they’d decided this before their mouth said it. “It’s not… it’s not nice. But it’s… it’s a place.” “Why?” I asked. “Why would you do that?” Ash looked away and scratched their wrist until a red bloom rose under their nails. “Because someone did it for me,” they said. “And because you look like you’d try to sleep in a doorway and that’s how you get your shoes stolen.” The street musician from earlier appeared at the corner, as if conjured, saxophone in hand. He set an upturned hat down and started to play. The first notes cut the air, rich and close to grief. People stopped like strings had been pulled. A man with a camera hung the thing against his chest and actually listened. A woman in scrubs smiled with her mouth but not her eyes. The notes slid into my bones. I felt the city like a bruise and like a hand on my back, both. The sky shifted. Somewhere, sirens wound up and unwound. “Okay,” I said. My voice was steadier than I felt. “I’ll come.” Ash nodded one sharp nod like the decision was a cord they could now tuck into a pocket. “Cool.” They kicked their board up into their hand. “It’s by the river. There’s a camp. They call it the Triangle even though it’s more of a rhombus. Don’t tell anyone I told you.” We walked by the water. The river moved like a sleeping animal—lazy on the surface, muscle underneath. The wind off it glided over my skin and carried scents of old pennies and something deep. A barge went by, slow enough it felt like it shouldn’t be able to, pushing a wall of water like it was moving a thought through a crowd. “You trust me?” Ash asked at one point, gaze straight ahead. “No,” I said, and then, because truth is complicated, “Maybe. A little.” They smiled without humor. “Good.” The camp was a tumble of tarps and blue tents, shopping carts turned into walls, bikes chained to trees, a smell that had layers: smoke, piss, oil, spice. A woman with hair in a scarf stirred a pot on a camp stove and didn’t look up when we passed. A man with a sunburn so bad it peeled like fish skin nodded at Ash. “You bring a baby?” he asked, not unkind. “Just for a night,” Ash said. “He’s cool.” He. A spot had been made between a cypress stump and a low wall with chalk drawings on it. Ash had a roll of blue tarp and a neat coil of rope. I didn’t ask where they got stuff. The sky tipped toward purple. The saxophone was a far-off ghost, swallowed by the river’s low murmur. Ash tied knots like they’d taught themselves in a mirror. They showed me where to put my backpack so it would be behind my head and my arm would cover the zipper in my sleep.
