Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 92.0
Prompt:
Folk Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Astrid said you could tell how serious a practice was by how many layers you put on before you did it. That night I wore two sweaters under my father's old parka and a hat that made my ears ache before it warmed them, and Astrid had wrapped a scarf twice around her neck so the ends trailed like white flags. We left our boots by the door to keep the sleet off the hall runner, then pulled them back on and stepped into the shin-deep snow anyway. The evening had that muffled sound that happens when the clouds hang low enough to press on your skull. In Stockholm, I would have been in my room, half-watching TV and half-pretending to study. Here, I followed a girl who claimed her grandmother taught her to talk to the dead like it was a skill you could learn between algebra and civics. "You have to keep quiet when we pass the birches," she said without looking back. "They don't like being counted." "Birches?" "The ones that bow. If you count them you forget things you need to remember." She paused under the first of them, its thin branches gloved in ice. "Grandma says some trees listen and some tell. Birches are tattlers. So keep your thoughts tight." It was such a strange mix of childish and precise that I nodded and zipped my parka up to my chin. My breath made a cloud that followed me. The little village had gone to sleep hours ago. Only two windows showed a square of yellow, both on the same house; later I would learn they belonged to a shift worker's wife who couldn't sleep without the kitchen light on. We threaded the snowed-over path to the hill the villagers called the mound. The first time I heard someone say it—"we'll meet by the mound after school"—I pictured a man-made pile of snow; it was a sloped hummock with stones like teeth at its crown, older than the church and older than the road. They said old bones lay under it, and that it hummed when the ground thawed. "Útiseta," Astrid said, rolling the word in her mouth like a bite of candy. "You sit out. Sit out in the place where the dead are used to people crying. They know how to listen there." "I thought you said we were just—" I didn't finish. It was always like this: a game that wasn't a game, a dare that came with rules. "It's a thing you do to ask," she said. "It's not like those stupid laser pointer magic shows they do on TV. It's older. It works if you do it right." She reached back to take my sleeve and pulled me forward. "Come on. We have to prepare." Her preparing always made me feel like I was performing in a play I hadn't gotten the script for. She'd told me earlier that it wasn't a joke, that you don't spit on the wind or whistle in the graveyard because "things notice," and that tonight we had to do Útiseta before the term started properly because after that the village would be too loud with people thinking ear-to-ear about tests and gossip. You did this when "the mind of the place" was quiet, she said. "What are we asking?" I said. Ice squeaked under our boots as we climbed the last rise. "What we always ask," she said. "About people. About what they think about us. Who's going to do what. Who's going to be trouble. You said you wanted to know if Emil likes you." "I did not." "You said maybe," she said, and grinned in the white breath. "We can ask for other things, too. Sometimes they tell. Grandma said don't ask for things like money or cars. Ask about people. Ask about yourself. That's the only thing they'll answer without making you pay with something you actually want." "You're doing that thing again," I said, but I didn't say which thing—the thing where she treated warnings like flexes of a muscle, like it impressed her to be the one who knew where the dangerous edges were. We didn't bring candles. You weren't supposed to bring light, she said. You were supposed to borrow it. She had two old jars with lids that she said came from her grandmother's pantry, and she had a little leather pouch with salt in it and something that smelled like tar. On the top of the mound the stones were layered with frost and slick as seal skin. She walked around them clockwise, muttering as she flicked salt at her boots. "You do it so you know where your feet have been," she whispered. "You close the circle with your steps." She gestured for me to follow, and I did, making a dent in the first set of my tracks. We made three circles, and the third time she stopped at a stone with a fissure that looked like a mouth and pressed her palm to it like a kid to a window. "You knock if you take something," she said. "Even if you just take time." She knelt and opened the pouch. The tar smell was stronger: smoked resin, maybe, or something from the boats that came west in summer. She rubbed a little between her fingers, then smeared a streak under each eye like black war paint. She did the same to me without asking. The cold took it hard, and the streaks felt like tightening glass on my skin. "For seeing," she said. "You scare off meat-things, the ones that like to crawl." "Please don't use the phrase meat-things ever again," I said. She laughed. "Stop talking," she said. "People don't say anything the first time. They think if you show you're polite you get the right visitors." We sat with our backs to the same stone, our shoulders not touching. I'd expected there to be a ritual, a chant, something to occupy my attention, but Astrid only drew shallow breaths and let them slow. After a while the night pressed under my skin like snow when you fall down and stay there. The shape of my body blurred into the dark. The hill under us had a pulse you could call your own heartbeat if you wanted to. Somewhere in the village a dog barked once and changed its mind. I counted my breaths and then lost count, and then remembered Astrid saying not to count the birches. I wondered if that mattered now. The air shifted from glass to fur; I mean to say it softened, like the sky was lowering itself around us. When the wind came it wasn't the wind, exactly, but the quiet vacuum of something moving past a hollow. My teeth ached, and I had a flash of wanting to be in our apartment in Stockholm, the two flights up and the radiator that clanked all night, and the half-finished long division workbook I'd once cried over for no reason. Here, I had a girl with resin on her fingers and gravel under her. Part of me felt adult and ridiculous at the same time. If you'd asked me then if I believed, I would have said no. I would have said yes. Those answers felt the same sitting there. "Don't look at your watch," Astrid said, so softly I didn't know if I'd imagined it. "Let the bells tell us." "There won't be bells," I started, but then a sound rolled through the air like it came up from the ground: a single chime, metal and old, a note that fell clean into the silence and made a ring inside my gut. It wasn't the hour. It was one sound, and it hung there long enough for me to feel it on my back the way you feel thunder. Our church didn't have midnight services. I'd heard that said. I'd said it myself when Astrid told me we should go at twelve. But there it was. One chime. Astrid didn't react. That steadiness was part of how she did this to me. If she'd flinched, I might have laughed. "The first thing that comes isn't the thing you want," she whispered. "Grandma says it's the thing that pretends to be what you want. Let it tell you a lie. Don't take it. Wait for the second." "How do I know which is which?" "You don't," she said. "You already forgot the birches. You're not supposed to know." I wanted to turn and look at her, to make sure she was beside me, but the idea of turning seemed impossible, like moving would be a kind of rudeness. The snow made the smallest noise: that sound of crystals sliding against each other. My skin tightened. Far off, a fox barked its broken-cough voice. Or a child, I thought, and that was stupid, but once the thought came I couldn't push it away. It wasn't that I heard words. It was more like the shape of words pushing through the sensations I had, like floating text you try to read through fogged glass. Names wanted me: Emil, yes, and Malin, who had threadbare mittens and chewed them; the math teacher; the boy with the scar. Images came that were too neat, like things that would satisfy me: a note passed in class folded like a bird; a key to a locker; a face turned to me in the corridor with the expression I'd always thought I deserved. It was like being handed easy money in plain envelopes. It made me resentful. Who was making it so easy? The mound? Astrid? Myself? I wanted to push it away. Part of me wanted to take the envelopes anyway. The wind shifted again and something colder knifed past my ear. A whisper, I told myself, an angle of air. But the thought that arrived with it was not flattering and not easy. It had the shape of the seam between two stones under soil. It was about Astrid. It was about the way she told me the rules and watched me to see if I would follow them. About the way she had smiled earlier when I said I could keep a secret, a smile like a match that had already been lit. About her grandmother, and how often she said that word, like invoking a fact. The thought came with a taste of metal: her grandmother's house had old nails in the door lintel. Did I know this? Had I seen them? The thought told me they were there. Another thought: someone had been buried without a cross here, and someone had placed a broken tooth under the stone with the fissure. Was this how people think when they are scared? Or was it too specific not to be something else? I could not decide. I wanted to decide. I couldn't. "Astrid," I said, and my voice came out wrong. It sounded like I'd spoken into the mouth of a jar. "Shh," she said. "You're making room." The resin under my eyes had sent a prickly warmth down my cheeks. I realized my hands had gone numb. The bone-deep cold that is a fact in this part of the world slipped in past cloth and skin, and a different feeling came with it: a sense of being watched not by someone but by a rule. A rule the hill kept. You sit, the hill said, or the part of my brain that translates fear into sentences said. You sit and you listen. You don't bring your own light. You don't ask twice. If they tell you something you don't want, you hold it like a hot stone until it cools. Something moved in the periphery of my eyes—a shift of the darkness that matched a pale strip between two trees. If I'd been somewhere else I would have called it a rabbit. Here I didn't want to name it. It made a path through the snow without lowering it. That should have been impossible. It made a shape the snow took back an instant later. "You see it?" Astrid said, not a reaction so much as a prompt. "Do you?" "I don't ask for seeing," she said. "I already see. I want names. I want what people owe. Stop talking unless you can't not." There was a bitter taste in my mouth that wasn't the resin. I swallowed. The cold on my eyelashes had crystallized; if I blinked, it might crack and fall onto my cheeks. I thought about my mother, asleep with her book on her chest, and my father, who had taken this job because it made more money and because he wanted to go somewhere quiet where no one would bother him. The kind of man who doesn't believe in superstition because he has never had to. I thought about him and a scuff on his shoe that looked like a crescent moon, and the thought that rose under it said he had a second phone I didn't know about. Why would I think that? It was ridiculous. It was like saying there were nails in the lintel because I needed there to be. The shape of the information didn't care whether I wanted it. I told myself if I looked down and saw a second set of bootprints between me and Astrid, I would scream. I looked down. I saw our local boot brand: thin ribbed treads. I saw scuffed clots of snow where we'd made our circles. I saw the dent of one small animal closer to the birches where it had hopped and paused to leave a little pellet. I did not see a third set. I felt more watched. "The second thing," Astrid said, and her voice had dropped, "is the true thing. This is when you promise something." "I didn't bring anything to promise," I said. "You did," she said. "You bring yourself. You say I will let you use my mouth for a day. Or you say I'll keep a thing you give me for a year. Or you say I'll put a stone back in a place someone took it from. Grandma says you never promise meat. She says you never promise shoes." "What happens if you do?" "You don't get them back," she said. "Or you don't like how they fit when you do." When she said it I realized that the undertone under her voice—steady, practical—was excitement. This was fun for her. Not fun like laughing but fun like control. She had been the one to tell me there were rules, and here she was asking me to make a rule with something that didn't ask me to sign my name. The anger that rose then surprised me. It flickered up like the match her smile had been. "I'm not promising anything," I said. "I'm not—" "Then say your own name in your head and close your eyes," she said. "Finish it. You can't get up until you finish it." "I can get up whenever I want," I said, and my voice broke on the last word. My legs were pins and wire. I put my hands on the rock to squat and stand, and the stone under my palms felt warm, impossibly, like it had held the sun from a season ago and was giving it back. The warmth was so human that I jerked my hands away, then put them back because the warmth was the only thing that didn't feel like the night. "Linnea," Astrid said, and it was almost gentle. "People don't think they'll ever do something until the moment they do it. That's how they end up doing it forever." "Is that your grandma again?" I said, bitter. "That's me," she said, and I couldn't tell if the shimmer in her eyes was tears or frost or delight. Maybe all three. "Say your name." In the end, I said it, but not like a promise, more like a test. I closed my eyes and said my name without sound and without any words after it, and then I waited for the second thing. What came wasn't a revelation so much as a boundary. It was like pressing your palm against glass and learning how thick it is. I knew, suddenly, that if I asked the wrong question here I would get an answer that would be true and unhelpful. I knew that if I promised something I didn't understand, the asking would not stop when we stood up. I knew that Astrid would keep doing this whether I did it with her or not, and that she would tell the story later her way if I didn't have my own way to tell it. The knowledge sat on me like a blanket that smelled of smoke. When it was done, it was done. There was no flare. The wind shifted back to ordinary. In the village, a car misfired and seemed as loud as a firework. Astrid drew a hard breath that turned into a laugh and then didn't. "I didn't promise anything either," she said, like a confession that wanted admiration. "Good," I said, and we stood, and my knees sang as the blood went back in. We rubbed the resin from our faces with snow and it left greasy tracks on our gloves. Astrid reached down and touched the fissure stone once, a little knock like a child leaving a friend’s house, as if that made what we'd done polite. We walked back without speaking, past the birches that bowed, and I didn't count them. The sky had the faintest hint of light in it that comes before dawn in winter, the kind that feels like a stain rather than rays. Somewhere behind us in the white, I thought I heard footsteps that were not our own, then told myself it was the sound of your own breath when you start listening for footsteps. Later, in my bed, I decided that the bell had been a trick of sound, that someone had let a sheep out and rung for help, that I'd made up the nails and the tooth and the second phone because I'd been told to wait for the second thing. The memory of the hill stayed anyway, heavy as if I'd carried a stone down in my pocket and forgotten to take it out. When I saw Astrid the next day she had the same look she always had, which was the look of a person who expects you to play along. "Did you get what you wanted?" she said in the corridor, as if all we'd done was leave notes under doors. "I got something," I said. "Good," she said. She went past me and put her hand on Emil's shoulder and leaned to say something in his ear, and he flushed with whatever it was she chose to tell him, whether it was true or not. Later, when we went to her grandmother's house, there were indeed three old nails hammered into the lintel like a row of teeth. I don't remember if I'd noticed them before. I don't remember if I had put my hand on my father's second phone and turned it over without turning it on. I do remember the sound the cold made on the mound, like a mouth to a jar, and Astrid's breath on the dark. I remember the single bell. I remember the felt sense that we'd moved something around that didn't like to be moved, had edged past a dangerous idea and turned it into a toy, and that even if nothing answered us, we had answered something by sitting there. That was the line. If you ask, something hears you. Or you hear yourself in a way you cannot take back. Either way, it's a kind of being heard. Either way, it keeps listening.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This folk horror piece effectively captures the essence of the genre through its setting, characters, and atmosphere. The narrative follows Linnea's experience participating in the Útiseta ritual with her friend Astrid in rural northern Sweden, creating a compelling blend of teenage dynamics and ancient folklore. The writing excels in establishing a sense of place. The descriptions of the cold Swedish winter night are vivid and sensory, from the "muffled sound that happens when the clouds hang low enough to press on your skull" to the "ice squeaked under our boots." These details ground the reader in the physical environment while simultaneously building an atmosphere of isolation and otherworldliness. Character development is particularly strong. Linnea's perspective as an outsider from Stockholm provides a perfect lens through which to view these rural practices. Her skepticism mixed with curiosity feels authentic for a teenage transplant. Astrid is brilliantly rendered as a complex character who wields her knowledge of local traditions with a mix of genuine belief and manipulative power. The line "the thing where she treated warnings like flexes of a muscle, like it impressed her to be the one who knew where the dangerous edges were" perfectly captures this dynamic. The prose maintains a consistent voice throughout—reflective but immediate, with Linnea's teenage perspective coloring the narration. The author skillfully balances colloquial teenage speech patterns with more lyrical passages that enhance the eerie atmosphere. The ritual itself is described with just the right amount of specific detail to feel authentic without overexplaining. The ambiguity about whether anything supernatural actually occurs is masterfully maintained. The narrative leaves room for both psychological and supernatural interpretations, with Linnea herself unable to determine what is real. The piece excels at creating tension through small, unsettling details: the single bell chime that shouldn't exist, the shape moving through snow without disturbing it, the warm stone in freezing temperatures. These elements build a creeping sense of dread without resorting to obvious horror tropes. The ending effectively reinforces the theme of dangerous lines being crossed. Linnea's realization that "we'd moved something around that didn't like to be moved, had edged past a dangerous idea and turned it into a toy" perfectly captures the central concern of folk horror—the consequences of treating ancient practices as entertainment. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Some readers might find the pacing in the middle section slightly slow, though this deliberate pace contributes to the building tension. A few metaphors occasionally strain ("the air shifted from glass to fur"), but these are rare exceptions in otherwise elegant prose. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of folk horror that succeeds in creating an atmosphere of unease while exploring the relationship between two teenage girls and their different relationships to tradition and belief. The writing maintains ambiguity about supernatural elements while clearly conveying the psychological and social dynamics at play. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Physical-spatial: Therapeutic Boundaries — Score: 94.3
Prompt:
**"Therapeutic Boundaries"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a former professional athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy after a career-destroying injury, harboring resentment toward recovery itself. Their physiotherapist is not only unnervingly attractive but also a former training partner from their competitive days who has successfully transitioned to a new career while the protagonist's identity remains shattered. We'll lean into the sexual tension of the scene by having her be attracted to him, but both of them attempting to maintain mental distance while being in physical contact as he shows her stretches & movements & manipulates her body, navigating the thresholds of pain. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—every movement, stretch, and manipulation must be anatomically precise and spatially consistent. Paint an exceptionally vivid sensory picture through detailed attention to pain thresholds, involuntary responses to touch. Capture the suppressed, flaring tension of physical proximity, touch, and the controlled infliction of uncomfortable movements. Physical clarity is essential — readers must understand exactly what is happening with the body during each therapeutic technique. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The room smells like eucalyptus and old sweat threads caught in the seams of vinyl. The treatment table creaks when I hoist myself up with my good arm. A wall-mounted diagram of human musculature looms over my shoulder, a bloodless atlas—front and back views, bands of red and white, names I used to recite like prayers. Vastus medialis. Gluteus medius. Iliotibial band. Labels for the things that failed me. He shuts the door with a soft click. It’s not the locker-room slam I remember; nothing about him is loud. His hair’s shorter. Beard now, trimmed tight. The polo stretches across his shoulders when he reaches for a clipboard. His forearm flexors ridge and relax as he writes, ink scratching. I know those tendons, the way they used to rope under skin when we drove the last interval of a 400, matching stride for stride in that converging rhythm that felt like the world was a belt and we were riding it. “Scale of one to ten,” he says, eyes flickering to my face, then down to the page. “At rest.” “Two,” I lie. His mouth tugs but he doesn’t call me on it. He never did, in the early days, when we were comrades in denial. He steps closer, the faintest drift of cedar aftershave; his hands are warm when he touches my shoulder, then slides along the line of my collarbone as if mapping where to avoid. “We’ll go slow. No heroics.” No heroics. The words belong to a different person than the one who gutted through lactic burn on a winter track, spitting steam, the two of us laughing as our thighs trembled, daring each other to one more rep. He’s a different person too, with the letters after his name stitched into his chest: DPT. I watch the embroidered thread ripple when he breathes. “Lie back,” he says. I shift from pelvis to shoulder blades, easing down. The table is a narrow raft; if I flinch, I could slide off. He positions my legs with a gentleness that irritates me. My left knee, the traitor, is elevated on a wedge. He has me straighten both legs out, aligning hip joints evenly. The ceiling hums with fluorescent light. “We’ll start with your ankle,” he says. “Distal to proximal.” He stands at the foot of the table and cradles my left heel in one hand, his other hand supporting over the dorsum of my foot, fingers splayed across metatarsals two through five. “Just relax,” he adds, knowing I can’t. He guides my ankle into dorsiflexion, bringing my toes toward my shin. His thumb presses gently against the calcaneus to prevent inversion. The stretch shows up like a thin blade along my Achilles, climbing into my calf—the gastroc bellies first, then deeper into the soleus. He stops at the point where the blade bites. “Where are you?” “Four,” I say, voice stiff. “Breathe into it.” He holds there, seconds ticking in the count he doesn’t voice anymore. My tibia feels anchored; his grip is precise. On the poster, the achingly red cords of the triceps surae stare back. He eases off, then repeats, increment by increment, coaxing range. When he adds overpressure—just a couple millimeters past where I think it should stop—my foot trembles. I hate that it trembles. The tremor quivers up the anterior tibialis like a noise in wire. “Okay,” he says. He lowers my foot and runs the side of his index finger up the medial arch. “Any tingling?” “No.” The sensation is straight pressure, no fireworks in the saphenous nerve territory. He nods. He switches to passive hamstring stretch. He steps to my left side, his hip close to the table. He cups my heel again and slides his other hand under my distal thigh. My skin prickles where his palm presses; it’s not pain. He lifts my leg, knee extended, hip into flexion. The hamstrings unspool in protest. At fifty degrees, I can feel the meat of biceps femoris tighten like it’s going to pluck itself. At sixty, there’s a hot line at the ischial tuberosity. My pelvis wants to posteriorly tilt, lumbar spine flattening into the table. He places his forearm across my ASIS to hold the pelvis stable, his elbow hooked lightly over my iliac crest. “Neutral spine,” he says. His forearm is solid heat across my hip bones. “Don’t let your pelvis rotate.” My breath climbs into my throat. “I’m not.” He smiles without showing teeth. He knows I am. He presses down, just enough to pin the pelvis, and carries my heel toward the ceiling another few degrees. The stretch shifts, deeper, closer to where the tendon bundles splay into the ischial attachment. Pain flares, crisp. Seven. I clench around it and he feels the contraction in my thigh; his fingers depress into the hamstrings and wait. “In through your nose,” he says. He’s watching my face. I make my breath slow, stupidly obedient. The pain backs down to a five, then a four, a throb instead of a knife. He comes back a degree more, and the breath stutters again. My toes are cold. My fingers have curled into the edge of the table so hard the vinyl seam bites. “I hate this,” I say, so quietly I could be talking to the diagram. “I know.” He lowers my leg with a care that makes something in my chest ache. He sets my heel down, aligns the malleoli. The room is too bright; the table’s paper crinkles under my shoulder blades. He picks up my foot again and draws it into a straight-leg raise, then deviates it a few degrees into internal rotation, targeting the medial hamstring. He tracks my patella to keep it from drifting. Each tiny adjustment changes the line of fire. He talks through the tissue: semimembranosus, semitendinosus. He says the words clinically, but they land in me like memories of drills, of out-and-back runs where our feet flicked up behind us, hamstrings snapping like cables. “Let’s try some nerve glides.” He flexes my hip to forty-five with the knee extended and then dorsiflexes my ankle while extending my knee another notch. The discomfort is a different flavor—more of a spreading burn along the back of my leg, a sensation that feels like water seeking a lower level. It peels down past the fibular head, into the calf, to the outer border of my foot. He reverses the ankle as he increases the knee extension to tease neural tension without cooking the nerve. He watches my eyes. “Talk to me.” “Six,” I say, meaning: manageable, as long as you don’t go zealous on me. He doesn’t. He cycles through a rhythm, slide and tension, slide and tension. My hamstrings twitch, tiny fasciculations like moths in a lampshade. He backs off when they intensify. He’s reading my legs like he read my stride all those years—knowing when I had one more rep, when I didn’t. He moves to my knee. The scar down the lateral side is a pale zipper. He places his thumb pads either side of the joint line and does a gentle varus stress at thirty degrees flexion, assessing lateral collateral integrity. The joint opens barely perceptible, firm end feel. He nods. He changes to valgus stress, medial gap. The MCL end feel is more yielding. He watches my mouth as he tests; I bite hard enough to feel a ridge of tooth in my tongue. He palpates the patellar tendon, the infrapatellar fat pad, the IT band distal tract where it inserts on Gerdy’s tubercle. When he strokes along the band, the tissue feels like a cable under my skin. He picks up a strip of kinesiology tape and measures from the Gerdy’s tubercle up to the greater trochanter with his fingers. He tears the backing half an inch, anchors it distal, then lays it up the lateral thigh with just enough tension to lift the skin microscopically. His fingers smooth the tape, heat activating adhesive. They travel, inadvertently, close to where my shorts end. The skin there is more sensitive from disuse, the hair growing back uneven. My breath stutters. He pauses, fingers hovering without touching. “Okay?” he asks. “Yeah.” It comes out like air leaking. He rolls a stool behind him with a heel push and sits, bringing his eyes level with my hip. He swings the therapy table extension out, bends my knee to ninety, and drapes my lower leg over his thigh to support the tibia. He places one hand on my ASIS again and the other on my distal femur. “Hip internal rotation,” he says. He eases my shin outward, rotating the femur inward. The deep lateral rotators mutter. I feel it deep in the posterior hip, around the greater trochanter, where the gluteus medius fibers fan. He targets glute med specifically next: he has me roll slightly onto my right side, my left leg stacked on top, knees bent. He slides his hand under my waist to keep my spine neutral, not letting me cheat by laterally flexing. His palm is a warm wedge, a fulcrum against my obliques. When he tells me to lift the top knee without rolling my pelvis open—clamshell—the burn is immediate at the outer hip, the gluteus medius and minimus firing. My TFL tries to jump in, the anterior fibers tensing, and he taps the posterior lateral crest lightly. “Back here. Don’t let the TFL dominate.” I adjust the angle, rotating my femur slightly to aim the contraction posteriorly. The burn sharpens, a coin of heat pressed under skin. He holds two fingers against the muscle and feels it engage. “Two seconds up,” he says, metronome calm. “Four seconds down.” My leg shakes by rep six. By rep ten, the muscle is a live wire. Sweat beads under my arms and sticks my shirt to my ribs. He counts to twelve and stops, not because I want to—because form fails. He always knew the difference. He takes my ankle and extends my hip behind me, knee still bent ninety degrees, and then draws my heel slightly toward the ceiling, small range. The gluteus maximus joins the chorus now, deep and powerful, but under that it stings where the proximal tendon attaches. He slides his fingers deep into the meat of my glute, finding the piriformis, and presses. It’s pressure so direct it feels indecent. I hiss and feel my pelvic floor reflexively tighten, a small panic clench. His eyes flick to mine and then away; his fingers don’t shift. “Breathe,” he says, voice a tone lower, steady. He works the trigger point, short compressions, then sustained. The pain blooms and then fades in waves. When it releases, it’s like a knot unties and the leg suddenly weighs less. He withdraws his hand slowly, careful not to drag, giving the tissue time to settle. My skin chills where his warmth has been. “Bridge,” he says, moving on. He helps me roll onto my back again, places my feet hip-width apart, knees up, neutral pelvis. He taps my ASIS and PSIS to cue the tilt. “No global tilt. Zip your ribs down.” He slides a hand under my lumbar spine to check space: not smashed, not arching. “Drive through your heels. Don’t push the knees outward; track over second toes.” He says these things because he doesn’t trust my old instincts, which are to throw everything at every problem. I lift my pelvis, vertebra by vertebra. The gluteal tissue cords up. The hamstrings try to dominate again; he snakes a belt around my thighs just above the knees, gives me the cue to press gently into it. The adductors turn on, and the glutes find their job. The strain is clean. He presses down with two fingers on my ASIS to keep the pelvis level. His hands are warm weights. The table paper crackles under me. Sweat runs along my scalp and pools in my ear. “Hold,” he says, breath close enough that I can feel it move the tiny hairs at my temple. I’m aware of the length of his hip next to my hand, the heat of him in the space under the fluorescent hum. The memory of his body moving beside mine years ago is a spool winding tighter while he watches my pelvis for a hint of rotation. I hold for eight seconds, then lower slowly. He adjusts the belt and asks for two more. I give him three. It’s not generosity; it’s defiance. When I finish, the glutes are heavy and alive, the knee feels both more present and less like glass. He wheels a cart closer and pulls out a jade-green band. He loops it around the balls of my feet, hands me the ends. “Ankle dorsiflexion isometrics,” he says. “Keep talar alignment.” He cups the front of my ankle joint line and presses the talus posteriorly as I draw the band toward me, avoiding anterior translation that would impinge. The tendon on the front of my ankle strings under my skin, extensor hallucis longus showing as a separate line. He nods. “Good.” He asks me to hold, then slowly control the eccentric letting go. The burn is small, neat. I can do neat. He stands, steps back, crosses his arms. The shift in distance makes the air cooler. My skin prickles. He scribbles something on the clipboard, then sets it aside. He looks up, finally meeting my eyes for more than a beat. “You’re doing well,” he says. “Define well,” I say, the bitterness reflexive, because praise slides off me now like oil. “Not avoiding. Not compensating. Listening.” He gestures to the diagram, the red-streaked body watching us. “This is a different kind of performance.” It’s a different kind of humiliation. My body, once a finely tuned machine, now reduced to joints needing to be coaxed like sullen children. I swallow, throat tight. The resentment tastes metallic. It’s not just at the tissue—I resent him too, resent the ease with which he has become something else, his stride smooth across the clinic floor. He catches my look and doesn’t flinch away from it. There were years when we knew everything about each other’s limits; now the only thing we don’t say is the only thing loud in the room. He sets up for soft tissue work along the IT band. “Side-lying again,” he says. He positions a white towel under my lateral thigh to protect my skin. He squirts lotion into his palm, rubs hands together, and then makes a fist with one hand, using the knuckles to strip slowly from the distal lateral quad up toward the greater trochanter, staying just anterior to the IT band itself—he knows not to grind into the band proper, to work the neighboring tissues. His other hand stabilizes my thigh. The pressure is slow, deliberate; I feel the drag under his knuckles, the heat building. At a certain point, near the mid-thigh, the TFL fires reflexively, and my knee jerks. He pauses the pressure, holds, waits for the muscle to melt. My breath gets shallow. He slides closer by a centimeter to keep his elbow over his wrist, over his knuckles; physically coherent, always. The smell of lotion mixes with that cedar, and my body confuses pain and something else in the same breath. He doesn’t change the pressure or comment. He strips again, resets. Over and over, careful. When he finishes, he cleans his hands and the lotion sheen from my skin. He tapes me again, two strips now, one Y-shaped curling around the patella to help guide tracking. He presses it down with his palm, heat activating. He keeps his palm there a beat longer than necessary. Or maybe it’s exactly necessary and I am making everything into intention. He helps me sit up. I can feel the muscles we lit up settling, the delayed onset not yet dawning, the pleasant heaviness that will turn to ache by evening. He steps back to a respectable distance. The loss of proximity is a relief and a deprivation. “You okay to walk?” he asks. His voice is professional again, a clinic voice that belonged to someone else in a different life and now belongs to him. “I can walk,” I say. Walking is what’s left when everything else is gone. He smiles, small, private. “You can walk better now.” The chart on the wall watches as I ease off the table. My knee tracks over my mid-foot without the medial wobble that has been my new signature. The tape holds my skin in pink waves. He’s beside me without hovering, hands ready but not reaching. I take a step. Then another. The first corner of the room arrives faster than I expect. The pain is there, old friend/new enemy, but it’s quieter. I could resent that too—the way he can make me less miserable with his hands, with a thought. At the door, I say, without looking at him, “I hate that I need this.” He’s quiet a long time. Then: “You don’t have to like it to do it right.” A pause. “You don’t have to like me either.” I almost laugh. It feels like swallowing glass. “I never did,” I say. His reflection in the glass of the door gives me away: his mouth quirks, an almost. “Liar.” When he reaches past me to open the door, his arm grazes my shoulder. A small contact, nothing. My skin remembers every finish line we leaned into, shoulder to shoulder, as if touch could break tape. For a second I think of the way his forearm felt across my pelvis, the careful pressure, the exactness of him, and I want to spin and say something foolish and irreversible. Instead, I nod at him like he is anyone, and step into the hall, the tape pulling gently at my skin as I move. Somewhere in the red-and-white topography behind me, the gluteus medius lights up like a warning flare and then settles. We have three more weeks of this. I will count them in breaths held, seconds of pressure, degrees of flexion logged, and the inches between his hands and my skin. I will count them in ways he’ll never see. Or maybe he will. He always did. He shuts the door gently behind me. The hinge doesn’t complain. My knee does, lightly, acknowledging a negotiation rather than a war.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative excels at creating a physically coherent and emotionally charged physical therapy session. The writer demonstrates exceptional knowledge of anatomy, physical therapy techniques, and the psychological dimensions of injury recovery. The narrative's greatest strength is its anatomical precision. Every movement is described with clinical accuracy—from ankle dorsiflexion to hip internal rotation, from hamstring stretches to gluteal activation. The writer uses proper medical terminology (vastus medialis, ASIS, PSIS, etc.) while making these technical details accessible through sensory description. The physical manipulations are spatially consistent and follow a logical progression from distal to proximal, as mentioned in the text. The emotional landscape is equally well-rendered. The protagonist's resentment toward recovery is palpable, manifesting in small rebellions ("I give him three. It's not generosity; it's defiance") and bitter remarks. The narrative effectively captures the protagonist's complex feelings: the humiliation of needing help, the resentment toward the therapist who successfully transitioned careers, and the unwanted attraction that complicates their professional relationship. The sexual tension is handled with subtlety and restraint. Rather than explicit statements, the tension emerges through physical awareness ("My skin prickles where his palm presses; it's not pain"), physiological responses ("my body confuses pain and something else in the same breath"), and the protagonist's hyperawareness of proximity ("The loss of proximity is a relief and a deprivation"). This approach creates a more authentic and compelling tension than would more overt description. The prose is elegant and precise, with effective sensory details that ground the reader in the physical experience: "The pain blooms and then fades in waves," "Sweat runs along my scalp and pools in my ear." The writer employs effective metaphors that connect to the athletic background: "My hamstrings twitch, tiny fasciculations like moths in a lampshade." The narrative maintains a consistent voice—clinical yet emotionally charged, reflecting the protagonist's attempt to distance themselves from vulnerability while being intensely physically aware. The ending avoids an unrealistic transformation while acknowledging a small shift: "My knee does, lightly, acknowledging a negotiation rather than a war." There are no significant weaknesses in this piece. It avoids purple prose despite the detailed descriptions, maintains focus without meandering, and shows rather than tells the protagonist's emotional state. The dialogue is sparse but effective, revealing character and relationship dynamics. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted narrative that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while creating a compelling, emotionally resonant scene with remarkable physical coherence and psychological depth. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Historical fiction: High Seas and Low Vices — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
High Seas and Low Vices: British Naval Officer in the Opium Trade Character: Lieutenant James Merrick, a high-ranking officer in the British Royal Navy stationed in Canton, China in the 1830s. Once promising and decorated, now struggling with a severe opium addiction he hides from his superiors. Synopsis: Write a chapter following Lieutenant Merrick during a single day as he shirks his official naval duties in what has become a daily need to satiate the dragon. Told primarily in dialogue with the characters he interacts with. Focus on brief slices of his journey through the shadowy underworld of Canton: interactions with acquaintances, negotiations with local dealers, schemes and unsavoury jobs taken to fund his habit. Writing Task: Use rich sensory details to describe a day in the life of James Merrick. Write for a real sense of time & place while avoiding cliche. First person, past tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
“Morning, Lieutenant. You’re late for inspection.” “I’m early for everything else, Sykes,” I said, fastening my collar with shaking fingers. “What’s the count?” “Boatswain says the stores are short two barrels of flour. And the captain wants a word about the Chinese envoy. You look a bit… you know.” “I slept poorly. The heat.” “It’s winter.” “Then I slept poorly for winter.” He sniffed. Pitch tar and river damp clung to him, to the deck, to the cotton cords of dock lines that creaked as the Pearl River breathed. Beyond our mooring, the foreign factories—brick bluffs with shuttered windows and flagstaffs—stood in orderly ranks. Junks drifted past like leaf-shaped ghosts. Somewhere a gong met the morning with patient clangs. “I’ll tell the men to lay off the rum for the envoy’s visit,” Sykes muttered. “You’ll come?” “I’ll be along,” I lied. The jade in my pocket was warm now, and I rubbed it without looking. It had a face of some god I didn’t know—mouth open in a silent O. My thumb had worn the cheek pale. “Lieutenant,” he said again, and in his voice a question: Are you fit? Are you ours? I turned away, took the gangplank with a jaunty authority that fooled neither of us. On shore the smell deepened. River, mud, fish offal. A market had unraveled itself along the lane: orange peel, ginger, chattering buyers, the lacquered clack of abacus beads. A boy ran past with a rooster under his arm that screamed like a pipe being scraped. Outside the Company’s hongs, clerks in hats like paper boats queued for letters. Behind a gate two soldiers shifted their pikes and watched me pass as if I were a bad coin. “You a busy gentleman today, Mister Lieut?” a voice chirped near my elbow. Ruby, her hair plaited with ribbon, her teeth lacquered black. She sold sweetened tea and gossip in equal measure from a cart whose wheels were a marvel of bamboo and rope. “Never busy enough when there’s tea.” She poured into a chipped cup. The liquid was bitter as a sermon. My hand trembled; the cup chimed against the saucer. “You need smoke,” she said softly, as if telling me my buttons were misaligned. “You white men, you go green without it.” “I need to see you smile,” I replied, and she rolled her eyes, but relief loosened something in me at her knowledge, her casualness. To be known, and for it not to be an alarm. “You show face at Mr. Herrick’s later,” she said. “He ask for you yesterday.” “Herrick’s asking for my money.” She shrugged. “He is snake, but his smoke too. You watch for runners today. They look like soldiers but they not soldiers. New ones. Sleeve red inside.” “Customs men?” She lifted her shoulders. Nothing. I nodded, paid her in small coin, and set off for the back lanes where the respectable walked with a purpose and the rest of us drifted. In Fanqui Town the facades were familiar: white paint and shuttered galleries, British flags and Portuguese and American. The smell there was ink and bread and varnished chests. Once I would have gone through those doors by right, my uniform crisp as a blade, to negotiate cargo manifests, to bully a tea merchant over duties. The captain admired my tongue then. Now I swerved behind a building, between coils of rope and stacks of cracked porcelain, into the shade where Canton unraveled into its own language. It was cooler there, the air damp and breathy, the sun fractured by overhangs and laundry. A butcher hooked a carp by the gills and slit it; its scales flashed like coins. At the warehouse yard I found Bacon leaning on a crate, hands black as a lamplighter’s, hat too small for his head. Bacon had once saved my life in a swell off Whampoa, and I had thanked him with rum and then with money and then with less. “Lieut,” he said, lazy with his greeting, but his eyes took me in, my posture, my blue lips. “You ghosting again?” “On business.” My jaw was rattling slightly. I set my teeth. “Mr. Herrick in?” “In his den. Mr. Choi already there.” “Choi?” “That’s the Canton name with the finger in everything. Pawnshops, girls, leaky boats. He came like a westerly.” “And he’ll go like a storm,” I muttered. Sweat had beaded under my collar. The jade in my pocket was now a hot coal; I rubbed it; it seemed to push back. “Look,” Bacon said, voice low. “You still owe him. You owe me. And the captain sent Sykes looking.” “The captain can wait.” “The captain, maybe. Sykes, he a dog. He bites from love.” Bacon tilted his head. “You sure you want to cross this threshold, James?” “I crossed it six years ago,” I said. “Very little left to fear.” The warehouse door opened into the dim, where bales of cotton and barrels of sugar towered like sleeping beasts. Lantern light made a cave of it. The opium room was at the back. It had a curtain of beads you could pretend muffled things. It muffled nothing. Do I need to tell you how it smelled? Lamp smoke, vinegar, the sweet rot of lotus. The thinnest string of music from a two-string fiddle that carried like a mosquito’s whine. Herrick sat at a table with ledgers spread and his hair combed with oil that reflected the lantern in points. Mr. Choi looked like a prayer book with the title in gold—plain, precise, the gold the only hint. He wore a scholar’s robe and his hands were clean. “Lieutenant Merrick,” Herrick said, teeth like little dominoes set in rows. “The navy’s own. We were just discussing your remarkable capacity.” “I’m a man of many capacities,” I said, breath catching on the last word. “You owe Mr. Choi twenty Spanish dollars.” “My account—” “Is a map of a war the enemy has already won.” He smiled at his own turn. He loved a phrase. “Yet you are a man of resource.” “I brought the papers,” I said, nails biting my palm. “The manifest for the rice shipment seized at Whampoa. Names, marks. The cut for you, the cut for the mandarins who will find a way to lose it.” Choi turned a single page, glancing at the ciphered script that had taken me all last night to copy by lamplight, the words swimming as my hands shook. He made a sound—approval, amusement, I couldn’t tell. Herrick chewed an invisible thread of patience. “Whose seal?” Choi asked. “Captain Rooke’s. He's never learned to keep his stamp as close as his wife.” “Sly boy,” Herrick murmured, but there was something bright behind his monotone. Calculation. “If these papers find their way to Dr. Sinclair, he will think it our charity.” “And he will pay in gratitude,” Choi said, “which spends as poorly as rice in the sun. But perhaps it buys other things.” “I want what I came for,” I said. “One parcel.” “One?” Herrick’s eyebrows went up. “You a monk now?” “Two,” I said. “Two will make me human again.” “Two for the papers and your charming company. The rest of your debt remains.” “Two and a promise,” I said. “I have something else. A cutter goes upriver tonight to look for smugglers’ camps. I know where she’ll pause. There will be rum aboard. And there will be silver. I can make sure she pauses longer where you want her.” “That will cost you a uniform and a career,” Herrick said softly. “Those are not currencies I still hold.” Choi looked at me across the table with a flat regard. “You like to lose. You wear it like a medal.” “I’m tired,” I said. “I like sleep.” He considered, then flicked his fingers. A boy in a blue vest came forward with two dark clay peas wrapped in oiled paper. They looked like nothing. My throat clenched at the sight. Sweat slid down my spine like a cold insect. “You smoke here,” Choi said. “We see you become human. Then we talk.” Herrick sighed. “Always the theatricals.” He shoved the little tray towards me, the lamp already hot, the needle to dissolve the extract, the thin bamboo pipes, the bed with its low cushion and its oil-stained pillow. The jade in my pocket bit like a small dog. My hands had smudged ink on the papers. There was a moment where the other day, the one with the envoy and the inspection, reached for me. And then I reached past it. “Not here,” I said. “Too many eyes.” “You’re a shy cat now?” Herrick said. “In an hour,” I said, swallowing. “When I can stand to speak without my voice tearing.” Choi’s lips twitched. “Go. But you are bound by breath now.” I took the parcels with a care that made my hands steady. Bacon watched me with a pity that tasted like tinfoil. On the way out, Herrick said, “James.” I stopped. The beads clicked like teeth. “Bring me something with teeth this time. Not just papers. A name. A schedule. Not Dr. Sinclair’s charity. A bite.” “You’ll see blood,” I said, and stepped into the heat again that was not heat but humidity, the air like silk dragged over water. The jade cooled in my hand; I squeezed it until my fingers hurt. Down the lane toward the lodgings where the walls were thin enough to hear your neighbor breathe, I met a man I had once boxed on the quarterdeck for calling the Chinese “rats.” It was Lieutenant Fenton now, hat like a crow’s wing. He recognized me midway, the way shame recognizes a mirror. “Merrick,” he said. “We missed you at morning roll. Captain’s displeased. There’s rumor you’ve taken ill.” “Rumor is a gossip with better posture,” I said. “You’re sweating.” “It’s winter.” He glanced at my pocket, at the lump, as if he could see the jade, the parcels. His face did a thing—anger and fear mixing like oil and water. “If you drag us into the mud,” he said quietly, “I’ll be the first to put you before a court.” “If I don’t drag myself, you won’t need to lift a finger.” He reached out as if to catch my sleeve, then thought better. “We were friends once,” he said, and I almost laughed. Once we had laughed at the fat of salt pork. Friendship had been as easy as finishing each other’s curses. I moved past him as the gong from some unseen temple turned the hour. The sound swept along the lanes, flattening conversation for a heartbeat. My room was up a stair the width of a coffin. The door stuck in the damp; I hip-checked it open. The bed was a narrow plank with a blanket that remembered other bodies. Light fell in a square on the floor, full of dust. I set the parcels on the windowsill and closed my eyes for a count of ten. The shaking didn’t abate. I unwrapped the paper with a care that was almost reverence. “James?” a voice whispered from the hall. I started. The tray clattered. Ruby slipped inside, bringing with her the steam of the street and the perfume of damp hair. “You do here?” she said. “Many ears.” “I do everywhere,” I said, and tried to smile. “Did you follow me?” “You white men walk like drums,” she said, shrugging. She came to the window and touched the packet with a fingertip, as if to test its temperature. “You owe me two dollars for the tea.” “I’ll be rich by sundown,” I lied. “Big liar,” she said lightly, but there was worry under it. “Mr. Choi, he say you too storm. He no like storms. He like rivers.” “I’ll be a puddle in a minute,” I said. “Do you mind?” She shook her head and sat cross-legged on the bed as if it were the most ordinary place in the world to watch a man undo himself. I warmed the pea, teased it into dark syrup, twirled it on the needle. The lamp licked at it like a polite animal. I loaded the pipe, held the stem in my teeth, let the smoke roll and fall as I chased it with the flame. The first inhalation always hurt, like forgetting how to swallow and relearning with fire. My chest fought me, then opened. The second swallow was a river over stones. “You like a god now,” Ruby said, amused, as the room tilted, as the square of light on the floor lengthened into a road and then a sheet and then a memory. The clatter of carts outside softened into pulse. The itch under my skin dissolved into a pale warmth that had nothing to do with the weather. The jade in my pocket cooled to a moon pebble. My hands stopped. My voice, when it came, had lost its burr. “Herrick wants names,” I said. “Tonight. I can give him Fenton’s. He’s on the cutter. He thinks he’s hunting smugglers. He’s hunting his own shadow.” “You do bad,” Ruby said without malice. “You do good. People like coins. Two sides. Both spend.” “I’ll tell him lies with enough truth to make them walk.” “You Navy,” she said, as if that explained my fondness for false weather. In the quiet, a rat grazed the wall. A child squealed, was shushed. “Ruby,” I said. “If I give Herrick’s men the cutter’s berth, there will be fighting.” “Many fight,” she said. “You just choose where your hands be.” “I used to be certain.” “You white men think certainty is rice. You hungry when it gone.” I turned my head to look at her. Her eyes were very black, and in them I saw the reflection of the lamp, a tiny sun. She touched my sleeve. “Time keeps going,” she said. “You think it stop because you slow? No. It go. You choose to run or to sleep.” “I choose to make a call,” I said, and the words felt distant, as if another man had left them for me in the bed. “Go to Bacon. Tell him the cutter will linger at the bend below the Weaving Goddess Temple. At dusk. Tell him to tell Choi. Tell him to keep his men’s fingers light.” “You want them to take only rum,” she guessed. “And the money,” I said. “No blood.” She stood. “No promise. Men fingers have nails. They scratch. Blood come.” “Tell them,” I said again, and she nodded, more out of kindness than belief, and slipped away. The light moved on the floor. I lay there and let the smoke teach my body its temporary mercy. The jade was smooth, all edges worn away. I held it, thinking of my father’s hands—he had given it to me in Portsmouth with a laugh at his own superstition, as if it were a joke he had included me in. “For luck,” he had said, as we smelled the sea together. He had died two years later, his lungs eaten, not by smoke but by a fever that coughed him inside out. I wondered what he would think of me now. I closed my eyes and saw the white line of Hampshire winter fields, the hedge black against it. It was a picture I returned to when the river silted me. When I woke the day had tilted, the street now full of afternoon voices, the light gone tinny. My tongue was leather. The second pea waited, patient as a stored insult. I put it in my coat instead, to carry through the next hour. Duty gnawed faintly at the edges; the envoy would be sweating under the awning on our quarterdeck, and Sykes would be lying through his smile. I splashed my face from the basin and nearly vomited at the smell, then laughed. My laugh sounded like someone else’s. Back in the lanes, I found Bacon at the corner by the wheelwright, where the smell of pine shavings and hot iron made a peculiar marriage. “You got a message,” I said. “You look like a man who found his pillow,” he said. “The Weaving Goddess bend. At dusk. Tell Choi to take rum and silver, leave the men their skin.” He blew air through his lips. “Plenty of ways a night can go wrong.” “Choose one that doesn’t involve the Navy waking with a knife,” I said. “I like my sleep.” “You owe me still.” “I’ll owe you less,” I said. He crossed his arms. “Sykes came looking. Twice. He gonna come again with Fenton. Fenton’s got a look like a fish when it see the net.” “Then tell Sykes I was here, discussing wheelwrighting.” “You don’t even have a wheel.” “No,” I said. “I have too many.” He shook his head, but his mouth softened. “Go. Before your legs remember they belong to someone else.” The riverbank was already purpled with evening when I reached the bend. Temple lanterns winked along the path like eyes closing, opening. Women washed clothes and beat the water with paddles; each slap was a metronome. A fisherman stowed his net like a priest folding a vestment. I crouched in the shadow of a banyan whose roots strangled its own stones and tried not to rub the jade. The cutter came sliding quiet as a thought, Fenton at the stern, hat low, men drowsing with the lazy attention of boys on a cart. They tied up, three knots, the boy’s voice counting in a Sutherland lilt. I could pick their shadows apart from three years of watching their bodies move at orders. In the reeds across, a whisper. Then canvas moved. Choi’s men were nothing but black on black, their oars wrapped. A gray shape alongside, a hiss. A bump. A hand, a knife, the whisper of coil. I stood to go, then stayed. The habit of an officer is to go. The habit of a man like me is to stay back. Each step away from the deck makes you less able to return. “Who goes?” Fenton called, sharp. “Friends,” said a voice in simple Cantonese, and I could hear the smile. A
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the gritty, morally compromised world of a British naval officer in 1830s Canton who has fallen into opium addiction. The writing demonstrates a strong command of historical setting, sensory detail, and character development. The first-person narration successfully conveys Lieutenant Merrick's deteriorating state through both explicit description and subtle cues in his interactions. The prose style balances period-appropriate language with readability, avoiding anachronisms while maintaining flow. Particularly effective is how the writing mimics Merrick's mental state - more precise when he's recently used opium, more fragmented when he's in withdrawal. The dialogue is a significant strength. Each character has a distinct voice that reflects their background and relationship to Merrick. Ruby's broken English conveys her character without becoming a stereotype, while the exchanges between naval officers carry the appropriate formality and subtext. The dialogue efficiently reveals character relationships and advances the plot without exposition. The sensory details are vivid and specific to the setting: "River, mud, fish offal," "The liquid was bitter as a sermon," and "the air like silk dragged over water." These details ground the reader in the physical reality of Canton while reflecting Merrick's altered perceptions. The piece excels at showing Merrick's moral compromise through his actions rather than explaining it. His willingness to betray naval secrets, his physical deterioration, and his rationalization of his choices all reveal his character without explicit commentary. The jade talisman serves as an effective symbol of his connection to his past self and values. The narrative structure follows Merrick through a day of increasingly compromised choices, building tension as he moves toward betraying his fellow officers. The pacing is effective, with moments of reflection balanced against action. Some minor weaknesses: The piece occasionally indulges in metaphors that, while evocative, can feel slightly overwrought ("Friendship had been as easy as finishing each other's curses"). There are a few instances where the prose becomes slightly purple, particularly in descriptions of Merrick's opium experience. The ending appears to be cut off mid-sentence, which prevents a full assessment of the conclusion. Overall, this is a sophisticated piece that creates a compelling character study while vividly evoking a specific historical setting. It balances sensory detail, character development, and plot progression effectively while maintaining a consistent voice and tone. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Humour: Sisyphus Gives Advice — Score: 95.7
Prompt:
Sisyphus Gives Advice Write a comedic scene in the style of Terry Pratchett featuring Sisyphus, who has started an advice column while continuing his eternal boulder-pushing. Rather than being bitter about his punishment, Sisyphus has developed a comfortably zen emotional intelligence and wisdom from his centuries of repetitive labor. Not in the cliche ways you might expect -- he's actually very grounded, warm & connected with the everyday human plight. He dictates responses to "Crow," his feathered familiar who serves as both scribe and mail carrier. The piece should include Sisyphus thoughtfully answering several advice-seekers' letters about everyday problems (relationship troubles, work-life balance, dealing with difficult people, life purpose doubts) while periodically returning to his boulder-pushing duties. His advice should be surprisingly insightful and practical. The humor should emerge naturally from the messages he receives, from mundane to risque. Sisyphus should genuinely enjoy helping others, finding meaning in this new pursuit while maintaining his boulder routine. The humour should be *understated and not forced*. Contrary to expectation, almost none of his advice involves boulder rolling metaphors (though he does sneak *one* subtle in there), nor a treatise on stoicism. We are also going against the obvious fish-out-of-water trope; in fact, he's surprisingly a natural at this. In all of this , it's important to *show, don't tell*. The format should be largely epistolary, with the occasional interjection for scene setting. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The wind is a polite sort of tyrant on the mountainside. It arrives when it wants, rearranges anything it fancies, and leaves Sisyphus’s hair doing something that could be prosecuted in certain barbers’ jurisdictions. The boulder is there too, of course, unkicked and entirely itself, squarely spherical and smug in a way only a rock that has outlived a dozen civilizations can manage. “Crow,” says Sisyphus, breathing evenly as they crest the midpoint. “What’s first?” Crow, black as spilled ink and wearing a quill behind his ear purely for the irony, shuffles letters with his beak. The letters make a sound like leaves deciding whether to fall. “We could start with the urgent one stamped ‘urgent’ and also ‘urgent’ in three different dialects,” he says, voice like polished sarcasm. “Or the one that smells faintly of perfume and very distinctly of decision fatigue.” “Perfume, then,” says Sisyphus. “I live to enable your priorities,” Crow mutters, and clears his throat. “‘Dear Mr. Sisyphus, My girlfriend wants me to move in. She’s amazing. I also like my solitude, my mess, and the freedom to eat cereal for dinner without commentary. I don’t want to lose her, but I fear condiments will become battlegrounds. What do I do? — Spoon in Two Places.’” Sisyphus plants his feet against a minor landslide. The boulder pauses, considers gravity, and resumes its ancient argument with it. He smiles. “To Spoon in Two Places,” he dictates. “Congratulations on finding someone whose existence competes with cereal. That’s rare. Moving in is less about drawers and more about world-building. Try this: set a date for a three-month trial. Agree on three non-negotiables each, in writing. Not because you don’t trust each other, but because people forget their own promises when the bin stares accusingly. Yours might be: I get one room to be gloriously mine; I can eat cereal for dinner once a week without commentary; I need two hours of silence on Sundays. Hers might be entirely different and unexpectedly reasonable. Schedule a weekly twenty-minute ‘house meeting’ with a timer and tea. If everything feels like it happened to you by accident, it wasn’t a decision. Make it a decision. If, after three months, you both miss your own spaces more than you enjoy the shared one, that’s also data, not failure.” He nods at Crow. “Add: ‘Prepare a condiment treaty; ketchup is a political party.’” Crow sighs, but writes. “Editorial note,” he adds in tiny, elegant script. “Cereal for dinner is a lifestyle, not a cry for help.” The boulder kisses the top with geological indifference and begins the long sigh downward. Sisyphus jogs beside it, hand on stone, not hurried so much as synchronized with inevitability. On the way down, Crow spreads his wings and lets the letters slap his feathers until he decides the next one has finished sulking in the sack. “Work-life balance,” he announces, landing atop the boulder as if it were a throne that kept trying to throw him off. “From ‘Burned To A Crisp, Esq.’” “Please,” Sisyphus says, and means it. “‘Dear Sisyphus, I’m a junior associate at a law firm where the hours are described as “heroic.” My mother calls me at 11 p.m. asking why I’m still at work, my supervisor calls me at 11:05 p.m. asking why I’m not, and my basil plant has joined a commune. I want to be good at my job. I also want a life. Advice? — BTC, Esq.’” “Dear BTC,” Sisyphus says. He gently nudges the boulder with his shoulder. “Banner your calendar with yourself. Not in fluorescent ink or blood, but in whatever your firm respects. If they like client names, be your own client. ‘BTC v. Collapse, recurring.’ Put two hours of immovable blocks a week during normal hours, and tell your supervisor what you’ll be doing—‘deep drafting time.’ People are bad at respecting vague boundaries. They are astonishingly good at respecting something that sounds billable. For your mother: give her one scheduled call a week that you keep religiously, and tell her your phone goes to a bowl at 10 p.m. Plant care: buy a hardy snake plant. Basil needs attention like a poet. You need something that thrives on neglect until you don’t. Ask one mentor at the firm to tell you the ‘real rule’ about email response times. There is always a real rule. Follow that, not the panic.” Crow’s beak does a shape that might be a smile if beaks could. “Editorial note,” he writes, “The snake plant does not judge you for anything except overwatering and hubris.” They switch sides around a jagged outcrop Sisyphus has named Reginald because it pokes him in the same place every day and keeps apologizing for it in his imagination. The wind, glad to be useful, takes a letter out of the bag, reads it, and returns it out of sheer curiosity. “Difficult people,” Crow says, tapping his talon against the parchment. “From ‘Office Phoebe.’ It’s quite juicy.” “Read,” says Sisyphus, and ducking under a low cloud, he does. “‘Dear Sisyphus, There is a man in my office who weaponizes muffins. He buys them for the team, then loudly mentions who did not say thank you. He documents perceived slights in a spreadsheet. He is also my project lead for the next quarter. How do I survive without becoming the sort of person who stares at muffins and sees war? — Office Phoebe.’” “The muffin tyrant,” Sisyphus muses. He adjusts his grip as the boulder flirts with a shale slip. “Dear Phoebe, Recognize you are not dealing with muffins. You are dealing with a person whose currency is gratitude measured, not gratitude felt. You cannot pay enough. You can, however, change the economy. Before the next muffin event, send a group email to the team: ‘Hey all, I’d like to start a rotating snack appreciation. I’ve signed up for week two. Please reply with your weeks.’ Put Muffin Man in week one by gently praising his initiative. When it’s his week, say thank you once, sincerely, and move on. When he mentions it again, say ‘We’re doing the appreciation round-up on Fridays now; I’ll add you to the list.’ He will either adapt to the new ritual or be too busy updating his spreadsheet to weaponize it. For the project: ask for expectations in writing. ‘What does success look like? What are the three most important deliverables?’ Keep your own spreadsheet of unfair requests. It won’t protect you from all muffins, but it will protect you from gaslighting. Also, bring your own snack. It’s symbolic.” Crow adds, in the margin: “Editorial note: Raisins are a trap.” A small avalanche of pebbles rattles down. They wait. The boulder waits. Sisyphus scratches behind his ear where a thought has been gathering. “Life purpose,” Crow says softly. “From ‘Twenty-Nine-ish and Itchy.’” Sisyphus breathes, rotates his hands against the stone, and nods. “Read.” “‘Dear Sisyphus, Is there a way to tell if you’re on the right path? Everyone seems to have a calling. I have a job I don’t hate, friends I cherish, hobbies that don’t embarrass me. And yet I keep thinking there’s a grander purpose. How do you know? — Twenty-Nine-ish and Itchy.’” “Dear Itchy,” Sisyphus says, and the mountain quiets in that way mountains do when they want to listen but won’t admit it. “Imagine your life five years from now if nothing ‘grand’ arrives. Could you like that person? Not love, not worship—like. Would you borrow their jacket and forget to return it because it’s comfortable? If the answer is ‘yes,’ you are not lost. If the answer is ‘no,’ don’t hunt a calling like it owes you money. Change one thing you touch every day. The mug you drink from. The walk you take. The person you text first. Purposes often arrive disguised as habits. If you need an experiment: pick one problem you can see from where you stand that bothers you, and spend twelve Thursdays trying to make it better, publicly and badly. You will discover either that the problem is not yours, or that it is, in which case the path will be embarrassingly well-lit.” Crow writes, and in a smaller hand: “Editorial note: This column is a twelve-Thursday project in denial.” They reach the top. The boulder hums with the potential energy of a story that has been told a thousand times and still finds itself surprised by its own ending. Sisyphus puts a hand on it, almost tender, and turns to Crow. “Do we have time for another?” he asks. “For something delicate,” Crow says, fluffing his feathers against a gust that smells like old nectar. “From ‘Three’s Company (Asking For A Friend).’” Sisyphus’s eyebrows, which have seen empires and new haircuts, remain unjudging. “Go on.” “‘Dear Sisyphus, My partner and I are considering inviting a close friend into our bed, just once. We are both excited and terrified of the afterward. We communicate well in general, but neither of us has done this before. Any advice beyond googling? — Three’s Company.’” Sisyphus contemplates the infinite horizon with its endless trick of always being there and never being closer. “Dear Three,” he says. “Yes. Discuss the exit strategy before the entrance. Decide in clear terms how anyone can pause or stop things without drama, and what happens next—tea? A board game? Sleep in separate rooms? People rarely regret the conversation they had; they often regret the one they didn’t. Also, talk now, sober, about jealousy—what does it feel like for each of you? Where does it show up in your body? If someone says, ‘If I get quiet and my shoulders go up, I need a break,’ honor that. Set a time limit you can revise in the moment. Afterward, schedule a debrief when you are not naked. Be kind to future you: make sure tomorrow includes comfort food and no major decisions. And remember this: you can decide after trying it that it’s not for you without declaring your relationship a failure. Some doors you open just to see the light, not to move in.” Crow pauses, quill hovering. “Editorial note,” he writes reluctantly, “Have snacks that are sexy as snacks but not as stains.” They start down again. A goat, who has made career choices, watches them respectfully. The boulder picks up thoughts about speed. Sisyphus leans it this way and that like a dancer wearing an extremely heavy partner. “Here’s one that simply says ‘Help,’” Crow says, and for the first time his voice is less like polished sarcasm and more like a wing folded over an egg. He clears his throat. “‘Dear Sisyphus, I lost my brother last year. People keep telling me to move on. I don’t want to move on. I want him back. The world has the audacity to keep being normal.
