The animal’s eyes were the same dark as before, flat but not dull, like someone had polished the glass inside. It stood as if at a crossroads, the world touched up around it with a careful hand. Mist curled from its nostrils. It looked at them. It looked at JT. The air was warmer, suddenly. He felt it on his face, on the inside of his wrists where the pulse beats. His heart climbed his throat. And then—slick and easy as a soap bubble—the memory of the clearing lifted and floated in front of him, the way his father’s fingers trembled, the way the rifle had hung slack. He felt the same urge to look away. The same sense of shame. And layering under it, this time, was a message—no words, exactly, but the shape of words: you are here. He thought: it knows us. “Don’t,” JT said, not sure who he meant, and the word snapped in the cold like a dry stick. It was enough. Dad blinked. He looked down at his empty hand, suddenly aware of it, and he fumbled for his rifle and brought it up in a motion that was all muscle memory and years. The spell—God, JT thought, he was using that word—was broken. The caribou lifted its head, shook out its breath, and faded back into the gray. They didn’t fire. Nobody spoke. Fog clung to their skin as they backed away, as if reluctant to let them go. The woods took on that underwater feel, sound muted, every color cooled down two shades. When the fog lifted, it did so in a shrug, and they were standing at an angle that didn’t make sense. The path under their boots was the path to the cabin. “Christ,” Mike said, an ordinary word spoken full of fear. “We came around.” Dad stared. His jaw worked. “We didn’t,” he said, though the wooden bench with the names in it crouched in front of them, and beyond that the trail went into the dark-line trees like a throat. He looked down at the ground and the ground looked back at him. “We didn’t,” he said again, and it was a child’s denial, not belief but wanting the wanting to count for something. Nobody suggested turning around. Turning around felt like something the woods wanted. So they went forward. The trail narrowed and the light changed—less of it, more of it, both at once. The trees grew close, branches knitting over their heads with those black claws. The air smelled like cedar and wet iron. JT heard the water first, a flat shushing, and then they were on the cabin’s porch, and when had that happened? The cabin was the same as it had been in the stories and also not—shrunken and soft at the edges, the roof sagging under years of snow, the window on the right broken but the glass in it unfallen, held by cobwebs and frost like a single sheet of sugar. The door was stuck in its frame, crooked. Someone had nailed a horseshoe over the lintel. There were scratches deep around the handle at a height of three feet or so. The kind of marks a dog might make. “Place is dead,” Mike said, but his voice had gone thin. Dad pressed a hand to the door. He didn’t push. He didn’t turn the knob. He splayed his fingers on the weathered boards and closed his eyes. His lips moved. JT leaned in, not meaning to. He felt heat radiate from the wood. He felt an almost-sound, the way you feel thunder when you’re under the bed and your brother is counting. Oh, he thought, blank and white. Oh. “What are you doing?” JT said. It came out harsher than he meant. Dad opened his eyes. Whatever was in them did not dim. He took his hand away like he’d touched a stove. “Nothing.” A creak ran through the cabin. A floorboard? The roof restraining itself? The sound had a shape. It came from below. It came from the idea of the floor more than the floor itself. It said, in the blank language of beams and joists and nail heads: I bear weight. I wait. Mike laughed, quick and high, almost a hiccup. “Hear that?” He cocked his head, listening. “Probably a raccoon. Or something. Ain’t nothing here.” “No raccoons,” JT said, and he didn’t know why, except that the minute the words were out of his mouth he recognized the truth of them like touching a tooth and finding the hollow inside. No raccoons. No birdsong, either. No flies. No silence, not really, because there was a sound like breath being held just beyond the edge of hearing, and it felt old. “Let’s go,” Dad said. He said it like a man remembering his own name, something practiced and plain. “Let’s move on. East. There’s a stand of alder where—” The door knob turned. Just a fraction. The polished circle of metal glinted in the pale winter light. It moved like a heartbeat. It didn’t seem possible. JT felt the movement in the meat at the base of his thumb, a sympathetic twitch. Nobody touched it. Nobody breathed. The door shivered in its frame, a dog shaking off water. JT saw, impossibly, that the scratches around the handle had fresh wood splinters at their edges, pale as bone. He smelled something sweet and low and hill-country: a rot that wasn’t ugly so much as patient. He thought, This is the payoff. The words ran across the surface of his mind like a subtitle on an old movie, and he hated himself. He hated the idea of a shape to this, the tidiness of it. His eyes blurred. When he blinked, the world snapped back to its meaner order. Dad raised the rifle. What he aimed at was unclear. The door? The idea of the door? The self that the door suggested, waiting in there? JT had the thought—fast and mean—that if his father fired into the place it would be like wounding a man in his sleep. He reached out and closed his hand over the barrel and pushed it down. His palm burned. He smelled oil and iron. “Don’t,” he said again, and now it was a plea. The knob held its breath. The woods held theirs. Mike’s grin had broken into pieces that didn’t match. The knob stopped. That was all. No slam. No whisper. The world resumed. Somewhere a crow called, the harsh caw like laughter turned inside out. JT realized how badly he was shaking and made his hands go still. He wondered, crazily, if the cabin had been opening the door not to get them in but to come out—to give them back something. He had a feeling—solid and cold as a coin in the bottom of a bucket—that if he came back alone, the door would be wide, and the warmth inside would make him cry. “We’re leaving,” Dad said. He spoke with the calm of a man who has walked away from the edge once too often to make a fuss about it. He didn’t look back. As they turned away, JT put his hand on the horseshoe without meaning to. It was ice-cold. He felt, for a second, an impression, like the press of a hand against his from the other side of the door. Bigger hand than his. He could have sworn it. “You felt that?” Mike said, almost excited, as if this were a game after all. “No,” JT said. They moved out of the dark of the path and into the thinner light. The fog had burned off. The names on the bench looked smaller. The Scar shone. JT could feel the tug of the day trying to reset itself around them, as if smoothing the wrinkles. The lodge was a shape he could hold in his head, the kitchen’s lantern playing its jittery light over the walls. The rifles would go back into their canvas, their smell of oil and satisfactions long ago. The woods would lean back. He kept looking over his shoulder even when he told himself not to. The look didn’t help. The feeling hung on him like a damp shirt: something had moved toward them. Not the deer. Not exactly the cabin. An arrangement. A possibility. The words someone else had put in his mouth. He didn’t tell them. He swallowed it. Safer that way. “You okay?” Dad asked once, without looking. “Yeah,” JT said. “Good,” Dad said. And then the crow called again, far off, and JT counted the beats between calls, and every number sounded like a name he didn’t know yet. The woods breathed in. The woods breathed out. They kept moving because stopping was worse. Because you never stand still for long in places that remember. Because you keep to your own perspective if you want to make it to
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This continuation of the surreal horror story demonstrates remarkable craft in maintaining the established atmosphere while deepening the psychological tension. The piece successfully captures the Stephen King-esque blend of grounded realism with unsettling surrealism, creating a pervasive sense of dread that builds organically throughout. The prose excels at establishing a distinct voice—terse, observant, and tinged with rural cadence. Descriptions are sensory-rich without becoming overwrought: "The lodge's kitchen smelled of bleach and venison and damp wool. The socks were steaming like little ghosts." These details ground the reader in a tangible reality while simultaneously suggesting something uncanny. The character development is particularly strong. JT's unreliable narration is handled with subtlety—we experience his uncertainty about what's real without the author resorting to heavy-handed signaling. His relationship with his father and brother feels authentic, with their dynamics revealed through small gestures and sparse dialogue rather than exposition. The family's strained interactions and JT's outsider status are conveyed through what remains unsaid. The dialogue is sparse but effective, revealing character through distinctive speech patterns. Dad's terse commands ("Put your head on straight and stay with us") and Mike's needling ("You were fiddlin' with your shoelace like a Sunday school boy") efficiently establish their personalities and the family dynamic. The piece masterfully builds tension through a series of escalating encounters with the supernatural. The progression from subtle wrongness to overt manifestation is handled with restraint. The cabin sequence represents an effective payoff to the building dread, with the turning doorknob creating a moment of genuine horror without resorting to explicit violence or gore. The writing demonstrates sophisticated control of pacing. Longer, more lyrical passages describing the environment alternate with terse, immediate scenes of action. This rhythm creates a hypnotic effect that mirrors JT's increasingly disoriented state of mind. The imagery is consistently strong and often unexpected: "The fog had burned off. The names on the bench looked smaller." Such observations carry psychological weight beyond their literal meaning. The piece also effectively employs repetition and callbacks to earlier motifs, creating a cohesive whole. One of the story's greatest strengths is its ambiguity. The supernatural elements remain undefined, allowing readers to project their own fears into the narrative gaps. The story respects the reader's intelligence by not over-explaining its mysteries. The ending is particularly effective—abrupt yet satisfying, suggesting continuation while leaving us with a powerful image. The incomplete final sentence ("Because you keep to your own perspective if you want to make it to") creates a brilliant moment of narrative disruption that mirrors the story's themes of interrupted reality. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Occasionally the prose becomes slightly too self-conscious in its literary effects. A few metaphors, while evocative, call attention to themselves: "The air smelled like cedar and wet iron." However, these moments are rare and don't significantly detract from the overall impact. In summary, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece of horror fiction that succeeds on multiple levels—as atmospheric prose, as character study, and as an exploration of psychological dread. It demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of the genre while maintaining its own distinctive voice. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fantasy-humour: Hell is Other Demons — Score: 90.0
Prompt:
Hell is Other Demons Write a day in the life short story. Lucifer morningstar's on again/ off again relationship with Lilith is currently in the "off again" stage, though the cycle may be coming around as Lilith has been stopping by for reasons other than purely violent ones, and Lucifer has been increasingly lonely. Write a day in the life of this power couple, with elements of dark comedy & fantasy. Use understated irony & absurdity by merging the black immorality and everyday business of running hell, against relatable domestic relationship drama. Take cues from Neil Gaiman. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Morning in Pandemonium arrives not with sunlight but with the sound of a thousand damned souls hitting their daily quota of lamentation. The lamentation clock is punctual if nothing else. Lucifer wakes to it as one wakes to a trusted alarm: irritated, exhaling smoke, and faintly proud of the punctuality of one’s subordinates. He lies in bed, staring at the cracked basalt ceiling, counting the new fissures branching like lightning, and feeling the familiar itch of decision. He turns on his side. The other side of the bed is empty. In his dreams, she had visited. Not in violence; Lilith never wastes energy that early in the day. She had arrived with a mug and said, “You’re brooding,” and he had said, “It’s the décor.” Now, awake, he notices the faint smell of burnt cardamom and realizes it wasn’t a dream. She had stood there, once again, as if checking the weather, and then gone again. He sits up, snaps his fingers to conjure black coffee, and gets a disappointed little cackle from the air as a reminder that the Imp in charge of Beverage Services has unionized. He settles for what manifests: bitter sludge in a chipped mug that says World’s Best Sovereign, the Best crossed out with a sulfur-stained claw. It’s deeply unfunny and therefore the office favorite. Cerberus—Lucy keeps calling him Cerb in moments of undeserved affection, though the Hellhound answers to various household utensils thrown his way—has gnawed the iron throne’s left leg down to a resentful stump. Cerb is industriously chewing, eyes half-closed, in the smug trance of a creature doing exactly the one thing you wish it wouldn’t. Lucifer watches the metal filings scatter like gray snow. “Of all the legs,” Lucifer says. “Literally infinite legs to choose from.” Cerb pauses, snorts a puff of steam, and digs his teeth back in. Melted iron dribbles out the sides of his jaws. He wags his tail; it thumps against a fresh pile of repentance paperwork. A demon clerk shrieks from the doorway and flees. “Good boy,” Lucifer tells the dog, picturing Lilith’s arched eyebrow, her particular look that says: You never gave me the throne. He puts the mug down on a human skull that complains under the heat. The skull will warm to him by lunch. His morning is meetings. First, the Department of Unrepentant Tyrants wants a new motivational strategy. Attendance has been low in the screaming pits; the tyrants have been noting that the screams of others are insufficiently personalized. Lucifer gestures at a prepared slide deck that shows a bell curve of despair. “You see this tail,” he says. A demon raises a hand and eats it, embarrassed. “Sorry, reflex.” “Right. The tail. We need individualized screaming. Think artisanal anguish. Use their unresolved mother issues. We all have them.” He flicks the remote. The second slide is a pie chart titled Pie and Pain. It has no pies, only pain. He thinks Lilith would have made a better joke about it, something with flakier crust. After, he receives a courier imp bearing a note from God, the neat handwriting brisk and mildly amused. It says: Hope you’re having a pleasant eternity. P.S. We are discontinuing one of the older plagues due to supply chain problems. Sorry for any inconvenience re: locusts. Lucifer reads it twice, then flips it over. On the back, there’s a doodle of a sun with a smile. He folds the note carefully and slips it into the drawer with her letters, which is unfair to both of them and he knows it. At ten, the damned poets gather to read their latest draft of forever. He walks the aisles, listening, adjusting the heat under the seats, offering faint praise like drizzle. It would be easier if he could be cruel or kind without thinking of how Lilith prefers silence at readings, how she’d touch his elbow and steer him toward the exit long before the sonnets began anthropomorphizing the stalactites. He smiles at a metaphor about bones being white flags. He suggests fewer adverbs. He eats lunch with the foreman of the Nine and a minor archdemon who thinks the moral arc of the universe is bent toward better PR. He signs requisitions for more pitchforks, though he long ago banned pitchforks in favor of more ergonomic instruments. Everyone wants something today. He wants the dog to stop chewing. He does not say this aloud because he is the Prince of Lies and it seems gauche to admit to small truths. Lilith arrives at two and a half past two. She has the courtesy of big entrances but the kindness to minimize the smoke. The floor curls under her feet in a polite bow. The hellhound looks up, squeals, and rolls onto his back, revealing a belly that is a topography of scars and unrepented sins. She scratches the dog under all three chins. “Oh, don’t encourage him,” Lucifer says, standing, as if he hasn’t been sitting all morning waiting for a reason to stand. “He thinks he is a hammer.” “He thinks he is loved,” she says without looking at Lucifer, which is the kind of remark he will replay over centuries. She has cut her hair since he last saw her. It has the kind of sharpness that seems fatal. Her dress could be described as black, but only if one had never seen a void. Lilith does not smile unless it benefits her. She smiles. “I was in the neighborhood,” she says. “Thought I’d steal something.” “Take the throne,” Lucifer says, and gestures. “There’s less of it than usual. He’s been… improving it.” She looks at the gnawed leg, the drool trails, the melancholy puddle of iron filings. She looks at him. The unasked question sits between them momentarily, a guest who knows their name is unwelcome but stays anyway. She sits on the arm, the way she always has, the position that says: I never wanted this seat, I wanted you to offer it. He doesn’t, and hasn’t, and that’s why they are them. “I heard a rumor,” she says, pulling a small dagger from somewhere impossible and picking something from her nail. “That the martyrs have started a choir. You hate choirs.” “I dislike parallel harmonies,” he says. “They encourage consensus.” “And yet,” she says, “you bought them sheet music.” He supposes she saw the requisition on his desk. He supposes he wanted her to. He says, “What do you want, Lilith?” She tilts her head as if considering whether the question is edible. “Something trivial. A favor so small it is almost offensive to ask. I require a room.” “Our rooms are occupied,” he says. “By sins and memories.” “A modern room,” she says. “White walls, an absence of skulls. A bed you haven’t bled in. A lock that does not respond to your name.” “Impossible,” he says, immediately wanting to make it possible. She shrugs. Her shrug is an empire toppling. She leans to scratch Cerb again; the hellhound moans in something like ecstasy and chews harder, perhaps to impress her. The throne creaks. “You could ask God,” he says, nodding toward the drawer that holds a neat note and eight messy ones. “God gives what God wants to give,” she says. “You give what you want to take away.” “That is slander,” he says, mildly. “I know,” she says, and smiles without humor. “That’s why it’s fun.” He takes her to the room he thinks might work. It is not modern but it is empty. It is the room where he has once, twice, sat in the dark, for theatrics. She walks its perimeter, trailing a finger along the walls, leaving a seam of black flowers blossoming behind her touch. They open and close with little gasps. He pretends not to notice. “This will do,” she says. “For an afternoon.” “For an afternoon,” he repeats, like a poorly trained parrot who happens to have ruled for eons. They stand there, the two of them, with an empty bed and a dog elsewhere gnawing a kingdom. If he speaks he will ruin it. If he stays silent he will also ruin it. He chooses a middle route, which is unlike him, and says, “I had thought perhaps we had moved past afternoons.” She considers. It is more consideration than the damned get in a lifetime. “We always move past afternoons,” she says softly. “We return in the evenings.” He wants to laugh. He doesn’t. She steps past him and goes. He follows. At the door she turns, and there it is: the smile that unthreads him into strands like old rope. “Your dog,” she says. “He will bring the throne down, you know.” “It was going to fall anyway,” he says. “Everything does, given enough time.” “Time is cheap here,” she says. “Spend something else.” He wants to ask what. He wants to say his name. He settles for: “Stay for the choir.” “I don’t like choirs,” she says. “They encourage righteousness.” “They’re dreadful,” he says. “Then perhaps,” she says, “I will.” The martyrs sing at dusk as the sky performs its nightly trick of not being there. Lilith stands beside him with her hands in her sleeves, an affectation he knows she adopted because he once told her it made her look like she had something to hide. The choir is as bad as anticipated: too earnest, too many unused notes. He adjusts the heat under their feet just enough to make them lift their chins in forced ecstasy. It helps. “I remember,” she says, “when you used to fix things.” “I have never fixed anything,” he says. “I rearrange problems.” “And yet you color-code them,” she murmurs. He glances at her hand. It is not in his. He puts his there, near it, as if warming his fingers. She doesn’t move away. Cerb ambles in, dragging a leg of throne behind him, tongue lolling. He deposits the twisted metal at their feet, proud, and looks between them with the eager guilt of a child who has broken something irreparable and wants praise. “You are a menace,” Lucifer tells him. The dog’s tail thumps feverishly, like a heart that has been misfiled. “The throne was ugly,” Lilith says. “Sit on something else.” He looks at the twisted iron. He imagines it as a chair. He imagines not imagining. After the choir, she stays long enough for a drink. They sit at his desk because the throne is compromised and because she never did like sitting below him. He pours from a decanter that refills only when someone is lying; it is always full. They drink until the glasses are empty of meaning. They talk about the business: the day’s quotas, the new demon who keeps bringing in sea glass because he thinks it is souls, the letter from Above without a return address. They do not talk about the last time they shouted. They do not talk about the time before that when neither of them said anything at all. “Do you ever consider retiring?” she asks, which is like asking a stone if it considers becoming air. “Often,” he says. “Between sentences.” “To what?” “A small island,” he says. “No weather. No people. A dog who does not chew.” “He would chew the island,” she says. “He would swallow entire beaches and wag.” “So he would,” he says. “And you? Would you visit?” “I hate islands,” she says. “They turn and turn and call it horizon.” He nods like he is hearing a new language. He is, a little. When she leaves, she does it without drama. She goes, and the room she occupied looks smaller, as if it has exhaled. He stands at the doorway and watches the absence like it is a fire. He resists the urge to call her name. Instead he says, “Heel,” to the dog, who has never learned, and the dog thinks about it, and then, for once, obeys. Night in Pandemonium is a suggestion rather than a fact. The damned dim themselves. The lava flows hum lullabies learned from geology. Lucifer walks the galleries alone, pausing to nudge a torment, to correct a metaphor, to put out a small fire with his foot and set another one elsewhere. He returns to his room. He sits on the throne anyway because some collapses are slow. He feels the bite-marked leg give slightly under his weight and smiles a little at its treachery. On the arm of the throne is a small mark—a crescent of pressure left by fingers that could have broken worlds and instead became punctuation. He rests his hand over it. He feels ridiculous, and so he rests it there longer. From somewhere below, the choir finds a harmony that works because it is resolved. He closes his eyes and tries to memorize the exact shape of this particular failure. Hell is other demons, he thinks, and dogs and women and old furniture and the mail. He drinks, lets the glass hang, and waits for morning to arrive with its thousand-throated alarm. Cerb settles at his feet, the twisted metal between his paws, and gnaws it tenderly like a bone. Lucifer looks down at him. “Fine,” he says. “Chew it all.” Cerb’s tail thumps. “If it falls,” Lucifer adds, “we’ll sit on the floor.” The dog looks up, iron in his teeth, and Lucifer can hear Lilith’s laugh in the way the sound echoes: across stone, against history, with the understanding that laughter is just another kind of surrender you practice until it looks like control. He lifts his glass toward the empty doorway and toasts whatever comes back through it tomorrow. Then he drinks, and Hell, which runs on schedules and spite, keeps running.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of Neil Gaiman's style with its blend of the mundane and the mythical, creating a darkly comedic portrayal of Lucifer and Lilith's complex relationship against the backdrop of Hell's bureaucracy. The writing demonstrates exceptional command of tone, balancing cosmic power with relatable relationship dynamics. Lucifer is portrayed as both the ruler of Hell and someone experiencing loneliness and relationship complications. The characterization is nuanced - Lucifer's external power contrasts with his internal vulnerability regarding Lilith, while Lilith maintains an enigmatic presence with clear agency. The prose is elegant and economical, with striking imagery that brings Hell to life: "Morning in Pandemonium arrives not with sunlight but with the sound of a thousand damned souls hitting their daily quota of lamentation." The writer skillfully employs metaphor and simile throughout, such as "Her shrug is an empire toppling" and "The dog's tail thumps feverishly, like a heart that has been misfiled." The dialogue is particularly strong, revealing character through subtext rather than exposition. Lines like "God gives what God wants to give," she says. "You give what you want to take away" efficiently convey the complex power dynamics and history between characters. The narrative incorporates absurdist elements effectively - the unionized Imp in charge of Beverage Services, the hellhound chewing the throne, the martyrs' choir - all serving the story's themes rather than existing merely for comedic effect. These elements create the requested irony by juxtaposing the cosmic with the mundane. The story maintains coherence while allowing for a somewhat episodic structure that follows Lucifer through his day. The pacing is well-managed, with the relationship drama unfolding naturally amid Hell's daily operations. The ending avoids both saccharine resolution and nihilistic despair, instead offering a moment of acceptance that feels earned given the characters' established dynamics. Some minor critiques: A few metaphors, while striking, occasionally border on being slightly overwrought. The narrative sometimes lingers in Lucifer's introspection when the action might have been pushed forward. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece. The story successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements, merging the business of running Hell with relationship drama, incorporating dark comedy and fantasy elements, and capturing Neil Gaiman's style of understated irony and absurdity. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 93.8
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
It was the hour when the sun slanted across the training yard and made the dust glow like beaten gold. The iron gate that opened to the street stayed barred, a lattice of shadow flung across the sand. The day’s heat had soaked into the wooden palisades and the stone walls of the ludus; even the air smelled of warm rope, oil, and men. Someone was mending a strap with a bone needle, and the sharp scent of new leather cut through the stink of sweat and old blood like a clean blade. I had come from the sharpening bench with filings glittering against my fingertips. They were not from my sword. I was a retiarius; the net was my weapon, and the trident my reach. What I sharpened was a hook, one of the small iron teeth threaded along the rope backing of the net, meant to catch against the greave or shield of the man opposite me. The hook was old, dark where the iron had pitted. The Romans called us fishers. I never minded. I liked the feeling that the sea had its place in me, that some salt remained. When the others—Thracian, Secutor, Sarmatian—boasted about swords and shields, I thought of water and rope. All the while, the city breathed beyond the wall. I could hear it, the groan of carts over paving stones on the Vicus Tuscus, the mule bells, the cry of the fishmongers, the quarrel of a couple in some close courtyard. Every gust that slipped over the top of the wall brought the smell of Rome: ash, human, ferment. Somewhere not far away someone was burning olive wood. It smelled better than the sweat around me. “Marcus,” Celsus called from the shade of the awning, lazy as only a big man could be at rest. He was polishing the smooth-domed helm of the secutor with a rag, bringing up the shine like he was rubbing a bronze mirror. He was not called Celsus for his height; it was a joke from when he first came and could barely lift his shield. Romans liked their jokes. “Hand me the oil.” I tossed him the bulbous clay flask. Oil slopped down his wrist. Every skin in the yard was slick with it, the sheen of men who could not be allowed to crack. The lanista said oil was wine for the body. The lanista said a lot of things in a tone like he was lecturing senators, even if he smelled like the amphorae stacked behind the kitchen. I sat with my back to the wall, where it was hot as a hearth. I spread the net across my knees, feeling for the weak strands and the places where the weave wanted to give. It had been mended many times. Each knot was a bead in a rosary that I had the fingering of. I had learned the pattern from the old Gaul who trained me; he made me cast it a hundred times a day until my shoulder burned and my thumb had a ridge in it from the rope. “You must feel the way the air takes it,” he told me. “The air has fingers too.” He had died in the winter, not with a sword in his gut but with a fever in his breath. The funerary rites were simple—no blazing pyre, not for men like us—but the lanista let us pour a libation. I poured mine to Hermes. He is my god, if any is. I imagine him as quick and lean, his feet clever, his eyes sly. I talked to him under my breath while I cast the net in training, while the others muttered to Mars or to Neptune or to the nameless gods of their fathers. Hermes is a god of crossroads and thieves, of merchants and messengers. If he could carry the souls of men into the dark, he could carry a prayer, whispered through the bars of the ludus gate and caught in the city’s breath. Hermes had many names and stories. The one I favored was the time he stole Apollo’s cattle and lied so well even the truth sounded like a song. That was a man after whose fashion I could shape my mind: not pure, but clever enough to live. “Look,” Celsus said then, not to me but to the yard. He had the helm in his hands and he held it away from him, admiring the way it took the sun. He could see himself in it, in that warped way polished things show you. A reflection that was you but also a stranger. That was Rome as well. The lanista came through the door that led to his rooms. He walked like a man who had never worked steel, his belly ahead of him and his hands clean but for ink. The God of Merchants had blessed him well. He clapped his hands for our attention, as if we were girls in a school instead of men whose backs were mapped with scars. “We will have visitors,” he said, his F’s and V’s slicing together in his rough provincial Latin. “Not senators,” he added, and there was laughter, though not much. “Better than senators. The people.” That made the laughter louder. The people mattered more than any senator. The bread for our bellies, the names shouted in the afternoon sun, the thumbs that slid sideways or up or down. The emperor was a rumor, a profile stamped on coins that sometimes passed through the hands of boys who ran in barefoot, shouting, to watch us on non-training days. The people were our weather. Their mood was a pressure we could feel in our bones like a storm. This summer they had been hungry, and the faces in the stands had been sharp, their eyes like knives. No one cut a rope with a kind look. “Visitors from the Subura,” the lanista said. “They come as part of the grain distribution. A favor to my brother-in-law. They will tour the yard, and we will not smell like goats. Marcus, cast the net. Celsus, keep your helmet on, look like a soldier, for the love of Jupiter Optimus Maximus. Publius—where’s Publius? There—stop picking your teeth.” There was a bustle and a cursing that sounded like home. I stood. My knee had a twinge in it, a little twinge that liked to speak when the weather changed or when a rain was coming. It had spoken this morning while I knelt near the gutter a slave-girl had poured grey water down, and she had looked at me quick and pitying, as if a man’s joints were something to be sorry for. Pity sits on the skin like a damp cloth. I shrugged it off and picked up the net. If a man had put me in a field, I would have set the net for thrushes, the way my father did in a different land, with little loops and twigs. The net I swung now had an edge of lead weights sewn to it. It felt like a shirt soaked in river water. I loved it anyway. When I cast it right, it made a shadow on the sand like a star. They came in under the awning, sweating already, the women with their hair knotted and scarves draped over them against the sun, the men with their tunics streaked with flour dust, the children like small copper coins pulled warm from the coals. They smelled of yeast and frying oil, of streets and brine. The steward with them had a bored face and a tally stick. The lanista smiled in a way that must have cost him. There was always the first look. It went one of two ways: disgust, as if we were animals, or awe, like we were commanders parading down the Via Sacra. I did not expect either. What I saw mostly were eyes that had seen enough ugliness that the sight of ours did not unsettle them. A woman with a baby on her hip, his mouth slick with milk, watched me cast the net. She did not blink. The boy next to her grinned like he might bite the rope. The old man behind them spat neatly to one side and said, “Retiarius. Like the fishermen at the Tiber. My brother was one. Dead now. The river takes everything.” Hermes has a little reed boat in some myths, ferrying souls across as if he were Charon’s apprentice. I thought of that and of the rope in my hands. I thought of the way a net looks when it catches sunlight under water, an idea I had kept from a childhood on a coast that was not Italian and which sometimes rose up in my dreams smelling of kelp and the kind of wind that cleans you. “You must be brave,” the woman said. She said it as if she were tasting the word. I shrugged. Brave was a word that men with full bellies liked to use. “I am paid,” I said. “And I prefer the sand to some choices.” “What choices?” she pressed, not unkindly. The baby hiccuped against her shoulder. “To be a laborer,” I said. “To go home.” There was a hiss in the yard, a small one, as if someone sucked a hurt tooth. Going home was the thing we did not name except when we were too drunk to be careful. Some of us did not have a home. Some had one that would not take them back. Some could have gone and did not: Celsus, for instance, who had a wife who had married in the meantime and two boys who were no longer boys. “You eat?” the old man asked shrewdly. “You take cold baths? You have a roof? Then you are fortunate. The warehouses burned last week. The grain spoiled. The city complains like a woman in labor and then laughs with blood on its lips.” “Old man,” the steward said, his tally stick tapping, “save your poetry. The proprietor has given you the magnificence of a tour.” “Save your counting,” the old man said back, and they glared with familiarity. The people do not much fear stewards. The lanista, who could smell the way a crowd might turn like a dog, clapped again. “Publius! Show them the wooden swords. Explain the honor.” So we did the motions. Publius, who was learning to speak without his provincial burr, held up the rudis and told them how a man who pleased a crowd and master might get that simple stick and his freedom along with it. He did not look at me. There were whispers, as there always were when the rudis was mentioned. The children’s eyes went soft the way eyes do when they are watching a story light itself in their heads. I cast the net again. It whispered as it opened, a sound like silk being shaken out. The weights made a soft clatter on the sand. I imagined Hermes’s hands in mine, swift and deft. I imagined him telling me a lie that felt like it could hold. Celsus took a step into the yard with his helmet on, his paired short sword in his hand. He made a poised profile, the clean line of his jaw under the bronze. He let the children touch the smooth curve of the helm. It was like letting them touch a monster. One of the boys squealed when he saw his own bent reflection. Celsus, who had the softest heart of any man I ever knew, lifted the helm and put it on the boy’s head for a breath. The boy staggered under the weight and grinned with triumph, a gladiator for a heartbeat with a crust of bread in his other fist. “Is it true,” the woman said to me, “that the emperor comes sometimes and shouts and turns his thumb?” “He watches,” I said. “He shouts if he wants to be seen. The thumb belongs to the people more than to him.” “Does he bleed?” the old man asked, sly again. “Everyone bleeds in the end,” I said, and Hermes smiled on my tongue for that one. When they left, the yard felt emptier than before, as if the breath of those dozen people had made the place warmer and their absence let in a draught. The lanista went back to his small coin-counting. The steward took his tally. The men returned to their gestures: step, thrust, recover; twist, feint, roll. Celsus took off the helmet and rubbed at his head where the padding had pressed. His hair was wet with sweat, short as a slave’s. “You have fans,” he said to me. He meant the woman and the boy, the old man. We all had fans, even the worst of us. There was a girl who came on days when I trained and sat with her chin on her hands and smiled a little. She had a rip in the hem of her dress. She had one grey eye and one brown. “They have bread,” I said. “Not for long,” he said, and because we were something like Roman now, we laughed and spat to the side. We were also something like other things—like the deer that hears the dogs too far off to run yet, like the man who reads his own name cut into a tablet and cannot decide whether it is an honor or a trap. We were men who held their breath between a shout and the answering roar. At the bath later, when the oil was scraped from our skin with strigils and the little curls of filth fell onto the stone in pleasing, disgusting crescents, I lay back on the bench and let the heat torment me. The smell of oil was sweet now it was not clotted with dirt. Steam made the air thick. The tiled ceiling above me had tiny, smooth-eyed dolphins worked into it, the tiles blue and green like the sea under a bright sky. Hermes did not belong in a bathhouse. He belonged at the threshold, in the doorway, in the space between. That was where I liked to meet him. When I had time in the evening and the gate’s shadow lengthened, I would stand with my hand on the iron and feel the paint flaking under my palm. Tiber smell would come if the wind turned. Once, not long ago, a funeral procession had gone past, the pipes keening, the men on their shoulders bearing a board with a pale face upon it. I had watched them go. The face had not been anyone I knew. That did not matter. The dead man had gone to Hermes for a few steps and then to the ferryman. Celsus cracked a joke in the steam that made the younger men hoot. Publius flicked oil at him and his grin went sideways. For a while we were only men in a room too hot to last in. The politics of the city were an animal we could hear scrabbling on the other side of the door: the price of grain, the rumor about the emperor’s trip to the provinces, the news that a senator had been accused of treason because he did not clap hard enough at a games. But here we were only breath and skin and edge-weariness, trying not to think of days that would come, that had been promised to the crowd like a list of offerings. When I returned to my place under the wall, the sun was lower, and the dust no longer turned to gold but to something like old parchment. A servant brought a platter of beans and onions, coarse bread, a handful of olives salty enough to make my mouth water. I ate fast and careful. Hunger is a god too, and a jealous one. I took the net into my lap again, though my fingers were tired. The knots were small worlds my fingertips knew better than my eyes did. I spoke to Hermes without moving my lips. I did not ask for anything that would displease the gods of the place. I did not ask for victory. I asked for my hand to remember the motion when the time came, for my mind to be calm, for the people’s eyes to be in a mood to see a man do something well and value it. I asked also for a little mercy for the small boy with the helmet on his head and bread in his fist, though that was not within Hermes’s usual purview. But gods like to be surprised. That is what I told myself. There are days that stick to memory like burrs. This was not one of them. This was only the day a woman with a child watched me throw a net, and the old man with the river on his breath made a joke about emperors, and Celsus looked handsome under a helmet that was made to make other men blind. It was the day the lanista said the people mattered and meant it because the grain was late. It was the day the boy’s reflection in the helmet was a bent thing and he laughed anyway, and I loved him for it and feared for him too, and I held my net like a man holds a rope tied to something that will pull him one way or the other and all he can do is put his weight where he wants it to go. It was an ordinary day in a city that is too many times itself, and I sat under a wall and thought of a god with winged sandals stealing cattle and laughed because I was alive. I had to be careful with days like that. They could trick you into belief. They could make you think the story would end with a wooden sword and applause. If Hermes stood at my shoulder, his breath smelled like fennel and the road. He is a god; he is also the tale you tell yourself so that the dust feels like gold even when it is not. At dusk the city hummed like a plucked string, and the iron gate’s shadow lay across my thighs. I spread the net one more time and watched it fall. The weights hit the sand, a soft, sure sound. Somewhere beyond the wall, a crier was shouting the morrow’s events. The people would come. Their voices would rise with the sun. The thumbs would be ready. My hands were clean and dirty, capable and shaking, and I smiled with a little corner of my mouth because I knew what part of the day I loved best: this part, when everything was still in the air, in the span of the cast, before any thing, or any man, was caught.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This historical fiction piece presents a day in the life of a Roman gladiator with remarkable attention to sensory detail and historical authenticity. The author has created a first-person narrative from the perspective of Marcus, a retiarius (net-fighter) gladiator, that feels immersive and psychologically nuanced. The writing excels at sensory immersion. From the opening description of dust glowing "like beaten gold" to the "smell of warm rope, oil, and men," the reader is transported to ancient Rome through carefully chosen details. The author demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of the gladiatorial system, incorporating specific terminology (ludus, lanista, rudis) and accurately depicting different gladiator types (retiarius, secutor). The protagonist's inner life is richly developed. Marcus's relationship with Hermes as his patron deity creates a spiritual dimension that feels authentic to the period while providing insight into his psychology. His memories of coastal origins and his attachment to his net reveal a complex character with a past beyond the arena. The author skillfully balances Marcus's pragmatism ("I am paid") with moments of poetic reflection. The piece effectively incorporates broader social and political issues of Roman society. The grain shortage, the emperor's distant but powerful presence, the class divisions, and the relationship between gladiators and the public are all woven naturally into the narrative. The visiting common people from the Subura and their interactions with the gladiators provide a window into Roman social dynamics. The prose is elegant without becoming overwrought. While occasionally verging on the poetic ("The city breathed beyond the wall"), it maintains a muscular quality appropriate to the narrator. Metaphors are fresh and fitting: "Hunger is a god too, and a jealous one." The author skillfully varies sentence structure and length to create rhythm. The piece succeeds as a "slice of a larger story" by implying a past (Marcus's coastal origins, Celsus's abandoned family) and suggesting a future (upcoming games). The ending is particularly strong, leaving Marcus in a moment of suspended possibility that resonates thematically with his identity as a retiarius, casting his net. There are very few weaknesses. The dialogue is sparse but effective, serving to illuminate character and social dynamics. The narrative occasionally lingers on philosophical reflections that might slow the pace, but these moments contribute to the character's depth and the thematic richness of the piece. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of historical fiction that brings ancient Rome to life through sensory detail, psychological depth, and historical accuracy while exploring universal themes of identity, fate, and the human desire for meaning. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 92.5
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Telegram: 14 March 1927, Isle of Flannan Station From: Malcolm "Cal" MacRae To: Mrs. Isobel MacRae, 12 Shore Lane, Leith Arrived. Fog thick as porridge. Keepers: Murdo old as granite, Sandy all elbows. Bell doesna stop. Tell Wee Annie I saw a puffin. Will write proper. —Cal — Letter: 20 March 1927 Ma, Did ye get my wire? I hope the post boat found the gut. The channel here, between Eilean Mòr and Eilean Beag, they call it the Black Hole with a grin. The swell thunders through and spits white, as if you could boil tea with it. The light sits like a tooth in the gum of the cliff. The men said I’d be sick o’ the spiral stairs afore I loved them, and I am. My thighs burn like a smithy. Murdo keeps a quiet house. He doesna waste words, so when he speaks ye snap to like the dog to the whistle. Sandy is always humming, God knows what, something he says he learned from a Glasgow music hall. I didna know there was a music hall that taught men to hum like they were swallowing flies. My cot is clean, if narrow. There’s a wee draught I canna find. I put my coat at the foot and sleep with my boots by, like ye told me. The lens is a beast of glass. Shines like polished guilt. First night I went out with the lamp-trimmer’s steps and counted them like prayers. I think it is the counting that keeps the mind right. Ye canna get lost in what ye can count. It’s quiet. The fog-horn sounds its soul through you. It doesna ask ye to be brave. It just goes on, like things must. I like that. I hope you and Annie are eating. If the grocer cheats you, tell Mr. Kelly I’ll set the lamp to point at his till. —Cal — Letter: 2 April 1927 Ma, Murdo has hands like gull wings. When he cleans the lens, ye can see your father’s face in it as if he were come back. He says he’ll leave end of summer, if his hip goes. Says I’ll be senior then, if I don’t drown. He laughs when he says it, so perhaps he doesna mean to frighten me. Sandy fell into the gig last week. Only his boots got wet. He cussed like a minister’s prayer turned backward. I didn’t laugh. It’s poor luck to laugh at a fall here. The island remembers. The cliff to the west, the Braeg, stands like a turned shoulder. If ye stand by the rail there’s a notch where ye can see Lewis on a clear day, a smear across the mouth of the world, like you’d laid a thumb on a smear of ink. They call that North Rona, that smear? Murdo says North Rona is lonelier yet. I told him there’s no lonelier place than a bed in a full house when you’re not right. Tell Annie I have a gull I named Minister. He shouts at me. I shout back. It passes the time. I sleep and wake to the same sound. It does something to yer days. I can feel the sun and not see it. My hands have cracked where the oil gets in. I miss your stew. I miss your voice without walls. —Cal — Telegram: 17 April 1927 From: Isobel MacRae To: Flannan Station We are well. Annie has the chicken pox and keeps her fingers away when I smack them. Mr. Kelly sends a crust with his apology. He said he’d cheat no more if your lamp points true. I told him it’s been pointing at his heart for years. Be warm. —Ma — Letter: 1 May 1927 Ma, I laughed at your wire till Sandy told me to shut it. The post boat brings rumour as if it were eggs, easily cracked. They say a German trawler found a drowned herring fleet off St. Kilda. They say there’s a minister there who married his cousin and no one noticed till the babes started to look like each other too precisely. I think other folk’s islands are mirrors you look in to see if ye’ve gone ugly. I’ve learned to hear ships before I see them. They send their hum under the wet. It sets the ladder shivering. Last week, a small cutter came in too quick toward the Black Hole. Murdo sent Sandy to the horn and me to the bell. He didna raise his voice. I pulled till my shoulder burned and my teeth rang. The cutter eased off. I could see a boy, younger than me by a year maybe, his hands white on the wheel. He lifted them to me after and I thought I saw your hands in his, so I waved. Then I went inside and put my head on the table in the kitchen and stayed till Sandy brought me tea. He didna say a word. I take my turn in the log. I write daft things and scrub them after. “Monday: lamp lit, fog horn sounding, gulls belligerent.” “Tuesday: lamp lit, fog horn sounding, the sea invented itself again.” Murdo says, “Keep your head. The weather is all the poetry we’re paid to report.” So I write the numbers and tuck the rest in my sleeve. We had a rat. It ate my biscuit. It was fat with my crumb. Sandy set a trap and caught his own knuckle. He is not great at plans. How is your knee? Does it ache when the wind swings? I can feel your aches now in my own. —Cal — Letter: 12 June 1927 Ma, Sandy took the post boat for a turn about the skerries and didna come back by supper. He had a likely look on him, the sort that thinks the sea is its friend. I kept the lamp and the horn and Murdo paced. He said nothing. He never uses a word till it’s the only one that fits. Clouds gathered, the colour of smashed plums. The lift of waves through the Black Hole went from a growl to a throat tore raw. He came back at midnight with a face like chalk and a rope round his waist cut nearly through. He hadn’t tied it proper to the ring in the rock. He said the boat wanted to go without him. He said the sea was a woman with bad ideas. I told him if the sea was a woman she wouldna have him. The next day he was meek. He scrubbed the oil room till the floor showed its wood again. He said, “I’ve been a fool.” I said, “Aye,” because it’s a kindness to give a man the word he’s asked for. Sometimes I stand on the Braeg and name the waves. This one’s your voice. This one’s the pots. This one’s the rain that came in under the door when Annie was sick that winter, remember? This one is nothing. This one is nothing too. —Cal — Letter: 4 August 1927 Ma, Murdo has a bad cough. I can hear it under the horn. He spits it in the sink like he can send it away that way. He keeps his pipe behind his ear because he cannot keep it lit. He tells me stories like he’s setting the last of the chairs on the table before he locks up. His father was a crofter at Tunga. He says the croft drowned without water when the boys left. I think you know what he means. I tell him about Leith. I tell him about your trick with the bread, how you make a loaf into a feast with one turn of your knife. He asked me where my father is. I told him where he always is: in where the heat is, and gone when there’s work. Annie writes me in pencil. She says her spots are gone. She says a boy at school told her my light is a story they tell to scare babies. She said she slapped him and the teacher slapped her and then the boy ran. I said I’ll send her a bit of glass if Murdo lets me. He says no. The lamp must be whole. So I sent her a feather from Minister instead. He may be missing one, but he looks no worse for it. —Cal — Telegram: 15 September 1927 From: Isobel To: Flannan Station Annie started at the cooper’s. She comes home with sawdust in her hair and a grin; she eats her bread with a pride. I keep your room as you left it, minus your smell. Visit soon? —Ma — Letter: 30 September 1927 Ma, There is no “soon” on this rock. There is only the next turn. But at the end of November, the relief boat comes. Murdo will leave and I will come across to you if the sea allows. I’ll bring my boots and my hands. Will ye make potato scones? I’ve a hunger for them that would shame a pig. Last night something happened I don’t know where to put. A light blinked to the north where there is no light. Three short, three long, three short. It could be anything, a trick, a mild sort of madness, a fisherman with a sense of humour. I answered with my hand-lamp on the gallery. My hand shook. The fog had laid down, pleased with itself. I could see nothing but the suggestion of something. I came in and sat with the ledger open and wrote “three short three long three short.” Murdo read it after and put his finger over it as if he could smudge it out. He said, “You keep your eye on your job. There’s no one out there for us. Our man lives inshore and his name is MacBrayne and he brings our bread.” I nodded. But I keep the feeling that somewhere something looks back sometimes. Maybe it is you. Maybe it is nothing. Maybe it is wishing. —Cal — Letter: 12 November 1927 Ma, The storms came. The horn is raw from it. So am I. Sandy went down at the steps to tie the post boat, and a wave lifted him to his knees like a prayer and then took his breath. He clung like a limpet. After we got him in he lay on the table while the tea boiled, and his lips were blue like roofs. He’s been quieter since. He hums less. He said to me, “D’you ever think, Cal, that you could just... walk? Just keep walking when the bell rings?” I said, “Aye.” Then I said, “No.” Because both are true. There is a ring in the rock at the Black Hole, and there is a ring in your soul. You hold one or the other. The Braeg is white with birds. They leap as one thing when the sea throws itself at the stone. I do not know why watching that makes me cry sometimes. Maybe it’s because they know something I do not, or maybe it’s only that they are together. I dreamt of you last night. You were on the steps washing them, and you looked up at me and said, “You missed a bit.” I woke laughing and the lamp was steady. —Cal — Telegram: 28 November 1927 From: Cal To: Isobel Sea bad. Relief delayed. Tell Annie I mind her. Tell yourself to eat. Will come when it lets me. —Cal — Letter: 19 December 1927 Ma, It didna let me. The boat turned back twice. Murdo sits with his coat on because he says he won’t be caught unready. He tells the same story twice now, and apologises for it, and then tells it again. I’ve started to talk to the lamp. I call it by your name. I say, “Isobel, do not go out.” Sandy hears me and doesna laugh. That is how you know it’s hard here. The gulls have blown east, and the air is so cold it comes in your nose and becomes a nail. At night, the sea speaks in its throat. There was that blink again last Tuesday. 3-1-3 that time. It made no sense, and I made it make none. I wrote “meteor.” I wrote “star.” I wrote “myself.” I do a thing I will not tell you but I write it now because it is only writing. I pull the door open sometimes and stand with my toes just so, at the line where the world says “enough.” I feel it pull. It is not a bad pull. It is like a bed when you’ve not slept, or a woman’s lap when you’ve not been held. It promises nothing. It promises an end of counting. I do not step. I shut the door and polish the brass instead. Murdo says, “Good man.” —Cal — Letter: 6 January 1928 Ma, Murdo took to the bed. He is as light as cloth now. He called me son when he woke at noon. I let him. I have begun to sleep in the day and wake at night because the night needs me and the day can do without me. Sandy asked me if he should send the flag. I said no. The flag means something final. I am not ready to say it. I thought of you when I cooked the porridge and held the pot against my belly for heat the way you do. I put too much salt, and I ate it anyway because it was hot and mine. Your hands made every hot thing right. I didna know it then. You will say you told me so. You did. I was not listening then. I am now. —Cal — Telegram: 9 January 1928 From: Isobel To: Flannan Station You read like a fever. Come home when you can. Even for a day. Bring your boots. I have tattie scones. Your father wrote. He is married in Greenock. No one asked. All right. We are not the asking kind. I am well. I am waiting. —Ma — Letter: 17 January 1928 Ma, Murdo died last night. He went like the wick when you pinch it, with two fingers and a patience. He was heavy again when we lifted him. Sandy cried with his hands covering his mouth like a man in church who doesna want to sing. We wrapped him in his oilskin because it seemed right, and put him in the store where it is cold. The sea stood still all at once at dawn, as if it had shut its eye to rest. His pipe sat on the sill like a small black boat. I wrote his name in the log. I wrote too many words and crossed them. I wrote the right ones after: “Keeper Murdo MacQuarrie deceased of natural causes at 0200. Lamp lit. Horn sounding.” I went to the Braeg and I shouted his name into the Black Hole. The echo threw it back at me and changed it. That is what the world does with a good thing. Sandy asked me if we should show the flag. I said yes. Sometimes the flag is not for endings, but for the boat it brings. —Cal — Telegram: 24 January 1928 From: Northern Lighthouse Board To: Flannan Station Relief vessel pending clement weather. Maintain operation. Record all. Acknowledge. — Note, pencil, torn from a ledger, sent folded into a letter: 1 February 1928 Ma, I have not slept, and when I sleep I walk. I woke with salt on my lips that was not my tears. I heard the blink again, and when I looked, there was a flare to the north, low, then gone. I put the hand-lamp on the gallery and waved it. Nothing came back. My heart beat as if it were trying to make a door in my chest. I thought of the boy at the cutter, his white knuckle. I thought of you with your apron and your hands in dough. I thought of Murdo under his oilskin dreaming nothing. Yesterday, Sandy went to check the moorings. He did not tie the rope. It is a story I am sick of. He is not a man of knots. He is a man of loose things. He went and the wave came and the rope was on the ground as if it were a snake had sloughed the skin of him. I could not see him when I reached the rail. His cap came up, and then it went, and then he was a seal and then not even that. I shouted his name till the horn had no place in me. I brought his cap in and set it on the table by the tin and the knife. Then I lit the lamp because that is the thing we do when a man goes. We make light. And I am making it now. My hands do not know how to do another thing. —Cal — Telegram: 5 February 1928 From: Isobel To: Flannan Station Cal. Hold. I am coming to Port of Ness to wait. Annie with me. We will be there when you land. Do not step. —Ma — Letter: 10 February 1928 Ma, I will not step. I will, but not that way. I did not tell the Board of the light that is not ours. I tell you. It blinked last night and it was wrong. It was a pattern. I listened and it sounded like words in a throat that had never spoken. I could not make them. I do not think it is a man. I think it is the sea learning to talk. That is foolish. Let me be foolish once. I am tired of being a good son at the edge of things. I took the clock down and it kept going. It does not need the wall. It needs no face. The gulls have started to nest in the crannies. I do not scare them. Let them have their small. We all need a thing to sit on in the wind. I will come down the steps when the boat shows. I will carry Murdo to it if they will. I will carry Sandy’s cap only. If there is no boat, I will sit. I will keep the lamp. I will write my name in the book and set the pen down. I will put my hand on the brass and feel the heat that is my own and say your name. That will be enough, for a minute. —Cal — Telegram: 14 February 1928 From: Northern Lighthouse Board To: Flannan Station Relief vessel on station 16 Feb. Prepare remains and log. Maintain operation until relieved. — Letter: 16
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative brilliantly captures the isolation and psychological strain of lighthouse keeping through a series of letters and telegrams between Malcolm "Cal" MacRae and his mother Isobel. The piece excels in creating a distinct Scottish working-class voice for Cal that remains consistent throughout, with dialectal features ("didna," "ye," "yer") that never feel forced or stereotypical. The correspondence effectively reveals a gradually unfolding plot centered around Cal's struggle with isolation, his relationships with fellow keepers Murdo and Sandy, and the mysterious blinking light that appears in the distance. The narrative builds tension as Murdo dies and Sandy is lost to the sea, leaving Cal alone with his increasingly fragile mental state. The prose is remarkably restrained yet poetic, with striking imagery that conveys the harsh beauty of the setting: "The light sits like a tooth in the gum of the cliff" and "The cliff to the west, the Braeg, stands like a turned shoulder." Cal's voice is authentic and distinctive, revealing his character through both what he says and what he chooses not to say to his mother. The letters effectively show Cal's psychological deterioration as he becomes more isolated, with his thoughts turning to the pull of the sea and the temptation to "step" off the edge. The mysterious blinking light adds an element of ambiguity - is it real or a manifestation of Cal's loneliness? This ambiguity enhances the emotional complexity of the piece. The narrative builds to an emotional climax as Cal is left alone, maintaining the lighthouse while awaiting relief. His mother's desperate telegram ("Do not step") reveals her understanding of his mental state and creates powerful emotional resonance. However, the piece lacks a satisfying resolution as it appears to be cut off mid-letter at the end, leaving the reader without closure on Cal's fate. Despite this incomplete ending, the piece demonstrates exceptional craft in its use of the epistolary form, with each letter revealing character and advancing plot while maintaining a distinctive voice. The telegrams provide effective contrast to the letters, their brevity highlighting the emotional weight of what remains unsaid. The narrative skillfully balances external events (the harsh conditions, Murdo's death, Sandy's drowning) with Cal's internal psychological journey. His relationship with his mother is tenderly portrayed through small details - her tattie scones, her hands in dough, the way she makes "a loaf into a feast with one turn of your knife." The piece avoids sentimentality while creating genuine emotional impact, particularly in Cal's matter-of-fact descriptions of tragedy and his growing sense of isolation. The writing is consistently strong, with no weak passages or lapses into cliché. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 3.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
By the time the host leads us to the corner booth, I’ve already flagged three points of entry: the unlatched side door with the push-bar that sticks, the QR menu taped at an angle so you could swap it with a spoofed sticker with a decent color printer and a ruler, and the Wi-Fi network named after the restaurant with “guest” appended and no captive portal. I fold my hands and smile like I’m not automatically mapping attack surfaces. It’s a tic that never quite left, like the way old programmers can’t stop fixing typos in their heads on signage. She slides into the booth and sets her phone face-down; I note the case with a sticker I recognize only because three years of auditing gave me an unnatural familiarity with fandom stickers: an old Jason Chan “Serra Angel,” scuffed at the wing. My heart does a small, embarrassing skip. Not an accident, maybe. Her profile had “board games, hiking, niche fantasy art” in it, which I’d filed under “safe bet,” not expecting us to share a specific love. My own phone, traitorous and heavy, thrums once. I ignore it. “Thanks for picking this place,” she says. “I’ve walked by so many times and never gone in.” “Happy to be your test subject,” I say. My default humor runs dry as a server’s apron. I mentally check myself: lighten up, human up. Vulnerabilities in people are not to be exploited. Past me would have said: that statement suggests risk-averse with FOMO tendencies. Now-me says: she thought of you when she passed by here. We fiddle with the menus. Paper, thank god. Paper is safe in a way JS-laden QR codes aren’t. I order something I’ll forget while I’m eating it because I’m thinking about other things. She orders a cocktail with a ridiculous name, laughs as she says it. The server smiles like he’s heard it a hundred times. The lighting is all Edison bulbs, the music is the kind you can’t hum but you feel it in your teeth. I force myself to focus on her eyes, which are a specific brown that in my head I want to call sepia, as if my internal runtime annotates with quaint variable names. “So,” she starts, “you said you do… security?” “Consulting,” I say. “On the defensive side, mostly.” “‘Mostly,’” she repeats, amused. I hold the pause. No need to confess like a Catholic in a hoodie. It’s part of my story, but it’s not a good icebreaker. “I used to be less choosy about who I helped,” I say. “I like it better now.” She nods, and that might have been the end of it, but then she says, “Oh, like ethical hacking.” She says it without quotes around it in her voice, which is rarer than it should be. “Yeah,” I say. “Like that.” And then, because there is a benevolent god and her name is variance, she leans forward and says, “Tell me you play Magic. The sticker gave you away.” The gravitational pull of a shared hobby is a strong one. I laugh in spite of myself, in spite of the part of me that’s always scanning the room. “I have a binder that is worth more than my car,” I say. “Commander?” she asks. “Mostly,” I say. “I got competitive in college. Now I just like big, silly plays. Dinosaurs swinging for lethal. Thematic nonsense.” Her grin widens like a curtain. “I have a Kaalia deck that is everyone’s least favorite until I promise to only use it once.” “I don’t know if we can be friends,” I say, which, in Magic terms, is flirting. We stack memories like cardboard rectangles. Pre-release stories, a judge call we both remember from a years-ago blog, that time someone proxied a Black Lotus with a post-it that read “$$$.” She talks with her hands, touchtyping air as she describes a combo that whiffed because of a single overlooked sideboard card. I mention that I once brute-forced the shuffle of an opponent’s sloppy pile, and she laughs like she knows I’m only half kidding. The server drops drinks. She reaches for her phone, and I catch a flash of lockscreen before she flips it. It’s an image of a cat perched on a mountain of basic lands like a furry dragon. Tabby, silvery, smug. The name “Mr. Whiskers” pops into my head unbidden, and I chide my pattern-matching. People name cats anything. But then she says, “Sorry, I’m waiting on my cat-sitter. Opal is a drama queen.” Opal. Gemstone names. Security questions close to the surface of casual conversation. Mental note: don’t be that guy. Put down the red flags. Let them be decorative. We talk about the microculture of LGSs we’ve both frequented. She mentions one in a college town I know too well. “I did my undergrad there,” she says. “OSU. Go Beavers.” She fake-pumps a fist. Birth year is almost on the table in the way she tells the story about being a freshman when Innistrad came out. She mentions her first commander, her roommate’s name, the fact that she hates cilantro, and I can feel the map of her secret questions being auto-filled in some dark browser I keep closed. Mother’s maiden name is a coin toss; favorite teacher is now a probability distribution. “Sorry,” I say, real and reflex. She looks confused. “What for?” “It’s just—I have this bad habit of… cataloging,” I say. “Occupational hazard.” Her mouth quirks. “Of the human variety?” “Both,” I say. “Systems. People. Doors with bad locks.” She glances toward the front, then back at me, amused. “Is that door a bad lock?” I open my mouth to make a joke about load-bearing code and load-bearing hinges, but then her phone lights up again. She picks it up, thumbs the screen, and because I am who I am and my eyes are traitors, I catch the gesture: up-right-right, down-left-down. A shape like a lightning bolt on a 3x3 grid. The smudge wear makes it worse—a faint, oily highlight on the most used dots. I clamp my teeth together. The taste in my mouth is copper and restraint. “It’s the sitter,” she says, glancing at the message. “Opal made a sound like a small child being murdered because the vacuum existed within fifty feet of her. Drama queen.” “It’s a common pattern,” I hear myself say, before my better judgment chokes me. “Ours. Humans. The pattern. It’s like… lightning bolt. Very memorizable. Very guessable.” She freezes, thumb hovering. “Is that—” “I’m sorry,” I say, steamroll apology. “Occupational hazard. I didn’t mean to—” “You saw my passcode,” she says, not quite accusing, not quite joking. “I saw your movement,” I say, because I can’t lie about these things. “I didn’t mean to. It’s… it’s my whole thing. I’m trying not to turn it on people in… normal settings.” There is a sound in my ears like a server room. She blinks, then lowers the phone, face unreadable under Edison light. “So you, what, constantly judge people’s passwords?” she asks. “Just walking around tut-tutting at unlock patterns?” “Not judge,” I say, which is true and not. “Observe. And sometimes nudge. Mostly when I’m paid to. Or asked.” “I didn’t ask.” “No,” I say. “You didn’t. I’m sorry.” Silence. Her shoulders square like the first move in a game, a draw step. She puts the phone away, flips it face-down again, as if that closes a loop. “That’s… intense,” she says after a beat. But there’s something soft at the edges. She is thinking. I think I have not fully torched the place yet. “I promise I didn’t memorize it,” I say. Lie-adjacent. My brain is a flypaper. “I don’t want to know anything you don’t want me to.” She looks at me for a long second, like she’s reading a card with too many lines of text. “Is it really that bad?” she asks, and now the curiosity slips through. Nerd recognizes nerd. “Yes,” I say, because if I’m going to commit to salvage, I have to commit to honesty. “Android pattern unlock is vulnerable in a few predictable ways. People start in corners, avoid crossing lines, favor certain shapes. The oil smear on the glass telegraphs the path. Tilt it under light, the trail is right there. And even if the smear’s not obvious, shoulder surfing is easier with directional swipes than with six digits. It’s… low-hanging fruit.” I hold back the urge to explain entropy and Markov chains and how you can get most people in under ten tries. This is not a lecture hall.
