She chews her lip. “What should I do instead?” Something in my chest loosens with the click of a lock. “Six-digit PIN, minimum. Better with more. Or a sentence for a password if your phone allows. And don’t use your birth year. Or your cat’s name. Or—” “Or OSU,” she says, smirking. “Or Beavers. Or cilantro.” “Exactly,” I say. “And for the love of—turn off lockscreen notifications.” She opens her mouth to tell me to chill, then laughs. It’s high and light and mine in that moment. She pulls the phone back out and says, “Okay, security dad. Show me.” “Only if you want,” I say. “I’m curious,” she says, and slides it over. I walk her through settings with my voice, not my hands. Consent matters. She taps with quick, competent fingers. Eight digits. A sentence. A mental model adjusting. On the lockscreen, the absent chime of previews now muted feels like tinnitus easing. “Thanks,” she says, after. The word lands like a token creature that pulls more weight than cardboard looks like it should. “Sorry again,” I say. “I am trying to be better about… not leading with flaws.” “I mean,” she says, “lead with them, but maybe not mine.” She raises an eyebrow. There’s a glitter there. Salvage operation not only saved but returning value. We eat. The food is what it always is in places like this: good enough that you remember the company and not the flavors. She tells me about her parents in broad strokes, then narrows to a story about her mother’s obsession with baking exactly one recipe every holiday, fruitcake, which she hates and everyone else pretends to love. “It’s a family tradition,” she says. “We also have a thing where we go to Disneyland every election year no matter what, which started as a joke and then turned into a weird superstition.” Christmas, Disneyland, election cycle—time scaffolding to build on. My brain lifts a hand like a student in class, wanting to guess her mother’s maiden name from a story about a childhood piano teacher and a sheet music book with “Mrs. R—” written in blue pen. I tell my brain to sit down. She asks about my family, and I give her the edited version: military dad, librarian mom, a sister who codes better than me and refuses to let me forget it. “At least tell me your first deck,” she says. “Is it embarrassing?” “Bor-ing,” I say. “Starter deck. I got wrecked by a little kid with a janky mill deck and fell in love with losing to cleverness.” She clinks her glass to mine. “A man after my own heart,” she says. And the words hang there like an uncommitted spell. At some point, the server asks if we want dessert. “Do you have anything with apple?” she asks, and then winces. “I shouldn’t say this,” she says, laughing, “but apple pie is my kryptonite. If a bear asked me my mother’s maiden name for a slice, I’d tell him.” “Please do not tell bears your mother’s maiden name,” I say, a reflexive bark of a laugh. “Also don’t post your ‘first internet handle’ in a meme thread on principle.” She smirks. “You really do think in attack vectors.” “I think in causes and effects,” I say. “Doors and keys. Also, to be fair, the bear could probably social engineer your dad with the right tone.” “True,” she says. “He loves being helpful. And he’s very loud on Facebook.” She catches herself, eyes widening. “Wow, look at me handing you a dossier.” “I’m on a date,” I say. “Not a hunt.” “Is this… a date?” she asks, suddenly quieter, and now the room feels like it’s pulled closer, like the edges have sharpened. “I hope so,” I say, before I can overthink it. Her smile spreads slowly, carefully, like something she’s learning how to do again. “Me too,” she says. We skip dessert. We talk about maps we haven’t walked yet, trails we haven’t hiked, the smell of damp leaves and cardboard sleeves. When the check comes, I don’t do the thing where I try to inspect the receipt for merchant IDs or miscalculated tax. I tip like a person. Outside, the air is the perfect kind of cold that makes your breath visible and your hands seek each other. We linger on the sidewalk, exchanging the awkwardness of two people negotiating the next layer. “So,” she says, tugging her coat tighter. “Next time, we bring decks?” “Only if you promise to show me Kaalia and then put her away when you see my fear,” I say. “I promise,” she says, laughing. Then, after a beat: “And… thanks. For the unsolicited vulnerability check. It’s annoying and also… useful.” “I’m working on the unsolicited part,” I say. “Old habits.” “I get it,” she says. “I used to correct everyone’s grammar. My sister threatened to stop talking to me until I stopped. You catch typos, I catch dangling modifiers. You catch patterns, I… pick easy lockscreen patterns, apparently.” “We all start somewhere,” I say. “We get better.” She takes a step closer. “Maybe we can… get better at this together,” she says, and the way she says “this” contains so much possibility it feels like cheating. As we part, she unlocks her phone to call a ride with her new code. I fight the urge to avert my eyes like it’s sacrament, and then I realize it is. I look at her instead. This is the system I’m choosing to learn, to respect, to not pen-test without consent. I let the holes in my vision fill with her smile and the way the cold makes her cheeks pink, and for once, I let the background processes idle. On the walk home, I pass the unlatched side door and do not test it. I think about a world made of doors and the keys we hand each other. I think about decks and the way you can build them to go off on turn three or you can build them to take a long, silly path that makes the whole table laugh. I think about Opal, trembling at a vacuum and trusting the noise to end. I think about a lightning bolt that becomes a sentence, about the shape of a life that doesn’t always have to be the shortest path between two points. I make a note in my head, not a log, not an exploit, just a reminder: bring sleeves next time. And maybe apple pie. But not maiden names. Not bears. Not this time. Not ever.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the perspective of a reformed white hat hacker on a first date. The protagonist's internal monologue reveals their habitual security-focused mindset while they attempt to engage in normal human connection. The piece excels in creating a distinctive voice for the protagonist. The technical terminology and security-focused observations feel authentic without becoming impenetrable to non-technical readers. Lines like "Paper is safe in a way JS-laden QR codes aren't" and references to "entropy and Markov chains" establish credibility while maintaining accessibility. The character development is nuanced and believable. The protagonist's struggle between their security-focused instincts and desire for human connection creates genuine tension. Their slip-up regarding the date's phone unlock pattern feels inevitable rather than contrived, and their recovery from this faux pas demonstrates growth without feeling rushed or unearned. The shared interest in Magic: The Gathering works effectively as a bonding mechanism between the characters. The references are specific enough to feel authentic to fans while remaining comprehensible to those unfamiliar with the game. The way this shared interest helps bridge the awkwardness after the security breach is particularly well-handled. The prose balances technical precision with emotional resonance. Metaphors like "My brain is a flypaper" and "We stack memories like cardboard rectangles" effectively blend the protagonist's technical mindset with their emotional experience. The writing maintains a consistent voice throughout, with the protagonist's internal monologue revealing both their security expertise and their self-awareness about how this affects their interactions. The narrative effectively builds tension around the phone unlock pattern incident and resolves it in a way that feels earned. The date's reaction—initial offense followed by curiosity and eventual appreciation—feels authentic rather than contrived. The ending strikes a hopeful note without suggesting the protagonist has completely overcome their security-focused tendencies, which would have felt unearned. Some of the security observations could have been more subtly integrated, as occasionally they feel slightly didactic. However, this aligns with the character's personality and doesn't significantly detract from the narrative. The piece successfully fulfills the prompt requirements, maintaining first-person perspective, focusing on internal monologue, and incorporating the specific scenario elements (restaurant setting, Magic the Gathering as shared interest, phone unlock pattern incident). The word count is appropriate, and the narrative effectively explores the tension between security mindset and human connection. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 95.5
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
When Mrs. Kline flips to the next slide, the projector squeaks like an anxious mouse that wants to be invisible, which feels appropriate. She says something about variables and control groups, and I tell my face to look attentive, which means eyes at approximately 60 percent open (not too wide, or I look startled), mouth neutral (no smile unless someone smiles first), eyebrows at rest (do not frown—it looks like disapproval), shoulders down. I pretend to take notes so no one thinks I’m idle. My pen writes “variables” in pale loop-de-loops while my brain tries not to leap ahead to the part where I have to actually talk. She’s assigning partners. She says our names like she’s calling roll: “…and Sam with Maya.” The squeak comes again; the screen blinks; my stomach drops, like the moment the bus pulls away from a curb faster than expected. Of all combinations of letters Mrs. Kline could have said, these are the ones that make my hands feel like uncooked pasta. He looks over and I look down like the desk has suddenly grown an interesting pattern (it has not). Your job is to be normal, I tell myself. Neutral. Functional. Airplane on autopilot, not the pilot at the little door narrating every cloud. But there’s a girl in my head doing cartwheels and bumping into furniture, and it’s hard to keep her quiet. He stands, shoves his notebook into his pocket like paper can fold that way without complaints, and walks to my table. The squeak again, as if the projector is practicing being me. He says, “Hey,” which is one syllable and very safe, and I would like to meet him there, but my voice is sleeping behind a locked door. I nod, which is maybe too much, like a bobblehead. Stop. Think. Slow nod. “Hey,” I manage. It comes out softer than I rehearsed in the mirror, which is fine; soft is better than loud, loud is suspicious of desperation. The word sits between us like a coin on a countertop that we both pretend we don’t want to pick up. He’s waiting for either the coin or the next coin. Okay, plan. Plan A: “So, like, I was thinking we could test plant growth in different light conditions?” Quick, throw science into the middle of the road so the car swerves away from feelings. Plan B: “Do you want to do something with magnets? You seem like a magnet person.” Too weird. What is a magnet person. Plan C: “Um, we could do something easy? Not that I think you can’t handle hard. I mean, not that I think you think I think… oh God.” Abort Plan C. Plan D: smile, say “Whatever you want.” But that’s floppy and desperate. People respect opinions. He has freckles I’ve never counted (never counted, never lingered), and a pencil with chew marks. He says, “Do you want to just, like, do the plant thing? That seems fine.” He must have heard me thinking. No, he just said the same thing as my Plan A because plant projects are what middle schoolers do when they are pretending to do science but really doing survival. I nod again. Moderate nod. “Yeah,” I say, and my voice doesn’t betray me and add “you have nice hands” because it’s smart enough to know that doesn’t go in the lab write-up. He sits down across from me, too far, maybe, to share materials comfortably, but not far enough to be safe. My heart does the bit where it steps on a rake. If he asked me what my heart rate is I could tell him, approximately 120, but nobody asks that in the first minute of group work. He is looking at me like I’m a person, which is both flattering and terrifying. I flip to a blank page. I write “Hypothesis” at the top in neat print. No hearts. Do not dot any i’s with hearts. You are an eight-year-old version of a robot. “Do you want to be the, like, plant-waterer person?” he asks. His hair doesn’t lie flat; it has decided standing up a little is a lifestyle. Later, I will wonder how much gel he uses and whether he smells like something expensive or just teenager. Now, I think of the narrow metal sink, the plastic watering can, the sound water makes hitting dry dirt. Words line up inside my head with military precision: That would be a good division of labor because it gives us replicable outcomes and I have access to the classroom before first period because I’m always early. Do not say always early; that is a personality reveal. Just say “Sure.” “Sure,” I say. Good. Two out of two. He scribbles something. His handwriting is messy but legible, like the inside of a boy’s backpack. I think of saying, “I can make the data table,” because data tables are safe, and Excel is my friend one day when I have a laptop that’s mine. I think of saying, “If we get basil for the plant I could take it home after and make pesto,” which is too revealing. I think of saying, “I like basil,” which is neutral. But can a person like basil too much? Is that a weird thing to like? Should I say “mint” instead? No, mint is intense. I say nothing and look at the squeaking slide, which currently shows the difference between dependent and independent variables like a before-and-after photo. We need a hypothesis we can measure. We need to agree on light conditions. “I can put one plant in my window and one in my closet,” I consider saying, and then hear the word “closet” and immediately burn it. He doesn’t need any words that could be metaphors around me. Also, that’s not controlled: the closet has different temperature and humidity. See? This is why you’ve got to think. “What if we do colored light?” he says, and I’m grateful the projector squeaks because it buys me a second to edit reactions. “Like, put, like, red cellophane over one and blue over another?” Red, blue, white. Stoplight. My face wants to smile, because he thought of something beyond “sun/no sun,” which is actually interesting, and I can compliment that without sounding like a fan club. A simple “Good idea” is safe, but maybe too bland. “That could let us see if light spectrum affects chlorophyll output” sounds like I’m auditioning for a show where kids have lab coats. “I like that” is personal. Don’t like things. Approve ideas, don’t like them. “Yeah, colored light is good,” I say, and I’m mad at my mouth for making it sound like I’m grading him, so I add, “It’ll be interesting to see if there’s a difference.” Neutral. Good. His eyes don’t flinch. He says, “My brother has this LED strip we can use. He put it in his room and it makes everything look like a video game.” He smiles at his own exaggerated eyeroll. Brothers are safe. Siblings are humanizing. I picture his house and throw the picture away like I should. My hands sit in my lap, palms down so I don’t fidget. I think about where to put my elbows. I decide elbows on table is too confident; elbows off is too stiff. One elbow on? Casual. One elbow on, chin in hand. But then it looks like I'm bored. I put my elbow on and then I feel the skin of my arm against the table and that becomes the only thing I can feel. “Cool,” I say. What a useful word. It means almost nothing and covers almost everything. He nods. We make a list of materials. I write them in my neat handwriting without hearts. I try to not write too neatly; that’s a thing. The projector squeaks and squeaks, like it regrets every slide. Sam leans back in his chair and the front legs hover a fraction and my lungs stop because what if he falls. He doesn’t. The class buzzes around us, low and chaotic like a beehive that doesn’t know it’s supposed to be organized. Someone at the back laughs too loud, and I flinch invisibly. I want to ask him if he wants to split up the research, if he likes doing the writing or the experiment more, if he wants to meet at the library after school. All of those sentences are crowded at the door of my mouth, but each wears a little sign that says “Desperate?” and I’m checking them like a bouncer. “You good with doing the research part too?” he asks, like he read my internal safety manual and skipped to the correct page. Relief floods me so fast that if I were a plant, my waterlogged leaves would droop. “Yeah,” I say. Understatement. “I can make the outline.” Outline is a safe word. It implies structure without implying control. He nods. We exist again in a silence that feels like a stage cue. I look at his backpack—it has a patch of a band I pretend to know. I think, “Say something about it,” before the thought can put on a trench coat and call itself bold. Say what? “I like that band”? Do I? What if he says “Name three songs” and my mind plays static. Alternatively, “That’s a cool patch” is too much cool. Or “Did you sew that on” which is weirdly domestic, like I’m asking him to mend my life. I choose six full seconds of not talking, then hear the length of six seconds like a metronome, then hate the six seconds for existing. Say something before the seventh. “Um,” I say, the least convincing preface known to man. My throat does a small dry-click noise, like the projector whispering to me that it’s rooting for failure. “Do you—do you want to write the introduction? You’re, like, better at the…” I gesture at the air to indicate words. Words. My specialty, when there’s no one watching. Out loud, I have the vocabulary of a possum. He shrugs. “I can, if you want. I don’t care.” It’s hard to read I don’t care. It can mean: truly chill; profoundly uninterested; a defense against feelings. I nod like I understand his heart. “Or you can,” he adds, and now I see it’s the version that means “I want to share.” “I can…” I say, and then the word disappears like a piece of gum under a desk. “We can split it.” There. Democracy saves me again. He smiles. It reaches his eyes, which is the dangerous kind of smile, the kind that makes me think of what it would be like to be the reason it happens, which is a deep ocean I am not equipped to swim. “Cool,” he says, and here we are in Cool Town, population: us. Mrs. Kline says something about due dates; the squeak punctuates the end like we’re in a cartoon. I write the due date three times, once on the margin, once on the top, once in my planner, which makes me feel like a person who has stayed on the sidewalk and not rushed into the road. He says, “What’s your email?” and it is such a simple question I almost cry. Because I have an email. It’s a string of letters and numbers where a word snuck in that I hope doesn’t sound like I wanted to be pretty when I was eleven. It does. He will see that. He will see eight-year-old me naming galaxies and chance. I write it carefully so that my loops don’t look like hearts. He writes his. His is first name dot last name at something that sounds adult. Of course. “Thanks,” he says, like I gave him a thing worth having. It’s just an email. It feels like a secret handshake. I feel a scrunch forming in my forehead because that’s what it does when I am thinking, and I smooth it out because I read somewhere that you can prevent wrinkles by not making faces, and then realize I am thirteen and welcome to the future. My hands want to twist the cap on my pen, but I don’t want to look fidgety. I tap my foot inside my shoe where no one can see it. My organs are doing a line dance. I consider making a joke. Something like, “If the plants die under blue light, then we’ve discovered the saddest color.” No, that’s not a joke. That’s a t-shirt at a store with fairy lights. Or, “Science: now with 50 percent more chlorophyll.” That’s nothing. This is why silence is a friend who doesn’t betray you. He leans forward like he’s about to say something, and then he doesn’t. The air between us floods with all the things unsaid. I decide I’ll say, “Do you want to meet in the library Thursday?” Because libraries are neutral. Because I love them. Because he doesn’t have to know that last part. Thursday is three days away, which is enough time to practice breathing. “Do you want to—” I start, but the projector squeals as the bell rings like it’s excited to ruin my timing. Everyone stands up at once. Chairs scrape. The hive takes flight. “Uh, I gotta go to gym,” he says, standing, slinging his adult email on his back. “Email me?” He looks at me. Specifically, at me. It’s like a tiny sunbeam. Do not go photosynthetic. “Yeah,” I say. I am a broken song with one lyric. He grins for half a second, and then he’s gone with the current, and I’m left at the table with two words written and a whole page of things I did not say. I pack my bag in slow motion so I can still be here in the before, even though now is after. The projector squeaks one more time as the slides go dark, as if to say: Good luck, kid. Don’t forget to label your axes. I walk out into the hall and remember to put my shoulders down and walk like a person. I replay every second in my head like a courtroom transcript. Assess: Did I smile too much? Not enough? Did my voice catch on his name? Did I sound like I was applying for the position of Person Who Can Email? Could he tell that my palms were rivers? Will he think my handwriting is trying too hard? Are my shoes too quiet? Is that a thing? People with quiet shoes seem suspicious. I think about his pencil, his messy letters, his not-mean shrug, the way he said “Email me?” with a question mark like an invitation. I think about how my brain wrote a whole essay and my mouth turned it into a sticky note. I think about basil. I think about not saying closet. I think about the LED strip making everything unreal. I think about how exhausting it is to be a puppet and your own puppeteer. I breathe. In the space between systems, between bell and next bell, I imagine typing out the email. A subject line that says “Plant Project” like it’s all business. A body that says “Hey, it’s Maya from science. Do you want to meet at the library Thursday?” A period, not an exclamation point; exclamation points are eager. Sign off with my name, like a normal human. Do not add “:)”. Do not add “Thanks!!” One thanks is plenty. Keep it simple. Keep it cool. The projector doesn’t squeak out here. The hallway hums. I move with it. I can do this. I can be a person who sends an email. I can be a person whose internal novel edits itself down to a sentence. I can be a person who waters plants. I can be a person who doesn’t say closet. I can be a person who remembers to label axes, label feelings, label nothing. I can be cool. Or at least cool adjacent. I hold onto the coin of “Hey” like a lucky thing I put in my pocket. I picture the blue light making the leaves lean, reaching for something that’s not quite sunlight but still something. I think, okay. Reach. Not all the way. Just a little. Enough to call it growth.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal monologue of an 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on her science project partner. The piece excels at portraying the gap between her articulate internal voice and her stilted external communication. The protagonist's overthinking is masterfully rendered through her constant self-monitoring and rehearsal of potential conversations. The writer creates a vivid contrast between her rich inner world and her limited verbal output, often reduced to single words like "Yeah," "Sure," and "Cool." This perfectly illustrates the prompt's request to show "the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud." The narrative employs several effective techniques to convey anxiety. The recurring motif of the projector's squeaking serves as an external manifestation of the protagonist's internal discomfort. The detailed attention to physical positioning ("I decide elbows on table is too confident; elbows off is too stiff") demonstrates her exhausting self-monitoring. Her consideration of multiple conversation approaches, each with potential pitfalls, effectively shows her fear of embarrassment. The prose is elegant without being overwrought, using metaphors that feel authentic to a bright 8th-grader's perspective: "my voice is sleeping behind a locked door," "my heart does the bit where it steps on a rake," and "my organs are doing a line dance." These metaphors are creative yet accessible, avoiding purple prose while maintaining literary quality. The character development is nuanced and believable. Maya is intelligent and self-aware, yet paralyzed by social anxiety. Her crush on Sam feels age-appropriate and genuine. The narrative avoids the trap of making her anxiety seem quirky or cute; instead, it portrays the genuine exhaustion of constant self-monitoring: "I think about how exhausting it is to be a puppet and your own puppeteer." The ending strikes a delicate balance, showing a small moment of hope without an unrealistic transformation. Maya doesn't suddenly overcome her anxiety, but she finds a way to function despite it: "I can be a person who sends an email. I can be a person whose internal novel edits itself down to a sentence." This represents growth without being an unearned transformation. The piece maintains a consistent voice throughout, capturing both the intelligence and vulnerability of the protagonist. The writing flows naturally, with sentence structures that vary between longer, rambling thoughts during moments of panic and shorter, more direct observations during calmer moments. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while creating a compelling, emotionally resonant character study of social anxiety in adolescence. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 20 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 20.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 95.0
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The phone says 3% and it might as well be my pulse. I watch the green sliver slide under the red, like a wound almost shut, and I think: if it dies, they’ll think I didn’t care enough to text back. Or I’ll think they didn’t care enough to text first. I plug it in for a minute, then panic that I’m going to be late and unplug it. 2%. I tell myself I am not going to text them first because they should want to see me. They should reassure me. They should just show up. They said six. It’s 5:47, the exact time that exists just to hum. I’m putting on my shoes and I say, in my head, “You shouldn’t worry. They said they were looking forward to it.” But then I say, also in my head, in their voice, “I said that because I didn’t want to upset you,” like they’re causing me mercy pain. I practice my response: “I’d rather you just be honest.” Then I see their face pulling into that patient, borderline pity smile that I hate, that I invented. “Okay,” they say. “I’m not that into this anymore.” And I go cold and noble. “Thank you for telling me.” I see myself standing up in the café, composed, leaving my cup on the table as if I’m donating it to someone stronger. I check the mirror. My mouth looks apologetic by default. I try to arrange my face into something that says I am fine without you. My phone pings and my heart slams against it. One percent. The message pops up: Running 10 mins late—train was delayed. Can’t wait to see you. A heart. Or is it a heart? No, it’s the one with the little sparkling stars. Is that less intense than a heart? Is it a hedge? Is it polite enthusiasm? It’s not the face with hearts, which I think is more intimate, so maybe they’re scaling back. I should not need this. Who needs this? I do. I type “No worries!” and then delete the exclamation point because it looks eager. “No worries.” Period. Then add a smiley face and take it away because it looks like I tried too hard. The phone blinks. Black. I hold down the button and it refuses to resurrect. I’m suddenly without oxygen. The cord is at home on the floor and there is no option but to go and wait. In the street, I make up their explanations the way I make up songs on walks when I’m alone. “I’ve been distant,” they say, “because work is stressful.” I nod. “I get it.” “And also,” they continue, “you’ve been a lot.” A lot. The words fan out like cards. I feel a preemptive heat rise from my collarbones. “Define a lot,” I say, coolly. “Don’t gaslight me,” they say. “You know.” I think of my messages two nights ago: Are you okay? Are you mad? Are you sure? I was attentive. Attentiveness is only a lot if someone wants less of you, and someone should not want less of me. I walk faster, then slower so I don’t look like I was rushing. The café is the one with the plants that look like they’re in recovery. I pick a table near the door so they’ll see me and I won’t miss their face, so I won’t have the chance to misinterpret a delay as a choice. The waiter says something cheerful. I interpret it as an assessment. Don’t look like a person waiting too hard. I order water because I don’t want to commit to a latte that might be interrupted by a dramatic exit. Every time the door opens, something in my spine twitches. I see them in my mind walk in and pause before seeing me, scanning the room, weighing something. I see them walk in with someone else, a coworker with that neat haircut that signals normalcy. They say, “Sorry, they were coming this way anyway,” and I decide to leave immediately. I rehearse a line: “I think I’ll give you the space you were about to take.” It makes my mouth taste like pennies. Then they actually walk in. The real them. The way their shoulders are slightly hunched from their backpack. The way they look at me first and grin like they’re at the end of a small maze, relieved, like I’m a prize. They open their arms and it’s not a calculation; it’s easy. They smell like their detergent. They say, “Hey,” in the register that means not performing for an audience. My body melts into them because my body is not as suspicious as my head. I store the sensation in the place where they said it’s easier to store trauma than joy because joy evaporates. I am trying to invent a jar. “You look nice,” they say. I say, “It’s fine,” because I meant to say “Thanks,” and what is wrong with me. “Thanks,” I add. They don’t flinch. They tell me about the train. The announcement that everyone booed. How an old lady tutted and he laughed and asked someone if they needed the seat. Ordinary, kind behavior that I twist into generosity I should be suspicious of. Who are you trying to impress? Why are you good? They reach for my hand and then pull back. I saw it. They were going to. It’s proof and also not enough. I look at their hand on the table, the soft vulnerable underside, the place where blood runs close to the skin, and I want to bite it so that they have to think of me later when it aches. “I’m sorry I’ve been a bit quiet,” they say, as if they were listening to the voice in my head and decided to rescue it. “I was just slammed with work.” My rehearsed—and excelled—responses rustle. “It felt like you were pulling away,” I say, lightly, like a person who can communicate. They squeeze my knee under the table. It is intimate in a way that lifts the hairs on my arms. The validation comes in a wave that almost knocks me off the chair. I have been waiting for this knee-squeeze all week, burning imaginary variations of it in my mind’s furnace, and now I have it. My brain, being an ungrateful dragon, says: They know that’s what you need. They’re managing you. It says: If someone has to touch you to keep you quiet, you should run. “Not pulling away,” they say, and the words are honeyed and perfect. “I’ve been thinking about you a lot, actually.” I tilt my head. I want to capture, freeze. “What,” I say, playing at coy, because if I show the hunger, it’s embarrassing. Inside, I say: Say it better. Think about me how? Of course you think about me; I’m intrusive. “I keep replaying last Friday,” they say, and grin that slow-grin that interns my knees. The night we became lovers, the night my skin felt like it had been ironed out and made flat and useful. My heart bangs and throws confetti. Then: “But are they replaying it because it was good or because there was something off?” I press my nails into my palm. This is the part where I should say, “Me too,” because it’s the normal call-and-response of intimacy. “Me too,” I say. It comes out like a testimony. “It was so good,” I add, which feels like I am spending a secret. They look relieved. “Yeah,” they whisper. There’s a sweetness to the awkwardness of whispering “yeah” in a café. This is not what rejection looks like. This is what acceptance looks like. I’m supposed to recognize it. I do. And then I immediately interrogate it. Why whisper? Are you embarrassed? Of me? Of us? “I didn’t want to overwhelm you,” they say, stirring their coffee unnecessarily. “I have this thing where I… misread how much to text and then I annoy people.” “Me too,” I say, too quickly. “I mean, not the annoying part.” My face burns and I want to claw time like a cat. “I just worry.” I am trying to sound self-aware, like the sort of person who reads articles about anxious attachment and uses phrases like “my stuff.” I visualize myself giving a TED talk called My Stuff. They nod. “I get it.” Do you? I want to open my ribcage and put their hand inside. “Okay,” I say. The part of me that prays for relief wants to bask. The part of me that believes relief is a trick wants a backup plan. I store this moment as evidence in both files: Proof That They Care and Proof That They Will Leave Me Later. The folders always get merged. The waiter brings me the latte I didn’t order and puts it down like an apology. “On the house,” he says, “sorry you had to wait a bit.” He must mean the drink, but my brain drags the sentence into our context. I laugh and it sounds high and brittle. “Thanks,” I say to the waiter, to the universe, to the part of me that is still holding onto the flare gun. We talk about a show we both watched. I listen and also splice in a scene where they say, “I think we should slow down.” In that scene, I turn my face into a mask and say, “No problem,” and then become a statue until they leave. It’s not happening, but my body rehearses: the weight on my shoulders, the speed at which I’ll put on my coat, the way I will keep my voice even so that they remember me as dignity. I catch myself doing this and get mad at myself. Stop. You’re here. Look at their mouth when they speak. Feel their knee. Feel your own knee. They notice something in my face. “Where’d you go?” they ask, gently, not as a test, just because they are curious. The genuine question punches a hole in my armor and a bird flies out. “Just… overthinking,” I say. Understatement as survival strategy. “I do that.” They smile, rueful. “Me too.” It’s probably true, for them. It’s also not the same gnarled vine choking the thing. But I take it and place it next to me like a pet. A mirror. “I like you,” they say suddenly, straightforward, and my spine goes liquid. Validation is a substance that, for me, evaporates the second it is exposed to air. I cup it. “Do you?” I say in my head. “For how long?” I say in my head. Out loud I say, “I like you too,” like a student. I want to ask them to repeat it, to say it in the past tense, the current tense, the future tense, to print it on the wall. I do not. I can see the path where this goes. I am being held, I am being fed the words that keep my neurons in their chairs, and I am still building a fortress in case the food stops. I feel ridiculous and also justified. I think of texting them later when I get home—except my phone is dead. “I can borrow your charger?” I ask, too quickly. They rummage in their bag without hesitation and I exhale like I had been underwater for days. This is a person who carries a charger. This is a person who doesn’t want to watch me drown. Or this is a person who likes to be needed. I plug in, the little lightning bolt appearing like salvation. The messages come back in, the earlier ones, their “Can’t wait to see you” glowing stupidly. I want to screen-shot it so I can send it to the version of me that wakes up at 3 a.m. sure that I am a burden. I can hear that version laughing. “They were trying to be nice.” I say, softly, “Sometimes I worry you’ll decide this is too much.” I say it like a tiny apology, to let it out of my body so it doesn’t shock me later. They take a second. I watch every muscle in their face shift and inventory it like I’m a scientist documenting microclimates. They nod, slowly. “Thanks for telling me.” No grand promises. My stomach dips; I wanted, “Never.” I also feel relieved: no lie I will have to make myself believe. Two things at once, always. They squeeze my knee again. The second squeeze is different; it says: You can survive this even if I don’t say the exact words you want. It’s both empowering and infuriating. I want to hurl my glass at the wall and I want to lay my head on their shoulder. I take a breath that feels like climbing a ladder. “Okay,” I say. It is both surrender and truce. I taste the bitter and the sweet, and they are the same drink today. The café hums around us with people who don’t know what it’s like to rehearse a fight with a person you love while your hand is in theirs. Or maybe they do. I am not special and also I am a singular catastrophe. I sip my latte. It is warm. It will cool if I don’t keep drinking it. I take another sip before I forget how.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal experience of someone with borderline personality disorder (BPD). The piece excels at depicting the protagonist's constant cycling between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments—all hallmarks of BPD. The internal monologue is masterfully executed, revealing the protagonist's thought processes as they prepare to meet their friend/lover. The narrative shows how even positive interactions are immediately questioned and reinterpreted through a lens of suspicion and fear. For example, when their date arrives and greets them warmly, the protagonist thinks: "They smell like their detergent. They say, 'Hey,' in the register that means not performing for an audience. My body melts into them because my body is not as suspicious as my head." This perfectly captures the cognitive dissonance between what they physically experience and what their mind tells them. The writing employs vivid imagery and metaphors that effectively communicate the emotional experience: "The phone says 3% and it might as well be my pulse. I watch the green sliver slide under the red, like a wound almost shut..." These metaphors aren't merely decorative but serve to illuminate the character's psychological state. The prose flows naturally with a rhythm that mirrors the protagonist's racing thoughts. Short, punchy sentences create tension, while longer, more reflective passages show moments of self-awareness. The voice remains consistent throughout—anxious, hypervigilant, and self-sabotaging. Particularly effective is how the narrative shows the protagonist's limited self-awareness. They recognize their patterns at times ("I catch myself doing this and get mad at myself. Stop. You're here.") but struggle to interrupt them. The piece also skillfully demonstrates how validation is desperately needed yet immediately questioned: "The validation comes in a wave that almost knocks me off the chair... My brain, being an ungrateful dragon, says: They know that's what you need. They're managing you." The ending avoids both unrealistic transformation and complete despair, instead landing on a nuanced note that feels authentic to the character's experience: "I taste the bitter and the sweet, and they are the same drink today." This shows the protagonist's momentary acceptance of their contradictory feelings without suggesting they've overcome their fundamental struggles. The piece excels at showing rather than telling, allowing readers to experience the protagonist's thought processes directly. The few instances of dialogue are well-crafted and serve to highlight the contrast between external interactions and internal reality. If there's any criticism to be made, it might be that some metaphors occasionally border on being slightly overwrought ("I want to open my ribcage and put their hand inside"), but even these serve the character's intense emotional experience and don't detract from the overall quality. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that demonstrates deep psychological insight, technical skill, and emotional intelligence. It succeeds brilliantly at the difficult task of portraying BPD from the inside while maintaining readability and emotional impact. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 20 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 20.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 86.9
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The torch sputters, a sun the size of a fist nailed high on a cracked pillar, its light wobbling across flaking frescoes and the yawning mouth of the roofless dome. Dust hangs in the cold air like the breath of ghosts. The ring is a space cleared of loose rubble—an uneven oval between a toppled altar and a fallen lintel, the floor scabbed with stone and weeds. Dozens of bodies crowd the broken colonnade, the circle tightening and loosening with each jeer and whisper. Wagers flash in the half-light—paper, coin, painted nails tapping on damp palms. The smell is wet stone and sweat, burnt pitch, and the faint metal tang of anticipation. They face each other at ten paces, the light pulling long, quivering shadows from their feet. Kanda is Jigen-ryū, all carved angles and iron discipline, hair tied hard against his skull, greenish veins mottling his forearms. He wears a faded indigo gi and hakama, the cloth stiff at the pleats, hands empty but positioned as if around a katana that is not there. His body vibrates in an almost invisible tremor: heel lightly rasping the ground, knees bent, hips tucked, spine stacked. His shoulders are a fortress. His gaze is a line drawn through his opponent’s chest. He is forward pressure even at rest. Opposite him, Liu shakes out his wrists and lets his long sleeves fall back to his elbows. Piguaquan has given him broad shoulders without thickness, a whipcord waist, the smooth lines of a reed that survives the river. His stance is open, feet staggered left-forward, knees soft, weight in the balls of his feet. He rolls a shoulder, sways a inch to the right, a inch to the left—testing the uneven floor, testing the air. His hands fall and rise as if gathering wind. The crowd leans. Kanda explodes. He doesn’t step so much as launch, his right foot stomping into the dust, left foot sliding after, the classic Jigen triangle lunge—forward, forward again. His right hand cleaves downward in a blade-hand strike that could be a sword cut, the left guarding his centerline. His chest is already twisting to draw power into the next cut. He aims for Liu’s collarbone, a decisive end before anyone can measure the beginning. Liu’s head snaps to the left like a bird’s peck and his whole body follows in a tight pivot on his left toe. The blade-hand tears through a ribbon of air where his neck was. He feels the wind of it cool the sweat near his ear. As Kanda overreaches, Liu’s right arm arcs out and down from the shoulder, a Pigua “whipping hand” aimed at the triceps of Kanda’s striking arm. The loose-hinged swing, powered by waist rotation, bites with the heel of the palm to shock the nerve. Contact. Kanda’s arm jolts, fingertips flaring. He absorbs it by dropping his weight a fraction, left foot sliding half a step forward into a compressed stance. He lets the impact feed the twist of his torso and brings his left hand up under Liu’s armpit, a rising hikite to jam and lift. Liu doesn’t allow the catch. His hips fold, belly cinching, and he lets his right shoulder collapse inward, turning the rising hand into a glancing scrape across his ribs. His right foot tucks behind his left and he spirals past Kanda’s left flank, pivoting counterclockwise in a tight arc. His left hand flicks out across Kanda’s face, fingers rigid, a slapping hammer that goes cheekbone-down-to-jaw and rides the rotation. Kanda’s head snaps right, back teeth singing. He lashes with a backfist from his right, aimed where Liu’s head was a heartbeat ago. The strike cuts only the flickering torchlight. Liu is already behind him, having completed his turn on the ball of his left foot, right foot stepping out, hands whipping again—one high, one low. High catches the back of Kanda’s shoulder with a chopping forearm, low smacks at the left kidney. Not heavy enough to end, but enough to sting and push momentum. Kanda does not chase his shadow. He drops his center of gravity and turns hard to his left into a short stance, left knee rotating, right foot planting with the heel digging a groove in the dust. The sudden torque whips his torso back to face Liu. In the same breath he stamps his right foot forward, sliding across the uneven floor toward the fallen altar, forcing Liu backward toward the litter of carved stone. His hands reframe, both palms blade-still, and he tears a diagonal cut from his left shoulder to right hip, the path of an imaginary sword aimed to split Liu’s attacking arc. This time Liu yields ground. He sees the obstacle—two broken altar steps, edges jagged. He retreats three quick, light steps, each one angled a few degrees right, never in a straight line. The diagonal cut hisses just in front of his chest, conducted through the air by Kanda’s raw intent. The Pigua man counters without setting his feet, hooking his right wrist under Kanda’s forearm as it passes and rolling it, the way you catch a thrown rope and guide it aside. His left foot finds a flat patch, his left arm whips with the whole body: shoulder leading, elbow slightly bent, hand slicing across Kanda’s forearm near the wrist—not a strike but a dragging, redirecting motion to turn Kanda’s chest. Kanda feels the rotational pull. He does not resist high; he drops low. His right knee buckles into a crouch and his left foot shoots forward, a stomping low strike aimed at Liu’s lead ankle. It’s an ugly piece of Jigen reimagined for empty hands—if he can break the base, the rest will follow. Liu sees the hip dip and the left knee turn. He hops. His right foot picks up and steps outside of Kanda’s stomping foot, a shallow crescent step to the right. Kanda’s stomp slaps dead stone. Liu lands with both feet offset to Kanda’s right side, nearly shoulder to shoulder. His hands blur—left forearm swings inward at Kanda’s jaw, right hand hooks down behind Kanda’s knee from the outside to the inside, a simultaneous high-low sickle. Kanda’s head jerks from the forearm whip; his left leg is trapped for a fraction. That fraction holds a canyon. Kanda rips his left hand down and back, elbow tight to his ribs, grabbing Liu’s right wrist and gluing it, preventing the knee hook from finding purchase. He counters the high strike by driving his right shoulder into Liu’s chest, collapsing the space. There is no room to whip when the reed is crushed. They bump bodies, breath intermingling. Liu feels the breath; he gives ground. He turns his hips away, letting Kanda’s shoulder slide past him, and raises his right forearm to brace across Kanda’s clavicle as he steps back. The brace isn’t a block but a guide. He leads Kanda a half-step in the direction of his own shove, using Kanda’s forward bias against him. Kanda’s right foot must step to recover or he’ll pitch forward. He steps. Right foot lands on the edge of the altar step. The stone shifts under the load with a gritty whisper. The crowd breathes in, the torch flares, and Kanda becomes stillness inside motion. His right leg stiffens, his left foot seeks grip, his hips align, and he decides. He doesn’t retreat. He commits through the imbalance, turning the slide into a burst. He rides the unstable step like a runner off a block, launching his left hand straight like a thrust into Liu’s sternum. Liu has been taught to hate straight lines. He drops his center, letting the thrust gust over his shoulder—feeling knuckles graze cloth—and he winds his torso like a silk rope. His left hand slings from below, palm heel rising from near Kanda’s left hip up under the ribs along the seam of the obliques. The strike is not heavy—it is placed. The pain hits like a spark under the skin, a burn that makes muscles shiver. Kanda snarls, the sound caught between teeth. He clamps his left elbow down to trap the offending arm. Liu sees it and lets the arm melt, elbow bending to slide out rather than be caught, his wrist twisting in Kanda’s grip path. He pivots again, choosing the open side—the side with more floor and less altar—and steps his right foot outside Kanda’s left, drawing a half-circle around him. As he completes the arc, his right hand lashes across Kanda’s face, knuckles rapping the bridge of the nose, and his left hand slaps downward along Kanda’s left elbow to unbalance. Kanda’s vision punches white for a beat. He answers with the thing his style has made him: a storm. He becomes a sequence of forward surges, short as heartbeats. Step-stamp, cut. Step-stamp, cut. He tears straight lines into the messy world, forcing Liu to yield, to spiral, to backpedal around the toppled lintel. The circle of bodies shivers back to make room as stone underfoot slides. Liu rides the perimeter, left foot, right foot, diagonals, his torso never squared, always at an angle, always feeding power into his whipping limbs even as he moves. Two exchanges later, Kanda feints a high cut and, with the torchlight wobbling in Liu’s eyes, drops level, hooking his right arm behind Liu’s left knee while his left hand clamps at the shoulder. He commits all his weight to the back-leg reap. Liu feels the vacuum—the emptiness under him—and yields before it can be created. He lets the left leg go slack, knee folding as if stepping into a deep lunge. Instead of resisting, he drops his pelvis in a controlled fall toward the floor, right hand slapping the stone to absorb force, left elbow tucking to protect ribs. Kanda’s reap finds a ghost of a leg and he over-extends, his chest leaning over Liu’s shoulder. Liu’s right foot bites into a patch of grit-free stone. He plants and pushes, twisting his waist clockwise from the ground. His left arm snakes around Kanda’s neck—not a choke, not a hold, just a short lever. He uses the twist to whip his left forearm across the line of Kanda’s throat, a cutting motion that is all rotation and no muscle. Kanda’s balance tilts forward; Liu’s right hand shoots to Kanda’s right wrist and pulls it across his own chest, sealing the lever. Kanda has a choice: fight the lever and stall or roll through. He knows stalling is death. He rolls. He tucks his chin, takes a crooked step with his left foot to save his neck, and spins clockwise to unwind. The movement frees his throat and, for a moment, puts his back to Liu. Liu is already moving. He lets the unwinding occur and follows, stepping to maintain flank. His right hand releases Kanda’s wrist and flattens to a blade, sweeping from behind Kanda’s elbow down to his forearm, pulling the arm across the body. His left hand arcs overhead and snaps down onto Kanda’s exposed right shoulder with clawed fingers, not to grip but to spike sensation and control posture. He steps in close, right hip almost touching Kanda’s right hip. Then he throws a Pigua back-knuckle from low to high, a short whip that cracks just under Kanda’s right ear. The sound is a dry slap of knuckles on bone. The world in Kanda’s skull tilts. He grinds his teeth and fires blindly backward with his elbow to where Liu’s ribs should be. Liu is already outside that line, his left step drawing him behind the elbow’s path, his right hand capturing the elbow as it sails by, guiding it into emptiness. He whips his left forearm diagonally across Kanda’s lower back, above the pelvis, a tearing motion that both strikes and steers. Kanda stumbles two steps forward, toward the base of a broken column. He plants his left hand against the stone to halt the momentum. He’s breathing through his nose, lips peeled back. Behind him, Liu bounces on the balls of his feet, resetting distance to two paces, circling right. The torch paints both men in shifting amber. Shouts rise and crash like surf. “Finish him!” from the Jigen corner, venom and pride. “Make him eat dust!” from the Pigua side, heartbeats synced to the gambler’s lust. Kanda turns in place, keeping his right shoulder forward, refusing to give the soft of his belly. He advances again, measured now. He taps the floor with the edge of his right foot to check for loose rocks, then stamps and cuts. His blade-hand whistles, not wide but tight, trying to herd Liu toward the fallen lintel where footing is treacherous. Liu gives ground but not that way; he drift-steps left, then feints left and cuts right under the strike, slipping inside the elbow. He peppers Kanda’s ribs with two forearm chops—low, high—then slides out before Kanda can fold him with an elbow. The exchanges build, each man scoring small truths. Kanda’s straight lines score bruises like straight handwriting down Liu’s tender places. Liu’s whips bleed sting into Kanda’s arms and back, dulling the snap in his strikes. The torch sputters lower; shadows lengthen and seek prey. A misstep is a god. It comes when Kanda edges Liu toward the altar steps again. Liu sees the trap and skirts right, but his right foot lands on a patch of gravel that acts like ball bearings. His heel skates. He is not falling, but he is slipping for one-half second, his weight not where it should be. Kanda watches for precisely that, and the world telescopes into a single line. He charges through the slip with a short burst, left foot slamming down to lock his hips. His right hand lashes straight, not a cut now but a thrust into the solar plexus. It hits with the heel of the hand. Air leaves Liu in a bark. Pain blooms behind his breastbone. Kanda’s left hand follows like a shadow and slams sideways into Liu’s right shoulder to collapse him. Liu’s spine flexes like bamboo in wind. He folds but as he folds his right foot recovers purchase and his waist answers pain with rotation. He chooses emptiness again—he pivots hard to his left, turning his right shoulder under Kanda’s controlling hand, and in the turn his left arm drags. The dragging arm hooks across Kanda’s right forearm at the wrist and tears. Kanda’s thrusting arm is drawn across his own body, pulling his shoulder joint out of alignment. Kanda’s feet must adjust. He registers, too late, that his hips are squared while his chest is not. He tries to step to reset. Liu will not permit. He steps deep with his left foot past Kanda’s right, planting it outside Kanda’s right heel. His hip meets Kanda’s thigh; his torso twists counterclockwise, stealing Kanda’s root. The left hand that was dragging the wrist now suddenly slips to clamp the hand itself and wrench it down, while his right forearm whips across Kanda’s throat from behind, not to choke but to lever. The combined torque—hip replacing, throat lever, wrist pull—draws Kanda backward over Liu’s thigh. They fall together, but only one lands on stone. Kanda’s back slams into the floor. Dust coughs up around his head. The breath in him leaves in a groan that is not consent. Liu rides down with him, knees wide, weight over Kanda’s hips to pin for a heartbeat. He does not stay. He knows Kanda will buck like a dragon. He slides to Kanda’s right, keeping control of Kanda’s right wrist with both hands for a moment, planting it on the floor. With the next beat he releases, whips his left forearm across Kanda’s cheek again, then pops up, stepping back to clear space and avoid a wild kick. Kanda bucks. His right leg scythes, his hips twist, he rolls to his left side in a stubborn attempt to bring knees under. He makes it to his knees, spitting dust, blood threading his nose. He surges to half-standing, teeth bared. Liu meets him with a descending whip from the left, a forearm that crashes onto the trapezius where neck meets shoulder. The strike breaks the rise. Kanda’s right knee softens. Liu’s right hand is already at Kanda’s jaw, heel of the palm driving up and back. Kanda’s head snaps, his vision stutters, and his body backs into the broken column. His right shoulder hits stone. He refuses the collapse. He stomps his right foot, draws his left foot up, and fires again—because Jigen-ryū knows only forward, because every story told to him as a boy carved that command into his bones. He tears through at close range with a final short arc of his right hand toward Liu’s throat. Liu saw the foot. He had waited for it. He slips his head outside the line, steps inside the arm, and rotates. His left shoulder bumps Kanda’s chest, killing the strike. His right arm snakes under Kanda’s armpit and up behind the shoulder blade, his forearm forming a bar. His left hand cups the back of Kanda’s skull. His body turns like a millstone. The movement is small and merciless. He wrenches Kanda’s upper body into a counterclockwise spiral while his right hip blocks Kanda’s right thigh from moving. Kanda’s lower body tries to follow; it finds the column. For a violent instant, Kanda is two men trying to go to different places. Something in a shoulder joint protests with a dry pop. His right arm goes white with fire. He drops to his knee because he must. Liu releases the bar at once, hands open, stepping back one measure to show the choice—the final class of the night. Kanda is a kneeling shape, chest heaving, eyes bright with pain and fury. A ring of faces crowd the light. The torch spits another gob of flame and the shadows leap. The Jigen supporters grind their teeth; some shake their heads, some watch with a silence that is heavier than shouting. The Pigua crowd sings under their breath. Kanda sways once, twice. He plants his left foot and pushes to standing. His right arm hangs at a lower angle, shoulder furred with violence. He stamps the floor and goes forward. Liu’s eyes narrow
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This martial arts narrative demonstrates exceptional technical precision in depicting a high-stakes underground duel between practitioners of Jigen-ryū and Piguaquan. The writer has created a physically coherent fight sequence that meticulously tracks the fighters' positions, movements, and techniques throughout the encounter. The physical choreography is the standout element. Each strike, counter, and positional shift is described with remarkable clarity, allowing readers to visualize the fight's mechanics moment by moment. The writer demonstrates deep knowledge of both martial arts styles, accurately representing Jigen-ryū's aggressive, linear attacks and Piguaquan's circular, whipping movements. The contrast between these styles creates natural tension and visual interest. The setting—an abandoned temple with crumbling architecture—is effectively established and consistently incorporated into the fight choreography. The environmental elements (altar steps, fallen lintel, broken column) become natural obstacles and tactical considerations for the fighters, adding complexity to their exchanges. Character development is somewhat limited but sufficient for the narrative's purpose. Kanda (Jigen-ryū) and Liu (Piguaquan) are primarily defined through their fighting styles and physical attributes, with brief hints at their psychological states. Kanda's stubborn forward pressure and Liu's adaptable evasiveness effectively embody the philosophical differences between their respective martial arts traditions. The prose is technically strong, with vivid sensory details and varied sentence structures that mirror the rhythm of combat. The writer employs precise, evocative language to describe physical movements without becoming overly technical or inaccessible. Occasional poetic flourishes ("A misstep is a god") add texture without disrupting the narrative flow. The narrative builds tension effectively through escalating exchanges, with each fighter scoring small victories before the climactic sequence. The ending, while abrupt (the response appears to have been cut off mid-sentence), successfully establishes Liu's advantage while maintaining Kanda's determined resistance. Some weaknesses include occasional overreliance on specialized martial arts terminology that might confuse general readers, and a few instances where the prose becomes slightly purple or overwrought. The narrative also lacks significant emotional depth beyond the immediate physical conflict, though this is somewhat mitigated by the brief glimpses into the fighters' psychological states and the cultural context of their rivalry. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted martial arts narrative that excels in its physical coherence, technical precision, and vivid sensory details. It successfully fulfills the prompt's requirements while creating an engaging, visually dynamic fight sequence. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Physical-spatial: Breaking Formation — Score: 89.8
Prompt:
**"Breaking Formation"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood who's won a scholarship to an elite K-pop training academy in Seoul. Desperately out of place culturally and technically, they struggle with a militaristically precise choreography that contradicts everything about their improvisational background. The punishing rehearsal takes place under a famous instructor known for breaking students to remake them, who sees potential in the narrator's raw talent but not their attitude. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—each dance move, position shift, and spatial relationship must be tracked with precision throughout the studio. Paint an exceptionally vivid kinetic picture through descriptions that capture not just movement but the contrast between the narrator's fluid, expressive style and the mechanical precision demanded. Their internal monologue should reveal culture shock, class anxiety, and the threatening realization that success here might mean losing their authentic movement voice. Include technical terminology that highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, moments when muscle memory betrays them, and a crucial decision point about whether to conform or rebel. Physical clarity is essential—readers must be able to visualize exactly how bodies move through space, how rhythms align or clash, and how the protagonist's body struggles against unfamiliar discipline. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The first thing that hits me is how clean everything is. The studio floor is smooth, sprung wood, lines of white gaffer tape marking center and quarter lines, mirrors running wall to wall. The smell is pine cleaner and sweat. I’m used to concrete, chalk dust, a speaker with a cough in the bass. Here, a silent subwoofer waits under a console. The large digital clock on the wall over the mirrors reads 01:59:57 in red, slashes of blood. It starts ticking down. We stand in two lines—three in front, four in back—placed on taped X marks, all body angles aligned to the front mirror. I’m on the back line, second from the left. The room is bright, the daylight combed through blinds, and I can see my face: too tight at the mouth, a haircut I did myself before the scholarship came through. Black sweatpants, white T-shirt, new training shoes that feel like they’re swallowing my footwork. “On instructors,” the boy next to me whispers. He bows his head with everyone else when she steps in. Madam Kwon is small, hair pulled into a bun that doesn’t move, black track pants, no logo. There’s a thin headset on her. She looks at us like a measuring tape. Her assistant, a tall guy in a gray tee, pads to the LED panel. The clock ticks. 01:59:25. “We will run the first chorus,” she says in Korean. I catch every other word; my language classes haven’t caught up with my dreams. She snaps her fingers as she speaks—clap, clap, clap-clap—eight counts like punctuation. “Formation, precision. Breath.” We walk to first position. It’s a diagonal for the count-in, then a quick converge to forward-facing, third position parallel, feet beneath hips. I’m used to starting wherever the beat lives in my chest. Here, the beat’s on the screen. She cues music. The bass comes in on a 4/4 with a hi-hat rattling a sixteenth-note pattern. We mark it once, bodies half-committed. “No marking,” she says, tiny mic catching the iron in her voice. “Full out.” “Five, six, seven, eight.” My eyes glue to the front because everyone knows the counts already, and I learned the video last night with my phone under a blanket. Shift weight to right, slide left foot in, heel slightly lifted, set left edge of the sneaker at forty-five degrees—this is what they call a bevel. Hands up on count two, wrists flexed at ninety degrees, fingers tight, palms facing out—blocks that look like construction cranes. I force my shoulders away from max relax. My b-boy heart wants to throw a groove on the up-beat, a little roll through the ribs. The choreography wants a crisp, isometric stop. On three, we all hit a micro hop, landing in second position, knees soft, torso lifted. My habit is to sink when I land, absorb like asphalt. Here, we’re a row of posts planted upright. “Energize!” the assistant calls. His accent makes it sound like edge-nighs. Count four, head snaps left, chin level. I overdo it and my cap brim nearly scrapes my ear, which makes me late for the five: right arm shoots to a ninety-degree angle forward, left arm cuts across in a sharp forearm. It’s a tutting shape, elementary box. I should own this. But my hands, raised on corners of boombox battles, tend to flex open into expressive fingers. Here, hands are blades. My left thumb peeks out and Madam Kwon pauses the music with a hand flick. She looks through the mirror, straight at me, not blinking. She walks between the lines to my X, and I fight every instinct not to step back. She lifts my left hand, presses my thumb in against my palm with one finger. It’s a small correction, which somehow feels like she pressed a stamp into me. “No freestyle in fingers,” she says, English crisp, a cut. “You leak everywhere.” I nod. The clock says 01:51:02. We start again. The opening crawl—step-together, hit, hit—beams through my quads. The third eight-count features a ripple: starting at the left-most dancer in front, through my line, we send a wave of chest pops on counts one-and-two-and to the right-most in back. The timing is mathematically neat: each pop is on an eighth note subdivided into two even sixteenth hits, one-and, two-and. In the cyphers, we ripple when we feel it, when someone’s pocket pulls you. Here, the tempo marks us like stitches. My chest wants to snake on a triplet: da-da-da. The song is crisp: da-da. “Control your wave,” the assistant says, tapping his own sternum. Madam Kwon stops again. She doesn’t raise her voice. She steps to the front line and rearranges ankles, tilts heads half-degree. When she passes me, she aligns my pelvis with her flat palm, rotates it to the front. “Parallel. No turnout,” she tells me. I’ve opened my feet, habit from footwork patterns that use external rotation to slide—l-kick outs, coffee grinders, swipes. Here, we’re toaster slots. We run the first chorus six more times. Sweat starts to make the floor sticky under my new soles. The mirrors fog at chin height. On the fourth run, the mannequin precision of my forearms is a fight; my scapulae feel like they’ve been taped down. When the choreography calls for a hover—arms extended forward, torso tilted to twenty degrees, knees bent, shoulders set—I accidentally let my shoulders bounce on the backbeat. It’s the tiniest groove, just enough. “Stop,” she says. The room freezes. The clock says 01:37:11. You could hear the electrical hum from the ceiling lights. She stands at center, facing us, four meters from my spot. “You,” she says, and my ear hears the you before my brain hears my name. Tryan. In her mouth, it comes out Try-ahn. “Step here.” I leave my X, my footfalls careful over the tape lines, and stand where she points, a half-meter ahead of the front line’s center mark. She moves my body without asking: a hand on my upper back to raise my sternum, a hand on my rib to press my floating ribs down. “Your movement is…,” she searches for a word, then finds it, “spill.” She steps back. “We do pour.” I know what she means. I’ve built a life on spill. On how hard it can slosh into soft. The kind of roof battles where the wind eats half your music, and you answer with body drips and sudden freezes that are yours, not written. Pour is even, measured. It’s respect to the container. I know if I say any of this out loud, I’ll sound like a brat with a bad attitude and an excuse. “Again,” she says, and the room retreats to a V around me like a funnel. I’m center now but not because I earned it; because I’m a problem. The assistant cues the eight count without music to test my alignment. “Five, six, seven, eight.” I set my feet under me, equal weight, press a line through the crown of my head. The counts come like bullets: one, two, three. On two-and, I nearly let my wrist relax. I catch it. Fingers pressed together, thumb tight. On three, I hit the micro hop, and clamp the bounce before it slides into groove. It feels like holding a sneeze. “Good,” she says at two decibels above whisper. “Now with music.” The track drops its same hi-hat chatter, the bassline walking a straight dotted eighth that never swings. We go from the top, me front and center, them watching through the mirror. I feel exposed and wrong in equal measures, like I’m wearing someone else’s skeleton. We go through the chorus. On the turn—a clean three-step pivot right, weight transferring from right to left, ball-ball-flat—my body screams to drag the last count a hair, to find a micro delay to show I own this space. I lock the count instead. My foot lands exactly on the “four,” and I can hear the assistant’s breath release like he’s afraid of being part of the air. At count seven of the phrase, there’s a body ripple that demands a wave chest out-to-in: sternum forward on seven, mid-ribs on seven-and, belly on eight. Street style wants me to cheat it with a tiny shoulder lift, make the wave mine. Here, my shoulders must stay level. I pull the wave straight through sagittal, no lateral. It hurts to be that clean. We end the chorus in the pose: lunge left, right leg extended back, left arm out like a blade, right arm at ninety degrees overhead, head dropped to the left at a specific angle. My back calf trembles with the holding. I hear my breath too loud against the mic on her face. “Again,” she says. We drill it until the clock reads 01:08:43. Water break is thirty seconds. They count it too. I jog to the wall, uncap my bottle, sip. The boy next to me—Minho, if I remember—doesn’t look at me. No one looks much. We’re all small economies trying not to crash.
