Back on marks. We try the bridge, where the chorus fragments and we travel. The move is a traveling shuffle in unison, three half-steps forward on the diagonal toward stage right while the upper body holds an isolating sequence: head to right on one, center on two, left on three, without the shoulders moving. It’s a body popper’s dream and nightmare: isolation plus locomotion. My muscle memory wants to let my shoulders roll to carry the head. I lock them and feel my traps fight back, a tremor of revolt. My step is too large on the second shuffle; I end up half a foot ahead of my line. “No,” she says. She taps the tape with her foot next to mine. “See the boxes? Hold your space.” We run the carry-over: a floor touch on count six, right hand to the ground, left leg scooping back into a switch, come up by seven-and. In the neighborhood, that’s where the freestyle would blow up. A sweep into a knee spin. A baby freeze to signal the end. Here, the hand just touches, a placeholder, and we’re up. My hand slides too much on the pine cleaner sheen. I overcompensate by gripping, and my wrist complains. I climb up on the eight with too much weight in the ball of my foot. “Heels heavy,” the assistant says. The clock hits 00:47:12, and everything tastes metallic. Madam Kwon starts talking about faces. We have to smile on the chorus, not with teeth—no American grin—but with eyes and cheek lift, jaw soft. The cognitive load of angles and faces makes my brain tilt. She stands in front of me and pinches the apple of my cheek up an inch. “This muscle,” she says. “And eyes awake, not angry.” I want to laugh because where I come from, angry eyes mean you mean it. It’s armor. But she doesn’t joke, and the clock ticks like someone dragging a knife across a floor. We run the entire sequence. I track my spacing like my life depends on it: I stay in my lane, a corridor two feet wide from my X to the mirror, and when we travel, I maintain the diagonal relative to Minho in front of me. At the chorus, we fan out to a wide formation; I step to the side exactly one-and-a-half tape tiles, heel aligning with the second tape line. My arm arcs cut clean across the girl at my right shoulder without grazing her. On the closing hit, our legs line like dominoes in a snap. The mirror shows a machine built of humans. And I feel something—fear? The thrill inside it is sharp and thin. If I get good at this, if I sand myself down enough, the things that spill out of me might dry. The boys back home who pop with me under bridges, who let the third count stretch because it feels good, who clap when a beat drops and you answer with a goofy, ungodly groove—where does that live in a lunge with a knife-hand? The scholarship bought me plane tickets and a bed and a future. Maybe it also bought my voice. We hit a section with a short break, music drops to just the hi-hats, and there’s a moment where Madam Kwon watches me. Not my body—my eyes. She tilts her head one centimeter. The assistant gives the count. “Three, four…” I know the next move cold: chest isolate twice, step-step, arm hit. The rest of the line will go perfect. No one will notice if I add nothing. I could relax my wrists, let a drip run through the elbow, let the chest wave linger a hair, make it me. Or I could keep everything poured into the container and prove I belong, no questions, at the cost of learning to keep my own taste out of it. The clock reads 00:31:05. My heart is a stomp pad. My breath hits my teeth. “Five, six, seven, eight,” the assistant counts. On one, I lock. Spine stacked. My sternum pops on the exact millisecond the hi-hat ticks. On the and, I let the wave carry a fraction longer, so small no one with a stopwatch could catch it, but I feel the extra half-glide in my skin. On two, my weight shifts to the ball of my right foot and my left foot traces an invisible circle the choreography never drew—no travel. My hips stay square. I pack the mischief into an internal groove, a rhythm inside the rib cage. On three, my arms slice out like razor blades, thumb still tucked, fingers tight. And on four, when my head turns to the mirror, my eyes don’t smile. My cheeks lift. My jaw softens. There’s a spark behind it that is mine, that doesn’t apologize. We finish, hold the ending pose, the silence after like a choke. Madam Kwon doesn’t move at first. She walks to the console. Time continues to evaporate on the wall. She doesn’t look at me directly when she speaks. “Better,” she says. Then, a bare flick of her eyes toward mine in the mirror. “You find container. Do not break formation. But do not become empty.” It’s not praise. It’s a condition. We run it again. If anyone sees my private rebellion measured in half-frames, no one says a word. My calves burn. My shoulders ache. My fingers stay pressed together, no leaks. The machine chews and I decide to jam a tooth into a gear—not enough to break it. Enough to feel where I am in it. The clock hits 00:00:02, 00:00:01, 00:00:00. And in that precise second where everything in the room stops, where bodies hover suspended in the end pose like they were hung that way all night, I feel both terrified and alive. The doors I walked through might shut behind me, but for now, I’m on my mark, in the light, counting down and counting myself.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the experience of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood navigating the rigid environment of an elite K-pop training academy. The piece excels in its physical coherence, tracking movements with precision throughout the studio setting. The author maintains exceptional spatial awareness, describing the protagonist's position in the formation, the specific angles of body parts, and the exact timing of movements. The contrast between the narrator's fluid, improvisational style and the mechanical precision demanded by the academy is vividly portrayed. The internal struggle is effectively communicated through phrases like "I've built a life on spill" versus "Pour is even, measured." Technical terminology effectively highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, with terms like "tutting," "chest pops," "ripple," "isolation," and "wave" accurately representing both dance worlds. The narrative excels at showing how muscle memory betrays the protagonist. Moments like "My chest wants to snake on a triplet: da-da-da. The song is crisp: da-da" and "I've opened my feet, habit from footwork patterns that use external rotation to slide" demonstrate the physical challenges of adapting to a new style. The writing maintains kinetic clarity throughout, allowing readers to visualize exactly how bodies move through space. The protagonist's internal monologue effectively reveals culture shock ("The first thing that hits me is how clean everything is"), class anxiety (noting their "haircut I did myself before the scholarship came through"), and the threatening realization that success might mean losing their authentic movement voice ("If I get good at this, if I sand myself down enough, the things that spill out of me might dry"). The crucial decision point comes when the protagonist must choose whether to conform or rebel, ultimately finding a middle ground: "I pack the mischief into an internal groove, a rhythm inside the rib cage." This resolution feels authentic to the character's journey without being overly simplistic. The prose is elegant and precise, with vivid sensory details and effective use of dance-specific language. The pacing mirrors the rehearsal, creating tension as the clock counts down. The ending strikes a balanced note of determination and uncertainty that feels earned. A few minor weaknesses: there's limited dialogue, though what exists serves the narrative well. The piece occasionally uses slightly overwrought metaphors ("My heart is a stomp pad"), but these instances are rare and generally fit the narrator's voice. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted response that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt with technical precision and emotional depth. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Gothic-fantasy-humour: Court of the Dreaming — Score: 93.7
Prompt:
Court of the Dreaming: Territorial Dream Dispute. Write a dark fantasy scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream where a case is being heard to determine ownership of a contested dreamscape. Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit who sits on sleepers' chests causing paralysis and terror, has recently invaded and subverted a carefully crafted recurring dream of a schoolboy, Max. The dream originally featured the boy lying in a field of wildflowers with his crush, always culminating in a muddled almost-kiss and a pleasant confusion of emotions. This dream was the meticulous work of "First Love" (a rosy-cheeked, slightly bashful entity who crafts formative romantic experiences). However, Mora has recently infiltrated the dreamscape, transforming the scene so that when the girl playfully mounts the boy, she morphs into a terrifying yet somehow still confusingly attractive vision who proceeds to sit on his chest and feed on his breath. Mora's defense largely consists of the practical argument that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" Write this scene as it unfolds in the courtroom of the Dreaming, with Dream's demeanour, typically impenetrable, betraying a sense of irritation at having to adjudicate such matters. The comedy should derive from the farcical situation, familiar elements of courtroom drama intersecting with the fantastical world of the Dreaming, and the droll portrayal of the characters and their interactions. The humor should be dark and understated throughout. Dream is tempted to some mischief in the resolution of the case. Use descriptives sparingly when setting scene. Write for readability & engagement. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Court of the Dreaming convened in a long hall of no clear length, hung with veils that shifted to suggest rivers, highways, inner monologues, diaries, the weather. The benches were occupied by the drowsy silhouettes of past litigants and sleeping jurists who would never be called. A bailiff in the shape of an hourglass with eyes thumped its own belly and announced, "All rise," even though some were already floating. Dream sat at the bench that also served as the horizon. He was pale and thin as a punctuation mark, hair a black scribble that the ceiling couldn't quite contain. He regarded the room with a patience so still it was almost a threat. He would have liked to be somewhere else—whittling a comet, perhaps, or unpicking a tyrant’s nightmare—anything but dream traffic court. To his left, First Love stood on tiptoe to be seen. Rosy cheeks, sweater vest, a polite awkwardness that made the air around him slightly warmer and more vulnerable. He clutched a folder—photos of sunsets, mixtapes, damp notes pulled from pockets, a library receipt for a book never returned. At his side lay a field of wildflowers pressed neatly into paperwork. To his right lounged Mora. She wore shadows the way some people wore jewelry—casually, as though it were all inevitable. She smelled faintly of night sweats and wet wool. Her grin showed nothing at all but her teeth implied the moon. She emitted a thin cackle that skittered up the pillars and got lost beneath the arches, returning a moment later, embarrassed to be overheard. When she moved, you felt a weight any mirror would deny. At the witness dais sat Max, a schoolboy shaped out of lint and whisper, his head tilted as if listening for a bell that hadn't rung yet. He kept glancing toward the door as though it knew something he didn't. "We are here," Dream said, "to hear the matter of the contested dreamscape of Maximilian of Room 3B. The complaint is filed by First Love, patron of formative blushes. The defense will be offered by Mora of the press and the paralysis. The Court recognizes neither time nor embarrassment, but we will attempt to be brief." The hourglass coughed and dribbled some minutes. First Love cleared his throat like a violinist tuning. "Your Lordship of the Endless Dream, this is simple: I initiated a recurring dream sequence for Max, age fifteen, appropriate to developmental stage. We had an agreed scenario: pastoral field, sunset at the mild end of rose. The girl’s laughter is the leitmotif, the almost-kiss is the unanswered question that teaches patience, vulnerability, hope. We were building a gentle cliff. Every Tuesday and on days he smelled laundry detergent. It was working. Grade-A overwrought heart-thumping, no permanent damage. And then," he flapped the folder open, scattering petals and exclamation points, "she sits on his chest, grows claws, red eyes, and—pardon me—moans. Max wakes thinking he may be into something he is not yet prepared to manage. Worse, he can't move or breathe. My sequence is out of key." Mora rolled her shoulders in satisfaction, emitting another faint cackle that ricocheted off the upper balcony, startled a flock of geese that had been dreaming of being jurors, and returned as an apologetic hiccup. "A girl's gotta eat too, you know?" she said, in a voice like a cool hand on a fever. "He was lying flat on his back in a meadow—do you know what that says to my demographic? Like putting a sign in the window. Open for business. You crafted him like a crème brûlée—crackable on top, trembling underneath. You expect me to walk on by? I am not made of fog." "It is not—" First Love began, flushing deeper. "It was not an invitation to predation. It was an invitation to tenderness. We were in Act Two of a five-act arc." "Five acts?" Mora snorted. "What is this, opera? He is fifteen. He barely survives gym class. He would have died of suspension alone." Dream steepled his fingers. The gesture quieted the geese. "Max," he said, turning to the boy, "tell the Court what you dream." Max was the sound of a chair scritching along linoleum, the smell of pencil shavings. "It's... I’m in this field. She’s there. She looks like how she looks in Chemistry but more like she would if I were braver. We lie down. We laugh. I forget my hands. We, uh, almost kiss. I wake up feeling like I know a secret I'm not allowed to keep." He faltered. "Then sometimes—lately—she’s... heavy. On my chest. I can’t move. Her hair’s in my mouth. It's terrifying. And also, I guess..." He caught First Love’s glare and flinched. "Confusing. I feel dumb afterward. And awake. Very awake." Mora beamed. It was like watching a cat pretend to be the moon. "See? Nutrition and education. A balanced breakfast." First Love pressed his folder to his sternum. "He is a child. You are a nightmare. You frighten and feed. That is your function. But you have no license to repurpose the architecture of a crafted formative experience. There is etiquette. Unspoken, but binding." "Etiquette." Mora rolled the word on her tongue. "I prefer 'instinct.' And I do have a sort of license. An ancestral one. Ask the old women of winter villages. Ask anyone who's slept on their back." "Objection," First Love said quickly, because it felt like something one should say in a courtroom. "Relevance?" "Overruled," Dream said, because it felt like something he should say. He pinched the bridge of his nose infinitesimally. "Proceed." Mora tugged at the hem of the dream, making an edge curl. "Your Sovreignty of Somnolence, I don't ask for exclusive rights. I just slid in for a taste. The boy's field? Fertile. The girl's eyes? Already pools. I didn’t break the toy. I shook it." "She unthreads sequences," First Love said, scandalized. "He now associates breathlessness with anticipation. He will chase danger to feel the first thing again. I built him a swing and she greased the chain. He will fall and think it is flying." "He will learn to ask for air," Mora said, suddenly almost gentle. "He will learn to push, to name heaviness, to say 'off' and mean it. Not my fault if he also discovers a fondness for bruises. I am not the curriculum coordinator. I teach what I am." Max slid lower in his seat as if the floor might be the right answer. Dream’s expression did not change, except to alter in all the ways that meant he was annoyed. There were kingdoms that rose and fell in the time he did not sigh. He examined the dreamscape as one might examine a bruise: academically, then personally. "You," he said to First Love, "claim authorship and intention. You," to Mora, "claim need and custom. The boy claims breathing." The Court felt colder; a star dimmed briefly. "I am not a moralist," Dream continued. "I am a gardener. I prune for shape, not virtue. Still." He leaned forward, and the horizon leaned with him. "I do not enjoy tidying the plates after your feasts." The hourglass-bailiff attempted a cough; time sputtered, then resumed. From the gallery, a deep sigh like wind through corn. Desire had stepped in, unseen, then almost all the way seen, and then vanished again, because it was an excellent way to be invited back later. "Max," Dream said, voice softening only if you had known him for a thousand years. "Do you wish for the field?" Max swallowed. He looked at First Love, whose smile trembled, and at Mora, whose smile did no such thing. "Yes," he said. "And also I wish to breathe. And also I don't want to be boring." The last came out in a rush, a confession to the cosmos. First Love shut his eyes in relief and pain. Mora laughed under her breath, and the pillars stiffened as if their legs had fallen asleep. "Then," Dream said, "we will draft a boundary." He raised a hand. The air above his palm turned to parchment made of fog. Words appeared in ink that smelled like rain and chalk dust. "Ruling: The dreamscape in question shall remain primarily under the custodianship of First Love. The meadow shall be restored to original intention: laughter, grass, inhalations in purple twilight, the almost-kiss like a held note that hurts a little. Permission to hover is granted." First Love nodded fervently. "Mora," Dream continued, "is granted a seasonal visitation. Night of storm, nights when the boy falls asleep on his back with homework crusted to his face, winter Sundays when fear tastes like coins. She may sit on his chest, feed on the edges of his breath." He raised an eyebrow, a flicker of the mischief he tried not to indulge. "But she must wear the girl’s face only by halves. No full morphs. Keep the teeth metaphorical. She may not alter the memory of consent." Mora's head tilted, a predator considering a leash. "And in exchange?" she asked, even though he hadn't offered anything. "In exchange," Dream said, too quickly, annoyed with himself, "you will refrain from nesting in the boy’s accumulated laundry, which you have been doing. It is unsanitary." Mora's grin faltered, then spread. "Fine," she said. "But if he leaves socks on the radiator, I make no promises." First Love seemed ready to object to something on principle, then thought better of it. "And the almost-kiss?" he asked, softly. Dream tapped the parchment. "Shall be occasionally a kiss. Not always. Rarely enough to ring like a bell down a decade. And—" He allowed himself the smallest of smirks, enjoyed it so briefly he might have denied it later. "On those rare nights, she will taste like peppermint lip balm and cold air, and the boy will wake thinking he has learned a secret he can keep." A soft murmur went through the gallery, a rustle of pens in diaries that would be read in thirty years. Max smiled, surprised at the feeling of his own shoulders. Mora emitted a cackle that slipped up the rafters, startled the moon into losing a button, and came back sounding like applause. It made everyone uncomfortable for exactly the right length of time. "Finally," Dream said, as if he had not just amused himself, "no feeding during gymnasium anxiety dreams, math test dreams, or the recurring 'teeth falling out while onstage in underwear' scenario. That buffet is closed to you, Mora." "Puritan," Mora said, without heat. "Fine." "Objection," said no one. Dream rolled the fog parchment. It vanished into his sleeve and became something a future poet would call a "feeling you recognize when you sit in a dark theater before the movie starts." "Case concluded," he said. "Do not make me see you again on this matter. I am patient, but boredom is a kind of violence I do not forgive." They began to disperse. The geese congratulated one another on their restraint. The hourglass-bailiff tripped and spilled a week, which ran under the benches and made everything smell briefly of late August. Max lingered, fiddling with the string on his hoodie. "Um," he said. Dream looked down and became, for a moment, a window onto a lake at four a.m. "Thank you," Max said, almost to the lake. "Also, if you could, uh, make it so my mom stops walking in right when I'm about to—" "No," Dream said, with an authority that ended empires. "That is not my jurisdiction." He paused, then, because mischief again tempted him, because the boy’s earnestness was a planet with its own gravity. "But I will insure the door hinges dream of oil." Max blinked, smiled, and vanished into a bell ringing somewhere else. First Love gathered his papers, pressing the wildflowers back into place. Mora rose in a sigh that made the ceiling feel lower and then again normal. She nodded toward Dream with a tilt complicated by gratitude and appetite. "Try the attic dreams in the blue house," Dream said, already regretting speaking. "Plenty of dust. No hearts in progress." Mora cackled, soft as moths, and the sound went up, around, through, back, and finally out, leaving the Court feeling as if it had been lightly pressed. "A girl's gotta eat," she said again, almost apologetic now. "I am aware," Dream said. The Court closed. The horizon folded away. The veils remembered how to be weather. Dream sat alone for an extra second he did not possess and allowed himself one small sigh that, somewhere, made a dandelion go to seed. Then he rose to go mischief elsewhere. The door hinges of Room 3B dreamed a little oil, and, for once, took it as a compliment.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkable achievement in dark fantasy with comedic elements. The author has created a richly imagined courtroom scene in the Courts of Dream that perfectly balances the fantastical with the mundane, creating humor through the juxtaposition of bureaucratic proceedings with cosmic entities. The characterization is exceptional. Dream is portrayed with appropriate gravitas and subtle irritation, maintaining his canonical demeanor while showing hints of mischief. First Love is endearingly earnest, while Mora is delightfully predatory yet pragmatic. The descriptions are economical yet evocative—Dream as "pale and thin as a punctuation mark," Mora wearing "shadows the way some people wore jewelry," and Max as "a schoolboy shaped out of lint and whisper." The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinct voice that reflects their nature. Mora's practical "A girl's gotta eat too, you know?" contrasts beautifully with First Love's more formal, concerned tone. The exchanges feel natural while maintaining the otherworldly quality appropriate to these entities. The author skillfully weaves humor throughout without undermining the dark fantasy elements. Mora's cackle that "ricocheted off the upper balcony, startled a flock of geese that had been dreaming of being jurors, and returned as an apologetic hiccup" exemplifies this balance of the comedic and the eerie. The resolution is satisfying and consistent with the characters. Dream's judgment feels fair yet mischievous, and the final image of him making "door hinges dream of oil" is both practical and poetic—a perfect encapsulation of the piece's tone. The prose flows naturally throughout, with varied sentence structures that create rhythm without calling attention to themselves. Metaphors are fresh and appropriate to the dreamlike setting: "He examined the dreamscape as one might examine a bruise: academically, then personally." If there's any criticism to be made, it might be that some readers could find a few descriptions slightly purple ("a feeling you recognize when you sit in a dark theater before the movie starts"), but these moments are rare and generally serve the dreamlike quality of the setting. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that fulfills all the requirements of the prompt while creating a genuinely engaging, imaginative, and well-crafted story. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Blood Moon — Score: 93.2
Prompt:
Blood Moon Alucard & Yennefer Write a story where Alucard (Hellsing) encounters Yennefer (The Witcher) in medieval Europe. Yennefer's magical abilities intrigue the vampire, while she's both repulsed and fascinated by his monstrous nature. Their power dynamic shifts constantly as they circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first. **Alucard (Hellsing)** Alucard is an ancient, immensely powerful vampire who works for the Hellsing Organization. He can regenerate from almost any wound and shape-shift at will. He's sadistic, arrogant, and takes pleasure in toying with his enemies before killing them. Despite being a monster, he despises weak vampires who can't accept their nature. He wears a distinctive red coat, wide-brimmed hat, and orange sunglasses. He uses massive handguns loaded with silver bullets. He seeks worthy opponents who can challenge him and potentially end his immortal existence. Famous quote: "The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame." **Yennefer of Vengerberg (The Witcher)** Yennefer is a powerful sorceress who magically altered her appearance to hide her congenital hunchback. She's ambitious, stubborn, and manipulative when necessary. She has violet eyes and smells of lilac and gooseberries. Despite her cold exterior, she desperately wants to reverse her infertility caused by magical transformation. She's centuries old but appears young. She's politically savvy and refuses to be underestimated. She has a sarcastic sense of humor and little patience for fools. Though she rarely shows it, she's capable of deep love and loyalty. Famous quote: "I'm not sweet and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The harvest moon rises swollen and red over the empty village, spilling a wine-dark sheen over slanted thatch and the upturned ribs of broken wagons. Doors hang ajar, windows gape toothless. A black dog whines once and vanishes beneath a stoop. The wind lifts ash and the sweet-sour breath of graves. He walks the main street as if through a memory, coat stirred as though in a tide, hat brim cutting the lunar shine. The smoked orange of his glasses burn with twin coals in the gloom. His boots crunch glass, bone, a weathered rosary. He tips his head to the sign that swings, creaking: a moon eaten by a bird. “The bird of Hermes is my name,” he says to the signboard, to the night. His smile is a slash. “Eating my wings to make me tame.” “Birds don’t fare well under the moon,” a woman’s voice answers, smooth as a drawn blade. He stops. Blood runs downhill toward him like a tongue. He turns, and there she is in the mouth of the square: the sorceress in the storybook he never read, violet eyes like bruised stars, hair spilling black and lustrous over the stark white of a fur-lined collar. She seems to distill the moonlight, to condense it on her cheekbones, a pale geometry of danger. The scent of lilac and gooseberries ghosts the broken square. He shows his teeth. “And witches fare better?” She steps forward, heels clicking on cobble. “Sorceresses. If you can manage not to choke on the syllables.” The village well stands between them, old stones rippled by time, the bucket half-spooled and frozen. He feels the power move with her—the pricking of his skin, the burrowing cold down his bones. A ripple that reminds him of the sea and no water. She feels him the way one feels a thunderhead: the pressure, the itch, a taste of metal on the tongue and something older that drags the spine toward a bow. “Alucard,” she says, and does not bow. “Hellsing’s bloodhound. I’d wondered what the fuss was about. I expected taller.” “And I expected horns,” he replies mildly. “Or a broom. Names are tethers, aren’t they? You know mine. Who tethers you?” Her mouth curves, humor without warmth. “Yennefer of Vengerberg. If you must,” she adds when the amusement in his face deepens. “You find that funny?” “I find all old things funny. It is how we keep from crying.” He lifts a hand in mock elegance. The glove flashes as his arm lengthens, fingers stretching, leather creaking, then contracts with a hiss and a click of bone. “You do smell as the tales say.” “Do I? You smell like a charnel pit someone set on fire.” She doesn’t blink as his hand returns to normal. “There was a nest here. Vampires. Weak ones. You know how I feel about weak things who hurt for sport.” He tilts his head. Somewhere down the street a piece of a door gives way and clatters, sending up a feather of ash. “I removed the nest. They were tedious. They mewled. It offended me.” “Hmm.” She takes another step, and the temperature drops by a degree, a ripple that makes the air sing like glass. Her gaze moves like a knife over the ground, over the licked-clean stones. “Then we are in agreement. Almost unprecedented.” He comes to the well, lays a hand on the old stones, and peers down into the dark. There is no water; there is only a depth that promises teeth. “Agreement suggests alliance.” He looks up with the ease of a wolf. “Do you need saving, maiden?” “I’m not sweet,” she says, violet eyes sharpening, “and I’m not a maiden in distress in need of saving.” He laughs, a low-lidded, delighted sound. “Good. Saving is dull.” He steps onto the lip of the well. She doesn’t flinch, though he can tell she wants to track the blur. He pivots so one long leg dangles into the dark, the red of his coat stark against the old stone. The moon paints him like a saint in a bad icon. He could have put the muzzle of one of his handguns to her heart from here, could have disassembled her with silver and zeal. He doesn’t. He waits. “Why are you here?” she asks. Her voice is bored. It’s a lie, spun thin. “Because the moon is red, and the dead make the best music.” His grin hardens, edges honed on old cruelty. “Because I heard of a black-haired woman with eyes the color of bruises and thought: finally, something to sharpen my teeth on. Because I am done with weak family. They were so certain they were monsters. They were not.” “And you are?” she asks. He watches the swirl of invisible threads gather on her fingers, the way light bends infinitesimally at her wrist. There is a sigil there, worked a thousand times, and she is most beautiful when she is arithmetic. He slides off the well and onto the square. “I am what happens when something refuses to die so long that the idea of death begins to be jealous.” “Jealousy is petty,” she says. But he hears the tremor under it, the chord he has plucked by accident or design. What does a woman centuries old long for that he can taste? Absence. A life that did not happen. A borrowed womb that will not answer. “You smell also of longing,” he says conversationally. “Gooseberries and absence. That is a cruel combination.” Her eyes narrow just enough. The well-chain rattles as if in a sudden gust. “You’re not the first creature that’s tried to sniff out my secrets.” “And eaten,” he says, rolling his shoulders as if to shake off cobweb. “Or survived? The rumor didn’t say.” The magic moves fully. It does not erupt; it unveils. A circle hums into being at her feet like frost traced fast. The dead wax peels. The lilac deepens, becomes cutting. He chuckles as a swarm of black-veiled tendrils climb his legs, cold as standing water. They pin his coat against his thighs. The ground grits under the weight of their insistence. “Show me what you are without the coat, old thing,” Yennefer says. Her voice is nothing now but blade. He relaxes. The tendrils find purchase and lift him, and for one heartbeat she feels triumph, because power has leaned and he has yielded. He lets his outline blur. The coat hangs a heartbeat empty, the hat floats like an idea, then skulls open like lily blossoms along his spine, wet and obscene and smiling. “Ah,” she says, pushed back a step despite herself. “That.” A spike of shadow thrusts up from the square and she meets it with a curt snap of fingers; glass walls flower around her from air; they hiss as his shadow points pierce, slide, knit; she gestures and the glass becomes slices of absolute cold. He grins with six mouths and bites at the spell, and his tongue smokes where it touches the frost. He shudders in delight. “Yes,” he says from everywhere. “Yes, little star. More.” Yennefer’s laugh is a brittle ornament. The tendrils around his legs tighten until even his immortal bones complain. She pulls, and the village shifts with her, the stones slurring, the whole square an opening jaw. “Careful what you ask for.” He lets himself be dragged and reforms inside his own collapse, standing with his boots in the heart of the sigil, coat steady, glasses in place. The complaining chains still. He has not moved, and yet he has disappointed the space he occupies, which wanted to be occupied by his undoing. It is a small insult. He savors it. “You’re not the only one who learned to be more than her body,” Yennefer says into the quiet. And there it is: a shard of bone-white truth thrown at him like a favor. He tips his hat. The brim cuts a red crescent out of the moonlight. “Taught by pain? My favorite teacher. She is stern.” “Pain is tedious.” Her voice is breathless now only because she has spent something. Sweat beads at her hairline and gleams like dew on iron. “Its lessons repeat.” “Then graduate,” he suggests. “Or repeat until you forget why you started.” “You’ve forgotten?” she says. And there is the edge of a knife in it. “No,” he says, softly. The hat’s shadow hides his smile for a breath. “I am very diligent.” They circle. The wind rises and the fur at her collar ripples like a sea. His coat licks the dust. He lifts one of the massive guns, the black length of it swallowing moonlight, six engraved sigils crawling faintly. He does it lazily, like a man lifting a wine bottle. He points it nowhere and everywhere, and she can feel the threat in it because threat is not the bullet but the intent. He lowers it again. “I’d rather not shoot a woman who can make me amuse myself,” he says. “Flattered,” she deadpans. “It’s rare to be considered a fool’s entertainment.” “Not a fool.” He flashes teeth. “A monster.” “On that we agree,” she says, and this time there is no lie in it. The square breathes, or perhaps it is the night. The red moon leans. Somewhere a bellless church imagines sound. “What do you want?” he asks, teeth clicking, head canted like a fox, like a question mark. She considers lying. It would be easy. She has lied longer than anyone in this village has been dead. But she has already invited truth into the square, and it is rude to slam the door on a guest. “I want,” Yennefer says, each word with weight, “what I was denied. I want to change the rules. I want a thing that cannot be had.” “And you think I relate,” he says. He taps one gloved finger against his collarbone, where somewhere in the skin something old is sealed. “The thing you want and the thing I want might meet on a road.” “You want to die,” she says, flat. He shrugs a shoulder, graceful. The leather squeaks. “Sometimes. Or to be surprised. You’ve done something like that. The surprise. It is rare.” “Don’t wag your tail yet,” she says. The retort is easy, an old skin. “I haven’t decided what to do with you.” “You cannot do anything with me that I do not also do with you,” he says, pleased. “That,” she murmurs, almost smiling, “sounds like a promise no one asked for.” They stand with the well between them, everything red and brittle around the edges. He lifts his face to the moon and inhales like a man before a plunge. “Shall we make a game of it?” he suggests lightly. “You try to hurt me. I try to make you admit you enjoyed it.” “Half of that is unnecessary.” Her violet eyes gleam. “You are arrogant.” “Arrogance is a kind of hunger,” he says. “You have it too.” Her magic hums again, but softer this time, not an axe but a harp. The frost re-traces itself as a lace at her cuff. “We could help each other,” she says, very carefully, as if assembling a labyrinth in air. “In a manner of speaking.” He regards her over the rim of his glasses. He can see the organs in her chest if he wishes, the small bird of her heart beating bruised and stubborn. He does not. It would be rude. “Ah,” he says softly. “Politics.” “Possibilities,” she corrects. “Don’t pretend the word scares you.” “Nothing scares me,” he says. It is, for once, not entirely a lie; what he means by fear is not what others mean. “Even the thought of never finding your equal?” she says, as if idly adjusting a ring that is not there. He laughs, abrupt and delighted, as if she had reached into him and tickled a rib. “There,” he says. “A cut.” The wind lifts again, hard this time, whipping her cloak and slapping the hat brim up to show his eyes. For an instant the orange glasses catch the crimson and throw it, two coins tossed upward and caught. He tips his head as if listening to a tune only he can hear. “Tonight,” he says, “I am not your equal. You are not mine. But we are not bored, and that is something.” She inclines her head a fraction, the acknowledgment a jewel stingy and real. “Don’t stalk me,” she says. “Impossible,” he lies. “I will loiter.” She turns then, cloak snapping, the smell of lilac and gooseberries like a signature. She walks away down the slain street into the deeper dark. She does not look back. He dismisses the guns in a whisper of steel and shadow, puts his hands in his coat pockets, and begins to whistle some graveyard tune that learned to be jaunty to keep from breaking. The harvest moon watches them both, low and leering, and the shadows of the deserted village lean after them like hands that almost touch and never quite do. The blood runs down the street and disappears into the thirsty earth, which is patient and takes everything eventually. He steps after her without hurry, and if the distance between them closes, it is only because the night is small and the world is old and certain conversations echo longer than the first words spoken. He smiles up at the moon as though at a long joke, and the moon bares its teeth back, and they go on under it, each a knife in the other’s pocket neither has decided to use.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkable character study that brings together two powerful figures from different fictional universes. The author has crafted an atmospheric encounter between Alucard and Yennefer that captures the essence of both characters while creating a tense, psychologically complex interaction. The writing excels in its atmospheric quality. The opening description of the "harvest moon... swollen and red" over an empty village immediately establishes the gothic tone. The author consistently maintains this atmosphere throughout, with vivid sensory details like "the sweet-sour breath of graves" and Yennefer's scent of "lilac and gooseberries." The imagery is consistently strong, creating a cinematic quality that allows readers to visualize this supernatural confrontation. Character portrayal is exceptional. Both Alucard and Yennefer are rendered with fidelity to their source material while being seamlessly integrated into this new context. Alucard's sadistic playfulness, his arrogance, and his desire for worthy opponents are all present. Similarly, Yennefer's cold exterior, magical prowess, and underlying vulnerability regarding her infertility are skillfully woven into the narrative. The author has captured their voices perfectly, with dialogue that feels authentic to both characters. The prose style is sophisticated and poetic without becoming overwrought. Metaphors like "her violet eyes like bruised stars" and "the moon paints him like a saint in a bad icon" are striking without being excessive. The author demonstrates remarkable control over language, using it to enhance the mood and characterization rather than calling attention to itself unnecessarily. The power dynamic between the characters is handled with nuance. As requested in the prompt, they "circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first." Their interaction is a psychological chess match, with each character probing for vulnerabilities while maintaining their guard. The tension between them is palpable, creating a compelling dynamic that drives the narrative forward. Dialogue is a particular strength. The exchanges between Alucard and Yennefer crackle with tension and subtext. Lines like "You're not the only one who learned to be more than her body" reveal character depth while advancing the psychological confrontation. The dialogue feels natural while maintaining the distinctive voices of both characters. The narrative structure is well-crafted, with the confrontation building to a climax before resolving into an uneasy détente. The ending avoids simplistic resolution, instead leaving the characters in a state of mutual wariness and fascination that feels true to who they are. If there are weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally, the prose becomes slightly ornate, though this generally suits the gothic atmosphere. The piece also assumes some familiarity with both characters, which might leave readers unfamiliar with either source material at a slight disadvantage, though the author does provide enough context through the narrative to make the encounter comprehensible. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of crossover fiction that demonstrates a deep understanding of both characters while creating something new and compelling from their interaction. The writing is sophisticated, atmospheric, and psychologically nuanced, making for an engaging and memorable read. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 20 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 20.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 91.3
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A dim overhead light flickers in the prison corridor at irregular intervals, breaking the darkness into slices of hard white and shadow. The air is chilled, bleached clean, like it wants to erase the scent of worry left behind by anyone who’s ever walked through here. Footsteps echo—one set slow and measured, the other tapping with a restless rhythm. Jolyne stares at the figure ahead of her through the bars as her fingers curl, index knuckle cracking a tempo of impatience. The woman is slender, auburn hair tied neatly, a long coat draped with the kind of authority that doesn’t apologize. Yellow ringed eyes soak in details without seeming to move. She stands next to a guard who keeps stealing glances at her, as if measuring, as if flinching. “New warden?” Jolyne asks, deadpan. “Or another freak in a suit trying to make my life interesting?” The woman smiles faintly. It’s the kind of smile Jolyne associates with loan sharks and fake girlfriends. “My name is Makima,” she says. “I’m here to assess threats. You qualify. I heard you can turn yourself into string.” “Stone Free,” Jolyne says, already unwinding a thread from her fingertip, the string gleaming like polished fiber in the wavering light. “You talk like you file people in cabinets.” “People are easy to file,” Makima replies, and the guard beside her nods, his breathing slowing, eyes going slack, like someone dimmed him from the inside. “You’re different. You’re interesting.” Jolyne flexes her jaw. If there’s no Mickey, this shit ain’t Disney. “Lady, I’ve had enough ‘interesting’ to last three lifetimes.” She pulls, and a tight loop of string slides through the lock of the gate with a metallic hiss. The guard doesn’t react. Makima watches Jolyne break into the corridor as if observing a painting. “That’s a poor way to greet a guest,” Makima chides softly. “Guess I’ll call the concierge.” Jolyne steps out. The facility is wrong. This isn’t Green Dolphin Street Prison, not really. The concrete is too smooth. The bars are new. The smell is antiseptic, an aftertaste of something metallic that coats the back of her tongue. The signs are in no language she recognizes, and yet she reads them anyway. And the guard beside Makima—his eyes reflect nothing. Jolyne’s skin prickles. She turns a corner, string slicing the air into tripwires as she goes. Makima follows, her shoes tapping without urgency. The guard falls in behind her like a shadow with a pulse. “When did you realize this isn’t your prison?” Makima asks. “When I realized you were smiling at me like a cat in a cartoon,” Jolyne says. “And that nobody else here blinks unless you let them.” Makima actually blinks at that—slow, appreciative. “You’re perceptive. Not all of you are.” “Us? You collecting people like trading cards?” “I prefer dogs,” Makima says. “They’re simpler. Loyal.” “Try a different word. That one’s making my skin crawl.” The corridor widens into a block of cells with glass fronts instead of bars. Inside one, a nurse sits in a chair, hands folded in her lap. She’s not breathing. Her eyes track Jolyne and Makima, but her chest doesn’t rise. In another cell, a man in a jumpsuit holds his hands up as if in surrender, kneeling to no one. “Let us out,” the man whispers. He doesn’t look at Makima. He can’t. “Please.” “Shut it,” Jolyne snaps without heat, and the man obeys. She doesn’t look away from Makima. “What exactly do you want?” Makima’s smile doesn’t move. Her voice is pleasant, soothing. “To understand how your strings handle pressure.” “You could have just asked.” “People lie,” Makima says. “Sincerity is easiest to procure when it is not optional.” “Is that what you tell yourself so you can sleep at night?” Jolyne tilts her head. “Or do you even bother?” Makima tilts her head in a mirror of Jolyne’s motion, as if considering which answer would disappoint her least. “Sleep is unimportant.” The light flickers. It takes a breath to come back this time. When it does, Jolyne’s threads are everywhere, mapped from floor drains to the hinges of doors, taut lines forming an invisible web. Makima has not stepped around them, but none of the strings touch her. Jolyne notices it like you notice a missing tooth with your tongue. Her threads have a sense, the same way fingertips can feel a ghost of a draft. The air around Makima is still. Not empty—obedient. The world bends. “You’re not human,” Jolyne says, fighting the urge to rub the goosebumps from her forearms. Makima’s expression doesn’t change. The guard’s eyes flick to her, then to the floor. “I didn’t say I was,” she answers. “Does that frighten you?” “It pisses me off.” She pulls. The strings snap taut around Makima’s arms and waist, thread-bands that could restrain a car engine. The guard jerks in front of her like a puppet, and Jolyne’s strings bite into him instead. He doesn’t scream. He doesn’t bleed. He just stops. Makima steps to the right, unbothered, as if the world has politely shifted with her. “You’ll find that intervening bodies are a common courtesy,” Makima says. “It keeps everyone from getting hurt.” Jolyne’s teeth grind. “I’m not ‘everyone.’” She extends Stone Free to full, her body unraveling into a cyclone of strings, spinning herself thin enough to slip through an air grate, slingshotting around, coming out behind Makima with a thin, needle-sharp thread aimed for her temple. The air resists like honey. The needle stops. Jolyne hits the floor and rewinds, her palms skidding on cold tile. Makima turns only her head. “You’re smarter than I expected.” “Don’t talk down to me,” Jolyne snarls. “I told you. I’m not a dog.” “No,” Makima concedes. “You’re a cat. You pretend not to need anyone, and then you curl up in the lap of whoever warms your bones at the right moment.” Jolyne takes a step, then another, strings whispering out to pull grates loose, to tighten sprinklers, to map every path. “Keep talking. It’ll make knocking you out even more satisfying.” Makima’s hands clasp behind her back. “Your father would disagree with your methods, but he’d be proud of your instincts. He’d want you safe. If I asked him, he would come.” “I’d like to see you try,” Jolyne says, but her chest tightens. The thought of Jotaro—his hand on her shoulder, his voice steady even when he’s cold—hits like a sucker punch. Bastard woman, using that. She swallows. “You think I’m going to fall apart because you say ‘dad’? Screw you.” In the cell to the right, the nurse stands up, slow and careful. Jolyne’s string at the corner of her eye flares. She yanks, and the glass splits the air with a shriek as the door slams shut again. “I don’t need you to fall apart,” Makima says. “I need you to be useful. Bring your strings. They’re elegant. I could teach you to control more than thread. I could teach you to pull people the way you pull doors.” “And what? Put collars on my friends? Make them bark?” Jolyne barks out a laugh. “That sounds like hell.” Makima’s eyes warm in a way that isn’t warmth. “Dogs are happiest when they have owners. It’s okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners.” Jolyne’s stomach flips, rage going white-hot. She’s moving before she thinks, body unraveling full, Stone Free blooming behind her, a human silhouette woven from a thousand fibers. She punches. The strings drive forward, forced through the air, denser, sharper. Her knuckles sing with impact as they hit— Darkness. The light dies, plunging the corridor into black. For a heartbeat, Jolyne senses only her own lines, singing through the space like taut harp strings. Then something else hums, deeper, the world thrumming like a throat clearing, like a breath held too long. The light returns. Her fist is embedded an inch deep into the concrete wall where Makima had been. Makima stands three paces away, not a hair out of place. The guard is gone. The cells are empty. The nurse, the kneeling man, the others—gone. “What did you do?” Jolyne demands, breathing hard. Makima’s eyes track Jolyne’s chest rising and falling, calculating. “I asked them to leave. You’d be more comfortable without an audience.” “You ordered them,” Jolyne says. “Like furniture.” “They were happy to be useful.” “I’m going to be sick.” Makima takes a step closer. Jolyne’s threads shiver around her like a living hurricane, every strand ready to cut and bind, to catch and break. “I’m not your enemy, Jolyne,” Makima says, almost tender. “I like you. You are efficient. You are brave. Under the right leash, you would be unstoppable.” Jolyne spits on the floor. “I’d chew through my own tongue before I wear your leash.” Makima’s smile widens, pleased, approving. “I thought you’d say that.” “Then why the song and dance?” “Because it’s polite to offer.” The light flickers again. This time the darkness lingers long enough for Jolyne to feel how the air tightens around her strings, how the world draws taut, as if held in a fist. Her thread sense screams. She dives, body disassembling in a whip-crack as a pressure wave bites the space where her throat was a heartbeat ago. The wall behind her folds inward with a groan. “You’re trying to crush me?” Jolyne asks, rolling into a crouch, Stone Free reknitting her muscles. “I’m trying to see how your strings taste under pressure,” Makima corrects, patient. “I don’t get many chances to play with this kind of texture.” “Lady, get a hobby.” She lashes out again, not at Makima this time, but at the grid in the ceiling, at the electrical lines. Stone Free bites through insulation, rewires, shorts. The lights go mad, strobing faster than thought. In the chaos, Jolyne weaves a cocoon of momentary blindness, threads reflecting and refracting, a micro labyrinth that confuses sight. For a breath, Makima’s attention shifts. Jolyne feels it like an absence of weight. She moves—past her, through a side door, strings guiding her like piano wire. Stone Free pulls locks, drags heavy gates, tangles cameras. The corridors twist but her web is a map that didn’t exist until she wrote it. “Running?” Makima’s voice carries, not loud but everywhere at once. “Cats run. They always come back to the warm spot.” Jolyne grits her teeth. “I’m choosing my battlefield.” She explodes out into an open control hall. Rows of monitors show corridors she’s never walked, empty cells she never wants to see again, a yard under a false sky. The long table in the center is littered with files. A coffee mug sits fresh and steaming. No one is here. No one has ever been here. Jolyne yanks the emergency alarm lever. Sirens rip the silence. She doesn’t expect help. She expects noise. She expects sources of vibration to lean on, currents to ride. Makima steps into the doorway as casually as if she’d been invited. She’s framed by the flickering light like a saint in a cheap painting. “No one is coming,” she says, almost gentle. “This place is for things that belong to me. You could belong to me.” “No thanks,” Jolyne says. “I’ve already got a life.” Makima’s gaze is steady, pitying, the way you look at a stray with matted fur. “You don’t. Not really. But you could have one that’s easier.” “I don’t do ‘easy.’ I do ‘right.’” Makima’s lips part in a sigh, affectionate, like a disappointed mother. “Stubborn.” “And you’re a control freak.” Jolyne rolls her shoulders, feels the hum in the walls and the song of the alarm and her own heartbeat, and for a second she can almost hear her father’s voice telling her to keep her head. She smiles, feral. “Let’s end this before I say something I’ll regret.” Makima nods. “As you wish.” They collide. The room screams. Strings whip, walls buckle, the world tries to close, and Jolyne threads it open, wedge after wedge. Makima advances with patience that feels like doom, every step a hand placed gently on the back of Jolyne’s neck. Jolyne doesn’t give. She improvises, ties the alarm cord to the sprinkler rigs, bursts them. Water falls in sheets, bead-laden threads. The air grows heavy and alive, every droplet a node, every surface connected. Stone Free becomes a web glistening with rain. Makima stops. For the first time, something like curiosity deepens. “Clever.” “Yeah,” Jolyne pants, grinning. “I have my moments.” Makima’s eyes lift to the water. The control room is a hive of paths now, every beat of rain a wire she didn’t make, and for an instant the world isn’t only obedient to Makima—it is busy with Jolyne. The pressure wave comes late. Jolyne rides it, flips the vector, anchors herself to pipes and panels, and hurls that redirected force sideways. The wall caves, the monitors explode, smoke blooms. In the choking fog, Jolyne hears a low laugh. Not cruel. Not warm. Enjoying the puzzle. “You’d make a good pet,” Makima says softly through the dust. “It’s a shame.” “Bite me.” The room clears. Makima is closer than she should be. Her hand lifts, palm out, like she’s about to pat Jolyne’s head. Jolyne snaps backward, strings coiling to yank her body out of reach, but she doesn’t need to. A thought strikes her with the same clarity as a punch: Makima wants the touch to land. She wants to define the dynamic with that gesture. Jolyne doesn’t do what she wants. She cuts sideways, rips a hole through a service hatch with Stone Free, and dives. The hatch slams. The world narrows to a crawling tunnel of concrete and old wires. Jolyne drags herself hand over hand, threads forward like antennae. Behind her, Makima doesn’t chase. She doesn’t need to. She can find people by their obedience. Jolyne grins in the dark. “Good thing I don’t do orders.” She spits a string to the side, digs into the unknown. The facility shifts, geometry bleeding strange, but Jolyne is a prison expert now. That’s the joke. They put her in a cage and she learned every way out. She slithers into a ventilation cavity and stops. Across the grate, in the pale slice of light, Makima stands. Of course she does. She smiles. Of course she does. “You’re persistent,” Makima says. “Cats are.” “Lady, I’m a hurricane with a manicure.” Makima’s head tilts. “I’ll see you again.” “Not if I see you first,” Jolyne says, because there’s no better vow here. Makima’s smile flickers, a flare of true interest. Then the lights go out one final time, deeper than before, a blackout that tears the world—and when they return, the grate is empty. The corridor beyond is just a corridor. The nurse is not there. The man is not there. The coffee is cold. Jolyne breathes, long and slow. She rewinds herself, sits up, elbows on knees. Her hands shake. She stares at the wet web of her strings and watches water run along them like veins, like a circulatory system she built to keep herself alive. “Makima,” she mutters to the empty air, tasting the name like a warning, like a splinter under her skin. “Next time, I’m bringing friends.” The overhead light flickers at irregular intervals. Jolyne grins at it like it’s a challenge and rises, threads trailing like a cape. She chooses a direction and moves, mapping, unafraid, a needle in her own compass. Behind her, in rooms she has already left, a soft voice echoes as if from a dream. I’ll see you again. And the air waits, obedient and patient, for the next command it will refuse to give her.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This story effectively captures the confrontation between Jolyne Cujoh and Makima in a supernatural prison setting. The writer demonstrates a strong understanding of both characters, maintaining their canonical personalities and abilities throughout the narrative. The prose is particularly strong in its atmospheric quality. The opening description of the flickering prison light immediately establishes the unsettling tone. The writer employs vivid sensory details throughout, from the "bleached clean" air to the way Makima's presence affects the environment. The imagery is consistently evocative without becoming excessive. Character portrayal is one of the story's strongest elements. Jolyne's hot-headed, defiant nature comes through in both her actions and dialogue ("Lady, I've had enough 'interesting' to last three lifetimes"). Her canonical quote is naturally integrated. Similarly, Makima's false sweetness masking cold manipulation is perfectly captured, especially in lines like "Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." The writer shows a deep understanding of what makes these characters tick. The dialogue is sharp and character-appropriate. Jolyne's crude, confrontational speech patterns contrast effectively with Makima's soft-spoken but menacing tone. Their verbal sparring reveals character and advances the plot simultaneously. The battle of wits and powers is well-executed, with each character using their abilities in creative ways. The writer demonstrates a thorough understanding of Stone Free's string capabilities and Makima's control powers. The action sequences are dynamic and clearly visualized, particularly the water-sprinkler strategy Jolyne employs. The story maintains tension throughout, with a natural escalation as Jolyne realizes the true nature of the prison and Makima's intentions. The pacing is excellent, alternating between tense confrontation and moments of revelation. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Occasionally, a metaphor might be slightly overextended ("a hurricane with a manicure"), but these moments are rare and don't detract significantly from the overall quality. The ending leaves things somewhat unresolved, though this is appropriate for a character confrontation that could naturally continue beyond this single encounter. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that demonstrates a deep understanding of both source materials while creating something that stands on its own as an engaging narrative. The writer balances character, atmosphere, and action expertly while maintaining a consistent voice throughout. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-████ Object Class: Pending (see Addendum) Special Containment Procedures: All handwritten notes attributed to Dr. E. [REDACTED] (Site-19, Applied Temporal Studies) shall be collected, catalogued, and stored in a secure document locker under double-key access. Dr. [REDACTED] is restricted from unsupervised access to stationary, printers, and blank Foundation memorandum pads. Onsite psychology and counter-memetics teams will conduct weekly evaluations. Exposure of additional personnel to the notes is limited to clearance-level necessity while counter-memetic screens are updated. Description: On ██/██/20██, I began finding handwritten notes in my office during routine work hours. The handwriting matched my own to a 96.3% confidence score, and the notes—including those found in secure environments—were always written on standard Foundation memorandum paper (Form-7F, blue border, watermark “Sine Timore”). Even when I locked all memo paper away, sealed in a safe, or replaced stock with non-Foundation notepads, any new note I found was on Form-7F. Preliminary analyses showed the paper fibers, watermark alignment, and printer-ink artifacts matched Site-19’s central stock. I will reproduce portions of my log interspersed with excerpts of the notes, as ordered, to enable both temporal and psychological review. Day 1: I was calibrating the chronometric lattice for SCP-3412 cross-testing when I saw a folded sheet under my keyboard. Note A: You hear it later than I did. Don’t ignore the alarms. Go to B-Corridor, bulkhead 3, before 14:12. Seal it from the inside. If you see Kline, don’t let him talk. I checked the security feed. No one had entered my office that morning, and the cleaning crew had clocked out two hours prior. 14:12 came and went without incident. I stayed at my desk, pretending not to glance at the door every thirty seconds. No breach. Kline stopped by at 15:20 to ask about an equipment requisition. He talked at length. Security flagged the note as a hoax. I was told to keep it and report any further anomalies. Day 3: Note B appeared on my chair, folded once inside a second piece of Form-7F. Tissue analysis later showed both sheets had trace sweat from my hands, consistent with my own personal profile. Note B: They moved the time. They always move the time. You won’t believe this yet. Look at the photograph in your second drawer. Stop thinking you’re alone. If you do nothing else—block the west stairs. Block them and don’t explain. I didn’t have a photograph in my second drawer. When I opened it, there was a photo I had never seen before: me, standing in B-Corridor, bulkhead 3, empty but with foam sealant sprayed around the hatch. My face was obscured by my raised hand as if waving to the camera. Security logs showed no such event. The timestamp on the photo was 09:06 the same day. At 09:06 that day, I was in a team briefing. I submitted to handwriting analysis, requested an amnestic as a precaution, and was denied pending further observation. Day 6: I found Note C wedged in the hinge of my locker, the metal biting its paper. The locker had been sealed with a tamper strip that remained intact. The note had no crease lines consistent with being slid through a gap. Note C: They started small because they needed you to think it was a joke. It’s not. The breach starts with a smell. You’ll think it’s solvent. It’s bone. If you can read this you still have both wrists. Don’t look at your wrists. Don’t shake Kline’s hand. By then, everyone had asked me how I was sleeping. I said fine, then started sleeping in my office chair. I washed with paper towels and antiseptic foam, because if I went to the dorms, I’d start looking for notes under the pillow. We formed an ad hoc task force: me, Kline, Dr. Park from Counter-Temporal, and two security officers. We installed a camera in my office pointed at the desk, the drawers, the cabinet, the underside of the chair. We replaced the memo pads with numbered sheets in tamper-evident sleeves. We switched my pen to a pressure-analyzed stylus that recorded stroke patterns. The task force asked me to pretend to ignore any note that appeared, to see who came to collect. Day 8: There were two notes. Note D1 (under keyboard, again): You waited. You always wait. Stop waiting. The alarms won’t sound. That was a lie I told you to get you moving. This time I’m not lying: don’t let them show you the footage. The footage isn’t yours. It’s older than your eyes. Note D2 (in my coat pocket, dry despite residual wet from a rainstorm I had walked through): They said it’s a memetic hazard. It isn’t. It’s a timing hazard. Don’t trust the blue border. They keep the borders when they swap the center. We examined Form-7F stock from four different storerooms. No anomalies. The blue border dye was consistent across sites. Park proposed a scenario: a contained entity with psychographic mimicry capabilities piggybacked on a common object. Another scenario: an unstable local time loop with self-consistent messaging from an older me. We put me on twice-daily mnestic microdoses to mitigate suggestibility. Day 11: I smelled solvent. The labs always smell like solvent. I told myself this. The smell was sweet, then mineral, then something else. I forgot my coffee on the hot plate and it boiled until the room filled with steam. I started sweating through my shirt. Note E was taped to the inside of my glasses lens. I had been wearing them for three hours. Note E: You’ll keep thinking you can outsmart it. You can’t. Break the fire glass and trigger the foam. It hates foam. Don’t tell Park. She won’t be her by then. It’s not her fault. You will forgive her if you live. The foam station glass was intact. I didn’t break it. If this was manipulation, triggering the foam could have harmed personnel or whatever was contained on the floor below. I put my glasses in an evidence bag and tried to work without them, squinting at fluctuating numbers that wavered and doubled like fish. Day 12: Security played me footage. It showed me, at 09:06 on Day 3, standing in B-Corridor, bulkhead 3, applying foam sealant. Then, as the camera panned, my arm bent in a way that made no anatomical sense, reached around behind my back, and set the frame back on the wall. This contradicted reality as I understand it. Park paused the footage and asked me what I saw. I said a smear of pixels. Kline said “We can doctor video if we want to scare him.” No one laughed. I asked to see the raw timestamps. The metadata was clean. Note F was tucked into the server rack, at the back, on a shelf no one had touched in months. We found it by accident while verifying the feed. Note F: This is the part where you think it’s about you. It isn’t. You are a tool someone else is using to pry open a hinge. Don’t be a hinge. Be a wedge. Wedges don’t swing. Wedges break. Go to bulkhead 3 now. 14:12’s a lie. It’s 13:34. It’s always 13:34 when you’re brave. I went. At 13:34 the corridor was empty. The bulkhead’s seal was normal. I touched the wheel. I smelled the sweet-mineral bone smell. I froze. Security found me there at 14:28 gripping the wheel, knuckles white, not moving. Day 15: I wrote a note to myself as a test. I locked it, with a hair, in a single-use polymer sample tube stamped with my initials, embedded in casting resin we poured on camera. I wrote: “If you read this, call me an idiot and tell me to go home.” At 03:02, the night guard reported finding Note G folded inside my pillowcase in the office. It was my stationery, my handwriting, with a faint imprint where I had scrawled the test note earlier—mirror reversed beneath. The content: Note G: It’s funny you thought that would help. I love you for it. Go home. You can’t, of course. They won’t let you. You’re doing good work. Today it gets loud. Block the west stairs. If I can catch your hand before you reach for the rail, maybe you keep both wrists. Don’t check: you still have both. I checked. I still had both. We tightened procedures. I wasn’t allowed to be alone. I slept under camera. I ate food sealed by someone else’s hands. When I blinked, I saw the blue border of Form-7F. When I dreamt, I saw bulkhead 3 doing something doors don’t do. Day 17: The first contradiction that hurt: Note H said, “Park dies first.” Park was alive. Note H also said, “We cut power to the wing at 12:14.” Power remained. At 12:14, the lights flickered. A UPS relay kicked in. I told myself that’s what UPS relays do. Park put her hand on my shoulder. I flinched like I’d been burned. Note H (continued on the back, cramped, as if written at speed): If you’re reading this, I learned to write with the left. You haven’t yet. This is how we know. The blue border is a lie. Look at the watermark. It’s wrong. It says Sine Timore—no, it says Sin Timor. They’re close. This is how it gets near. I held the memo up to light. The watermark said Sine Timore, correct. I tried another. Sine Timore. A third. Sine Timore. I wanted to find one that said the wrong thing so that I could be right. Day 19: Counter-memetics performed a battery of tests. No cognitohazard signatures beyond normal ranges. They escalated to a running hypothesis: either an undetected temporal leakage affecting local messaging or a high-fidelity psychological manipulation keyed to my motor patterns and personal narrative, maybe seeded via residual contact with SCP-3412’s instrumentation. We reviewed containment logs for entities with known reality-adjacent communication methods. None had access to Stationery. Some had access to me. Note I was inside my left glove between my palm and the fabric. I removed the glove at a sink and the note fell onto the counter like a moth. Note I: When it finally opens, it’s quiet. Don’t trust quiet. Bulwark is a word. Say it. Then say wedge. Then say forgive. If you can say forgive, you can keep going. If you can’t, step away from the wheel and let them empty you out. It’s better than the other thing. I said bulwark. I said wedge. I couldn’t say forgive out loud. I whispered it and it sounded like a lie. Day 21: They showed me the footage again. This time, the camera saw me at 03:02 walking to the office, entering, shutting the door, then flattening myself against the wall. The door opened without anyone pulling it. The lights flickered. A stack of Form-7F slid across the desk by itself. I stepped forward, picked one up, wrote furiously, folded it, tucked it into my pillowcase. Then I stood in the dark for eight minutes and didn’t move. I watched myself do it and I remembered sleeping dreamless from 01:00 to 06:00. I asked for a different angle. The other angle didn’t exist. The camera was “under maintenance.” I asked Park to watch with me. She watched me write and didn’t say anything. Kline said, “That’s not his writing posture.” I signed a consent for increased surveillance and for the possibility that my notes represented a memetic infection vector requiring isolation. They moved me to a smaller room with padded edges and no drawers. They took my belt and my pen and my glasses. The notes stopped for two days. I felt skin grow over the idea. Day 24: Note J was under my tongue when I woke up. I coughed paper and blood into my palm. Note J: We are not sick. We are not possessed. We are not a containment risk. We are a warning. If you don’t move now, you will write this from a chair with straps. You will learn to write with your left. The bones in the right don’t fit anymore. I still have both wrists. You still do. If you act, you’ll keep them. Security found no lacerations in my mouth. Counter-memetics found skin cells on the paper that matched mine and epithelial cells that did not match anyone on staff. Park closed her eyes. Kline left the room. Day 25: The alarms sounded for 22 seconds before cutting out. Everyone looked at me. I looked at the west staircase and saw nothing. I smelled bone. I grabbed the pallet jack parked nearby and rammed it into the staircase gate until the wheels bent and the metal sang. Security shouted. I shouted back that the notes had said to block the stairs. The breach did not happen. The daily incident log recorded “False alarm due to sensor spike in B-Corridor; no breach; minor property damage; reprimand issued.” That night, I took my left hand and wrote on my palm with a marker I had borrowed from Kline when he wasn’t looking: don’t be a hinge. It washed off in the morning. Day 27: I asked Park if she believed me. She said belief wasn’t operational. I asked Kline to shake my hand. He hesitated. I grabbed his anyway. Nothing happened. I felt the bones of his fingers. They fit where bones go. Note K appeared inside a sealed evidence bag we had left on the table as a control. It fogged the plastic as if it were warm.
