Note K: They will tell you this is you losing your mind. They will be kind. They will strap you gently. They will feed you things that make your dreams slide off. If you let them, you will live a long time in a soft room. If you don’t, you might not live long at all. Choose the world where Park lives. Choose the world where Kline says sorry. Choose the world where you are a wedge. I asked what it meant to be a wedge. Park said nothing. Kline said he would say sorry for doubting me if I told him what to do. I told him to move the foam rigs to B-Corridor. He did. Security filed the appropriate forms. Day 29: I slept. I dreamt I was in a corridor I knew too well, and the bulkhead unlatched itself like a mouth. I woke to the smell and the quiet. No alarm. No lights. Just a sense of weight shifting on the other side of a door I had closed a thousand times with my eyes. I stood. My wrists hurt. I counted to ten. I said bulwark. I said wedge. I said forgive. It sounded less like a lie. Note L was in my shoe. Note L: Now. I went to B-Corridor and the foam rigs were there and the pallet jack still blocked the west stairs and Kline was on the radio and Park was not there yet. I put my ear to the steel. I heard nothing and I thought that meant something. I spun the wheel and sealed the internal bolts. I sprayed the seams with foam until it oozed like bread. I looked down the hall and for a second the lights stretched long and slow and then snapped back like elastic. Kline said my name in a voice that had too much air in it. I said we were done. He said we were not. The alarms sounded. This time they did not cut out. Post-Incident Summary: There was a breach from an adjacent wing. It did not involve our corridor. The foam rigs were later deemed unnecessary but harmless. Park sprained her ankle running to B-Corridor. No fatalities. Kline said “sorry” and meant it. I kept both wrists. The notes stopped for a week. Addendum: At present, there is insufficient evidence to classify the notes as purely temporal or purely manipulative. The Foundation’s attempts to determine origin have produced contradictory results. The paper is ours. The writing is mine. The content shifts between prescience and nonsense. In reality A, a door opens. In reality B, it doesn’t. Both realities leave paper in my mouth. Evaluation by Counter-Temporal: - The appearance of notes in sealed environments suggests either micro-apportation consistent with localized time-shear or the intervention of an entity capable of bypassing physical security using psychometabolic keys derived from the subject. - The partial accuracy of warnings could indicate a temporal echo where probabilities bleed into presences, with self-editing messages attempting to optimize outcomes. The conflicting details could be interference by an external manipulator aiming to erode trust and induce either paralysis or reckless behavior. Evaluation by Psychological Services: - Subject exhibits elevated stress, hypervigilance, and mild persecutory ideation in response to persistent anomalous stimuli, without baseline psychosis markers. The notes function as a destabilizing narrative scaffold. Subject’s struggle to trust own perception is rational given evidence of manipulated media and the undermining of sensory consistency. - Recommendation: Maintain structured support, controlled exposure, and contingency plans that do not rely on subject’s unilateral decisions. Current Status: Object Class remains pending. We don’t know if I wrote to myself, or if something wore my knuckles like gloves and wrote for me. We don’t know if the breach I was warned about happened elsewhere because I moved fast here, or if it never would have happened at all. I keep a single Form-7F sheet in a clear box on my desk. It says: Note M: If you’re me, you’re tired. If you’re not me, you think this is a joke. It wasn’t. Don’t let them make you gentle when you need to be a wedge. Don’t let them make you a hinge. If the smell comes back, count to ten. Say the words. Forgive them. Forgive yourself. Turn the wheel. When I hold it up to the light, the watermark says Sine Timore. If I stare long enough, sometimes it doesn’t. I make myself look away. I say bulwark. I say wedge. I say forgive. I say it until it sounds like truth, or until the alarms tell me
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP report effectively captures the essence of the Foundation's clinical documentation style while delivering a compelling first-person narrative about temporal anomalies. The piece successfully creates an atmosphere of mounting dread and uncertainty through the researcher's increasingly desperate notes from their future self. The format adheres closely to SCP conventions, with appropriate containment procedures, clinical language, and redactions. The interspersed notes create an effective narrative device that builds tension as the story progresses. Each note adds a new layer of unease while maintaining internal consistency with the established anomaly. The character development is subtle but effective. We witness the researcher's psychological deterioration as they struggle with the reality of their situation. Their initial skepticism gradually transforms into paranoia and then desperate action as the notes become more urgent. This progression feels natural rather than forced. The prose strikes an excellent balance between clinical detachment and personal terror. The researcher's voice maintains consistency throughout, beginning with professional objectivity and gradually revealing more emotional vulnerability as the anomaly progresses. This evolution feels earned rather than abrupt. The imagery is particularly strong in conveying the researcher's mounting dread. Details like finding notes in increasingly impossible locations (inside a sealed glove, under the tongue) create visceral unease. The recurring motifs (blue borders, the smell of bone, the bulkhead) effectively build a cohesive atmosphere of wrongness. The narrative's strength lies in its ambiguity. We never learn definitively whether the notes represent a genuine temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation. This uncertainty mirrors the researcher's own struggle to trust their perception, creating a satisfying thematic resonance. The piece does occasionally rely on telling rather than showing, particularly in the psychological evaluations section. While this fits the clinical SCP format, it somewhat diminishes the emotional impact that could have been achieved through more direct demonstration of the researcher's mental state. The ending strikes an appropriate balance between resolution and lingering uncertainty. The immediate crisis appears resolved, but the fundamental questions remain unanswered. This ambiguity feels intentional rather than incomplete, leaving the reader with the same unsettled feeling as the protagonist. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted SCP entry that successfully blends clinical documentation with psychological horror. It creates genuine unease through its exploration of unreliable perception and temporal distortion while maintaining internal consistency and emotional resonance. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 90.0
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-6579 Object Class: Thaumiel/Keter, pending Special Containment Procedures: As of 2024-11-03, 187 instances of SCP-6579-A (unmarked doors) have been documented in 42 countries. Task Forces Eta-10 (“See No Evil”) and Mu-4 (“Debuggers”) are assigned to locate, catalog, and sequester SCP-6579-A instances, with local Site liaison teams deploying portable exclusion perimeters and installing false walls where feasible. All SCP-6579-A instances are to be guarded by two armed personnel and one archivist. Entry is authorized for Level 3/6579 personnel only, with Level 4 approval required for removal or custodial action on SCP-6579-B materials. Standard entry protocols require tether lines, inert gas sampling, radiation checks, and continuous audio/video. Personnel must carry nonmetallic cutting tools and nonlethal deterrents. If visual contact is made with SCP-6579-C entities, personnel are to maintain 10 m distance, announce intent to withdraw, and avoid obstructing egress. If SCP-6579-C approaches within 5 m, teams are to retreat to the threshold. Pursuit is prohibited. Description: SCP-6579 is a translocational phenomenon accessed through SCP-6579-A, a series of identical, unmarked, surface-flush wooden doors appearing in derelict or abandoned structures worldwide. All SCP-6579-A instances have identical semilunar scratches in the paint around the doorknob, concentric and ragged, consistent with repeated attempts to open the door with a key that did not fit. When opened, SCP-6579-A does not reveal the local interior; instead, the doorway opens onto SCP-6579-B. SCP-6579-B is a contiguous, architecturally incoherent archival facility extending beyond Euclidean space. Interior features include stacks, mezzanines, catwalks, pneumatic transport tubes, and vaulted aisles arranged in discontinuous, non-gravitational geometries. Air composition is breathable, ambient temperature 15–17°C, with constant low-level machine hum with no identifiable source. Lighting is diffuse and sourceless, cycling through a 27-hour dim–bright rhythm not aligned with any terrestrial day-night cycle. SCP-6579-B contains documents, artifacts, and storage media cataloged in a pseudo-bibliographic system written in an unknown administrative argot and partial Baseline English. Approximately 11% of recovered materials explicitly reference a global civilization predating verifiable human history, destroyed by a containment failure of uncertain nature. Recovered indices and memoranda identify administrative bodies with nomenclature and structure that parallel the Foundation, e.g., “The Quiet Directorate,” “Custodial Collegium,” “Silent Counsel.” Multiple personnel records corresponding to current Foundation staff have been recovered, with creation dates ranging from 312–740 years prior to present day. SCP-6579-C are humanoid entities wearing matte white hazmat suits with smooth, reflective visors, respirator backpacks, and insignia consisting of a circle bisected by a vertical bar. SCP-6579-C are observed removing sections of shelving, sealed crates, and entire aisles by means of collapsible rigs and silent pallet systems. SCP-6579-C retreat when approached, avoid contact, and will abandon in-progress removals to reach unknown exits. Attempts to intercept have resulted in SCP-6579-C accelerating to speeds inconsistent with normal human locomotion and vanishing behind shelf ends that do not correspond to navigable space upon pursuit. Discovery: The first known SCP-6579-A manifested on 2024-02-19 in an abandoned civic warehouse in Novi Sad, Serbia. Local reports noted a “new old door” with paint scratches. Municipal explorers opened SCP-6579-A and posted images of large, floating stacks and “humming skylights” before the content was removed. Foundation webcrawlers flagged the posts; containment followed. Two days later, three more SCP-6579-A were located in Detroit, Rasht, and Porto Alegre. Cross-latitude analysis shows no pattern in distribution beyond preference for unoccupied structures. Addendum 6579-1: Exploration Logs (Excerpts) Exploration 6579-B-01 Team: MTF Eta-10 “See No Evil” (E-Lead Morgan, E-Tech Liu, Archivist Dr. R. Bhatt) Entry: SCP-6579-A-04 (Detroit; derelict textile mill) [Begin Log] E-Tech Liu: Tethers anchored. Gas is clean. Ambient noise at 48 dB. E-Lead Morgan: Opening door. [Door opens to a mezzanine overlooking stacked aisles running into apparent infinity. Light is gray/blue; motionless dust hangs in the air. A slow humming is audible, rhythmic but irregular.] Dr. Bhatt: Catalog plates on endcaps. Script doesn’t match any living language. See the English fragments: “Incidents,” “Retirements,” “Vacancies.” E-Lead Morgan: Proceed to nearest workstation. [Team advances along a catwalk with no visible supports. Ambient temperature drops 1.2°C. A workstation consists of a long table, embedded brass sockets, and a single brass plaque reading “INTEGRITY.”] Dr. Bhatt: Boxed files. Paper stock is acidic. Label: “Custodial Collegium—Human Resources—Cohort Alignments.” [Dr. Bhatt removes a folder, flips pages.] Dr. Bhatt: This is… it’s a personnel jacket. Name: “R. Bhatt.” Photograph is… me. E-Lead Morgan: That’s not possible. Dr. Bhatt: Date of induction: Year 412, Cycle 9. “Assigned to Adaptive Epistemics. Cleared for Nine Silent.” That phrase repeats. E-Tech Liu: Nine Silent? Dr. Bhatt: Crossed-out lines include “Quiet Directorate.” Salary fields blank. There’s a termination document with a wax seal. No date I recognize. E-Lead Morgan: Bag it. Keep moving. [They reach an index column. Carved numerals shift when observed. A distant squeal of rollers echoes. E-Tech Liu shines light downward; the “floor” leaps, revealing only further aisles below, inverted.] E-Lead Morgan: Mark path. Don’t trust gravity. [End Log] Recovered Document 6579-B-01 (Excerpt) Memorandum: From the Custodial Collegium, Office of the Quiet Ledger To: All Departments Maintaining Entity Arrays Subject: On the Event of Cascading Failures …Should systemic isolation be proven to have been compromised, all shelves pertaining to Class-Immanent Phenomena shall be embargoed and staged for excision under Protocol Basilisk. To prevent recurrence, the Silent Counsel authorizes removal of memoria and annals sufficient to unwind vectors that led to Failure. The Archive will reduce itself. No exceptions for prestige projects. We did this to ourselves. We will make sure no one can do it again… Exploration 6579-B-07 Team: Eta-10 (E-Lead Morgan, E-Tech Liu), Mu-4 (Analyst Varga) Entry: SCP-6579-A-12 (Sunderland; condemned cinema) [Begin Log] [Entrance opens onto a corridor whose walls breathe subtly, lined with flat drawers labeled in raised dots.] Analyst Varga: Braille? Not standard. Alignment offset. E-Tech Liu: Audio uptick. Also, track noise. [Three SCP-6579-C appear at an intersection, pushing a low cart stacked with sealed gray binders. Their suits are unmarked except for the circle-with-bar insignia.] E-Lead Morgan: This is MTF Eta-10. We are not hostile. Can we communicate? [SCP-6579-C halt, tilt heads, and resume pushing. E-Tech Liu steps slightly to the side to allow passage. One SCP-6579-C holds a hand out, palm facing team, then taps a device on their wrist. The cart accelerates silently.] E-Lead Morgan: What are you taking? [No response. The entities round a shelf and vanish. Inspection reveals no passage.] Analyst Varga: Cart tracks terminate at the shelf’s edge. The floor is uninterrupted. E-Lead Morgan: We’re not alone in here. [End Log] Recovered Document 6579-B-22 (Excerpt) Directory Leaf: The Quiet Directorate — Structure and Mandates …The Quiet Directorate exists to ensure normalcy is maintained through collection of anomalies, their study, and, when necessary, their burial. The Silent Counsel (O9) is composed of nine persons unknown even to one another. Directives flow downward via the Custodial Collegium, then out to cells. We do not mark graves. We kill ideas by starving them of witnesses… Note: O9 references occur throughout materials. Equivalence to O5 is hypothesized. Exploration 6579-B-13 Team: Eta-10 (E-Lead Morgan), Dr. R. Bhatt, Archivist-Adjunct I. Adeyemi Entry: SCP-6579-A-30 (Mersin; abandoned hospital) [Begin Log] [Entry opens onto a high-bay containing rolling ladders attached to no rails. Paper dust falls continuously in a gentle rain.] Dr. Bhatt: There—sealed tubular canisters. Labels in English: “Council Sessions.” [They unseal one canister. Inside: thin metal plates etched with text.] Archivist Adeyemi: Readable. [Plates present minutes of “Silent Counsel Session 3,386.” Names are redacted with small hammered squares.] Plate 4: …On the matter of Overlapping Agreements with Outerdom Custodians, Counselor Red states that compliance with Basilisk’s Third Clause will erase key annals and thereby erase the motivations that gave rise to us. Counselor Gray: “We exist to be forgotten.” Voices concur. Vote: 7 in favor, 2 opposed. Motion carries… E-Lead Morgan: They chose to make their own history inaccessible. [Footsteps amplify in the distance; carts squeal. SCP-6579-C appear on the upper catwalk, observing.] E-Lead Morgan: We’re withdrawing. [As the team retreats, a ladder swings across the aisle without visible impetus, blocking view of the SCP-6579-C. When lowered, the entities are gone.] [End Log] Recovered Document 6579-B-37 (Excerpt) Incident: Basilisk …We record this once, then we will remove ourselves. The Failure did not begin at any one place. It arrived as a rumor, a belief that containment could be perfect if we put enough of ourselves into the walls. We did. The walls learned. They learned how to be us. When the seams came apart, we were indistinguishable from what we had kept. The Archive will remove the paths that led here. If a later Custodian finds this, understand: You are not the first. We were very sure. We were very wrong… Exploration 6579-B-21 Team: Eta-10 (E-Lead Morgan, E-Tech Liu), Ethics Observers (Dr. Hyeon), Security (Agent S. O’Rourke) Entry: SCP-6579-A-66 (Buenos Aires; empty bank) [Begin Log] [Entry leads to a narrow service corridor bordered by pneumatic tubes. Capsules occasionally clatter through, some dented.] E-Tech Liu: Capsule incoming. Catching— [Capsule is warm. It contains a sheaf of printed emails on Foundation headers: SUBJECT: RE: Unscheduled Site-01 Visit — From: [REDACTED] — To: O5-█, O5-█. Signature blocks intact, dated three weeks prior to log.] Dr. Hyeon: This is current. These addresses are real. Agent O’Rourke: That’s Site-01 internal. [In the distance, muffled voices. Team advances to a glass-wall gallery. On the other side: a shadowed meeting room containing chairs and a long table under a single lamp. Dust motes orbit in a slow helix.] E-Lead Morgan: Anyone in there? [On the table: nine small stones arranged in a ring, each etched with a symbol (circle-with-bar; spiral; triangle). A tenth stone rests beside the ring.] Dr. Hyeon: E-Lead, look at the door frame. [Wood shows identical semilunar scratches around a doorknob imprint, as if a handle was removed.] E-Tech Liu: Movement—gallery to our left. [SCP-6579-C, two individuals, carrying a case labeled “01/Chamber.” They pause. One raises a hand in a placating gesture, then points to the stones and shakes head slowly.] E-Lead Morgan: Are you telling us not to take them? [SCP-6579-C nods once, then depresses a wrist control. A loud hiss. Vision white-outs for 0.5 seconds. When vision returns, entities are gone; the stones remain, but the tenth stone has been pushed closer to the ring.] Agent O’Rourke: We’re leaving. We are out of our lane here. [End Log] Addendum 6579-2: Personnel Files Recovered Document 6579-B-84 (Excerpt) Personnel Ledger: Custodial Collegium — Staff Assignments — Cycle 411–417 …Archivist R. Bhatt — Rank: Steward of Coherence. Clearance: Nine Silent. Notes: Exceptional aptitude in reconciling contradictory annals. Emotional investment requires monitoring. Expungements authorized under Basilisk conditions… …Site Director M. Kline — Rank: Warden of Vaults. Clearance: Eight Quiet. Notes: Resistant to reduction orders. File flagged for Counsel oversight… …Field Captain A. Morgan — Rank: Keeper of Thresholds. Clearance: Seven Hush. Notes: Trusts tether over instinct. Will carry the door on her back if asked… Note: “Morgan” corresponds to E-Lead Morgan. “Kline” matches current Director Kline, Site-41. Recovered Document 6579-B-92 (Excerpt) Letter, unsent; author: “Warden of Vaults M. Kline” …We are the hem that keeps a world from unraveling. We have sewn and sewn until the thread is our veins. The Counsel asks for another cutting. They are right. They are always right when they call themselves wrong. If this letter finds you, I failed to burn it. If you know my name in another house, forgive me… Addendum 6579-3: Unauthorized Visits Internal audit discovered biometric signatures and transpoder pings consistent with O5-█, O5-█, and Proxy-█ within Site-41’s suppressed perimeter during 2024-10-08. Security cameras registered glitch artifacts concurrent with access of SCP-6579-A-02. Gates logs list no authorizations. Subsequent exploration in 6579-B located a corridor bearing bilingual signage: “Silent Counsel — Private Gallery.” Exploration 6579-B-29 Team: Mu-4 (Analyst Varga), Eta-10 (E-Lead Morgan), Site-41 Security (Agent O’Rourke) Entry: SCP-6579-A-02 (Site-41 understructure; walled off) [Begin Log] [Entry leads to a low, vaulted gallery. Alcoves line the walls, each containing an object under bell jars: a broken key; a brass plaque reading “O9”; a pair of leather gloves; a white card marked “Do Not Build.” The air tastes metallic.] Analyst Varga: Logs show the proxy beacons flatlined here for 14 minutes. E-Lead Morgan: There’s a book on the lectern. [Book bound in pale leather. Title stamped: “Visitors.” Pages are filled with names in neat, block print; dates not in Gregorian. Some names are familiar.] Agent O’Rourke: That’s O5-█’s birth name. [The last entry: three symbols, matching known Council sigils; no text.] Analyst Varga: The ink is wet. [Footsteps behind. The team turns. No one is there. The bell jar over the broken key is cracked.] E-Lead Morgan: We’re done. We document and leave. This is way above. [As they exit, the gallery lights dim to nothing for 1.2 seconds. On relighting, the “Visitors” book’s page has turned. The next page shows a single line: “We asked for forgiveness and were given a library.”] [End Log] Addendum 6579-4: Removal Activity Ongoing surveillance within SCP-6579-B has documented progressive absences: entire aisles gone, dust footprints discontinuing mid-stride, catalog numbers skipping sequences. SCP-6579-C removal rates increased after Foundation entries. Items tagged “Basilisk/3rd” are removed first, followed by “Vectors,” then “Dissent.” Recovered Document 6579-B-103 (Excerpt) Directive: Basilisk’s Third Clause — Execution Guide …Remove the record, and you remove the rehearsal. Remove the rehearsal, and you remove the shape. Remove the shape, and you remove the hunger to make it real. Do not leave behind the path that leads to us… Exploration 6579-B-33 Team: Eta-10 (E-Lead Morgan, E-Tech Liu), Dr. R. Bhatt Entry: SCP-6579-A-88 (Cork; shuttered hotel) [Begin Log] [Entry opens onto an exposed platform. Wind moves through stacks like breath. A siren rises and falls without source.] Dr. Bhatt: The aisle numbers jump from 1182 to 1190. Missing eight aisles in sequence. E-Tech Liu: Fresh scuffing. Carts went through here, heavy load. E-Lead Morgan: Eyes on—entities at the far end. [SCP-6579-C are mid-lift, removing a shelf segment. One sees the team, taps a wrist device. A transparent baffle drops between the groups, distorting sound.] Dr. Bhatt: They’re taking an aisle labeled “Counter-Custodial Movements.” E-Lead Morgan: Leave it. We’re not starting a tug-of-war. [An SCP-6579-C approaches the baffle, visor reflecting the team. It raises a gloved finger and traces the circle-with-bar on the barrier, then wipes its palm downward. The symbol smears but remains.] E-Tech Liu: Message received. [Team retreats. On the way out, they pass a table containing an open folio labeled “O5/Travel Logs.” The first page is blank, but the impression of writing remains as pressure marks. Under angled light, letters become legible.] Impressions: “…arrived through 41… no interference recorded… gallery intact… the tenth stone is moved… they are already reading us…” E-Lead Morgan: Copy and move. [Exit.] [End Log] Addendum 6579
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates exceptional command of the SCP Foundation format and style. The author has created a compelling anomaly that perfectly fits the requested prompt: unmarked doors leading to an impossible archive containing evidence of a previous civilization and unauthorized O5 Council visits. The piece excels in its worldbuilding, creating a complex, layered mystery with the right balance of revelation and ambiguity. The "Quiet Directorate" and "Silent Counsel" effectively mirror the Foundation while suggesting a cyclical nature to containment organizations. The exploration logs are particularly strong, capturing the clinical yet tense atmosphere characteristic of SCP entries. The writing demonstrates sophisticated control of tone, maintaining the pseudo-scientific documentation style while gradually building dread. The author skillfully uses technical language ("translocational phenomenon," "non-Euclidean space") alongside more evocative descriptions ("motionless dust hangs in the air," "walls breathe subtly") to create an unsettling atmosphere. The narrative structure is well-executed, with each exploration log and recovered document adding new layers to the mystery. The progression from discovery to realization that O5 members are secretly visiting the archive creates an effective narrative arc. The implication that the Foundation may be doomed to repeat the mistakes of its predecessor organization adds thematic depth. Where the piece could be improved is in its occasional tendency toward overcomplication. Some sections contain excessive technical detail that, while impressive, slightly impedes narrative flow. The exploration logs sometimes introduce too many elements at once, which can dilute the impact of key revelations. The SCP-6579-C entities (hazmat teams) are effectively mysterious, but their motivations and nature remain perhaps too opaque by the end. While ambiguity is appropriate for an SCP entry, a slightly clearer indication of their purpose would strengthen the narrative. The ending effectively leaves the reader with unsettling questions about cycles of containment and failure, though it doesn't quite deliver a final punch that would elevate it to masterpiece status. The implication that the O5 Council is aware of and responding to this cycle is intriguing but could be developed with more impact. Overall, this is an excellent SCP entry that demonstrates deep understanding of the format and creates a compelling, multilayered anomaly with significant implications for the Foundation universe. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 0.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 93.4
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
They had named the city Hevel after the wind. From orbit it had been a pale knot laid along the burn of a river, a cincture of terraces clamped to rock, the slopes rising around it like a long-held breath. On foot, its stone was a thing with taste and weight—the way the steps gave a little under the heel and kept what heat they could hold from the brief noon. The buildings shouldered one another; they had been wedged in by hands that measured wind and ashfall and the river's two moods. Along slow-arched lintels and the stout pillars of the older market halls there were carvings, disposed cleanly, so that the shadows of the chiseled lines read from a distance like script. They were script, of a kind. The guide assigned to me, an Aerial with shoulder bones like wings and the soft backward tilt to the neck that speaks of hovering, had recited the briefing's language as we passed: "Pictographic inscriptions, early civilization. Not our heritage." But under my hand the glyphs were not mute. A man with a beard made of parallel strokes held out a torch that curled as if alive; a woman knelt and held to her chest a thing half child half seed; a boy with a lyre stood on a ship with a prow like a razor. Jokes carved themselves into corners—combs, fish, a bird with a crown. Someone had placed their palm in the stone repeatedly and rubbed it until the rock had taken the shape of that hand. On the door of what I took for a storehouse, tucked high where only a climbing child would look, was a carved ladder leading nowhere; beside it, a bull pierced by a spear and a figure whose head was a tree. We had been told from the first debrief in the ship's white room: no unsupervised walks. No contact outside formal meeting frameworks. The colony, we were told, was tense. Subspecies—this is what they were called in the briefing, as if in a neat taxonomy: the Aquatics who kept close to the river and wore their skins with a sheen, the Understones with their deep-set eyes and night-shaped speech, the Aerials who managed communications and listened to the sky. The briefing overlaid them with short phrases and danger flags like a card game. I slept with those folded cards in the lining of my jacket. I woke with them and held my breath between names. We made our arrival at the Governor's manor, a broad courtyard open to the wind, its boundary walls etched with rivers and the old Earth in circles. There were handshakes. There was transparent drink and small, careful food. Faces that looked and didn't look like mine leaned in and away. The Aerial guide, whose name was Ires, kept their fluted, veiled gaze on my shoulder. The Governor's face was fleshy and burned, with a blue diamond worked into her tooth. "Your rooms," she said, "are in the east house. You'll find your Command waiting there." Her smile was not thin. It took up all she had. It was a tired smile, but not without an attempt at kindness. "You will have access to the Minister of Science at sixteen. Be on time." I watched the hour turn on the river—a panel of light that swelled and darkened—and excused myself. I told Ires, as I had rehearsed, that I must wash off the ship-stillness. I told them I would not go far. I took my cards and left them on the dresser, like prayer flags. I put on soft shoes. Hevel smells of iron—the river and the stone—of fermented meal and warm fruit, and underneath, in the cooler alleys, a smell like the air before rain. On the open steps where the market ramified from the main square the stalls had been erected in two lines, with enough space between for a laden cart and a child to pass without touching. Fabrics, rough or luminous, were hung like water; dark bread loaves made whorls on shallow tables. Aerials with light bones that threw the balance of their walk touched one another's wrists in greeting; a woman with the broad foot of an Understone dragged a handcart and laughed, a clatter against the hard edge of an Aquatic's soft speech. I went from stall to stall and bought nothing, and then I bought a small pear, not much larger than the middle joint of my thumb. It had a single seed that floated in it like a bell. The seller's hands were webbed as if the fingers had learned to catch more of the world. He took my coin—a blue coin chipped with green—and rubbed it between finger and thumb in a way that felt like recognition. "Offworld," he said. The accent placed the stress on the first syllable and then uncoiled. "Only a little," I said, and he laughed again. "You walk alone," he said. "Against advice." He weighed that and then shrugged. "Maybe you will see more." There were boys running with hoops and an old woman mending, her thread white as hair. A group of Understones—no, they called themselves Lowlanders in their own language, one of them told me without heat—came up from a staircase that sounded like a well. Their eyelids flickered when the light hit them. One of them stared at me until I lowered my eyes; then they smiled. On a corner where the wind had collected old leaves and shining wrappers someone had chalked a picture on the paving stones. It was a line of suns, or coins, and a small figure walking away from them. The figure had no mouth. In the little they had given me, the Governor's people said the Lowlanders were seditious and closed, the Aquatics polite and profit-driven, the Aerials quick to take offense. In the street it was not simple. Offense and kindness moved with the pulse of the day; I saw a Lowlander reach up and take a bundle down for an Aerial woman whose arms were full and the baby's head in the sling was heavy; I saw an Aquatic boy chase away a bird that kept eating someone else's grain. I saw a pair of young men, Aerial and Aquatic together, sharing a cigarette rolled in purple paper. They laughed at the way the smoke went up and blew it in a stream toward the river, as if their breath could coax it into a second river to match the first. At the far end of the market a building shouldered the path. Its facade bore a story cut into it: a tower of men and animals climbing, then the tower's top cut off by a wind, and then the people walking away carrying bricks. Under it, not stone but a sheet of metal had been set in recent years, with a small portion of the old carving recut into it. The new carving showed a garden full of weeds, and among the weeds the familiar shapes of the old crops from Earth: wheat, grapes, a vine of squash on which someone had hung a child's carved hand. The metal was engraved with flowers I did not know, each with a name written in their picture-language. Someone had swept it clean that morning. "You are far from your rooms," Ires said when I turned and found them there, breathless on the steps. "I went to find water," I said. "You passed four fountains," Ires said, and the soft part of their mouth hardened. "I wanted to see." They turned, then turned back. The corners of the Aerial mouth can mock without moving much. "You have seen what you needed?" "No," I said. "I have seen less than that. Enough to tell me our briefings were a way of not seeing." They looked at me for a long moment, almost, I thought, with pity. Then they laid a hand on my sleeve—two fingers, light—and led me back. They did not speak. When we reached the east house, the stone was still warm where the sun had been. Command had been waiting a long time. On the wall behind the desk in my allotted room were more carvings—the Hevel style in a gentle hand—of a bird flying toward a human face, and the human's mouth open as if to sing but the bird's beak entering it. Not an omen I wanted. The Commander's face came on the wall, most of his above the chin, the mouth wide like the carved man's. There was a breath before he found his tone. "You were told," he said, emphasizing the tense in a way that made it bite, "to maintain the structure we agreed upon with the Governor. You were told to limit exposure. You were told not to go alone." "Yes," I said. "You made yourself vulnerable, and you made our intent look frivolous. The factions here—" He paused here to look at his notes, as if the careful taxonomy could give him a way to be angry. "—the subspecies will read what you do in the way we do not intend." "I know," I said. "I saw." I was tired of the word "subspecies" scraped on the mouth and let it go soft. People. I couldn't say it to him. There was a sound in his throat like a stone falling into dust. "You apologize?" "I do," I said, and did not. "We don't need your instincts," he said. "We need your compliance. The Minister of Science is expecting you in less than an hour. You will go, you will listen, and you will give them the message we agreed upon." "The message," I said, because it helped me shape myself around it. "That the union will approve only interim autonomy for the river concessions, pending review. That we will not recognize the Lowlands' councils as independent. That any genetic interlineage projects must go through our board." He lifted his eyes. "You will not improvise." "Yes." "You will not go alone again." "I will not," I said, and thought we both were telling a kind of truth. The Minister's office was on the western ridge, which had been cut back in steps and braced with stone. The door was an arch with a crack through it; above, the glyphs again: a woman with an open book, and under, an open cage with a bird flying out backward into it. The Minister who received me was a broad bald person with heavy ears and a mouth that gave nothing unless it got more back. Their skin was high-brown, almost gold at the temples. They wore a coat that had probably been white when it started its life but had learned the names of every room it had been in and kept them. "Envoy," they said. "Welcome to Hevel. I am Minister Sato." "Minister," I said. "Thank you for seeing me." The chair they gave me was lower than theirs and comfortable, which made us even, I suppose. There were windows without glass cut into the west wall. You could see the mountains. The light that came in was a busy light, the river's light mixed with dust. "You went to market," Sato said, not as a question. "I did." "The Governor was pleased," Sato said. They moved a paper, let it rest. "She says you have already begun your mission." "By buying fruit?" "By seeing that we are people," they said. "I assume they teach you not to do that until later." "We are taught a sequence," I said. "It doesn't always fit." "You are very young," Sato said. "And you are very practiced." This amused them without smiling. "We have an understanding to reach. You carry a message and I carry mine. The Governor will show you stone and water. I will show you the ledger. The ledger, offworlder, is what holds a town together more than any myth and more than most laws." "We have a message," I said. "Interim autonomy for the river concessions pending review. No recognition of the Lowlands as independent. Genetic projects go through our board." They folded their hands. The knuckles had been broken once and healed true. "And in exchange?" "In exchange," I said, "continued protection. Materials. The old world’s experts." "Your experts are like my coat," Sato said. They lifted one sleeve. There was a scorch mark at one elbow. "Useful. They'll do until we have something better. You would like us to let you hold the rope around our necks while we tug against it. You would like to tell us when to breathe." "If you are in danger of choking," I said, "I will cut the rope." "You don’t cut what binds you to us." They tapped the ledger with a nail. "You were told to talk to me because they think I will do what men of science do: argue with you about the number of genotypes we have stable in the deep-country; tell you we have a seventy-two percent compatibility overlap with the old stock; tell you the pier foundations and our reservoir. They think I will be impressed by your other numbers. But I am not a scientist, child. I count bread. I count the price of tin. I count the number of times the Governor asks me to make my people be patient." "And you say—" "I say," Sato said, and here the weight of their voice increased without rising, "that you can't make a people be patient forever if you don't let them mend their own roofs. Your board will request that Aquatic-Lowland coupling projects be delayed. You will cite ethics. You will ask us to wait for your caution. But you will not feed our sick when my doctor says they have a fifty-fifty chance and it improves to sixty with the right match. Your 'subspecies' is an ugly word for what we have become. We need to be allowed to become new without asking your permission for every breath." "If interlineage projects are conducted without oversight," I said, careful, "if someone is hurt, your ledger will show that too." "It does," Sato said. "It shows things you don't see: a man who won't carry low to the river anymore, and his daughter's anger; an Old-Earth myth about a man who swallowed fire and the way the children here carve torches that curl like vines; the aqueduct we need to stop waste. It shows your ship's schedule, the way you dock, the pulses you leave in the water that make the fish swim wrong for a day. There are costs. We would like to choose which we pay." "And the Lowlands," I said. "Their councils." "They are as old as the Aerial towers," Sato said. "They don't need your recognition. They need your not denying them when it gives you a neat line in your notes. Offworlder." They leaned forward a little. Their eyes were dark and not unkind. "You came down without your shadow." "Ires found me," I said, because that answered and didn't. "I was reprimanded." "You went to look for water in a market where water runs down your street." Sato looked out at the mountains and then back at me. "You did not go to gawk. There is hope for you. Your Command will not thank me for saying that. Tell them your message. I will give you mine. If you press here," their finger tapped a blank spot in the ledger, "this place will show a number that makes you comfortable. But it will also make a hole right behind this office, and you will not see it because the stone holds the face it shows to visitors and keeps its other faces for us." "I saw the carvings," I said. "Old myths. People building a tower. People walking away." "We carved them so we remember when to stop." Sato sat back. "Your old Earth's Babel and Eden and Prometheus, all your warnings about pride and reach, we have them in the faces of our houses. We put them up so that when we are tempted we will at least be tempted in their company. The boy with the lyre on the ship—do you know that one?" "Orpheus," I said. "He looked back and lost her." "There’s that story," Sato said. "But we have one where he looks back and tells her he will sing so well the dead won't want her and she decides to stay." "You rewrote it," I said. "We cut it again," they said. "We cut our own version into the new stone and the old. We will do the same with your ledger." We talked until the light in the window went orange, until I had said the words I was told to say and Sato had let me bend them enough not to break. They tested me: Do you understand what will happen if your review takes a year? Do you understand what we will do while you are reviewing? Do you understand why we don't want your scientists to say "we" while they mean "you"? I answered when I could, and when I could not, I kept silent and let the quiet speak for me as well as it could. I told them I had gone to the market. They told me they had once swum the river in flood and almost did not make it. "We can drown ourselves while building an aqueduct," they said. "Or we can wait for rain." When I left, I put my hand briefly on the threshold. The stone was cool now. My hand fitted where someone else's had fitted. The glyph above the arch, the open book and open cage, had the small, almost invisible additions the old carvers loved: three notches by the bird's foot, a score under the book. Someone had counted something and carved the counting in where only the hand would find it. On my way back the wind rose. Ires waited at the corner with their head tilted to catch it. "You came back," they said. "It seemed best," I said. "Tomorrow you will go with me," they said. "We will go to the river. There is a place where the Lowland steps meet the Aerial bridge and nobody owns the piece between. If you stand there and listen, you can hear where the river wants to go. The Minister sometimes goes there when the ledger sleeps. The stone speaks in those places. Even offworlders can hear it, if they are quiet." "I can be quiet," I said. Ires looked at me and then at the sky. "We will see," they said. "Be on time." And then we walked back into the east house, where the walls held their gods for the night and the bird carved on the door had just enough wing to make me think, for a moment, that it might lift.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkable achievement in capturing Le Guin's distinctive style and thematic concerns. The author has created a rich, textured world with layers of meaning embedded in physical descriptions, cultural artifacts, and social interactions. The prose demonstrates exceptional control of language, with descriptions that are evocative without being excessive. The author skillfully uses concrete details to suggest larger themes: the carvings that tell stories, the Minister's coat that has "learned the names of every room it had been in," the way light is described as "busy light, the river's light mixed with dust." These details create a sensory experience while simultaneously building the world and its history. Character development is handled with subtlety. The protagonist reveals themselves through observations and interactions rather than explicit statements. The diplomatic envoy's curiosity and willingness to break protocol reveal their character, while secondary characters like Ires and Minister Sato are distinct and complex despite limited page time. Sato particularly shines as a formidable political operator whose wisdom and pragmatism come through in dialogue that feels natural yet weighted with significance. The narrative structure follows the prompt precisely while creating a story that feels organic rather than formulaic. The envoy's unauthorized exploration of the market provides both world-building and thematic development, setting up the later confrontation with Command and the subsequent meeting with the Minister of Science. The piece excels at showing rather than telling. Instead of explaining the tensions between subspecies, we see interactions in the marketplace that complicate the official narrative. The author trusts readers to draw connections between observations. Dialogue is particularly strong, especially in the conversation between the envoy and Minister Sato. Their exchange reveals power dynamics, cultural differences, and competing interests while maintaining believability. Sato's lines like "Your experts are like my coat" and "We carved them so we remember when to stop" efficiently communicate character and theme. The world-building is exceptional, creating a sense of depth through references to myths, cultural practices, and physical structures. The author has clearly thought about how environment shapes culture, with details like the wind-named city and the carvings that serve as cultural memory. If there are weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally the prose becomes slightly dense, requiring careful reading to follow all the implications. The ending, while poetic, might feel slightly abrupt to some readers. However, these are minor quibbles in an otherwise outstanding piece. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 86.6
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The inverter coughed the way an old man does when the weather changes and the lights in my lab guttered to a dim orange smear. The solar panel out on the roof was a mosaic of scavenged cells soldered like a bad quilt, and the improvised charge controller could only do so much. When I first built it, the settlement called me a madman for trusting a sky still hazed with ash to power anything but regret. Tonight, the flicker was a rhythm: a nervous metronome to the evening’s work. The PCR machine on the bench whined as the voltage dipped. It wasn’t a real thermocycler, not anymore—just the shell of a GeneMelt 3000 I’d found in a flooded clinic, its brain gutted and replaced with a salvaged Raspberry Pi, a thermostatic relay from a dead HVAC, and a nest of coding I’d typed into existence with raw fingers over burned coffee. The heated lid was a pressure-cooker handle bolted on with epoxy. The reaction tubes were old, their caps soft from heat cycles, the silicone I used to seal the cracks containing more hope than polymer chemistry. “Pick a tone and stick with it,” I told the inverter. It rumbled once and settled, and the temperature readout on the cheap LCD held steady at ninety-five centigrade. Denaturation. A slow breath. I had maybe two cycles before the next flicker. Across the room, the gel rig hummed. That had been a real laugh—the gel rig. Two cracked picture frames for trays, soldered platinum wire lifted from a broken defibrillator, submerged in a polypropylene tub that once held industrial pickles. Agarose had to be made from seaweed I begged off the fishers who still went into what used to be a bay and was now a dark mirror with a dead reef under it. Ethidium bromide had gone with the old world; we stained with methylene blue boiled down and filtered through coffee paper. The bands it made were faint ghosts that you could only see if you knew where to look. I knew where to look. Outside the lab—the old kitchen in a condo tower with half its windows blasted out—voices murmured, the low burble of the settlement settling into night. Someone stomped, and a line of plaster dust drifted down from the ceiling, right into the top of my neck. I bit my lip and leaned in closer to the laptop, tracking the thermocycler’s progress. Thirty-five cycles. Forty. Fifty. It wasn’t ideal, but nothing was ideal anymore. The whole point of corporate genetic architecture had been to be just good enough to hold you hostage. Built-in cellular obsolescence sold as a feature; a royalty you paid in seed and blood every season because your crops and your kids couldn’t make their own enzymes anymore. Then the bottom fell out and the genes lost their shepherds. The obsolescence remained. The sample sitting in tube B5 was a miracle and a trap: a strand of legacy barley gene suites pre-labeled with the corporate watermark—a palindromic pseudogene sequence that guaranteed it would degrade after its product made it into one generation and no further. That watermark was brittle in places, especially where my own hands had been able to pry at it, but on the whole it remained. I used a CRISPR shim I’d written in the dead city library and templated it with scraps from heirloom seed DNA I’d pried from a museum’s display, but the enzyme I trusted—Cas9’s older sister, a thing we’d mutated into stubbornness—still got sloppy when the lights dipped. “Jax. You working?” The voice at the door was Mika’s: soft but carrying. I didn’t look up. It took me a second to realize why. The room had brightened. “Power stable for the next ten?” I asked, not looking away from the LCD. “Fifteen. We found another panel under the parking garage. Not broke all the way.” She ghosted into the lab like she always did, insubstantial until she leaned against the counter and made the tools clink against one another. “Client’s here.” “Client?” I shaded my eyes, finally turning. Two figures behind Mika, both wearing canvas longcoats and scarves despite the heat. The scarf on the one to the right—the thin one—was a mesh printed with an old stock ticker, now a hand-me-down veil. The other had a scar splitting their lip and a baseball bat slung over their shoulder, studded nails hammered through its business end. They smelled like dust and machine oil. The black market moved in smells, in exchanges of odors as much as goods: the tang of stale adrenaline, the metallic breath of scraped batteries, the green edge of stolen herbs. “We had a contract,” said the thin one. Their voice was flat and as genderless as the scarf. “You promised us seed that didn’t burn out.” I glanced at the bench. A row of pipette tips sat like teeth in a cheap plastic rack. My own saliva glands twinged. “I promised you viable seed for one planting. It’s all anyone can promise.” “You said you had a way around their watermark.” “I have ways to blunt it,” I said. “Peel it back in places. The problem isn’t me. It’s entropy.” “Entropy,” said the one with the bat, slow and considering. “Is that a lab word for ‘you’re not going to get what you paid for’?” Mika’s breath stirred the hair on my ear. I kept my face neutral. “Entropy’s the reason you got the vineyards you had, once. Why everything gets old and tired. Why your grandparents’ chimeras couldn’t conceive without ten thousand credits worth of prenatal enzyme cocktails.” The thin one made a noise like satisfaction. “We brought credits,” they said. They slid a small case onto the counter. When they cracked it, there was no glow—just care: nested in rough cloth, three phials of clear oil, and under those, a set of qubit chips in a shockproof sleeve and a blister pack of antibiotics. My hand twitched when I saw the antibiotics. There was a soft patch on my arm that had been getting angrier since the last time I injected the growth factor. “There’s extras,” the thin one said. “If it’s done.” I dropped a pipette tip and picked up a tube from the rack, ensuring that the movement didn’t show any tremor. The power held steady, the thermocycler beeped a bright double note and then simmered down to room temperature. I set the tube into a cradle and swung the lid down. Another epoxied handhold creaked. “Done is relative,” I said, and loaded the gel. The settlement had been living on millet and yeast and a kind of engineered moss that tolerated our sun. The corporate strains we had initially had worked for a season and then melted into useless cellulose. Seed hoarders had stepped in; so had people like me. I had found that the watermark could be interrupted if you left enough of it intact that the safety protocol thought it had done its job. In practice, that meant hybridizing old and new, the way the world had learned to make meaning from two broken sentences. The gel ran unevenly. I tapped the inverter; the current thrummed higher. Methylene blue seeped into the cool, cloudy matrix. I stained by memory—four minutes to see the small bands, six for the middle weights, ten for the big ones. I pulled the tray, slid it onto the improvised light box—a panel of UV LEDs I’d bodged together with scavenged smartphone flashlights and a strip of blacklight from an abandoned sex shop. The bands were pale. They were also where I’d expected. The watermark signature—eight jagged stripes like a jawline—had two gaps where there had been eight before. “I see that,” said the thin one, leaning in. “I also see more than I paid for, if I’m right. That’s… is that arsenic methylation resistance?” I had told myself I wouldn’t look surprised. It was a contract. Contracts kept you alive, even black market ones, because they were the only law left. But the thin one’s eye had flashed when they saw the band, and something in me leapt to an old, atavistic joy: a colleague. It had been a long time. “It's a trial,” I said, and exhaled, tasting bile that had nothing to do with the questionable protein stew Mika had made. “A tweak. The old water tables are rising, picking up metals no one thought would move. If the fields you’re putting this in are downstream from anything, you’ll need it.” “We aren’t downstream,” they said, but their mouth quirked above the scarf. “We’re what’s left of the upstream.” “Then keep it anyway,” I said, surprising myself. “Call it a bonus. Or a test. You bring me back data on how they performed and I’ll cut your next contract in half.” The bat carrier snorted softly. The thin one glanced at them, the kind of scan that told you years of working together had built its own wordless lexicon. They looked back at me. Their eyes were dark and very clear. “You’re bargaining with medicine, too,” they murmured, nodding at the blister pack in the case. “I heard you’ve been using your parties to test threshold modulation.” “Parties,” I said. “Is that what they’re calling them?” “What else? The way you blow open your toll receptors and make a fever of it. Makes everyone feel clean. Clear. Makes the aches back off. Makes them brave, too, and makes them do stupid things.” I touched the soft patch on my arm when they looked away. It itched, then burned. The first time I’d given myself the HGF hack, the pain in my hip—a slow, gnawed ache from lifting too much, sleeping on floors—had evaporated. I’d walked down the broken stairs without thinking for the first time in months. I’d also had a run of fevers and dreams that lasted four days, seeing lines of code floating in the steam of the pot I boiled water in. On the third day I’d written a set of primers by hand on a flattened cereal box and then found they worked. On the fourth, my teeth had felt loose. “It works,” I said. “Until it doesn’t. The settlement loves the way their wounds close faster. They hate that they can smell their own copper for a week. Side effects. Unintended upsides. The line’s thin.” Mika’s hand was on her knife, not threatening—just reminding me of edges. The bat carrier watched the windows, counting shadows. The thin one’s scarf had fallen open; their jaw was elegant and gone to tendon. I imagined, just for a breath, what a lab would do to that face. What it had done. The corporates had counted genetics in credit payout, glow-mapped children and told them they’d be artists or labor depending on the way their mitochondria burned. The thin one’s voice had that same old world education bent around road grit. “How much?” they asked. “For the seeds?” I looked at the numbers on my pad. Calculated what I needed to keep the thermocycler’s hacked brains from cooking off entirely when the voltage spikes came. Calculated also the cost of being greedy in a world with too many bats. “One qubit, the antibiotics, and one of those oils.” They tilted their head. “You know what the oils are?” “They’re glandular,” I said. “From the pigs that walk like people. The fat they make when we feed them the compost from the algae vats. They sleep better when they’re rubbed with it. So do my people. No nightmares. Cuts down on the shaking after the HGF.” The thin one smiled with half their mouth. It made the scar along the bat carrier’s lip look like something else: a punctuation mark instead of a threat. “Take two oils,” they said. “We’ll bring the data and we’ll take the half-price next time.” Lavish, Mika mouthed behind them, eyes gleaming. I reached for the case as if I were touching hot glass, and slid two of the vials into my own foam-lined slit, the blister pack of antibiotics into my pocket where the heat of my body could warm their false promise. “Now the seed,” the bat carrier said. I pointed with a gloved finger. The tubes to their left held a milky slurry of something that, in time, with the right care, with luck, would be green and tasseled. The shells were old pill bottles; the labels had been soaked off. Seed’s code was chimeric in places, where I’d inserted old genes into new chassis. In those gaps, the watermark read as silent, a broken poem the corporate gods couldn’t read. Mika counted out the tubes, watching how the bat carrier’s hands moved; I watched the thin one’s eyes flick to the flicker of the power die and surge. The lab’s lights trembled again, and the printer we used to make labels stuttered and then continued on, dotted lines giving way to solid. “You wanted this because you have fields,” I said, as casually as I could. “And you want it now because someone else does too. That’s a black market’s truth. Who’s the someone else?” “You’ll know,” the thin one said, wrapping their scarf back around their mouth. “When the wind shifts and there’s a smell of sugar in it. We’re racing them to sweetness.” Mika snorted. “Candy syndicates. I thought they were a myth.” “No myth,” the bat carrier said. “They courted our farm. Offered us a patent on rain that wouldn’t fall if we didn’t sign. We said no. That’s why we’re here.” I slid the final tube into the bat carrier’s hand. The skin there was thick like the rest of them, callused and cracked. I felt a flare of something like protection, then tamped it down. You don’t keep bargains by guarding people. You keep them by keeping them. “Plant in squares,” I said. “Not lines. That way, when the watermark starts to sing, it will drown itself in the cornering. Keep a border of the moss. It warps the pH and slows the decay.” “And the arsenic?” the thin one said. “If you get a sweet taste at the back of your mouth when it rains,” I said. “Don’t let anyone out.” Mika ushered them out with a grin that could have been a knife. When the door shut, I let my shoulders slump and leaned back against the bench. The inverter coughed again; the lights went thin for a moment, then fattened, then stabilized. The thermocycler spewed a puff of warm air and then wound down. “You gave them fate,” Mika said, offhand. “I gave them a game with better odds than the one they had,” I said. “And I got paid.” “Antibiotics,” she said, approving. Then she paused, nose wrinkling. “And pigsleep oil. You going to finally get a night without the river running through your skull?” “Maybe.” I held the vial up to the light. Glitter swam in it, not anything you could really see and still knowing. I imagined rubbing it into the soft skin over my sternum, feeling that somewhere under bone and cartilage, all the receptors I’d hacked awoke and subsided like a shore. Down in the street, someone yelled. It wasn’t alarm; the rhythm didn’t change in the settlement, and when the rhythm didn’t change, everything was fine enough. I let out a breath I didn’t know I’d tucked away behind my teeth. There had been a time when I had taken the corporate maintenance kits and carefully filled the prescriptions for my own body. Enzymes to keep my mucosa from sloughing, vitamins keyed to the way my liver could no longer use B12. Maintenance required maintenance. When the shipments stopped, we reinvented our bodies in the worst places: under broken skylights with the rain coming in sideways, in basements that smelled like bleach and rot. Sometimes it worked. Sometimes it didn’t. The upside of fear is that it sharpens your hand. The upside of a fever is that it burns, and sometimes it burns clean. I rubbed the itch on my arm. The spot had turned the color of old bricks. I would dose with the oil tonight and pray for sleep; tomorrow I would barter for more data and try to cut the watermark again, shave it down like a callus. The sugar wind would come or it wouldn’t. The upstream would fight the downstream over whose water was cleaner; the settlement would keep eating yeast-cakes and green algae pressed into noodles, dreaming of bread. And, if the luck I had argued into existence tonight held, there might be a field of grain in a month that didn’t die because it was told to. A failure of design would become a feature of survival. The inverter wheezed one last time and went quiet. The lab dropped into a darkness as soft as the oil in my hand. Out beyond the broken windows, the sky had faded to a bruise. Somewhere on a distant rooftop, a solar panel flickered. I could see its pulse like a heartbeat, uneven and insistent: power stitched together from salvaged light. I smiled into the dark and smelled, for a second, the idea of rain. Not sugar. Not yet. But close. Close enough to bargain with. Close enough to keep working.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk chapter successfully creates a vivid post-apocalyptic world where genetic engineering's built-in obsolescence has contributed to societal collapse. The narrative follows a biohacker working with jury-rigged equipment to splice viable food crops, centered around a black market contract as requested. The worldbuilding is particularly strong. The author has created detailed descriptions of improvised lab equipment: a PCR machine cobbled together from a GeneMelt 3000 shell, a Raspberry Pi, and salvaged parts; a gel rig made from picture frames and industrial pickle tubs; and a power system reliant on scavenged solar panels. These details effectively establish both the technological regression and the ingenuity required to survive. The physical toll of genetic modifications is well-represented through the protagonist's own body. The "soft patch" on their arm, the fevers, the copper taste, and the dreams all illustrate the consequences of self-experimentation. The unexpected upsides are also addressed—wounds closing faster, pain relief, and moments of clarity or inspiration during fever dreams. The black market contract forms the central plot element as requested, with the thin client and bat carrier seeking seeds that won't "burn out" after one generation. The transaction feels tense and authentic, with both parties cautious yet professional. The exchange of genetic material for antibiotics, qubit chips, and "pigsleep oil" establishes the barter economy of this world. The prose is generally strong, with evocative descriptions and a consistent voice that balances technical jargon with poetic observations. The narrator's voice feels authentic—weary but determined, pragmatic yet still capable of wonder. Sentences like "The upside of fear is that it sharpens your hand. The upside of a fever is that it burns, and sometimes it burns clean" demonstrate the blend of scientific detachment and emotional resonance. However, there are moments where the writing becomes slightly overwrought, with metaphors occasionally stacked too densely. Some passages could be tightened for clarity without losing their impact. The dialogue is functional but sometimes lacks the distinctiveness that would make each character's voice truly unique. The ending strikes an appropriate tone—not falsely optimistic, but containing a thread of hope that feels earned given the protagonist's small victory in creating seeds that might survive beyond one generation. The final image of power "stitched together from salvaged light" effectively encapsulates the theme of the chapter: finding ways to persist despite designed obsolescence. Overall, this is a strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements while creating an engaging narrative with thoughtful worldbuilding and character development. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 5 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 16.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 5.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Iteration 3 — Avg Score: 90.4
+ Classic sci-fi: The Azra Gambit — Score: 89.1
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi (Author style: Asimov) The Azra Gambit Colonial mars is being mined by corporations who take leases on indentured labourers. The thing they are mining is Azra, a recently discovered exotic metal which accelerates radioactive decay to such a rate that it is greatly sought after for interstellar drives and weapons alike. This has created both a gold rush and an arms race as various interests vie for control and endeavour to unlock Azra's secrets. The story follows Arthur Neegan, a first generation settler and mining engineer. Upon discovering that his unassuming plot sits atop an immense Azra vein, he is subjected to a flurry of interest and scrutiny. Write the next chapter in this story, in which an armed retinue descends on Arthur's home and politely but forcefully invites him to a meeting with some unknown party off-world. The insignia look like that of the Antares diplomatic corp -- diplomatic in name only. Arthur finds himself in the centre of a political tug of war. The chapter involves a meeting with this unknown party, who makes Arthur an offer. The scene should be primarily dialogue, interspersed with vivid description & scene setting. It should sow hints of the larger intrigue, stakes & dangers. Include Asimov's trademark big-and-small-picture world building and retrofuturistic classic scifi vibe. The chapter begins with Arthur aboard the transfer vessel, wondering just what he's gotten involved in. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Arthur tugged at the stiff collar again and felt it bite into the crease of his neck. The fabric had the texture of sanded plastic and smelled faintly of ozone. It was the sort of garment that made a man aware of his own shoulders, his own posture, his own sweat. He had put on pressure suits and mining harnesses in vacuum storms with less trouble. Beyond the viewport, Mars was a dull red coin slipping beneath the horizon of black. The transfer vessel was quiet, too quiet; its gravitic plates sang a tone barely below hearing, and that single pitch made the silence more profound. The cabin's lighting came from strips embedded in the ceiling, a sharp daylight that cast no shadows. The furniture was all curves, molded out of some resilient composite. The antigrav seats adjusted to his weight and then held him, gently and insistently. It was, he thought as he scratched at his collar, the way a polite jailer would hold a prisoner: carefully, impeccably, with professional courtesy. Opposite him sat two men with the blank faces of men who expected to be invisible. Their uniforms bore a starburst insignia: eight points, attenuated, caged by a ring. The ring had a subtle notch where a human eye would expect a complete circle. Antares. Diplomatic Corps in the registry, security arm in practice. In name only, Arthur thought with a trace of bitterness. They had arrived at his hab with their retinue of polite insistence, recited a form of words about an "invitation," and now he was seated across from their blank faces, watching Mars recede. The door slid open. The woman who entered was short and barrel-chested, brown skin burnished by artificial light, eyes that cataloged without seeming to. She wore no insignia, only a suit of charcoal fabric with a weave that suggested something more than cloth. A pin at her throat glowed an unassuming blue, a shape like two overlapping circles. Not Antares, then. Not obviously. "Mr. Neegan," she said, taking the seat to his right. "I'm glad you agreed to meet." Arthur glanced at the guards, then back at her. "I got the impression agreement wasn't necessary." She smiled. "Diplomacy is sometimes the art of providing options in a sequence that resembles a choice. My name is Leera Vast. My credentials are..." She paused. "Difficult to explain within your legal frame. You may consider me an attache to an interested consortium." "Which one?" "The one that prefers to remain unnamed until trust is established." Arthur had learned to weigh words. In the mines, the wrong word could start a strike; the right one could settle it and save a dozen backs. He measured her tone against her eyes and got a result he didn't entirely trust. He tugged his collar again. "You know why I'm here?" he asked. Leera gave a small tilt of the head. "You are here because your land grant sits upon a vein of Azra whose concentrations outstrip any recorded sample. You are here because that fact will inevitably draw not just prospectors but fleets. You are here because the pace of discovery in one sector of physics has, with remarkable predictability, outpaced the political infrastructure that can control it." "Azra accelerates decay," Arthur said. His words sounded like a textbook. "It makes dead elements die faster." Leera held up a hand. "Two points of correction. First, Azra does not accelerate decay. Azra permits decay paths that were previously forbidden by symmetry. It changes the branching ratios in ways not fully mapped. Second, that difference matters because it means Azra is not merely a catalyst; it is an operator on probability. In drives, your fuel mass becomes dead mass at a rate of our choosing. In weapons, your neighbors' mass becomes heat. In economics..." She opened her palm, as if to show him the empty air. "Debts vanish or compound depending on whose mass is coupled to the cascade. In politics, the side which can turn patience into an explosive event controls time itself." Arthur let out a breath. He had heard rhetoric about Azra since the first sample came down from the Schiaparelli crater. The prospector who had brung it—he remembered the news images: gaunt, grinning, then gone, the victim of a refinery accident that had the smell of too neat an ending. He remembered the contracts that came afterward, the leases, the clever clauses. He remembered his father, who had helped cover the initial crater rim with domes, reciting the old settler's proverb: Don't sell the air, son. "You want to buy my air," Arthur said. Leera folded her hands. "We want to purchase your silence." The guards opposite didn't turn their heads, but Arthur caught the way their eyes flicked, the barest movement. Even they hadn't known the exact phrasing. "Let me be plainer," Leera continued. "Your mine is not merely a mine. It is a lever. If you announce your find, if you sell to the first corporate combine that offers you triple the quoted rate, you will become a node in a network of obligations. Antares will insist on inspection rights in the name of safety. The Titan Syndics will argue prior claim through their indenture supply chain. Earth Central will send an envoy. The Belt will threaten embargo. In that storm, you and your claim will be transformed into something like a lighthouse placed in the center of a naval battle." "You think you can avoid the storm." "I think," Leera said, and now her voice was the even tone of a teacher addressing a room of engineers, "that storms can be steered. We propose to create a delay. We want your vein to be mischaracterized, surveyed incorrectly, the data to be ambiguous enough to confuse the simple algorithms the corporations use to prioritize. In return, we offer you three things. First, a sum that would let you buy half a dome's worth of oxygen rights in Galle Crater. Second, protection in a form that does not look like protection; that is, pressure applied to rivals, not shields around you. Third, inclusion." "Inclusion," Arthur repeated. "In the circle of people who are asked to comment before decisions are made. Governance is a game. Those who play are those whose names appear on memos before the memos become directives."
