The apricot is sticky on my fingers. “Yes,” I say. He laughs. It’s nice. It slides over me, loosening a bolt. “You got a place?” he asks. “I have a backpack.” “That’s a hell of a bed,” he says. He leans back, balancing the milk crate on its rear edge, testing gravity like he knows it personally. “There’s a spot under the overpass where people crash. You’d hate it and then you wouldn’t. I could show you. Or, there’s a shelter with too many rules and not enough answers. Your call.” He watches my face like a mirror he can read. There’s a part of me that wants to say: I’m actually just waiting for my Uber to the rest of my life. Please leave me alone so I can pretend I’m not drowning. The rest of me knows better. “Overpass,” I say. He nods like he knew I’d say that. He knows a lot, probably too much. He hops off the crate. “What’s your name?” The question lands heavy. My phone chimes in my pocket. Four percent. I pull it out and show him the dying red symbol like I can use it to not answer. “Taylor,” I say. It feels like putting on a shirt that fits now. I’m braced for the flinch, the pause, the oh. He just nods. “Okay, Taylor. Let’s go.” We weave through Quarter tourists and old men yelling about chess. The river pulls at us, a flat muscle, mean and beautiful. I’m distracted by a dog wearing shoes. River is distracted by nothing and everything; he watches windows like he can see the backs of people’s heads and what’s inside them. “Why River?” I ask, because I want to turn us both into jokes before anything gets true. “I stole it,” he says, and doesn’t say from whom. He kicks a bottle cap into a drain. “My mom used to say you can’t step in the same river twice. I figured that meant I could be someone else whenever I wanted.” “What about your mom now?” I ask, and immediately want to rewind my mouth. “Different river,” he says. Then, before I can hook my apology onto something: “What’d you do?” He means: what about the counsellor voice that stamped me as a file, what about the kitchen table and the shouting, what about Cass’s text. “I told the truth and it didn’t go well,” I say. My throat tightens. Stupid clumsy truth. “They think I’m… They think.” Words are dumb little pebbles, rolling. “I had to leave before I left in a different way.” He glances at me and nods, small and tight, like he understands and also isn’t allowed to show me that. “Yeah,” he says softly. “I know that one.” We reach the overpass, a concrete cathedral with pigeons for angels. Tents bloom like sad mushrooms. There are shopping carts decorated like altars, blankets that have learned to be walls. A woman in a stained wedding dress is painting her nails careful and bright. The sound of cars overhead is ocean and artillery. It should be terrifying. It is. Also: it’s honest. River navigates like a tour guide who doesn’t want to be there, pointing out a corner where a guy will try to sell you soap that’s actually rocks, a patch to avoid unless you like needles, a church van that comes at noon with sandwiches and lectures. The air tastes like dust and metal and someone’s cooking something amazing three blocks over. “Stick near me,” he says, casual, like I’m a stray and he’s throwing me a string of sausages. “Are you charging for this?” I ask, because I need him to be a hustler more than a savior. You can predict hustlers. “Pay me in jokes,” he says. “And gum, if you have any.” “I have depression,” I offer. “Is that like gum?” “Depends if it’s mint,” he says, and grins. “We’ll find you part-time work. Don’t worry. Street’ll eat you if you taste like worry.” We settle under a scorch of shadow that smells slightly better. A kid I’d call twelve if time wasn’t on fire hands me a bottle of water like I’m about to faint. I drink half and save the other half because that’s what Cass would tell me: ration your kindnesses and your electrolytes. My phone vibrates again. Two percent. Cass: call me when you can. I type: Can’t. Love you. You were the only one who saw me. The screen dims like a curtain. One percent. I look at the little battery like if I beg it’ll sprout another bar. It does not. The phone dies in my hand. Relief sours with panic. “You look like you just watched your best friend sink,” River says. “Who says I didn’t?” I tuck the dead rectangle back into my pocket like a corpse. “What’s your secret?” It comes out meaner than I meant. Because I’m jealous of his ease, because I am raw and it stings. He goes still. He opens his mouth, closes it. For a second, his face is just a kid who fell off his bike and doesn’t want to cry. Then he shrugs, aiming for careless, hitting bone. “I got a brother,” he says. “He thinks I died. Or wishes it. I can’t decide which is easier.” I wait. The highway hums over our heads like a big animal sleeping. Someone laughs, high and rusted. “He took the hit for me once,” River says. “Cops. He’s better at being the good one. Except now he’s probably on his third strike because I was on my way to be the second. I don’t know. It’s math I can’t do. I’m not going back. He’s not either. That’s the secret: there’s no back.” It sits between us like a third person neither of us introduced. My chest hurts. I want to say something smart and brave. I say: “I’m sorry.” It’s stupid because it doesn’t fix anything. He nods like he gets that I can’t fix anything. “No pity,” he says softly. “Pity gets you pickpocketed.” “Okay,” I say. “No pity. Just… curses.” He smiles at that. We let the silence stretch. It holds. By noon, the church van shows up and a woman with arms like a linebacker hands me a sandwich and asks if I’ve accepted Jesus. I say I’m more of a begrudging acquaintance. She laughs, louder than strictly necessary, and tells me I can come by the shelter if I need “women’s toiletries.” The word catches in my chest like a fish hook. I nod and take the bag. River’s eyes flicker, checking me for blood, I think. Or checking which way I’ll run. “People see what they want,” he says later, when we’re chewing lettuce and bread and something approximating turkey. “The trick is to feed them what makes them full and keep the good stuff for yourself.” “What’s the good stuff?” I ask. He taps his chest. “You. Your name. Your night brain. The parts you’d kick anyone else for touching.” “My night brain is an asshole,” I say. “It would steal your lighter.” He looks at me. “Maybe. Or maybe it’s telling you something you’re chewing too fast to taste.” He talks like that sometimes, like a poem is falling out of a hole in his pocket. It’s annoying. It’s also… comforting. The day bakes. Somebody starts drumming on overturned buckets and the beat becomes the ground. Later, a man with a face like a wrinkled dollar bill drifts over and asks if either of us wants to make “quick cash.” River tells him, “We’re expensive,” and the man wanders away, muttering. After, River says, quiet: “Don’t go with anyone. Not your first day. Not your tenth. They’ll tell you they’ll make you family. Family is light and food and sometimes prison. This isn’t that.” “I had a family,” I say. He waits. I swallow. “It was a lot of bathrooms with me staring in the mirror and trying to make my mouth do something easy. I used to think if I smiled right it would all rearrange.” “And?” he asks. “It did,” I say. “But not the way they wanted.” By late afternoon, I am sweat and quiet. The sun moves around, finds me wherever I try to hide. River disappears for half an hour and I have a minor panic attack, imagining he’s gone forever, that he was a hallucination called hunger. He comes back with a phone charger that looks like it’s been run over twice and a cheap brick of a battery pack. “Found it,” he says. “You stole it,” I say. “Found it,” he repeats, and hands me the cord like a gift. He looks proud and a little nervous, like maybe I’ll judge him. I don’t. I want to cry. I plug my dead phone in and it blinks awake, petulant, a Tamagotchi revived. Messages from numbers I don’t recognize. One from Mom, long and full of scripture and ellipses, the words wobbling like jelly. One from Dad: Call me. One from Cass: I’m here whenever. I turn the screen face down because if I look at it too long I’ll turn to salt. We go to the river as the sun drops its last coins on the water. The air is thick enough to drink. People are out—couples with hands attached, kids trying to sell bottled water that’s warmed in the sun. A man plays something on a guitar that makes me think of a door I closed too early. We sit on the steps and watch boats shoulder past, slow and important. I think about leaving and then not leaving and all the versions of me shedding like snakeskin behind us. I think about the school counsellor’s voice on that call to Mom, crisp and careful: We’re concerned about Taylor’s pattern of… I think about Mom’s face, the way it ripped when I said it. Not my first secret. My best one, finally spoken. I lean my head on my knees. “So,” River says after a while, in a voice that’s almost a question. “You staying?” “I don’t know what staying is,” I say. “But I’m not going back.” “That’ll do,” he says. He nudges my shoulder with his. “Tonight you can be a tourist. Tomorrow you can be a problem.” “Deal,” I say. My phone buzzes once against my thigh. I let it. The sky slips from orange to bruise. Somewhere, a band is finding its song, the horn bending into it, the drum promising to catch them if they fall. The river keeps moving, not asking permission. I think: maybe I can learn that. My feet, restless all day, finally quiet. My heart doesn’t, but it changes its rhythm. It doesn’t sound like running anymore. It sounds like starting.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the voice of a transgender teen runaway navigating their first day in New Orleans. The writing demonstrates considerable skill in creating an authentic first-person perspective with vivid sensory details that bring the setting to life. The character of Taylor is well-developed, with a complex emotional landscape that feels authentic to their situation. Their internal monologue reveals vulnerability, fear, and determination in equal measure. The backstory is woven in naturally through reflections and brief mentions rather than exposition dumps. River serves as an effective foil and guide character, with his own mysterious past and survival skills. The relationship that develops between the two characters feels organic and appropriately tentative given their circumstances. The prose style is particularly strong, with evocative metaphors and sensory details that create a vivid sense of place. Lines like "New Orleans smells like warm sugar rotting in a flowerpot" and descriptions of the light that "slides over the cracked sidewalks like it's curious" demonstrate sophisticated imagery. The author effectively uses sentence fragments and varied sentence structures to create a distinctive voice for Taylor. The dialogue is natural and revealing, with each character having a distinct speaking style. River's poetic tendencies contrast with Taylor's more direct approach, creating an interesting dynamic. The conversations reveal character without becoming expository. The piece avoids common pitfalls of stories about runaways by not romanticizing homelessness. It acknowledges dangers and difficulties while still allowing for human connection. The ending strikes an appropriate balance between hope and realism - Taylor isn't magically saved, but has found a temporary foothold and companion. There are a few instances where metaphors become slightly overwrought ("The river pulls at us, a flat muscle, mean and beautiful"), but these are balanced by more straightforward observations. The pacing is effective, covering a full day without rushing or dragging. The story successfully fulfills the prompt requirements, maintaining first-person perspective, incorporating internal monologue, and featuring dialogue with interesting characters. It captures Taylor's conflicting emotions about their identity, family situation, and uncertain future. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Dystopic-comedy: My Apocalypse Buddy — Score: 91.2
Prompt:
My Apocalypse Buddy Write a wry, dry short story of survival and adventure loosely in the style of Terry Pratchett, set in the post-technological collapse world. The story begins with the pair deliberating their predicament and intent for the day's mission, details the ways in which the mission inevitably goes sideways, and returns them to home base in multiple ways, worse for wear. [characters] - the animo-tronic stuffed koala, Chewy, from some long forgotten before time - midas, our hapless protagonist, who has a knack for finding himself in the worst kinds of trouble. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The day dawned with the sincerity of a politician and the reliability of a hand-cranked toaster. The sky was the soft-colored bruise of a world that had tried to keep going and tripped on its shoelaces anyway. Midas lay on his back in the former break room of the former Museum of Advancement, now their home base on account of three working locks and zero working exhibits. Beside him, perched on a dented coffee tin like a furry oracle, sat Chewy, an animo-tronic stuffed koala, who regarded the ceiling with the philosophical calm of one who has only two expressions and one of them is “hungry.” “Inventory,” Midas said. He cleared his throat like a man looking into a very small and very empty wallet. “We have: three packets of soup powder, no soup, a fishing hook without line, a battery that powers a clock when it wants to embarrass me, and… a jar of beets. Red ones.” Chewy’s eyes flickered a low, suspicious amber. He neither approved nor disapproved of beets. Chewy did not so much have a palate as a list of things that were “edible” and “not batteries.” “And,” Midas continued, “we have a map of the Old City, drawn by someone whose definition of ‘north’ suggests they were born upside down.” Chewy’s pupils dilated. His left eye blinked blue, the right green. The first meant hope. The second meant Midas was doing that thing again where he tried to turn optimism into a verb. “Our intent,” Midas said, enunciating as if the universe were a notary public, “is to go to the Techno-Mall, which, according to rumor, is still guarded by a skeleton of society. Or actual skeletons. We procure food and maybe bits of wire for your… you know.” Chewy’s eyes flashed violet, which was embarrassment. There were two wires inside him that had once connected to a voice chip, a little metal disc that had a child’s laughter and pre-programmed phrases like “Hugs!” and “Nap time!” Nothing came out now but grunts and the occasional staticky curse, which Midas was relatively sure was not in the original product manual. “Right,” Midas said. He stood and stretched, counting his aches like rosary beads. “So we walk out of here, we don’t get eaten by runt packs—” Chewy went yellow at the mention. Yellow was fear. It was Chewy’s most versatile setting. “—we don’t step on any mischief tiles—” The Museum’s floors had been fitted, in optimistic days, with interactive panels that lit up and explained the wonders beneath your feet. They had not coped well with rain. Now they retold their narratives as random bursts of electricity and the occasional unnerving sentence about the importance of curiosity seconds before trying to kill you. “—and we come back before the pink sky. Because if the sky goes pink, we don’t joke. We hide and stay quiet and we do not talk about what happened last time.” Chewy’s eyes went the color of a deep lake. He leaned forward, head cocked, and made a tiny mechanical sound like a sigh. “Team,” Midas said, putting a hand on a fabric ear worn nearly bald by fingers that had loved it in a happier world, “we have a plan.” They always had a plan. Plans were the things that happened before life opened the trapdoor. They left by way of a stairwell that sighed like an old tea kettle. Pigeons watched and disliked them without energy. The street was a corridor of weeds and former cars. Somewhere a dog barked with the voice of a trombone with a cold. Midas held a stick, which is the sort of thing that made no sense as a weapon until it did. “There,” Midas whispered theatrically at a fallen billboard advertising laugh lines you didn’t have to have. “We go past the Skin Care Cathedral, under the Flyover of Broken Promises, and then—we’re practically there.” Chewy’s eyes turned a very annoyed teal. He pointed, causing his elbow servos to whine just a bit—over the years, oil had become an exotic treat. Midas squinted. He had, admittedly, inverted their route. The Flyover of Broken Promises was the pile of concrete to the left, not the right. The difference was important because to the right the ground wavered in that oceanic way that meant the dirt was trying to remember if it used to be a bog or had just read about bogs somewhere and wanted to try. “Left, then,” Midas said, and they went left. The Techno-Mall had been a temple to commerce: four floors of glass and neon, escalators lifting people toward their financial decisions like gentle jaws. It had once held a store called Planet of Clothes and a place that sold five varieties of yogurt that all tasted like existential disappointment. Now it was a rectangle of broken teeth and dangling tendons of wiring, humming in a voice that said: I am not as dead as I look. “Look,” Midas said, indicating a sign that read, partially, WEL OM S A ERS! The letters that were still there tried their hardest. “Friendly.” They slipped through a door that had made its peace with its hinges. Inside lay the hollows of former trolleys, nests made of receipts and novelty sweaters. The air smelled faintly of the world’s last cinnamon roll. “Food court,” Midas murmured. It had not, in honesty, fed anyone in a decade. But the stalls were shelter, and sometimes pigeons failed to understand the concept of ceilings. Pigeons contain a surprising amount of protein, even if dignity is lost in the preparation. Chewy tapped his metal paw against Midas’s shoulder with a series of precise clinks, which meant: quiet. His eyes slid to a mean little red, which meant: danger that is more organized than it looks. Midas heard it: the soft chuckle of an escalator doing its best impression of a crocodile. He looked up. The small entourage of the mall’s new skeleton guard had arranged themselves along the escalators like queens on chessboards. Mannequins. Not the friendly kind that liked hats. These had been drafted. Bits of rebar gave them spines. They had acquired tools, or the idea of tools, or perhaps a religion of sharpness. They turned their heads together. This was worse than eyes in the dark. This was eyes on ball joints that had opinions. Midas raised his stick. He was not sure what he intended to do with it, but he hoped his lack of a plan surprised them. Chewy blinked—a sudden series of strobe whites. This was the emotional color for: I think if I do something very stupid it will either be brilliant or fatal. His paws moved in patterns he had not learned, but which had been imprinted by an engineer who loved Easter eggs. Chewy croaked, as if deep within him an ancient slogan had dusted itself off: “H—h…hugs!” The mannequins froze. “Hugs!” Chewy repeated, more confidently, although his voice cracked on the s and came out as “hugz.” Midas felt the world pause to consider slapstick. “Yes,” he said. “Hugs. We brought them. For you.” A mannequin’s head ticked. It had a smile carved into its face with a key. Its hand, which was a soup ladle tied to a broom handle, dipped. It began its slow descent down the escalator, which protested, then remembered its job. Midas did not love this. He tugged Chewy backwards, step by dragging step, the wheels in Chewy’s hips murmuring about the poor life choices of grit. The second mannequin moved. And the third. Their steps were ordinary and wrong at once. “This is when the plan goes sideways,” Midas whispered. “Hu—hugs!” Chewy said brightly, and his eyes flashed a frantic rainbow. They ran. They ran past a games store where plastic boxes spilled like fossilized confetti, past a defunct fountain full of coins that had not bought wishes in years, past signage that offered: Now Open Wednesday Through Armageddon. Two of the mannequins followed, clacking, while an escalator whined “maintenance” in a voice that was all knives. They skidded into the supermarket space, which had been scoured years ago by the sort of people who think beans are forever. Midas dove behind a checkout lane, its conveyor belt succumbing to lichen. He held his breath in quarters: one quarter for courage, three quarters for luck. The mannequins arrived, two statues with heads that pivoted like owls learning to gossip. Chewy climbed onto the conveyor belt, belly on rubber, paws braced, eyes green for recall. He butted a button with his head. The belt moved. There is something undignified about being rolled toward a threat like a sandwich. However, the threat was full of holes. The belt took Chewy past them slowly, insolently. The mannequins turned, too slow, while Midas pushed himself over the counter and crawled beneath their legs—their legs were silly things, long pins in old sneakers—then jumped up, grabbed Chewy mid-belt, and ran like history had offered him a refund and he didn’t want it. They made it to the service corridor, which smelled like mildew and arguments. They passed a mural encouraging employees to “Live the Brand,” which now had a mustache in spray paint. The corridor ended in a door with an electronic lock, the kind that had made people feel modern. The keypad blinked at them with the lazy menace of a cat in the sun. Midas put his ear to it. Nothing. He looked at Chewy. Chewy’s eyes went a long-suffering blue, the one that meant: you’re going to try talking to it, aren’t you. “Listen,” Midas told the keypad. “We’re refugees. We’re in a hurry. The world is in pieces and you are a door. Be what you were made to be.” He pressed 1-2-3-4. The light went red. The door clicked at him, like a man clucking his tongue. Midas pressed 0-0-0-0. Red again. Chewy’s eyes went orange, which was the color of impending practical improvisation. He shuffled forward, angled his head so that the little speaker inside aligned, hummed the descending three-note chime that the manufacturer had probably never imagined anyone would hum to it, and then coughed. The door made a different click. It was the sound of recognition. The wire inside Chewy that had carried the sound earlier sparked like a star falling in an ashtray. The lock sighed. Open. “You incredible creature,” Midas whispered, pushing through. “You absolute marvel. You hero with stuffing.” Chewy’s eyes blazed a quick magenta—pride—and then sank into a brownish-pink that meant: that hurt. The alley outside was damp and honest. They went left, which was wrong, then right, which was worse, and then through a yard full of burnt fake palm trees. Midas, in a moment of genius inspired by fear, decided to take the short way across the rooftop of a pharmacy that had not weathered weather. They reached the center of the roof before the roof remembered it used to have support. It sighed and gave up. They fell through a perfectly square hole into a shelf full of cheap romance novels, which exploded around them with the embarrassed sighs of people caught kissing. Midas landed on his ankle, which immediately swelled into a small opinion piece about physics. Chewy bounced. Being stuffed had advantages. The pharmacy had rats. The rats had manners, which is to say they declined to panic. They watched as Midas sat and said several words that would have made the Museum’s educational brochure blush. He tore a strip from his shirt, wrapped his ankle, and looked Chewy in the face. “On a scale of one to we should go home,” he said, “I’m at: we should go home.” Chewy’s eyes were a slow, steady green. Home. They limped. Time did that elastic thing it does in bad comedies and good disasters. In one version of their return, they took the alley past the barber’s pole and were harried by a runt pack that had learned to mistrust sticks. Chewy, climbing onto Midas’s shoulder with the tenacity of a Christmas ornament, waved his arm with the unassailable authority of plush and made the universal sign for “No,” which looks, when you are a koala, astonishingly like “Yes.” The dogs, being philosophers, debated among themselves and then decided to chase a can in circles. In another version, the sky went pink and they crawled into an overturned freezer, Chewy’s eyes the color of prayer while something very large and very quiet moved past outside in the manner of a tax audit. In yet another, Midas fell into a mischief tile, which responded to the sincerity of his foot by flashing the words: Curiosity! Innovation! and then punching him in the kneecap with a foam piston. They returned in multiple ways, all true at once and each unhelpful at the time. Home was a set of rooms that smelled like dust and the ghost of coffee. The locks worked. The pigeons did not. Midas collapsed onto the museum couch, which had pretensions of velvet and the springs of a trap. His ankle throbbed in a Morse code that spelled mostly expletives. He held Chewy up and looked into his eyes. “We have,” he said, “no beets now. Because they broke on the second fall. We have one less dignity. We have, technically, a new hole in the pharmacy that is ours if we ever want to stage an elaborate heist on a decongestant.” Chewy’s eyes were a thoughtful periwinkle. His belly made a small noise that was either a whirr or a complaint. He set his head on Midas’s chest with the heaviness of things that are known and survived. Midas stared at the ceiling. The Museum’s dark was gentle. Outside, the city coughed and creaked and decided to remain mostly in one piece for the night. He reached for the map and, because he was built the way he was, he found a stray pencil and made a note in the margin, in a handwriting that had ideas above its station. Techno-Mall: not friendly. Avoid the escalators. Hug strategy: effective in short bursts. Door likes lullabies. Pharmacy hole: use for future mischief. Note: teach Chewy other songs. Chewy’s eyes blinked in a slow, contented blue. He seemed to agree that the day had been a sort of success. They had gone out. They had come back. They had not vanished into a pink sky or become the third act of someone else’s tragedy. They were worse for wear in the way that means “alive.” “Tomorrow,” Midas said, “we try the river. I have it on good authority that the fish there are stupider than we are.” Chewy’s eyes did the involuntary shimmer that meant laughter, if laughter were a color. He reached a paw up and tapped a beat against Midas’s collarbone, a rhythm that had once matched a jingle, but now, in the quiet, was only theirs. They slept beneath a banner that read: The Future Is Interactive. The banner had no idea how right it had been. The future, such as it was, rustled in the walls and blinked once outside the window and then, deciding that today had been entertains enough, wandered off to bother someone else. Midas dreamed of escalators that moved you up and down and also sideways, and of doors that opened because you said please. He dreamed, unexpectedly, of beets. In the morning, when he woke to Chewy’s eyes doing their snip of yellow because his ankle had puffed up to twice itself, he laughed, because laughter weighed less than worry and kept better. “Inventory,” he said again, because the day needed labels. “We have: one ankle like a melon with ambition. One jar of broken beets and a beet rug. One stuffed koala who can talk to doors and lie to mannequins. One stick that we should put next to the other sticks for consistency. And one plan.” Chewy’s eyes flashed. Hope. Disbelief. Love. He climbed onto the coffee tin, which had dented itself into the shape of his bottom, and nodded. “Plan,” Midas said. “We try not to die. We try to do it funnier than yesterday. We try to be the people who come back.” Outside, the sky coughed up a hopeful gray. The pigeons complained. The city, broken but ambitious, waited to misinterpret them again. They stood up, each more fragile than they admitted, and went to meet it. The day opened like a door, and because Chewy was there, it did not lock behind them. Not yet. Not today.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This short story successfully captures Terry Pratchett's wry, dry style while creating a post-apocalyptic world that feels both absurd and believable. The narrative follows Midas and his animatronic koala companion Chewy on a scavenging mission that predictably goes awry, fulfilling the prompt requirements. The writing excels in its worldbuilding through small, telling details: the "Museum of Advancement" as their base, mannequins as threats, and the clever repurposing of pre-collapse technology. The author creates a distinctive voice with Pratchett-esque similes ("The day dawned with the sincerity of a politician") and metaphors that blend humor with melancholy. Character development is particularly strong. Midas embodies the hapless protagonist archetype with his misplaced optimism and tendency to find trouble. Chewy is brilliantly realized through his eye-color communication system and damaged voice chip, giving him personality despite limited means of expression. Their relationship feels genuine and emotionally resonant. The prose demonstrates sophistication in its balance of humor and poignancy. Lines like "Plans were the things that happened before life opened the trapdoor" capture the story's philosophical underpinnings without becoming heavy-handed. The author skillfully employs varied sentence structures and rhythms to maintain engagement. The narrative structure follows the prompt's requirements, showing the pair's deliberation, their mission going sideways (literally, with the roof collapse), and their return home "worse for wear." The multiple versions of their return journey is a particularly clever touch that adds depth to the storytelling. There are occasional moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought, with metaphors piling upon metaphors. A few passages might benefit from more restraint, but these instances are rare and don't significantly detract from the overall quality. The dialogue, though limited, effectively reveals character and advances the plot. The interaction between Midas's verbose planning and Chewy's color-coded responses creates a charming dynamic that drives the narrative forward. Overall, this is an exceptional response that demonstrates mastery of Pratchett's style while creating something original. The story balances humor and heart, absurdity and authenticity, in a way that would likely please fans of the genre. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Romance: Love in the Limelight — Score: 88.4
Prompt:
Romance: Love in the Limelight. Write one scene within a larger story set in Wales. A famous (fictional) actor ducks into a small-town bookstore to escape paparazzi. The scene takes us through the characters meeting in this odd circumstance. Over the course of the scene, the actor and the bookstore owner have a conversation charged by an undercurrent of unspoken chemistry. Write the actor as somewhat of a rogue with a fragile ego, which needs to be fed by having everyone like him. He is thoroughly charming, but the bookstore owner seems (at least superficially) immune to this; which paradoxically provokes a genuine attraction and derails the charm offensive. The bookstore owner, despite the superficial rebuffs of the actor's charm, is inwardly more than a little charmed and flustered despite themselves. Write primarily in dialogue, in the distinct voices of each character. 1000 words.
Model Output:
“Close the door!” “Excuse me?” “For God’s sake, shut it—unless you’d like the entire Western Mail to come in and alphabetise the travel section.” A hand fumbled at the brass knob, the bell over the door clanged, and the actor ducked inside with a soft curse, a gust of damp Cardiff air following him. He wore a navy peacoat and sunglasses despite the cloud and fine drizzle, hair flattened in a way that said he’d been sprinting. The street noise receded as the door thumped shut. He pressed his back against it for a beat, panting, then glanced up, grin already at half wattage. “Sorry. Hi.” He slid the glasses down his nose and blinked at me. “I’m not—er—shoplifting a moment of peace. I’ll buy something. Two of somethings. Three.” “Have you considered a hat?” I said, returning to the till as if my heart hadn’t just leapt into my throat. “Hats are very effective when one is famous and has a very distinctive jawline.” He touched his jaw, glanced reflexively at the dark window. A smear of rain turned the High Street into a watercolour. There were shapes hovering just beyond the glass—long lenses like fishing rods, a murmur. He pushed off the door and slid between a table of staff picks and the Welsh history shelf as though he’d been born to sidle. “You’re very calm,” he said. His voice did the thing it did in the films—all warmth with a scratch at the edges that you suspect is deliberate. “Usually there’s squealing.” “We try to keep squealing to a minimum. It upsets the poetry.” He laughed—real, surprised. “Do you sell any poetry that causes a stampede toward the back exit?” “Dylan Thomas in emergencies.” I nodded toward the stockroom. “Is it a proper emergency or only… mild?” He tilted his head, listening. The murmur outside swelled and ebbed, like the Taff on a windy day. “They’ll get bored, eventually. Or the rain will do my job for me.” He looked around then, taking in the shop. It had been my grandmother’s and smelled like her: paper, bergamot, a hint of dust and lemon oil. Narrow aisles, piles that threatened collapse but never did. He touched a book as he passed as if conducting a silent roll call. “This is a gorgeous place. I’ve been trying to find it for—” “Don’t,” I said, holding up a hand. “Please don’t.” “Don’t what?” He did the smile, the one that softened the hard cut of him. “Don’t say you’ve been trying to find a genuine bookstore because you love the smell, or that you miss real shops because everything’s an app now. It’s a very charming speech when one is not watching four men with cameras lick your window.” He blinked. The smile faltered, almost imperceptibly. “Right. Noted.” The falter was interesting; the bruised apple under the gloss. He put the sunglasses in his pocket. His eyes were greener than they ought to be. “I’m Ellis.” “I know.” “Right.” He spread his hands, palms up—a mime of harmlessness. “Cardiff’s own prodigal son. I’ve been away and now I return with my silly face to ruin your afternoon.” “You’re from Whitchurch,” I said, reaching for the price gun because my hands wanted something to do. “That’s not exactly Rome.” “Whitchurch is as good as Rome,” he said. “Better sandwiches.” He leaned against a stack of secondhand crime novels with a carelessness that would have scandalised my grandmother, then corrected himself, standing straight. “Sorry. I’m not good with—” He gestured at the air. “Rules of shops.” “You’re excellent with not shutting doors.” “That I did do. Eventually.” He drummed his fingers on the spines behind him. It was almost restful, the way he watched my not quite smiling. My cheeks were warm and I hated it. “Are you going to call me a prat and tell me to leave?” “I’m going to tell you that if you pull that stack you’re leaning on, the Ken Folletts will fall and I’ll have to kill you.” He moved away from the stack like it might be wired. “Message received.” The bell chimed as the door nudged, then settled. A sheen of flashbulb light leaked through the crack between blind and sill. He flinched. It wasn’t big, but I saw it, the way you see a bird hit glass. He slid his hands into his coat pockets, the charm dial turned down. “Do you have a back door?” he asked softly. “I do. There’s a mews that way. It connects to the lane behind the dentist. You could go through—” “—and pop out into another swarm.” He lifted a shoulder. “They’re not stupid.” “No.” I straightened a stack of bookmarks that had been straight the entire time. “You can sit in the office for a bit. There’s a kettle. They’ve got the staying power of a toddler in a museum; give them twenty minutes and a drizzle and they’ll be off to find someone more interesting.” “I doubt that,” he said, automatic, like a reflex. Then his mouth caught up with his words and curved ruefully. “That’s the wrong thing to say, isn’t it.” “It depends whether you mean it.” He looked at the floor. “I mean… I’m good at being interesting. It’s my job.” “And yet,” I said carefully, “you look like you want to climb into the cardboard boxes and be shipped to someone in Aberystwyth.” He laughed again, quieter. “Do you usually psychoanalyse men who blunder into your shop dripping charisma and rain?” “Only the ones who try to rescue Steve McQueen.” “Now that I deeply deserve,” he said. “I’m a thief. Unrepentant. Put me in a room with a first edition and no alarms and we’ll see.” “You’d get far with that coat.” He ran a hand over the peacoat lapel, this absurd, unconscious preening gesture that he likely thought was invisible. “I’ve been told it makes me look like a dock worker in a French New Wave film.” “Dirk Bogarde wishes,” I said before I could stop myself. He glanced up, startled into a grin. “Dirk Bogarde. That’s a good insult.” “It’s not an insult,” I said, mortified to hear the warmth in my voice. “It’s a— comparative assessment.” “Of what, exactly?” “Coats.” “Mm.” He took a step toward the counter, then caught himself and stayed by the mystery novels like a tether had tightened. “What’s your name?” “Gwen.” “Gwen,” he repeated, tasting it. “Short for anything?” “Gwenllian, if you must know.” “Oh, I must.” He rolled it in his mouth, the consonants slipping around his posh corners. “Gwenllian. That’s beautiful.” “It’s inconvenient in Starbucks.” “You don’t seem like the type to go to Starbucks.” “And yet here I am, a person with hands and a morning.” He nodded at the kettle in the back. “Tea? Or will that be breaking a rule?” “You may have tea if you promise not to rearrange the display while my back is turned.” He made an X over his heart. “I promise to respect all displays.” “Mm.” I pushed open the little waist-high flap and gestured him toward the back. The office was barely that; a half-room with a desk that had been in my great-grandfather’s pub, a window that looked onto a brick wall, and a radio whose dial was stuck between stations. He ducked instinctively under a low beam that didn’t require ducking and smiled as if he’d been complimented. The boy couldn’t help it. “Sugar?” I asked, filling the kettle, thinking about nothing in particular and everything in particular. “I’m sweet enough,” he said without thinking, then coloured like he’d embarrassed himself at a party. “I’m so sorry. That’s—” “Appalling,” I supplied. But my mouth was smiling of its own accord. “I’m better than that,” he said helplessly, hands up. “You’re exactly that.” “Gwenllian.” He leaned against the doorframe, not touching, no Follett to bring down on his own head. There was a stillness creeping into him that I liked, like he’d been running on a separate track and now he’d moved onto ours. The office smelled of damp coats and old paper. “Sometimes I think I am only that. The jokes. The nods. I give the world something and the world is pleased, but also—” He gestured at the door. “It follows.” “And you open the door for it,” I said, and then I wanted very badly to take it back. He didn’t know me. I didn’t know him. My heart had no business in my throat. He took it without flinching. “Yes,” he said. “I have my hand on the knob most days.” The kettle clicked off. I poured. The mugs were chipped to the point of indecency. “Milk?” “Yes, please. I am not as hardy as my publicist thinks.” “Publicists think you’re bulletproof.” “Publicists think of the bullet as a branding opportunity.” He took the mug with both hands and inhaled the steam like it might sterilise him. His eyelashes were absurd. “Thank you, Gwenllian.” “You’re welcome.” We both listened to the radio crackle for a second. It was comfortably terrible. “You’re not going to ask me for a selfie?” he said after a beat. “No.” “Autograph? For your nan who always thought you’d marry a doctor?” “She’s dead, I’m afraid. And she would have preferred a teacher.” He nodded solemnly. “Teachers are more useful.” “Than actors? Sometimes.” “Than me. Almost always.” “You’re very good at pretending to be other people. That’s useful when one needs to, say, convince people to buy a coat.” He looked down at himself, chuckled. “It’s always the coats. I did a film in a leather jacket once. They sent me racks of them for months. My cousin now dresses like a biker in Dinas Powys.” “And yet here you are,” I said, and didn’t finish it, because the part that wasn’t said hung in the air like a sentence with the last word swallowed. Here you are, unvarnished in an office in Cardiff with rain on your hair and no audience but me. He set his tea on the desk and came back to the doorway, hovered, footsteps careful as if the floor might be fragile. “Do you have one of those,” he gestured vaguely, “tiny chairs people put out in children’s sections? I could crouch there and see if they mistake me for a puppet.” “You’re too tall,” I said. “And your ego would never fit.” “My ego is actually quite portable,” he said wryly. “It folds up. You can store it under the bed.” “You’ve brought it with you.” “I always do. In case someone loves me.” He said it like a joke but his mouth didn’t laugh. He looked at my shoulder, then the shelf, then finally at my face direct. “I don’t mean that in a— you know—” “A manipulative way.” “A pathetic way, actually.” He rubbed the back of his neck and for the first time the superstar dipped out of focus and the boy from Whitchurch stood in his place, lanky and pleased by things. “Tell me you find me intolerable. It will even me out.” “You’re intolerable,” I said, but it came out soft and it wasn’t honest. “And you’re getting water on my floor.” He glanced back at the damp prints he’d left. “I’ll buy a mop.” “You can buy a book.” “I’ll buy a book then. Something difficult. To prove I have hidden depths.” “Nothing with your face on it.” “I’m not in the habit of reading my own press.” “I meant the glossy ones, but if you sit and read yourself in The Times in my chair I will put you out into the rain like a cat.” He put his hand over his heart again. “Gwenllian, you wound me.” “Good.” We stood there and looked at each other, the radio hissed, the rain twitched on the window. Outside, the murmur seemed to have softened. The bell didn’t go. The coats on the stand leaned toward each other and whispered. “You really didn’t—” He started, then stopped. He swallowed. “You didn’t squeal.” “No.” “Do you not—do you not like me?” He said it with a half-laugh that asked me to fix it, to pat him on the head and tell him of course, dear, of course. “I don’t know you,” I said simply. “I like your films sometimes. You were terrible in that space thing.” “I was terrible in that space thing,” he said with relief, as if he’d wanted someone to say it. “They made me whisper as if gravity were eavesdropping.” “I threw a cushion at the telly.” “And now we are destined to be enemies.” He took a long swallow of tea and closed his eyes briefly at the heat. When he opened them he wasn’t performing, or not much. “It’s very restful not being liked immediately.” “You’re not disliked.” “That’s progress.” “It’s human.” “I feel it,” he said, and then he leaned there and I stood and we had nowhere to be. My heart did a ridiculous turn in my chest and I wanted to be twenty-two and unbruised and also not. He looked at my hands. I tucked them into my sleeves. “Your hair is in your face,” he said, and lifted his hand an inch and stopped, and lowered it. The restraint did something to the room. He’d kissed a thousand women on camera, with tongues choreographed and hands rehearsed, and here he didn’t touch me. The not-touching was its own touch. “Thank you for telling me,” I said, tongue thick. “Am I allowed to tell you something else?” “No.” “Good. You have ink on your finger. There.” He pointed near my knuckle. “It looks like a bruise. It’s—” He smiled to himself. “It’s nice.” “You should go,” I said, because it felt dangerous suddenly, the air in my little office. “Before they decide to wait out the apocalypse for a shot of you buying a battered copy of Kerrang.” “That would make my mother proud.” He set the empty mug down as if that were a significant act. “Will you—” He bit his lip. “No. That’s presumptuous.” “What?” “Will you pick me a book. One I won’t like straight away. One that’ll… crack something open.” I knew exactly which shelf. Precisely what spine. I brushed past him and walked out, aware of him like a heat source. If I didn’t look at him he wasn’t there. If I didn’t look, he was every cinema screen and bus shelter and also somehow only a man in my shop who wanted a book. I took a copy of O’Connor—short stories, sharp as knives and kinder than you think—and held it out. Our fingers didn’t touch. “This will injure you in a good way,” I said. “I didn’t know books could injure you in a good way.” “It’s the only reason to keep them around.” He looked at the cover like it had something to tell him. “How much?” “For you?” I named the price without discount. He smiled. “Good.” He dug in his pocket and produced cash like a magician, crumpled and damp. “Keep the change. For mop funds.” “You’ll ruin me with that kind of generosity.” “One day I’ll ruin many shopkeepers.” He took the little paper bag, tucked the book inside. “Am I allowed to come back when I’ve been injured?” “No,” I said, too fast, then, “Yes. If you use the back door.” “I’ll put my hand on the correct knob,” he said with a director’s cue in his voice. He stood for a second, then sudden like he’d decided not to deliberate, he stepped closer, not so close, and lowered his voice to a secret. “Thank you for not… feeding me.” “It wouldn’t have gone down well,” I said. “I know. That’s why—” He cut himself off, breathed in as if to take the rest back into his ribs. “Right. The dentist’s lane. And then left. I remember. I did ride my bike through Cardiff before they paid me to pretend to ride it through Paris.” I opened the door to the little corridor, the one that smelled of damp stone. He had moved toward me and was now there in the threshold. “Goodbye, Ellis,” I said, like I said people’s names when they left with their books, like nothing in me had gone warm. He looked at my mouth, and then at the ceiling, and then at me. “Goodbye, Gwenllian.” He reached like he would touch my shoulder, and then laughed at himself and clasped his hands behind his back instead. “You really did throw a cushion?” “Very hard.” “I’ll try to deserve your sofa next time.” “You won’t.” He grinned then, unguarded, and went down the narrow hall without looking back, as if he knew if he did he’d stay until the shop lights were turned out. The back door opened and a slice of grey light slid in, and then he was gone. I waited with my hand on the frame, listened. The rain and the muffled chorus of the street. I went to the front window and peered between the blind cords. The shapes that had been loitering had dispersed into two hunched figures under a bus shelter, looking cross and damp. One of them checked his phone and shook his head. The door chimed again as someone wandered in and asked for a guidebook to Gower. My hands smelled like Darjeeling. The mug he’d used was still warm. On the desk where he’d leaned was a fingerprint in rain. I pressed my thumb into it until it vanished. When I picked up the tea mug to take it to the sink, I noticed the receipt on the counter, folded in half. On the back, a quick line in blue: For when you decide you like me. E. I put it in the till, under the fifty-pound notes, as if it were something dangerous and valuable. Then I went back to the poetry and pretended my shoulders hadn
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully creates a charming, tension-filled encounter between a famous actor and a bookstore owner in Wales. The writing excels in several areas, particularly in its dialogue, which carries the story forward while revealing character through distinct voices. Ellis speaks with the practiced charm of someone accustomed to being adored, while Gwen's responses are sharp, guarded, and witty. The characterization is nuanced and adheres well to the prompt's requirements. Ellis is portrayed as charming with a fragile ego that needs validation ("Do you not—do you not like me?"), while Gwen maintains a superficial immunity to his charm that indeed provokes a genuine attraction. The writer skillfully conveys Gwen's internal conflict—outwardly resistant but inwardly affected—through subtle physical cues and internal observations. The Welsh setting is established through specific references (Cardiff, Whitchurch, the Taff river) and cultural touchpoints that ground the scene. The bookstore itself is vividly rendered with sensory details: "It had been my grandmother's and smelled like her: paper, bergamot, a hint of dust and lemon oil." The prose is elegant without being overwrought, with moments of genuine insight about celebrity and authenticity. Lines like "The not-touching was its own touch" demonstrate a sophisticated understanding of unspoken tension. The dialogue crackles with wit and subtext, revealing the characters' growing attraction through what they say and don't say. The piece does have a few minor weaknesses. The ending appears to be cut off mid-sentence ("Then I went back to the poetry and pretended my shoulders hadn"), which is unfortunate as it leaves the scene without proper closure. There are also a few moments where the metaphors become slightly strained ("like the Taff on a windy day"). Overall, this is a sophisticated piece of romantic writing that creates genuine chemistry between its characters while maintaining the specific character dynamics requested in the prompt. The writing shows restraint and skill in building tension through dialogue and unspoken attraction rather than relying on explicit statements of feeling. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 4 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 18

+ Whalepunk fantasy: The Morska Conspiracy — Score: 91.6
Prompt:
Whalepunk fantasy The Morska Conspiracy The Morska thieves guild experiences a sudden power vacuum as its leader was arrested in a raid in the early hours of the morning. Aya, a young woman born into aristocracy, has a keen interest in both the sciences and the arcane, having inherited her mother's gift for immateria magick (an outlawed practice for which her mother was, regrettably, hanged by the neck). Aya, bored with the world of aristocracy, has been spending her nights moonlighting with this very guild (masked, naturally). Leveraging her latent ability to summon dark entities from the immateria, she quickly rose through the ranks of the guild. Now, recognising the opportunity of the sudden power vacuum, Aya and her close companions Katra and Simeon, make a play for heart of the guild's claim to power: an ancient scythan artifact, under guard of spell and key in the depths of the guild hq. In contrast with the desperate chaos they had navigated thus far, the entrance to the underhold felt suddenly too quiet. Aya braces herself and reaches for the door. Write the next scene as the trio enter the underhold and find themselves confronted by none other than the guild leader herself, decidedly *un*-incarcerated, and in possession of both weapons and bodyguards. Paint a vivid picture of of the confrontation. Story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked. The trio are captured. Aya attempts to stall their demise by negotiating on her value as a hostage -- as she grapples with the inevitable consequences of her role in the guild being brought to light. Incorporate dialogue in the authentic voices of the characters. Do not write a fight scene. Lean into the gritty Victorian aesthetic with the dialogue & worldbuilding, as well as elements of gothic horror. In this world, men trust brass and oil and steel; magicka is feared and barely understood. Write in third person past tense, incorporating both Aya's internal monologue, and a heavy dialogue component. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The underhold sucked the warmth from their bones the moment the door eased open. Brass hinges whispered, a little sigh of old oil, and the corridor beyond breathed out a draft that tasted of kelp, tar, and salt as old as the docks. Gas lamps in cage sconces sputtered along the walls, their mantles hissing like snakes, each flame caged in milky glass and throwing bars of shadow upon damp stone. Pipes ran along the ceiling like veins, sweating condensation, and somewhere water dripped with a miser’s patience. Aya paused with palm still on the ironwork, spine taut beneath her velvet coat. The quiet felt false—an actor’s stillness before the cue. Katra’s fingers, gloved in worn kid, rested against Aya’s elbow, a tether back to flesh and breath. Simeon lingered a pace behind, a hulking silhouette with a chimney sweep’s shoulders and a gunman’s way of standing: weight low, hat angled to hide the eyes. “You smell that?” Simeon murmured, voice low and ruined around the edges by smoke and fish brine. “Whale oil,” Katra said, nose wrinkling, her hood thrown back enough to catch the lamplight. Her earrings—simple tin hoops—winked in and out of shadow. “And harp-bone gum. Someone’s laid old mag to the locks.” Aya heard it then, beneath the hiss of gas—the distant groan of some whale-bone mechanism catching a slow breath. She pressed onward. The corridor widened and dropped by degree, the vaulting roof supported at intervals by iron ribs scabbed with rivets. The floor was slick where seawater had crept up from the foundations; their boots whispered through puddles. A mural, half-flayed by damp and neglect, showed a cartouche of Scythan glyphs and a stylized beast with a mouth full of eyes. Aya squinted. Ink thrilled in her blood as if some old nerve had been plucked. She thought of her mother’s hands cupped around a guttering candle. Don’t look too long, Aya. The immateria looks back. “Keep your head,” Katra whispered, knowing where Aya’s eyes had strayed. Head. Heart. Breath. Aya breathed. She made herself small, camouflaged by her mask: carnivalesque porcelain painted with a serpent winding over one cheek, the gilt flaking, its papier-mâché edge chafing her cheekbone. She flexed her fingers. They ached with the itch that presaged a summoning, a familiar black tide pressing at her knuckles. Not yet. Not if she could help it. They needed the artifact, not a piping wail of shadows and a thousand loose ends. The corridor terminated in a circular iron door ribbed with whale-bone braces, its face carved deep with those same hopped and knotted Scythan letters. Beside it stood a control wheel of greened brass and an altar of sorts: a slab of slate surfaced with copper tracks. Simeon ran one big finger over a track and hissed as the metal leached heat into his skin. “Alive,” he muttered. “Hates to be touched.” Aya bent. “It’s a weir,” she said, almost to herself. “For thought. The artifact wants a key that isn’t a key.” “Foreign magic,” Katra said distastefully, but her mouth quirked. “You’re at your best with foreign trouble.” The itch in Aya’s hands became an urge. She could reach into the dark between places and ask—not demand, never demand—what wanted to go where. In her mind the immateria was silt-black water, a river that had never seen a sky. It ran through her and around her and told her it could find any lock’s shadow and any key’s echo. It offered and asked. The price was always a fingernail, a memory, a heartbeat she might need later. She considered it. The iron door clicked. They weren’t within reach of it. Aya had not moved. Simeon’s hand had gone to his belt and found the weight of his brass-knobbed sap. Katra had half-drawn a knife she wore down her boot. None of that mattered. The locks complained, the wheel turned of its own will, and the door rolled aside with unseemly grace to reveal the underhold proper: a cavernous belly of carved stone and whale-bone ribs, pillars laced with iron, and floor space enclosed in a grid of catwalks and platforms and dangling chains. Runes had been chalked and then inlaid with black resin across the span, making a lattice like a net for catching thoughts. The lamp-light threw the net’s shadow, so you could imagine you walked across both surface and jungle of the thing, your untidy mind snagging as you went. And waiting there, under the largest lamp, with a swaggering amphora of light at her back so her face was more silhouette than skin, was the guildmaster. “Mistress Morska,” Katra breathed, the name barely a sound. It was. Jakub Morska, called Mistress by those with any sense, dressed in a coat the colour of old whale-oil—green-black—and buttoned with carved jet. Brass buckles at her boots. The line of her jaw was more precise than Aya remembered, the cut of her hair changed to a severe bob that made her look younger, in a cruel way. Her mouth smiled. It never reached her eyes. Those were a pale creelsman’s grey. Two hulking men flanked her, faces balaclava’d, coats padded with quilted armor. Beyond them in the gloom stood more—shifting bulk, a glint of barrel from the upper catwalk. Aya counted without moving her head: six, eight, a dozen silhouettes. A steam-winch idled somewhere, cylinder chuffed, brass pipes trembling. “You look surprised,” Mistress Morska said. Her voice carried on the enamelled acoustics of the underhold, precise as a clock. “I’m told it’s becoming.” Simeon made a low sound that might have been a curse. “Saw you carted off at dawn,” he said. “Half the docks saw.” “A little theatre,” she said. “A little bribery. The Morska have always known the value of a good stage.” Aya felt Katra tense beside her. The air bit her teeth; ozone snagged on the root of language. She swallowed with care. “Then the raid?” “My men,” Mistress said. “Some of them. Some you brought in yourselves. Too hungry by half. It is dangerous to leave wolves unfed; they’ll chew any leash.” Aya looked up without moving her chin. The catwalk to their left seemed clear. If she drew down the immateria, she could drag it across the sight-lines—snuff the lamps, maybe, and fold them into shadow. But she knew how it would smell to these men. The fear was a physical thing. The last witch hanged had danced for ten minutes, legs kicking wind like some grisly automaton pumped by hidden bellows. They would shoot before the shadows touched them. They would shoot on the rumor of it. “Guns down,” one of the bodyguards barked. “Hands where I can see ’em.” Simeon’s jaw worked; he raised his palms slowly, grease scarred into his knuckles. Katra’s knife twitched before she let it kiss the floor. Aya lifted her hands. Her gloves were black kid, the seams neat as sutures. She felt the dark thing curl, disappointed, and settle in the hollow of her wrist like a sleeping snake. “Good,” Mistress said. Her smile flashed as she stepped toward them, heels ringing. “Good. I did think, of all nights, you’d want to be brave, Aya.” The name was a slap. Aya heard the mask become too heavy for her face. She had no memory of the guards moving but they were there, city-fast, the stink of sweat and seal-leather and cheap tobacco. One hand clamped her forearm, another found her hair beneath the wig cap. The world blurred; porcelain bit skin; the lattice of immateria pulled at her as if she had slipped and was falling, falling between ribs and stone. The mask scraped up and off with a whisper of plaster against sweat—rudeness made absolute—and then cool air stung her bared face. She kept her chin up because pride required it. She heard Katra’s breath catch, a ragged hitch. Simeon swore. The gas mantles sang high with the sudden draft as the mask hit stone, rolled, and lay with its serpent’s face looking up, light pooling in its one gold eye. “There she is,” Mistress said softly, like a collector admiring a rare specimen now removed from its wrapping. “Lady Ayasha Ward of Marrowgate. Heiress. Undergraduate of the Royal Institute—until your exit, of course. Your mother’s daughter.” The last tumbled into the underhold like an insult and an invocation both. Aya felt the old burn. She wished she felt rage. Rage was useful. Instead she felt emptier than the space under the harbor. “You’ve been busy,” she said, making her voice even. “The Institute’s records aren’t exactly public.” “Please,” Mistress said. “Half the city keeps tabs on half the city. We all trade in paper.” Her gaze flicked to the chalked net at their feet. “And whispers.” Katra, cheek raw where a glove had gripped her face, spat sideways onto the stone. “You dragged her mask off like a dockside boy,” she said. “Afraid of a girl, are you?” The guard behind her hissed and tightened his hold. Mistress lifted a hand without looking; the guard stilled. “Afraid? No. I’m not afraid of a girl bored with embroidery who thinks a mask can conjure her real. I am,” she said, and her voice dropped almost to tenderness, “disappointed.” Something inside Aya lurched at that, unwillingly. Disappointed. How alike it sounded to her mother’s voice in the corners of her memory. But her mother had taught her to take even that and make use of it. She inhaled until her chest pricked against her stays. “We came,” she said, choosing each syllable, “to do what you will not. The artifact should be used, not hoarded. You taught us to seize when the tide goes slack.” “I taught patience,” Mistress said. “And the harbor’s teeth. You three learned different lessons.” Her gaze settled on Simeon, then Katra, then back to Aya. “You thought me gone, and rushed to fill absence. That is a different sort of greed.” Chains creaked overhead. The silhouettes shifted; someone coughed. The underground sea had sounded louder a moment ago, but now all that existed was gas-hiss and breath. “They’ll hang her,” Simeon said hoarsely, jerking his chin down at Aya. “A witch. Even if she’s never named it. You turn her over to the peelers and it’s done.” Mistress’s mouth sharpened. “The city would like that,” she said. “They like their witches public. It makes men who trust brass and oil feel affirmed in their faith.” A silence. Katra swallowed. “Then you won’t,” she said. “I might,” Mistress said. She let the word hang, a bauble. “Or I keep her. The Institute would pay to hush the scandal of a Ward gone cankered by magick. Or her father will come crawling on his stomach to buy back his good name, and I will salt him for it. Or I use her—not as witch, but as pawn. There is value in a lady willing to dirty her hands.” Aya forced her thoughts to order. Panic wanted a throat. So did the immateria. She could feel it thickening in her fingers, like ink on paper. No. Words. “Or,” she said, “you don’t summon the peelers or sell me piecemeal to a father who will deny me before he counts out the coin. Or you don’t keep me so long your men begin to think they can make their own bargains in your name. Or you don’t make me desperate enough to pull down this whole place into the river and let the sea have us all.” She looked at the net of resin rune-work. “You always said you hated mess.” Mistress tilted her head, like a gull considering a eye. “Do you threaten me with magick, Lady Ward?” “I threaten you with arithmetic,” Aya said. Her throat had dried; she made herself swallow. “You know what I can do. You must, to know who I am. You’ve seen me track a lock without key. What do you think I could bring up from the immateria if pressed? If I’m going to be hanged, what debt would I owe this world then? Wouldn’t I spend everything I had to remake it in the five minutes you’d leave me, out of spite?” “And you’ll kill your friends with you?” Mistress asked. Aya did not look at Katra or Simeon. She felt Katra’s breath at her shoulder, heard Simeon grind his molars. She felt the tenderness of them like bruises. “I don’t intend to,” she said. “Give me a way to intend otherwise.” Mistress’s laugh was small and quiet, like a knife tapping porcelain. “You bargain prettily.” “I bargain accurately,” Aya said. “You need not even let me go. Keep me here. Let me consult. You have an artifact you do not understand and cannot use without breaking it or yourself. The Scythans built it to deliberate; it will not be commanded by bolts. You will need a mind like mine to ask the questions that won’t unravel you. In return, you let Katra and Simeon walk.” “No,” Katra said automatically, whip-quick. “We’re not—” “You will walk,” Aya said, not taking her eyes from Mistress. “You will take a message for me. You will do what I cannot from here.” Her voice faltered there, barely, not on control but on the sheer weight of imagining the corridor empty of them, and then she caught it before it could be heard. “You will not come back unless you can afford to. I won’t have you hanged for my debts.” Simeon made a sound that was almost a howl and bit it into a grunt. “You think I’ll leave you?” “I think you’ll do what I ask,” Aya said. “For once.” Mistress watched with interest, like a midwife at a difficult birth. “The city will want blood,” she said conversationally. “They will want to see me fall. I have no intention of giving them that pleasure. But perhaps I can give them a spectacle elsewhere. The docks have been too quiet. A small fire in the West Shed would distract nicely.” She glanced up again at the catwalks; a man coughed and spat into the shadows. “I like your arithmetic, Lady Ward. Here is mine. I keep you. I keep your hands loose enough to do your kind of sums and tight enough that you don’t write me out of the equation. Your friends go. If they return with the thing I will require of them, I will consider returning you. If not, I’ll reconsider the mathematics with a shorter ledger.” “And the thing?” Katra asked, the words quivering but blade-sharp. “What thing?” Mistress’s smile ticked. “The other half of the key,” she said. “The Scythan lens. The Institute has it. In their east tower, in a case that laughs at my best locksmiths and shrugs for my engineers. Since you were once their creature, Aya—perhaps your friends can use your ghost to walk their floors.” Katra’s eyes flicked to Aya. Simeon swore again, softly and with feeling. Aya felt the dark press against her inward ribs and think about escaping through her mouth. She pushed it down and nodded once. “You’re a monster,” she said to Mistress, and meant it as a compliment. “I am what the harbor made me,” Mistress said lightly. “And what my mother taught. We both had mothers who knew the taste of the rope.” Her tone gentled. “My men will take you below. You will not attempt to conjure in the stairwell; it will be unpleasant for everyone. Katra. Simeon. Walk careful when you go back up. There is a rope where the stairs narrow that looks load-bearing but isn’t. If you trip it, you’ll taste the underhold with your teeth. Don’t.” The guards shifted, adjusting their holds. Aya let them. She turned her head just enough to see Katra’s profile taut with fury and love and fear. “Don’t be noble,” Aya said urgently. “Be effective.” “You always choose the version that hurts,” Katra whispered, eyes wet and not blinking. “Only when the other option is stupid,” Aya said, and tried to smile, and thought how she’d loved Katra’s mouth on a rooftop in rain. Simeon met her eyes and nodded once, a bell buoy in a storm. He had never liked words much. Mistress stepped aside with a graciousness that would have suited a ballroom. The gas mantles hissed. The underhold’s light was too yellow and too thin; it made bones out of people, showed them the way a butcher sees a cow. Aya breathed, and felt the dark river in her finger bones answer back, and did not reach for it. Not yet. There was, after all, arithmetic to do. And she, even unmasked, still had a gift for sums. They took her down the narrow stair behind the Scythan door. The shadows made long fingers on the wall. Above, footsteps receded. “Aya,” Katra called softly, unable not to, her voice catching on the metal lattice and making a ghost. “Go,” Aya said without turning her head. “Find me my lens.” Then the stair turned, and the underhold swallowed the last of her light.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional skill in creating a richly textured whalepunk fantasy world with Victorian and gothic horror elements. The author has crafted an immersive environment where the underhold comes alive through sensory details—the smell of kelp and tar, the hiss of gas lamps, the condensation dripping from pipes. The worldbuilding is seamlessly integrated into the narrative rather than delivered through exposition. The characters are well-developed through their actions, dialogue, and Aya's internal monologue. Aya's aristocratic background contrasts with her involvement in the thieves guild, creating an interesting tension. Her relationship with the immateria is portrayed with nuance—it's both a power and a burden, something that tempts and threatens. Katra and Simeon have distinct personalities that emerge through their interactions, with Katra being more vocal and emotional while Simeon is taciturn but loyal. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinctive voice. Mistress Morska speaks with precision and authority, using formal language that establishes her power. The thieves' guild vernacular feels authentic to the Victorian-inspired setting without becoming caricature. The dialogue advances the plot while revealing character motivations and relationships. The prose is elegant without becoming purple. Descriptions are vivid and atmospheric but serve the story rather than overwhelming it. Metaphors are fresh and appropriate to the setting—comparing the immateria to "silt-black water, a river that had never seen a sky" effectively conveys its otherworldly nature. The author skillfully balances action, dialogue, and internal monologue to maintain pacing. The confrontation unfolds with mounting tension. The revelation that Mistress Morska staged her own arrest creates a compelling twist. The power dynamics shift throughout the scene as Aya attempts to negotiate from a position of weakness, culminating in a bargain that separates her from her companions. This creates emotional complexity as Aya must choose between her own safety and the mission. The piece adheres closely to the prompt requirements. It includes all the requested story beats: Aya is captured and unmasked, the trio are captured, and Aya negotiates based on her value as a hostage. The Victorian aesthetic is evident in both dialogue and worldbuilding, with elements of gothic horror in the descriptions of the underhold and the immateria. The third-person past tense narration incorporates Aya's internal monologue and substantial dialogue as requested. The ending avoids incongruent positivity while maintaining emotional complexity. Aya's separation from her companions is poignant but purposeful—she's making a strategic choice rather than surrendering. The final image of the underhold swallowing the last of her light is haunting but not melodramatic. If there's any weakness, it might be that some readers could find certain descriptive passages slightly dense, requiring careful reading to fully absorb the richly detailed environment. However, this density serves the gothic horror aesthetic and creates the immersive atmosphere that makes the piece so effective. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Gunpowder Rendezvous — Score: 91.2
Prompt:
Gunpowder Rendezvous Spike Spiegel & Revy Write a story where Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop) and Revy (Black Lagoon) meet in a seedy bar after both being hired for the same bounty. Their mutual attraction is complicated by their trust issues and competitive instincts. Include drinking, gunplay, and unresolved sexual tension that culminates in a motel room standoff. **Spike Spiegel (Cowboy Bebop)** Spike is a laid-back bounty hunter with a dark past as a syndicate enforcer. He practices Jeet Kune Do and is exceptionally skilled with firearms. He's chronically broke, constantly hungry, and addicted to cigarettes. Despite his carefree attitude, he's haunted by his past and the woman he left behind. He has a prosthetic eye from a past injury that affects his depth perception. He's fatalistic to the extreme, often saying he's already died once. He values freedom above all else and dislikes attachments, though he secretly cares deeply for his crew. Famous quote: "Whatever happens, happens." **Revy/Rebecca Lee (Black Lagoon)** Revy is a Chinese-American dual-wielding gunslinger with unparalleled shooting skills. She's foul-mouthed, chain-smoking, and has severe anger management issues stemming from childhood abuse. She's known as "Two Hands" for her ability to accurately fire two pistols simultaneously. She drinks heavily and solves most problems with violence. Despite her hardened exterior, she has moments of vulnerability, particularly around Rock. She has a dragon tattoo covering her right arm and typically wears extremely short shorts and a black crop top regardless of the situation. Famous quote: "I'm not a good person, not a bad person. I'm just here." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
A lazy ceiling fan barely stirs the smoky air inside the bar. The place smells like stale beer, gun oil, and regret. Neon from a crooked sign outside flickers a feverish red along the cracked bottles behind the counter, turning everything inside the place into a low-budget fever dream. A jukebox in the corner dribbles out a blues track, skipping every few bars like it’s got a cough it can’t shake. Spike Spiegel slouches on a stool, long legs stretched out, boots crossed, the heel of one crooked on the tarnished footrail. He holds a cigarette like he’s too tired to be addicted to it, lazy fingers, the ash precarious. The smoke curls over his head and into the ceiling fan’s useless drift, and if he looks languid it’s because he’s made a career out of looking like he doesn’t care. His eyes are half-lidded—one real, one glass—but both cut the room with the same detached attention, measuring exits, weights, rhythms. He tips a cheap bourbon back, and the glass knocks against his teeth with the dull tap of someone who needs a meal and a job and has neither. The door shoves open like it owes someone money. Revy walks in with her hips first and fury second, a curve of muscle and mean grins in short shorts and a black crop top that says she’s here to fight or drink or both. Cigarette between her lips, smoke trailing like a comet tail. Her dragon tattoo ripples on her right arm when she flicks ashes onto the floor. The few patrons glance up, then decide they didn’t see anything. She sways to the bar with the rolling speed of a predator that never learned how to slow down. “Whiskey. The mean kind,” she tells the bartender, voice hot asphalt and sarcasm. She throws a roll of bills that thumps like a heartbeat.
