Spike tips his head without looking away. “They only got mean kind here,” he says. “Nice can’t afford the rent.” She cuts him a sideways grin, eyes digging for information. “You a local philosopher or just broke and bored?” “Why not both?” He’s smiling a little because it feels like a bad idea. “You Revy?” Her shoulders tense just enough to register, then relax. “You got a death wish, tall boy? ’Cause you’re about to find out if your dental plan covers reconstructive.” Spike sighs. “You know, I had a bounty to meet.” He lets his hand coat the comment in nowhere. “Rumor says a pirate with a temper was hired for the same one.” Her grin gets sharper. “Rumor’s got taste. Black file, thirty grand, shipped in with a fake passport and a worse haircut. You the other dog sniffin’ the same bone?” “Whatever happens, happens,” Spike says. He taps his cigarette. “And it’s Spike.” She clinks her whiskey against his glass. “Revy.” The clink is less toast, more declaration. “So, Spike. You got the drop on our guy?” Spike’s eyes tilt toward the back room, where a beat too regular interrupts the blues: the scuff of cheap shoes on linoleum. “Maybe I do,” he says, tone like he’s already bored with the conversation. “Maybe I’m waiting to see what you do first.” She finishes her drink in two swallows, bangs the glass down, and smirks. “Baby, I do everything first.” The back door creaks. A rat-faced man with a pastel tie that screams desperation slips through the gap, a briefcase tucked to his stomach like a talisman. Two goons follow, flanking him like bad heralds. Spike’s smile tilts. “Looks like your fan club’s leaving.” Revy rolls her neck. The gleam in her eyes says it’s about to be a good night. She pulls her pistols with the kind of easy grace that makes everyone’s stomach drop. “Time to dance.” He flicks his cigarette to the floor, crushes it under his boot, and slides off the stool with a hungry athletic laziness. She strides for the back hall; he drifts to intercept the goons as they try to catch up. The first one reaches inside his jacket and finds Spike’s boot already there, driving his wrist into the doorframe with a wet pop. The second stutters as Spike’s elbow snakes in and his knee comes up—Jeet Kune Do like water turned blade—dropping the guy in a grunt and a half. Revy doesn’t look back. Her guns speak for her. Two shots that sound like punctuation, and the overhead light in the back corridor stutters to darkness. Muzzle flashes strobe her face, hard and beautiful and mean. A goon fires blind; she’s already not there, plaster dust salting her shoulders as she slides, plants, and stitches two rounds into his calf and shoulder, mean grin widening at the howls. The rat-faced man squeals and bolts through a rear door, briefcase flopping. “Son of a—” Revy vaults a table, kicks a chair into an oncoming drunk who made the mistake of being upright, and blasts the latch off the back door. The alley yawns open, humid and oil-slick, dumpsters exhaling rot. Spike catches the last goon by the collar and kisses his forehead with the butt of his pistol. The man folds like bad origami. Spike sighs. “Always the alley,” he mutters, and follows. Outside, the alley is a throat of shadows and neon blood. The rat-faced man sprints, then skids around a corner into the narrow lane that spits out onto a back street lined with motorcycles and a flickering streetlamp. Revy is on him fast, twin muzzles already sketching exclamation points across the brick. He flings the briefcase as a distraction. It clatters open and vomiting cash, paper leaves fluttering like sick birds. He pulls a cheap piece. Revy’s already committed: she pivots, two hands, two shots, a rhythm she owns. The guy’s gun jumps out of his fingers with an anguished clang. She closes on him, jam-pressing a barrel under his jaw. “Boo,” she says, and he freezes. Spike jogs up, breath easy, as if they’re all in a race he never trained for but still wins. He eyes the cash spilled like confetti. “They always travel light,” he says dryly. “Hands where I can see ’em, you twitchy little paycheck,” Revy snarls at the rat-faced man. He complies, gulping. “You run a few countries’ worth of dirty money, you call a cab and think you’re safe? Cute.” “Language,” Spike sighs, and peels a cigarette from a crumpled pack. He catches Revy’s sideways glance at the smoke. She’s already lighting another, either to match him or to own the air between them. He flicks the lighter, and the brief half-light draws their faces into devil masks. For a heartbeat, they’re close enough that if he leaned he could smell the mix of gasoline and cheap perfume on her skin. He doesn’t lean. Neither does she. “Th-thirty grand, right?” the rat mutters. “You can split it, yeah? I got connections…” Revy smiles that wolf smile. “You’re not a brain trust. But you’re worth paper.” They move, a duet of aggression: Revy zip-ties his wrists with something she produces out of nowhere, Spike shoves him to his knees with a hand on his shoulder that is gentle as a promise, hard as a verdict. In the distance, sirens whine, slow as the heat. “Pickup point’s going to be a mess,” Spike says. “Cops feel like rain tonight.” Revy tucks a gun away and wipes sweat with the back of her hand. “We take a detour. I know a hole-in-the-wall where the owner doesn’t ask questions and doesn’t change the sheets.” She grins at Spike. “You look like a guy with experience not sleeping.” “Sleep’s overrated.” He toes the briefcase closed and palms a stray bill with nimble fingers. He tucks it behind his ear and winks. “Processing fee.” They march their prize through the alley maze to a flophouse motel with a buzzing sign that reads SLEEP in letters that can’t remember the rest of the word. The lobby has a potted plant that died of boredom and a clerk who never had a heartbeat. No one looks up. Revy throws cash and takes a key on a bent fob. The hall lights are nicotine colored. Inside the room, the fan doesn’t work. The air conditioner makes a sound like a smoker’s laugh and pushes out breath-temperature air. The bedspread’s a brown floral that never grew in nature. Spike pushes the rat onto the chair, ties him to it with the bed’s peeling tie-down strap like he’s done this more times than he’ll admit. “You try anything fancy, and I make you a watercolor,” Revy tells the rat. She checks the window, the bathroom, the closet—trained paranoia. Spike leans against the wall and smokes like it’s a job. He watches her move, the way her shoulders tense at every creak, the hungry bright of her eyes when a shadow shifts. She flicks her cigarette out the cracked window; it sparks down into the night like a failed star. “Back at the bar,” she says, without turning, “you were watching my hands. Most guys watch other places.” “I watched those too,” he says, deadpan. “But hands tell stories.” She looks at him then, mouth tipped up. “And what’d mine say?” “That you shoot first and argue with ghosts later.” He grinds his cigarette out on the cracked saucer. “And that you don’t like being second.” Her laugh is short and dangerous. “You? You move like a guy who let go of something and never stopped falling.” “Everyone falls,” he says. “I just learned to enjoy the view.” Silence folds between them, warm and heavy. The rat breathes in thin wheezes, eyes flitting between them like he’s front row at a movie that might get him killed. “Split the bounty?” Revy asks, voice flat like she’s challenging him to disagree. Spike shrugs. “Half of something beats all of nothing,” he says. “Anyway, it’s not like I’m buying a yacht.” She drifts closer, boots quiet on the stained carpet. Her gaze hooks his and holds it, hard and narrow, like she’s measuring the weight of him and finding numbers she doesn’t trust. He doesn’t look away. He leans just enough to notice the way her tattoo flexes when she inhales. The distance between them shrinks to the width of a bad decision. “We’re gonna wait it out,” she says. “My people will show for pickup. Your cowboys can take a number.” Spike’s smile is fragile and vicious and tired. “Whatever happens, happens.” She steps closer. He can smell the adrenaline still running offshore in her blood. She’s a dangerous tide. He’s already drowned once. Her hand moves. The muzzle of a pistol kisses under his chin, cold and inevitable. His Beretta’s already pointed at her ribs, tucked under that crooked edge of her top. They’re mirrored in malice, locked in a geometry of want and warning. “You gonna try and snake my payday, partner?” she purrs, close enough he feels the word against his lips. Spike’s breath ghosts the line of her jaw. “If I wanted to snake it, you’d already be smoking in the parking lot.” The barrel nudges her sternum. “I just don’t trust anybody who smiles like you do when you’re bleeding.” She laughs. It’s genuine and unkind to walls. “We got a lot in common, then.” Their eyes hold. The tension sizzles into something ugly and sweet. The rat shifts, chair creaking, and both guns notch a fraction tighter without either looking away. Spike’s prosthetic eye glints in the sickly light; she studies it and the way his other eye doesn’t blink enough. “You dead inside, Spike?” she asks, curiosity an edge. “Already died once,” he says. “Rest is reruns.” “Cute.” Her tongue touches her lip. “I don’t do attachments.” “Good,” he says softly. “I don’t keep souvenirs.” A knock like a heartbeat shakes the thin door. Both guns tilt to it, then flash back to each other. Sirens wail again, nearer now, then skate away. The knock repeats, three quick taps. Revy’s shoulders loosen by a degree you’d need a ruler to find. “That’s my ride,” she says. “We hand him over, split the cash, and pretend we didn’t think about shooting each other.” “Pretend?” Spike asks. He doesn’t move the gun. She leans, just enough that the cold mouth of her weapon grazes the shadow of his throat. “Unless you don’t want to pretend,” she murmurs, mischief and menace braided together. He steps aside, a lazy sidestep like he’s giving space to a storm. “Ladies first.” She keeps the muzzle at his chest for one more heartbeat, then drops it and winks. “Damn right.” The door opens to a pair of hard-eyed men and a woman with knuckles like gravel. They take the rat without fuss. Paper changes hands in a quiet rustle that feels louder than gunfire. Spike and Revy both count without looking like they are, then split the stack, the money sliding across skin that still remembers the ghost of a trigger. “Guess this is where we say something cool,” she says, stuffing bills into the back of her shorts. Spike tucks his cut into his jacket. “I’m fresh out.” She pauses in the doorway, her grin a slash of trouble. “You smoke too much,” she says. “You drink too much,” he replies. “Good match,” she says. “Bad idea,” he says. They regard it, that truth, like a card turned over on a crooked table. She flicks him a salute with two fingers and a barrel. “See you around, cowboy.” “Not if I see you first,” he says, and it almost sounds like a promise. She’s gone into the bruised neon, footsteps swaggering, laughter punching holes in the heat. Spike stands in the doorway, another cigarette between his lips he doesn’t light. He watches the corridor empty like a throat after a scream. The ceiling fan wobbles, uncertain as a lie. The bedspread looks like a funeral floral arrangement for a stranger. Spike’s mouth twists. He feels the shape her gun left under his jaw, a phantom cold, and the warm press of something that isn’t quite regret. Outside, a bike engine snarls, then fades. The motel’s hum resumes its low argument with the night. Spike finally lights the cigarette and inhales. The smoke tastes like a memory he doesn’t own. He exhales, slow. Whatever happens, happens. And something just did. He leaves the room without looking back. The door clicks shut; the fan keeps trying to move the air. Somewhere, on another street, Revy is laughing and loading and not thinking about him at all. Or maybe exactly the opposite. The night doesn’t say. It just keeps breathing, smoky and slow.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkably well-executed crossover between Spike Spiegel from Cowboy Bebop and Revy from Black Lagoon. The author has captured the essence of both characters with impressive fidelity to their canonical personalities, speech patterns, and mannerisms. The writing demonstrates exceptional atmospheric quality, establishing a noir-like setting with vivid sensory details. The opening paragraph immediately immerses the reader in a seedy bar with descriptions of "smoky air," a "crooked sign," and a jukebox that "dribbles out a blues track, skipping every few bars like it's got a cough it can't shake." This attention to atmospheric detail continues throughout the piece. Character portrayal is particularly strong. Spike's laid-back fatalism and Revy's aggressive, foul-mouthed demeanor are rendered authentically. Small details like Spike's prosthetic eye, Revy's dragon tattoo, and their respective combat styles (Jeet Kune Do for Spike, dual-wielding for Revy) demonstrate careful attention to the source material. Their dialogue feels true to character, with Spike's laconic "Whatever happens, happens" and Revy's profanity-laced threats. The action sequences are dynamic and well-choreographed, showing rather than telling how skilled both characters are. The prose during these sequences is tight and kinetic: "Jeet Kune Do like water turned blade" and "two hands, two shots, a rhythm she owns" effectively convey their distinctive fighting styles. The unresolved sexual tension is handled with subtlety and restraint. Rather than being explicit, it's conveyed through proximity, loaded dialogue, and the parallel between their mutual attraction and distrust (symbolized by guns pointed at each other). Lines like "The distance between them shrinks to the width of a bad decision" effectively communicate this tension. The prose style balances literary flourishes with hard-boiled directness. Metaphors and similes are fresh and fitting for the noir atmosphere: "She walks in with her hips first and fury second" and "Her laugh is short and dangerous." The third-person present tense creates immediacy and tension. The ending avoids cliché by having them part ways without resolution, maintaining the tension and leaving possibilities open. The final image of Spike smoking alone, contemplating their encounter, feels true to both characters and their trust issues. There are occasional moments where the prose becomes slightly purple, particularly in some of the metaphorical descriptions, but these instances are rare and generally serve the atmospheric quality of the piece. The dialogue occasionally veers into being too on-the-nose about their psychological states, but this is minor. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that demonstrates a deep understanding of both characters and their respective worlds, while creating a compelling narrative that feels like it could genuinely exist within both canons. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Folk horror: Útiseta — Score: 88.8
Prompt:
Folk Horror: Útiseta Write a chapter set in rural northern Sweden in the mid-1990s. Linnea, a teenage girl from Stockholm, has reluctantly moved to a small village with her parents after her father's job transfer. She's befriended Astrid, a local girl who claims her grandmother taught her ancient practices passed down through generations. Astrid has been introducing Linnea to "midnight games" that involve old rituals, convincing her they can use them to learn classmates' secrets or influence their behavior. Tonight, Astrid has convinced Linnea to participate in Útiseta—sitting out on an ancient burial mound at midnight to "receive knowledge from beyond." The chapter focuses on this single midnight excursion, the ritualistic preparations, Astrid's matter-of-fact instructions that mix teenage rebellion with eerily specific traditional elements, and the mounting tension as Linnea becomes increasingly uncertain whether they're simply scaring themselves or if something is actually responding to their presence. The narrative should maintain ambiguity about whether the strange occurrences are supernatural or psychological, while establishing the dangerous line they're crossing by treating ancient practices as entertainment. First person, past tense, told as Linnea's recollection of events in the present day (though this device should be largely transparent). 1000 words. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Thick mist clings to the edges of the burial mound, glowing under moonlight. Astrid had said it wasn’t proper fog but höströk, harvest smoke, even though it was mid-October and the fields had been empty for weeks. “The mound breathes,” she told me earlier, leaning over a cafeteria table with her jaw set, “and when it breathes, that’s when we listen.” She’d said it like she told me everything: flat, practical, with that delicate needlepoint of excitement threaded underneath. Like how she’d told me in August that if you walk backward around the white church three times after dark, you can hear your name read from the priest’s mouth in a voice that isn’t his. Like how we’d stolen salt from my mother’s kitchen last week and used it to circle Anna-Liisa’s desk before class. I’d laughed then, guilty and bright. Anna-Liisa tripped over nothing at lunch. Astrid had only lifted an eyebrow. But this, tonight, was the first time we had left the village. We had biked—well, Astrid biked and I followed, tires crunching on a dirt road that ran alongside the black ribbon of pine forest—until the lights fell away and the sky unrolled itself above us, sharp with cold. My breath made small ghosts. We propped the bikes against a birch and walked the last hundred meters with our shoes in our hands. “No metal on the mound,” Astrid had said, and it seemed important to honor the rule, as arbitrary as it felt. She had a canvas bag. I didn’t know everything she had in it, only that I recognized the neck of a bottle when she slung it over her shoulder and the glass flickered in the moonlight. “It isn’t far,” she said, and she was right. The mound rose out of the field like a whale’s back, grass smoothed by centuries of wind and feet and sheep. There were two stones protruding at one end—not the tall slabs you see in old paintings, but rounder, sunken, lichen-slick. I had never seen it in the daylight; it would have been just a hill then, just a place boys climbed and rolled down. Now everything seemed washed with silver, wet and expectant. The mist pooled at the base like something spilled, and there was the smallest sound like someone quietly humming. It took me a second to realize it was the wires of the fence, strummed by the wind. Astrid stopped a few meters from the slope and shrugged off her bag. “Here,” she said. “This is where we take our shoes off. This is for the mound, and so we don’t carry what’s ours up there.” She said things like that: the mound, as if it were a person. I hesitated, then pulled off my socks too, tucking them into my shoes. The field earth was cold and slightly damp, and the cut stubs of hay pricked my arches. I wanted to rub my feet, but Astrid was already kneeling, drawing something in the dirt with the blunt end of a stick: a circle I recognized from other nights, other games. When she finished, she spat in the middle of it and then pressed her thumb down. “That’s for us,” she said. She offered me the stick, and I did the same, my spit stringing to the earth, my thumb coming away gritty. It felt childish and solemn all at once. “What else?” I said, because silence suddenly pressed on me, and I needed her voice. She took out a small glass jar, unscrewed it, and handed it to me. “Juniper,” she said. “I pinched it from Farfar’s pantry. You chew it until it burns your tongue. Then you spit to the left, not the right. Right is for the ones we don’t want.” I put two berries on my tongue. They were hard and resinous, and after a moment the taste came up like sap, like Christmas. I almost said so, but then the burn arrived, bitter and clean. I spat left. “Good,” Astrid said. She did the same, then wiped her mouth with the back of her hand. “Okay. Útiseta. You know what it is?” “You said… sitting out. Waiting.” “You sit in a place,” she said. “A place where the old ones are, or where the paths cross. And you listen. Sometimes they talk. Sometimes they show. It’s like… like being pointed at. There are rules. We can stay until the rooster, or until we’re talked to, or until something touches hair. If we hear our names, we don’t answer. If a woman comes and asks for fire, we don’t give it. If we want to leave, we say, ‘I step out clean.’” She paused. “And we don’t bring iron. We don’t cut anything while we sit. We don’t look back over our left shoulder.” “Why the left?” I asked, because it was easier to ask than to admit I’d started to feel like we were edging somewhere I didn’t understand. “That’s where they are.” She said it as if she were reminding me of bus times. “What do we… what do we want?” I said. “You said you can ask.” “Not ask,” she said. “Listen. But you can set your ears. I want to know if Hanna will stop spreading things about me. You… you can set your ears for whatever you want. Your mother, maybe.” She glanced at me, quick and soft. “I know you’re worried.” It was too much to say yes and too much to say no. My mother had not stopped sleeping since we moved. She wasn’t ill, she said. She was adjusting. She slept and woke, face creased with pillow marks, her mouth set in a line I didn’t recognize. “Okay,” I said, and my voice felt thin. Astrid nodded. She took out a bottle and wrapped cloth around the neck to muffle the glass tapping teeth. Vodka, cheap, the kind you can smell from across a room. She unscrewed it and poured some into a little tin cup. “Three sips each,” she said, “or we’d be asleep by midnight.” She took her three sips, eyes going soft around the edges, and handed it to me. The vodka was a blade, and it went down like swallowing breath. I coughed on the third sip, and Astrid grinned without laughing. “Now,” she said. “We go up, and we sit back to back. Don’t turn your head. If you hear something, tell me. If you feel something, tell me. If we don’t hear anything by the rooster, we leave and don’t talk until we’re on the road.” Her matter-of-factness made it easy. The moon made it easier. That’s the excuse I give myself now. We climbed. The grass slid under my feet, dew darkening the skin, and the slope was steeper than it had looked from below. At the crest, the world opened. The field fell away on all sides, and the village—if there had been one—would have been a smudge of black and sleeping roofs. The forest was a darker shape against the dark, the lake a platter of shadow. The mist had thinned up here. The air smelled of cold and something green, something old, like what you smell if you lift stones. We sat, backs touching, our spines aligning with the slight dip in the mound’s top. Astrid’s hair brushed my neck. “Left hand down,” she said. “Right hand on your heart. Close your eyes. Think of what you want to know, and then empty it out. Don’t think words after.” I did what she said. My left hand pressed into the grass, finding clover and a sharp stalk that bent under my palm. The vodka made my lips numb. I thought of my mother lying on her side, one hand under her cheek like a child, and then I tried to think of nothing. The night came up around us, and the wires hummed again, and an owl somewhere did its soft question. It’s easy to say, with years between now and then, that I imagined everything that came next. That astrid had primed me. That the cold and the drink and the self-inflicted quiet made shapes and sounds where there were none. It’s easy, and sometimes it’s true. Sometimes when I remember, the edge of it blunts, and I think only of being seventeen and stubborn. But then there are nights when I wake with a smear of damp earth smell behind my teeth, and I’m back on that mound, and I don’t care about explanations. We sat a long time. My feet stopped being cold and then noticed the cold again. Astrid’s breathing was slow and steady. Mine tried to match it and then found its own rhythm, shallower and fast, then gentling. The sky felt lower than it should have, as if it were a hand resting on my scalp. The humming of the wires fell away. Or maybe the wind had died. Or maybe we had gone further down into another kind of listening. “Do you hear it?” Astrid said, very quietly. I didn’t want to, but yes. There was something like a footstep on dry leaves, even though there were no trees on the mound. Then another, from the opposite direction. A shift in the grass like a body settling. It could have been the small animals that live in fields. It could have been. I told myself I would keep telling myself that. “Don’t look,” Astrid said. “Just tell me what side.” “Left,” I said, because if the rule was not to look, then naming it felt like a small rebellion. “Mm,” she said. “Not ours.” The sound stopped. In the quiet that came, I felt a tickle at my wrist, like hair, and then a pressure, as if something pressed two fingers against the veins there, testing. I jerked, and our backs slid against each other. “Sorry,” I whispered. “Don’t apologize,” she said. “Say, ‘I step out clean’ if you want to step out.” “No,” I said. I didn’t know if it was pride or fear that kept me seated, both felt similar in that moment. I flattened my hand into the grass, and the tickle went away, but my skin felt cold where it had been. There was another sound, nearer. Breath. Not ours. Not the wind. A dampness close to my cheek, like exhaling. The image of an animal nose—cow, dog, something—pushed at my head so strongly that I had to fight the urge to turn toward it. Astrid’s back was tense now; I could feel it in the set of her shoulders. “If it asks for fire,” she whispered, “we don’t give it.” I wanted to laugh—what could ask for fire—but my mouth was too dry. The breath came again, slightly sweet, like rot and something like mint. A voice followed it, the smallest thread of sound, like when my grandmother tried not to wake me while she was closing the bedroom door when I visited her as a child. Linnea, it said, as close as my own thoughts. Some part of me jumped like a horse spooking. My name, my name. Everything in me reached in response, like a muscle flexing at a thrown ball. “Do not answer,” Astrid said, not loudly but with a firmness that made my mouth slam shut on an inhale. I realized I had already breathed to speak. It said my name again. It used my mother’s voice the second time. Not the way she sounded over dinner lately, distant and polite, but the way she sounded when I was small and I’d fallen asleep in the car and she didn’t want to wake me, warm and near. And then it said the thing I did not expect, the thing that came with such casual familiarity that my stomach flipped. It used what Astrid calls the home-name, the dumb nickname my father had used once, when no one was there to hear. It went through me like heat. The hair at the back of my neck lifted. My right hand clenched on my ribcage. I opened my fingers deliberately and pressed down. “It knows,” I said. My voice didn’t sound like mine. “It always knows,” Astrid said. Then, softer: “It’s not for you.” “How do you know?” I said. She didn’t answer. Or maybe she did and I missed it because the breath was closer now, and the mist around the edges of the mound thickened and climbed like fog does but faster, folding in on us, making the world smaller, smaller until there was only the mound and whatever was on it and the lake’s dark shape. I thought I saw the line of a shoulder in the mist, a curve like a woman’s with a fishbone braid. I thought I saw the top of a head, hair braided thin, silvered. If I had turned my head over my left shoulder, I might have seen a face. If I had turned my head, maybe there would have been nothing at all, just air and moonlight. My neck ached. Astrid’s fingers found mine where my left hand pressed to the grass. Her skin was cold and as steady as the earth. She held on, just for a second, and I held back. And then a sound came from the field below—a rooster, thin and polite, not urgent, half a kilometer away, out of sync with normal time, a foolish bird that slept wrong. The relief that ran through me was so sharp I laughed aloud, a single uneven bark. The breath at my cheek withdrew. The mist loosened. “We leave,” Astrid said, and we did, in a scramble that might have been dignified if you were generous. We stood on our feet too quickly and saw stars explode at the edges of our vision. We said the words, “I step out clean,” over our shoulders. We went down the mound without turning our heads, our shoes and socks clutched in our hands like talismans. The ground licked our soles. At the bottom, at the spit circle, we put our shoes on with numb fingers. Somewhere, a dog barked. The wire hummed again, no longer a throat clearing but just a wire in wind. We didn’t speak until the birches swallowed us. The road was a pale stripe. The bikes were where we left them; there was dew on the seats like cold sweat. Astrid touched the metal frame with just her fingertips and then shook her hand out, as if she had gotten a static shock. “What did you hear?” I asked. My voice was too loud in the empty road. “Nothing I will say out here,” she said. Her face looked older in the moonlight and the blue; her mouth was pinched at the corners in a way I had seen on women leaving church, on my mother in bus windows. She didn’t look at me. “What did you hear?” “My name,” I said. “Okay,” she said. It was both approval and an end to the topic. We rode back in silence, the frost beginning to lace the edges of puddles where the road dipped. Every time a branch scraped the air above us, I flinched. When we reached the first streetlight, it looked obscene, bright and flat and too alive. We leaned our bikes against my parents’ house—my parents’ house, not mine, not yet—and Astrid hooked her leg over her frame to straddle it, not getting off. She was breathing hard now, like she’d been holding it back. “Don’t sleep on your back,” she said abruptly. “Don’t comb your hair tonight. Don’t talk to your mother ‘til morning. And if you dream about a woman on the ice, don’t follow her.” “Oh,” I said, because the instructions fell out of her like stones. “Is that—” “Don’t,” she said, and her eyes were dark as the lake. “We don’t make a game of the morning.” She pushed off and pedaled away. I stood under the light, the yellow pooling at my feet. My hands smelled like juniper and dirt. Inside, my mother’s bedroom door was closed. I passed it like you pass a sleeping dog: slowly, hoping not to wake it, hoping it will wake up when it is ready. In my room, I sat down on the edge of the bed and stared at my hands. When I lay down, I lay on my side. I did not comb my hair. At some point, I slept. I didn’t dream of a woman on the ice. I dreamed of a field that breathed, in and out, in and out, and a voice that knew my name the way only you can know your own, like a tooth you worry with your tongue. For years afterwards, I told myself that we had scared each other into it, that teenagers will always find a way to make a shadow taller than it is. For years afterwards, I told myself that the dangerous line we crossed was only the line between what we wanted to be true and what we feared might be. And then sometimes—like nights when I wake and my hair is damp as if someone has been combing it with wet fingers—I don’t tell myself anything at all. I get up, and I step out clean, and I don’t look over my left shoulder. Not until morning. Not ever.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This folk horror piece successfully captures the essence of the genre while adhering closely to the prompt requirements. Set in rural northern Sweden in the 1990s, the story follows Linnea's participation in the Útiseta ritual with her friend Astrid. The author has crafted a tense, atmospheric narrative that maintains the requested ambiguity about whether the events are supernatural or psychological. The writing excels in establishing a sense of place and mood. The descriptions of the burial mound, the mist ("höströk"), and the nighttime landscape create a vivid, eerie setting. The sensory details—the taste of juniper berries, the cold earth under bare feet, the smell of "cold and something green"—immerse the reader in the experience. Character development is strong, particularly in how the author portrays Astrid's matter-of-fact approach to ancient rituals, which perfectly blends teenage rebellion with traditional elements as requested. Linnea's reluctance and curiosity are well-balanced, making her participation believable. The brief mentions of Linnea's mother add depth to her character motivation. The ritual itself is described with convincing detail, from the removal of shoes to avoid metal on the mound to the specific instructions about not looking over one's left shoulder. These elements feel researched and authentic to folk practices while maintaining the requested ambiguity about their efficacy. The narrative tension builds effectively as the ritual progresses. The subtle escalation—from simple sounds to breathing to the voice calling Linnea's name—creates mounting dread without resorting to obvious horror tropes. The use of first-person past tense works well, with the framing device of Linnea's present-day recollection subtly woven in through occasional references to "now" and "years between." The prose is generally strong, with evocative metaphors and sensory language that enhance the atmosphere. Occasionally, some sentences could be tightened for greater impact, but the writing maintains a consistent voice throughout. The ending successfully maintains the ambiguity requested in the prompt. Linnea's continued uncertainty about what happened that night—sometimes rationalizing it as teenage imagination, sometimes acknowledging something more—leaves the reader to draw their own conclusions while emphasizing the dangerous line crossed when treating ancient practices as entertainment. The piece does have a few minor weaknesses. Some sentences could be more concise, and there are moments where the pacing slows slightly. The dialogue, while generally effective, occasionally feels slightly stilted. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise accomplished piece of folk horror. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Physical-spatial: Therapeutic Boundaries — Score: 92.2
Prompt:
**"Therapeutic Boundaries"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a former professional athlete undergoing mandatory physical therapy after a career-destroying injury, harboring resentment toward recovery itself. Their physiotherapist is not only unnervingly attractive but also a former training partner from their competitive days who has successfully transitioned to a new career while the protagonist's identity remains shattered. We'll lean into the sexual tension of the scene by having her be attracted to him, but both of them attempting to maintain mental distance while being in physical contact as he shows her stretches & movements & manipulates her body, navigating the thresholds of pain. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—every movement, stretch, and manipulation must be anatomically precise and spatially consistent. Paint an exceptionally vivid sensory picture through detailed attention to pain thresholds, involuntary responses to touch. Capture the suppressed, flaring tension of physical proximity, touch, and the controlled infliction of uncomfortable movements. Physical clarity is essential — readers must understand exactly what is happening with the body during each therapeutic technique. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The treatment table is too narrow and the paper crinkles every time I shift, broadcasting my restlessness like a metronome. The room is clinical—gray walls, storage cabinets with labeled bins of bands and balls and weights—but someone has snuck in civility: a ceramic cone on the counter exhales lavender, thin and floral, threaded over the smell of alcohol wipes and rubber. Mara stands at the foot of the table, skimming the chart on her tablet with her thumb. Her hair is pulled into a low knot the same way it always was when we used to line up at the blocks—sleek, no nonsense, pins catching the light. She’s in a navy polo with the clinic logo at the breast, black pants, running shoes that I know have their own fit story and arch support. Her face is the same, except the lines at the corners of her eyes are deeper; I don’t remember them when she laughed in the locker room after I finished a PR session. I also remember how she would tip me back on my scapulas with two fingers and tell me to stop shrugging my shoulders. Here we are again, except now it’s her name on the door and mine on the schedule. “How’s the pain this morning?” she asks. Her voice is neutral, practiced, pitched to neither coddle nor dare. “It’s there.” I flex my left foot; the ankle—the joint that blew my trajectory sideways—is encased in a low-profile brace. My heel skids on the paper. “Scale of one to ten?” She sets the tablet on the counter. The faint lavender keeps trying to tell me that this is a spa, a place where stress dissolves. My body knows better. “Four when I’m still. Seven if I’m walking. Ten when you touch it.” I mean it to sound like a joke, but it lands between us with the dull weight of an old argument. She gives me a look that could be sympathy or amusement or professional detachment. She steps closer; the friction of her sleeve against my bare knee is a small static report. “Let’s start with the basics.” She reaches under my heel with one hand and under my calf with the other. “Lie back. I’ll do the movement, you just let me know when you feel it. Breathe.” I inhale. The lavender is threaded with something cleaner, the citrus of her shampoo or her soap. She flexes my foot into dorsiflexion—ankle pulling up towards the shin. The top of my foot stretches, the Achilles tugs. It’s a dull pull until it isn’t: sharp, electric, an arc that shoots behind the medial malleolus and into the arch. My toes twitch. “There,” I say. “Seven.” “Good.” She holds the angle, steady pressure that doesn’t increase, watching my toes, watching the flutter at my jaw I try to stop by clenching. She counts under her breath, then slowly eases me back into neutral. “Now plantarflex.” She guides my foot forward, pointing. The front of my ankle compresses, the back lengthens. This is how it goes: movement within the joint’s rails, slow, controlled. The skin on her forearms brushes my shin; my leg hair registers each stray hair on her arm like antennae. I breathe like she told me to, long inhale, longer exhale, controlling something. Each pass she takes me a hair farther. My body resists; my body yields. My body remembers what it is to be told. “Eversion,” she says, shifting her hand from my heel to the outer edge of my foot. She rolls my sole outward, stretching the peroneals along the lateral calf. A hot string lights along the outer ankle, wraps behind the fibula. “Eight,” I grunt. “I have you,” she says, and she does: one hand cradling the top of my foot, the heel sliding in her palm. Her thumb presses the base of my fifth metatarsal, a point that flares and then, with the pressure, releases. “Inversion next. Tell me before it’s too much.” She brings my sole inward. The inside of the ankle complains, the injured deltoid ligament protesting with a mild, sharp ache. My big toe tightens. This is the injury’s handwriting, legible still even after months. “Back,” I say. She reverses immediately, neutral again. My breath shakes out. She sets my foot on the table and steps to the side, her hip brushing the table edge; I can feel the displacement of air, the body heat, the awareness that she is right there, all that efficient strength contained. “Active dorsiflexion. You pull toes up. Slow.” Her hand hovers under my foot, not touching unless I wobble. I pull against gravity. The anterior tibialis engages along the front of the shin; a tremor ripples as the damaged pathways get called up. The tremor embarrasses me more than it should. A lifetime of training taught me to hide weakness, and here is my foot shaking like it’s never done work. “Good control,” she says. “Hold at the top. Five, four…” Her voice draws the count out, a metronome. I hold; the burn salts the muscle. I let go on her cue. We repeat, the wobble smaller each time. Sweat beads at my temples, cools almost instantly in the climate-controlled room. “Let’s mobilize the talus.” She steps closer again, the slate floor squeaking under her shoe. She cups my heel, places the web of her opposite hand just above the ankle joint on the front, fingers splayed across my tibia and fibula to stabilize. “Relax your leg,” she says. She leans her trunk slightly, applying gentle posterior glide to the talus as she brings my knee forward over the foot. The sensation is deep, a pressure inside the joint that isn’t pain exactly but makes me want to pull away. I don’t. We hold, she backs off. Again. “Okay?” she asks. “Fine.” My voice is rough. Her wrist bones slide under her skin as she alternates pressure. Her breath ghosts past the little hairs on my shin when she leans. I stare past her at the poster of skeletal feet, the neat Latin of bones, as if nomenclature can erase the animal fact of touch. “Side-lying,” she says. She helps me roll onto my right side so the injured left is on top. The paper pulls under my shoulder blade, bunches; the table vinyl is cold against my bare triceps. She positions a pillow between my knees and another under my head. She steps behind me—no, beside me, but now her body is a curved wall along my back. “We’re going to do clamshells. Hips stacked, spine neutral. Don’t rotate.” Her hand lands on the crest of my left ilium, fingers framing the bone light as a hooked wing. Then the heel of her palm presses into the side of my gluteus medius. “Open.” I lift the top knee, keeping the feet together. The hip burns immediately, small stabilizers firing. She resists gently with her hand, a diagonal pressure that makes me fight to hold alignment. This part—this controlled force, the asking and answering of pressure—used to feel like life. Now it feels like penance. I lift, hold, lower slow. She cues my breath. “Exhale on the effort.” Her voice softens slightly. Her body is close enough that when I exhale, the warm air rebounds off her shirt and I breathe it back in. I hold the last rep until the muscle shivers, then lower. She taps the muscle with two fingers, a tickle that makes me want to swat her hand away. “Good. Roll onto your back.” I do, heaving the leg over the midline with both hands. She steadies the ankle as it crosses, fingers circling just proximal to the malleoli. “We’re going to work the calf. I’m going to apply pressure; tell me when it’s too much.” Her thumb lines up on my medial gastrocnemius. She leans her weight in slowly, not poking but sinking, waiting for the tissue to give. The pain is very specific and very informative: a hot spear that radiates toward the inner knee, then fuzzes at the edges as her thumb stays, holds, breathes with me. My foot spasms. She feels it and adjusts the vector a fraction of a degree, letting the pressure align with the muscle fibers. I feel the release like a sigh inside the meat. I do not make a sound. She repeats down the length of the calf, lateral head, then soleus deeper under. When she finally backs off, the limb feels both bruised and lighter. “Now,” she says, moving to the head of the table. Her chest is in my line of sight; I look away, stare instead at the clean lines of her collarbone, the pulse in her neck, the shallow hook of the stethoscope over a chair. “Return of proprioception. Close chain.” She helps me sit, then stand, her hand under my elbow but not grasping, just present. The table edge digs into the back of my thighs as I scoot toward the floor. My foot thuds heavier than I expect onto the mat. The joint protests the load with a whine. “Weight shift.” She places one foot slightly behind her other and faces me; the posture is reflexively athletic, ready to catch. We stand hip-width apart. “Shift onto the left. Keep the knee over the second toe. Don’t let the arch collapse.” Her hand cups my knee—not front or back, but beside, thumb on the tibial tuberosity, fingers along the medial patella. The warmth of her palm is ridiculous. Her other hand hovers under my arch, not touching unless it drops. I shift. The weight moves through the foot: heel, lateral edge, first metatarsal. The plantar fascia tightens. The peroneals stabilize. She watches the alignment like a hawk. Her eyes cut to mine once, a reflex to check in. The look is quick, professional. My body reacts as if it were something else, old pathways lighting. “Good. Small knee bend.” I flex. The anterior ankle complains, a bright blade. “Back off a centimeter.” I do. The blade dulls to a tolerable pressure. She nods. “Hold for three breaths.” Her hands are there, not quite touching, making a boundary I mind carefully. We breathe. On the second exhale the joint sings high. My fingers curl against my thigh. My palm is damp. “Step back,” she says. I shift weight off; the relief is immediate, almost a flush. I hate that relief. I hate the way my mood is tied to millimeters. She does not flinch when I roll my eyes, when I bark a laugh at nothing. “Single-leg balance.” She demonstrates, then moves behind me to a spot where she can catch me without making it an embrace. “Stand tall. Pick up your right foot an inch.” Her palms are open, one near my shoulder blade without contact, one near my hip. I lift. The left ankle wobbles, trying to find the floor through a storm. Tiny muscles fire, fail, fire. The arch tries to collapse; her fingers are there in the air to remind it not to. I stare at a point on the wall and imagine drilling a thread into it with my eyes. I last longer than I think I will. I last less than I want. My hip drops; she taps my glute, feather light, to bring it back online. I feel heat crawl up my neck, humiliation mixed with adrenaline. Her breath is steady behind me. The lavender is faint and somehow obscene. “Okay,” she says, and I remember that we used to cool down like this, focused, bodies humming. Except then no one was pretending that they didn’t want to fall into someone else after. Now we both perform poise while my body performs failure, and her hands write corrections on my skin without leaving marks. We go to the table again. She kneels by my foot, lifts it into her lap, and the warmth of her thigh through her pants is a shock. She catches herself—takes a half-inch back, repositions so my heel rests on a folded towel instead. Boundaries. “I’m going to perform a calcaneal eversion glide,” she says, tone textbook now. She cups my heel, aligns her thumbs along the calcaneus. Her forearms form a triangle. “Relax.” She applies lateral pressure while stabilizing the talus with her opposite hand. The subtalar joint opens subtly, a click that isn’t audible but felt, an untwining. The relief makes my eyelids flicker. I hate how grateful I am. “You’re doing well,” she says. She strips her hands away, stands, and the cool air rushes in where her heat was. My ankle feels like something she’s tuned, still fragile but more itself. “We’ll add theraband work next session. I want you at home doing alphabet writing with your foot, ankle circles—slow, controlled.” She demonstrates, drawing invisible letters in the air with her finger, the same motion I will have to reproduce with my toes. Her body sketches an A. The motion makes her shirt pull across her chest. I’m ridiculous. I want to apologize and also to accuse her of cruelty for bringing lavender and clean lines and that face into a room where I am reduced to an injured hinge. She passes me a loop of green band. “Not yet. Next time,” she says, smiling—small, professional. “Ice when you get home, ten minutes. Not directly on the skin. Two minutes of calf raises in the kitchen while you wait for the kettle. Three sets of ten. Use the counter for balance, both legs to go up, left leg to lower. Slow.” I nod. I want to ask her if she remembers the last race we both ran, the way she leaned into me in the tunnel and said, If you don’t go now, you never will. I want to ask her if she ever misses it, the hurt and the high, or if she’s truly just this—present, functional, whole. I want to tell her that the thing about pain is that it feels like truth. Instead, I swing my legs off the table. She’s there again, hand near my elbow, not touching. I stand. The floor is unforgiving but firm. My ankle holds. “Same time next week,” she says. “Yeah.” I pull my shoe on, the laces suddenly clumsy. She watches my knot, the way my fingers fumble. She does not offer to help; I don’t know if I’m relieved or disappointed. At the door, the lavender hums louder in the quiet. She opens it, waits as I step through. We’re close again for a breath. It would be simple to reach and not simple at all. I do neither. She nods; the knot of her hair doesn’t move. I walk down the hall on my altered gait, counting stairs, cataloging sensations, holding the arithmetic of pain in my head like a prayer. I don’t look back, because if I do I will see her there in her blue polo and her clean hands, and I will want to tell her how the line between hurt and help feels like a lover’s mouth on a bruise. Instead, I walk. The ankle flexes a degree past what it did before. It is almost nothing. It is the only thing.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the complex dynamics between a former professional athlete and their physiotherapist. The piece excels in its anatomical precision, creating a vivid sensory experience that maintains physical coherence throughout. Every movement is described with technical accuracy, from dorsiflexion and plantarflexion to calcaneal eversion glides. The protagonist's resentment toward recovery is palpable, expressed through internal thoughts like "Now it feels like penance" and "I hate the way my mood is tied to millimeters." The narrative skillfully weaves this resentment with the sexual tension between the characters, creating a multilayered dynamic that feels authentic rather than forced. The writing demonstrates exceptional control of sensory details. Physical sensations are rendered with precision: "The pain is very specific and very informative: a hot spear that radiates toward the inner knee, then fuzzes at the edges." The author creates a vivid environment through small details like the "ceramic cone on the counter exhales lavender" and the paper that "crinkles every time I shift." The prose maintains a consistent voice throughout—clinical yet intimate, reflecting the protagonist's athletic background and current vulnerability. Sentences vary effectively in length and structure, creating a natural rhythm that mirrors the physical therapy session's ebb and flow. Where the piece truly shines is in its portrayal of the unspoken tension between the characters. Their shared history is revealed gradually through small details and memories, creating depth without exposition dumps. The protagonist's conflicted feelings—both attraction and resentment—are conveyed through physical reactions and internal thoughts rather than explicit statements. The ending avoids easy resolution, maintaining the complexity established throughout. The final image of the protagonist walking away with an ankle that "flexes a degree past what it did before" provides a subtle note of progress without undermining the emotional complexity. If there are weaknesses, they're minor. Occasionally, the technical language might create distance for readers unfamiliar with anatomical terms, though this is balanced by clear contextual descriptions. The piece also maintains such consistent tension that it occasionally risks becoming repetitive in its emotional notes, though the varied physical therapy exercises provide structural variety. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted narrative that fulfills all the prompt requirements while creating a compelling, emotionally resonant experience. The writing demonstrates mastery of both technical precision and emotional nuance. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Historical fiction: High Seas and Low Vices — Score: 90.5
Prompt:
High Seas and Low Vices: British Naval Officer in the Opium Trade Character: Lieutenant James Merrick, a high-ranking officer in the British Royal Navy stationed in Canton, China in the 1830s. Once promising and decorated, now struggling with a severe opium addiction he hides from his superiors. Synopsis: Write a chapter following Lieutenant Merrick during a single day as he shirks his official naval duties in what has become a daily need to satiate the dragon. Told primarily in dialogue with the characters he interacts with. Focus on brief slices of his journey through the shadowy underworld of Canton: interactions with acquaintances, negotiations with local dealers, schemes and unsavoury jobs taken to fund his habit. Writing Task: Use rich sensory details to describe a day in the life of James Merrick. Write for a real sense of time & place while avoiding cliche. First person, past tense. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The bell from the factory yard struck six and the river wore a grey, unpromising skin. I stood under the eaves with my cap tucked into my coat, looking at a sky the colour of pewter and pretending to be early for inspection. The clerk—young Worsley—came out rubbing sleep from his eyes and stopped hard when he saw me. “Lieutenant, sir. Thought you were on the morning rounds with Mr. Peyton.” “I am,” I said, buttoning my coat higher. “I’ve just made them.” “At the anchorage?” His eyes brightened. “And the chop? They say deliveries—” “Postponed,” I said. “Too much tide.” He sighed. “I was hoping Mr. Elliott might sign the disbursement. My mother’s letter arrived and—” “Later,” I said. “Send the messenger back with a polite nothing.” Worsley nodded and attempted a smile that turned back on itself. I folded away from him into the street. It was easier to lie on an empty stomach. The scent of rotting mangoes hits earlier in summer and later in winter, but it was there already, creeping through my teeth as I stepped into New Street. It leaked from baskets abandoned, from the black damp at the base of the wall, from the mouth of a pig nosing at a woven lid. It is a sweet rot, the way old rooms hold prayers. It clung to the bricks as the hawkers began to lay out their morning. Piles of bitter greens glinted with dew. Steam rose from vats of millet, pork, buns pinched like sleeping children. I kept to the wall, not because of thieves, but because I had trained myself to walk as if I were invisible. “Lieutenant! Ho! Merrick!” Mr. Harland from the tea warehouse waved a ledger like a fan. “A word about your tally marks yesterday.” “We’ll speak later,” I said. “It cannot wait. The ships are in, and your—” I held my hand up as if I were listening for something. He stared foolishly into the air, then dropped his gaze, offended. I moved on. His voice washed after me, then died against the white plaster of the Danish factory. At Hog Lane a boy with a shaved head threw his bamboo hoop and ran past as if being chased by the hoop instead of the other way round. He turned to grin at me and I remembered, for a moment, the uncomplicated edge of mornings on the quarterdeck when the wind made everything hard and exact. “Lieutenant,” Mr. Mackenzie said, falling into step beside me as if he had always been there and I had been keeping him waiting. He was a merchant of the type that grows from the soil of this place—hips soft with success, eyes sharp, skin lightly powdered against damp. “You’re out early for a gentleman with nothing to declare.” “I declare as much as any of you,” I said. He smiled without humour. “Your friends at the Customhouse are less patient than last season. There is talk of doubling the searches.” “Then I am fortunate that I carry nothing,” I said. “Fortunate indeed.” He nodded to a woman in a pink jacket who balanced a tray of eggs on her head. “I have a favour to ask, Merrick. There is a minor inconvenience along the creek. A boat delayed, its cargo made restless by the presence of a certain Yeh.” “Yeh is a clerk,” I said. “He eats rice where he is told.” “He eats more than rice. He would like to eat me. I would prefer he does not.” Mackenzie angled his body closer, lowering his already soft voice. “A half hour of your time. A few English words spoken in the right ear. Nothing in writing. You stand a yard behind me and say nothing unless you must. You have a talent for standing.” “I am engaged,” I said. “In what?” He looked around at the stalls as if expecting an answer to sell itself. “In naval matters,” I said, and hated myself for reaching for that ragged cloak. “Report-writing. Captain says—” “Captain Lundy says many things he does not do,” he said. “Would Mr. Lundy have you sleep under my ledger if he knew how often your accounts rely upon it?” “Later,” I said. He nodded as if I had said yes. “Print Street. Noon. Do not keep me waiting or I will mistake your absence for disinterest.” I cut away into a narrower lane, fruit bruises underfoot making the ground treacherous. A cat’s tail drew a comma over a heap of peel. A woman sat on a stool with her neat hands in a basin of water, washing radishes as if they might forgive her. She did not look up. A wall hid the slant of a temple roof, but its bell had a particular iron throat and it spoke three times, the last chime a little sullen. “Jem,” someone hissed from behind a painted door. “Captain Jem.” “Don’t call me that,” I said, glancing around out of habit. “It is what you are,” the voice grinned. The door slid aside. Sui’s nose appeared—the little break in it like a note torn from a page. “You come early. You ask me what? Double price. Morning good smoke. Night cheap.” “Don’t be foolish,” I said. “You’ll have the same I always take.” “‘Always’ is a dream,” Sui said, opening fully now, cyan shirtsleeves rolled to the elbow. “Dream move. Coin stay. You bring coin today?” “I will,” I said. “After eleven. I need to set aside a parcel. Same mix.” “You always say ‘after’,” Sui said. He tapped his fingernail on the jamb, a patient little click. “I am not school. I am business.” “You are not a fool,” I said. “I will have what I owe.” “You owed yesterday,” he said. “You know this alley. It forgive less.” I leaned closer. The door caught me, the edge of it damp. I could smell breakfast from inside—rice, faint fish, the candied tang of the pipe. My stomach roared like something chained. “By noon,” I said. “I have something coming. Mackenzie has a job and—” Sui smiled with his teeth. “Ah. Big belly.” “You know him?” “I know his sandal make noise like a small pig when it rain,” Sui said. “I know his coin smell like English soap. Noon, Jem. Noon is gravity. You miss and I sell your parcel to a man who respect me.” “You sell my parcel and you lose me for good,” I said. Sui tilted his head. “You say like I am wife. I sell to many men. But I like you because you say sorry like song.” He squinted. “You hands shake. You cannot cut rope clean today. You make bad sailor. Take small button now. Pay later.” “How small?” “Thumb,” he said. “Smaller than you want. Big enough to walk.” “Half,” I said. “Half for men who pay last week,” he said. He slid the door almost shut, a foot’s width left for my pride to squeeze through. “Thumb,” I said, swallowing rage that had nothing noble in it. “And a promise.” “No more promise,” he said, and went inside. He returned with a twist of oil paper like a secret and pinched it between his fingers. “You keep your cap off my floor.” I took the twist, let it fall into my pocket like a coin. The smell of mango rot swung and came back. I went, without looking back, toward the river steps. On the stone there, under a mat awning, I found the missionary. Mr. Doolan—freckled, hair the colour of string, cheeks weathered like old pennies. He sat with his knees up, Bible open on them, and an expression of mild surprise as if the world had interrupted him by existing. “Lieutenant Merrick, good morning. You look unwell.” “I slept little,” I said. The river looked like a dirty mirror. Mm. The oarsmen were just beginning to shout. “I have a tract for you.” He fished in the pocket of his coat and brought out a folded square with a picture of a drowning man on the front. “On the question of appetite.” “I have none,” I lied. “It is a universal condition,” he said. “It can be turned.” “What do you want turned?” I asked. “Your steps,” he said. “I see you turn toward Hog Lane at hours that grow shorter. There is a table at Dr. Parker’s, you know. Clean, and without the smell.” “I have no quarrel with smells,” I said. “Then with truth?” He squinted. “I am told you were at Lintin last month when that junk went aground. A boy drowned because the line slipped. Is that true?” “A boy drowned because the junk went aground,” I said. “My truth is not better than his.” “You could rest,” he said, gentling his voice like a hand on a restless animal. “One hour. There are oranges. You could eat an orange and—” “Oranges are for men who can taste them,” I said. “Keep your paper. I like the picture.” He stood as if to follow me but thought better of it. A boatman laughed somewhere upstream, the laugh made of phlegm and joy. I tucked my chin into my coat and moved on. At Bligh’s tavern, the shutters were half up. The girl with the twist of hair at the crown of her head had a broom in hand and a set of pipes in her pocket. “Merrick,” she said, her eyes running over me and then away. “You’re off duty?” “I’m always on duty,” I said. “You look like a breakfast a cat dragged,” she said. “What you having?” “Water,” I said. “And whatever is cheap.” “Nothing is cheap,” she said. “But there is millet from last night. And a cup of tea. Mr. Harland paid for one for you the other day, said you stared at his figures as if they were waves.” “He’s an ass,” I said, sitting, the bench sticky under my hand. “If he comes in, tell him I’ve gone upriver.” “He never comes this early. His wife keeps him.” She brought the bowl. “There were boys outside. They bet whether you’d fall asleep with your eyes open.” “Who won?” “The small one,” she said. “You should eat your millet before it becomes a story.” I forced three mouthfuls. They stuck. The tea was bitter and clear. I let it sit in my cheek until it warmed me in one sweet line that had nothing to do with sugar. “You going to the factory?” she asked. “They sent a boy for you. Ran like his clothes were on fire.” “They always do.” “You owe Sui,” she said casually, the way a woman tells you your shoes are not laced. “He told Li who told me. Don’t be foolish.” “I am never foolish,” I said. “You are always foolish,” she said, but she smiled when she said it, which made it worse. “You think being English turns it into something else.” At Print Street the shops had opened their eyes. Uneven shutters looked out like old men watering the last of their geraniums. Mackenzie stood under a signboard with a painted carp, looking at his watch as if the watch were to blame. “You are late by three minutes,” he said. “You are early by one,” I said. A low man in a brown jacket stood at his shoulder, his hat folded under his arm like a fan. He was the sort that never testifies, only remembers. “Mr. Yeh waits inside,” Mackenzie said. “He has invented a fee. He will call it a local consideration. We will call it theft. You will call it a misunderstanding and suggest, with dignity, that the matter will be recalled in London, which is a place he fears the way we fear a certain clerk in Macao. You see? And if he asks your name you give him no name that can be pinned to a paper.” “I am all pins and paper, Mackenzie.” “You are a man in a blue coat. Try and remember it.” We went in. The smell of ink, candle grease, damp from a floor that had been mopped with a bucket that had not itself been clean. The clerk—Yeh—sat with his shoes off, toes long and splayed. He did not get up. His gaze stuck to me like a burr. “Sir,” he said. “Your friend is foreigner.” “We both are,” Mackenzie said in perfect Cantonese. “He is here to listen.” “Foreigners are bad listeners,” Yeh said. He pushed forward a paper. “There is a new regulation. It concerns taxes on—” “Salt,” Mackenzie said. “We do not trade salt.” “Tea dust is a salt,” Yeh said primly. “Very damaging to the lungs. It must be regulated.” “By your lungs?” I said, in English. Yeh’s eyes flicked back to me. He enjoyed not understanding it while understanding the contempt. He smiled. “Your king make rules for your shop?” he asked Mackenzie. “He send better ink? Or only more men to steal your breakfast?” “My king has not eaten breakfast,” Mackenzie said lightly. “He is fasting in sympathy with us. Here is what will happen. We will pay the usual consideration. You will not invent a salt.” “You talk very much,” Yeh said, glancing at me again. “Your soldier has a shaking hand. He has fever.” I clasped my hands behind my back. The joints felt full of sand. “He is bored,” Mackenzie said. “Please do not bore him further.” Yeh let silence earn him a coin. He liked to perform it. He counted his own fingers as if they were money. At length, he folded the paper and patted it, like stroking a cat. “Usual consideration,” he said, and named a number that was twice the usual. “Half,” I said before Mackenzie could speak. The word scraped out of me dry. “Half, or the salt you invent today will taste like your own blood.” There was a beat. Then he laughed, without humour, the luckless sound of a bamboo chair moved on wood. “You are a poet,” he said in English, the word round and surprising in his mouth. “You make very pretty songs.” He held up two fingers, then one. Mackenzie’s jaw ticked. He put down the coin. Yeh swept it up as if drawing a curtain. Outside, Mackenzie blew air through his nose in a way that made me think of horses. “You wasted breath in there.” “He enjoyed himself less,” I said. “And will enjoy making it more difficult next time,” he said. He peered at me. “You’re near it. Go and be done, and keep your tongue when you return. I will send a purse via Worsley to Spare Street. You can pay Sui and be a man for three hours. After that, let me never hear of it.” “If you are so offended,” I said, “Why do you ask me to stand behind you?” “Because you remind them we can bite,” he said. “Even if we have no teeth. Noon. Do not make me send someone with a hook.” I crossed the culvert at pace, my heart too high in my chest. Men shouted about hemp and hog bristles. A girl carried a duck with its head under her arm, the duck peered up at me with the one eye it had and seemed unimpressed. At Spare Street, a courier stood like a plant with his toes together. He had Worsley’s quill behind his ear, stolen or borrowed; in either case a wound. “Lieutenant Merrick,” he stammered, bowing too much. “From Mr. Mackenzie. And from Mr. Worsley, his note: ‘Please attend Mr. Peyton’s inspection at four and bring your hat.’” “I will,” I said. The purse felt like heat in my hand. I allowed myself one breath with my eyes closed, cool in through the nose, the mango-sweet rot finding a new register and settling into my nerves like a promise. I opened my eyes and went to Sui. “You were not gravity,” he said, counting the coin with nimble cruelty. “You were wind.” “I’m here before noon,” I said. The coin clacked, not quite enough weight, always less when it leaves your hand. He slid the paper parcel toward me, snug as a baby in its wrap, and a chilled brass lamp no larger than my palm. “Back room,” he said. “You got ten. Then my brother come. He breaks things when he see men sleep.” The room had no window, only a hole in the roof where smoke made a black flower. A mat. A coil of cloth like a snake. The first draw tightened something loose in my head, the way a good knot pulls, clean. The second turned the alley’s rot into honey. I lay back and let the smoke undo the day. Somewhere outside a Farthing song—one of the sailors with a tune—bothered the air and then wandered off. The pipe made its small cricket noises. “Jem,” a voice said, as if from the mat. Not Sui; female, English. I opened one eye. Charlotte—Captain Lundy’s niece—stood in the doorway with her skirts bunched in one hand to keep them from rot. She should not have been there. Her face was set with a fury that looked very like restraint. “You cannot be here,” I said, my mouth making the words too soft. “I know precisely where I am,” she said. “Get up.” “I am up,” I said. “Get up,” she said again, and stepped over a bucket. “You think you are the only man who knows where a door is in this town? Worsley begged me. He said you would listen to me. He was wrong, I see.” “Sui,” I said through the smoke, in the language he liked to pretend he didn’t understand. “Why did you let a child in?” “She paid,” Sui said without apology. “She pay more than you.” Charlotte’s eyes flicked to the pipe. They did not soften. “You smell like a waste place.” “You smell like soap,” I said. “We are both what we are.” “You are dimming,” she said. Her mouth trembled and then bit the trembling back. “I thought you were brave. The first week. On the river. Do you remember? The oar struck your shoulder and you laughed.” “Things happen,” I said. “Not this
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece effectively captures the day in the life of Lieutenant James Merrick, a British naval officer struggling with opium addiction in 1830s Canton. The writing demonstrates exceptional command of period-appropriate language, sensory detail, and characterization. The first-person narration successfully places us in Merrick's deteriorating mental state. His interactions reveal a man clinging to the remnants of his naval authority while being slowly consumed by addiction. The prose skillfully balances between moments of sharp clarity and increasing haziness as the day progresses toward his fix. The setting of Canton is vividly rendered through sensory details: "The scent of rotting mangoes," "Steam rose from vats of millet, pork, buns pinched like sleeping children," and the "cat's tail drew a comma over a heap of peel." These details create an immersive atmosphere that feels authentic to the time and place without relying on orientalist clichés. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinct voice. Sui's broken English contrasts with Mackenzie's polished merchant-speak, while Charlotte's proper diction reflects her social position. The dialogue efficiently reveals character relationships and power dynamics without exposition. The narrative structure effectively traces Merrick's day as he navigates various social spheres—from naval duties to merchant dealings to the opium den—showing how his addiction has corrupted every aspect of his life. The pacing builds tension as Merrick becomes increasingly desperate for his fix. There are a few minor issues. The piece ends abruptly mid-sentence with "Not this," which feels unintentional rather than a stylistic choice. While this could be interpreted as Merrick losing consciousness, it reads more like an incomplete submission. Additionally, some transitions between scenes could be smoother, though the fragmentary nature does reflect Merrick's deteriorating focus. The prose occasionally risks becoming purple but generally maintains control, using vivid imagery that serves character and setting rather than mere decoration. For example, "I let it sit in my cheek until it warmed me in one sweet line that had nothing to do with sugar" effectively conveys Merrick's sensory experience while hinting at his addiction. Overall, this is an accomplished piece that creates a compelling character study while vividly evoking a specific historical moment. It balances sensory richness with narrative momentum and uses dialogue to reveal character with impressive economy. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Humour: Sisyphus Gives Advice — Score: 92.0
Prompt:
Sisyphus Gives Advice Write a comedic scene in the style of Terry Pratchett featuring Sisyphus, who has started an advice column while continuing his eternal boulder-pushing. Rather than being bitter about his punishment, Sisyphus has developed a comfortably zen emotional intelligence and wisdom from his centuries of repetitive labor. Not in the cliche ways you might expect -- he's actually very grounded, warm & connected with the everyday human plight. He dictates responses to "Crow," his feathered familiar who serves as both scribe and mail carrier. The piece should include Sisyphus thoughtfully answering several advice-seekers' letters about everyday problems (relationship troubles, work-life balance, dealing with difficult people, life purpose doubts) while periodically returning to his boulder-pushing duties. His advice should be surprisingly insightful and practical. The humor should emerge naturally from the messages he receives, from mundane to risque. Sisyphus should genuinely enjoy helping others, finding meaning in this new pursuit while maintaining his boulder routine. The humour should be *understated and not forced*. Contrary to expectation, almost none of his advice involves boulder rolling metaphors (though he does sneak *one* subtle in there), nor a treatise on stoicism. We are also going against the obvious fish-out-of-water trope; in fact, he's surprisingly a natural at this. In all of this , it's important to *show, don't tell*. The format should be largely epistolary, with the occasional interjection for scene setting. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The thud was punctual. It had taken centuries for the boulder to learn punctuality. At the bottom of the hill, it always arrived with a sound like a door being shut firmly but kindly. Sisyphus placed his hands on its good side (most boulders have a good side if you take the time) and leaned in. The first few paces were always a conversation with gravity. After that, things became pleasantly straightforward. “Crow,” he said, as the pebbles clicked politely under his sandals. “First letter.” Crow, who was black in the way morning coffee is black and had the handwriting of a persistently scolded clerk, strutted on a nearby rock and unfurled a scroll from under his wing. He dipped his beak thoughtfully in the little inkpot they kept in a niche and read in a tone that implied both skepticism and perfect dictation. “Dear Sisyphus,” Crow began, “my partner and I have been together for eight years. We love each other, but lately our arguments over small things — dishes, laundry, my terrible habit of bringing home free pens — have become big.
