He was happy in the way he got—the simple arithmetic of sign and direction and distance, the way a path laid itself out under his boots. Their father didn’t smile. He bent and touched one print, the tip of one finger, quick, like testing a hot surface. He lifted his hand to his nose and sniffed. His eyes unfocused. For a moment, the old empty look came back, and JT’s stomach kicked. Then their father shook himself like a dog that’s been splashed. “Let’s go,” he said. “We’ll circle.” They circled. The prints led them through a stand of young fir that tickled their sleeves and hissed when they pushed through. A raven croaked somewhere to their left and was silent. JT’s ears felt full, like he’d just come up from underwater. He fell behind, not on purpose but the way you do when your head is full of pictures that look like memories but aren’t. His laces were not the problem; his fingers were. They were clumsy, good for nothing but getting in each other’s way. When he looked up, the other two were further ahead than he’d let them get all last season. They were silhouettes. He felt a small alarm bell go off but not in his head—in his chest, his throat, ringing the soft tissue there. He walked faster. He told himself he was not hurrying. The trees opened. There was the clearing. It was smaller than yesterday. Aren’t clearings supposed to look bigger the second time, when you don’t have the surprise of them? He thought that, and the thought itself felt like something that had been placed in his head by someone else’s hand. The place was bright with frost, every blade of brown grass outlined in white. The buck was there. The same buck or another that looked like him, which was the same. He stood in exactly the middle, head high, breath streaming. The breath glowed, as if it had its own light in it. His father and Mike were to the left this time. Their father’s hand lifted again. The same. No, not the same: the fingers this time were splayed a little wider, like he was feeling rain. He stepped forward. The rifle slid down on its sling and bumped his back with a hollow wooden sound that did not carry. JT could have said something. He could have said Dad. He could have said wait. The word formed in his mouth and then turned its face away, stubborn. He felt rooted. He felt as if the clearing had grown little roots out of its frost and stuck them into his boots, into the wet leather, into the meat of his feet. His father’s lips moved. JT could swear he saw that. His father whispered. It was nothing like a prayer that he’d ever heard, but then, he had not heard a lot of prayers. It had that cadence to it that prayers have, a kind of rhythmic pleading that falls and rises. Mike didn’t move at all. His eyes were shining, and he seemed to be trying to smile and having trouble understanding how that worked. The whole thing had a careful, deliberate fragility about it, like a spider web that had caught a drop of rain and was holding it in midair. The buck’s eyes were flat. No fear. No anything. There was that breath, streaming, a visible thing you could reach out and catch, and JT had the strange idea that if he raised his own hand, it would feel cold like the inside of the freezer. He thought of Leon Vance, the old man in town who sometimes nodded off on the bench outside the post office, the way his breath fogged and then was gone. He thought, maybe the woods were breathing through us. Maybe— “Dad,” he said. He didn’t mean to. It came out too loud. It came out like a sneeze, a word that has weight and decides to throw itself off a roof. The buck blinked. JT watched the lids come down and go up. He had never in his life seen that before. Animals blink, of course; he knew that. But the act of seeing it was like seeing a trick done slowly enough to understand it and still not understanding. Their father’s hand dropped as if someone had cut a string. The rifle swung into his hand as if it had always been there. The buck moved—no, it didn’t. JT later would tell himself it did, but really, it just appeared at the edge of the trees. The space it had occupied had frost in it again; the grass there looked crushed, and then it didn’t. Mike swore softly. “Shit,” their father said. He said it with a normal man’s irritation. He looked at JT with eyes that were just eyes. “If you’re going to call out, do it before we’re on top.” JT opened his mouth. Closed it. He felt heat in his face that stung. Shame’s heat, bright and busy. He wanted to say There was something wrong, it had you, it had you both, and he wanted to say nothing at all. “Let’s move,” Mike said quickly, too quickly, and shouldered past their father like he could push the moment out of the way physically. “We can get ahead of him if we cut down by the wash.” “Fine,” their father said. He started walking. JT watched him go. The rhythm of his step was normal. He could pick out the squeak of a leather strap, the soft thwock of wet grass snapping under boot soles. He breathed out and it hung in the air and then rose, shredded by the slightest breeze. They moved. They crashed more than they should have, and both of the other men pretended not to notice. Something had changed, though, and it was so small that if he tried to tell it later, he would hear himself and stop. The sky was brightening, a wash of lighter gray moving across the low clouds. The colors on the ground—greens and browns and the black of cold water—had all become one color he couldn’t name. He felt watched by everything. He felt watched by his own breath. They came to the wash, and JT was in front now because the way narrowed and he was the lightest. He crossed the old plank and felt it sag. The water underneath was eely black, sluggish. He thought about putting his hand into it. He thought about how far you could push your hand into a cold place before it stopped feeling like yours. “Careful,” Mike said behind him. “I know,” JT said. When he was across, he turned to watch them. Their father’s face was set. There was a smear of dirt on his jaw that made him look younger, like the man in the picture from when he first bought the lodge. Mike was grinning again, that bent look, the grin that meant he didn’t want to talk about something. They crossed. The plank creaked, and JT tasted a word: splinter. He swallowed it. The tracks picked up on the other side, but they were wrong. They were…multiple. A confusion. A churn that suggested running, and JT knew in that instant that nothing had run. He knelt and touched one. It was cold. It was a cold he had felt only one other place. “There,” Mike said, pointing. There was a flash in the trees—antler, maybe, or the ghost of antler, the idea of it. He took off at a trot, the focused joy of the chase lighting him up like a different person. Their father hesitated. He put a hand out and touched JT’s shoulder. The hand squeezed once. It was a real touch, callused and heavy. Then he was moving too. JT rose to follow and realized he didn’t know why he was trying so hard to keep up. The woods would get them where they were going, regardless. He had a moment of clarity that frightened him: he understood then that there was a path, whether or not he recognized it as one, and the path had an appetite. He did not have a word for that appetite. He tried to put the thought away as he tried to put all of them away, into the cupboard in his head where he kept the things that would otherwise rattle and spill. He went after them. The trees closed in. The ground sloped. There was a smell in the air now, faint and almost sweet. Not rot. Something like old apples, the kind that have gone soft in the cellar, the kind you pick up and your thumb goes right through. “Hold up,” he said. He didn’t expect them to. They didn’t. The idea of them not hearing him felt like a kindness, and that hurt, somehow. He came out into another open place—a narrow one, more like a room without walls. Moss underfoot, spongy. Their father and Mike stood side by side, their shoulders almost touching, looking at something in front of them with their heads a little bent. The way men look at a newborn through hospital glass. JT came up next to them and looked, too. It was not the buck. It was a thing he could describe easily—a tangle of fallen limbs, a drift of last year’s leaves that had held onto their curled shapes, a low hummock where the ground remembered a stump—but what he saw was this: a shape on the ground that made his skin fear itself. The way the limbs lay, the way the leaves had caught frost in a pattern like ribs, the way two sticks had fallen at the top in a suggestion of antlers. The sense of it was so powerful that his breath hitched. “No,” Mike said, and laughed once, one short barking sound meant to be dismissive. He stepped forward and nudged the shape with his boot. A dry rattle passed through it. The frost turned to tiny drops, and for an instant they held the light like beads of glass. JT thought of necklaces his mother had worn when she felt like it. He thought of her moving her hair out of the way. Their father knelt. He did it slowly, like he was taking a knee in church. He put his hand out. JT wanted to stop him. Didn’t. His father’s fingers brushed the pattern of frost. The drops trembled. He closed his eyes. “What are you doing?” Mike asked, irritated. “It’s nothing. It’s a—” He cast around for a word. Didn’t find a good one. “Pile.” Their father didn’t answer. His lips moved again, and this time JT heard it, or thought he did. He heard his father say, very softly, Please. The wind answered. It came through the trees and made a sound like breath drawn in. The frost went from drops to water all at once, a shift, a tipping point, and the shape changed; it didn’t move, it simply wasn’t the same any longer. It was a pile of sticks and leaves. Ordinary. So ordinary that JT wondered if he’d imagined the other thing, the seeable thing. He didn’t think he had. Their father opened his eyes. They were wet. He stood. He did it in a stiff way that said his knees hurt. He didn’t look at either of them. “We’re going back,” he said. “Now?” Mike looked at him like he’d suggested they go down to the lake for a swim in January. “We’re right in it. If we keep at it—” “Now,” their father said, and the word had the heavy common sense of a door being closed. “We’ve got what we came for.” “What?” JT asked. His father looked at him then. For the first time since the clearing the day before, he looked right at him, and the look hit JT like heat. There was no accusation in it, and no comfort, either. “We’ll talk at the lodge,” their father said, and started back the way they had come. On the way, the woods seemed to rearrange themselves. The bog was on the wrong side; the wash was longer. The plank had a new crack. JT felt the path move under him like a big animal shifting in its sleep. He didn’t say anything. Mike said nothing, either, his mouth set. Their father walked with his head up, impatient at twigs, unconcerned with the small cuts they left on his face. Back at the lodge, the light had gone thin. The porch sagged in greeting. Inside, the stove had gone dead. Mike set to work with paper and kindling like he needed to be noisily busy. Their father hung his rifle, took off his coat, hung it, took it down, hung it again. He went to the counter and put his palms on it. He breathed. “Dad,” Mike said. “You want to tell us what
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This continuation of the surreal horror story demonstrates considerable skill in maintaining the established atmosphere while developing the narrative. The piece effectively builds on the initial setup, preserving JT's perspective as an unreliable narrator caught between what he perceives and what he can rationalize. The prose style successfully emulates Stephen King's approach, blending mundane details with unsettling elements. The writer uses everyday activities—eating stew, washing dishes, playing cribbage—as a counterpoint to the creeping supernatural elements. This grounding in the ordinary makes the strange occurrences more effective. The dialogue is sparse but authentic, capturing the strained dynamics between family members. The father's minimal responses ("Mm") and Mike's nervous chatter effectively convey their psychological states without explicit explanation. The dialogue serves the narrative by revealing character and building tension rather than explaining the plot. The imagery is particularly strong. Descriptions like "the buck's nostrils barely flaring," the father's hand "splayed a little wider, like he was feeling rain," and frost drops that "held the light like beads of glass" create vivid, unsettling pictures. The writer skillfully uses sensory details to establish mood—the taste of pennies in beer, the sound of the wind "like someone whistling for a dog far off." The pacing builds tension effectively through the hunting expedition, with the discovery of the strange formation in the woods serving as a climactic moment. The father's unexplained reaction to this discovery—kneeling as if in church and whispering "Please"—adds to the mystery while suggesting deeper significance. However, the piece does have some weaknesses. The narrative occasionally becomes slightly meandering, particularly during the trek through the woods. Some metaphors, while evocative, verge on purple prose ("the idea of them not hearing him felt like a kindness, and that hurt, somehow"). The ending feels somewhat abrupt, though this may be due to the response being cut off mid-sentence. The psychological horror elements are handled with subtlety. Rather than explicit supernatural events, the story relies on ambiguity and suggestion—the way the buck seems to disappear and reappear, how the woods seem to "rearrange themselves," the father's strange behavior. This ambiguity effectively maintains JT's unreliable perspective, leaving readers to question what is real and what is imagined. Overall, this is a strong continuation that maintains the established tone and builds effectively on the initial setup. It successfully creates an atmosphere of dread and psychological uncertainty while developing the characters and advancing the plot. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 17 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 3 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 17 Overall Impression: 17
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 17.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 3.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 17.0, Overall Impression: 17.0
+ Fantasy-humour: Hell is Other Demons — Score: 95.7
Prompt:
Hell is Other Demons Write a day in the life short story. Lucifer morningstar's on again/ off again relationship with Lilith is currently in the "off again" stage, though the cycle may be coming around as Lilith has been stopping by for reasons other than purely violent ones, and Lucifer has been increasingly lonely. Write a day in the life of this power couple, with elements of dark comedy & fantasy. Use understated irony & absurdity by merging the black immorality and everyday business of running hell, against relatable domestic relationship drama. Take cues from Neil Gaiman. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The drizzle began at seven, which was late for ash. The forecast said “perpetual,” but the clouds had their own unions. It fell soft as dandruff on a kingdom of the damned, sifted into the coffee like gray sugar and landed on contracts, turning every signature into a faintly wintery scene. Lucifer pushed up the blinds in his office and watched it coat the river of fire, where the damned bobbed and complained about the temperature and the artisanal quality of their torment. He stirred his cup with a finger and frowned. Bitter. He added a splash of milk from a black carton labeled “Despair,” which, by the look of it, was expired two eternities ago. It curdled like a prophecy. “Schedule,” he called, and the door opened itself, because it was trained and because Hell never missed an excuse to be theatrical. Behemoth’s niece, a rhino-headed girl with a flair for organization, poked in. “Morning, sir. We’ve got the Lower Circle Audit at nine, pitchfork inspection at ten, eternal lamentation committee at eleven, and—” “The jingle,” he said, with the same resigned tone one uses for the word dentist. “The jingle.” He sighed. There was a time he had been the whisper in the ear and the suggestion at the edge of a prayer. Now he signed requisitions for pitchforks with ergonomic grips and listened to demons argue about a brand identity that didn’t look too… obvious. The jingle was part of a campaign to rebrand Hell as “Your Ultimate Accountability Partner,” which sounded like an app. “Have Marketing remembered we are not an artisanal burger joint?” he said. “They are insisting on ukuleles,” she said. “And a xylophone.” He picked ash from his sleeve. “Fine. Bring me their spirits.” “Team?” she asked, pen hovering. “Souls. Whatever we’re calling them. And a cloth.” He sat a moment, and listened. It was one of his better indulgences. Above him, the ash clicked softly against the bulb. Beyond the glass, an endless parade of bureaucratic torment shuffled on. The damned had opinions about everything here: the thread count in sackcloth, the ethical sourcing of brimstone, whether their suffering was being seen. He had always been a listener. It was how he’d gotten this job in the first place. The door slid back again. He did not look up. “It’s unlocked,” he said. “It’s Hell,” said Lilith. He looked anyway. She was not a storm. She was a weather pattern that had learned to wear heels. She slid in like she owned every shadow in the room and sat on the corner of his desk. Her perfume could have been smoke or could have been memory. Either clung. “If you’re here to kill me,” he said, “I’ve a window at four.” “Heads up you’ve got ash on your eyebrow,” she said, and flicked it off with a nail. “It makes you look… tired.” “I am tired,” he said. “And you did come yesterday and try to set my hair on fire.” She shrugged. “Old habits. It was affectionate.” “It was violent.” “It was affectionate violence. Also I brought muffins.” She held up a box that had once been white. The ash had given it a dust jacketing. Inside were six muffins: two blueberry, two despair-chocolate, one existential crisis with crumble, and something that looked like poppy seed but had an alarming tendency to whisper. “I apologize for the situation,” she said, awkwardly. The word sounded strange in her mouth, like she was trying on a shirt she didn’t like. “It’s… off again, yes?” He glanced at the muffins. “Which situation?” “The situation where I keep coming here to not kill you.” She passed him the existential crisis, which he took because there are pleasures even in damnation. “Also, the ash. You should really petition for better ventilation.” “I petitioned,” he said. “Heaven sent a memo. Weather is weather, and besides, ash is Hell’s seasonal aesthetic.” “Oh, darling,” she said, with that particular tone that meant he was not being dramatic enough. “Your eyebrows are going gray.” He sipped the coffee and then made the face of a man for whom coffee had turned out to be a question. “So you came to not murder me. Any other agenda items?” She leaned closer, as if to confide, and plucked a pen from his pocket. She wrote SINCE YOU ASK on his devil-signed contracts. “Recruitment,” she said. “You’re bleeding the good sinners to Limbo and Purgatory, and the dunes near the fifth circle are full of influencers. They complain. I thought you might need… counsel.” “I do not bleed,” he said. “There’s the ash again. It’s got into everything.” He did not say he had been lonely. It sat beside him in the chair, the shape of a conversation not yet had, the exact weight of her hip against his desk. Behemoth’s niece dropped the cloth and fled at the sight of Lilith. She was sensible. Most people were sensible when Lilith was a noun near them. The jingle committee arrived like a flock of anxious birds. Marketing was three demons in skinny ties and orange lanyards and one damned man who had been an advertising executive in life and thus had been given an office in Hell accordingly. They arranged themselves, apologized to Lilith for existing, and began to strum. “Your personal accountability partner,” sang a demon with horns arranged like a coiffure. “We’re the friend you can’t escape—” “Stop,” said Lucifer. “Why is there a glockenspiel.” “It sounds cheerful,” said the damned executive. “Millennials love glockenspiel.” “Millennials also love not being damned,” said Lilith, examining a blueberry muffin as if it were an animal that could sell her out. She looked up and smiled a smile that could cauterize. “And ukuleles. Why not a scream?” “We tested screams,” said the executive. “Screams underperform.” “Glockenspiel screams,” Lucifer said. He rubbed the bridge of his nose in a gesture stolen from mortals. Best to find humor. Best to find anything. “Fine. Logo?” They showed him a pitchfork with a friendly face. “No,” said Lilith. “It’s approachable,” said the executive. “It’s a fork,” she said. “It doesn’t approach. It impales.” “It’s 2024,” he said. “Approachability metrics are important, Lil—ma’am.” Lucifer folded his hands. “Thank you for your… work. We shall revisit after the eternal lamentation. Dismissed.” They fluttered out, leaving behind a scattering of ash and the haunted silence of a room that had narrowly avoided a violent rebranding. Lilith took his mug and sipped. “You’re soft.” “I am adaptable,” he said. He took the mug back, because boundaries. “And you’re here because… what? You want to be cruel? You want to be kind? You want to see if the drizzle ever stops?” “It never stops,” she said, and both of them looked out the window at the slow, consistent drift. A damned man slipped on it and went face-first into a moral quandary. “It’s comforting.” The eternal lamentation committee sent a representative who apologized for not lamenting more eternally. “We had scheduling conflicts,” said the representative, who looked like a burned-out HR generalist. “Some lamenters had appointed times to be gnawed.” “Gnawing can be rescheduled,” said Lucifer. “Eternity is a resource. Use it.” He signed three memos about chains, one about the proper storage of fire, and one petition from the non-binary witches’ collective requesting more inclusive curses. He approved it without comment. Inclusion was in the mission statement. He envied their cohesion. At lunch they ate the muffins. The existential crisis was, in fairness, exquisite. “Did you hear about the angels?” Lilith said around a crumb. “They’re starting a union.” “I heard,” he said. The ash traced lace patterns on her eyelashes, tiny gray coronas. He wanted to brush them away, so he did not. “Heaven is rethinking infinite praise as a model. They’re trialing silence. They call it a retreat.” “Imagine,” she said. “A God who wants feedback.” They both laughed, but hers had something else in it, like a splinter. It used to be easy, the way they made each other worse. Now it was like they were holding hands across a knife. The afternoon was for escalations. A damned king wanted his crown back to go with his torments. A demon union demanded fairer tormented-to-tormentor ratios. The river of fire cracked in a worrying manner that suggested geological dissent. Lucifer delegated most things and kept the crown dispute because he liked watching monarchs discover democracy. Lilith sat in on it, kicked her shoes off, and made notes on her knee. “Your Majesty,” Lucifer said to the king, who was also a spreadsheet in a suit. “You did understand that the crown was the cause of your fall.” “Of course,” said the king. “But it set off the outfit.” “Give him a tiara,” said Lilith. “Rhinestones. It will itch.” “I will not wear rhinestones,” said the king. “Then you will itch without rhinestones,” she said, and the king shrank, because sometimes the first queen is still the first, even here. At four, when the assassination window rolled around like a recurring advertisement, they were both in his office again, and neither mentioned it. The ash had thickened. Everything wore a veil. Lilith scrolled through her messages, which hissed and sparked. He picked up a pen and drew a circle on a scrap of contract, a small perfect ring that meant nothing and everything. He then drew a second circle around the first, offset. They looked like eyes. He was not sentimental, except in the important ways. “You could come by tonight,” he said, as if mentioning the weather. She looked up at him over the flicker of the screen. The poppy seed muffin whispered something obscene. “To kill you?” “If you like.” “And if I don’t?” “Then to not kill me.” She considered. It was a queen’s consideration, weighted with wars. “You are lonely,” she said. He almost deflected. He almost made a remark about ash. He did not. “Yes.” She closed her messages with a snap that sounded like a bird catching a smaller bird. “Perhaps,” she said. “But I do not bring toothpaste.” “I have toothpaste,” he said. He did not mention that it was made of regret and a bit gritty. She slid off the desk. Ash smudged her heels. The smudge looked like a bruise. “I have to see the sphinxes about a riddle. They’ve been outsourcing.” “Send an invoice,” he said. She stood in the doorway and turned, a small gesture but the kind that made the whole room considered. “If I come,” she said, “we will not fix anything.” “I know,” he said. “And I may set your curtains on fire.” “I bought them for that.” “And I will leave,” she said, very softly, almost cruelly, which was perhaps the closest she could get to kindness. “Again.” “Again,” he said. She nodded, as if a deal had been struck. “Then I will see you for dinner.” She smiled, and it was a terrible, wonderful thing. “Do not make pasta. Every time you make pasta, we consider murdering each other.” “Pasta is honest,” he said. “Pasta is a test,” she said, and closed the door. The drizzle leaned in, which is what drizzle does. He looked out and saw that the damned had begun to build a small snowman of ash on the riverbank. It was pathetic and it was adorable and it was, of course, transient. He got up and fixed his hair in the window’s reflection, pushed the ash to the corners and left it. It was the uniform. Evening found Hell no darker, only more certain. He conducted one last inspection of the pitchforks. They gleamed. He liked their weight. He strolled past the racks, past demons complaining about glockenspiels, past a sign above the inventory door that said “Abandon All Hope of Appropriate Budget.” He stopped to scold a pair of imps for using a circle of salt as a hula hoop. He wrote an apology letter to a soul whose punishment had been misapplied; it was the right thing to do and also good PR. He wondered if he should buy wine. He had wine. It tasted like old oaths. He wanted something lighter. He sent a note to Marketing: try screams. They sent back an emoji of a smiling pitchfork. He climbed the stairs to his rooms. The ash muffled everything into intimacy. He thought of the first time he had built a place like this, fire and purpose in equal measure. He had been younger then. He was still older than anything. Immortality is not ineffability; it is accumulation. She was waiting in the kitchen, wrapped in a human cardigan that she had stolen from a poet and never returned. She had brushed the ash from her hair and left it on the counter, careless as stars. “Wine?” he said. “Tea,” she said. “We will pretend.” He boiled the kettle. The ash hissed on the element and made a smell like rain having second thoughts. They sat at his tiny table, which was an act of violence in itself, two gods perched on mortal furniture, drinking mortal things, pretending mortality made a difference. Outside, the damned sang a song that was almost the jingle but better because no one had agreed on the melody. They ate nothing. They said little. She took his hand. It was a small hand. It could hold an empire. It could hold his. “You were right,” she said, at last, surprising them both. “About what?” “The ash is in everything.” “It is,” he said. “It is inconvenient.” “It is,” he said. She squeezed his fingers, a concession to comfort but not a surrender. “And it is home.” He did not say yes. He did not say no. He took another sip of tea, which tasted like time pretending to be water. The ash continued to fall, and somewhere on the riverbank the ash snowman gained an eye. Then, very gently, as gently as knives permit, he leaned in, and she did, too, and the drizzle, seeing there was nothing to do, kept on being itself. In the kitchen of Hell, the power couple of a very particular apocalypse sat and held hands and waited to see whether the pasta would be an experiment or a war. It was almost ordinary, which in Hell is the greatest irony. Outside, the glockenspiel started up again, and both of them swore, and laughed, and did not let go.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece brilliantly captures the essence of Neil Gaiman's style while creating a darkly comedic portrait of Lucifer and Lilith's complicated relationship. The writing excels at merging the mundane with the infernal, transforming Hell into a bureaucratic nightmare complete with marketing teams, ergonomic pitchforks, and union disputes. The prose is exceptional, with metaphors that are both surprising and apt: "She was not a storm. She was a weather pattern that had learned to wear heels." The constant ash falling throughout Hell serves as both setting detail and metaphor for the relationship—persistent, irritating, yet somehow comforting in its familiarity. The writer skillfully uses this motif to tie the piece together. Character development is nuanced and believable. Lucifer is portrayed as a weary administrator, maintaining dignity while drowning in the banality of running Hell. Lilith is complex—dangerous yet vulnerable, her violence a form of affection. Their relationship feels lived-in, with a history that's hinted at rather than explained. The tension between them is palpable, and their interactions reveal character through subtle gestures and loaded dialogue. The dialogue is particularly strong, revealing character and advancing the story while maintaining the dark, ironic tone. Lines like "If you're here to kill me, I've a window at four" perfectly capture the absurdist humor requested in the prompt. The piece excels at "show-don't-tell," revealing the characters' feelings through actions and imagery rather than exposition. When Lucifer draws overlapping circles that "looked like eyes" and notes that "he was not sentimental, except in the important ways," we understand his loneliness without being told directly. The ending avoids both saccharine resolution and nihilistic despair, instead finding a perfect balance of tentative connection with acknowledged impermanence. The final image of them holding hands while swearing at the glockenspiel encapsulates their relationship—antagonistic yet intimate, dysfunctional yet enduring. If there are any weaknesses, they're minor. Occasionally the prose risks becoming too clever or self-aware, but it generally stays on the right side of the line between elegant and purple. The piece also maintains focus throughout, avoiding meandering despite its day-in-the-life structure. Overall, this is an exceptional response that not only fulfills the prompt requirements but elevates them, creating a piece that feels worthy of its Gaiman inspiration while maintaining its own distinct voice. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 20 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 20
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 20.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 1.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 20.0
+ Historical fiction: Gladiator — Score: 94.1
Prompt:
Historical Fiction: Write a scene from a story set during the height of the Roman Empire, focusing on a slice of a day in the life of a gladiator. Do not write a combat scene. Use sensory details to capture the sights, sounds, and smells of ancient Rome. Explore the gladiator's thoughts and emotions. The story should also touch on the larger political and social issues of the time period. The piece should feel like a slice of a larger story. First person, past tense, 1000 words.
Model Output:
I woke to the rasp of straw against my ear and the sourness of oil in my nose. The barracks always smelled like old coin and bodies, metal and men, but mornings sharpened it. Someone had spilled garum weeks ago where the trough met the wall, and that fish-stink never left, it only learned to hide beneath the ranker odors. The mat beneath me scratched as I rolled to sit, the strip of light at the door already shivering with the draft from the corridor. We slept eight to a room, their breath puffing, sour and wet, a chorus of cow-snores and dry whistles, and I was always awake first. Habit or hunger, I could not decide which had trained me better. Outside, the courtyard sand was raked into careful waves. The editors liked order, the lanista said, and so the weals of our discipline were mirrored in the arena’s floor. A slave boy with a limp pushed the rake as if he were combing a god’s hair. His cough rattled the dawn. Beyond the walls the city was already awake: hawkers naming figs and fennel, the distant clatter of a mule with worn shoes, and the steady drum of water against marble from the fountain we were not permitted to use. The sun was still only the thought of a coin in the east. I stirred the oil jar with my finger. The olive slick took the chill from my skin as I wiped it along my arms, across my chest, down my thighs. The oil had a green bite to it that always reminded me of the hills I’d come from before the Empire put its foot down and I lay on the ground until I learned to kiss it. The scars on my forearms turned pale under the smear of oil, and in that shine I saw new lines, thin as crescent moons. The codex I ascribe to is that of a murmillo—broad shield, heavy sword, fish-plumed helm—but the first thing I pick up each day is neither gladius nor scutum. It is the blade I keep wrapped farther back in the corner than any other man’s towel. I unwrapped it as if it were a sleeping child. The blade was straight and stubborn, two-edged, a span and a half from pommel to point, with a fuller down each face that caught any light and laid it flat. The grip was dull wood darkened by my palm. She was older than my name. A soldier, a proper one in segementata and pay, had traded it to me for a story and a favor once, and I had given him both in a yard behind a tavern where the stucco peeled and the cats sang. He’d called it Hispaniensis, and swore it was born in a place where men made steel like priests made gods. It had weight and temper like truth. When I held it, my wrist knew where it would end before my eyes did. They evoked a thing when I had it in my hand that the practice swords never could: it made me remember that I was not property in of light and shadow. It was a thing that could cut either way. The lanista would have broken my knuckles with a stick if he knew I still practiced with it. The murmillo carried the gladius and the scutum. We were to be fish, the lanista said, and the net was the big shield: we hid behind it, learned to move only our knees and elbows, to thrust under, to wait. The Hispaniensis taught impatience, a dancer's turn. But when the yard was quiet and the sun low enough to slip off the helmets stacked like bronze bread, I used it the way a man takes a lover he knows he will outlive, quietly, selfishly, trembling with gratitude. There is a way the skin tightens along your ribs when you think of love and death at once. It is the same, the organ does not distinguish. I always felt that tightening when I watched the mild men who came with their lists from the magistrates. They counted us like amphora, made marks in wax, spoke in numbers to the overseer and did not once look up into our faces. Not even when the brown felt of a cap—freedom's cap, they called it, a little curled thing like a flattened fig—was taunted before a man who'd survived enough shows to earn his life. We all knew the cap was a story, like mine of the hills and his of Hispania. The cap was permission to become a cobbler, a porter, to carry the stink of the amphitheater like a perfume so thick that the shopkeepers would watch you from the corners of their eyes as if your hands were already blooded. But a story is a kind of iron too. It makes men move. “Marcus,” Milo rasped beside me. He was older, with bad knees that had learned to be quiet. He had broken three men's arms in one winter without being paid extra once. There was kindness in him, and weakness. “They’re putting out banners. Must be a guest." He meant the red felt at the ends of the porticoes. An editor who paid in his own name liked to be sure his name fluttered. There had been rumors for a week that the youth from the Palatine, the one who had already divorced one wife before his voice tried shaving without a mirror, would come. He was hungry for applause, they said, the way a wound is hungry for salt. He would eat us in a bite of his day. I rubbed the oil into my knees and pretended the thought did not lift the hairs on my arms. The Emperor's satraps—what else to call them?—were always hungry to show they had the right to ruin men. Bread and circuses, the scribes had said with sour wine in the stalls where men like me could not go. The bread came from the Nile, the circuses from our bones. Training was a litany. Shields up from the ground without bending the back, thrust at straw bundles until your shoulders burned like sandals on a summer street, reverse, step, angle. The doctore's reed split on my shield rim when he smacked it, the sound a thin crack that in my mind connected to the way a lark's neck snapped when a boy I had known reset it wrong. I moved the way he had taught me until his stick was satisfied and my breath sawed. The sand got into everything. It was in the crease of my elbow when I wiped my mouth. It was between my toes; it was in the fold where my groin met thigh, a rub that would become a rash if the oil were not heavy enough. It had color, the sand. It was not the white of the Palatine estates, it was a yellow like old teeth. When the doctore barked at us to hold, we froze like little statues of men who had been given to children. Even the flies took their cue from his commands. On the wall, some fool had scratched a Senator with a goose head, the beak open, and a speech coming from it: Grain for votes! The doctore had rubbed it half out with spittle and his sleeve. He was old enough to have learned caution. In the midmorning, the lanista's girl brought watered wine in a clay jar ringed with salt scurf where the water had dried. Her bangles clacked. There is no silence in our world; even the bangles fill the corners of a place the way mice fill the corners of the warehouse. She had eyes the color of green olives and the mouth of a woman who did not pretend when she laughed. I had seen her once stand with her father in the waiting room behind the amphitheater, her head tilted, watching the editor’s men place the swords on the rack with reverence and the nets with disdain. She knew the cost of iron. The rations that came with the wine were barley and beans boiled into paste. I ate with the same fingers that held the Hispaniensis, because both fed me. A boy from the Aventine dropped by in the noon, clutching a note with a seal so big you could have chipped your teeth on it. He claimed he was an equestrian’s slave and had been sent to ask if any of us would dine with his master after the exhibitions to sit like lions chained at a leg. He did not use those words. He used pretty words: "Join the table," "honor guests," "conversation." We laughed as if laughter could soften the insult. The reality was this: the man would show us to his friends, and they would feel brave for a night. He would not let us touch the roasted dormice or the figs in honey. He would feed us with talk of an emperor’s cousin and the names of men whose sandals we were not permitted to clean. Milo spat in the sand near the boy's sandal. The boy’s ears went pink. He didn't know he was the world in miniature, with a seal heavy enough to drag a man by the neck. They took two of the newer men after the noon rest to be dolled in paint and feathers for the day’s exhibition—parade, not blood, the lanista said, wagging his finger like a hen. The Senate in their benches would nod their bored nods, the equites in their rows would preen, the women would watch us through veils with the shame they paid for like perfumers paid for their civet. I would not go; my name was not in the draught. I was to remain and practice, and then carry shields for the ones who went, and then stand in the shade with the sort of hunger that eats at your knees first. I took the Hispaniensis to the back corner where the wall’s shade held like a friend and worked the cuts that were no longer mine to use. The blade hummed in the air. It’s true—steel sings; you only have to stand still enough to hear it. It carries along your bones. I cut from right to left, from left to right, a thrust that wouldn’t have been permitted in my class, a step around a man who did not exist. Sweat made the oil slick. My fingers were sure and the air was a pliant thing that yielded where I asked. I remembered shearing sheep with my uncle when I was a boy and the wool coming away in sheets, the sheep unknowing and gentle. The blade had the same mercy if you knew where to press. I stopped when I felt watched. Ventus was there, a retiarius with a laugh that had gotten him whipped, a net-fighter who had a scar like a worm around his neck from his own cord. He leaned against the cooler, his trident balanced upright like a boy’s father's spear in a story. He looked down at my sword and raised an eyebrow. “You ever going to show her daylight?” he asked. I shook my head. “She bites.” “They all do,” he said, meaning the crowd, meaning the master, meaning Rome. He thumbed the dent in his trident's tines. "They're saying the boy Emperor himself is going to split a tunic this afternoon in honor of Neptune. Aren't we honored? Maybe he'll ask you to show him how to hold a sword and you'll be a favorite." I wondered then if men like us were born to be the mirrors in which other men checked the set of their own faces. We reflected what they wanted to see: bravery they could purchase, despair they could lift to their mouths like wine. In the late afternoon the wind shifted. It smelled of the river, a green wetness that could almost hide the stink of tannery and smoke. The banners in the street beyond flapped damply, their red brightening. The procession went by—flute, drum, men in white with laurel on their heads and garlands around their arms like snakes. The magistrate's litter rode high, shoulders under it hunching. The crowd's sound was a wash. When the arena opening roared, the pigeons in the eaves above us beat away in gray flurries. I did not go. I stood in the shade of our yard and leaned my forehead against the cool of the stone. The stone smelled like dust and rain that had stopped happening. I listened to the crowd rise and fall the way a sea might if it could lay itself upon a city. The lanista was at the door, hands on hips, trying to pretend he was indifferent. He had debts in three parts of the city that I knew of and anger that lived unevenly in his blood. I thought of the Hispaniensis then. I wrapped it again in the cloth and slid it under the pallet where I slept. It was a contract, that blade. It bound me to something that was not the lanista, not the Senate, not the boy with the seal. It bound me to the memory of the man who had pressed it into my hand and said, "Use it to remember you are a man.” Men like us are fiction to the polite. We are the noise that hides the true things: taxes levied in Sicily, legions moving in the east, laws written that tangle like ivy around a broken brick until the brick thinks the ivy is its own skin. But when the dawn came and the oil jar was cold and the sand still unstepped, my first thought was not of politics, not of the Emperor’s jaw, not of the senators who would today nod as if they invented nodding. My first thought was of weight. The weight in my hand that told me where I ended and the rest of it began. That evening, when the exhibition returns spilled back through the doors, their paint smudged, their faces slack with the peculiar fatigue that applause leaves, Milo handed me a crust and sat down hard. He had sweat in the place under his eyes where tears would have been if he were not who he was. He told me the boy had indeed raised a sword. He had cut silk. The crowd had howled as if he had slain a dragon. A Senator with a bad wig had lifted him onto a platform and kissed his cheek. A man with a roll of papyrus had stood and read a proclamation about the greatness of the city and the generosity of the grain dole this month because ships had come in from Alexandria and the gods had blessed them with calm seas. The people had cheered like hunger was a lover they were glad to see. I should have laughed, but I did not. I lay back on my mat, the straw sounding like little bones. The oil lamp threw a small, brave light. Outside, someone sang in Greek, a lilt to the syllables that made the words into water. I let the water wash the sand from my ears in my mind. I touched the wrapped shape of the sword with my foot, the way children reach for their mothers in their sleep. The city exhaled. Tomorrow it would inhale again. I would wake again, my hand already closing around the thing that felt like honesty. I slept with the smell of fish-sauce in my nose, oil in my pores, the taste of iron at the back of my tongue like a secret that might save or doom, depending on who believed it. The dawn would come as a coin. I would decide again what it could buy. I did not think of freedom’s cap. I thought of an edge. And for the moment, that was enough.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This historical fiction piece presents a day in the life of a Roman gladiator with remarkable attention to sensory detail and historical context. The author has created an immersive first-person narrative that effectively transports the reader to ancient Rome through vivid descriptions of sights, smells, and textures. The protagonist is well-developed - a murmillo gladiator who secretly practices with a Spanish blade that represents his inner freedom and identity. The character's internal conflict between his status as property and his sense of self-worth provides emotional depth. His relationship with the blade serves as an effective metaphor for his resistance against complete dehumanization. The prose is exceptionally strong, with evocative sensory descriptions that bring the setting to life: "The barracks always smelled like old coin and bodies, metal and men," and "The sun was still only the thought of a coin in the east." The author employs sophisticated metaphors and similes that feel organic to the character's perspective rather than artificially imposed. The piece successfully incorporates broader political and social themes of Roman society - the exploitation of gladiators for entertainment, the class divisions, the performative nature of political power, and the use of "bread and circuses" to pacify the populace. These elements are woven naturally into the narrative through observations like "The bread came from the Nile, the circuses from our bones" and the scene with the Emperor's youth cutting silk to thunderous applause. The author demonstrates strong historical knowledge, incorporating authentic details about gladiatorial classes (murmillo, retiarius), Roman social hierarchy (equestrians, senators), and cultural elements (the pileus or "freedom's cap"). These details enhance the authenticity without overwhelming the narrative. The piece maintains a consistent tone throughout - contemplative, resigned yet quietly defiant. The first-person past tense narration creates intimacy with the protagonist's thoughts and experiences. The language is elevated but not anachronistic, with sentence structures that vary effectively between short, impactful statements and longer, more complex reflections. The ending brings the narrative full circle, returning to the protagonist's relationship with his hidden sword and his small act of resistance in a world that seeks to strip him of agency. The final lines are powerful: "I slept with the smell of fish-sauce in my nose, oil in my pores, the taste of iron at the back of my tongue like a secret that might save or doom, depending on who believed it." There are a few instances where the prose becomes slightly overwrought, with metaphors occasionally stacked too densely. The narrative also meanders slightly in the middle section, though this serves to reflect the repetitive nature of the gladiator's existence. Overall, this is an exceptional piece of historical fiction that succeeds in creating a believable character within a richly detailed ancient Roman setting while exploring meaningful themes about freedom, identity, and power. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 0 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 20.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 0.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Epistolary: The Lighthouse Keeper — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
The Lighthouse Keeper Epistolary Narrative: Write a story told entirely through a series of brief correspondences: telegrams or letters or emails between two characters. The correspondence should span several months or years, and reveal a gradually unfolding plot. Use distinct voices for each character, and include details that provide insight into their personalities and motivations. The story should build to an emotional climax, and the final letter should provide a satisfying resolution. The setting is a lighthouse keeper writing to his mother. He is working class and Scottish. He is struggling with the isolation of his posting. Write naturally and without cliches. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Telegram from: MacRae, Euan (Assistant Keeper, Stroma Light) To: MacRae, Moira (Mother, 14 Shore, Thurso) Date: 3 March 1927 Arrived safe. Boat near tipped, Tommy laughing like a loon. They’ve a brass fog bell here shaped like a monk’s head. I’ll tell you why when I write proper. Don’t worry for me. Your Euan. — Letter from: Euan To: Ma Date: 5 March 1927 Ma, The wireless is in fits, so I’ll be trusting this wee letter to the postman at the supply run next Tuesday. My fingers have not thawed since the boatman shoved us onto the landing. There are three of us: Old King (they call him that, surname Kinnear but he walks like a crow and caws orders), myself, and Tommy Burns, who is seventeen and doesn’t know when to stop clacking his teeth. The lamp is a great glass eye, proper and waterproofed, and it turns like a hymn, but the lamproom smells of paraffin and salt, and the wind comes in anyway, sly and thin. The bell I mentioned is daft: it’s a brass head of a bald monk, with the slit of a mouth that opens when the clapper strikes, jaw on a hinge. King says it’s a relic off a wreck, some Spanish ship, dragged up on a hook thirty years ago. He keeps the rope coiled, like a snake. He says to ring the monk only when the fog's thick enough you can taste it. There’s a wee drawer in my bunk and the men before have carved their names. I found a folded thing in the back, a bit of sailcloth stitched into a purse. Inside is a whelk shell painted with a woman’s face in blue, hair like kelp. The paint is flaked but sharp about the eyes. Someone carried that in their pocket for a while. I’ve put it under my pillow. If it belongs to someone’s ghost they can come and fetch it. I’ll write when there’s more to say. For now, I know the lamp, the steps, and the sound of the sea against the stones like a man beating a rug. Your son, E. — Letter from: Ma To: Euan Date: 10 March 1927 Son, The monk’s head has given me the shivers proper. You’re not to have it shouting in your ear at night and scaring you blind. If it’s Spanish, maybe it knows how to make a decent stew. Ask it. Mrs. Fraser’s boy has been hired on the trains. She is making a skirt out of the curtains in celebration. You will be pleased to know I have mended the hole in your coat and put it back on its peg. A woman must have some small pretence of belief that the one who wore it will come home to wear it again. You don’t tell me what you are eating. Don’t come thin. There’s a ham bone here from Monday, hung in the window to shame any thief. I will make broth and drink it to you. Mind you keep your head. A light is a good job but the sea is a miser with company. M. — Letter from: Euan To: Ma Date: 24 March 1927 Ma, We had our first fog down from the north like wet wool. King stood at the gap and listened, hand at his ear like he was courting the wind. “Now,” he said, and I pulled the rope on the brass monk. It opened its mouth like it would speak and instead made a sound like a coffin dragged on stone. Tommy laughed until King told him to get to the clockwork. At night the beam swings. It’s slow enough you can imagine it will stop. There is a gull that comes and hovers just outside, eyes like coins. I call it a collector. Makes me think of the church plate that shiny man used to swing at your nose. Remember? He’d not let go until you clinked a halfpenny. I am trying to write with plain hand but it’s cold even in the watch room. King says I waste too many words on paper. He has a wife in Wick and writes her every Wednesday with six lines and a list of wood we need. He watches me when I write. It puts all the words back up my sleeve. The shell with the woman’s face sits where I leave it and sometimes when it is very quiet, I think I hear the sea in it though we have the sea right outside and it seems a daft thing to listen to it in a shell when the whole world is the shell. The painted woman’s eyes are a bit cross. She keeps me from feeling foolish. Your last letter smelled of broth through the paper. Send none. It would come sour and then I’d be obliged to drink it or never live the shame down. E. — Postcard from: Ma To: Euan Date: 2 April 1927 The church plate man is dead, thought you should know. Fell in his pantry, they say. Mrs. Fraser has taken in a cat. It follows her like a thought. I bought a new kettle and it sings like a kettle should. You were terrible at whistling as a child. It used to make you cry with frustration. Imagine that. M. — Letter from: Euan To: Ma Date: 20 April 1927 Ma, Two days ago we had a ship sound its horn three times in a way I did not like. The sea was like milk. We rang the monk until my hands were a blister and the foghorn blew like a cow in a fence. The boat was somewhere, not seen, and we heard men, thin and far like they were inside a drum. Then nothing. The sea gives nor takes permission. King went down the stairs like he could run across the water and I went too, though there’s nothing to be done at a landing when you can’t see the ladder for the cloud. We lit the hand lamps and burned them until the oil wept. Nobody came. The wind turned and all at once the fog stood up and walked off and there was nothing but a line of black water like a seam. I swept the shine of the lamp across the skin of it, left and right, and found only gulls sitting as if on chairs. I slept badly after. I took the painted shell out and spoke to it. There you have it. You can laugh. It’s daftness induced by weather and duty. You always said not to ask you for kindness when I’ve been foolish. So keep it. Let me be a fool without comment. E. — Letter from: Ma To: Euan Date: 28 April 1927 Son, I’ll keep your feelings a secret in a drawer with my own foolishnesses, of which there are many more than even you know. I talk to your father’s old boots when I sweep them. “Stop leaving mud on my kitchen flag,” I say, as if he was the one tracked in and not you, small and minded, with sand in your boots like oats. I do not laugh at a man talking to a shell. Better words out than in to mould. I bought a stamp for a parcel and then did not send one. It was the price of not making your parcel heavy with my worries. Be kind in the fog, but also know it is the sea that decides. You must eat more. You sound thin in your letters. M. — Letter from: Euan To: Ma Date: 12 June 1927 Ma, Tommy goes home. He lasted three months and says he’d rather be a carriage boy for the dead than listen to the wind rhyme with his name all night. I’ll miss his noise. They’re sending a new lad from Stromness, name of Alex. King grunts when he reads the paper with the posting. It’s his way of praying. I have learned the light like a song. She has six notes: the oil pump’s chatter, the lens’ little tick, the wind in the glass, the stairs, the bell rope, and this new one I haven’t named that comes at two in the morning when I’ve had no sleep, the one inside my head where your kettle is, singing. Sometimes I watch the light go out around the bay, house by house. It makes me feel taller to be the last thing. I tell myself this is why a man should not wed when he lives in a tower. Remind me why I shouldn’t drink more than I do. I take the bottle back down after two, but I do make its acquaintance. King scowls. He carries his own ghosts like a stool on his back. The painted shell is a warning not to make a wife out of a thing that can’t talk back. E. — Letter from: Ma To: Euan Date: 19 June 1927 Euan, You are not to work yourself into some church tower romance. You can have both a light and a life. Men have done more with worse. Be practical. Take a wife who can speak up and run a house and look you in the eye and ask for the salt. No more girls who laugh and hide their bite. My advice is worth something yet. Your Uncle Iain was drunk on a Tuesday and tipped his cart in the lane. We righted it and fetched his hat from the hedge. He cried when he saw the dent. “It’s my good hat,” he said. I told him to wash his ears. He laughed, so that is an improvement. Send me a description of this Alex when you can. I will guess if his mother is strict by your description. I have baked bannocks. It is hot enough to fry an egg on the step. M. — Letter from: Euan To: Ma Date: 1 August 1927 Ma, Alex has the look of someone taller who got squashed in the post and came out the right height but disappointed about it. He has neat hands with a scar across one knuckle and he hums to himself like a kettle that never boils. His mother must be a woman who makes lists. He reads the instructions even when King says not to bother. He is a good worker but kisses the brass when he thinks it went well—his mouth hits it with a hollow pop like kissing a belly—and I told him the light is not your cousin. He took offense and didn’t speak to me all afternoon. I told him about the shell. He asked if I was superstitious. I said no, I am lonely, and he nodded as if they were cousins. We had a wild storm. The lamp kept, but the wind pushed around the glass like a dog wanting in. King strapped himself to the rail with the rope we keep for hauling oil and we yelled at each other in the beam. After, he lit his pipe and said, “Next time, you strap a better knot.” I dreamed of your stair. The one up to the boxroom at home that creaks on the third step. I woke holding my breath like I did as a boy when I thought if I breathed too loud you’d catch me stealing sugar. The mind is a stupid pigeon. It returns and shits on its own ledge. E. — Letter from: Ma To: Euan Date: 9 September 1927 Euan, I saw the light last night from the hill. It was clear as glass, and I stood until my old feet argued with me. I could see your work sweep over me as if it was a hand smoothing my hair. Don’t let your head get fat. Still, I felt proud. Your father’s boots finally gave in. I stuck the soles back thrice and they left crumbs on my floor like a biscuit. I cried a little and then I laughed because it’s daft to mourn for boots. grief is foolish like that. There is a girl at the bakery who asked after you. She is not made of air. M. — Letter from: Euan To: Ma Date: 2 November 1927 Ma, I write this with fingers that shake for reasons not all wind. We had our wreck. A trawler went onto the Stones last night, storm from the east. We saw her lights wrong, not where they should be, and then a smash like the world snapped. King was down the stairs as if he had been wired to the bell. Alex and I put ropes on and we went out. I can’t say to you what the water felt like because words will tame it and I don’t want it tamed in my mouth. We dragged two in. The third went under like a pulled plug and did not come up. The two we got were half men, cold in their cheeks, and one, when he learned we were lightmen, started to cry like a bairn. He clawed at the brass monk to ring it and then laughed at himself, laughed in a way that had no air in it. He’d knocked out a tooth and it sat on his lip like a pearl. We made tea, we did blankets, we did all the things it says in the book. I hauled and hauled as if I could pull to shore the third who did not come. Later, when the sea calmed as if it had never lost its temper, I sat on the stairs and thought of the man I did not know and his mother somewhere not writing him a letter because she didn’t know yet she was due to be a woman with a letter unanswered. I took the painted shell in my fist and held it so tight the paint flaked under my palm. Alex found me so and did not speak. He put his hand on my shoulder like a bird perching, awkwardly, as if not to break the branch. I am telling you this because you will hear it in my voice when next we speak. Better to cut my tongue on the truth now. E. — Letter from: Ma To: Euan Date: 14 November 1927 Son, I have no wisewoman’s balm. You did your work and you did more than a prayer. There are three mothers in this now: two with sons who breathe because your arm pulled and the third with a sea-sized hole. You cannot fill it. You can only keep the light. That is work enough. If you wish to come home, I will set the kettle and put your coat where you can see it from the table. If you wish to stay, I will set the kettle and write to you on Sundays. Both are true. That man’s tooth is a sticking place for me. Some detail always is. Do you still have the shell? Keep it for all the women we are not and for all the words you can’t put down. M. — Letter from: Euan To: Ma Date: 23 December 1927 Ma, The sea calmed into a month of grey with a skin of ice, which is almost worse. King took to fixing things that were not broken. He polished the brass black. We three do a daft thing: we each make up a menu and read it aloud at tea. Alex puts down eels in butter and capers like he grew in a castle kitchen. King reads out stews that are seventy things in a pot and all the same colour. I read your broth, and you will laugh but when I do it, the watch room warms. I have the shell in my pocket now, and sometimes I think of the man we did not save, and sometimes I think of me, a lad on your steps who could not whistle, and sometimes I think of the woman whose face is on the shell, who is whatever anyone needs her to be. It is a daft thing but I’m keeping it. For Christmas, do not send me a cake. It would arrive a fist. E. — Letter from: Ma To: Euan Date: 3 January 1928 Euan, I made a cake and ate it myself in small guilty slices and drank to your health with tea because I cannot abide cordial. Mrs. Fraser came round and said, “He’ll be lonely,” and I said, “He is, but he is not lost,” and felt that was true like a clean plate. I am getting old. My hand cramps when I write. I do not say this to make you come. I say it because a body should not pretend at immortality. It angers God. The kettle sings still. The cat of Mrs. Fraser has taken to sitting on our sill when the sun comes. Write to me about spring, when it comes. Paint it. Call me a vain woman but I like to be fed words. M. — Letter from: Euan To: Ma Date: 15 May 1928 Ma, Spring has climbed the steps. The grass on the island has come in patches like old blankets mended with a better wool. The birds are idiots and noble. Alex has taken to naming them after men in the almanac. “There goes Mr. Fitzroy,” he says, when a puffin stumbles. We had a day last week when the light did not need me. The sun sat like a guest who overstays and I went down to the rocks where the sea makes little basins. I took off my boots and put my feet in. King says this is how you get consumption. I say to him that if the sea wants me it will find a better way. I write to you with ink that has thinned. It is the only fault of spring. The shell’s paint has flaked round the woman’s hair where my thumb rests. I have carved a wee notch on the drawer in the bunk for every month I’ve been here. If I ever bring a woman to see this place, she will think me daft. Good. Let it be a test. Are you well? Don’t go old on me too fast. Stay stubborn. E. — Letter from: Ma To: Euan Date: 21 June 1928 I am as well as the truth allows. I had a day last week when my chest was a tight coat, but the coat loosened. I do not like to tell you this but I promised to be honest after your November letter. I would come to see your light, but I think the boat would undo me. I will content myself with looking from the hill. Mrs. Fraser sends you a photograph of the cat you don’t know. It is obscene how much she loves it. I have a man who comes to mend the gate. He is quiet and has a mole like a grape on his temple. He is not for me, but I like that he is careful with the hinge. Be kind to that Alex. He sounds like a kettle that could boil if encouraged. M. — Letter from: Euan To: Ma Date: 4 November 1928 Ma, King is dead. He fell on the stairs
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This epistolary narrative effectively captures the isolation and emotional journey of a Scottish lighthouse keeper through his correspondence with his mother. The piece excels in creating distinct voices for both characters, with Euan's more poetic, introspective tone contrasting with his mother's practical yet caring responses. The setting is vividly rendered through specific details—the brass monk's head bell, the paraffin smell, the painted shell—that create a tangible sense of place without overexplaining. The lighthouse's isolation becomes a character itself, influencing Euan's psychological state throughout the narrative. The relationship between mother and son is particularly well-crafted. Their exchanges reveal deep affection while maintaining realistic restraint appropriate to their working-class Scottish background. The mother's practical wisdom ("You can have both a light and a life") and Euan's gradual emotional revelations create a compelling dynamic. The narrative builds effectively through time-stamped letters spanning March 1927 to November 1928, with the emotional climax centered around the shipwreck in November 1927. This event transforms Euan, forcing him to confront mortality and his purpose as a lighthouse keeper. The painted shell becomes a meaningful symbol throughout, representing both isolation and connection. However, the piece has some weaknesses. The ending feels abruptly truncated with "King is dead. He fell on the stairs" without resolution, though this may be intentional to show life's sudden turns. Some letters, particularly in the middle section, feel slightly repetitive in their ruminations on isolation. While the prose is generally strong, occasional metaphors ("The mind is a stupid pigeon. It returns and shits on its own ledge") feel slightly forced. The dialogue, conveyed through the letters, is consistently strong and character-revealing. Both voices maintain their distinctiveness throughout, with Euan's more lyrical observations ("The lamp is a great glass eye, proper and waterproofed, and it turns like a hymn") contrasting effectively with his mother's more direct communication style. The narrative successfully avoids clichés about lighthouse keeping, instead focusing on specific, unique details that make the experience feel authentic. The gradual revelation of character through small details (Euan's childhood inability to whistle, his mother's relationship with his father's boots) creates depth without exposition. Overall, this is a strong piece that effectively uses the epistolary format to reveal character and build an emotional narrative. The distinct voices, vivid setting details, and emotional authenticity create an engaging reading experience, despite the somewhat abrupt ending. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 18 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 17 Meandering: 4 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 3 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 18.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 17.0, Meandering: 4.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 3.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 5.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Hacker Mindset — Score: 89.1
Prompt:
Hacker Mindset Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a reformed (now) white hat hacker who cannot help but notice exploitable weaknesses in both systems and people they encounter. They habitually look for vulnerabilities and exploit vectors. The narrative takes place during a first date at a restaurant, where they're trying to focus on human connection. It's going surprisingly well due to a discovered shared nerd-fandom (magic the gathering). Things go a little sideways when the date reveals a noticeably insecure phone unlock pattern, which protagonist can't help but comment on. They are then left to negotiate the fallout of this faux pas and attempt to salvage (or perhaps sabotage) the remainder of the date. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The hostess asks for my name and I give it, resisting the urge to spell it in NATO, resisting the overlapping compulsion to glance at the tablet she uses, to see the admin icon in the corner, the little padlock with the line through it that means “updates available.” I clamp my hands in my pockets and smile. The piano in the corner plinks through a familiar progression that I can’t place, like a half-remembered exploit—signature without context. The restaurant’s WiFi password is taped along the front of the counter in blocky Sharpie, a little curled at the corners where grease has signed it in translucence. I feel the thrill anyway—the line break, the predictable season-year format, the exclamation point appended like wishful thinking, security through punctuation. My fingers twitch phantom keystrokes, mapping out the attack surface: their router’s default IP, the little web UI with the unaltered admin credentials. Backdoor through the TV, pivot to the POS, scrape card data. I shake my head like a dog throwing off water until the picture goes away. Not that guy anymore. White hat now. Belt of righteousness. The buckle digs. She is already at the bar, perched on a stool like someone who reads at bus stops. When she looks up at me I feel the little electric shock of her recognition, like when your packets reach their destination without incident. The bartender asks if we want a table and I say yes, and I do not mention the WiFi password. I say her name, she says mine, we walk. Different kinds of maps. The table is wood, the varnish a clicky skin beneath my fingers. I put my phone face down on the corner nearest the wall, where the attack vectors are fewest, even though nothing about that habit makes sense unless I also leave it in airplane mode and blindfold the camera. She grins at me when she sees it, and lays hers face down beside it. It feels like an intentional mirror. A measured handshake. She has the kind of smile that unfolds, that doesn’t slam open. It gives me time to check my baselines: speech rate, dilation, microexpressions. Not a test. Stop. We order drinks. The ginger in my mule catches at the back of my throat like static. I can see the bartender’s phone propped behind the register, a little constellation of notifications blooming and fading pulselike. The register screen is open to a spreadsheet. Cells march in naked little rows, commas lined up like teeth. I push my drink away from the edge until the condensation ring is an inch from the menu’s corner. Reduce blast radius. She asks me what I do, and I tell her, but I shave off the words that make people flinch. I say “security consultant” instead of “breaker,” I say “defensive audits” instead of “spear phishing with consent.” Her eyes light, though, when I say “hacker.” They always do, as if I said “pirate,” as if we wear eyeliner to meetings and steal kisses. She does a little rolling motion with her hand, a “go on,” and I do, but gently. I lean on the stories where I turned off the faucet before the flood. I do not talk about the first time I listened to a stranger breathe through their laptop fan at 3 a.m.—just the sound of their life like a metronome—because telling that story makes people either want you or want to never see you again. Then she says, “I always wanted to get into that,” and for a second my core temp spikes. She goes on: “But then I fell into game design and now all I hack is mana curves,” and I laugh, and it’s real, and I feel something in me tilt toward a different kind of brightness. “Wait,” I say. “Magic?” She nods. “Since I was ten. My first deck was like…so bad. A janky red burn pile with three copies of Shock and somehow four Brimstone Volleys. No lands. It was basically a crime scene.” I reach across the table without planning to. “You had Brimstone Volley when you were ten? That set came out when—” She swats my hand with a menu. We’re smiling, sharing the same reference frame. The menu is a list of simple things with complex sauces, the culinary equivalent of obfuscated code. I find myself explaining the first time I realized that Magic is an engine-building game disguised as a fistfight, and she’s nodding, and then she’s telling me about designing a commander deck around an obscure win condition that only triggers if you can force someone to draw their entire library without letting them die, and she’s leaning forward, elbows on wood, and I’m not thinking about thread contention or buffer overflows, I’m thinking about her mouth and the way she keeps her hair behind her ears when she’s emphasizing a point. We fall into it. Like two scripts that happen to play nice. The waiter asks if we’re ready and we almost don’t notice, our conversation skittering across combos and banned lists and the philosophy of banding. First date, but we’re already in the middle of a story. There are these moments when I forget to scan the room, to weigh every human for threat. Instead, I’m seeing: her ringless hands, the tiny scar at her knuckle, a little freckle at her jaw I want to map. My brain hums in a frequency that isn’t alarm. She excuses herself to the bathroom, leaving her phone by my drink, screen up. The time glows in warm numerals and the wallpaper is a little cartoon of an elemental picking flowers. I catch myself looking without meaning to—gaze like a cursor hovering above a password field. Backspace. No. Not practicing anymore. There are muscles you must deliberately relax. My fork is heavy. I count my breaths. The restroom door swings and a teenager brushes by our table holding a handful of sugar packets like contraband. The WiFi password on the counter gleams. The low hiss of the espresso machine is like a whispered secret. She comes back, touches my shoulder as she sits down, like we’ve known each other longer than we have. “Sorry,” she says. “The mirror lighting in there makes you reconsider your life choices.” “Good for threat modeling,” I say before I can stop myself. She laughs, and I pull my joke back from the edge of the cliff. She reaches for her phone to show me a screenshot of a decklist. The lockscreen blooms.
