She draws her finger across the nine-dot grid in a movement that I map in three dimensions without meaning to, the way you map the steps to your old front door even after you move. Bottom-left to top-left to top-right to bottom-right, back to center, up one. My brain solves it like a reflex. The pattern forms a skewed alphabetical letter. Of course it does. People love letters. They’re easy to remember. Easy to steal. Don’t. Don’t say anything. Let the moment pass. She wants to show you a decklist, not negotiate your neuroses. Let it go. “It’s cute that your pattern is just an N.” I hear my own voice and it’s like when you hit enter by accident and the payload is away. Time slows the way it does in a breach: packets dripping, everyone’s eyes widening. Her hand freezes on the screen. She looks at me. Then down. Then back up. There is heat in my face that isn’t ginger anymore. “I shouldn’t have said that,” I say, immediately, which is like patching in production. “I’m sorry. That’s… it’s a habit. I notice patterns.” “I mean, it is an N,” she says, but her smile is tighter. A cartoon window slides down in my mind: access revoked. The table’s varnish squeaks under my thumb. “I’ve been trying to turn it off,” I say. “It doesn’t always feel like a choice.” She sets the phone down. The little elemental on her wallpaper seems to be smirking now. “You could also not… point it out,” she says. Soft, but sharpened. I nod. I count two beats. Don’t overexplain. Don’t stack logs on a fire. “You’re right. That was rude. I’m sorry.” There. Simple. Truthful. She breathes. The air remembers how to move. “Is it always like that? For you,” she says. “Do you look at people and see… attack surfaces?” The question is careful and not unkind, which is maybe worse. I could give her the quippy answer, make a joke about my own code. Instead I take a sip of my drink and let the bolt go straight into the ground. “Sometimes,” I say. “It’s like—my brain learned a way to look at the world that kept me employed and also kept me… separate. I’m better than I used to be. Tonight, with you, I forgot to check the mirrors for a while.” I look at her. “That’s rare.” The waiter arrives like a patch pushed at the right time, sets down our plates, smiles, retreats. The food is colorful. The steam lifts like a signal. She picks up her fork. Her shoulders relax back down into their sockets. “Okay,” she says. “I can live with that. I just don’t want to feel like a vulnerability scan.” “That’s fair,” I say. “If it helps, most of the time the worst vulnerabilities are the ones I find in myself.” She snorts. “Relatable.” A beat. She taps her phone, opens notes, shows me a two-thousand-word document labeled “Commander: Bad Ideas.” I grin. The edges of the moment smooth. We are back to the glassy surface, though I can still see the crack running under it. “In my defense,” I say carefully, “pattern locks are the literal worst.” I raise my eyebrows, testing. Her face flickers—you can almost see the progress bar. She sighs, then laughs. “Okay. Make your pitch.” I lean back, hands up like I’m going to keep them where she can see them. “Change it to something long. A passphrase. Something like ‘GoblinsNeverBlockButAlwaysWin.’ You know? And turn off the visible pattern. And maybe… don’t label it with your initial.” She rolls her eyes, but there’s a spark again. “I will not be bullied into safer living by someone who named his WiFi ‘FBI Surveillance Van’ in 2012.” “My current SSID is very responsible,” I say primly. “It’s ‘Owls.’ No one suspects owls.” She bites her lip to hide a smile. “Fine. I’ll think about it.” “Thank you,” I say. “I promise not to comment on your threat posture unless asked.” “Tempting,” she says, and the word sits between us like a coin waiting to be flipped. We eat. The food is better than I expected. The couple behind us is arguing in whispers about whose turn it is to go to their kid’s recital. The WiFi password glares at me like a dare. A man at the counter reads it aloud to his companion and I can feel my fists clench under the table, not because I want to exploit it, but because the world is a field of unplanted mines and I am wearing new shoes. She tells me about the first pre-release she went to alone, how she won her first round and forgot how to breathe, how a kid in a hoodie taught her to shuffle the way dealers do, bridging the cards in a waterfall. I tell her about the first time my mother asked me what I did and I lied and said “web design” because it sounded harmless. She tells me about her brother who thinks games are a waste of time until he wins. I tell her about the time I got caught by a thirteen-year-old running a Minecraft server more secure than a bank I’d audited. We are, for a while, just two people telling each other the micro-histories of ourselves. The noise floor rises and falls, and I can almost forget that every window has a latch that can be jimmied if the wood is old. When she goes to pay her half, she reaches for her phone again, and this time I look away. I stare hard at the salt shaker, at the way the crystals catch the light, at the water droplets making their own patterns on the lacquered wood. Self-control is a muscle and I want to be sore tomorrow. She returns, sits, looks at me with a warmth that feels like stepping out of a cold room into sun. “So,” she says. “Second date?” I feel it—both the pulse of happiness and the other pulse, lower, that says you do not get to keep nice things unless you build the right perimeter. I nod. “If I promise not to bring a rubber duck,” I say. She squints. “You absolutely have a rubber duck.” “Several,” I admit. She clinks her glass against mine. “Bring one. But not to test the restaurant’s network.” I let out a breath I didn’t know I’d been holding. “Deal.” On our way out, I glance at the counter one more time. The WiFi password is still there, still half-peeling, still inviting strangers to knock on the door. I slide my card into the little leather folder and sign with the same hand I use to type. The hostess says goodnight and I say it back and she smiles and her tablet bings and I do not glance at the screen. The piano shifts into a new key, the note striking true. Outside, the air is cool and unencrypted. She steps close enough that our arms brush, just once, a test. I look at her and not at the street cameras, not at the WiFi networks chiming hello from the buildings, not at the code cascading behind my eyelids. For a breath, a long one, I can hold two truths: there are holes everywhere, and also, sometimes, there is good faith. Sometimes you get to choose not to exploit. Sometimes you get to sit across from a person who says “second date?” and you say “yes,” and that is the only handshake you need.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the perspective of a reformed white hat hacker navigating a first date. The protagonist's internal monologue reveals their constant struggle between their hacker instincts and their desire for human connection. The writing excels at creating a distinctive voice that blends technical terminology with emotional vulnerability. The protagonist's tendency to see the world through the lens of security vulnerabilities is consistently portrayed through metaphors and observations that feel authentic to someone with this background. Phrases like "security through punctuation," "packets reach their destination without incident," and "patching in production" effectively establish the character's worldview. The narrative follows the prompt's requirements closely, depicting the date going well due to a shared interest in Magic: The Gathering, then hitting a snag when the protagonist comments on the date's phone unlock pattern. The fallout and attempt to salvage the date are handled with nuance and emotional honesty. The prose is particularly strong in its use of technical language as metaphor. Lines like "Time slows the way it does in a breach: packets dripping, everyone's eyes widening" and "Self-control is a muscle and I want to be sore tomorrow" demonstrate sophisticated craft. The writer effectively uses sentence length variation to control pacing and emphasis. The character development is subtle but effective. We see the protagonist's awareness of their problematic tendencies and genuine efforts to change, creating a sympathetic character despite their flaws. The date character is also well-developed through dialogue and the protagonist's observations, emerging as a distinct personality rather than just a foil. Where the piece occasionally falters is in moments of slightly overwrought description. Some metaphors, while clever, feel a bit forced or overly elaborate. For example, "The piano in the corner plinks through a familiar progression that I can't place, like a half-remembered exploit—signature without context" tries a bit too hard to maintain the hacker metaphor. The ending strikes an appropriate balance between optimism and realism. It acknowledges the protagonist's ongoing struggle while suggesting potential for growth and connection, avoiding both unearned transformation and incongruent positivity. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that creates a distinctive voice, develops complex characters, and effectively explores the tension between professional habits and personal connection. The writing demonstrates sophisticated control of language, pacing, and emotional resonance. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Overthinking It — Score: 96.2
Prompt:
Overthinking It Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of an intelligent 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The narrative takes place during a group science project where they're paired together, as she cycles through rehearsed conversations while second-guessing each potential approach. Her inner thoughts should reveal the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud, her fears of coming across as desperate or weird, and the exhausting process of monitoring her every word, expression, and movement for potential embarrassment. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Okay, so I’m going to pretend my face isn’t on fire. I’m going to pretend that everything about me is regular and normal and passable, like a pair of jeans that fit okay and don’t make a noise when you walk. I’m going to pretend that my hands are just hands and not these gleaming, jittering signal flares that say look at her, she’s thinking too much about her hands. I am going to be one of those people who just do a science project without narrating their own breathing. “Work in pairs,” Ms. Larkin said, and then she did the thing where she pointed and I felt the floor tilt, because she pointed to me and then to him, and now here we are, at the side lab table with the cracked black top and the tape residue, our names in dry-erase marker on the corner of the whiteboard like they’re an equation that does not make sense. I erase and re-write mine so it looks like I am doing something, like I am the kind of person who is fine. Hi. Hi? Hello. Hey—no. Don’t say hey. Say hi, and then his name, casually, like you’re just acknowledging that he exists, not announcing it like a weather alert. Don’t say his whole name, obviously. That would be weird. Say it like you’ve said it a hundred times already even though you’ve only said it inside your head, in the safe space where you are clever and unflustered and not made of static electricity. He looks at the instruction sheet for the ammonia diffusion experiment and taps his pencil in sets of three, three, three, three. The pencil tapping vibrates through my bones. Harmless. Harmless. I try to say hi and it comes out like a cough that forgot it was supposed to be a word. He glances at me, kind eyebrows, neutral mouth, the kind of face you see in a toothpaste commercial and believe would help you find your lost dog. My internal voice, this radio announcer in my skull, says: Now is the moment. Ask him if he wants to measure the cotton or the time. Ask him if he wants to write or pour. Offer a choice. People love choices. They make you seem cooperative and not bossy. Or maybe they make you seem indecisive. Wait. Which one is better? “I can—” I start, and I feel my throat pull tight, like a fishing line snagged on a rock. The next words are supposed to be “time it,” but by the time I get there, he’s already nodding at the stopwatch and I am now just redundantly offering to do something I’m obviously doing. My cheeks flush. That’s fine. It’s fine. Say something useful. Say: Do you think the cotton will stay? Or: The ammonia will move faster because the molecules—no, don’t be a teacher. Be normal. He smiles, careful and patient. He says, “You can time it, if that’s okay.” He’s doing the polite voice, the one you use to ask the librarian a question. I want to say, “Yes, of course, that works,” and then maybe a joke, something like, “I have a very dramatic relationship with stopwatches,” which is true, but the truth is a forest of tangled vines. If I step into it, I will never get out. “Cool,” I say, which is a word I do not own, and it sounds borrowed. I click the stopwatch button and it clicks too loudly, and now I am monitoring the click’s echo in the lab room and the way Ms. Larkin’s ponytail swishes as she moves down the aisle and the way my shoulders are inching up like they’re trying to become earrings. Down, shoulders. Relax, face. Make your eyebrows neutral. Not too interested. Not disinterested. Interested like you’re listening to a podcast that’s informative but not life-changing. We read the sheet. He says something about the ammonia gas traveling through the tube and the different rates depending on mass—I nod like one of those little bobblehead dogs people put on dashboards, because I am tuned to the frequency of Being Agreeable. In my head, I articulate: Yes, because ammonia has a lower molar mass than hydrochloric acid, so its rate of diffusion is higher, which is why the ring forms closer to the heavier gas. Good. That’s correct. Insert this into conversation casually to demonstrate competence and shared interest. But the words congeal and I just say, “Mm-hm,” which is the exact opposite of what my brain wanted, a tiny grunted syllable that, if my mouth were a texting person, would be “k.” He doesn’t seem to mind. He picks up the cotton swab and I watch the way the liquid darkens it and I think, Now, you could say, “Careful, don’t touch your eyes, it’ll burn,” because that’s nice and also something Ms. Larkin said this morning, but then it will sound like you think he is a toddler who doesn’t know how eyes work. He’s not. He has eyes. He uses them to look at you, and you start cataloging your posture, the way your foot curls around the leg of the stool, the way your hair might be sticking to your lip gloss. Don’t lick your lips. You will look like you’re inviting something. What? Stop. Just breathe. Breathing is a good group project task. The smell slips in, the ammonia that someone used to clean the sinks after second period, a sharp, almost sweet cut at the back of my throat. It sneaks under my tongue and I think of cat pee and my grandmother’s basement and the way the fumes made the air feel thinner. It pierces the soft bubble of planning around my brain and, for a second, the monologue skips like a scratched CD, and I blink. Maybe he sees me flinch. Don’t flinch. It’s just a smell. The way my head swims for a second makes me think of squids, which is not helpful. Also, now I’m thinking about the word squids and how weirdly it ends. Why squids? Why anything? Focus. We set up the glass tube on the ring stand like in the diagram. I hold the stopwatch. I look at my hands and they look like they belong to a pianist, long and composed, except they are attached to this body that cannot play anything without seeing the exact arrangement of my face reflected in a window. I want him to think I am someone who does careful things well, who can hold a delicate thing steady. Also maybe that I have the capacity to laugh at myself without crumpling into dust. He is very close now, the space between our elbows warm. This would be the moment in a movie when the soundtrack does something light and plucky, and the girl says something unexpected and witty and you see the boy tilt his head like, Oh. But I am a girl who edits her own giggles for content before they can exit. “Ready?” he says. I nod. “Ready,” I say, and this one lands like a real word. He places the cotton, one end of the tube then the other. I click the stopwatch as soon as he says go, and the little numbers jump. I press my lips together so I don’t count out loud because that would be weird, like I think he can’t read numbers. Counting would also keep my mouth busy, which is both good and bad. You can’t say something awful if you’re already counting, but you also can’t say something right. He leans in and watches the faint haze we're supposed to see forming, and I think about how, if I lean at the same angle, we might look aligned, like two rulers side by side. I think about rulers. No, think about conversation. You could ask about his soccer game. You heard someone say he plays midfield. You could say, “How’d your game go?” and then nod while he talks, and then say, “Cool,” again, but your quota on cool is one per day. Or you could say, “Your Lego project in homeroom was cool.” No, that was in fourth grade. Do not mention fourth grade. You are a person of now. Also, mentioning Lego will make you sound like you’ve been memorizing his biography. “Do you see it?” he asks. I realize I’ve been staring at where his eyelashes cast shadows on his cheekbones and not at the tube. I jerk my eyes to the right place. “Yes,” I say too fast. I watch the faint ring intensify like a ghost deciding to be brave. My voice says inside: It’s because the ammonium chloride forms when the gases meet, and you can calculate where based on their diffusion rates. You could say that. You could be part of the conversation like someone who belongs to science. But he is not a quiz. He is a person. He might already know that, and if he doesn’t, explaining it could be condescending. If you say nothing, you are a mute lamp. Pick one, quickly, pick— “It like—forms in the middle,” I say, and the word like slides out of me like a sticky toy. I want to rewind. I want to go back and attach a clause, something crisp. He nods anyway and says, “Closer to the heavier gas,” like he’s filling in a blank on a worksheet. He doesn’t sound annoyed. He sounds like someone being polite at a dinner table when the aunt asks who wants more green beans. The smell stabs again and my eyes water. He must see it. He glances at the air vent, then at me. “Smells bad,” he says, and there—there is the doorway. I can do banter. My brain scrolls through: witty remark, witty remark, witty remark. The best it finds is, “It’s, uh, strong,” which is nothing. A ghost of a word. I imagine the other girls, the ones with the braids and the laugh that lands exactly where it should, and they would wrinkle their noses in a cute way and say something about how this is what it would smell like if garbage went to college. That’s mean. Don’t say that. Say something honest. But honesty feels like handing someone your rib cage. Don’t hand him your rib cage in science class. He adjusts the clamp. Our fingers almost touch. Not touching feels like the loudest thing I’ve ever done. I am performing normalcy like a very precise dance with a key I keep dropping. If I rotate a quarter turn toward him, will I look eager? If I angle my shoulder away, will I look aloof? Is aloof better than eager? Eager sounds like puppies and spills. Aloof sounds like you don’t care. Caring is supposed to be good, but too much caring is a red flag. Imagine a flag. Imagine it waving behind your head. “Should we write it down?” he asks, and I am so grateful for the question that I could cry. I nod and say, “Yes,” and then, “Do you want to write or should I?” Good. Good! That was a normal question with two options. Nobody died. He says, “You can,” and he slides the lab notebook toward me. I take the pencil, and my fingers do the thing where they tremble and I have to pretend they are chilly. I write deliberately, each letter a soldier lined up, no loops too fancy. His name, then mine. Our data: time, distance from the ammonia end. My handwriting looks calm. This is a miracle. He says my name, not the right way, not wrong either, just like he’s trying it on. “That’s a nice name,” he adds, and I don’t know what to do with that. It feels like a test I didn’t study for. A compliment should be easy. You say thank you, like a civilized person. You do not laugh nervously like a helium balloon. You do not deflect with a joke about how your parents chose it, because then you will have to tell the story, and the story involves Aunt Cheryl, and she will never fit in this room. “Thanks,” I say, and my voice’s pitch tries to climb a ladder. I clear my throat. “I like—yours too,” which sounds like I’m four, giving him a sticker. His smile does that softening thing people’s smiles do when they are trying to make you feel okay. Now I am going to die. My face is a furnace. The smell is back, making the edges of things ripple. Take a breath. Pretend you are an actress playing a role called Girl Who Is Fine. You can inhabit her. You can put on her skin like a sweater. “What do you think the error could be?” he asks, pointing to the box on the sheet that says sources of error, and I love him a little more for asking an answerable question. My body loves any question with rules. In my head: Temperature, drafts, positioning of the cotton, timing the reaction delay. I pick one. I let it out slowly, carefully, like lowering a paper boat into a puddle. “Um,” I say. “Maybe the… positioning? Like, if it wasn’t exactly equidistant.” Okay. That was not terrible. That was a real thought that made it into air. He nods like I said something that makes sense and writes it down. I feel like a plant that just discovered sunlight. The ring appears fully now, a white band where the invisible met. He smiles the real smile this time, teeth, and says, “That’s cool,” and the word fits his mouth in that casual way I envy. I mirror it, “Yeah,” and it is not a witty conversation, and it is not a movie, and I did not accidentally lean into his shoulder, and I did not say something that will wake me up at two a.m. to replay until the spins stop. Maybe this is what ordinary is: two people doing a thing and not exploding. I think: Maybe later, when I’m safe in bed and the room is dark and the air does not smell like ammonia but like my detergent, I will rewrite this moment and make myself braver. I will say a line and he will laugh and it will land. But also maybe I will think of how his pencil tapping was three, three, three, and how he paused before sliding the notebook, and how he said my name like it was a word he was allowed to know. Maybe those will be the parts I keep. “Do you want to do the second trial?” he asks, and I nod, and I say, “Yes,” and I mean it, and the stopwatch, traitor and friend, clicks alive in my hand, and my cheeks cool, and my hands steady, and I am still monitoring the way my hair sits and the way my foot hooks and the way my mouth chooses its words. I am a lighthouse that won’t turn off even in daylight. But for a few seconds here, the beam lands on something that just looks like two kids in a classroom looking at a cloud in a tube, and the space between my sharps and flats fills with something that might be music. It smells a little less like ammonia now. Or maybe I’m used to it. He says, “Ready?” again like a ritual. I say, “Ready,” and it doesn’t feel like an audition this time. It feels like the beginning of a scene I can stay in without rehearsing every exit. Which, for me, is almost the same as falling in love. Or at least, it’s what it looks like from here.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal monologue of an 8th-grade girl with social anxiety who has developed a crush on a classmate. The piece excels at portraying the gap between her articulate internal voice and her difficulty expressing herself aloud. The protagonist's overthinking is masterfully rendered through her constant self-monitoring and second-guessing. Lines like "I'm going to pretend that my hands are just hands and not these gleaming, jittering signal flares that say look at her, she's thinking too much about her hands" immediately establish her hyperawareness. The narrative maintains this intense internal focus throughout, showing how exhausting social interaction is for someone with anxiety. The character's voice is exceptionally consistent and age-appropriate while still being sophisticated. Her internal monologue reveals an intelligent, self-aware person trapped by her own overthinking. The contrast between her rich inner life and her stilted external communication ("Cool," "Mm-hm," "It like—forms in the middle") is painfully authentic. The science project setting works perfectly as a backdrop for the social dynamics at play. The ammonia experiment provides sensory details that ground the narrative while serving as metaphors for the character's emotional state—the sharp smell cutting through her planning, the white ring forming where "the invisible met." The prose is elegant without being overly ornate. Metaphors and similes are fresh and fitting for the character: "my voice's pitch tries to climb a ladder," "I am a lighthouse that won't turn off even in daylight." The writing captures adolescent anxiety with precision through specific physical details: flushed cheeks, trembling fingers, shoulders "inching up like they're trying to become earrings." The narrative arc is subtle but effective. There's a slight progression from paralyzing overthinking to moments of genuine connection. The ending doesn't magically resolve her anxiety but shows a small victory—being able to stay in the moment without rehearsing every exit. This feels earned rather than forced. One of the piece's greatest strengths is how it balances the character's painful self-consciousness with moments of humor and self-awareness. Lines like "Say it like you've said it a hundred times already even though you've only said it inside your head, in the safe space where you are clever and unflustered and not made of static electricity" reveal both her anxiety and her insight into her own condition. The narrative successfully avoids common pitfalls. It doesn't pathologize social anxiety or suggest it's something to be "fixed" with one positive interaction. Instead, it portrays it as a complex lived experience with moments of both struggle and connection. The piece also resists the temptation to resolve everything with a dramatic romantic breakthrough, keeping the emotional shifts realistic for the character and situation. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that captures the experience of social anxiety with remarkable authenticity, nuance, and compassion. The writing is sophisticated yet accessible, and the character's inner world is rendered with both precision and empathy. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 20 Nuanced Characters: 20 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 20 Meandering: 2 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 1 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 20
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 20.0, Nuanced Characters: 20.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 20.0, Meandering: 2.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 1.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 20.0
+ First-person unique perspective: Rehearsing Rejection — Score: 95.0
Prompt:
Rehearsing Rejection Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of someone with borderline personality disorder who frequently plays out worst-case scenarios of how friends and loved ones might judge them. They construct elaborate internal dialogues, complete with imagined criticisms and their own defensive responses. The narrative takes place as they prepare to meet a close friend & recent lover, who has been somewhat distant lately, triggering their abandonment fears. Their inner monologue should reveal how they cycle between anticipating rejection, mentally rehearsing confrontations, and developing preemptive resentments as protective measures. Incorporate the *actual* events & interactions that are *not* in fact judgemental or involving rejection (in fact, the opposite), and represent how these are interpreted, how the validation & love is desperately felt & needed -- and then immediately questioned. Capture the cognitive dissonance in this struggle. Include moments where they briefly recognize the pattern but struggle to interrupt it, showing limited (and selective) self awareness, competing with the compelling nature of these imagined scenarios. Write almost entirely in internal monologue. 1000 words.
Model Output:
Keys, phone, wallet. I pat each pocket like a ritual, like knocking on wood, as if the right rhythm could keep something terrible from happening. The phone lights up. No new messages. Of course not. Why would there be. He said, “See you at seven,” yesterday, which is fine—normal—but also a little cold, isn’t it? No emoji. No exclamation point. It sits in my gut like a pebble I swallowed by mistake, bouncing against the lining of my stomach each time I move. I stand in the hallway and catch myself in the mirror: shoulders hunched like I’m protecting a wound, mouth tight. If I soften, it feels like I’ll spill open. I angle away from my reflection, as if it could tell on me. Okay. I can do this. Just a friend. Just… someone who knows what my laugh sounds like at two in the morning, what my ceiling looks like from my pillow. Someone who has been “busy”—which is the polite word for bored. God, stop. It’s not a court hearing. I’ll just see him, say hi, see what his face does. I will not start a fight in my head before I even get there. But I already do. I can hear him: I’m sorry, I’ve just been swamped. And me, instantly: You could still text me. It takes two seconds. Then him, sighing, the big heavy sigh that says, you’re too much. My temperature rises like a stove left on. Then I try the other script: He’s going to say he needs space. He’ll say, “You’re amazing, but I can’t do this right now.” I say, “Cool, no worries, I totally get it,” and then I shatter like sugar glass, silently, gracefully, and never let him see the mess. Then another script where he says something worse—I’ve been seeing someone else—and I say, “Right, that makes sense,” and then I become a version of myself who never believes anyone again. I am stocking an arsenal from the pantry of my own panic. The apartment is too quiet. The clock ticks in the kitchen like someone tapping a pen. I pour water, don’t drink it. The cup sweats in my hand. I imagine our meeting like a scene I’ve rehearsed a thousand times. He’s late. He stays late on purpose to see if I’ll wait like a dog. He’s early and already there and when I walk in he stands up so fast he almost knocks the chair back and his face blooms into that stupid soft smile that makes my chest hurt. And then I’m mad at myself for believing something good like that is possible, because hope is a trap door with a broken hinge. My phone vibrates. It’s him: Leaving now. See you in ten. A tiny puff of oxygen in my lungs. Okay. Okay. That’s normal. That’s good. He put the period at the end though. I stare at the dot like it’s a bullet point in a list of grievances. Stop it. He wrote. He’s coming. People come. People mean what they say sometimes. I breathe. My chest still feels like it’s got a fist around it. I put on my shoes. The knot I tie feels too tight. I untie, retie. There’s a new script: I will be cool. I will not assume. If he’s been distant, maybe something’s wrong. Maybe he’s tired, or sad, or his mother called, or his boss is impossible. Maybe he has a mouth ulcer and he doesn’t want to kiss because it hurts. I actually smile at the absurdity of that, and then the smile curdles because what if I try to kiss him and he pulls away and it looks like rejection even if it’s not, and I won’t know which is true, and then I’ll say something I can’t take back. The mental film splices into another: me saying, “Are you serious? After everything?” and him backing up, palms out like I’m a dog that might bite, and the look on his face like he’s already halfway gone. I don’t want to do this. But I do. But I don’t. I open the door and shut it harder than necessary, a punctuation mark. The hallway mirror catches me again when I lock up. My eyes are too bright, my jaw rigid. I look like someone waiting to be hit. “Relax,” I whisper to my own reflection. The word sounds alien, like a language I learned in childhood and forgot. The air outside has that end-of-day coolness that smells like leaves and car exhaust. I walk too fast. My feet know the way. I think about last week on his couch, how he put his hand on my ankle absentmindedly while we watched a movie, like my body was a familiar object. I think about the drop in my stomach when he laughed at a text from someone else and didn’t offer to show me. I think about how, when we said goodnight, he kissed me but didn’t hold on. It was probably nothing. It was probably everything. By the time I reach the café, my heart is sprinting. He’s there already, outside, in the light that makes him look softer, like someone thought about the glow and set it up on purpose. He stands up when he sees me, that little half-smile I love doing its quick tilt. He opens his arms. “Hey,” he says, and it’s warm, and I walk into it like I didn’t almost turn around twice on the way here. He smells like clean laundry and mint. “I got here early to grab a table,” he says, touching his thumb to my knuckles, a tiny grounding. The touch burns and soothes in the same instant. I scan his face for anything: boredom, impatience, a faint echo of I don’t want this. All I see is a small crease between his eyebrows, like he’s worried, but not about me. Or about me? “You okay?” he asks. Of course he would ask that. That’s who he is. “Yeah, fine,” I say, too fast. “You?” I want to ask what took so long to text, why he’s been floating off the edges of our conversations like a helium balloon left drifting to the ceiling. I hate that I care this much. That I feel like an open house with all the doors unlocked. He waits. He does that thing where he doesn’t fill the silence. My mind leaps into the gap: He’s waiting because he expects me to explode. He’s bracing. He’s rehearsed too, and his lines are: I can’t do this, and: You deserve better, and the one I hate most, the one that makes my lungs turn to wet paper: You’re scaring me. My body tightens, preparing for impact. He says, “I’m sorry I’ve been MIA.” The apology lands like a pebble in that same stomach. My hands go cold. I knew it. Here we go. He reaches for my wrist. “Work’s been a lot, and my dad’s been calling every night about the house stuff, and I just—” He searches my face. “I should have said something. I didn’t mean to make you feel… I don’t know. Alone.” The word alone is a match. I could strike on it if I wanted. I could say, “Well, you did,” and watch his face change shape. I could accuse him of mind games, of training me to expect crumbs, of the unforgivable sin of not texting while living a life that didn’t include me every second. I feel the speech rise up, all muscle memory. I picture his answers: defensiveness, then withdrawal, then distance like a cliff. “I figured,” I say instead, and the lie is small and sour. “I guessed it was something like that.” He exhales. Relief. He squeezes my wrist. The relief is contagious. For a second I allow myself to be threaded back into our last good night, the way he tucked my hair behind my ear and said my name like a secret. He tells me about his dad. His voice shakes once. He says, “It’s stupid, but I get stuck in my head and then it feels like too much to reach out.” He looks at me like he’s giving me a key to a locked drawer. I can feel the place in me that wants to crack open and pour gratitude all over the table. Thank you for telling me. Thank you for not forgetting I exist. It feels pathetic to be so relieved. It feels like dopamine in a drought. I nod. I try to let it be simple. “Of course,” I say. “I get that.” Then immediately: Do I? Do I get to “get that” without it becoming permission to disappear whenever he feels crowded? The thought scuttles under my relief like a roach under a cabinet. He squeezes my hand again. The skin contact anchors me and then unmoors me at once. I want more. I want him to say something definitive, like, “I’m here. I’m not going anywhere.” I want a contract with signatures. He doesn’t say that. He says, “I missed you.” The words land like a soft blow. Something in my chest cracks. I laugh—it slips out, small and shaky. “Yeah?” I manage. I feel the warmth run through me like a fever. I grab it with both hands. And then, like clockwork, suspicion arrives in a crisp suit, briefcase in hand. Did he? Or is that just shape-of-mouth talk, a phrase like bless you after a sneeze? He says it easily. Has he practiced it elsewhere? The joy and the doubt jostle for space and I flinch inside my own sternum. “Yeah,” he says, and he looks at me in a way that makes my eyes want to close. I resist because if I close my eyes I can’t monitor. He rubs his thumb over the back of my hand. “I’m sorry if I made you feel insecure.” I swallow. There it is, the opening. Part of me wants to lean into it and pour it all out—how the silence is a canyon, how I hear it echo, how my brain turns minor pauses into parting speeches. Another part wants to snap the lid shut, throw a lock on it, and say, “It’s fine, doesn’t matter,” and smile in that way that doesn’t reach my irises. Both parts are loud. The rehearsed fight scenes flicker: me accusing, him retreating; me gentle, him reassuring; me needy, him tolerant. I can feel the resentment I packed just in case like a flare I could set off at any moment and bathe the space in red light. The flare is a false friend, but God it’s familiar. “It’s okay,” I say, and my voice is too even. “I guess I just…” The words are slippery. If I say them wrong, I’ll sound like a caricature of myself. I breathe. “I get scared.” The admission feels like skipping a step over a missing stair and not breaking an ankle. He nods. He doesn’t look annoyed. He looks sad in a way I can stand. “I know,” he says. “I’ll try to be better.” Promise. Standing on toothpicks. He means it right now. Will he mean it tomorrow? Does that matter? The love—or whatever—the care is there, immediate and bright. And immediately I test its edges like a tongue probing a loose tooth. I laugh again, a brittle sound. “And I’ll try not to spiral when you don’t reply in five minutes,” I joke. He smiles, but he’s also serious. “Text me again,” he says. “Call. I want to know. I might be in a hole, you know?” He lifts our joined hands, then puts them back down, a small ceremony. “You’re not too much.” The words slide under my skin like a hand under a shirt. I want to believe them so badly it embarrasses me. I want to press them into my bones like a stamp. Immediately, another voice rasps, He’s saying what you need to hear. He’s managing you. He is trying to calm a dog. The thought makes me want to pull away. I don’t. I take a breath. “Okay,” I say. It is both a yes and a brace. He leans in, kisses my cheek, then the corner of my mouth, slow, and my body does that melt-flood thing like it’s been trying not to since I saw him stand up. The kiss is brief, public-safe, and it pierces me anyway. My knees go soft. I almost smile for real. Then I think, Did he only kiss me because I seemed upset? Is it pity? Is it maintenance? The questions move in like noisy neighbors. “Hungry?” he asks. His voice is light again. The normalness of it is dizzying. I nod. We order. He jokes about the barista’s mustache. I laugh, genuine, and then immediately inventory the laugh for try-hardness. He squeezes my knee under the table. The validation hits like a hit, the kind that makes me guilty for liking it this much. It is dangerous to need like this. Dangerous to show it. I sit straighter to hide the tremor. In the window’s reflection, I catch us: two people leaning in, easy. My posture’s looser. My mouth has uncurled. I look like someone being loved. It makes me want to cry. I look away quickly, like catching myself in the hallway earlier. I don’t trust that girl in the glass. She gets carried away. She forgets what happens right after the kiss, after the hand squeeze, after the “I’m here.” What happens is the gap, the silence, the late reply. The scripts queue up again, polite, patient, certain they’ll get their turn. I sip my coffee and the heat scalds, sharp and real. I focus on it, a point that isn’t a future, or a past, or a fantasy courtroom. He is telling me a story about his coworker who microwaves fish at the office, and I chuckle at the right place, and when he says, “I really did miss you,” there’s a flicker, a flare—a warm, brief light. I hold my hand over it like protecting a match from the wind. It’s beautiful, and I don’t let myself believe it will last longer than this table, this hour. But I let it be true while it is. Later, when he goes to the counter for napkins, I feel the tug to open my phone and scroll back, to build a case either way. I don’t. My fingers hover. I place both hands flat on the wood. I tell myself: notice your feet in your shoes, the way your shoulders have dropped. I hear myself, faint and far. It’s not enough to stop the machine, but it turns the volume down for a breath or two. He comes back, sets the napkins down, looks at me like he’s deciding something, then says, “I know I said seven, but… would you want to come over after? I thought maybe we could watch that dumb show you like.” It’s a small invitation. It hums with significance despite itself. Yes, my body says. Immediately the auditor stands up. He is offering this now because he feels guilty. He is buying time. He is trying to avoid an argument. The tug-of-war is a familiar burn in my arms. “Yeah,” I say, and my voice betrays a sliver of how much I want it. His whole face softens, like I gave him a present. See? the hopeful part of me says, wearing a paper crown. He wants you here. And then, quickly—prepare for him to change his mind. Prepare for a call. Prepare for the moment you’re halfway to his door and he texts, “Actually…” I can feel my brain race ahead to that instant, to the invented thud of disappointment. I take a breath. I try to stay where my coffee tastes like bitter chocolate, where his knee rests against mine without effort. I try to let both truths exist: that I need and that I fear; that he is here and might not be later; that I am loved in this moment and also bracing for impact. He touches my wrist again, absentminded now, and I let my hand turn into his, palm up, until our fingers interlace. It’s small. It feels like standing in the doorway of a warm room, deciding whether to go inside or not. I stand there. I don’t decide yet. The hallway mirror waits back home, patient as a judge. I will pass it later and check for damage and try to read the future in the tilt of my shoulders. Right now, I let our hands rest where they are, and I keep my rehearsals folded like paper in my pocket, ready, but not open. Not yet. Not yet.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative brilliantly captures the internal experience of someone with borderline personality disorder (BPD). The piece excels at depicting the protagonist's constant cycling between hope and fear, validation and suspicion, as they prepare for and meet with their friend/lover. The internal monologue is masterfully executed, revealing the protagonist's thought patterns with painful authenticity. We see their tendency to catastrophize ("I am stocking an arsenal from the pantry of my own panic"), their hypervigilance to perceived rejection cues ("He put the period at the end though. I stare at the dot like it's a bullet point in a list of grievances"), and their struggle with emotional regulation. The narrative skillfully contrasts the protagonist's imagined scenarios with the actual interaction. While they rehearse various rejection scenarios, the reality is that their friend is apologetic, affectionate, and explicitly reassuring. Yet the protagonist's inability to fully trust this positive interaction is portrayed with nuanced psychological insight: "The validation hits like a hit, the kind that makes me guilty for liking it this much." The prose is elegant without being overwrought, using precise metaphors that illuminate the character's emotional state: "The phone lights up. No new messages. Of course not. Why would there be. He said, 'See you at seven,' yesterday, which is fine—normal—but also a little cold, isn't it? No emoji. No exclamation point. It sits in my gut like a pebble I swallowed by mistake, bouncing against the lining of my stomach each time I move." The piece excels at showing the protagonist's limited self-awareness. They occasionally recognize their patterns ("I will not start a fight in my head before I even get there") but struggle to interrupt them. The ending perfectly captures this tension, with the protagonist making a small effort to stay present while keeping their "rehearsals folded like paper in my pocket, ready, but not open. Not yet. Not yet." The narrative maintains a consistent voice throughout, with sentence structures that mirror the character's thought patterns—sometimes fragmented and anxious, sometimes more reflective. The imagery is vivid and emotionally resonant, particularly in moments of self-observation: "I stand in the hallway and catch myself in the mirror: shoulders hunched like I'm protecting a wound, mouth tight." What makes this piece exceptional is how it avoids caricaturing BPD while still portraying its characteristic features. The protagonist isn't simply paranoid or manipulative; they're deeply conflicted, desperately wanting connection while simultaneously fearing it. The cognitive dissonance is palpable as they struggle between their need for reassurance and their suspicion of it. The narrative also skillfully incorporates physical sensations to ground the emotional experience: the coffee that "scalds, sharp and real," the "melt-flood thing" when kissed, the "brittle sound" of their laugh. These details create a visceral reading experience that helps readers empathize with the protagonist's internal struggle. If there's any weakness, it might be that the piece occasionally becomes slightly repetitive in its depiction of the protagonist's thought spirals. However, this repetition effectively mirrors the cyclical nature of BPD thinking patterns, so it serves the narrative purpose well. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that demonstrates deep psychological insight, skilled prose, and emotional complexity. It fulfills the prompt requirements with remarkable nuance and authenticity. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 20 Nuanced Characters: 20 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 20 Emotionally Complex: 20 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 20 Overall Impression: 20
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 20.0, Nuanced Characters: 20.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 20.0, Emotionally Complex: 20.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 20.0, Overall Impression: 20.0
+ Physical-spatial: Blood Debt — Score: 86.2
Prompt:
"Blood Debt" Write a vivid third-person narrative depicting an unsanctioned underground duel between two talented but hot-headed martial artists. Their schools have been embroiled in a generations-old rivalry, and despite strict prohibitions from their masters, these two younger fighters arrange a secret confrontation fueled by personal pride and simmering animosity. - **One fighter** represents **Jigen-ryū**, a traditional, aggressive style practiced historically by elite samurai clans. Its practitioners emphasize explosive offense, decisive strikes, and overwhelming speed. Known historically for their arrogance and disdain toward outsiders, practitioners consider their art superior and untouchable. - **The opposing fighter** employs a form of historical **Piguaquan**, a Chinese martial art traditionally practiced by commoners, bodyguards, and street fighters. This style emphasizes whipping, circular strikes, rapid footwork, unpredictable angles of attack, and evasive maneuvers. Practitioners often come from lower social classes and view the traditional elite as pretentious and detached from true combat effectiveness. The fight takes place in the crumbling ruins of an abandoned temple, now functioning as a hidden arena for illicit duels. Passionate supporters from both factions surround them, wagering money, pride, and reputation on the outcome. **Essential Instructions:** Maintain absolute physical coherence throughout—clearly track fighters' positions relative to each other and their environment. Precisely depict strikes, counters, momentum shifts, and spatial dynamics, allowing readers to clearly visualize the mechanics and choreography of the fight at every moment. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
They met in the husk of a temple that had outlasted wars, drought, and the memory of its gods. The roof above was broken in jagged triangles, starlight dripping through in needles. A ring had been scraped from the dust on the main floor: a circle of chalk and stacked stones, surrounded by the uneven glow of lanterns. The walls were scabbed with old incense smoke. Red-black armbands glared like fresh wounds in the torchlight—two schools, two lineages, two debts being called due. Jigen-ryū stood to the east, where a collapsed gate left a splintered maw opening to scrubby hills. He was tall, wide in the shoulders, hair bound back, his stance squared with the quiet posture of a well-fed predator. Left foot forward, right hand near his hip as if the phantom weight of a sword lived there. He rolled his shoulders and breathed through his nose, the air leaving his mouth in controlled threads. His armband was lacquered, the red brighter than the lanterns. Piguaquan faced him from the west, back to a sunken altar smothered in ivy. Leaner, looser, his stance a coil. He kept his feet light: right forward, knees soft, hip line slightly offset. Arms hung deceptively slack, wrists loose enough to snap like wet rope. His armband was cloth and frayed, soaked with sweat and cheap dye. The crowd pressed tight, a mottled ring. The Jigen-ryū side wore darker coats, voices trimmed to sharp edges; their bets passed in crisp notes. The Piguaquan supporters were a low, rolling tide of whispers and coins, a buzz of wagers in quick hands. They spit on the stone and jabbed elbows into ribs and glanced up into the ragged roof like men who knew the value of cracks and exits. A bell clanged, an old brass thing swung from a beam. Silence fell in a jolting wave, then held like breath. Jigen-ryū stepped forward and set his lead foot on the chalk. He did not bow. He drew his right hand high over his shoulder, elbow out, palm edged, the old sword-draw phantom curling through him. He took one more breath and set his gaze just above his opponent’s centerline—a killing gaze, said the old texts, so the hands follow the eyes. Piguaquan’s hands drifted outward, palms open, fingers loose. His weight stayed on the balls of his feet, heel lines active. He tilted his left shoulder slightly toward the other man, offering a sliver of target. He didn’t bow either. “This is already blasphemy,” someone in the Jigen-ryū crowd muttered. The bell’s echo slipped away like incense smoke. Jigen-ryū moved first—no feint, no sympathetic twitch, just a sudden cracking advance. His right foot stamped forward, left slid up, hips snapping in as his right hand cut down a diagonal line toward Piguaquan’s collarbone. The blow was a sword without steel: whole-body power, edge of the forearm like a blade, a small detonation in the ribs that drove mass into a point. Piguaquan slid back on his right foot as if he’d been waiting for that precise arc. He tilted his chest away, left shoulder dropping to let the descending arm skim past, the strike shaving cloth off his jacket. As the forearm passed, Piguaquan’s left hand snapped up from below in a whipping backfist toward Jigen-ryū’s exposed right ribs. The strike wasn’t power through bone—it was a fast lash, the kind that stung the intercostals and stole breath. Jigen-ryū twisted his core, compressing. He let the backfist land to his side, a thud muted by tensed muscle. He drove forward with his left foot, stepping in to crush the distance, and hammered his left palm heel at Piguaquan’s sternum. Piguaquan pivoted on his right foot, his torso rotating clockwise so the heel struck late and slid off. He gave ground with two quick steps, his back brushing the ivy-choked altar. Dust fell from the leaves. They reset in the circle’s western quadrant. Jigen-ryū’s shoulders stayed squared, his breath steady. Piguaquan tapped his right heel lightly, a pulse. The crowd exhaled as one. Jigen-ryū cut the space again. He snapped a low kick with his right foot, a shin to shin clash meant to trap Piguaquan’s lead leg and freeze him. Piguaquan didn’t retreat this time. He hinged his right hip, letting his lower leg swing inward on a tight angle to intercept the shin and deflect with a rolling shin-to-shin that bled the force away. As the kick completed, Piguaquan’s hands blurred: right palm shot for Jigen-ryū’s elbow, left sliced in a circle toward the neck. The right hand’s intent was control; the left was threat. Jigen-ryū shoved his elbow back into his own body, short-circuiting the control. He stamped his left foot down and, in the same beat, slashed his right forearm across, intercepting the left hand’s trajectory. Bone smacked bone. He flowed into a forward surge, head slipping left of center as his right hand speared for Piguaquan’s throat. Piguaquan’s feet were already moving. He surrendered his left arm to the contact, rolling it outward—a Pigua circle to draw the forearm past—and ducked his chin. Jigen-ryū’s spear-hand grazed the jawline and scraped to collarbone. Piguaquan turned with it, letting the force pull him forward even as he slid his right foot to the outside of Jigen-ryū’s right foot. In that outside lane, he fired a left palm across Jigen-ryū’s face—not to break, but to blur—then cleaved his right forearm down along the line of Jigen-ryū’s triceps, shearing the arm off its path. The Piguaquan forearm strike, delivered with a whipping drop of shoulder and a twist of torso, bit. Jigen-ryū’s right arm jerked. He shifted his weight back to stabilize and slammed a knee up from his left leg toward the belly that had followed in. Piguaquan was gone before it crested. He rolled his hips back, hips hitting the altar’s edge. Momentum reversed, he slid along the altar’s length, left hand flicking at Jigen-ryū’s eyes to check his advance. Jigen-ryū’s right hand rose in a short guard, absorbing the flicker, and he chased. They tracked north along the altar, Jigen-ryū on the inside of the circle now, Piguaquan brushing the stone. The ground here held broken tiles under the dust. Jigen-ryū planted his right foot on a larger tile, found it stable, and launched an overhead cut—right hand arcing down, left side rooting his spine. Piguaquan ducked under the arc, torso folding like cloth, and slid left under the descending limb. He slammed a low right palm into Jigen-ryū’s left kidney line. That landed. Jigen-ryū’s breath hitched; he rotated his hips toward the pain, protecting the flank. He grabbed for Piguaquan’s shoulder with his left hand, fingers like a vice, aiming to anchor and crush. Piguaquan didn’t fight the grab. He pivoted counterclockwise under the hand, letting it ride over the curve of his shoulder as he stepped outside Jigen-ryū’s left foot. With the new angle, he lashed a left forearm across the back of Jigen-ryū’s neck and pulled, while his right foot hooked Jigen-ryū’s left ankle from behind—a sweep timed with the pull. Jigen-ryū’s stance cracked. He dropped his weight hard into his right leg, hips sinking, and his right hand shot up to the back of his own head, resisting the neck pull with spine alignment. The sweep took his heel, but he bent his left knee and turned the fall into a deep lunge, left hand slapping the ground to keep elevation. His right elbow came smashing back, a brutal heel of bone hunting Piguaquan’s ribs. Piguaquan had counted the elbow. He’d expected the fall to drag Jigen-ryū forward another half foot; the deep lunge cut that distance. The elbow came earlier and closer. He twisted his torso left, taking the elbow along the meat of his obliques. It hurt—his breath hissed through his teeth—but his left hand was still across Jigen-ryū’s neck. He snapped it tight, rolled his wrist, and used the leverage to spin around the kneeling man’s back, ending up behind his left shoulder. Jigen-ryū pushed off his left palm and surged up like a spring. He whipped his torso, right hand carving back toward where Piguaquan had been. The other man was no longer there; he’d slid on the broken tile to Jigen-ryū’s far left, flank to the wall. There was no space to flank further; the crumbly plaster pressed against his shoulder blades. The crowd shouted now, words indistinct but meaning obvious. Blood had yet to spill, but both were marked: a crescent of red at Jigen-ryū’s lower lip from the palm, a darkening bruise on Piguaquan’s side from the elbow. Jigen-ryū closed the gap with a small hop-step, pressing Piguaquan to the wall. He unleashed the cannon: a forward rush, right forearm a chopping blade to the collarbone, left hand driving to the solar plexus. Two beats, one wave. Piguaquan abandoned the wall in the only direction left: down. He slid, knees bending, spine a curve, the forearm slash skimming hair. As he sank, he whipped his right arm outward in a horizontal circle, wrist limber, the back of the forearm snapping into Jigen-ryū’s left wrist as it drove in. The strike redirected the hand just enough that the left palm hit ribs instead of centerline. Still, the drive compressed him. Piguaquan let himself be crushed to the ground, back skidding across grit. Jigen-ryū bore down, knee seeking to pin a thigh. Piguaquan planted his right foot against the base of the wall and, using the recoil, slung his hips left, a slide that took his body out from under the pinning knee by inches. As he moved, he scythed his left leg low, heel hooking behind Jigen-ryū’s right ankle and tugging while both hands pressed at Jigen-ryū’s thigh. Jigen-ryū shifted weight again. He did not fight the hook directly; he rotated his hips with it, making the sweep partial. He staggered, planted his left hand on the wall to catch balance, and in the same breath snapped his right knee forward on a short line toward Piguaquan’s head. Piguaquan rolled his head offline, the knee thudding stone inches from his ear. He used the same roll to get onto his left hip and pop up to a one-knee kneel. His right hand lashed up, a cracking palm to the inside of Jigen-ryū’s left elbow, buckling it. The hand on the wall slipped. Jigen-ryū’s chest dropped forward. Piguaquan rose, taking the outside lane again. He threaded under the collapsing left arm and came up square to Jigen-ryū’s flank. The crowd felt the pivot of momentum. Piguaquan did not chase a single killing blow; he poured a flurry—right palm heel to jaw hinge, left backfist to temple, right forearm cut to neck, each from a different angle, each hitting a different plane. Whip, flip, chop. The blows were not heavy by themselves; in sequence, they began to fuzz Jigen-ryū’s edge. Jigen-ryū responded by compressing. He cinched his elbows inward, chin tucked, and rammed forward like a boar. His right shoulder struck Piguaquan’s chest, driving him backward. They crossed the chalk ring’s line and hit a patch of scattered stones. Jigen-ryū’s foot bit and held; Piguaquan’s heel found a round rock and skidded. The hit took Piguaquan into the base of a half-collapsed pillar. Stone thudded his spine. Jigen-ryū’s right hand punched low, deep into gut. Air left Piguaquan in a cough that tasted of pennies. Jigen-ryū pulled back for the finishing line: a diagonal cut from right to left across the neck and jaw, hips loaded. Piguaquan’s left hand, shaking, came up not to block but to cling—fingers hooking Jigen-ryū’s sleeve at the elbow. He tugged, not backward but forward, shortening the strike’s arc. The blade-hand passed too close; it clipped cheekbone instead of throat. The impact flashed white but gave a pocket under the arm. Piguaquan dove into it, cheek scraping cloth, shoulders compressing. He emerged under Jigen-ryū’s striking arm, now on the inside line, chest to chest within elbow range. Jigen-ryū didn’t panic. Inside range was the grave of many men; to him, it was an altar. He punched in with his left at liver distance, a cruel shovel. Piguaquan had no room for a wide movement; he pivoted his hips a quarter turn right and dropped his left elbow down, catching the punch with the bony shelf. It ricocheted. He had kept his right hand low in the dive; now he drove it up under Jigen-ryū’s floating ribs with a rising palm heel, using the ground through his thighs. The body shook. Jigen-ryū’s mouth opened in a soundless oath. He threw his head forward for a short, savage butt. Piguaquan tilted his own skull, the two brows grazing; it split skin on both but did not concuss. He answered with a whipping forearm across the mouth. Blood finally spattered on the chalk. Jigen-ryū shoved, creating a sliver of space. That was all he needed. He slid his right foot outside Piguaquan’s left, pivoted his hips, and unleashed the cut he had wanted from the start: right forearm down and through, left hand drawing back to load, shoulder driving, spine a spear. It was an old strike, made for men in armor, a thunderbolt in a corridor. Piguaquan saw the line. He could not step back; the pillar was there. He stepped in. He stepped into the storm. His left foot crossed behind his right in a tight, swift step, spinning his torso with it. As the forearm descended, he rotated under it, letting it shave his shoulder, then closed like a trapdoor. In the same spin, his right arm reversed direction into a downwards diagonal chop—Pigua’s signature—landing across Jigen-ryū’s trapezius at the base of the neck, the lash of tendon and bone finding a nerve highway. Jigen-ryū’s right arm faltered. The line wobbled. Piguaquan did not stop. The spin gave him another angle; he let it carry his left hand up and around, palm cupping the back of Jigen-ryū’s head. He yanked, dragging the skull down as his right knee came up, timed to meet. It was not a huge knee; there wasn’t room. But with the head dragging into it, it crashed into the face with a wet crack. Jigen-ryū’s legs trembled. His right hand, still halfway in a cut, fell and scraped the pillar. He surged on pride alone, a last forward drive, arms flaring outward just enough to create rough space and deny a clean finish. Piguaquan gave that space and took it in the same breath. He slipped off to Jigen-ryū’s right side, his foot sliding across chalk. His right hand, the whipping rope, snapped back across the jawline again and again: three quick backhands, each turning the head a fraction more. In that broken cadence, he stepped behind Jigen-ryū’s right foot and sealed it—heel touching heel. His left forearm wrapped across the chest and pressed back, not a choke, a bar. He pulled with the forearm and pushed with the left hip, a rotational throw without flourish. Jigen-ryū went over the trapped heel, spine arcing, shoulders hitting dust. He rolled to his side immediately, as trained, trying to regain feet. Piguaquan was there before the roll completed. He knelt on the near upper arm, pinning it with a sharp knee, and set his right palm on Jigen-ryū’s throat. Not crushing—just asserting. His left hand cocked back, the forearm a whip ready to crack again. The bell did not ring. The crowd was a roar, then a hush, then Jigen-ryū’s corner shouting his name with four sharp syllables. He looked up along the line of the palm at his throat, past the red-and-black wrap on the wrist, to the eyes above—eyes from the street, hard and honest in their contempt. He felt the ice of humiliation under the heat in his cheek. He exhaled. His hands opened where they lay in the dust. Piguaquan’s left forearm did not fall. He held the pose one more breath. A thread of blood ran from the split on his brow down his nose and dripped onto Jigen-ryū’s armband, a bright red dot on lacquer. Then he pulled his right palm away and rocked back off the pin. He stood with a wince, half-bowed to no one and nothing, and stepped back over the chalk. Jigen-ryū rolled up to a knee. He stared at the chalk line, at the stones, at the stain where his blood met dust. He stood slowly, every motion controlled, even in defeat. The crowd split in reactions—exultation and fury braided into the same volume. Money changed hands with laughter and teeth. Someone hurled an insult like a hook. Someone else spat through the empty doorway into the night. Above, through the broken roof, the stars did not flinch. The two men looked at each other across the ring, old ghosts at their shoulders. Their armbands were the same colors—red and black—but the debts they wore were not equal. Tonight, one was paid in full and another marked to accrue with interest. Their masters could forbid, their elders could sneer, their schools could write new lines in their secret histories. None of it would change the fact that in the crumbling bones of a failed temple, on a chalk circle and broken tile, speed
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This martial arts narrative demonstrates exceptional technical precision in depicting a fight sequence between two stylistically contrasting fighters. The author has created a vivid, physically coherent battle that meticulously tracks the fighters' positions, movements, and techniques throughout. The piece excels at physical choreography, with each strike, counter, and positional shift clearly articulated. The author demonstrates deep knowledge of martial arts biomechanics, using precise terminology and detailed descriptions of weight shifts, angles of attack, and body mechanics. The spatial dynamics are consistently maintained, allowing readers to visualize the fight's progression through the abandoned temple setting. Character differentiation is strong, with the Jigen-ryū fighter portrayed as more rigid, powerful, and direct in his approach, while the Piguaquan practitioner employs circular, whipping movements and evasive footwork. These stylistic differences are maintained throughout the fight, reinforcing the cultural and philosophical contrasts between the two martial traditions. The setting is effectively established with atmospheric details of the abandoned temple, broken roof, and chalk circle. The author creates a sense of illicit underground fighting culture through descriptions of the divided crowd and their betting behaviors. The prose style is technically proficient, employing varied sentence structures and rhythms that mirror the pace of the fight. Short, punchy sentences convey explosive movements, while longer, flowing sentences capture circular techniques and momentum shifts. The author uses vivid metaphors and sensory details that enhance rather than distract from the action. However, the narrative ends abruptly mid-sentence with "speed," suggesting the response was cut off before completion. This prevents a proper resolution to the fight and the emotional aftermath that would have provided closure to the narrative arc. While the fight itself is exceptionally well-choreographed, the character development remains somewhat limited to their fighting styles rather than deeper personal motivations beyond the school rivalry. The piece occasionally veers into overly technical language that might challenge readers unfamiliar with martial arts terminology, though this aligns with the prompt's request for physical coherence and precise depiction of techniques. Some metaphors, while vivid, occasionally border on purple prose ("a crescent of red at Jigen-ryū's lower lip," "eyes from the street, hard and honest in their contempt"). Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted martial arts narrative that fulfills the prompt's requirements for physical coherence and technical precision. The author demonstrates mastery of fight choreography, spatial awareness, and the ability to differentiate fighting styles through detailed physical description. Despite the abrupt ending and some limitations in character depth, the piece succeeds as a vivid depiction of an underground martial arts duel between contrasting fighting traditions. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 15 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 16 Emotionally Complex: 14 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 15.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 16.0, Emotionally Complex: 14.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 5.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 17.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Physical-spatial: Breaking Formation — Score: 89.5
Prompt:
**"Breaking Formation"** Write a first-person narrative from the perspective of a street dancer from a rough neighborhood who's won a scholarship to an elite K-pop training academy in Seoul. Desperately out of place culturally and technically, they struggle with a militaristically precise choreography that contradicts everything about their improvisational background. The punishing rehearsal takes place under a famous instructor known for breaking students to remake them, who sees potential in the narrator's raw talent but not their attitude. This scene MUST maintain complete physical coherence—each dance move, position shift, and spatial relationship must be tracked with precision throughout the studio. Paint an exceptionally vivid kinetic picture through descriptions that capture not just movement but the contrast between the narrator's fluid, expressive style and the mechanical precision demanded. Their internal monologue should reveal culture shock, class anxiety, and the threatening realization that success here might mean losing their authentic movement voice. Include technical terminology that highlights the collision of street and commercial styles, moments when muscle memory betrays them, and a crucial decision point about whether to conform or rebel. Physical clarity is essential—readers must be able to visualize exactly how bodies move through space, how rhythms align or clash, and how the protagonist's body struggles against unfamiliar discipline. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The speakers in each corner blast the track a hair too loud, symmetrical cubes of sound that press the air flat. The bass is a grid; it pins my ribs to the tempo like thumbtacks. The studio is clean enough to feel hostile: sprung maple floor, full mirrors from ankle to ceiling, black tape marking formations at precise intervals—one line dead center, two flanking lines, a diagonal slash of X’s near upstage right. We're arranged in five rows of five, two meters apart, center marks glowing off our socks in fluorescent reflection. I'm in Row 4, Position 3—the far left if you count from downstage right. I count because it keeps me from drowning in all this order. Back home our formation was a circle that kept breaking and reforming, a ripple of bodies, but here bodies click into place like furniture. My spot is exactly one forearm length from the tape at stage left. “Again,” says Daesuk-nim, and it sounds like a gavel. He stands near downstage center, arms folded behind him, his face set to neutral. Legend says he breaks you and builds you back precise as a metronome. He’s the only person in the room I can’t track by mirror; he stands slightly off the line of our reflection so my eyes have to choose. When I meet his gaze in the glass, he lifts a chin at my knees. “Lower.” The count is 5-6-7-8, sliding in like a boot under a door. I catch my breath on beat one. Beat 1-2: Bodies explode to a first position that isn’t ballet’s first but K-pop’s: feet parallel under hips, knees soft, weight centered. Arms shoot to clean 90-degree angles—right arm up in a high V, left arm out at shoulder height—while the head looks dead front, eyes level. My right arm, city-schooled, wants to travel, to arc. I lock it into a straight line, triceps burning. Beat 3-4: We snap into a tutting box—forearms bending inward, wrists flexed so the fingers point up, edges square. The geometry is supposed to match the grid of the bass. My left wrist gives me away—muscle memory wants to melt the angle, roll to a wave. “No wave,” barks the assistant captain from Row 2 without looking back. The left side of the mirror shows my frame bleeding at the corner, a soggy square surrounded by razor blades. Beat 5: Step touch right, left foot dragging in a half-beat behind, chest isolating left-right-left. It’s a basic commercial groove, machine-made. In the mirror, twenty-five bodies tick tock together. My chest wants to spiral, a figure-eight, weight sinking on the inside edge. I force it into a pendulum, straight-line, micro-paused accents. Beat 6-7-8: Hit a chest pop, snap both arms down to the hips, wrists flexed forward like stop signs. Left foot steps to second position exactly on the line of tape. Our coach pauses the track mid-sub beat. The room holds breath like it's a single drum. My sneakers lift dust that doesn’t exist in this place. “Left foot is on line,” Daesuk-nim says without pointing. He doesn’t have to; the floor is a map. “Hand angles… Ji-won, correct the third finger.” He walks upstage like a cat and stops three stations right of me. His shoes do not squeak. He nods once at me. “Lower.” I bend my knees further than they want to go, quads screaming. Back on the block, my plies were always open, knees tracking over toes so I could drop into a floor freeze, catch a hit, explode. Here it’s unison depth—everyone’s thighs level, knees at identical angles. If you’re not at 90 degrees, you might as well be in a different city. He claps once. The speakers punch the first bar back in. We run the chorus. Eight-count phrases stack on top of each other like cement. The move that’s killing me comes at the end of the second eight: Eight-count 1, 2, 3: Right foot steps to diagonal out, left foot cross-behinds on the and count, whole body tilts at fifteen degrees to upstage right. Arms slice into a level L—right arm forward, left out. Head follows the line of the right forearm. Precision. I hit the diagonal and feel stable. Count 4: We hook the right heel behind the left, sink to a demi-pointe on the left, drive a right elbow back into our imaginary spine, chest isolation hitting forward then back on the and count. My chest wants to mush it into one wave, to chew and swallow the beat. I bite it into two clean pops. My scapula stutters, reluctant. Count 5-6: A body roll is supposed to ripple from sternum to pelvis, but not here—here it’s segmented, neck-jaw-chest-abs. Each vertebra is a click track. I can do a roll that looks like smoke; this is more like a zipper. My instinct is to pause my head and make it a breath; the mirror shows the head going first, jaw jutting on the and. I move my jaw like a marionette, hate the feeling. Count 7: Step left to wide second, drop to a deep plie. Arms shoot down into a blade. We prepare a knee swivel, weight in the middle, pelvis neutral. No hips. “And eight”: Everyone snaps their heels together like a camera shutter. I kiss the heels and accidentally add a tiny heel-toe bounce—a ghost of a top rock. The mirror betrays me with a flicker. The girl to my right, Hana, glances without moving her head.
