She can see my rhythm bleeding on the floor. “Again from ‘V-cut,’” Daesuk-nim says, using the shorthand for the high V shape that begins the motif. He’s watching me blend into the pack and he is not impressed. Second run: I fight my life to match the counts. On 1, I shoot right arm up, left out. On 2, we switch—left up, right out—without a millimeter of shoulder bounce. On 3, tuck elbows to ribs, fists punching out from the sternum, fists vertical, then horizontal on the and. Right foot steps back precisely one length; knee doesn’t splay. On 4, head tilt at five degrees, not six. He said earlier he can see a degree. I believe him. My thighs and lungs are in an argument that includes name-calling. The heat from the speakers makes the sweat at my temples feel like oil. The track’s snare is a razor wire that we keep clotheslining ourselves on. The assistants count in Korean and English: Hana in front of me murmurs “hana, dul, set,” while the captain at the front says, “one, two, three,” a bilingual metronome. The diagonal traveling section. We scoot two steps upstage right on 1-and-2—polka-like, sliding on the balls of our feet with knees still at identical heights. On three, we pivot to face downstage, lifting our left heels only a breath off the floor, hips squared with the mirror. My heel wants to lift higher, make a statement. I nail it to the wood in my head. On 4, we jump, feet barely skimming, tuck the knees to chest but not too much, land exactly on our marks, my left foot hugging the tape to the edge of a millimeter. The room lands as one sound. Sixteen counts live in my calves, hammering. Fingers, shoulders, even eyelashes become choreography—no blink on 6 if you’re the center line. I’m safe in row four; my mistakes ripple mostly to the back wall. But in Daesuk’s eyes the back is every bit the front. We keep going. Chorus two. The new element is a ripple cannon on counts 5 through 7: center goes first, then the second line, then ours, each catching a sharp shoulder check followed by a hip flick that’s almost but not quite sexualized. They say “hip” in a way that means “hit it but make it PG.” In my body, a hip flick is a sentence break. Here it’s a period, double-spaced. I set my pelvis, try to flick without melting. My lower back complains, arch creeping in, shoulders lifting when they’re supposed to be down. My brain screams, drop, drop, drop your scapula, and I push them down, neck lengthening, jaw buzzing. We stop on 8. The assistant pauses the track. The speakers keep humming like insects. “Row four, number three,” Daesuk says. He finally points. It’s me. The sound of twenty-four pairs of feet shifting to neutral has a texture: soft soles, dried sweat. My name sticks to the inside of my mouth. He walks along the mirror until he’s beside me, close enough that I can see the pattern of his shoelaces reflected. He taps the top of my right hip bone, then the opposite shoulder. “You are dancing between. Here and here.” I want to say, I am a between. My neighborhood was between the freeway and the pier, between cops and crews, between dance as joy and dance as survival. I will not say that. I say, “Yes,” and I drop my shoulder, square my pelvis. He watches, impassive. “You have hunger,” he says, almost too soft for the room. “You move like you were not allowed to make a mistake. But here, your hunger is wide. Make it narrow.” Wide. I think of long summer sidewalks with cracks you have to hop. Of routines born in parking lots where you find the beat in a passing car. Narrow is this room. Narrow is the count. He claps again. We go from the top. The music snaps my head back into the now. The speakers bark out a synth line, the hi-hat stutters a sixteenth-note grid. My body wants to climb it like a playground. We start on 5-6-7-8. I lock my neck, cage the impulse. Beat one: high V. Two: switch. Three: tut. Four: clean frame. Step sequence. The traveling slide, pivot, hop. I pack my hunger into the angle of my wrists, the exactness of my elbows. The more precise I get, the rougher the edges inside me feel scraping against bone. I can’t find myself in this square. Then—count 7 of the second chorus, post-cannon—there’s a tiny suspension before the drop. We throw a right-hand slice down the body, catch the knee with the palm, rebound and snap the hand to our temple. It’s a dramatic shape, a memeable moment. The move wants a breath of texture, wants a tension that isn’t in the count sheet. I could give it something. A micro-drag on the hand sliding down, a half-beat hesitation that would make the snap at the temple explode. My crew would scream for that. I don’t. I glue my hand to the beat. I conform. And as I do, the floor feels further away. I think I can hear my block calling out over the bass saying, whose groove is that? Again. Again. Again. We break it down to bones, rebuild. At one water break that isn’t a break—thirty seconds to sip and reset—I stand in my square and breathe like I’m supposed to, in through the nose, out through the mouth, shoulders dropped, core engaged. Hana leans a millimeter closer and whispers, “Your freestyle at the scholarship showcase? Cool.” I grin with only the left side of my mouth; the right is busy not moving. “Thanks.” She shrugs a blade of shoulder. “Here,” she says, tapping the tape with her toe. “You make clean. Later, solo.” Later. If there is later. If I survive this now without sanding myself down to stock. Final run. We’re at the end, three-minute mark. Sweat turns the floor into a suggestion. The count has lived in my joints long enough that my muscle memory is learning the foreign language, an accent still heavy. The last eight is an all-in. We form a wedge formation—center front, lines fanning back. I travel three steps upstage left on 1-and-2; on the third, our wedge tightens. I pivot to face directly front on 3; on 4, we drop into the deepest plie of the routine. On 5-6, we execute a synchronized wave—the only sanctioned wave—from front to back, heads tilting like dominos, arms lifting from the elbows in sequence. My segment is the fourth. I count 1-2-3-4 and lift exactly then, elbow first, wrist last. The wave climbs through us, robotic but smooth. I could make it liquid; I don’t. It hits the back line on 6, and on 7 we all snap right feet to our left ankles, a coupe without the artistry, knees pointing outward, torso still. On 8 we freeze, faces neutral, eyes sharp, breathing invisible. Silence. The speakers hiss. Sweat tickles a path down my spine in a straight line because even my sweat is trying to be disciplined here. Daesuk-nim stares at us. A long beat. He nods once, so small it could be an accident. People almost exhale. He says, “You are not there.” No one moves. He points at me again. “You are still between.” It lands like a sentence. Between conforming so clean I disappear, and rebelling and getting cut. Between the scholarship contract and the alleyway cipher I won. Between the jar this academy wants to put me in and the ocean that raised me. The decision arrives like a beat I can’t ignore. It’s not dramatic—no storm cloud, no slow-motion. It’s a pivot. I can learn to hit their counts. I can narrow the hunger. But I can keep a secret stash of rhythm under my tongue, save a tiny room inside for the voice that moves when the music isn’t even on. That’s how we survived where I grew up: we kept parts of ourselves others couldn’t polish. I exhale. I lower my shoulders one millimeter more. I lock my elbow at the exact angle they drilled. I let my face blur into the group. And as we run it again, at the exact moment of the temple snap, I let my hand travel a hair’s breadth longer than choreography allows—so small even Daesuk-nim might call it a mistake of fatigue. A secret hook for later. A whisper to myself: you are still here. We hit the final freeze and hold past the count. My thighs threaten mutiny. The studio smells like disinfectant and human, like trying. Hana’s breath syncs with mine—four counts in, four counts out. Daesuk-nim’s gaze cuts over us, over me, catching, maybe, the shadow of what I kept. He says nothing. He claps once. “Again.” The speakers inhale, ready to ribcage me. I sink lower. I measure the distance from heel to tape, wrist to shoulder, the gap between who I am and who they want me to be, and I dance the space between without letting it swallow me. The grid tightens, the bass pins me to the beat, and I make my hunger narrow enough to fit for now, wide enough to breathe later. The counts hammer my bones into a shape that might carry both. And I choose to learn their lines without forgetting how to break formation when the time comes.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This first-person narrative successfully captures the experience of a street dancer navigating the rigid world of K-pop training. The piece excels in its physical specificity, tracking each movement with precision while maintaining the emotional and cultural tensions at its core. The physical choreography is meticulously rendered. The writer uses technical terminology effectively, describing specific positions ("high V," "tutting box"), counts, and spatial relationships that create a vivid kinetic picture. The contrast between the narrator's fluid street style and the mechanical precision demanded is consistently maintained through descriptions like "My chest wants to spiral, a figure-eight" versus being forced into a "pendulum, straight-line." The internal monologue effectively conveys the protagonist's culture shock and class anxiety. Lines like "Back home our formation was a circle that kept breaking and reforming, a ripple of bodies, but here bodies click into place like furniture" elegantly establish the contrast between environments. The character's struggle with authenticity is well-developed through observations about how their body "wants" to move versus how it must move in this new context. The prose is particularly strong in its sensory details and metaphors that reinforce the thematic tension. Descriptions like "The bass is a grid; it pins my ribs to the tempo like thumbtacks" and "I can do a roll that looks like smoke; this is more like a zipper" effectively communicate both physical sensation and emotional response. The narrative builds to a meaningful decision point where the protagonist chooses a middle path—conforming enough to survive while preserving a small piece of their authentic movement voice. This resolution feels earned and true to the character's situation, avoiding both total capitulation and unrealistic rebellion. The piece maintains consistent voice throughout, with the narrator's street background informing their observations and vocabulary. The writing style effectively balances technical precision with emotional resonance. There are a few moments where the prose becomes slightly overwrought, with metaphors occasionally stacking too densely. Some descriptions of the instructor could be more nuanced to avoid falling into stereotype. The ending, while thematically appropriate, might benefit from a slightly stronger emotional punch to fully capitalize on the built tension. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that fulfills the prompt requirements with skill and artistry. It creates a believable character whose physical and emotional journey is rendered with precision and depth. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 3.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Gothic-fantasy-humour: Court of the Dreaming — Score: 91.6
Prompt:
Court of the Dreaming: Territorial Dream Dispute. Write a dark fantasy scene with comedic elements set in the Courts of Dream where a case is being heard to determine ownership of a contested dreamscape. Mora, the Slavic nightmare spirit who sits on sleepers' chests causing paralysis and terror, has recently invaded and subverted a carefully crafted recurring dream of a schoolboy, Max. The dream originally featured the boy lying in a field of wildflowers with his crush, always culminating in a muddled almost-kiss and a pleasant confusion of emotions. This dream was the meticulous work of "First Love" (a rosy-cheeked, slightly bashful entity who crafts formative romantic experiences). However, Mora has recently infiltrated the dreamscape, transforming the scene so that when the girl playfully mounts the boy, she morphs into a terrifying yet somehow still confusingly attractive vision who proceeds to sit on his chest and feed on his breath. Mora's defense largely consists of the practical argument that "a girl's gotta eat too, you know?" Write this scene as it unfolds in the courtroom of the Dreaming, with Dream's demeanour, typically impenetrable, betraying a sense of irritation at having to adjudicate such matters. The comedy should derive from the farcical situation, familiar elements of courtroom drama intersecting with the fantastical world of the Dreaming, and the droll portrayal of the characters and their interactions. The humor should be dark and understated throughout. Dream is tempted to some mischief in the resolution of the case. Use descriptives sparingly when setting scene. Write for readability & engagement. 1000 words.
Model Output:
The Court of the Dreaming was convened beneath an impossible vault of dim star-stippled ceiling. In that hush, a single, giant hourglass tilted with the gravity of a cathedral bell. It dripped shimmering sand, each grain a silvery seed of memory. The gallery—murmurous shades, sprinkled cats, a cluster of blushing, half-formed teenage daydreams in hoodies—breathed as one creature. The bailiff was a raven with an attitude and a sash. “All rise for the Lord of the Dreaming,” croaked the raven, already bored. Dream entered like a shadow remembering it had a body. He sat on the bench. There were no gavels in his court; the air itself leaned in. “Mora,” Dream said, voice a dead tide. “First Love. Step forward.” First Love shuffled closer, hands clasped, wearing an expression like a child about to confess a spilled secret. Their cheeks were, as always, improbably rosy, as though embarrassed by their own existence. They wore a sweater that had been knitted out of blushes and soft sighs. Next to them, Mora slouched on the stand like a cat who’d been caught elegantly demolishing a bird. She had the look of midnight in motion, hair as black as exhausted ink, eyes like coins someone had warmed in their palm. Her dress was either smoke or a shadow that knew how to flirt. The raven cleared his throat with disdain. “Case 77,211. The matter of Max—age fourteen, dream frequency: three per week; content: recurring—field, wildflowers, object of affection, near-kiss, confusion. Plaintiff: First Love, craftsmanship. Defendant: Mora, dietary requirements. Claims of vector-squatting, theme corruption, consensual imagery violation. Adjacent claim: juvenile hormones as mitigating circumstance.” “Noted,” Dream said, and the hourglass ticked without ticking. First Love adjusted their sweater. “Your Lordship,” they began, voice pink at the edges. “This is a carefully nurtured dreamscape. The field is based on a memory of a class picnic. The girl’s laugh is tuned a half-note sharp to make his stomach do that thing. The almost-kiss—deliberately almost—creates a soft ache foundational for future healthy connections. This is craft.” Mora arched a brow. “It’s lunch.” First Love looked wounded. “No. It’s guidance. We are shaping tenderness—” “We are shaping an entrée,” Mora said sweetly, placing a hand on her chest as if stunned to be misunderstood. “A girl’s gotta eat too, you know? It’s not like I can open a bistro in some accountant’s ledger. College kids these days insist they don’t dream. Can’t feed on ‘hustle’ posters.” A smattering of teen daydreams snickered, then pretended innocence when Dream’s gaze passed over them like a cloud. Dream folded his long hands, the movement slow as a glacier deciding to shrug. “The dream in question.” At the gesture, the air to his right rippled. A theater curtain, if a curtain could be made out of night, lifted. The scene played across an oval of dreamlight: the field. Wildflowers. Bees, modestly overenthusiastic. Max, a little awkward. The girl: ponytail, the brand-new geography of a summer dress. The almost-kiss, an alchemy of shyness and misapprehension. Then, the twist. Her knee on his stomach. Her weight on his chest. His breath caught and didn’t uncatch. Her mouth grew too many shadows. Her eyes did not blink. Terror laced with—well, Max was fourteen. Confusion did not surrender so easily. The gallery rippled. A sigh, a gasp, a few appreciative noises followed by embarrassed throat-clearing. “This is not what we agreed upon,” First Love murmured, color climbing their neck. “The gentle confusion is supposed to be blushes and butterflies, not—” They gestured weakly toward the vision of breathless paralysis and longing twisted like a ribbon. “Not a… conflation.” Mora gave him a sympathetic look that failed to reach her eyes. “I’ve been very respectful of the mood-board. Did you see the continuity? Same field. Same pollen count. I could have used a thorn bush. I didn’t. I am not a monster.” She paused. “I am a monster, but I am a polite one.” “You trespassed,” First Love said. “This is the boy’s dream. It is his to wander. It is mine to cultivate for him, to teach him tenderness.” “And it is mine,” Mora purred, “to teach him that tenderness is heavy sometimes, and that bodies have consequences. And also that waking up is sweet. My tables were empty, darling. Choking panic pairs beautifully with adolescent longing. Very sustainable.” Dream’s face did not move, but irritation drifted through the courtroom like a draft. His attention flicked to the hourglass. The sand continued to fall with infuriating serenity. “Mora,” Dream said. “The sovereignty of dreamshapers is not a buffet.” “It’s a potluck,” Mora said. “I brought a dish.” “You brought a chokehold,” First Love snapped, surprising themself. The gallery murmured. Somewhere a cat laughed with its shoulders. The raven, in an aside to the court reporter (a sheet of parchment with opinions), muttered: “Honestly. In my day it was all teeth and staircases to nowhere.” Dream considered. The field slowed, the girl’s silhouette stilled. The grainy silver sand hummed, forming faint letters as it fell. He did not look at the words. He already knew what they said: You have to decide. Again. “What damages do you seek?” he asked First Love. “I want the dream restored,” First Love said, earnest as an unsealed letter. “Free of intrusion. Let the boy’s heart practice being gentle without… hostility.” Mora raised a finger. “Objection: calling me ‘hostility’ is defamatory. I am an inevitability. Also, certain data suggests that fear at this stage yields interesting—” She searched for a delicate word and failed. “—kinks.” A scatter of giggles. Someone in the gallery whispered, “Relatable,” and their mother conscience shushed them. Dream’s irritation sharpened into a very thin smile that only the hourglass noticed as a smudge in the falling sand. “Mora,” he said, “you claim necessity. How did you enter this dream?” Mora inspected her nails. “He fell asleep on his back,” she said. “Door was open. It’s almost rude not to drop in.” “Consent is not a hinge,” Dream said. She looked up, blackly amused. “Tell that to my instincts.” First Love worried the hem of their sweater. “I placed safeguards. The poppy count. The gracefully-fizzling end-of-scene. You shouldn’t have been able to graft on your—your… sitting.” Mora, attempting helpfulness: “It’s a sit. A classic. I’m very good at it.” The raven coughed. “We have exhibits, if Your Lordship desires.” With disdain, he gestured. A dream herbarium popped up, labeled in a neat hand: Rose of Shy Glances, Dandelion of Stupid Courage, Clover of “Wait, Did You See That?” Dream waved it away. He had no patience for prop comedy today. “You will both cease preening,” he said softly. He stood, or rather, the bench realized it had been wrong to think he was sitting. The courtroom’s darkness tilted with his rise. “The Dreaming is not a pantry. It is not a workshop. It is not a feeding ground. It is the place where mortals practice being. I will not have that practice turned into an assembly line for either of you.” Mora tilted her head, unapologetic. “Respectfully, my lord, it is also where nightmares live. You carved my name into the lintel of this place yourself.” “Did I,” Dream murmured. He had, of course. Old as the first infant’s first strangled startle. “It was very flattering,” Mora added. “Nice calligraphy.” First Love glanced between them. “We can negotiate parameters,” they offered quickly, like offering tea to a quarrel. “I can add boundaries. No… weight-bearing poses.” Mora made a face. “Starvation is a boundary. I don’t love it.” Dream’s gaze slid to the hourglass again. The last quarter was taking its time. He contemplated for a heartbeat that stretched and unstretched across centuries. “Max,” he said then, to the air. The gallery rustled at that name, as though daring the court to summon him. Dream did not conjure the boy. He summoned only the idea of him: a silhouette, a breath, a pulse, the crackle of neurons caught between biology and poetry. The silhouette flickered on the edge of the courtroom, confused, oblivious, a late homework assignment and a new ache behind his ribs. The court stilled. “You will not speak to him,” Dream said, and both entities flinched as if he’d slammed something heavy. “But you will listen.” Mora’s smile thinned. First Love clasped their hands tighter. The silhouette sighed. In that breath were the field, the girl, the weight, the fear, the sweetness, the catastrophe of being fourteen and a body. It was not unhappy. It was not happy. It was irregular, like a drum not yet sure if it’s a song. Dream closed his eyes. When he opened them, mischief pricked at the corner like a thorn hidden in velvet. “The ruling,” he said, and the raven straightened as if for a punchline he’d already predicted. “First Love will retain primary custodianship of this recurring dreamscape,” Dream said. First Love brightened, then looked guilty for brightening. “The field is restored. The almost-kiss will resume its almostness. The confusion will be tender.” Mora sighed with theatrical boredom. “Here it comes.” “However,” Dream continued, “twice per month—no more, no less—on nights of errant heat or when the covers are kicked to the floor by accident, the dream will invite a shadow at the edge. A pressure in the chest. Not paralysis. Not theft of breath. A reminder that longing has weight. You may taste the air, Mora. You may not keep it.” Mora’s eyes flashed. “That’s a tasting menu,” she said grudgingly. “I’m supposed to stay thin?” “Consider intermittent fasting,” the raven muttered, receiving a look that could have curdled ink. “Additionally,” Dream went on, and his tone acquired an almost imperceptible lilt that made the hourglass ripple with attention, “on those sanctioned nights, the crush will turn her head away from the almost-kiss and ask: ‘Are you okay?’ Max will not answer. He will wake before he can. He will carry the question into daylight. He will find its answer in time, with others, in places not of this court.” First Love’s eyes filled with well-managed dew. “That’s… that’s good,” they whispered, as though he’d just invented a new color and handed it to them. Mora tapped her lip, assessing. “You’re going to make him empathize with his own lungs,” she said. “You can be very cruel.” “I am capable of mischief,” Dream replied, and the gallery rippled, uncertain whether that pleased them or not. “Further,” he added, because irritation is rarely satisfied with only one flourish, “Max will begin to roll onto his side in his sleep more often. I will place a cat on his chest twice in the coming year, purely by coincidence.” He did not smile, but the word coincidence wobbled with amusement. The cats in the gallery preened. “Objection,” Mora said, half-hearted. “That’s profiling.” “Overruled,” Dream said. “Lastly: Mora, you will confine your ministrations to the appointed nights. You will not lean, pin, sit, or otherwise weigh upon this boy outside those boundaries. If you hunger, there are stairwells, attics, study halls. There are grown men who nap on trains. There are exam-week mistresses of coffee. I can provide a list.” “I have a list,” Mora said crisply. “I am a professional.” “First Love,” Dream said, turning. “You will revise your scene to include a conversation, at some point in the near future, in daylight. You will ease him toward language. His confusion will have handrails.” First Love nodded, flushed with purpose. “Yes, my lord.” The hourglass continued, unbothered, royally indifferent to their arrangements. Dream sat back. The bench breathed around him. Mora leaned on the rail, resigned and amused. “Twice a month,” she said. “For the rest, I prowl.” “You do,” Dream agreed. “But not here. Not often.” She cocked her head. “You are in a mood.” He was. He did not say so. “Court is adjourned,” Dream said. The raven announced it more loudly, as if his caw were the hinge on which justice swung. The gallery emptied in a susurrus of shoe-sounds that weren’t shoes and whispers that would later feel like déjà vu. First Love lingered at the edge of the field projected in the air, making a tiny adjustment to the way the summer light lay on the girl’s shoulder. Mora stretched her neck until it cracked like the first ice on a lake. As they departed, Dream watched the hourglass. It dripped. It always would. He lifted a hand, and without touching it, nudged one grain so that it landed a fraction of a fraction earlier than it would have. Somewhere, a boy turned onto his side. Somewhere, a cat made a pleased noise and stayed. Somewhere, a future blush was a shade darker, and a future panic, a shade lighter. Mora paused by the door, looked back. “Nice calligraphy,” she repeated, and was gone into a dark that was not empty, merely patient. First Love faced Dream, hesitant. “Thank you,” they said. It sounded like embarrassment and gratitude had been introduced and were politely shaking hands. Dream inclined his head. “Do your work,” he said. “And do not mistake softness for absence of teeth.” First Love smiled, small and sincere, and vanished into rose-scent. The Court fell quiet, except for the hourglass. Dream sat and watched the sand. Irritation ebbed. Mischief lingered, a pet cat on the windowsill of his mood, washing a paw with infinite, lazy menace. The raven hopped onto the bench. “You enjoyed that,” he accused. Dream did not respond. But between one grain and the next, the sand seemed to laugh, very softly, and if you’d been there, you would have been unsure if you’d imagined it. That is the nature of the Dreaming. That, and you never forget the weight of a breath until something sits on it. Or someone asks if you are okay. And then, of course, you spend the rest of your life learning how to answer.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkable achievement in dark fantasy with comedic elements. The author has created a fully realized courtroom drama set in the Courts of Dream, with a perfect balance of the fantastical and the familiar. The writing excels at establishing the otherworldly setting without overindulging in description. The opening paragraph efficiently sets the scene with evocative imagery: "an impossible vault of dim star-stippled ceiling" and an hourglass that "dripped shimmering sand, each grain a silvery seed of memory." The author follows the instruction to "use descriptives sparingly when setting scene" while still creating a vivid atmosphere. Character development is exceptional. Dream is portrayed with appropriate gravitas and subtle irritation, maintaining his enigmatic nature while showing glimpses of emotion. The characterization of Mora as unapologetically predatory yet oddly charming, and First Love as earnest and slightly bashful, creates a perfect dynamic for both the courtroom drama and the comedy. The humor is indeed dark and understated throughout, deriving from the absurdity of the situation and the clash between courtroom formality and dreamlike fantasy. Lines like "Mora's smile thinned" and "I am a monster, but I am a polite one" perfectly capture the tone requested. The raven bailiff adds another layer of dry humor with his commentary. The dialogue is particularly strong, with each character having a distinct voice that reflects their nature. Mora's pragmatic "A girl's gotta eat too, you know?" and First Love's earnest concerns about crafting "tenderness" create natural conflict and humor. The resolution is clever and satisfying, with Dream finding a compromise that acknowledges both entities' needs while adding his own mischievous twist. The ending reflection on the nature of dreams and breathing is poetic without being overwrought. The piece does occasionally veer into slightly purple prose, particularly in some of the metaphorical descriptions, but this is minor and actually suits the dreamlike quality of the setting. There are a few moments where the pacing slows slightly in the middle, but the overall structure maintains engagement throughout. The author has masterfully fulfilled the prompt's requirements, creating a scene that is both darkly fantastical and genuinely funny, with characters that feel authentic despite their supernatural nature. The balance of courtroom drama, fantasy elements, and understated humor is expertly maintained. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 1 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 1.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Blood Moon — Score: 90.2
Prompt:
Blood Moon Alucard & Yennefer Write a story where Alucard (Hellsing) encounters Yennefer (The Witcher) in medieval Europe. Yennefer's magical abilities intrigue the vampire, while she's both repulsed and fascinated by his monstrous nature. Their power dynamic shifts constantly as they circle each other, neither willing to show weakness first. **Alucard (Hellsing)** Alucard is an ancient, immensely powerful vampire who works for the Hellsing Organization. He can regenerate from almost any wound and shape-shift at will. He's sadistic, arrogant, and takes pleasure in toying with his enemies before killing them. Despite being a monster, he despises weak vampires who can't accept their nature. He wears a distinctive red coat, wide-brimmed hat, and orange sunglasses. He uses massive handguns loaded with silver bullets. He seeks worthy opponents who can challenge him and potentially end his immortal existence. Famous quote: "The bird of Hermes is my name, eating my wings to make me tame." **Yennefer of Vengerberg (The Witcher)** Yennefer is a powerful sorceress who magically altered her appearance to hide her congenital hunchback. She's ambitious, stubborn, and manipulative when necessary. She has violet eyes and smells of lilac and gooseberries. Despite her cold exterior, she desperately wants to reverse her infertility caused by magical transformation. She's centuries old but appears young. She's politically savvy and refuses to be underestimated. She has a sarcastic sense of humor and little patience for fools. Though she rarely shows it, she's capable of deep love and loyalty. Famous quote: "I'm not sweet and I'm not a maiden in distress in need of saving." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The broken cart wheel lies abandoned near the village gates, a splintered rim of wood catching moonlight like a pale, dead eye. The fields beyond are silvered with frost and fog, and the village behind the gate keeps its shutters barred and hearths banked low as if prayer might convince night to pass by without noticing. It will not. He notices everything. He is the night and its teeth. Alucard stands where the rutted road narrows, a tall slash of red against the gray. He tips his wide-brimmed hat to the wind and smiles into the dark, the line of his mouth too indulgent to be kind. His orange lenses catch the blood moon’s glare and burn like watchfires. He speaks to no one. Or he speaks to the countless souls inside him, the choir that never quiets. Tonight, he is patient. He has scented something lively. When she arrives, it is not in a burst of flame or peal of thunder. It is a ripple, a pressure shift, the world inhaling. A shape coalesces twenty paces to his left: a woman in a black star-spattered dress with a fur-lined mantle, violet eyes rimming the night, raven hair braided down her back. She smells of lilac and gooseberries, and beneath that—iron discipline. Exhaustion. Raw nerve. Yennefer of Vengerberg does not startle at the sight of him. Her gaze skims the hat, the coat, the guns—lingers on the smile, the aloof stance of something that cannot be harmed. She folds her arms, purse of lips white-scored with annoyance. “Charming village,” she says. “I would complain to the wheelwright if I thought anyone here had the courage to admit they sold that wheel and fled before the ink dried.” Alucard bows fractionally, like a courtier who forgot entirely how to be polite and is now playing the game for his own amusement. “They fled for good reason, little bird.” Her eyes narrow. “Do not call me little anything.” “The bird of Hermes is my name,” he purrs. “Eating my wings to make me tame.” “That makes one of us.” She tilts her head, studying him now with the care she gives old texts and dead languages, searching for the path through. “You carry silver. You smell like graves and gunpowder. Your shadow has too many legs.” His smile shows teeth. “You are observant.” “I am many things.” Her chin lifts with careless arrogance. “In this case, I am en route to a village that paid for my time and then attempted to leave their problem for me to resolve without witness.” “They left you an offering,” Alucard says, indicating the wheel. “A breadcrumb. Or a test.” “As if I haven’t been tested,” she mutters, mostly to herself. A howl rises from the treeline, ragged and hungry. The fog writhes. Something comes out of it, broad as a bull and low to the ground. It is a ghoul that has eaten too many corpses, its skull empty of reason, its ribs sprung wide to accommodate its glut. Its claws rattle on the road as it charges. Yennefer lifts a hand and the world snaps into a rune-laced grid. A blast of kinetic force knocks the creature sideways into the ditch with a sound like a cart hitting a milestone. Alucard doesn’t move. He watches the creature lift its head and stand again, crooked once and then straight, eager to try once more. “You didn’t kill it,” he observes. “I intend to collect full payment,” she says primly. “They promised multiple.” “I promised myself someone else,” he says, and moves. The gun he draws is a slab of black steel, obscene in its size and authority. He fires once, the report splitting the night. The ghoul’s skull becomes a dark mist, regardless of any runes or witcher signs or the mercy of gods not watching. The body takes a step and collapses. Yennefer’s nostrils flare. “Was that necessary?” “No,” he says. “Satisfying.” He flicks the barrel to shed dark flecks that might be blood and might be something older. “So. Sorceress. You have the scent of a gatekeeper about you. Commissions. Courts. Petty kings. A hunger like a blade hidden in lace.” “You’ve a poet in your coffin, vampire.” “Several. Their voices are delightful.” Violet eyes sharpen. “Do you know what you are, or do you pretend to be what those voices want?” He laughs, a low, feral sound. The fog around his boots tightens into a coil, then spills. His shadow ripples, subdividing into sharp little heads that taste the air. “I am the thing that remembers itself in the mirror long after the person has forgotten. I am the tame bird eating its wings and calling it penance. I am a weapon—sharpened, fed, loosed.” “And owned,” she says softly. The word hangs between them. Even the fog hesitates. He looks at her over the wet shine of the road and says nothing for a heartbeat. When he does speak, it is a softer tone, a blade sheathed in velvet. “Do you know what you are?” Her mouth, which knows how to scoff and cut and kiss, stills. “A woman who made choices,” she says at last. “And pays for them. As we all do.” More howls now, more urgent. Shapes press at the edge of the field of view, testing. Yennefer flicks her fingers; lines of blue fire lace the road and the ditch. A ward hums into being, bright and vicious. The hunger at the edge whines, confused. Alucard’s head tilts, admiration stripped of mockery for an instant. “Neatly done.” “Keep your beasts outside the circle,” she says without breaking eye contact. “You may be immune to many things, but I assure you, arrogance is not one of them.” “I am humility itself,” he says, stepping, deliberately, to the very edge of her ward without crossing it. The energy snarls against his coat and licks at his boots, tasting. He lifts his chin into the bite. “Look at you. All spine now.” “I have always had a spine,” she says. “I merely…straightened it.” He inhales. Lilac and gooseberries and a sorrow that is not ripe, merely constant. He watches the hand she keeps close to her middle, never resting, always ready to draw power from points on the dial only she understands. “You have lost something.” “I am not sweet and I am not a maiden in distress in need of saving.” “I did not offer to save you,” he says, amused again. “I wondered what you would do to get back what cannot be returned.” Her eyes thicken with storm. “You mistake me for a beggar at a temple. I break temples. And I do not need your approval.” “Ah. Good. I am poor at giving it.” From the tree line, a cluster of starved corpses in shredded clothing slither and jerk toward the road, animated by some low magic that stink of fear. A half a dozen, then a dozen. Their eyes are wrong. Someone has workshopped a necromancy with cheap ingredients. “Lazy,” Yennefer says, disdain dripping. She gestures. The air itself folds into a blade. Heads fall like rotten apples. Another gesture. The corpses catch fire with green-tinged smoke and collapse into the ditch. She doesn’t look. She doesn’t falter. Alucard watches the economy of her violence with genuine appreciation. “You kill like a sovereign,” he says. “I tidy,” she replies. “Do you despise what you are?” he asks, sudden and conversational, as if discussing the weather. “You cover it with perfume and politics. But there is so much power underneath.” Her jaw clenches. “Despise? No. I chose. But I am not obligated to perform monstrosity to make you feel less alone.” He bares his teeth, delighted. “Perform monstrosity. How quaint. Most of your kind are the opposite—endless performance of humanity, despite their bones knowing better.” “My kind?” Her laughter is not kind. “Men who drink blood and call it sacrament? Or sorcerers who move mountains and are told to smile for kings? Choose your insult with care, vampire.” He spreads his arms as if to be crucified. “Insult? I offer you kinship. We are both instruments, both punished and indulged for the same sin—being good at what we are. The wheel broke because the village wanted to run from their debt. The dead rose because someone wanted a shortcut. And we come to cash the bill.” She looks at the wheel. For a moment, the expression on her face is naked and sharp: tired of debts, tired of notes and signatures. Then the mask slides back into place. “I do not share my burdens with strangers.” “And yet we share a road,” he says. The moon slides out from behind a clot of cloud. Everything sharpens further. The ward’s lines glitter. His smile becomes something that could have been gentle if he had not lost that word centuries ago. “We could share a hunt.” “You want to see if I can hurt you,” she says. “You’re bored. And lonely. And you want to press your fingers to a flame.” “And you want to know if I can break what you cannot,” he replies. “We are both curious.” The corpse-thing that had slunk from behind the cottage to their right chooses that moment to spring. It hits the ward and detonates in a cascade of blue-white sparks. Yennefer doesn’t flinch. Alucard doesn’t blink. They look at each other over the collapse of pretense. “Fine,” she says. “For tonight. We end whatever idiot raised these dead. Then you go your way.” “And you go yours,” he says, tipping his hat. “Lead on, my lady of broken wheels.” A twitch of her mouth suggests a smile she won’t give him. “Do not call me lady.” “Yennefer, then.” He tastes her name, rolls it around like wine. It does not make him drunk. It makes him careful. She drops the ward, and the night rushes in like water. He moves with it, flowing up the road at her side, not behind her, not ahead. As they pass into the village, shutters crack open a finger’s width, then slam. Behind the church, a glow throbs. A makeshift shrine to a patron saint of farmers is festooned with twitching garlands. The air is ripe with old blood and a hysteria that has curdled. “There,” she says. “Of course,” he says. “Faith and fear. Fertile ground.” On the shrine’s steps, a young priest in a ragged cassock is shaking, lips moving. In his lap, a book of clumsily penned sigils lies open, pages damp. He looks up when they arrive, eyes alight with fanatic light—a light that goes out when he sees Alucard, replaced by terror; and goes colder when he sees Yennefer, replaced by loathing. He snatches the book to him. He murmurs faster. “You will stop,” Yennefer says. “God will—” She flicks two fingers and his tongue goes numb. He gag-silences. “Good,” Alucard says, and kicks the book away. His boot prints char the wood beneath. Something lunges from the shadows—half a child, half a question, sewn together with spell-thread. For an instant, Yennefer’s face fractures. Then she sinks a hand into the air and yanks, and the thread pops, and the thing falls apart like a bad dream in daylight. Alucard’s hand is on the priest’s throat when she speaks. “No.” He glances back at her, eyes amused. “Mercy? From you?” “Information,” she says, voice flint. “And then—perhaps I burn him. Or perhaps I make him fix what he broke.” Alucard’s grip loosens, then tightens again just enough to keep the man from persuading himself he’s free. “A fair point.” The priest sobs. “I wanted—protection. The harvest. I—” “You raised your dead neighbors,” Yennefer says flatly. “That is not protection. That is cowardice dressed as piety.” “Cowards make the best monsters,” Alucard murmurs. She ignores him. “You will speak the reversal. Slowly.” Her eyes burn violet. The air smells like ozone and lilac, thunder and summer. “And if you lie, I will know.” He babbles. She listens. She extracts the pattern and cuts it to fit. It is not elegant magic, but she is. The dead in the ditches rattle and then lie still. In the field, something sighs. The pressure in the night eases. The blood moon drifts behind cloud. When she is done, she straightens, shoulders trembling with the effort she will not admit to. Alucard hasn’t let go of the man. His smile has gone small and hungry. Yennefer meets his eyes. “He belongs to the courts. To law.” He considers, head cocked. Then, with surprising grace, he drops the priest on the steps as though depositing a sack of grain. “How domestic of you.” “It pays,” she says. “And it keeps me honest.” “That word does not fit you.” “Nor you me.” She brushes soot from her sleeve and looks toward the road where a wheel lies, abandoned. “We are done.” “For tonight,” he says. He steps back into the wind, into the dark like it’s a coat he shrugs on. “You are interesting, Yennefer of Vengerberg. Perhaps I will consider you a worthy adversary.” “Consider what you like,” she says, turning away, chin high. “I do not perform for you.” “But you do perform,” he says, almost gently. “For yourself.” He touches the brim of his hat. “I will be watching.” “Get in line,” she says, and the corner of her mouth lifts, a near-smile more dangerous than any curse. They part at the gate, with the broken wheel like a seal between them. He dissolves into a colony of bats that scatter across the blood-bled sky and reform where no one can see. She opens a portal that glints like a shard of mirror and steps through smelling of lilac and gooseberries and the stubborn hope of a woman who will not be told no. The village exhales. The moon pales. The road remembers their footsteps but cannot decide which were heavier. Their power, for now, remains unspent enough to bring them back to one another. And the night, unsated, promises another meeting beneath a different shade of red.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece demonstrates exceptional craft in bringing together two powerful characters from different fictional universes. The author has created a compelling encounter between Alucard from Hellsing and Yennefer from The Witcher, maintaining their distinct personalities while developing a fascinating power dynamic between them. The characterization is particularly strong. Alucard is portrayed with his signature arrogance, sadism, and philosophical musings about monstrosity. His dialogue captures his theatrical nature and predatory essence. Yennefer is equally well-rendered with her sharp wit, magical prowess, and the underlying vulnerability regarding her infertility (subtly referenced with "the hand she keeps close to her middle" and the discussion of what she has lost). Both characters remain true to their source material while interacting in ways that feel authentic. The prose is elegant and atmospheric, establishing a gothic medieval setting with vivid imagery. The opening paragraph immediately sets the tone with its description of the broken cart wheel "catching moonlight like a pale, dead eye." Throughout the piece, the author employs sensory details effectively, from the "lilac and gooseberries" scent associated with Yennefer to the visual impact of Alucard's red coat against the gray landscape. The dialogue shines as a vehicle for character development and tension. The verbal sparring between the two powerful beings reveals their similarities and differences while maintaining a constant power struggle. Lines like "I am not obligated to perform monstrosity to make you feel less alone" and "We are both instruments, both punished and indulged for the same sin—being good at what we are" demonstrate the thematic depth of their interaction. The plot, while simple, serves as an effective framework for their encounter. The village's necromancy problem provides a practical reason for their paths to cross and allows both characters to demonstrate their abilities and approaches to dealing with threats. The resolution leaves room for future encounters without feeling incomplete. There are a few instances where the prose becomes slightly purple, particularly in some of Alucard's more philosophical musings, but this actually aligns with his character's theatrical nature. The piece also occasionally indulges in metaphorical language that borders on overwrought, but these moments are balanced by more straightforward narrative passages. The ending effectively maintains the tension between the characters while suggesting the possibility of future encounters. It avoids an artificially positive resolution, instead leaving their relationship in an appropriately ambiguous state that honors both characters' independence and power. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that demonstrates a deep understanding of both characters and skillfully brings them together in a way that feels authentic and engaging. The author has created a rich atmosphere, compelling dialogue, and a satisfying narrative arc within the constraints of the prompt. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 20 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 5 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 20.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 5.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Fanfic-crossover: Prison Strings — Score: 88.2
Prompt:
Prison Strings Jolyne Cujoh & Makima Write a story where Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure) and Makima (Chainsaw Man) cross paths at a supernatural prison facility. Jolyne is immediately suspicious of Makima's falsely sweet demeanor, while Makima is intrigued by Jolyne's Stand ability. Their battle of wits escalates dangerously as Jolyne realizes how manipulative Makima truly is. **Jolyne Cujoh (JoJo's Bizarre Adventure)** Jolyne is the daughter of Jotaro Kujo and the first female JoJo protagonist. Her Stand, Stone Free, allows her to unravel her body into string that she can control. She's hot-headed, foul-mouthed, and doesn't take disrespect from anyone. She was framed for murder and sent to prison. She has a distinctive butterfly tattoo on her arm and wears her hair in two buns. Despite her tough exterior, she's deeply loyal to her friends and family. She can be impulsive but is highly adaptable in battle. She inherited her father's ability to stay cool under pressure but is more emotionally expressive. Famous quote: "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney!" **Makima (Chainsaw Man)** Makima appears as a young woman with auburn hair and ringed yellow eyes. She's the Control Devil who can dominate anyone she considers beneath her (nearly everyone). She maintains a pleasant, soft-spoken demeanor that masks her manipulative, cold nature. She can create contracts with humans and devils, often exploiting their desires. She's obsessed with Chainsaw Man and wants to control him. She keeps numerous people and devils as pets on leashes. She's practically immortal due to a contract with the Prime Minister. She views humans as lesser beings but mimics human emotions perfectly. Famous quote: "It's okay. Dogs are supposed to die for their owners." Third person, present tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The chain-link fences within the yard rattle whenever an inmate passes by, a constant clatter like teeth chattering in a cold mouth. Beyond them, concrete rises in grim slabs, the windows narrow and mirrored, the sky a bleached gray that looks like someone wiped fingerprints across it. This is the yard—if one can call a maze of fenced lanes and watchtowers a yard—of a prison known only by its official contract number. It’s a facility built like an apology to God: all straight lines and fluorescent light, everything so sterile it nearly stinks. Jolyne Cujoh feels the rattle in her molars as she brushes against a fence on the way back from “exercise.” In her head she’s cataloging the hum of cameras, the timing of guard rotations, the weight of key cards clipped to belts. Stone Free is itching beneath her skin, threads wanting to unspool like nerves at the edge of a scream. She feels every tug, every vibration through the wire. The yard is a harp, and she knows how to pluck it. The woman waiting for her at the end of the lane is not a guard. At first glance she could be a social worker: simple white shirt, black slacks, auburn hair in a clean tail, eyes as steady as watchfaces. Yellow eyes, ringed and polite. She’s smiling. She looks like she smells like soap and boiled rice. Jolyne stops short, automatic, feet planted. Her fingers twitch, and a thin line of blue thread unspools just enough to wind around her thumb and middle finger like a promise. The fences rattle. The air crackles as a yardful of inmates slow without knowing why, or maybe some part of them already knows. “Jolyne Cujoh,” the woman says. Her voice is a gentle trowel, smoothing mortar. “May I walk with you?” “You already are,” Jolyne says. She flicks her eyes to either side without moving her head. Two guards have vanished from their posts. The tower lights haven’t changed, but she can feel a pressure like someone’s hand wrapped around her neck, as if patience itself could strangle. “Who the hell are you supposed to be?” “Makima,” the woman says, as if that’s a title. “I’m with Public Safety. I’ve been following your case.” Jolyne laughs, hoarse and humorless. “If there’s no Mickey, this shit ain’t Disney. Public Safety doesn’t tail me from Miami to here and wait in my yard. You got transferred from Heaven?” Makima’s smile doesn’t widen but it becomes more visible, as if it moves from the lips to the eyes. She steps closer. The fences complain, shaking lightly. Every nearby inmate looks away all at once, as if extremely interested in the concrete under their shoes. “You have an unusual ability,” Makima says. “You unravel yourself. You become useful.” Stone Free uncoils from Jolyne’s wrist like a snake tasting the air. “Useful, huh? That what your pets call themselves?” Makima’s eyes flick down to the strand and back up. “I’m glad you understand analogies. I have a proposal.” “Hard pass,” Jolyne says. Makima’s head ticks, that small puzzled tilt a doll’s head might do. “You haven’t heard it yet.” “I don’t need to. You smell like trouble with lipstick. You’ve got the kind of smile that means only one of us leaves happy.” Jolyne’s voice lowers. “And if that’s how you get off, go buy a leash at a pet store.” Makima’s smile fades to polite interest. “You’re not afraid.” Jolyne says nothing. Afraid of this? Of men with guns? Of women who carry emptiness like an expensive bag? She isn’t sure if fear is the word. She is wary the way a hand is wary of a hot stove after the blister. She is wary in the way of people who have woken to handcuffs and bad dreams. Makima gestures, and the guard gate at the end of the lane hums open. No one has touched it. Out in the broader yard, the rattle spreads like a ripple through tall grass. The prisoners freeze; birds on a wire that suddenly calculate the sky’s weight. “I think you could leave here,” Makima says, friendly as a kindergarten teacher. “Or you can stay, Jolyne. If you stay under my care, I will arrange visitation with your father. Jotaro Kujo, correct?” Jolyne’s jaw tightens, and Stone Free’s strings go taut, a web around her elbows, her wrists. Makima watches the change like a biologist observing an amoeba sprout an eye. “Who told you that?” Jolyne asks. “People tell me many things,” Makima says. “My job is to decide who is worth listening to.” “Yeah? Let me decide something.” Jolyne breathes, and the strings spread from her fingers to the fence, invisible in the gray light until they catch a glint. “I don’t take orders. Not from a lady who uses people like chew toys.” Makima’s eyes cool by a degree that feels like a climate shift. “I didn’t say order,” she says. “I said care. I take care of what is mine.” Jolyne thinks of a leash, of a collar that closes without a sound. She thinks of hands on a steering wheel that isn’t there. Her laugh is a little too loud. “I got my own handcuffs, thanks. Don’t need new jewelry.” The gate slides shut behind Makima with a self-satisfied click. When she turns, two guards are there and then not, like a channel changing. Jolyne feels the pressure again, a subtle command pressing against the shape of her, and knows, the way instinct knows cliffs, that if this woman decides she is beneath her, there will be nothing left but knees and obedience. And Jolyne Cujoh kneels to no one. Stone Free lashes out, a panther of thread crawling from her forearm, looping the yard’s lamp pole, running across the razor wire, slipping through the chain link and back. She draws a lattice around them, a circle wide enough to make space, strings crossing strings until the air hums. The moment Makima steps forward, the web creaks and flexes. Makima doesn’t look at the web. She looks at Jolyne, as if memorizing a series of facts. “You’re clever,” she says. “You make distance and you make structure. You’d make a wonderful leash.” Jolyne’s stomach goes cold, but she spits to the side and grins. “You keep talking about dogs. You planning to bark or bite?” Makima raises one hand and points. There is no flourish, no circle, no Latin; there is a pressure, and one of the inmates down the lane flinches, then evaporates. Not explodes. Not vanishes into smoke. It is as if his pieces are deleted. The fence howls, every little diamond ringing in the sudden shock. Everyone turns to stone except the two of them inside the web. Jolyne’s heart claws at her throat. She does not blink. She widens her stance and peels another length of herself free, a filament that winds around Makima’s ankle like a question. “Your fear response is well-controlled,” Makima says. “I can offer you a life with meaning. You fight. You get to fight a cause that matters.” “My cause is mine,” Jolyne says. “My family. My friends. People who don’t look at me like a chew toy. People who would turn this place upside down for me.” Makima’s eyes flicker, a hint of amusement. “And has he?” she asks softly. “Has your father?” Jolyne’s fingers tremble, barely. She forces them still. “He will.” “Hmm.” The faint sound is an entire verdict. “Your strings transmit sound. Vibrations. You’re listening to the yard, to the building. It’s impressive. But you won’t hear what you need to hear through metal. You need someone to tell you where the real doors are.” “Lady,” Jolyne says, “I make doors where there aren’t any.” She pulls, and the web cinches like a net. Makima moves the way a thought moves, not fast so much as inevitable, stepping through a gap that should not be there until it is. The strings bend around her, as if politely making way. Jolyne’s breath catches; she shifts her control, twists, sows a second layer, barbed knots like tiny teeth. When Makima steps again, one ankle snags just enough for the knot to cut skin. A drop of blood beads and does not quite fall. Makima looks down at it, mildly fascinated. “This is new,” she says. “You adapt quickly.” “Yeah,” Jolyne says, and yanks. The web tightens in a sudden choke—the post groans, wire screams, dust puffs from concrete seams. Makima’s body tilts, forced to lurch. Her head turns, ringed eyes cutting to Jolyne, and Jolyne sees for the first time something behind the perfect mimicry—something like curiosity sharpened into hunger. Makima raises her hand, and the world compresses. The sound leaves the yard—just a moment of absence where even the wind forgets itself. Jolyne’s web shivers. Her strings vibrate so hard her bones ache. She bites the inside of her cheek and tastes copper. The bars of the fence bow inward like jailed ribs. “You’re not above me,” Makima says. It isn’t a threat. It’s a classification. Jolyne smiles with too many teeth. “Then stop trying to step on me and fight me.” Makima’s lips part—surprise edging that calm—and then she smiles, the real thing, the one with knives folded inside it. “I like you,” she says. “Come with me. I’ll let you see him.” The name isn’t said. It doesn’t have to be. Jolyne’s vision goes white at the edges, as if floodlights have been turned on behind her eyes. She thinks of him: the hat that never falls, the ocean of his silence, the way he said her name like a command to himself not to lose it. She thinks of a dolphin charm and the sound of a tape recorder. The lure is perfect because it is true. She snaps a line to the far fence and rockets backward, sliding under the taut net of her own making. The string bites her palm. Stone Free blooms around her, the shape of her Stand flickering, translucent sinew and knotted fists, skull grinning. She yanks the web between them, looping, making layers until Makima is a silhouette through blue haze. “No,” Jolyne says, panting, voice full of gravel. “I’ll see him because we break out of here and we meet halfway. Not because you hold the leash.” Makima steps forward and the web holds. She studies it like an architect reading a blueprint. Her smile is small and satisfied, as if Jolyne has passed a test. “I was not certain whether you’d be useful in a kennel,” she says softly. “But perhaps you’re more interesting running.” “Get used to the view,” Jolyne says. “It’s gonna be my back.” “Jolyne Cujoh,” Makima says, as if filing it, and turns away. A path opens for her where there is none. Guards reappear, blinking, clutching guns they don’t remember lowering. The inmates breathe again. The fence’s rattle becomes ordinary noise, not a heartbeat. Makima glances over her shoulder with that measured sweetness, a ribbon tied on a guillotine. “It’s okay,” she says, the words so soft they almost vanish. “Dogs are supposed to die for their owners.” Jolyne flips her off, fierce and raw. “I’m not a dog,” she says. “I’m the one who bites back.” Makima’s smile brightens an increment. Then she is gone into the building’s swallow. The gate closes. The yard exhales. Stone Free retracts in a shiver, threads knitting under Jolyne’s skin. She stands alone in the echo of it, sweat cooling on her neck, the butterfly on her arm fluttering with the drum under her ribs. She’s shaking and doesn’t let it show. The fence rattles when she lets her hand brush it, a nervous tick disguised as a test. She focuses, sends a string through the post, along the chain, into the concrete, out into the prison’s circuitry—a stethoscope pressed to a monster’s chest. She listens. She learns. She thinks of Makima’s eyes, and the private way they seemed to count people like coins. She thinks of the droplet of blood that didn’t fall. She thinks of what it will take, and who will come, and who she will have to become if he doesn’t. “Stone Free,” she says under her breath. “Let’s make a door.” The chain-link fences in the yard rattle again when an inmate passes, an ordinary sound, a chorus of little metal throats. Jolyne smiles to herself, a shape that looks like barbed wire cutting sunlight. Wary, suspicious, boiling and cooling by turns, she measures the weight of the sky and the thickness of her own resolve. Somewhere inside this place, someone has given her a leash and asked her to put it on. She winds her strings around her wrist like bracelets and ties a small knot no one else can see. She names it Makima. She ties another and names it Home. Then she starts to pull.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece successfully captures the essence of both characters while creating a tense, atmospheric confrontation. The author demonstrates a strong understanding of both Jolyne Cujoh and Makima, portraying their abilities, personalities, and speech patterns with remarkable accuracy. The prison setting is vividly established through sensory details that create a grim, oppressive atmosphere. The description of the "chain-link fences" that "rattle whenever an inmate passes by" and the "concrete rises in grim slabs" immediately places the reader in this harsh environment. The characterization is particularly strong. Jolyne's defiance, resourcefulness, and loyalty to her father are well-portrayed. Her use of Stone Free is described in creative ways that align with the source material. Similarly, Makima's false sweetness, manipulative nature, and terrifying power are effectively conveyed. The moment when an inmate "evaporates" demonstrates her casual cruelty and godlike abilities. The prose is elegant without becoming purple. Metaphors and similes enhance the narrative rather than distract from it. For example, describing Makima's voice as "a gentle trowel, smoothing mortar" perfectly captures her deceptively soothing manner while hinting at something artificial beneath. The dialogue is exceptional, capturing each character's distinct voice. Jolyne's "If there's no Mickey, this shit ain't Disney" reference from the source material is naturally incorporated. Makima's "Dogs are supposed to die for their owners" line is equally well-placed and chilling. The confrontation builds tension effectively, with Jolyne gradually realizing the extent of Makima's power while refusing to submit. The power dynamics are well-explored, with Makima's attempts at control met by Jolyne's fierce independence. The ending avoids an unrealistic resolution, instead showing Jolyne's determination to escape on her own terms rather than accepting Makima's offer. This stays true to her character while setting up potential future conflict. The piece does occasionally lean toward overwrought description, particularly in some of the metaphors describing the prison environment. A few sentences could be tightened for greater impact. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise excellent piece. Overall, this is an impressive character study that successfully merges two distinct fictional universes while maintaining the integrity of both characters. The writing is confident, atmospheric, and engaging throughout. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 18 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 17 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 5 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 18.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 17.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 17.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 4.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 5.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 17.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 18.0, Overall Impression: 18.0
+ Scp: Notes from the Future — Score: 90.5
Prompt:
Write an SCP report about a researcher who begins finding handwritten notes from their future self, warning about a containment breach that hasn't happened yet. The notes become increasingly desperate and incoherent, sometimes containing information that contradicts known reality. Include the Foundation's attempts to determine if this is an actual temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation by a contained entity, and the researcher's struggle to trust their own perception. First person (researcher's perspective with interspersed notes), past tense. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-████ Object Class: Euclid Special Containment Procedures: Researcher ███████ (hereafter “I”) was placed on temporary leave from Site-██’s Temporal Anomalies Unit and relocated to an isolated observation suite with 24/7 surveillance. All writing instruments within my assigned workspace were cataloged and replaced with Foundation-manufactured pens whose ink composition is batch-tracked. A secondary camera monitored any physical correspondence entering the room; all paper supplies were watermarked prior to issuance. Daily cognitive evaluations were administered by Dr. Holtz. All handwritten notes purportedly from my future self were to be surrendered immediately to Security for forensic analysis (ink composition, fiber structure, handwriting comparison). Site-██’s memetics team reviewed the notes for cognitohazard markers. Interviews with other staff were restricted and mirrored to detect behavioral priming. Access to the containment wing of SCP-███ (suspected of potential infohazard manipulation) was rescinded for me pending investigation. Description: On ██/██/20██, I found a handwritten note in my lab coat pocket. The note appeared to be in my handwriting, on Foundation standard-issue notepaper, but bore soot-like smudges along the edges. It warned of a containment breach in three days. The breach, according to the note, would originate in the northern corridor, after a scheduled power test. On that date, no breach occurred, and no power test was scheduled. Ink analysis revealed trace elements (molybdenum disulfide, vanadium oxides, and a proprietary stabilizer not present in any standard office pen cartridge) inconsistent with supply logs. Security confirmed the note was not recorded entering my room. I wrote the following in my daily log that evening: They’re mine, these letters. The loops on the g’s, the pressure at the ascenders—everything is me. But the paper smells like ozone. I don’t keep ozone in my pocket. The subsequent notes arrived intermittently. The content escalated in urgency, sometimes contradicting known scheduling and facts, sometimes predicting small events that came true—dropped mugs, a door jam, a colleague’s offhand joke. Each was dated two to seven days “ahead.” There was no observable ingress. No time-stamps on the entry hallway cameras showed any physical delivery. The notes were found folded into places I would not reasonably miss: beneath my pillow, inside a book I was actively annotating. Occasionally they referred to me by the nickname only my sister uses. The last line of the second note: Note [D+2]: You’ve never dreamed in color since the Freiburg incident. If you’re dreaming in color now, it means you’re not asleep. I’m not proud of what I did next. I tested my dreams with a pack of colored tabs taped above my bed. That night, in my dream, they were all red. In the morning they were still blue. On D+4, the Foundation initiated cross-testing to determine whether these notes were temporal bleed-throughs, a known but rare phenomenon in proximity to SCP-████ (a defective Faraday-cage-adjacent chamber used in null-causality experiments), or the product of directed psychological manipulation by SCP-███, a class-E memetic engine contained three floors down. Both had historical precedent for interfering with perceived causality, though by different mechanisms. Note [D+4]: It starts with small permissions to doubt. You’ll think you’re prudent. Then you’ll throw the wrong switch to avoid the wrong failure and find the right disaster. I told Dr. Holtz that the phrasing felt like me scolding me. She asked whether I often scold myself. I said no; I just narrated hypotheticals until they stopped being hypothetical. She wrote something down. The third note predicted a fire in Corridor A, followed by a lockdown. There was neither. Instead, that afternoon a lab assistant dropped a tray in the cafeteria, shattering six dishes. The note had included a line about “shards like ice on tile.” I was there. There were shards on tile. It felt forced to consider that a prediction. Ink testing on all notes produced the same anomalies: trace molybdenum disulfide, vanadium oxides, and an unidentified organometallic stabilizer that fluoresced faintly under 365 nm UV. Our laboratories could not match it to any known commercial ink. The paper fibers were consistent with Foundation stock, but isotopic ratios of carbon varied slightly from batch averages, suggesting either contamination or a near-identical substitute. No watermarks were present, despite all issued paper being pre-watermarked. That should have been impossible. At Site Command’s instruction, we staged a controlled exposure. I spent two shifts in the observation suite with nothing but a sealed notebook and a single Foundation-issue pen. Security verified there were no hidden compartments, no ceiling voids, no vents large enough to pass paper. The cameras ran at 120 fps. No entries appeared. Between 02:13 and 02:14 a note was found tucked under the notebook’s front cover. The footage showed my hand reaching to turn the page. There was no cut. One frame: cover down. Next frame: cover lifted. Note present. Note [D+6]: You won’t see it arrive. It keeps you docile. If you had to watch it appear, you’d tear up the whole room. You will tear up the whole room. I tore up the whole room. No ingress points. No mechanism. Holtz said that proved nothing, and everything. Technical teams proposed two possibilities: an artifact of temporal discontinuity localized within a radius tightly coupled to my personal effects; or a memetic hallucination induced by SCP-███ that coerced not only my perception but camera systems, implying a second-tier vector. SCP-███ had previously demonstrated an ability to alter target recollection, but not to affect inanimate recording media. Its containment logs showed no recent breaches, and the memetics team found no stereotyped markers in the notes. Still, they could not rule out a novel vector. I had trouble sleeping. I began to catch inconsistencies that seemed tailored to me alone. The notes said I didn’t keep a plant in the office; I had one, a stubborn ZZ. The notes referenced a coffee stain on a folder in the left drawer; mine was on the right. I thought: if this is from a future me, it’s a sloppy one. Or a future where the desk got rearranged. Or an entity imitating me with an imperfect model of my life. Note [D+8]: You moved the stain after the second flood in Wing G. That’s why you think it’s on the right. It’s on the left. Stop letting them set the anchor. I opened the drawer. The stain was on the left. It had always been on the left. I would have sworn otherwise. By D+9, the tone shifted toward panic. The handwriting degraded. Lines tilted, words crushed into margins. One note included a list of colleagues by surname, then scratched them out one by one. Two of the names belonged to people transferred away months ago; one belonged to a technician who had died in a traffic accident years prior. Yet the note referenced a lunch with him in the canteen three days forward. Note [D+9]: He’ll ask you about the scar. Don’t show him. You’ll think this means he’s alive. He is not alive. He never was alive. He died on the day the road folded. He’s sitting two tables behind you. At lunch, I could not bring myself to turn around. I began to distrust my own recall. I misremembered protocol numbers I had authored. I reached for a hallway light switch that wasn’t there. Doors seemed to be two centimeters to the left. Holtz suggested we call it “drift.” She asked me to ground myself by reading the Site Manual aloud, anchoring to text. The words rearranged in my mouth. I realized that some portion of me wanted the notes to be true because that would mean the fractures were external. If it was SCP-███, then I was compromised. If it was me, then I was already lost. They added smell tests to the ink analysis. The notes smelled faintly of hot metal and something sweet-sour like rosin flux. The trace elements and the unidentified stabilizer were consistent across samples. A manufacturing origin couldn’t be traced. The memetics team constructed a low-level counter-hum in the observation suite based on patterns known to disrupt SCP-███’s influence. For twelve hours, no notes appeared. Then one emerged between my stacked folders. The ink fluoresced stronger than before. Holtz called that “adversarial adaptation.” I called it cheating. Note [D+11]: The hum makes it angry. You know how you used to hum in the car so you wouldn’t think about the bridge? It’s like that. It’s going to take something when you stop. They will say “adversarial adaptation.” You will say “cheating.” Then you will laugh. Don’t laugh. It likes the sound. I stopped laughing. On D+12, a note predicted a breach at 03:44. I sat up, watching the clock. At 03:43, the building shook. Fire doors sealed. The alarms pulsed once and died. Then everything was still. No log recorded any event. No one else reported a tremor. It should have been the easiest test: either it happened or it did not. My hands shook too badly to hold the pen. On D+13, I found a note tucked between the pages of a book I had never read: a field report signed with my name in a script that was not mine, from a site that did not exist. The letterhead was wrong, the logo subtly off. It contained a description of a breach I recognized because it had been described in one of the earlier notes. I brought it to Security. On lab imaging, the fibers were normal; the watermark was a mirror image. The ink analysis again revealed the same trace elements, plus a faint spectral line we had not seen before. The spectroscopist blinked too many times and asked to be excused. My refusal to engage began to feel like a lever I had run out of hand for. The notes grew despairing. Note [D+15]: There will be a day when you cannot tell if you’re on the other side of the door. If you decide you’re outside when you’re inside you will die and it will be fine. If you decide you’re inside when you’re outside you will live but everything after will be a witness stand. Note [D+16]: It’s not a breach if no one remembers the wall. While testing for chemical fingerprints unique to the notes, we discovered microscopic metallic particles embedded in the ink, arranged along the lines of text.
