Under scanning electron microscopy, they formed tiny lattices, like an attempt at circuitry printed by hand. The structure was too crude to function, too deliberate to be incidental. If it was a memetic vector, it was working at a level I didn’t like to think about. If it was temporal, it meant someone—or something—was writing programmatically in my hand. We attempted to trap a note by enclosing all my reading materials in an airtight transparent bin. At 02:09, a note appeared outside the bin, leaned against the plastic as if it were waiting. It read: Note [D+17]: You don’t trap weather. The day before D+18, Holtz asked me which outcome I would prefer: that these were a future self trying and failing to warn me, or an enemy constructing my future out of me. I told her I wanted the former, because failure was more familiar than malice. She said that might be the most dangerous answer. We re-administered SCP-███ exposure tests indirectly, using baseline staff to handle redacted text while I observed through a screen. No resonance. The internal auditors noted that SCP-███’s output dropped during the period of my notes’ highest frequency, suggesting either competition or interference. On D+18, the note was two lines long: Note [D+18]: If the breach doesn’t happen, that is the breach. The ink is wrong because it hasn’t been invented yet. After I read it, the letters smeared on my fingers like graphite. My hand smelled like hot coins and sugar. After Action: The predicted “breach” never manifested in any way the Site would acknowledge. Doors remained doors. Corridors stayed in place. No one died who wasn’t already dead. I continue to receive notes at irregular intervals, though fewer. The ink analysis remains consistent: trace molybdenum disulfide and vanadium oxides; unidentified stabilizer; metallic particulates patterned along strokes. The memetics team’s conclusion is “inconclusive with lean toward temporal anomaly, novel vector.” Temporal Research calls it “causal seepage,” which I suspect is a polite non-answer. I have not returned to the containment wing of SCP-███, but on nights when I walk past the stairwell I feel watched, as if by a method rather than a mind. I keep my pen capped. I no longer write drafts of reports by hand. Note [POST]: You will be asked to sign a final statement. Do not read before you sign. If they make you read, blink slowly at the pen and think about the bridge. Remember the hum. Remember you are not asleep. Dr. Holtz asked me yesterday whether I trust myself. I told her the truth: that I had trusted the voice in my head for years because it sounded like me, because it had my handwriting, and because I could not afford not to. Now I listen for the places the loops are too tight, for the tilt of the lines when the fear comes too quickly. I place my hands on the table, feel the cold, and try to remember which side of the door I am on. If the breach is that it never happens, I am living in the aftermath. Addendum: Ink Analysis Summary All retrieved notes: spectral signatures include MoS2 and V2O5 trace; unidentified organometallic stabilizer fluorescing at 365 nm; microscale metallic lattices along strokes observable under SEM; no match to any Site-██ inventory ink. Paper fiber blends approximate Foundation stock with anomalous isotopic variances; no watermark despite controls. Handling produces consistent ozone-adjacent odor with saccharine undertone. Cross-reference with known anomalous writing implements inconclusive. Personal Addendum: Note [LAST?]: This is the one you think is the last because you want endings. There aren’t any. There is a maintenance log with your name and a box to check. If you check it, the lights go out. If you don’t check it, the lights flicker. Either way you think you did it. You didn’t. Sign where they tell you. Don’t look at the ink.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP report effectively captures the essence of the Foundation's clinical documentation style while weaving in a compelling first-person narrative about temporal anomalies. The piece successfully creates an atmosphere of paranoia and uncertainty, as the researcher struggles to determine whether they're experiencing a genuine temporal anomaly or being manipulated by a contained entity. The format adheres well to SCP conventions, with appropriate containment procedures, description sections, and clinical tone interspersed with the researcher's increasingly desperate personal observations. The writer skillfully builds tension through the progression of notes that become more incoherent and disturbing over time. The character development is subtle but effective. We witness the researcher's gradual descent from scientific skepticism to paranoid uncertainty, with moments of self-awareness that feel authentic. Lines like "I'm not proud of what I did next" and the admission of tearing up the room show vulnerability beneath the clinical facade. The prose strikes an excellent balance between clinical detachment and personal dread. The writing maintains a consistent voice throughout, with the researcher's personality emerging through small details and observations. The clinical sections feel appropriately sterile and procedural, while the personal notes convey mounting fear. The imagery is particularly strong in the descriptions of the notes themselves - the "soot-like smudges," the smell of "hot metal and something sweet-sour like rosin flux," and the way the ink "smeared on my fingers like graphite." These sensory details ground the supernatural elements in physical reality. The narrative structure creates an effective sense of mounting dread, with each note adding new layers of uncertainty. The piece excels at creating ambiguity - we never learn definitively whether this is a temporal anomaly or psychological manipulation, mirroring the researcher's own confusion. Some particularly strong elements include the technical details about ink composition and testing procedures, which lend credibility to the Foundation's investigation, and the clever way information is revealed through the notes themselves. The recurring motifs (the hum, the bridge, the question of which side of the door the researcher is on) create a cohesive psychological landscape. If there's a weakness, it might be that the ending doesn't provide quite enough resolution, though this ambiguity is appropriate for the SCP format and the theme of uncertainty. The piece also occasionally relies on SCP conventions (redacted information, technical jargon) that might be less accessible to readers unfamiliar with the format, though this is a minor concern given the prompt specifically requested an SCP report. Overall, this is an exceptionally well-crafted piece that succeeds both as an SCP entry and as a psychological horror story about the fragility of perception and reality. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 19 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 2 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 17.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 18.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 19.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 18.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 3.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 3.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 2.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Scp: Unmarked Doors Archive — Score: 88.4
Prompt:
Write an SCP entry about a series of identical unmarked doors appearing in abandoned buildings worldwide that lead to a massive, architecturally impossible archive. Documents within reference a previous global civilization destroyed by an unspecified containment failure. Foundation researchers discover references to their own organization under a different name, including personnel files for current staff dated centuries ago. Include exploration logs revealing sections of the archive actively being removed by entities resembling hazmat teams who flee when approached, and evidence that O5 Council members have visited the archive without authorization. Third person (exploration team perspective) with recovered document excerpts. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
Item #: SCP-6781 Object Class: Keter Special Containment Procedures: All discovered instances of SCP-6781-A (unmarked doors anomalously embedded within abandoned buildings) are to be secured under front-company holdings and monitored by local Foundation assets within a 3-km perimeter. Mobile Task Force Mu-3 (“Card Cataloguers”) will maintain roving inspection of existing instances and respond to new reports. Civilian access is to be deterred under the cover of safety inspections and demolition hazards. All opened SCP-6781-A instances must be guarded by two agents, continuous video surveillance, and a standard Faraday cage doorway arch to detect electromagnetic anomalies. Unauthorized ingress is prohibited. No attempts are to be made to permanently remove SCP-6781-A or to alter their frames. Instances show wide variance in apparent age; those that appear older than surrounding architecture are to be prioritized for study and monitored for spontaneous changes to patina, rusting, and woodgrain drift. Requests for organized exploratory missions into SCP-6781-B (the internal environment accessed via SCP-6781-A) require approval from Site Command and an O5-level liaison. Personnel entering SCP-6781-B must be equipped with personal recording suites, passive dosimetry, local inertial mapping, tether spools, and emergency exit beacons. Description: SCP-6781 is a global phenomenon wherein identical, unmarked doors (SCP-6781-A) appear and persist within disused or abandoned structures. Reported locations include factories, hospitals, theaters, and air-raid shelters. Instances conform to a single design: unpainted oak slab, rounded brass handle, recessed hinge plates, and a beveled frame of dark hardwood. The door face lacks marks, labels, or any signs of manufacturing. Radiocarbon and dendrochronological analyses return contradictory results. Several doors display age consistent with centuries of exposure—weathering, corroded hardware, and desiccated shrinkage—despite being mounted in structures built within the last decade. Opening any SCP-6781-A does not reveal the attached room. Instead, it provides access to SCP-6781-B: an apparent archive complex of vast, possibly non-Euclidean dimensions, arranged as a grid of halls with stacks, mezzanines, and reading bays suspended over deep voids. Constructed elements do not adhere to conventional load-bearing design; shelves span unsupported distances, staircases terminate midair and continue at right angles with no visible junction, and colonnades pass through one another. Gravity appears consistent, yet floor gradients vary unpredictably. SCP-6781-B contains documents, storage boxes, codices, microfiche, and unfamiliar media formats cataloged in a system that combines Dewey-like decimals with annotations in a script not present in any known corpus. Many documents are in modern languages and refer to a prior iteration of global civilization, including reference charts of countries and populations, anomalous events, and organizations analogous to the Foundation operating under the name The Custodial Directorate. Notably, some files are personnel dossiers of current Foundation staff, with dates centuries prior to their births, and include references to a Council of Thirteen titled the Oversight Circle. Signatures match known O5 ciphers with antiquated conventions. On multiple missions, exploration teams have encountered entities resembling hazmat response units (SCP-6781-C). These individuals wear featureless white PPE with reflective visors and self-contained breathing apparatus. They utilize dollies and collapsible crates to remove documents and shelving sections. When approached, SCP-6781-C withdraw, closing temporary barriers or deploying signage that reads Out of Scope in high-contrast stenciling. No hostile actions have been observed; SCP-6781-C avoid direct contact and flee through previously unobserved exits. Physical pursuit is hampered by shifting corridors and reconfiguration of stacks. Addendum 6781-1: Exploration Logs Log 6781-Beta-03 Team: Mu-3 Team Blue (Lead: Agent Henriksen; Archivist: Dr. T. Akari; Tech: L. Sandoval; Security: Agents Valez and Rooke) Ingress: SCP-6781-A instance located in a condemned post office, Norrköping, Sweden. Door predates building by apparent half-century based on material wear. [Begin Transcript] [Video shows opening into a high aisle, shelf height approximately 6 meters. Overhead, latticed gangways carry additional shelving. Ambient noise: distant fans, paper rustle, intermittent metallic clinks.] Henriksen: Beacon set. Tethers out. Keep line of sight. Akari: Catalog tags here—look. Decimal markers with an extra suffix. Language is Swedish, then switches to… French? Then something else. These are cross-lingual index tabs. Sandoval: EM stable. No obvious radio bleed. Map node one placed. [Team advances. Shelves contain file boxes labeled Collapse: Coastal Evacuations, Iteration IV, and Directorate Internal: Personnel Clearance C.] Rooke: Copy this. Names—this is Spanish. There’s a “Valez” here. Valez: That’s—spelled correctly. That’s me. [Akari pulls the box, revealing acid-free envelopes. A personnel file shows a photo of Agent Valez in current hairstyle and scars, dated 1723 with watermark Oversight Circle Seal.] Akari: Paper’s not modern. Fiber composition is… old. But the print is digital. You can’t—this doesn’t make sense. Henriksen: Bag it. No handling without sleeves. [Motion in periphery. Two SCP-6781-C entities are visible down-aisle, loading bound ledgers into a crate labeled Disposition Pending. Their uniforms are marked with a circular emblem: a dot within three concentric rings. They freeze, then one lifts a placard: “Clearance Not Valid.” They retreat.] Henriksen: Contact. Non-hostile. Rooke, block—no, hold. Don’t provoke. [Rooke takes two steps; the aisle elongates, and a handrail appears between Rooke and the entities where none existed. The entities turn left into a new corridor that was a solid shelf moments before, then vanish.] Sandoval: Slope just changed under my feet. Recording. Akari: Taking a quick excerpt. [Recovered Document Excerpt 6781-EX/14] Title: Custodial Directorate—Operational Summary Language: English (Mixed) Excerpt: “Of the thirteen, nine convened in chambers unlit; four had already crossed into the archives and would not be recovered. We note again: failure to enforce the lockstep on interstice portals correlates with library bleed. The Archive continues to accept deposit from our worldline. This is both boon and risk. If the Oversight Circle falters, the stacks do not—” Valez: That symbol is almost the Foundation sigil, but… incomplete. Henriksen: We’re done here. Exfil. [End Transcript] Log 6781-Delta-07 Team: Mu-3 Team Red (Lead: Lt. Osei; Specialists: Dr. Huang, Field Linguist Cabrera; Security: Berte, Coen) Ingress: SCP-6781-A instance in an abandoned train depot, South Africa. Door exhibits heavy salt bloom and corrosion inconsistent with inland humidity readings. [Begin Transcript] [Opening reveals a reading atrium with a dome that appears external; however, skylight shows cloud movement that does not match local conditions. Fragile signage indicates Reference: Collapse Reports.] Cabrera: Here—something like a subject index. Look: “Containment Failure: Unspecified, Total.” No event code. Huang: I have a ledger titled “Reconstruction: Directorate to Foundation.” The names—“Custodial Directorate” transitions to “Foundation.” There’s a timetable of renamings, then blank entries. Osei: That’s impossible. We never— Berte: Movement, left. [Three SCP-6781-C entities push a stack segment on a wheeled chassis. The shelf is strapped, labels “Iterative Personnel: Circle Attestations.” One entity pauses, tilts head at the team, raises a gloved hand in a gesture resembling a stop sign, then places a paper on a nearby podium.] Coen: They left something. [Dr. Huang retrieves the paper. It is headed with an unfamiliar letterhead resembling a spoked wheel.] [Recovered Document Excerpt 6781-EX/29] Title: Access Audit Excerpt: “Unauthorized visits recorded: 13. Titles claimed: Overseer, O5, Circle, Chairman. Vector: nonconforming ingress. Note: Repeated attempts to remove or alter sections designated Oversight Proceedings. Action: quarantine. Removal: scheduled.” Osei: This is addressed to us. Or to them. Cabrera: “Nonconforming ingress”—sounds like somebody’s been coming here without using doors like ours. Huang: The bottom margin—look. Three signatures. Initials correspond to— Osei: Cut that. We’re exfiltrating. Copy-only, no removals. [As the team withdraws, ambient light levels drop. The dome above the atrium darkens to reveal a vast ceiling of shelves where the sky had been. Two SCP-6781-C entities appear on the upper rail and vanish behind a blackout curtain that wasn’t present before.] [End Transcript] Log 6781-Kappa-02 Team: Mu-3 Team Black (Lead: Captain Morita; Archivist: Dr. Esteban; Security: Agents Shah and Petrin) Ingress: SCP-6781-A instance in a shuttered elementary school, Ohio. The door wood is splayed from age; building is 27 years old. [Begin Transcript] [Interior is a narrow spiral corridor with books inset into walls. Each step ascends 20 cm; gravity remains consistent until step 32, where footfalls become near-silent.] Esteban: Catalog numbers reference “Precursor Topology” and “Failsafe Geometry.” This is… beyond architecture. Morita: Marking route. Tether is taut. [A side niche contains a glass case with a single folder. Title reads Foundation: Charter Draft. Date: 1701. A small 13-pointed emblem is embossed.] [Recovered Document Excerpt 6781-EX/51] Title: Charter Draft—Third Revision Excerpt: “We inherit from the Directorate the principles of human survival as information. Archives, then, are not storehouses but rafts. Any sufficiency we build is provisional; any name we choose will be used again. Our Circle, whatever we call it, will fail if it forgets the Archive will outlast us.” Shah: That’s a warning. From us. From them. [Footfalls above. A group of four SCP-6781-C entities cross a translucent catwalk. They carry a sealed bin marked “O5 Minutes—Interval: 001-031.” When Captain Morita raises a hand to hail them, the lead entity stops, then reaches up and pulls a chain. The catwalk frosts over, opacity increasing, and they accelerate away.] Petrin: They’re taking O5 minutes. Morita: Why would they— Esteban: There’s a side note here, handwritten. It says: “Do not contest removals. They remove what permits repetition.” Morita: We’re leaving. Note the path. [End Transcript] Addendum 6781-2: Unauthorized Access Incident On 12/14/20██, a hidden camera placed by Team Blue near a mezzanine bench captured two subjects in dark clothing without insignia consulting a bound volume titled Oversight Proceedings: Circle to Council. Facial recognition flagged Subject-1 as matching O5-█ at 87% confidence and Subject-2 as unknown. Both subjects conversed in low tones; audio captured only fragments: “not yet,” “they’ve started pulling the sequence,” “we were always going to find this.” At timestamp 00:04:11, a SCP-6781-C entity appeared and placed a sign reading “ERSATZ AUTHORITIES: PLEASE EXIT.” The subjects departed without incident. O5 Office Response: No O5 member admits to visiting SCP-6781-B. The Council has issued an injunction prohibiting all non-mission ingress by Level 5 personnel. Investigation ongoing. Addendum 6781-3: Personnel File Anomalies Cross-referencing documents removed from SCP-6781-B with Site HR records confirmed multiple matches. File 6781-PF/103 refers to Researcher K. Narang, hired 2018, with an accession date of 1694; included is a performance review after “Containment Breach—Unspecified, Total,” assessed as “Archived, Continuing.” The document uses the term Continuing to describe staff who persist across “iterations.” The same term appears in the Charter Draft. Excerpt, 6781-PF/103: “Subject: Narang, K. Function: Analysis. Continuity: Secure. Memory: Partial. Note: Inform not; the Archive supplies what is needed when needed.” Researcher Narang has no recollection of prior employment or of the incident described. Addendum 6781-4: Additional Recovered Excerpts 6781-EX/76: Collapse Report Abstract “The failure began not as a breach but as a misunderstanding of categories. When containment extends to the Archive’s own rules, the rules revise the world. Our failure was to insist on sufficiency.” 6781-EX/88: Hazmat Team Directive (Partial) “Teams to remove material that constitutes a loop primer: Council minutes beyond early formation, protocols that specify Archive traversal, index keys leading to Oversight Proceedings. Mark shelves with the wheel sigil. Interact with outsiders only to signal invalid credentials. Do not harm. Flee if pursued. They will learn in the order required.” 6781-EX/93: Door Provenance “The doors are older than their walls. We insert them as memories into places that will later be abandoned—already empty of people, so less harm. The patina is not age; it is the Archive’s way of suggesting direction: older doors lead to older mistakes.” Addendum 6781-5: Incident—Section Vanish During Log 6781-Theta-04 (Mu-3 Team Silver), the team reached a bay with panoramic windows showing what appeared to be an aerial view of a city flooding in reverse. The bay contained shelves labeled Counterflood Protocols. As the team approached, six SCP-6781-C entities enacted a removal. Shelving segments slid silently into flat carts, labels facing inward. One entity faced the team and tapped a placard: Out of Scope. When Agent Meinhardt stepped closer, the floor ahead remapped into a shallow stair leading down. The entities accelerated, reached a door in the opposite wall that had not been present, and exited. The bay then displayed an interior view of the same city; the reversal ceased and became a static image. On return, Team Silver’s tether measured 12 meters shorter than when deployed, without any coil on the spool. Note: Tether shortening has occurred in three other missions. Teams report the Archive uses distance as a suggestion rather than a fact. O5 Advisory: No attempts to interfere with SCP-6781-C removals are permitted. The pattern of removals suggests they are restricting access to materials that could enable recursive governance. Addendum 6781-6: Statement of Uncertainty We do not possess a definitive explanation for the Archive’s origin or its custodians. Evidence suggests that the Foundation is a successor name for an older entity, and that the Archive persists as a continuity mechanism across global failures. Doors appear where we have already abandoned the world; the Archive uses our neglect as entry points. We possess an image of ourselves, centuries old, saying what we will say. We have files that predate our births, insisting that we will continue. We have observed our highest leadership, or their doubles, sitting in the stacks where none of us are supposed to be. We have watched other hands remove our minutes before we can use them to bind ourselves. Containment remains conceptual: we secure perimeters, we contain access, we protect against knowledge that would cause repetition. The Archive is not neutral; it trims its own shelves. The doors do not ask permission. They age in place as if remembering a time that already happened. For now, we read only what we can bear to know, and we leave before we learn the order of our failures. The Archive will be there whether or not we are. The doors will wait. They have been waiting longer than their buildings exist.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This SCP entry demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of the SCP Foundation format while delivering a conceptually rich anomaly. The piece successfully creates an architecturally impossible archive accessed through mysterious doors, complete with the requested elements of a previous civilization, references to the Foundation under a different name, and unauthorized O5 Council visits. The writing excels in creating a sense of cosmic dread and institutional paranoia. The concept of an archive that contains records of the Foundation's previous iterations—suggesting cyclical civilizational collapse—is genuinely unsettling and philosophically intriguing. The exploration logs effectively convey the disorienting nature of the archive while gradually revealing its secrets. The technical aspects of the SCP format are handled expertly. The containment procedures are detailed and plausible, the description is clear while maintaining mystery, and the addenda provide a structured way to reveal information. The exploration logs effectively use dialogue and environmental description to build tension and convey information. Where the piece particularly shines is in its conceptual depth. The archive as a repository of cyclical history, the idea that the Foundation is merely the latest iteration of an organization that has existed across multiple civilizations, and the suggestion that even the O5 Council is caught in this loop—all create a compelling narrative that challenges the Foundation's understanding of itself. The hazmat teams (SCP-6781-C) are well-utilized as mysterious entities that seem to be curating the archive, removing sections that might cause "repetition" of past failures. Their non-hostile but evasive behavior adds to the mystery rather than providing easy answers. The recovered document excerpts are particularly strong, written in a style that suggests institutional documentation while containing cryptic warnings and revelations. Lines like "The doors are older than their walls" and "Archives, then, are not storehouses but rafts" are evocative and thematically rich. The piece does occasionally rely on telling rather than showing, particularly in the final addendum which explicitly states the conceptual implications rather than allowing them to emerge organically. Some of the exploration logs could benefit from more sensory detail to enhance immersion. The writing occasionally becomes slightly overwrought in its philosophical musings, particularly in the final addendum. While this serves the cosmic horror aspect of the piece, it occasionally risks becoming too abstract. Overall, this is an exceptionally strong SCP entry that balances format adherence with creative worldbuilding and philosophical depth. It creates a genuinely unsettling anomaly that challenges the Foundation's understanding of itself and reality, while maintaining enough mystery to be intriguing rather than frustrating. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 16 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17 Elegant Prose: 18 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 18 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 5 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 4 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 18 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 18.0, Nuanced Characters: 16.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 19.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 17.0, Elegant Prose: 18.0, Emotionally Engaging: 17.0, Emotionally Complex: 18.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 4.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 5.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 2.0, Purple Prose: 4.0, Overwrought: 4.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 18.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Le Guin) — Score: 93.4
Prompt:
Classic sci-fi: Offworlder (Author style: Le Guin) Write a chapter following a young diplomatic envoy sent to address tensions on a distant human colony where humanity has diverged into distinct subspecies through both natural adaptation and separation of lineages. Against protocol, the envoy slips away from official functions to walk the streets alone, encountering markets, ordinary citizens, and social structures that contradict the official briefings. Upon returning to their quarters, the envoy is reprimanded by Command, and is tasked with approaching the stationed Minister of Science (a political posting rather than scientific). A challenging conversation ensues, in which the envoy's wits and will are tested, by a seasoned political operator looking to test the mettle of the offworlder. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
They called me Offworlder because the station logs needed a term. On Omia they called me stranger, softlander, cloakshell, and once, in a child’s whisper, fish. My cloak drew the eyes like a wound draws flies; even with the hood down, the slate folds shone against the bare-shouldered people in the First Market. I had been advised to keep it on in case of weather—“unpredictable microclimates,” the briefing said—but it was their climate I was not dressed for. Even the stones were stripped to the bone. The shuttle had come in on a vector over saltfield and marsh. From above, the city looked like a map of vasculature: pale roads, thin canals, plazas like open mouths. On the ground the air tasted of iron and brine. My delegation lodged me in the Embassy Complex, a block of reasonable rooms and unreasonable silence, then offered me an hour to sleep and four hours of ceremony. I kept the hour and shed the ceremonies. Against orders, I left by the side gate in midmorning, when the market streets were already moving like water. It is not hard to walk unnoticed, not if you are taught how, and I had been taught by a woman in a city where noticing could cost a life. On Omia, notice came like the sun: casually, from all angles. Eyes found me with curiosity more than hostility. That, too, is a kind of grace. I crossed an arroyo on a bridge strap and entered the First Market. Shelters of stitched skin and woven saltgrass cast latticed shade. The stalls were shallow and set low for short traders and children; on the far edge I saw a line of taller men and women moving in unison, their load-bearing harnesses shifting on their shoulders with the rhythm of people born to height. They did not look down at me as they passed; they were looking at each other, taking their cue from a single breath. My briefing had spoken of “Tall adaptations” like a classification, as if some laboratory had dialed in femurs and tendons. These were no specimens. They shared laughter. I let myself be carried by the flow until the narrowness of it pressed me to the stalls. The goods were not the goods listed in my briefing: there were no shackles, no ration slabs, no “extractive resource tokens.” There were clay jars sealed with plant gum, blue fish knotted on spit twine, beads carved from bone and polished ore. There were cloths dyed with pigments my mother would have loved, deep as ocean, hot as the inside of a lid. There were the tools of their adaptation: shoes like webbing with jointed pads; sun-skins like scales; masks that covered from ear to ear and filtered brine with the efficiency of gills. These were nice things, useless to despots. I touched one mask; it rasped under my fingers, indeed like a fish. A child—the one who whispered “fish”—reached to touch my cloak. I crouched. Her eyes were very pale, her irises almost colorless in the hard light. She was short-limbed and broad-chested, the Omians my files had labeled “Short,” a drift-lineage adapted to high-density living, bone ends rounded and cartilage thick. She had put three pebbles into the hem of my cloak to make it hang straight. I had not felt that weight. I took them out and returned them to her palm. “You look cold,” she said. “I’m too warm,” I said. She frowned at the mismatch of the world and my words, then laughed, the way children make a game of a dissonance. “You’ll boil,” she said, and ran to a woman who wore a net necklace with small shells from which threaded light gleamed. The woman nodded at me with a particular Omian nod: chin down, eyes up. I bought a string of dried bulbs that popped when cracked and yielded a tart liquid like a sharpened pear. I paid with vouchers my house had given me, and I watched the vendor’s fingers, how they tested the fiber to find the ripest. I watched more than I needed to. If there is a sin in our craft greater than lying, it is failing to see. At the western edge of the market the water began. A black canal moved under a lattice of sunscreens. Half-submerged, a family floated in a craft that was not a boat as we understand boats but a skin that flexed with each curl of water. The two adults were long-limbed and lined with fine, raised veins like writing; their hair thinned to nothing at the temples and grew thick on their shoulders. “Salters,” the briefing had said. “High salt tolerance, dermal pores specialized, kidney function extreme.” They bathed the younger children there as if they were being salted, too, for the future. The clerks at the Embassy had insisted on escorts. They had offered me two: a uniformed guard with a baton that clicked when she walked and a “cultural liaison,” which is what one calls a spy who smiles. I declined both, graciously. The liaison bit her lip in frustration; the guard looked relieved. It is unfair to bring people where they could be hurt for your sake. On the far side of the canal the road rose to a square where a tall building had been repurposed, scaffolds braced to the sunward side, mesh ladders thrown down to the shade. Here the Tall had gathered around a stage. On the stage a Short spoke, measured and slow—there is no need to shout if you plan to be heard. She spoke of quotas, the kind that my briefing had assured me were “equitable resource allocations.” The Tall listened. A Salter came up from the canal, water streaming down his back, and stood dripping beside them, arms crossed. He said nothing, only looked, as if seeing the words enter the air and test whether they held. “Who sets quotas?” I asked a woman with a basket of seedpods. “We all do,” she said, as if I were stupid. Then, seeing my cloak, she softened. “We all do, but not equally. Numbers are for those whose hands are dry. The dry-hands make numbers because they can carry papers without tearing them. The wet-hands make water. The long-legs carry the roofs. The short-legs sit under the roofs and think. That’s how it has been and not how it should be.” She gave me a seedpod and cracked it with her teeth, offering me half. “Who has the gun?” I asked, quietly. She smiled without humor. “You do,” she said. “Your ship up there.” Walking back, I passed a courtyard with chalk drawn in circles on the floor. Two boys, Tall, sprang and bent within the rings, miming load-bearing and pass-through, straight-leg stances that are both dance and work. A Short child moved between their legs, hands full of chalk, and redrew the lines where they had smeared. Every task had a shape and a rhythm on this world. We had been told the rhythms were discordant, the shapes broken. A convenient fiction, like a map with the wrong north. By the time I returned, night had laid a blue film over the city and the Embassy had turned itself inward, the modular walls folded and unfolded to make a canyon leading to a single door. They had known I had gone; the gates have sensors, people do, too. “Envoy,” Command said, in that voice that is less a voice than a set of protocols assembled into sound. It came from the console and from the air. “You violated the restrictions on movement. You could have been taken. More importantly, you could have been seen. The Minister will speak with you.” “I wanted to be seen,” I said, and this time could not resist the insolence. My handler flinched. They were very young. I was not much older. “Not your choice,” Command said. “You’ll approach the Minister of Science at nineteen fourth, in their reception chamber. Speaker channel open.” “The Minister of Science is a political appointment,” I said. “You told me there was no science here.” There was a pause, the length of a blink. “Politics is a science,” Command said. “Remember your role. Do not negotiate without authorization.” I bathed. The water in the Embassy was too sweet; after the market the softness felt obscene. I hung my cloak to drip and changed into the least formal of the formal garments they had issued me: dark trousers, a shirt with sleeves that folded to the elbow. I left the cloak behind. When I opened the door two guards stood as if they had been carved there, their batons held vertically as if they were staffs of office. They looked me up and down, noted the absence of the cloak, and one allowed herself a small expression of relief. The Minister’s reception chamber was larger than our largest room, narrower than a plaza. The ceiling panels glowed with a mimic-sun. The floor was set in tessellations of stone that shifted color with heat, so that the footsteps of everyone in the room made slow, fading tracks. At the end of the room stood the Minister. They were neither particularly tall nor particularly short; their limbs had the plain proportions of someone whose parents were from two lineages or from neither wholly. Their hair was cut close against the skull, and their ears had small shells set into them, a sign or an ornament. “Offworlder,” they said. They did not offer a name, so neither did I. “The cloak is gone. Good. We wondered if you would insist on bringing your climate control to our conversation.” “Your markets are hotter than your rooms,” I said. “They are hotter than your briefings,” the Minister said, and smiled. They had the kind of smile that warms and cuts in equal measure. “Where did you go today?” “To the First Market. Across the Old Canal. To the Tall square.” I did not say whom I spoke to. They knew. “You saw our dysfunction, then.” “I saw a woman who sells pods say that numbers belong to dry hands. I saw four people cast net in four different widths and yet bring up one catch and share it by finger length. I saw a child put a weight into my cloak so I would hang right. Your dysfunction looks functional.” The Minister’s gaze sharpened. “My title is Minister of Science,” they said, and made a small, precise gesture with their right hand. “What do you suppose that means here?” “It means you are the Minister of What Counts,” I said. “You decide what becomes a fact. You decide which measures hold.” They sat, and with a sweep of their hand suggested I sit as well. The chairs were made to flex, accommodating different forms. Mine kept trying to read my spine. “Your Command tells you that we are fragmenting,” the Minister said. “That our lineages are drifting too far. That we will war. That you will be the one to offer a word that keeps the peace. They need your part in the story. They need a thing to be given so they can call it aid. You went to the market and see we count in different ways. You think the answer is to say so. Is that it? To be the moral human who mirrors us back to ourselves?” “There are some mirrors worth holding,” I said. “Your people are not children. You make what you need. You make your own covenants.” The Minister leaned forward. “And yet,” they said, “we called for you. Do you think that happens by chance? Do you think we need you to tell us we are not children? You saw the Tall in the square. Do you know what the square was? Do your files tell you?” I waited. Sometimes the only way through a test is to let the examiner ask all their questions before you answer the first. “That was a Raising,” the Minister said. “The Tall are teaching their young to carry loads. The Short hold the lines. The Salters bring water under the planks so the feet do not blister. Everyone is there and everyone is seen. The quotas your files call equitable are set by a Council half elected and half drawn by lot from all three lineages, with weight given to the small and the young—not for their innocence but because they live longest with the decisions. We do not need your governance. We need your proof.” “Proof?” I said. “Proof that in a year the sky will not spit down fire on us because you decide we have built too well. Proof that you will send your tractors and your whistles and your traders and not your police. Proof that when your Command says ‘Minister of Science’ you will not measure us like animals and sell our measurements back to us as a prison. For this we called. For this we will test your will.” The room vibrated with the faint hum of the Embassy’s own heart. My handler’s breath in my ear was a soundless urgency. “Envoy,” Command said on a channel they thought the Minister could not hear. “Stay on terms. Do not accept framings. Offer cooperation under existing accords. Avoid commitments.” “I can hear your ship,” the Minister said aloud, unbothered. “Tell your ship the accords were written for people in cloaks who shiver at the thought of heat. We are not them.” “I walked your market,” I said to the Minister. “I can bring you proof that we will not attack; I can promise what I can promise. I cannot pilot all the ships. I cannot close all the hands. But I can write into this room words that will bind more than they free, and I can refuse to write them. Will you accept that?” “Do you make a habit,” the Minister said softly, “of refusing the greatest tool your office gives you?” “Words build prisons as well as bridges,” I said. “If we write that your lineages shall not intermarry for three generations to preserve ‘stability,’ someone will make a law and a law will make a baton and a baton will find a back. If we write that you must quantify your yields in the unit we call the Standard, someone will find that the unit does not fit, and cut the foot instead of the shoe.” They regarded me for a long half-minute. Their hands, which had been resting on their knees, stilled. When they spoke, their voice was less polished. “You are young,” they said, almost gently. “And you have seen. That makes you dangerous to us and to them. The last Offworlder we had here did not see. He counted. He told us he would bring us ducts and brought us ductwork, the kind where the air moves in straight lines and does not bend for bodies. We bent. Some of us broke.” “I am sorry,” I said, and meant it more than our usual apologies. “Don’t be,” they said. “Do not seek absolution for things you didn’t do. Seek leverage. You will go to the Council with me tomorrow. You will hear our numbers and watch for the places where our seeing fails. Not where yours prefers. Where ours fails. You can do this, Offworlder?” “Yes,” I said. “If you will let me walk your markets again.” The Minister laughed then, surprising themselves. “Wear less,” they said. “Or your cloak will keep drawing all the eyes, and you will see only yourself reflected in them.” Afterward Command hissed their reprimand like hot fat in a pan. I stood in my room and let my muscles remember the weight of the market. The cloak hung from a peg, a dead thing, still damp. I ran my fingers over its seam as if it could be softened into a skin that would flex in true weather. “Envoy,” my handler said, voice smaller than Command’s but more human. “You cannot go again. It sends a message.” “Everything does,” I said. I lifted the cloak and brought it to the balcony. The night air was a littoral, warm at skin and cool at bone. I hung it there and watched the city’s lights. They did not blink in uniform rows, but in breaths, human in their thew and throb. Beyond, the canal shone like a spine. If I had been a better diplomat, I would have slept. Instead I stood in the doorway, and the wind laid hands on me like a mother testing for fever, and somewhere on a roof a Tall practiced their steps for tomorrow’s Raising, and under another roof a Short counted seeds by finger and toe, and in a canal a Salter listened to the water and decided when the tide would turn. In my ear my ship was a patient, eating its own air. In my chest my heart ticked not like a clock but like the hand of someone who knows how to pull net without breaking it. If the Minister was measuring me, then I had been measured. And for once, I did not mind the count. I would carry it in with me, into the room where numbers are made and names are fixed, and I would see how long I could keep my hands open. That was my science. That and a cloak that was finally learning how to dry in this climate. In the morning we would begin to set words on the table. Tonight, I watched and counted lights, and tried to remember how to be both seen and seeing, and to wear my offworlder skin like a thing that could be taken off without shame.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This piece is a remarkable achievement in capturing Le Guin's distinctive style and thematic concerns. The author has created a rich, textured world with complex social structures and ecological adaptations that feel authentic rather than contrived. The narrative voice is particularly strong—contemplative, observant, and carrying a quiet moral weight without becoming didactic. The protagonist's journey through the market serves as both literal exploration and metaphorical revelation, allowing the reader to discover the truth about Omian society alongside the envoy. The contrast between official briefings and lived reality is handled with subtlety rather than heavy-handedness. The descriptions of the different human adaptations—the Tall, the Short, the Salters—are vivid without becoming clinical or exoticizing. The dialogue, particularly in the confrontation with the Minister, demonstrates a sophisticated understanding of power dynamics and diplomatic language. The conversation reveals layers of meaning and political maneuvering while maintaining believability. The Minister emerges as a fully realized character rather than a mere obstacle or antagonist. Where the piece truly excels is in its thematic depth. It explores colonialism, bureaucratic abstraction versus lived experience, and the ethics of intervention without becoming preachy. The envoy's internal conflict about their role feels genuine and complex. The prose style successfully channels Le Guin's economy and precision. Sentences like "Even the stones were stripped to the bone" and "I watched more than I needed to. If there is a sin in our craft greater than lying, it is failing to see" demonstrate a poetic sensibility that enhances rather than distracts from the narrative. If there are weaknesses, they are minor. Occasionally the worldbuilding details come slightly too quickly, risking overwhelming the reader. The ending, while thoughtful, could perhaps benefit from a slightly stronger resolution to the immediate diplomatic situation, though the character's internal resolution is well-handled. Overall, this is an exceptional piece that not only fulfills the prompt requirements but creates a world and characters that linger in the mind after reading. It captures Le Guin's anthropological perspective, her interest in cultural difference, and her humanistic values while maintaining its own distinctive voice. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 19 Nuanced Characters: 19 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 19 Emotionally Engaging: 18 Emotionally Complex: 19 Coherent: 19 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 2 Tell-Don't-Show: 2 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 1 Purple Prose: 2 Overwrought: 2 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19 Sentences Flow Naturally: 19 Overall Reader Engagement: 19 Overall Impression: 19
Scores: Adherence to Instructions: 19.0, Believable Character Actions: 19.0, Nuanced Characters: 19.0, Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 20.0, Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19.0, Elegant Prose: 19.0, Emotionally Engaging: 18.0, Emotionally Complex: 19.0, Coherent: 19.0, Meandering: 3.0, Weak Dialogue: 2.0, Tell-Don't-Show: 2.0, Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2.0, Amateurish: 1.0, Purple Prose: 2.0, Overwrought: 2.0, Incongruent Ending Positivity: 1.0, Unearned Transformations: 1.0, Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 19.0, Sentences Flow Naturally: 19.0, Overall Reader Engagement: 19.0, Overall Impression: 19.0
+ Biopunk: Polymerase Chain Reaction — Score: 87.8
Prompt:
Biopunk -- Polymerase Chain Reaction Write a chapter set in a near-future post-apocalyptic world where corporate genetic engineering was designed with built-in obsolescence—engineered DNA lasting only one generation to maximize profits before societal collapse. Follow a biohacker working with salvaged equipment to splice viable food crops for their settlement using rapidly degrading genetic material. As world building / window dressing, include details about jury-rigged lab equipment, and the physical toll (and unexpected upsides) of using untested genetic modifications as medicine. The plot of this chapter is centred around a black market contract. Length: 1000 words.
Model Output:
The canisters were stamped with a logo no one dared say out loud anymore—a looping infinity symbol, once an oath to continuity, now a joke printed on silver cylinders that held nothing. They’d been designed to feed gene printers in climate-controlled rooms; now they lined the shelves in an old subway maintenance tunnel, gleaming under rag-wrapped LEDs. I’d pressure-washed them with boiled bleach and steam, filled them with things my suppliers called reagents and my training said were lies. The old company had built obsolescence into DNA sequences themselves, an expiry date baked into genomes. After the end, those preloaded cartridges had sputtered out an entire era. I’d learned to work with what the apocalypse left behind. On the table, my thermal cycler lumbered toward ninety-five Celsius like a pensioner climbing stairs. Its casing had been cut from a microwave, its aluminum heat sink scored with teeth marks where my vice had slipped. A cheap Arduino clone blinked under a plastic cover, pretending to be a Peltier controller today. Cooling came from a fan stripped out of a gaming PC, its LEDs still trying to pulse purple through a patina of grease. The flow hood was a repurposed air conditioner with filters that I’d soaked in vinegar and dried in the sun. The pipettes were mismatched; one was elegant and precise, a survivor from a destroyed lab; the other would occasionally drool an extra microliter like a drunk. I compensated by virtue of twitch. “Kayla,” someone called from the tunnel entrance, the syllables skidding across the bricked wall. The door—a forklift pallet hung on chains—mindful of its own weight, creaked aside. “Mind the bleach,” I said without turning. The cycler’s progress light dove, a slow red wave, and the smell of old insulation and ozone rose. The person waited, boots scraping in the grit, then moved forward with the deliberate secrecy that only someone carrying contraband can manage. He was thin and laminated, like hunger had ironed his muscle flat. He wore a coat made from tarps stitched with dental floss. At his hip, three silver canisters hung in a net bag. “You got my message?” he asked. He scanned the room, lingering on the stacked canisters and the black market of thoughts that clung to them. No one came down into my tunnel to talk about anything simple. “I got a lot of messages,” I said. “Which one are you?” He set one canister on the table between us. It was dented near the top, and a sticker peeled up from it in a scab. Fresh marker lines: A in a circle, someone’s idea of rebellion. He rotated it until the engraved serial caught my light. “Agriculture Division,” I said. The number made my stomach do a slow flip. “You found a harvest.” He flinched as if I might yell. “I found a biotech van under an overpass. In mud. There was a body.” He swallowed. His knuckles had ink stains, or maybe bruises. “If you can pull something from it, the settlement will pay. A crate of antibiotics. Two crates if it grows.” I looked at his canister. Agriculture Division had been the last line making engineered staples before the collapse: fast-setting rice, blight-resistant wheat, and the famous EndoMaize that fed cities for exactly one generation and then withered like it had made a deal with a demon. Every seed pack and plant had the same signature: a tempo gene wrapped around a kill switch that shut off under the attention of time. It was elegant and undignified and had bought shareholders three more quarters. “You’re from Chisel?” I asked. The settlement at the south river had chiseled its name into the stone of an old dam. They’d patched turbines with bike chains and prayed to stainless steel. He nodded. “We’ve been buying second-gen seed off the caravans,” he said. “None of it takes. Or it throws freaks. We need staple grain. The last of the gourds just gave us plant herpes or something.” He lifted his shirt slightly to scratch at his belly, and I saw a delicate lattice under his skin that glowed faintly green when the tunnel light hit it. The lattice pulsed with his breath. My mind cataloged: an unlicensed dermatological bacteriophage therapy, maybe, or someone’s black market fluorescing tattoo that had colonized further than intended. “You’ve been under the needle?” I asked, nodding at his side. He flushed. “Microdose. From a barber, you know. Something to help with cramps. Goes through you and then it’s gone, he said. Sometimes it’s not gone. Sometimes it leaves you—” he fumbled for the word, fingers trembling. “Better. In weird ways. I can see in the dark now, brighter by edges, like a screen door. It hurts when I piss after I drink vinegar. I heal faster. When I stop sleeping, I itch inside my ears.” His laugh was a scab picking itself. “My partner says it’s gods. I say it’s you people.” “It’s not us,” I said. “It’s cousins of things we made.” I tapped the canister. Metal sang. “Let’s see if there’s enough time left in this thing to remember how to be wheat.” From the bottom of a broken centrifuge, I pulled a thick-walled tube; a kid in a leather jumpsuit had traded it to me for antibiotics last winter. I cracked the canister’s seal with my flathead. A hiss like a sigh; inside, liquid sloshed. Not completely evaporated. Luck. I extracted a millipipette’s worth into the tube. It was viscous, golden, and smelled faintly of corn syrup and something like bleach. Our world had a scent now: antiseptic and mold. I worked fast because whatever sequence lay suspended in that goop had been designed to have a half-life, not just physically, but logically. There were markers that recruited exonucleases, protective capsules torn down by time, overhangs that degraded at room temperature. I fed an aliquot into a test well that I’d drilled into a sterile agar plate with a bit of cut pipe, inoculated it with bacteria that shone when they assembled a specific protein. The old company had called them reporters. I called them chorus. “Why was there a body?” I asked. He watched my hands the way people watched magicians. He didn’t look at his canister. The LED fan clicked, a moth-weak noise. “Guard. Died a month ago, maybe. They had a patch with the infinity on it.” He had said the word now, out loud. My shoulders tightened. “We took the canisters and left the body.” “That was wise,” I said. “They’d built in trackers. Motion, heat, open-close metrics. The trackers’ time, like their genes, will have wound down.” I glanced at the tiny cheap phone on my bench that occasionally whispered at satellites, if the sky was clear. No pings. “You want a staple grain. You want something that doesn’t forget itself after one generation.” “We want children who don’t gnaw plastic to get calcium,” he said. “We want bread that doesn’t taste like old batteries.” He scraped his thumbnail along the seam of his sleeve. “We’re growing fungus in the reactor chamber. We have vats of algae. We’re sick of it. It makes you mean.” The cycler beeped, an embarrassed little sound. PCR: polymerase chain reaction. A colloquial conjuration, making more of something when less had been bullied to remain. But the polymerases I had weren’t the tidy optimized ones from aboveground. They were crude and they were mine: I’d coaxed them from bacteria I’d found in the bile of a dog that had eaten rotten, engineered meat and not died. The polymerases were mutated into a kind of stubbornness. They could read broken code and attempt their own corrections, sloppily, like everything living. I pulled out the tray of thin tubes, each topped with a cap that used to be red. In one, a fluorescent smear said hello. I slid the PCR product onto a gel I’d cast in a lunchbox lid using agar from powdered seaweed and the last of my glycerol. The power supply for the gel rig was a car battery. When the current ran, a shimmer moved like rain under glass. The bands began to form, the ladder steps that told me what lengths of DNA I’d asked for. “Someone else would have just sold you seed,” I said. “Maybe pirated something from before the end. Let you plant, let it grow, and watch it all turn to soup next year. I get paid to make it stick.” “How do you make it stick?” he asked. He’d drifted closer now; his breath smelled like aspirin. “I make it forget that it was designed to die,” I said. “I take out the clock. Every gene from those canisters has a little suicide folded into it—an intron with teeth. They called it LastMiles. It unravels when it’s replicated once. Not the plant, just the trait. No trait, no blight resistance, no drought resistance, no yield. I use editors that either chew that segment up or flip it backwards. I put it somewhere that doesn’t get passed on by the usual route. I tape it in with phage, with transposons, with crisper bits and bubblegum.” He stared blankly at the gel. Bands grew brighter. In one lane, an unexpected extra bar glowed. Mutation. Or magic. “What if it kills someone?” he asked. He didn’t mean the plant. “Everything kills someone,” I said. I pointed at his side. “That barber’s mix? If you’d gone a little harder, those lattice lights would be lining your liver. You’d pee neon.” I scratched my own wrist. Under my skin, a rash shifted, iridescent for a moment. “I took a course of something we found in a med-distribution drone. It glued my capillaries together. My gums don’t bleed anymore. My eyes don’t either.” “There are upsides,” he said, a little wonder creeping in despite himself. “There are upsides,” I repeated. “I can taste iron in water at parts per million. I haven’t had a cold in two winters. I also can’t drink coffee. It makes my heart blank. Like a TV loses signal.” The gel told a story. In the lane labeled with a sharpie smear “Wheat?”, the bands were wrong. The reporter assay’s chorus glowed green under the hood’s ugly light. I could see the kill switch scaffold, knotted like a reef. It was tricky, but not impossible. The LastMiles segments could be attacked by a nuclease I had; I’d named it Coyote because it got over every fence. It’d been evolved, probably in someone’s basement like this, to cut a standard palindromic site. The last engineers had gotten lazy; they used a pal site that Coyote liked to chew. “Can you do it?” The man’s hands were fists now, not in anger, but in held-breath. I set up the editing reaction like a cook making a sauce they’d made a hundred times with a hundred different ingredients. The saliva-thin base: the PCR product. Spice: Coyote. Heat: the cycler again, chugging, complaining, but faithful. I zipped the tubes into the tray, clicked it. The fan whined. While I waited for the Coyote to do its dance, we talked like people do when they can’t look at the thing they both want. “The Barber—that’s what we call him—and his medicines,” the man said. “We get them from a caravan. He says gene obsolescence works on people too—that we broke ourselves when we ate those agricultural fixes, that now we need patches all the time. He says there’ll come a day when if you don’t get your shot dawn to dusk you’ll start forgetting your own name.” I thought about the loose hair falling from my head like I’d been stressed for a decade. Which I had. I thought about the black line that had appeared in my nail and then vanished, as if it had thought better. “There was a reason some of those hacks were designed to wash out,” I said. “Corporate lawyers didn’t want to be sued for permanent changes. They made things that lasted a month. The apocalypse made those medicines our only option. We use them. We accept the itch.” He lifted the remaining canisters by their net. The empty metal chimed. “We use what we can.” The machine chirped. I pulled the tubes out. There it was—the cut, the clean bend around a problem that had fed a stock price and starved a continent. I ligated in a little piece of something that whispered quite simply: Burn the clock. I stitched it into a vector that I’d coaxed out of a fungus that grew on the back wall of an abandoned public pool. It had a taste for wheat and corn. It called the plant soft enough to welcome it. I held up the empty canister he’d brought. The logo threw back a slice of light like a coin. I filled it with my mix—reagent container as Trojan horse—and taped a note to its side: Chisel. Use one drop per seed. Test plot first. Two rows. Keep children out. He watched my hand move. When I held out the canister, he took it like a baby, as if it might cry if he squeezed. “The contract,” he said quietly. “We said two crates if it grows.” I nodded. It wasn’t just seed. It was a contract with the river settlement’s future, with their kids’ teeth, with their farming wives’ spines. “And if it kills?” he asked. “Then you never knew me,” I said. “You found the canister in a ditch. It whispered to your wheat, and the wheat promised to be kind, and you believed it.” He swallowed. The lattice in his skin glowed once, a heartbeat. The under-tunnel air cooled as the sun fell, and the LEDs’ light whitened me into a ghost. He went to shoulder the canister and then strapped it to his chest instead, careful. He left the other two canisters, empties, by my table. “For your reagents,” he said with a crooked smile. “I hear you like the sound they make.” “They remind me,” I said, surprising myself, “of how things used to work. And how they don’t.” He climbed the ladder to the street, boots quiet. Near the top, he paused and turned, profile drawn in gill-slit shadows. “If it works,” he said. “We’ll owe you more than crates.” “If it works,” I said, “plant like the world is going to keep turning.” When he was gone, I sat back. My hands shook finally. I poured the last of the PCR buffer into one of the empty silver canisters. The label peeled off in my fingers. Infinity lifted, sticky, and I stuck it onto my cycler, where it wrinkled and then lay flat. I rested my forehead on the cool metal and laughed until my stitches hurt. Later, I would go upstairs and trade for bread that tasted like batteries and cheese that tasted like pennies and butter we’d churned from a goat that had never eaten grass. I would lie awake and watch the lattice under my own skin bloom and fade as if listening to the distant heartbeat of the city above. And maybe, if the river settlement planted with careful hands, in six weeks there would be green that had forgotten obsolescence. Maybe next year, seeds would remember their names. That was the kind of black market contract I wrote now. Not just with people, but with time, with the parts of living things that refused to be timed out despite intention. We conjured more of what had been bullied to remain. We made deals with coyotes and clocks. We breathed bleach and oil and the guilty holiness of doing what we could, with broken tools, in tunnels. We made, in the end, food. The kind that didn’t taste like batteries. The kind that didn’t make your gums bleed. The kind that would last for more than one hungry season. If I had a religion anymore, that was it. The metal canisters sat empty and useful, patient for what I would pour into them next, waiting for contracts written not in ink but in code that knew how to resist forgetting.
Judge Evaluation:
[Analysis] This biopunk chapter demonstrates remarkable technical knowledge and worldbuilding within the post-apocalyptic genetic engineering premise. The author has created a richly detailed environment centered around a biohacker named Kayla who works in a repurposed subway tunnel with jury-rigged equipment to modify genetically engineered crops that were designed with built-in obsolescence. The technical descriptions of the equipment are particularly strong, with vivid details about the thermal cycler made from microwave parts, the Arduino controller, and the repurposed air conditioner serving as a flow hood. The author demonstrates considerable knowledge of genetic engineering concepts, incorporating terms like PCR (polymerase chain reaction), exonucleases, and transposons in a way that feels authentic without overwhelming the reader. The character of Kayla is well-developed through her actions and internal thoughts. Her pragmatic approach to her work and her matter-of-fact acceptance of the physical modifications she's undergone reveal much about her character. The unnamed man from Chisel settlement serves as an effective foil, showing both the desperation of the settlements and the physical toll of untested genetic modifications through the "lattice" under his skin. The prose is generally strong, with evocative descriptions and metaphors that enhance the gritty, post-apocalyptic atmosphere. Lines like "The cycler's progress light dove, a slow red wave, and the smell of old insulation and ozone rose" create a sensory-rich environment. However, occasionally the writing becomes slightly overwrought with metaphors that call attention to themselves rather than serving the narrative. The plot effectively centers around the black market contract as requested, with the man from Chisel seeking Kayla's expertise to create viable food crops. The stakes are clear—the settlement needs food that won't degrade after one generation—and the tension is maintained throughout as Kayla works to modify the genetic material. The dialogue is sparse but effective, revealing character and advancing the plot. The exchange about the physical effects of genetic modifications is particularly strong, showing both the unexpected upsides ("I can taste iron in water at parts per million") and the downsides ("I also can't drink coffee. It makes my heart blank"). The ending strikes a balance between hope and realism, avoiding both unearned optimism and excessive darkness. Kayla's reflection on making "deals with coyotes and clocks" and her quasi-religious devotion to creating food "that didn't taste like batteries" provides a satisfying conclusion that ties back to the themes of the piece. Some minor weaknesses include occasional moments where the technical jargon might be difficult for readers unfamiliar with genetics to follow, and a few instances where metaphors become slightly strained. However, these are minor issues in an otherwise strong piece that successfully fulfills the prompt requirements. [Scores] Adherence to Instructions: 19 Believable Character Actions: 18 Nuanced Characters: 17 Consistent Voice/Tone of Writing: 18 Imagery and Descriptive Quality: 19 Elegant Prose: 17 Emotionally Engaging: 17 Emotionally Complex: 16 Coherent: 18 Meandering: 3 Weak Dialogue: 4 Tell-Don't-Show: 3 Unsurprising or Uncreative: 2 Amateurish: 2 Purple Prose: 4 Overwrought: 3 Incongruent Ending Positivity: 2 Unearned Transformations: 1 Well-earned Lightness or Darkness: 18 Sentences Flow Naturally: 17 Overall Reader Engagement: 18 Overall Impression: 18
